1	nasa has announced that asteroid 2004 bl86, which is currently approaching earth, will be the closest known asteroid of its size to pass by until 2027. the asteroid, approximately 745,000 miles (1.2 million kilometers) from earth during its closest approach on january 26, 2025, is estimated to be about a third of a mile (0.5 kilometers) in size. although currently only visible to southern hemisphere astronomers, it will become visible to those in the northern hemisphere on january 26. nasa plans to learn more about the asteroid through microwave observations using the deep space network antenna at goldstone, california, and the arecibo observatory in puerto rico. asteroid 2004 bl86 was discovered in 2004 and poses no threat to earth in the foreseeable future. retiring nasa manager don yeomans encourages everyone to observe it using binoculars and emphasizes their importance as sources of life's building blocks, water, and future resources.
2	a us soldier's admission to using a quran for target practice at a shooting range in baghdad has prompted outrage from iraq's most powerful sunni arab political party, the iraqi islamic party, which strongly condemned the action as a "blatant assault on the sanctities of muslims," and demanded the "severest of punishments" for the soldier. the soldier, a staff sergeant who was a sniper section leader, has been formally apologized to by the u.s. commander in baghdad, maj. gen. jeffery hammond, and has been relieved of duty, dismissed from his regiment, and redeployed. however, the iraqi islamic party wants more severe consequences for the soldier as a deterrent for future incidents. local tribal leaders and residents protested against the u.s. military's handling of the incident, with sheikh hamadi al-qirtani speaking on behalf of all tribal sheikhs of radhwaniya, condemning the shooting as an act of aggression against the entire islamic world. the association of muslim scholars in iraq also issued a statement condemning the shooter's actions and the u.s. military's belated acknowledgment, and holding the occupation and the current government responsible.
3	andy carroll, west ham united's record signing and england international striker, took a gloomy selfie from the hospital just before undergoing ankle surgery. carroll, who has suffered numerous injuries over the past few seasons with liverpool and west ham, was hoping to finally have a healthy campaign and fulfill his potential. however, he is expected to be out for four months after tearing ligaments in his ankle. he missed significant parts of the previous season due to a heel injury and made only 16 appearances. despite these setbacks, west ham made the transfer permanent last summer in a calculated risk. fans and the team are hoping that this is the last of carroll's injury problems as his contract runs until 2019. he has only score two goals since joining west ham on a weekly wage of around £80,000 and has cost them £1 million per premier league game so far.
4	los angeles has traditionally been a destination for european artistic dreamers in film and acting, but until now, it has not been considered a hub for international music careers, with london and new york taking the lead. however, with the democratization of the music industry through platforms like youtube, european and eastern european singers are finding los angeles to be the new gateway to the us market. artists such as estonia's kerli, italy's marco bosco, t.a.t.u.'s lena katina from russia, slovakia's twiins, and austria's fawni have recently moved to los angeles with dreams of making it big. these singers have been making a presence in the city through small clubs like the troubadour, red carpets, and purchased billboards on sunset boulevard. the timing for these european singers couldn't be better as america is finally embracing the globalization of pop music. swedes robyn and medina have seen success in the us, and estonia's kerli is poised for a breakthrough with her latest single "army of love." kerli, a former "american idol" winner from the baltics, has been slowly winning over american fans since moving to la around four years ago. the singer's debut album "love is dead" did well for a new artist, but she and her label are thinking bigger this year after buzz surrounding her new single. slovakian twins twiins, who moved to la last year, are also working on their first record and are collaborating with known us producers. though they have faced challenges as non-native english speakers, they are determined to make a name for themselves in america after some success elsewhere. the twins' single "welcome to hollywood" offers a cautionary tale to other aspiring singers about hollywood's "friendly faces" that may not be as they seem.
5	the opening ceremony of the london olympics was estimated to be watched by a billion people worldwide, with tens of thousands more attending in person. the show, masterminded by artistic director danny boyle, was a fast-paced and diverse spectacle featuring tributes to british history, literature, and music. inspired by shakespeare's "the tempest," the ceremony began with the tolling of a harmonically tuned bell and presented an idyllic view of the british countryside before showcasing various aspects of british culture. there were also tributes to the national health service, children's literature, and popular music. the ceremony involved 10,000 adult volunteers, 900 local schoolchildren, and intricate technological wizardry. the athletes entered the stadium to declare the games open, and the grand finale saw the olympic flag hoisted and the torch lit, marking the start of the competition.
6	canadian counterterrorism officials arrested and charged a man named suliman mohamed, 21, for conspiring with twin brothers ashton and carlos larmond in a terror plot. the royal canadian mounted police (rcmp) announced mohamed's arrest on monday, and linked it to the arrests of the larmond brothers, both 24, who were arrested on friday in ottawa and montreal, respectively. ashton was arrested in ottawa, while carlos was attempting to travel overseas for terrorist purposes at the montreal airport. carlos was charged with participation in a terrorist group and attempting to leave canada to participate in terrorist activity abroad. both brothers have denied the charges and have yet to retain legal representation. the rcmp statement did not disclose details of the allegations, but added that the recent arrests serve as a reminder of individuals in canada becoming radicalized and willing to act upon it. canada's terrorism laws were amended in 2013 to include an offense for anyone leaving or attempting to leave the country for the purpose of committing a terrorist act abroad. few canadians have been charged under this law, and the outcome of this case will be closely watched by counterterrorism officials. neighbors near mohamed's east ottawa residence reported police activity in the area all weekend.
7	in swat valley, pakistan, rehana haleem, the sister of the suspected shooter of malala yousafzai, apologized to malala for her brother's actions. attah ullah khan, 23, is wanted by authorities for shooting malala, a 15-year-old activist who had spoken out against the taliban's attempts to ban girls from attending school. rehana expressed remorse, saying her brother had brought shame upon their family and taken away their happiness. malala was badly injured in the attack, but is recovering in a hospital in birmingham, england. authorities have arrested six men in connection to the shooting, but are still searching for khan. the taliban, who have issued threats against malala, have warned that they would attack her again if she returns to pakistan. malala's family members, including her husband, uncle, and brother, have been taken into custody by security forces.
8	zimbabwe's prime minister morgan tsvangirai has dismissed speculation that his wife's car crash was a result of foul play, calling it "one in a thousand" chance. his comments came amid widespread suspicion that his political opponents aligned with president robert mugabe were behind the wreck that left his wife and bodyguard dead. tsvangirai's movement for democratic change party has called for an independent inquiry. the power-sharing agreement between tsvangirai and mugabe was implemented just weeks ago, following a disputed presidential election. the crash occurred on a busy highway between tsvangirai's hometown and harare. some in tsvangirai's party believe the driver of the truck that hit their vehicle deliberately targeted them. a former us ambassador to zimbabwe questioned the official explanation, noting president mugabe's past history of suspicious car accidents. however, he also noted that traffic accidents are common in zimbabwe due to poorly maintained vehicles and inexperienced drivers.
9	russian newspaper kommersant reports that the lourdes signals intelligence facility in cuba, which was closed in 2001 and used by russia to spy on us telecommunications, may reopen as part of a deal between russian president vladimir putin and cuban president raul castro. the report came after putin's visit to cuba on friday to strengthen ties and forgive over $30 billion in soviet-era debt. cuban and russian officials, as well as a us state department spokeswoman, declined to comment on the possibility of the base's reopening, and it's unclear how soon it could become operational or how much russia would pay. the facility, which was once a top-secret and tightly guarded complex, is now in disrepair with many buildings falling into ruins. it is currently partly used as a computer science university.
10	stewart parnell, the owner of peanut corporation of america (pca), and his brother michael parnell, along with quality assurance manager mary wilkerson, have been found guilty of conspiracy and other charges in a federal trial in albany, georgia. the trial stemmed from a salmonella outbreak in 2008 and 2009 that sickened 714 people and led to nine deaths. the defendants are charged with knowingly shipping contaminated peanut butter to customers and faking lab tests, resulting in one of the largest food recalls in u.s. history. prosecutors focused on the defendants' actions of defrauding their customers by selling contaminated goods, rather than directly causing illnesses or deaths. the trio faces severe punishment if convicted, with a potential maximum sentence of 754 years in prison and $17 million in fines for stewart parnell. the cdc determined that 714 people were affected by the salmonella outbreak in 43 states, resulting in nine reported deaths, although it was unclear if salmonella directly caused these fatalities. the defendants' attorneys argue that the scheme was carried out by two plant managers who pleaded guilty.
11	usain bolt, the jamaican sprint superstar and commonwealth games record-breaker, enjoyed a night out in london after his victory, leaving mahiki nightclub at 3am with two female companions and heading to raffles until 5am. the following morning, he was spotted in clapham, south-west london, in a dentist's surgery and on the street. bolt had earlier filmed a puma advert in a hot tub with mario balotelli and sergio aguero. despite controversy over his remarks on the commonwealth games, he won over fans with his selfies and autographs in scottish garb. an earlier video showed him racing a bus in buenos aires.
12	widow of british bomb disposal expert gary o'donnell, who was killed by a booby-trapped device in afghanistan in 2008, is selling his bravery medals, including two george medals, to provide for her four children. o'donnell, a member of the elite bomb disposal unit, had an exceptional career, saving countless lives in iraq and afghanistan. his first george medal was awarded for persistent courage in iraq in 2006, and the second one was for his actions in afghanistan in 2008, where he defused eleven taliban bombs. his medals, which include the general service medal, operational service medals, nato medal, isaf medal, jubilee 2002 medal, accumulated campaign service medal, and the regular army medal, are expected to fetch £60,000 at auction. o'donnell's death came just weeks after he received the posthumous second award.
13	researchers from the university of edinburgh led an international study involving 1,326 older women with early-stage hormone-sensitive breast cancer, who were aged 65 or older and had not had their tumors spread to the lymph nodes beneath the arm. the women underwent breast-conserving surgery to remove their tumors and were then split into two groups: one received hormone treatment and radiation, while the other received only hormone treatment. after five years, approximately 96% of both groups had survived, and most deaths were not caused by breast cancer. however, approximately 1.3% of those given radiation experienced cancer recurrence in the treated breast, compared to 4.1% of those who did not receive radiotherapy. a separate study found that pregnant women were more likely to quit smoking if offered shopping vouchers as part of a treatment plan. the researchers split 612 pregnant smokers into two groups, with half receiving only advice and nicotine replacement therapy, and the other half receiving up to £400 worth of vouchers to spend at certain stores if they quit while pregnant. of the women offered shopping vouchers, 69 quit smoking compared to 26 in the other group, with 15% of the voucher group remaining off cigarettes 12 months post-delivery. however, critics may argue that offering financial incentives amounts to bribery to get mothers to prioritize the health of their children. the edinburgh researchers concluded that, while radiotherapy will remain the standard of care for most women after breast-conserving surgery, the modest reduction in risk of recurrence from radiotherapy in low-risk older women receiving hormone treatment makes omitting radiotherapy an option for carefully selected patients. in the uk, around 50,000 women develop breast cancer each year, with nearly 12,000 deaths annually. radiotherapy is offered to around 35,000 women undergoing breast conserving surgery.
14	two female firearms officers, victoria wheatley and rachael giles, will receive payouts of £35,000 each from the civil nuclear constabulary (cnc) after winning a sex discrimination case. they claimed their guns were too big for their small hands and they were subjected to lower marks in firing range tests, bullying, and isolation due to unsuitable equipment. the officers, described as petite, also complained about oversized protective gear and a wooden barricade that offered no support for their shorter statures. the central london employment tribunal found the cnc guilty of discrimination, and although claims of victimisation were dismissed, the force plans to appeal. the officers worked at different stations and were supported by the civil nuclear police federation. the cnc has promised to conduct an equality impact assessment to ensure proper training and equipment for all officers. this case is one of several workplace injury compensation claims made by uk police forces, with notable cases including a pc awarded £8,000 for flea bites and a pcso given £4,000 for knee injuries.
15	suge knight's attorney claimed last week that surveillance footage would prove his innocence in the homicide of terry carter at a compton, california fast-food restaurant. however, the owner of tam's burgers confirmed that their cctv camera was not operating on the night in question. law enforcement is now hopeful that someone may have captured the incident on their cell phone. knight, the founder of death row records, turned himself in to authorities after being contacted by deputies regarding an altercation at a film location. the argument between knight and terrence "t.c." sloan escalated at the fast-food restaurant, where knight allegedly ran over and killed carter and injured sloan. knight claims he was an innocent victim trying to escape a violent attack. the incident comes less than six months after he was shot six times at a west hollywood nightclub. knight is being held on $2 million bail and could face up to 30 years in prison due to prior convictions. his legal tangles include a famous feud between tupac shakur and biggie smalls in the 1990s and a prison sentence for battery.
16	noel harrison, a british singer best known for his hit song "the windmills of your mind," has passed away at the age of 79 after suffering a heart attack at his home in devon. born in london to actor rex harrison and collette thomas, harrison's music career took off when he moved to america as part of the british invasion and starred in the tv series "the girl from uncle." his cover of "the windmills of your mind" won a best song oscar in 1968 and became his most notable work. the singer, who was married three times and had five children and four grandchildren, also had a passion for ski-racing and represented britain at the olympics. harrison returned to britain in the 1990s and settled in devon before playing at the glastonbury festival in 2011. his co-star in "the girl from uncle," stefanie powers, paid tribute to him on twitter. harrison will be remembered for his timeless hit song and his successful career.
17	an interactive map created by hertfordshire-based driving experiences highlights the world's most dangerous roads, with the north yungas road in bolivia rated as the most perilous due to its deadly drops and lack of barriers. factors such as local driving techniques, weather conditions, and road surfaces were taken into account when assigning fear factor ratings to the 22 locations. other dangerous roads include scotland's a726, known for head-on collisions, and pakistan's fairy meadows road, which features treacherous high altitudes and narrow mountain roads. the map aims to raise awareness about road safety, as over 1.2 million people are killed and 20-50 million are injured annually in road accidents.
18	phil jagielka expresses frustration over john terry's possible return to the england squad despite his successful partnership with gary cahill. terry, who retired from international duty in 2012, has been a subject of discussions due to his performances at chelsea. however, jagielka, who has 31 caps and is expected to start for england in the world cup, defends young english talent and compares them favorably to european players like gerard deulofeu. jagielka returned to action for everton after a hamstring injury and expressed his desire to improve and play in the upcoming england friendly matches.
19	staten island district attorney daniel donovan, who oversaw the grand jury process in the case of the white police officer being cleared in the chokehold death of eric garner in 2014, has announced his candidacy for congress. donovan is seeking endorsements from the republican, conservative, and independence parties. the announcement did not mention the controversial case, which touched off nationwide protests and calls for justice. donovan's opponent in the special election, following the resignation of rep. michael grimm on tax evasion charges, includes potential democratic candidates such as state assemblyman michael cusick and former u.s. rep. michael mcmahon. donovan's previous experience in politics includes running for state attorney general in 2010 and losing to eric schneiderman. the grand jury's decision not to indict the officer contributed to the 'i can't breathe' movement and angered the city's african-american population, who made up just under 10% of the borough's population at the time.
20	at least nine climbers, including a nepalese guide and a german man, were killed by an avalanche on mount manaslu, the world's eighth-highest mountain, in northern nepal. six climbers were reported missing. the team, which consisted of french and german climbers, encountered difficulties on the mountain's slopes. the bodies of two victims and the injured were being airlifted to hospitals, while rescuers were also attempting to retrieve the bodies of the deceased. weather conditions were deteriorating and it was not possible to continue air searches. ten climbers survived the avalanche, but many were injured. the avalanche occurred when the climbers were at camp 22,960ft high, preparing to ascend to the 26,760ft summit. this marks the beginning of nepal's autumn mountaineering season.
21	daniel radcliffe and other mourners, including downton abbey creator lord fellowes, actor nigel havers, and former bond girl carmen du sautoy, paid their respects to the late british actress richard griffiths at his funeral in stratford-upon-avon on april 9, 2013. griffiths, best known for his roles in withnail and i, harry potter, and the history boys, died at age 65. the service was held at holy trinity church and was filled with laughter and tears as his life was remembered with immense warmth and affection. guests sang hymns, read poems and excerpts from literature, and spoke about griffiths' life and career. radcliffe openly wept during the funeral, and comedian jack whitehall, who was griffiths' godson, also attended. griffiths' 3ft-wide coffin entered the church to the hymn "praise my soul the king of heaven," and was followed by the recital of bach's brandenburg concertos as it left. flowers and tributes from dame judi dench and richard e. grant were laid at the church. griffiths built his reputation as a young actor at the royal shakespeare company and is survived by his wife heather.
22	roy hodgson, the england manager, did not include cristiano ronaldo in his ballon d'or votes, instead choosing javier mascherano of barcelona as his top pick. mascherano played for hodgson at liverpool in 2010 before moving to barcelona. hodgson also selected germany goalkeeper manuel neuer and captain philipp lahm for his other two votes. wayne rooney, the england captain, voted for ronaldo as his first choice, with toni kroos and gareth bale coming in second and third, respectively. a total of 544 international captains, coaches, and journalists were given votes, with ronaldo receiving 37.7% of them. messi, ronaldo's main rival for the award, did not select him in his top three choices, instead choosing angel di maria and andres iniesta. neither player picked the other in their votes. mascherano received votes from hodgson and belarus head coach alyaksandr khatskevich for the main prize.
23	tel aviv, a young and modern city in israel by the sea, is known for its sunny weather, vibrant nightlife, and rich culture. founded at the beginning of the 20th century, tel aviv boasts impressive modernist architecture, including the "white city" area, which is a unesco world heritage site. culture lovers can explore tel aviv's art scene at the tel aviv museum of art, contemporary galleries, and performance venues such as the habima national theater and israeli philharmonic orchestra. the city also offers unique experiences like the nalaga'at center, a theater where actors are deaf, blind or both. visitors can enjoy dining, sleeping, and partying at various hotspots, including betty ford, a 1950s-inspired bar, and luxury hotels like the david intercontinental and boutique montefiore. additionally, tel aviv is famous for its gay and lesbian scene, street food, and offers unique experiences such as scuba diving in its mediterranean waters.
24	nike has withdrawn a pair of tattoo-style leggings from its collection after they were criticized for being culturally insensitive and exploitative. the monochrome printed leggings, inspired by traditional samoan pe'a male tattoos, sparked controversy in australia and new zealand, where many residents found the design offensive. a new zealand parliament member criticized nike for not consulting the pacific community before launching the product, and an online petition against the leggings gathered over 750 signatures. nike apologized for any unintended offense and withdrew the leggings from their collection. some facebook users defended the product, arguing that sharing cultures is educational and not offensive.
25	a senior conservative mp, eleanor laing, has come under criticism for spending over £2,000 of taxpayers' money on two black dresses and a jacket for her role as deputy house of commons speaker. the expenditure was nearly double the cost of two ornate costumes for the associate serjeant-at-arms. laing, who earns a salary of £103,420, charged the cost to the taxpayer. she had paid back £25,000 in the expenses scandal in 2010 after selling a second home for a £1 million profit without paying capital gains tax. the spokesperson for the house of commons defended the expenditure, stating that the items were expected to last for several years. laing had previously expressed her passion for democracy, the dignity of the house of commons, and its role as a forum for national debate during her election campaign for the deputy speaker position in october 2021. the speaker's team carries a salary premium of £36,360 in addition to the standard mp's salary.
26	a new strain of bird flu, known as h7n9, has killed four people and infected eleven others in china. this strain is unknown to have caused illness in people before and has started to mutate, raising concerns for a potential human pandemic. chinese authorities are investigating the virus while japan, hong kong, and vietnam have increased precautions against it. experts believe the virus can spread to other animals, increasing the risk for more human cases. authorities in hong kong and japan have activated alert levels, and vietnam has banned imports of chinese poultry. the gene sequences of the virus reveal some mammalian adapting mutations, indicating that it may have already acquired some of the genetic changes it needs to spread from person to person. the chinese government has faced criticism for its handling of the outbreak, as some feel it took too long to report the cases. the government has pledged to strengthen its efforts to combat the virus and keep the public informed. flu experts around the world are analyzing samples of the virus to assess its potential for a human pandemic.
27	during bike week in daytona beach, florida, half a million motorcycle enthusiasts are taking over the city, making a significant economic impact with approximately $650 million generated through this and another similar event, biketoberfest. the family-friendly event, which began in 1937 and has transformed from a gang-ridden event in the past, attracts visitors from all over the country, many of whom can afford expensive motorcycles. bike week offers various activities and opportunities to explore nearby communities, appealing to both men and women. this year, the event has also become more diverse, with an increased number of women participants, who are now catered to with motorcycle designs specifically tailored to their needs.
28	a talented photographer named danny beath posthumously won the travel photo of the year award in the uk for a striking image of a lightning bolt over poppy fields. he had previously entered the competition multiple times but never won, despite holding several other photography awards. sadly, danny died of a heart attack three weeks before the competition results were announced, during his funeral in shrewsbury, shropshire. his win would have granted him new camera gear and a photo commission to papua new guinea. danny, who held a phd in tropical ecology, was a familiar face in the photography community and was described as a "great talent and a lovely man." his father expressed his deep sadness over the loss and the outpouring of support from danny's friends.
29	the liberal democrat conference in glasgow was affected by high winds and heavy rain, making it challenging for attendees to reach the venue. nick clegg, the lib dem leader, addressed delegates, insisting he had not held secret talks about forming a coalition government with either labour or the conservatives after the next election. however, he suggested a power-sharing deal with the conservatives might be preferred, as he believed labour would "wreck" the economy if given the opportunity to govern alone. clegg also indicated his support for higher taxes on the wealthy, including a proposed mansion tax, to help fill the budget deficit. the lib dems conducted a poll that showed 39% of activists preferred a coalition with labour, while only 15% favored another coalition with the conservatives. clegg predicted more coalitions in the future and urged all parties to be transparent with the public about their non-negotiable policies. vicky pryce, a former lib dem mp's wife, criticized the idea of a mansion tax, dismissing it as an arbitrary tax with no economic justification. she also disagreed with business secretary vince cable's concerns over the coalition's proposal for low-deposit mortgages potentially leading to a new housing market bubble.
30	sir greg martin, the headmaster of durand academy in south london, earned a total income of £390,000 in 2012/13, which included £161,000 as the sole director of a leisure center operating on the school site, along with his basic salary and pension contributions of over £229,000. the mps at the commons public accounts committee were shocked to discover that sir greg also ran a dating website from the same address as the school, with a twitter account featuring provocative content. margaret hodge, the labour mp who chairs the committee, criticized sir greg for "taking his eye off the ball" and expressed concern that the money generated from his leisure business could have been used to benefit the students' education. the academy trust is facing a financial notice to improve from the education funding agency and may be required to bring in new staff if improvements are not made. the contracts allowing sir greg to operate the leisure center are a concern to the agency. sir greg argued that the leisure business subsidizes school lunches, evening childcare, and free boarding, and defended his actions, stating that durand's success was due to private investment. sir greg's plans to set up a state boarding school in west sussex were rejected, and it is understood that his dating site is called the coterie.
31	a google glass explorer named cecilia abadie was fined by police in san diego for wearing the smart device while driving, despite it being classified as a navigation device by some. abadie, who has received support from fellow glass users, was given the ticket for having a monitor visible to the driver, according to the police. the law prohibits drivers from using monitors for entertainment purposes while operating a vehicle, but exempts gps devices and other specific uses. google glass is a wearable computer with an optical head-mounted display developed by google, with an explorer edition currently available for $1,500 and a consumer version expected in 2014. some supporters have suggested arguing for its use as a navigation device in court, but others argue that it is not built to disable itself like other in-vehicle navigational systems. abadie, who is a self-confessed tech enthusiast and google glass pioneer, has given ted talks about the smart glasses. the ticket also cited abadie for speeding.
32	manchester united's interim manager ryan giggs expressed his excitement over seeing 18-year-old james wilson scoring on his debut against hull city, looking forward to the future of the team under new manager louis van gaal. united has a history of promoting young players, with stars like paul scholes, phil neville, nicky butt, and ryan giggs himself coming through the academy. van gaal, renowned for bringing young talent at ajax, barcelona, and bayern munich, may be better suited for wilson and other youngsters as he prefers attacking football and has a track record of developing young players. players like andres iniesta, marc overmars, and thomas muller emerged under van gaal's guidance, making instant impacts in their respective careers. the club's young prospects, including andres pereira, joel castro pereira, sean goss, marius rashford, and ro-shaun williams, have been earmarked for potential stardom. van gaal's leadership style and emphasis on youth could lead to opportunities for these players, providing they prove to be good enough.
33	maria sharapova reached her third consecutive french open final by coming back from a set down against eugenie bouchard. sharapova, who has a remarkable record in three-set matches on clay, won her 18th consecutive deciding set in a 4-6, 7-5, 6-2 victory. bouchard, 20, who was playing in her second straight grand slam semi-final, pushed sharapova to the limit. despite losing to sharapova in the second round last year, bouchard demonstrated significant improvement, hitting the ball more aggressively. the semi-final was not for the faint-hearted, with both players fighting hard. sharapova recovered from a set down in both her previous matches and came back from 2-4 in the third set to take the lead. however, her serve was inconsistent and she struggled to serve out the set. bouchard, who had never lost a grand slam match after winning the first set, fought back, saving four match points. in the end, sharapova clinched the set and the match when bouchard netted a forehand. sharapova will play in her third consecutive french open final on saturday.
34	florida osteopath dr. daniel mcbath, who was banned from treating female patients due to allegations of sexual abuse and professional misconduct, has died of a heart attack at the age of 53. mcbath, from dade city, was investigated by the dade city police department and the florida department of law enforcement for allegedly drugging at least three female patients with cocaine and sedatives and sexually assaulting them. he was accused of misdiagnosing one patient with obesity and giving her a cocktail of drugs, and on another occasion, injecting an unknown substance into a patient's vagina and having sex with her along with another man. mcbath is survived by his wife and three children, and the allegations against him reportedly led to the loss of many of his friendships. the investigations into mcbath's actions are ongoing.
35	a study by aston university's pharmacy school, titled the aston medication adherence study (amas), analyzed one million prescriptions and found that one in three patients is putting their health at risk by not taking their medication properly, costing the nhs an estimated £500 million annually. factors such as side effects, poor doctor instructions, and lack of trust in pharmacists were identified as contributing to this issue. the study identified certain ethnic groups, such as those whose primary language is urdu or bengali, as well as older adults aged over 60, as being particularly susceptible to difficulties in understanding medication instructions. the report recommended that healthcare systems should take account of patients' first languages and offer more advice to those taking medication for long-term conditions. the study focused on patients suffering from type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, and high cholesterol in an ethnically diverse inner-city area with high levels of deprivation. it provided insights into adherence behavior and identified barriers to adherence from the patients' perspective. further research is planned to identify primary reasons for non-adherence in specific patient groups.
36	the u.s. air force conducted the first unmanned flight of an f-16 jet, which was retrofitted by boeing as a drone named qf-16 full scale aerial target. the reconditioned aircraft was piloted remotely from a ground control station by two u.s. air force test pilots, performing maneuvers, reaching supersonic speeds, returning to base, and landing without a pilot in the cockpit. previously, the military used outdated qf-4 aircraft for aerial target practice, but the modified qf-16 offers a more realistic adversary for current jet fighters. boeing retrieved and restored six retired f-16s from davis-monthan air force base for this purpose and is planning for live fire testing to take place at holloman air force base in new mexico.
37	two people in vermont, including a 49-year-old carpenter named scott sgorbati and an 87-year-old man named richard hollis breen, have died from eastern equine encephalitis (eee), a rare but fatal brain infection transmitted through mosquitoes. the victims are the first and second cases in the state since 2010, with the virus causing swelling of the brain and leading to death in about a third of cases. eee is part of the alphavirus family and affects the central nervous system, causing symptoms such as fever, headache, irritability, restlessness, drowsiness, vomiting, convulsions, and coma. no reported cases of eee were recorded in vermont from 1964 to 2010. the centers for disease control and prevention (cdc) recommends wearing long sleeves and insect repellent when outdoors to avoid mosquito contact and avoiding being outside during dusk and dawn. the risk of contracting eee is low, but health officials advise taking precautions to prevent transmission.
38	prince william and prince harry are both competitive on the polo field, but have different post-game routines. while william returns home to his family, harry is up for celebratory drinks. australian polo player alec white, who has become friends with the brothers, shared this insight after playing with them at the audi polo challenge in ascot. white described the princes as down-to-earth and friendly, with harry being the more fierce player. white and his cousins, also professional polo players, spent six months a year overseas competing, and were thrilled to play with their royal teammates. during their encounter, william expressed his love for australia and his desire to return, while harry entertained white and others with his fun-loving personality. white found the experience surreal and cherished the opportunity to play on home turf in scone when he returns. the 'three whites' grew up on a family property in the hunter valley region of new south wales that breeds polo horses. the siblings hope to compete in scone's 'polo in the paddock' competition soon. alec began pursuing polo professionally during his gap year and now lives and plays in england and argentina. he values the support of his cousins in england and hopes to compete as far as he can before returning to breed and train high-level polo horses in australia.
39	the miami dolphins cheerleaders have released a video of themselves miming to taylor swift's "22" in bikinis, following last year's popular miming of carly rae jepsen's "call me maybe." the video was filmed during their annual photo shoot in the dominican republic. the new orleans saints cheerleaders have entered the miming-to-pop-songs-in-bikinis competition with their own video, which includes hamburger-eating, boxing, and albino alligator-holding. the saints cheerleaders have been declared the winners for creativity, camera shots, and organization by nfl.com. it's unclear whether both teams collaborated on their cover choices or if it was an independent decision. other cheerleaders may join in the trend.
40	new york city officials are battling a large rat population, and a group of dog owners known as the ryders alley trencher-fed society (r.a.t.s.) are assisting them by taking their dogs on night-time hunts to kill vermin. the group, which was founded in 1995, consists of various terrier breeds such as border terriers, wire-haired dachshunds, and feists. the dogs are trained to hunt rats, and their owners allow them to make kills before taking the rats from their jaws. experts estimate that the number of rats in the city could be double the 8.4 million people living there. the city has taken measures to combat the rat infestation, including hiring more inspectors and using contraceptives to curb the population. animal rights advocates have criticized the rat hunts as a blood sport. the origins of rat-hunting with dogs date back to medieval times, and it remains a contentious issue.
41	england manager roy hodgson is looking for a strong start in euro 2016, with captain wayne rooney attempting to lift the team's spirits by comparing raheem sterling to marc overmars. rooney showed sterling videos of overmars before the world cup and believes the youngster has the potential to match the dutch legend's destructive qualities. england's record against switzerland is good, with a win percentage of 63.6% in 22 matches. england have won 14 of those matches, drawing five and losing just three, and are unbeaten in their last eight games against the swiss. rooney is a good bet to score against switzerland, having netted in each of his three previous appearances against them. hodgson is preparing for monday's game against switzerland without daniel sturridge and potentially jordan henderson. injuries have been a issue for england, with sturridge's withdrawal more damaging than the loss of midfield rookie jack colback or backup keeper ben foster. hodgson has danny welbeck ready to step in for sturridge. england will play on a monday for only the 10th time in 45 years and hodgson refuted any theories that a 67-year-old coach might not be best-equipped to coach modern footballers. the team practiced with a diamond midfield at times last week and have options to deploy sterling, with the possibility of keeping him at the tip of the diamond or moving him back to the wing. england's record on mondays is good, with a win percentage of 55%, 37 draws, 11 losses and a win percentage of 67.3%. hodgson emphasized that either you're a good coach or not and that it's important to have the best players in key positions and to ensure those around them complement them.
42	mayor ray nagin of new orleans traveled to havana, cuba, over the weekend to learn about disaster management and preparation following hurricane katrina. cuba's exceptional disaster response has been internationally recognized, with nagin planning to meet with officials, including those from the latin american medical centers for disaster, to learn about their strategies. cuba, which has experienced several hurricanes in recent years, has managed to minimize losses and fatalities through mandatory evacuations and government preparation. nagin is the first new orleans mayor to make an official visit to cuba in 50 years, with the state department approving the trip. the visit comes after president obama held a town hall meeting in new orleans, discussing the failure of government response during katrina and its aftermath. new orleans has since adjusted its disaster response, with the successful evacuation of over 18,000 residents during hurricane gustav in 2008. despite some differences in government structures, some americans believe that lessons can be learned from their caribbean neighbor.
43	ashton kutcher and demi moore, in their first prime time interview together, discussed their new foundation, dna foundation (demi & ashton), which was established to combat child sex slavery in the united states after they encountered a trafficking victim at the us-mexico border. kutcher revealed that between 100,000 and 300,000 children are sex slaves in the us, and the average age of entry into the sex trade is 13. traffickers are often normal-looking men in their 30s who manipulate and deceive vulnerable girls into trafficking, beginning with a courtship process. a 17-year-old girl, identified as "nicole," shared her story of being trafficked when she was 13 after her father went to jail and her mother struggled with drug addiction. social media platforms, like twitter, are being used to spread awareness about the issue and encourage action against sex trafficking online. the couple emphasized the importance of acknowledging the problem and remaining dedicated to finding solutions.
44	julia gillard, the former prime minister of australia, discussed the challenges faced by female leaders with hillary clinton during their tenures in office. gillard expressed that being a female leader is isolating, and sharing experiences with other women in similar positions is crucial. she highlighted the ways in which female leaders are often judged differently than male leaders, including being questioned about their ability to lead instead of their leadership style. gillard also referred to her famous "misogyny speech" in parliament, where she addressed the sexism she encountered as the first female prime minister and chose not to tolerate it anymore. the former prime minister emphasized the importance of acknowledging and addressing the sexism encountered by female leaders, as it remains a significant issue despite the presence of some prominent female leaders like angela merkel and christine lagarde.
45	a cease-fire between israel and gaza appeared to hold hours after it was declared on november 14, israeli officials said, despite reports of rocket violations. the agreement called for both sides to halt all acts of aggression and for border crossings to be opened. at least 139 palestinians had been killed, mostly civilians, and more than 1,450 targets were hit by israeli forces during the conflict, which was sparked by the assassination of ahmed al-ja'abari, the head of hamas' military wing. the egyptian government played a key role in brokering the peace deal, and prime minister benjamin netanyahu warned of possible additional military action if the cease-fire fails to lead to long-term security. the united nations called for the safety of civilians to be prioritized and called for long-term solutions to address the underlying causes of conflict. a bus attack near tel aviv wounded 24 people, and hamas claimed responsibility. u.s. secretary of state hillary clinton continued to work with regional partners to implement and expand the agreement.
46	an unidentified man was caught trying to jump the white house fence on friday afternoon and was apprehended by secret service officers. the man was carrying two large bags, but the secret service is not currently concerned about them as they have the suspect in custody. standard protocol includes investigating the bags by washington's metro police department's explosive ordinance division. president obama was not at the white house during the incident as he was in michigan for the signing of the new farm bill, and the first daughters were not at home as the incident occurred in the early afternoon.
47	according to a leaked u.s. diplomatic cable from 2009, obtained by wikileaks, american diplomats expressed concern to their russian counterparts that north korea had supplied iran with long-range missiles, specifically 19 bm-25 missiles, which could potentially give iran greater strike capabilities than previously discussed in public. the russians expressed skepticism, citing a lack of evidence. the u.s. believed that iran was interested in the propulsion technology of these missiles. however, the authenticity and accuracy of the missile parade footage in pyongyang were debated during the meeting, with the russians questioning whether north korea even had the bm-25 missile in the first place. the russians also shared their assessment of iran's missile program, believing that tehran's missiles could reach targets in the middle east and parts of europe, but could not inflict substantial damage with conventional warheads. they believed iran might develop a long-range ballistic missile program after 2015, but did not see it as an immediate threat. the cable's author concluded that the missile programs of iran and north korea were not considered a current threat to the u.s. or russia.
48	manchester united midfielder adnan januzaj has been given the honor of wearing ryan giggs' famous number 11 shirt next season, as giggs himself has moved on to become louis van gaal's assistant manager. united have not filled the vacant numbers five, seven, and nine, with van gaal looking to bring in new signings. januzaj takes the iconic number from giggs, who retired from playing in may after a 23-year career at old trafford. giggs did not want united to retire his number and welcomed the idea of januzaj taking it on. januzaj made 27 appearances last season, scoring four goals, and signed a new five-year contract. giggs revealed that he received the number 11 shirt simply because it was traditionally worn by left wingers when squad numbers were first introduced.
49	james rodriguez and radamel falcao, two prominent colombian soccer players, have a unique connection as their fathers were former teammates on deportes tolima, a professional colombian football club. this historical connection could explain why the pair has a seamless partnership on the international stage for colombia, and even during their time together at monaco last season. rodriguez, a standout performer at the 2014 world cup, recently joined real madrid, while falcao is currently on loan at manchester united. despite injury issues with his settling in process at united, falcao scored an equalizer for manchester united against aston villa during the weekend.
50	cockroaches fitted with electrical "backpacks" containing microphones are being developed into cyborg creatures, or biobots, that could help locate survivors in disasters by detecting sounds. these biobots could be kept within a defined area using an "invisible fence" technology and steered towards sounds using directional microphones. the researchers, from north carolina state university, believe they could differentiate between important and unimportant sounds and create a reliable mobile network. previous research showed that biobots could be used to map disaster areas, and the researchers plan to merge their research for both mapping and survivor detection. the use of cockroaches as cyborgs is not new, but the ethical implications of controlling their movements are debated.
51	in china, despite the success of a few wealthy self-made women, gender inequality persists. the country has a population of 34 million more men than women due to a preference for boys under the one-child policy, selective abortions, and marital property owned by men. the government is criticized for not doing enough to protect women's rights, with no women on the ruling communist party's politburo committee. a derogatory term, "leftover women," has been used to shame urban educated women over 27 who are still single, and there's social pressure on women to get married. successful women in china have achieving despite the societal challenges, not because of them. women's rights advocates like wu qing and scholars like leta hong fincher and joy chen arespeaking out for women's rights in china. wu, a tireless activist, founded a school to empower rural women.
52	arsenal secured a valuable 2-0 win against borussia dortmund in the champions league, with yaya sanogo scoring the opener after just 73 seconds and alexis sanchez adding a second-half goal. sanogo's goal came at a crucial moment, easing pressure on arsenal and soothing the nerves of the home fans. arsene wenger was delighted with the performance, especially given that arsenal had gone three games without a win and he faced criticism for his tactics. sanchez continued his impressive goalscoring form with his 13th goal in his last 16 games. however, injuries to yaya sanogo (hamstring) and mikel arteta (calf) were a cause for concern, adding to arsenal's inconsistent form and stretched squad. damian martinez put in a solid performance in goal, making several important saves, and sanogo's early goal came after just holding off a challenge near the edge of the dortmund penalty area and flicking a pass to santi cazorla, who returned the ball for the young striker to finish. dortmund made a sluggish start and jurgen klopp's team were not the same fast and furious side that they were in the opening game of the campaign. martinez and the arsenal defence held firm, and the team sprang on the counter-attack with sanchez, cazorla, and oxlade-chamberlain causing problems for dortmund. arsenal have a chance to win the group but need to beat galatasaray and hope anderlecht win in dortmund. the dortmund fans, who were outnumbered by arsenal supporters, were mainly satisfied with their team's performance, as they had already qualified for the last 16.
53	a southern california woman, catherine kieu becker, age 48, was arrested and jailed on multiple charges including aggravated mayhem, false imprisonment, assault with a deadly weapon, poisoning, and spousal abuse, after allegedly drugging her husband, cutting off his penis, and disposing of it in the garbage disposal while he was asleep following a dinner monday evening. the 51-year-old victim, whose identity was not released due to being an alleged victim of spousal abuse, underwent emergency surgery at uci medical center. the couple is going through a divorce.
54	in a philadelphia daily news editorial board meeting on monday, sen. hillary clinton admitted to "misspeaking" about her arrival in bosnia in 1996, where she had previously claimed her group ran with their heads down to avoid sniper fire. video footage from the event, however, showed clinton and her daughter calmly exiting the plane and interacting with locals. clinton stated she was told there was a threat of sniper fire and had to greet an eight-year-old girl; her memory of the event, she claimed, was being questioned due to her focus on her foreign policy experience. meanwhile, john mccain addressed the economy and mortgage crisis during a roundtable discussion in santa ana, california. hillary clinton continued campaigning in pennsylvania and dismissed concerns about her chances of securing the nomination, while barack obama was on vacation in the us virgin islands and set to resume campaigning in north carolina.
55	malaysia observed a national day of mourning as the remains of 20 victims of malaysia flight mh17, which was shot down over eastern ukraine in july, arrived in kuala lumpur. families of the victims, including prime minister najib razak and king abdul halim mu'adzam shah, gathered at the airport to receive the bodies. a minute's silence was observed nationwide as the last casket was unloaded. forty-three of the 298 people killed were malaysians. the process of identifying the remains is expected to take months. malaysia airlines distributed black ribbons and flew its flag at half-mast in mourning. the mood was somber as families awaited the arrival of the victims' remains, with some breaking into tears and others taking seats to await the special flight. the remains of seven passengers were flown back to their hometowns, while the rest were transported by land for proper burials.
56	two white vans came dangerously close to colliding on the m5 motorway after one driver passed a drink to another at around 60mph. the incident was captured on the dashboard camera of a concerned driver, who expressed concern for the potential deadly consequences of the reckless stunt. road safety campaigners have condemned the drivers and call for them to be held accountable for risking other people's lives. police are currently examining the footage and will be contacting the van owners for further investigation.
57	arizona's new immigration legislation, one of the toughest in the country, requires immigrants to carry registration documents and authorizes police to question individuals suspected of being in the us illegally. critics argue it may lead to racial profiling and have raised concerns over constitutionality and cost. the bill, awaiting governor jan brewer's signature, has generated interest in other states. supporters say arizona is leading the way in addressing the lack of a national immigration policy. similar bills have increased in number in recent years, focusing on issues like driver's licenses, health, and education. opponents, including the aclu and immigrant advocacy groups, have pledged court challenges and warn against following arizona's approach. the fate of this legislation will influence other states' actions.
58	osama bin laden communicated with al qaeda in the arabian peninsula (aqap), a yemen-based wing of al qaeda, according to materials found in bin laden's compound after his death in pakistan. the documents also confirm that bin laden was involved in planning attacks, encouraging direct plots against americans and u.s. interests in europe late last year. the threats that emerged during that period came from "al qaeda central," a term used for bin laden and his direct associates. the intelligence community had classified information suggesting bin laden's involvement before, but the documents provide confirmation. bin laden placed a priority on attacking americans and was aware and supportive of plots against europe.
59	professor les ebdon, the head of the office for fair access (offa), urged universities to consider academic potential beyond qualifications when recruiting undergraduates. he revealed interventions at 26 universities to make targets for recruiting disadvantaged pupils more ambitious. ed miliband, labour leader, plans to shift public funding from elite universities to those offering vocational education and "technical degrees," aiming to help those who do not attend university. miliband believes these degrees will benefit the "forgotten 50%."
60	hillary clinton called for economic equality for women to become a political movement during a roundtable at the center for american progress. she emphasized the importance of turning issues into political movements to demand candidates' attention during elections. clinton, along with other high-profile female lawmakers, urged women to become part of a movement for women's empowerment and to speak up and demand action. the call to action includes encouraging more women to vote and participate in the political process. clinton is currently considering a run for the 2016 presidential nomination, and her focus on women's issues is a key part of her message as democrats prepare for the midterm elections.
61	severe flooding in bangkok, thailand, threatened the central areas of the city on saturday, with high tides predicted to reach 13 feet. residents waited anxiously to see whether the city's defenses along the chao phraya river and canals would hold. the suburbs were already submerged, but central bangkok had mostly remained dry. the city faced two converging threats: runoff from the north and high tide pushing water in the opposite direction. authorities ordered work crews to cut channels in roadways for faster drainage, but later opted for dredging canals and using pumps instead. health concerns were increasing with the filthy floodwater, which was reported to contain dangerous animals such as snakes and crocodiles. an estimated 1 million of the city's 12 million residents had left as of saturday. the government had evacuated some residents from northern and eastern suburbs and set up flood relief centers. thailand's ministry of public health had transferred patients from bangkok hospitals to upcountry facilities. the floods, caused by monsoon rains, had killed 373 people nationwide and affected more than 9.5 million people. the government called the flooding the worst in thai history, and it might take over a month for the waters to recede from some areas. overall damage from the floods could exceed $6 billion. us authorities urged against all but essential travel to affected areas and had provided relief resources, including pumps, purifiers, and life vests.
62	two women attending different university halloween parties went viral on twitter after pictures of them appearing naked were posted. a blonde woman from arizona state university (asu) was the first to gain attention, with a picture taken by twitter user @amandajanson4 being shared by the unofficial asu anonymous account @asuconfessions. a few days later, @asuconfessions posted a picture of a brunette woman at a different party, also unidentified, with a man, causing similar reactions. the debate on social media revolved around the women's choices, with some seeing it as a bold statement, while others considered it inappropriate and potentially against public decency laws. the originators of the photos remain unidentified.
63	a group of five american graduate students, including two rhodes scholars and three naval academy graduates, attempted to swim the english channel to honor veterans and raise awareness for the nonprofit organization, mission continues. they faced challenges such as seasickness, hypothermia, and massive swells, but were unsuccessful in reaching the french shore. despite the failure, they raised $5,000 for mission continues, which provides paid fellowships for wounded and disabled veterans to continue serving their communities. the students were inspired by the sacrifices made by veterans of the past and present, and considered their effort a success in bringing attention to their cause.
64	two female traffic wardens in tangshan, china, were caught on camera fighting each other while they were supposed to be directing traffic during rush hour. the women, who were supposed to protect pedestrians, instead engaged in a physical fight, hitting and punching each other for over a minute in the middle of a busy road. they were fired the next day for their unprofessional behavior. the dispute turned into a street brawl and caused a disruption in traffic. the traffic wardens were hired assistants, not full-time employees, and the fight occurred just before 9am on july 8. police confirmed that both women were dismissed following the incident.
65	hannah bowness-major, a 13-year-old girl from cheshire, england, has addison's disease, a rare condition that affects just 160 children in the uk. the condition leaves her adrenal glands unable to produce enough of the hormone cortisol, which helps regulate blood pressure and deal with stress. if hannah becomes too excited, stressed, or worried, her body goes into an adrenal crisis, which can result in fainting or collapsing. she takes a cocktail of 30 drugs daily and has severe allergies that limit her activities and put her at risk. the condition also makes it difficult for her to fight infections, and even a common cold or exposure to allergens can make her severely ill. hannah and her family are raising funds to enable her to have a hydrocortisone pump fitted, which would constantly supply the hormone she is missing, allowing for a more normal life.
66	jordan spieth, a 20-year-old golfer, has quickly made a name for himself in professional golf, drawing comparisons to tiger woods. before turning pro, spieth was a multiple u.s. junior amateur champion and dominated college golf in his freshman year. he became the first teenage winner on the pga tour in 82 years, and at the tournament of champions, finished second to zach johnson. tiger woods, a 38-year-old and 14-time major winner, spent time with his girlfriend lindsey vonn before beginning his 2014 season. he ended 2013 as the pga tour's golfer of the year and aims to win his 15th major this year. rory mcilroy, the world's top-ranked golfer in 2013, had a difficult year but hopes to win two majors in 2014. adam scott, who finished second in the world rankings in 2013, missed out on the "triple crown" at the masters but aims to reclaim the top spot in 2014 and add to his major wins. south korean teenage golfer lee chang-woo won the asia-pacific amateur championship and earned a spot at the masters and final qualifying for the british open.
67	researchers at the foundation for research and technology-hellas in greece have developed a robotic octopus inspired by the underwater movements of the real octopus, which can travel at up to 25mph (40km/h). the robotic octopus, which has webbed arms and a streamlined head, moves at half its 14-inch (360mm) body length every second. early versions used silicon arms to propel the robot, but researchers added webs between the arms to increase speed and efficiency. the robotic octopus can also crawl along the seabed using suckers on its arms. the team's tests show that the robot swims faster with the addition of webs, reaching speeds of 7 inches (18cm) per second. the researchers claim the robot could be used for monitoring fish populations and the underwater environment in a more discreet way. the robot, which was presented at the ieee international conference on intelligent robots and systems, was a finalist for two best paper awards.
68	barry lewis, a 32-year-old father of two from weston-super-mare, became a youtube sensation after teaching himself to cook and documenting his journey on the platform. with fewer than 5 years of cooking experience, lewis had no idea how to poach an egg before starting his channel. his videos, featuring him and his six-year-old daughter phoebe, have garnered nearly 10 million views and 150,000 subscribers. lewis has also published a best-selling cookbook called 'dinner's on' and has appeared on jamie oliver's food tube channel. recently, sainsbury's announced lewis as the new face of their 'love your freezer' campaign, which promotes cooking nutritious family meals straight from the freezer. lewis, who used to rely on takeaways, hopes to inspire others to learn to cook and has plans to quit his full-time job as a quantity surveyor to pursue a career in cooking.
69	a british actor named thomas hare, who went by the stage name tommy vine, was found dead in the mekong river in cambodia on march 16, 2013. the 25-year-old, who was from bristol but lived in london, had studied at the arts educational school and had acted in shows such as casulty, sky's a touch of cloth, and channel 4's top boy. colleagues and friends, including the creator of the bbc sitcom gimme gimme gimme, paid tribute to him online after his body was discovered by a fisherman. hare had last been seen swimming in the river on thursday.
70	a massachusetts couple, ryan barry and ashley cyr, have been charged with manslaughter for allegedly giving their 5-month-old daughter, mya barry, a bottle of formula laced with heroin, resulting in her death in september 2011. the couple, both of quincy, were arrested on friday and pleaded not guilty, while being held on $200,000 cash bail. an autopsy determined that mya died from opiate poisoning, and a grand jury returned manslaughter indictments against both parents on thursday. prosecutors allege that ryan had seen ashley snort heroin off a dr. seuss book and that her drug use was reckless, and that the heroin likely got into the formula when someone cleaned a dirty syringe in the water bottle used to make it. ryan's lawyer, liam scully, claimed that it was unclear who put the heroin in the bottle and that ryan denies any wrongdoing. ashley's lawyer didn't immediately comment. the couple is due back in court on november 8 for a pretrial conference. ryan has a history of legal issues, including a 2006 guilty plea for raping a minor during a drug- and alcohol-fueled party, for which he served 15 months in prison and was placed on three years’ probation, and a heroin possession charge in april 2013.
71	janelle monáe, a singer-songwriter from los angeles, california, is gaining recognition for her unique brand of "futuristic soul with a real '80s quality." she is often described as an android traveling through time from another planet, escaping destruction for falling in love with a human. monáe's music blends classic sounds from the past with a futuristic edge, which has earned her comparisons to artists like donna summer and the beatles. her live performances include unexpected covers and energetic choreography, which she performs both on and off the stage. monáe, or her alleged android persona cindi mayweather, has already gained the support of influential figures like garth trinidad of kcrw radio, who believes she will be a household name soon. monáe's talent matches her theatricality, and she has recently signed to bad boy records and landed a deal with coca-cola. upcoming performances include shows with gwen stefani and the hollywood bowl, with more to be announced.
72	u.s. student amanda knox and her former italian boyfriend raffaele sollecito are awaiting a verdict from an italian court in the long-lasting murder case of british student meredith kercher. knox and sollecito were acquitted in 2011 but the italian supreme court overturned their acquittals, stating that the jury did not consider all the evidence and that discrepancies in testimony needed to be addressed. the retrial began in september in florence and a verdict is expected on thursday. knox and sollecito have maintained their innocence but face potential sentences of 26 years for homicide and additional years for slander if found guilty. if knox is ultimately found guilty, italy could seek her extradition from the united states. both sides will have the opportunity to appeal the verdict to italy's supreme court. knox and sollecito were convicted of murdering kercher in 2009; kercher was found with more than 40 stab wounds, and a deep gash in her throat. kercher's family, represented by their lawyer, believes that more than one person was in the room when kercher was killed, and has criticized the acquittal as "superficial and unbalanced." a lawyer for knox, meanwhile, has emphasized her innocence and stated that she "is doing very well" as she awaits the final decision. rick ferguson, a man who was freed from missouri prison after his murder conviction was overturned, has been advocating for knox and communicating with her while she faces this current trial.
73	a son of a man who died alongside his brother and cousin while kayaking on the river tyne in the uk two years ago nearly drowned in the same river. the tragic incident occurred on sunday when darren thorpe, 41, and mark thorpe, 39, both from south tyneside, along with their cousin gavin bradley, 36, from jarrow, went kayaking and failed to return home. the group had parked a car at hexham and planned to paddle 14 miles downstream to reach a second car at wylam. however, they got into difficulty near corbridge, and all three men drowned. the trio were last seen around noon at devil's water, a tributary of the river tyne, using 'sit on' style kayaks. the river was swollen due to torrential rain, making it faster, deeper, and more dangerous than normal. emergency services were joined by the raf and the coastguard in the search, and the bodies of two men were recovered near riding mill pumping station, while the third was found a mile upstream in the corbridge area. three kayaks have also been recovered. darren and mark's neighbor expressed her condolences, noting that darren's son anthony had also had a close call with the river a few years ago. the men had been experienced kayakers, but the sit-on-top kayaks they were using are typically associated with leisure kayakers, and the area where they were found is considered treacherous even for experienced kayakers. the tragedy is the second in just over three years on the same stretch of the river tyne.
74	a tory mp, stewart jackson, is being sued by the independent parliamentary standards authority (ipsa) after refusing to pay £54,000, which represents the increase in value of his second home while he was claiming mortgage interest on expenses. this comes after it was revealed that mps collectively made over £1 million by selling their second homes, sparking accusations of profiting from taxpayers' money. jackson is the only one of 29 mps who has refused to repay the demanded amount, while others including four cabinet ministers have agreed to pay a total of £484,828. ipsa has launched legal action at the high court to recover the money, but jackson vowed not to pay up and accused ipsa of bullying. the controversy arose from the 2010 ban on using commons expenses to pay mortgage interest, but transitional arrangements allowed some mps to keep claiming the money until august 2012, as long as they agreed to return any potential capital gain. former mp martin bell, who campaigned for greater transparency, urged mps to repay any profit made on their properties. ipsa required formal valuations from the royal institute of chartered surveyors for properties and accepted only independent valuations at the start and end of the claim period. those not asked to repay any money included deputy prime minister nick clegg and david miliband.
75	rail fares in britain have significantly increased over the past 20 years since privatization. open return tickets on some popular routes have risen by up to 246%, making them more expensive than traveling to mediterranean destinations or even flying to new york. an open return ticket from london to manchester, for instance, cost £96 in 1995 but now costs £329 - an increase of 243%. this has made cars and flying more cost-effective alternatives for solo travelers and families. rail passengers registered the lowest level of satisfaction this year due to overcrowded, late-running and expensive services, with season tickets seeing a 2.5% increase in january, despite the average inflations rate being lower. the rail industry defends the increases stating that passengers numbers have almost doubled and contributes to reinvestment in improving the railway, but critics argue that rail bosses are paid large bonuses while passengers suffer. the transport salaried staffs association (tssa) conducted the research, and its general secretary, manuel cortes, called for an end to the "persecution of passengers" and privatization.
76	survivors of the sandy hook elementary school massacre in newtown, connecticut, are beginning their first full academic year since the december 2012 shootings that left 20 students and six teaching staff dead. the children are now attending classes in a renovated former middle school in monroe, connecticut, where several hundred students are being bused daily. armed guards and real-time monitoring systems have been implemented in newtown schools as part of new security measures. newtown voters will decide in october whether to approve plans to demolish the sandy hook elementary school building and construct a new one on the same property, with a $750,000 state grant allocated for the new school's design. a referendum will also allow voters to approve the remaining $50 million from the state grant for the project, which is expected to be completed by september 2016. students will continue to attend classes in monroe until then. adam lanza, the gunman, killed his mother before the massacre and took his own life as police arrived at the school. the motive for the shooting remains unclear.
77	victor spinetti, the welsh actor known for starring in all three beatles films, has passed away at the age of 82 after a battle with pancreatic cancer. born in cwm, wales, spinetti attended monmouth school and the cardiff college of music and drama. his acting career began as a waiter and factory worker before he gained prominence in the beatles' films "a hard day's night," "help!," and "magical mystery tour." spinetti appeared in over 30 films throughout his versatile career, including "the taming of the shrew," "under milk wood," and "the krays." he also had successful runs on broadway and the west end, and won a tony award for his role as an obnoxious drill sergeant in "oh! what a lovely war." spinetti also directed and co-authored "john lennon in his own write" at the national theatre and directed productions of "jesus christ superstar" and "hair." he wrote poetry and prose that have been published, and his memoirs, "victor spinetti up front," were filled with anecdotes about his career. spinetti's close friendship with the beatles during their fame helped solidify his place in entertainment history. he died at a hospice in monmouth, with close friend barbara windsor among his final visitors.
78	the tragic crash of malaysia airlines flight 17 on july 17, 2014, resulted in the death of 298 people. the cause of the crash is under investigation, with blame being traded between ukraine and russia. u.s. officials believe pro-russian rebels were responsible. the international community calls for an immediate, thorough, independent investigation, as families of the victims deserve justice. the dutch safety board should lead the investigation due to its expertise and past successes. security at the crash site must be established, and all parties involved should commit to full transparency. the investigation is crucial as commercial aviation is essential for global commerce, and any threat to commercial airliners could cause a significant economic impact. leaders from around the world must demonstrate strong leadership to ensure a true independent investigation is launched.
79	harold and ruth knapke, a devoted couple who met in elementary school and married after world war ii, passed away just 11 hours apart at a nursing home in russia, ohio. their children described their deaths as their "final act of love." harold's health had been declining for a year, and when he was told of his wife ruth's impending death, he appeared to follow her soon after. the couple, who had six children together, were known for their strong bond and dedication to each other. they met in school and reconnected during the war through letters, and their marriage lasted 66 years. they are remembered for their long-lasting love and commitment. harold and ruth knapke, an ordinary couple from ohio, met in elementary school but were separated when harold's family moved away. they reconnected during world war ii through letters, and their relationship grew. they married in 1947 and had six children. harold worked in the education system as a principal, teacher, and coach, while ruth became a school secretary. the couple was known for their unwavering love and dedication to each other. when ruth contracted a rare infection and her condition deteriorated, the couple's children noticed a shift in harold. he appeared to be rapidly declining, and three days later, he died. ruth passed away the same night. their children believe that harold may have waited for ruth, a mutual devotion that lasted their entire lives. the couple's love story, which spanned over six decades, is a testament to the enduring power of a strong marriage. they were laid to rest together in a joint funeral.
80	a new study presented at the consumer electronics show in las vegas on thursday revealed that nearly 70% of american adults experience eye strain caused by extended use of computers, tablets, and smartphones. symptoms include back pain, blurred vision, and headaches. the vision council reported that many adults spend between 6 to 9 hours per day using digital devices, with 4% spending over 10 hours. the constant focus on nearby screens can strain the eyes' focusing system. eye care providers have reported a rise in patients with screen-related eye strain. however, there are ways to reduce the effects, including positioning screens at arm's length, holding handheld devices below eye-level, and taking frequent breaks. the optical industry is also developing lens technologies to address the causes of digital eye strain.
