81	mark cavendish, a british cyclist and the current uci road race world champion, is known as the "fastest man on two wheels." with a record of 25 tour de france stages, including four consecutive wins at the champs-elysees, cavendish revealed the keys to his success. he credits his strong competitiveness since childhood, embracing his differences in size and efficiency, training his brain through logic games, trusting his team, having a photographic memory, and using criticism as motivation. cavendish believes these elements set him apart and contribute to his status as one of the greatest sprinters in cycling history. daisy carrington from cnn contributed to this report.
82	a woman named katie lawton from stoke-on-trent was surpriseed and embarrassed when a fairground worker likened her to overweight pop idol winner michelle mcmanus. the encounter motivated katie, who weighed over 19 stone, and her step-sister stacey wisdom, who weighed almost 13 stone, to join weight watchers and lose a combined total of 12 stone. the sisters supported each other throughout their weight loss journey, with katie crediting stacey for helping her stay on track and vice versa. they have since transformed their lives and gained newfound confidence. before losing weight, both sisters struggled with shopping for clothes and dealing with the psychological effects of their size. now, katie and stacey feel happier and more confident, and have adopted healthier eating habits. their weight loss journey began in 2011, and they continue to maintain their svelte figures. their weight loss diets included cereal, sandwiches, and pasta for meals, and chocolate, crisps, and biscuits as snacks for both sisters. since then, they have made significant lifestyle changes.
83	a woman was caught on camera stealing donated charity clothing from a village hall in oxfordshire, replacing them with her own rubbish. the woman, dressed in an olive green parka, made several trips between her unregistered blue vauxhall corsa and the collection point, dumping her rubbish at the side of the hall. the stolen clothes were intended to raise money for the county's air ambulance service. the parish council had installed a new cctv camera just weeks before the theft and the woman was seen smiling directly at it. the rubbish included an old extractor fan and electrical equipment. the parish council had to hire a van to clear up the waste and are hoping for the public's help in identifying the woman. chairman douglas kedge called the woman's actions "reprehensible" and urged her to return the stolen clothing to the charity. the incident resulted in additional costs for the council since the rubbish was taken to a professional waste disposal facility.
84	mps have called for the scrapping of black friday discounts due to the disorder and injuries caused during last year's sales. a commons motion was laid, signed by three mps, condemning retailers for offering huge discounts, resulting in scenes of disorder with many police in attendance and some stores being forced to close. the motion cited incidents of fighting over televisions at asda in wembley and 200 people refusing to leave a tesco extra store in manchester. the mps are urging all uk retailers to ignore black friday in 2015 and beyond, citing disrupted timing and rhythm of christmas sales, and potential harm to police resources. black friday saw an estimated £810million in online sales in the uk last year.
85	plans to build britain's largest muslim cemetery on rural land in catherine-de-barnes, near solihull, west midlands, with a capacity for 11,000 graves have faced opposition from local residents. the objections include concerns about traffic, greenbelt land, and the need for such a large facility. currently, the largest muslim-only cemetery in the uk is in ilford, essex, with 5,000 plots. local residents argue that there is ample space for burials in the existing facilities. conservatives and residents' association representatives criticized the proposals, stating that the greenbelt land should be preserved. councillor alison rolf shared similar concerns and expressed understanding for local frustrations. the development would also include 95 parking spaces. the proposal received support from the local muslim community, who argued for a desperate need for more burial spaces as the muslim population grows rapidly, and the current cemetery in handsworth is nearly full. funeral director mohammed khalil highlighted that even 11,000 plots would not be sufficient for the next 50 years with the population aging and more families remaining in the uk. both applications are set for hearing at the planning committee next month.
86	the article describes the 2005 presidential election in egypt, won by hosni mubarak, which was likely rigged in his favor. mubarak, a former military man, had vast resources and lacked scruple, making it difficult for challengers to compete. since his resignation in 2011, the military, in the form of the supreme council of the armed forces (scaf), has continued to control the country, while overseeing democratic elections. scaf has pledged to hand over power to a civilian president by the end of june. in the upcoming presidential election, voters can choose between candidates representing the status quo, like amr moussa and ahmed shafik, or a new islamic order, with the muslim brotherhood's mohamed morsi and abdelmonem abul fotoh as options. the military and establishment are wary of an islamist victory and have expressed concerns about the potential for violence and instability if the brotherhood comes to power. gamal, a bank clerk, and ashour darwish, a farmer, express their support for the muslim brotherhood due to their promises of improving the healthcare and education systems, and addressing the plight of the poor. the brotherhood's political wing, the freedom and justice party, has gained significant power since being allowed to operate freely following the revolution, raising concerns about the potential for an islamist takeover of both the legislative and executive branches, which many view as a risk for egypt's future. polls show that a significant number of egyptians are undecided about their choice in the election.
87	two notorious terrorists, omar hammami from the us and habib ghani from the uk, have been reportedly killed in a gun battle in somalia. hammami, also known as "al-amriki," joined al-shabab in 2006 and had been on the run since falling out with the group's commanders. ghani, known locally as sheikh towfiq, was a british bomb-maker and had been hiding with samantha lewthwaite, the "white widow" and wife of 7/7 london bomber jermaine lindsay, since 2011. ghani had allegedly been working with lewthwaite for several years. both hammami and ghani were believed to have been killed by al-shabab gunmen who had been laying in wait for them in a village. hammami, who made jihadi rap videos and was on the fbi's most wanted list, and ghani were associates of somali islamist sheikh hassan dahir aweys, who split from al-shabab in june, and had been hunted down by the group since then. ghani was born in the uk to a pakistani father and a kenyan mother and had reportedly gained bomb-making experience in pakistan before fleeing to somalia. the bodies of the two terrorists were reportedly dragged away by rebels after the attack. samantha lewthwaite is still at large and is believed to be a vital conduit between al qaeda groups in pakistan and east africa.
88	health secretary kathleen sebelius stated that repairs to the troubled obamacare website are "on track" and the user experience will significantly improve by the end of november, according to a conference call with state and local officials. the website's capacity has been increased, allowing for 50,000 concurrent users, and the administration is working to address previous issues. despite this, enrollment figures have been lower than expected, with just over 200,000 people signed up for new private insurance through obamacare and over 370,000 for medicaid. sebelius urged officials to continue spreading information in their communities to help people enroll. additionally, house speaker john boehner announced he signed up for obamacare with the help of government assistance, but specifics were not provided. republicans continue to criticize the law, particularly regarding cancelled insurance policies and perceived lies from the administration. the supreme court is set to hear a case regarding obamacare and contraception coverage.
89	martin middleton, 26, pleaded guilty to causing an explosion in bolton, uk, which resulted in a man losing several fingers and the evacuation of about 40 homes. middleton, who was living with his fiancee, called emergency services and was later found unharmed. police and bomb disposal teams searched the area, and middleton's fiancee escaped uninjured. middleton had previously posted pictures of a bomb tattoo design and facial burns on his facebook page. he told friends he couldn't get the bomb tattoo due to his mother's objections. middleton is expected to be sentenced later this year and has been remanded in custody. it was revealed in court that middleton may have previously experimented with home-made explosives and suffered serious facial burns from a tennis ball bomb. the case was adjourned until june 14 for a pre-sentence and psychiatric report to be prepared. neighbors and former work colleagues described middleton as a changed person who had been a grafter but became a pain to work with. the incident occurred in january, and police and bomb disposal teams attended the scene.
90	rihanna, 23, received four grammy nominations for her song "we found love" and her album during a break from her european tour in london. she was pictured on the set of her music video for "you da one" wearing a blonde wig, bowler hat, and exaggerated bottom lashes, which drew inspiration from the film "a clockwork orange." rihanna has been credited for sparking trends with her constant fashion experiments, but this latest look felt familiar to some. she filmed the raunchy music video in a punk-provocative outfit, using a black cane as a prop. rihanna has been seeking advice from beyoncé after her intense touring schedule left her feeling overwhelmed. despite her demanding schedule, she will perform in manchester on friday and return to london for three shows before christmas.
91	the national crime agency (nca), dubbed "britain's fbi," has been rocked by allegations that two of its officers, sheila roberts and brian adair, have used their positions to unlawfully obtain sensitive information, including intelligence reports and personal files on suspects. roberts and adair, who worked on a drug-trafficking investigation, have been arrested and charged with data protection offenses. a former superintendent, glyn evans, from norfolk police, is also accused of data protection crimes and is believed to have been co-director of corporate security consultants (csc), a firm offering security to uk embassies in central america. the nca, which was launched last year to tackle serious and organized crime in the uk with a £450 million budget, has a reputation for secrecy and has arrested more than 350 people without much publicity. the allegations mark the first major controversy for the nca and come weeks after it refused to comment on the arrest of a top number 10 aide, patrick rock, who was spirited away in the middle of the night. the nca expects the highest standards of professionalism and has a zero-tolerance approach to corruption. the suspended officers are being prosecuted by the information commissioner, who enforces the data protection act. csc terminated evans' employment upon learning of the investigation.
92	megan hull and jessica brown, both mothers of three, discovered that caring for tiny rabbits helped them overcome post-natal depression. the women bonded over their love of animals and started breeding mini lionhead and mini lop rabbits as a hobby, creating bunnytales rabbit ranch. these tiny pets, measuring just five inches long and weighing 3oz, brought the pair joy and restored their mental health during their darkest times. they sell their rabbits as pets and aim to produce them in various colors. the women believe that rabbits are more intelligent than people assume, as they can be house trained, taught tricks, and even perform show jumping. through their rabbit breeding and care, megan and jessica found a release and a source of happiness.
93	a greyhound coursing event took place in county limerick, ireland, where muzzled dogs chased hares for the first prize of €80,000. one determined greyhound fixed its gaze on the quick-witted and elusive hare, which managed to evade capture despite multiple attempts by the dogs. the ancient sport, which involves letting greyhounds chase hares, is legal in ireland but has been banned in the uk since 2005. the hare has powerful reflexes and used them to stay one step ahead of the pursuing canines, causing some dogs to twist and turn in their desperate pursuit. controversy surrounds the sport, with some considering it a cruel bloodsport.
94	the justice department is considering a request from 13 states to help them acquire sodium thiopental, an anesthetic used in lethal injections which is no longer being produced in the us. the states, which include alabama, colorado, florida, and others, are facing a shortage of the drug due to ethical objections from its manufacturer and may need to look for alternatives or imports to carry out executions. the fda is allowing imports of the drug without ensuring it meets regulatory standards, leading to a federal lawsuit from death row inmates. texas, which performs the most executions in the country and is also facing a shortage, is exploring alternative drugs or sources for sodium thiopental or changing execution methods with lawmakers' approval.
95	gwyneth paltrow was recently seen carrying chanel's graffiti tote bag, worth $3,800, at jfk airport, making her the latest celebrity to be spotted with the popular 'it' bag of the season. the distressed-looking tote, which resembles an art student's tote with graffiti, handmade lanyards, and frayed edges, has been criticized for its high price tag. despite the controversy, the collection has reportedly sold out worldwide. the bag, first presented in chanel's spring 2014 collection, has been seen on various celebrities including miley cyrus, diane kruger, kristen stewart, kris jenner, and khloe kardashian. each celebrity has styled the bag differently, from understated to glam-rock. some consumers have expressed their disapproval of the bag's price and its distressed appearance, while others continue to purchase it despite the controversy.
96	cnn.com features an article about babycastles, an underground collective and gallery in brooklyn dedicated to redefining the concept of a video game arcade. founded by kunal gupta and syed salahuddin, babycastles started as a small gathering in 2009 and has since grown into a cultural hub for indie game developers, players, and fans. the cozy underground space hosts diy games, often designed by young creators from around the world, and encourages alternative approaches and rule-breaking. the games, which are often quirky and minimalist, are presented in ramshackle cabinets and are accompanied by indie music and chiptune performances. babycastles aims to create an economy for independent gaming developers outside of large studios and introduce a wider audience to the world of hobbyist game development. the collective's mission challenges the dominant culture of mass-produced console games and has faced the challenge of winning over a skeptical public. despite this, babycastles' events have gained a reputation for their raucous gatherings and diverse community.
97	teachers have been advised to be on alert for students who may be taken out of the country against their will and forced to marry strangers. up to four children a day are believed to be at risk of this during the summer holidays. a new card, titled "marriage: it's your choice," will be distributed to schools, airports, and gp surgeries to help those at risk of being abducted by their families. the card provides information and contact details for those in danger. between june and august last year, the government's forced marriage unit received over 400 reported cases, compared to 1,485 for the whole year. a new law making forced marriage illegal is currently going through parliament and is expected to become law in march next year. the number of reported cases of forced marriage in england is estimated to be between 5,000 and 8,000 a year.
98	prime minister david cameron and his wife samantha took a break from their glamorous schedule during their trip to washington d.c. to visit the national children's center, which provides services for children and adults with developmental disabilities. the center held special significance for the camerons as they had a personal connection due to their late son ivan, who was born with a rare condition causing epilepsy and cerebral palsy and passed away in 2009 at the age of six. during their visit, they met with therapists and nursing staff, spoke with families, and showed support for the children and young adults receiving care. afterward, they headed back to the white house for a state dinner.
99	peter hore, a notorious protester and disrupitder from newcastle, has been banned from attending the g20 summit in brisbane due to his history of causing trouble at public events. the 54-year-old, who is one of just two people on the g20's prohibited list, revealed he had planned to walk naked across brisbane's gateway bridge during the summit, but was unable to attend due to an outstanding arrest warrant in queensland. hore has a long history of disrupting public events, including interrupting the melbourne cup and cricket matches, as well as appearing at high-profile funerals and watch houses. he was also arrested for storming a corruption hearing at the independent commission against corruption in sydney earlier this year and charged with assisting asylum seekers to escape from the woomera detention centre in 2002. despite denying any plans to protest at the g20, hore has a long history of courting media attention and has been dismissed as an "imbecile" and "criminal" by law enforcement officials.
100	a former north korean spy named won jeong-hwa, who used to steal sex secrets for kim jong-il, now lives on government benefits in south korea as nobody will employ her due to her past. despite some former spies finding success in the south, won has faced discrimination and been fired from various jobs after her past was discovered. she has struggled to adjust to life in the south and has been ostracized by society due to the sexual nature of her crimes and her controversial past. despite her claims of being a highly trained spy, there are doubts about her elite status, and some believe she was merely an informant. she was imprisoned in 2008 for using sex to extract secrets and plotting assassinations but now regrets her actions and wishes to start anew. however, she feels trapped in south korea, unable to find work or support herself and her daughter.
101	forty-seven republican senators blocked a vote on the paycheck fairness act, an legislation aiming to address pay discrimination against women. the paycheck fairness act is a non-partisan issue, and the story of terri kelly, a woman from kentucky who experienced significant pay disparity despite her excellent performance and negotiations, illustrates this. kelly, a long-time republican, testified in support of the bill and shared her personal experience of discovering her husband's higher salary through coincidence. proving pay disparities and winning a lawsuit for the affected women, including kelly, took years, involving numerous lawyers and substantial expenses. the absence of transparency and accountability in compensation practices can leave women uncertain about their own fairness. instances of women being unaware of underpayment were shared during the litigation process, revealing gaps even in companies that appeared to offer equal opportunities. the paycheck fairness act would shift power to employees by simplifying the process of sharing pay information and combating unfair practices. the consequences of gender pay gaps are widespread, with potential solutions including lower poverty rates and a larger gdp. the republican party's opposition to the bill was criticized for prioritizing corporate profits over american families, urging working women and men to push for its adoption or to elect supportive candidates.
102	scientists have identified radon gas from nearby uranium mines as the cause of a mysterious sleeping disorder affecting residents in the remote kazakhstan village of kalachi. the colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas seeped to the surface from open spaces left by the mines, and prolonged exposure is known to cause lung cancer. despite low radiation levels in the mines themselves, the villagers have been affected, with around one in five people displaying symptoms such as dizziness, fatigue, and memory problems. local officials are considering relocating the village due to the impossible task of eradicating the radon gas. radon is present in most air, but high levels can lead to lung cancer, and some believe it may also increase the risk of leukemia. symptoms include excessive fluid in the brain and a sweet smell detected in mineshafts. past residents of a nearby closed uranium mining town, krasnogorsk, have allegedly claimed to detect high radiation levels and toxic waste in the area. the soviet-era mines are thought to have left a deadly legacy for the village of kalachi.
103	intense monsoon rains in northwestern pakistan have devastated the regions of swat valley, punjab, and sindh, affecting 3 million people and resulting in the death of at least 1,500 people, officials said. the destruction caused by the flooding includes the demolition of thousands of homes and countless bridges, leaving behind bloated rivers and flooded neighborhoods. while some areas, such as parts of northwestern pakistan, saw a respite from the rains on thursday, others remained under heavy downpour. many areas also face challenges in accessing safe drinking water and electricity due to the destruction. us secretary of state hillary clinton and pakistani prime minister yousuf raza gilani have urged for aid and donations to help those affected by the disaster.
104	maureen fleming, a 63-year-old scottish grandmother diagnosed with bowel cancer six years ago, is being forced to consider moving to england to receive life-prolonging cancer treatment not available to her in scotland. the drug, cetuximab, is free in england but costs about £3,000 a month in scotland. first minister alex salmond explained that the decision to restrict its use was made as a result of an application by the drugs company. the couple, who have ten grandchildren and have contributed to the nhs for decades, have approached local msp jackie baillie for six months but feel let down by the nhs. labor leader johann lamont raised their case during a debate at holyrood, describing them as "health refugees." salmond argued that not every treatment could be approved for use on the nhs and criticism of him by fleming was unjustified. the couple, who have exhausted their savings, have started searching for suitable rented accommodation in newcastle to relocate and receive the drug for free. a spokesman for salmond later criticized the assertion that painkillers are freely available in scotland while cancer treatment is denied. baillie stated that her party would find the funds to offer more cancer drugs to patients.
105	castambul castle, a modern medieval-style residence, was built in 2008 in rural australia despite being designed to resemble a 400-year-old european castle. the property in paracombe, near adelaide, is nestled in a valley and features seven bedrooms, turrets, gargoyles, ornate furnishings, and a lift. construction took eight years due to the intricate details, including hand-painted ceilings with gold trim and intricate diamond and ruby chandeliers. the rooms have unique themes, such as one with images of the castle and valley. no expense was spared in creating a luxurious, decadent living experience, including a wine cellar, a library, and a home cinema. the castle is surrounded by 60 acres of land and boasts a marble and gold-detailed kitchen, hand-carved furniture, and chandeliers throughout. the castle also offers modern sophistication, such as a home cinema, a television in the master bedroom's ensuite, and a swimming dam. the property is currently for sale for the first time and is a unique, luxurious lifestyle unlike anything one has ever experienced.
106	a bountiful cherry harvest is underway in kent and herefordshire, with trees heavily laden with deep red fruit and pickers working long hours to keep up with demand. the yield is expected to reach £20 million, a significant increase from the £7.5 million in 2012, due to the ideal weather conditions and a resurgence of interest in british produce following campaigns to revive cherry farming. the neaves family farm in kent, which was mostly devoted to apple and pear cultivation in the past, has seen its cherry crop surge from 30 acres to 85 acres, using the gisela dwarf rootstock and adopting modern farming practices from european growers. the season is set to last longer than ever, and the cherries are larger and sweeter than the heritage varieties once sold by the roadside.
107	a bipartisan deal on immigration reform is gaining momentum in the senate, but house gop opposition remains a significant hurdle to passing a bill. the failure of the farm bill in the house, which exposed deep divisions within the party, underscores the challenges house speaker john boehner faces in navigating the contentious issue through the house. boehner has compared immigration reform to obamacare and emphasized the need for bipartisan support and strong border security. house judiciary committee chairman bob goodlatte wants a focus on interior enforcement programs and a step-by-step approach. republican opposition to a path to citizenship and skepticism towards democratic commitment to passing a bill adds to the complexity of the situation. the senate could pass its comprehensive bill before july 4, while the house is considering more narrow proposals on enforcement and security. the urgent need to address the country's debt limit in the fall complicates the timeline for immigration reform in the house. vice president joe biden has urged a final push for immigration reform.
108	a photograph of a mother, ariane grabill, cuddling her three-year-old son, aiden, who had battled kidney cancer, went viral on facebook. aiden has since turned five and is cancer-free. the poignant image was taken during a family vacation in florida when aiden was undergoing grueling chemotherapy and radiotherapy. the photo touched the hearts of many parents going through similar experiences and inspired thousands of messages of support. ariane and her husband, zach, have since become advocates for childhood cancer awareness and are now board members of the ask childhood cancer foundation. the image's popularity can be attributed to the fact that people can project their own feelings onto the situation and see the mother's love.
109	the bbc has spent approximately £11 million on relocating 850 staff from london to its new £1 billion headquarters in salford. this includes one-time payouts worth 10% of their salary and coverage of moving costs. an additional 1,000 staff will relocate in the future, increasing costs. some high-profile presenters, including susanna reid and bill turnbull, have taken advantage of the "assisted relocation" package. the bbc is also helping staff sell their houses and covering moving costs, totaling an additional £621,000. a conservative mp criticized the move as expensive and unnecessary, as the programming from salford is not deemed as good as london's. so far, 170 staff have used the relocation package, 174 have used the remote location allowance, and 25 have sold their houses through the scheme. a bbc spokesman defended the move, claiming it is delivering value for money and positively contributing to the regional economy.
110	nick clegg, the liberal democrat leader, admitted setting fire to rare cacti belonging to a german judge during a school trip to munich in 1983. he described the incident as a "very bad thing" he was not proud of and an example of "rare anti-europeanism." after getting drunk, clegg and his friend tom browne caused damage to several cacti in the judge's conservatory. the incident resulted in penance, including community service and missed opportunities for sightseeing. clegg hinted he might not block a eu membership referendum in the event of a future coalition government, focusing instead on other priorities like fairer taxes.
111	former british prime minister tony blair, currently serving as middle east envoy, spoke at the united nations and addressed the threat of militant islamist ideology, stating it is "insidious and venomous but difficult to beat." he emphasized the need to put religion in politics' proper place to combat terrorists who "fight without hesitation, kill without mercy, and die without regret." blair expressed concern over the spread of extremism in various parts of the world, including the middle east and emphasized that 'unless we are educating people to a tolerant and open-minded approach,' the problem will persist. he warned that while the death of osama bin laden didn't put an end to the ideology and welcomed the un's potential resolution on eliminating syria's chemical weapons, he stressed that "a threat of firm action from the west" is needed to end the syrian crisis. finally, blair declined to comment on damian mcbride's briefings against labour party members.
112	bob collins, a london-born photojournalist, is known for his candid black and white photographs capturing 30 years of life in the city. his career began as an amateur photographer while he was still a watchmaker in covent garden. he rose to fame for his depictions of celebrities like shirley bassey and tony hancock, but also chronicled everyday scenes of london life, from markets and protests to royal events. after the ill-fated tv mirror magazine went bankrupt, collins continued his work on the streets of london until his death in 2002 at the age of 78. an exhibition at the museum of london showcases 50 of his most treasured scenes of london life, including speakers' corner, the changing of the guard, and the evening rush hour crowds. collins' style was candid and he often worked without his subjects noticing him. he adopted techniques such as slow shutter speeds to add depth to his images. born in london's east end, collins never married or had children, and was wedded to his job. he was inspired by the work of henri cartier-bresson and took rolls and rolls of film. the exhibition includes his contact sheets, shedding light on his methods. collins served in the second world war but was injured by a land mine, which he later described as a blessing in disguise. his photographs are going on show at the museum of london, which has an estimated 150,000 photos in its collection.
113	dominic solanke, a 17-year-old striker, made his chelsea debut in the champions league match against maribor, replacing oscar. solanke, who only turned 17 a month prior, has been at the club since 2004 and has already played for the under-21s and in the uefa youth league. he led the fa youth cup team with 18 goals last year and scored the winner for england's under-18s against holland a month prior. solanke, who is eligible to play for nigeria due to his father's nationality, came on with 17 minutes remaining as chelsea were winning 4-0.
114	behrang safari, the basle defender involved in lazar markovic's red card during liverpool's champions league exit, has denied accusations of diving and insisted he was actually bleeding from the mouth after the incident. markovic was sent off for flailing his arm towards safari's face, but contact was minimal and safari claimed he didn't realize he had been sent off until surrounded by angry liverpool players. liverpool manager brendan rodgers disagreed with the referee's decision, with liverpool eventually drawing 1-1 and missing out on the last 16.
115	the october issue of martha stewart living and the martha stewart halloween special edition are currently available on newsstands. the halloween issue provides tips for hosting a pumpkin carving party, including pumpkin selection, carving techniques, and invasion templates. the magazine also features kitchen shortcuts, perfect laundry methods, and efficient cleaning tips. for the pumpkin carving party, martha stewart suggests selecting smooth, firm, symmetrical pumpkins. carving designs require careful planning and the use of various tools, while protecting surfaces is essential. additionally, the magazine offers ideas for no-mess desserts and party menu suggestions, such as sage popcorn, mac and cheese, hot whiskey sour, and sweet-potato soup. halloween-themed party favors and a curated selection of pumpkin seed crafts and recipes are also included. the issue closes with an article on curbing food cravings with yoga.
116	authorities in tennessee are seeking the public's help to find two children, 9-year-old chloie leverette and 7-year-old gage daniel, who were last seen around 6:30 p.m. on sunday before their home in unionville burned down. the children have been missing for over a week, and investigators have been unable to find evidence that they were inside the home during the fire. the grandparents' bodies were recovered, but no cause of the blaze has been determined. the biological parents have been contacted and are cooperating. chloie is described as a 4-foot-8, 75-pound girl with brown hair and blue eyes, while gage is a 4-foot-5, 50-pound boy with brown hair and eyes. authorities consider the children endangered and fear for their safety. community members have set up a vigil at unionville elementary school, where the children attended, in support of their family. the search of the home has been concluded.
117	nigella lawson, the tv chef, returned to twitter two months after a public dispute with her husband, charles saatchi, by sharing a photo of a victoria sponge cake she made to celebrate the return of "the great british bake off." she made no mention of the controversy or her impending divorce. saatchi, an advertising mogul, has repeatedly spoken out about the incident, while lawson has remained silent despite public appearances to move her belongings out of their shared home. the great british bake off, which started its fourth series last night on bbc2, has also been involved in a love spat as presenter paul hollywood left his wife for a colleague. saatchi initially dismissed the fight as a "playful tiff," but later announced his divorce from lawson, who filed the papers. the couple married in 2003 following lawson's first husband's death. lawson's teenage stepdaughter has accused lawson of abandoning her, while friends of saatchi suggest he is nursing suicidal thoughts. lawson's tweet drew a response from the official qi account regarding elizabethan ladies keeping apple slices under their armpits. lawson had previously tweeted only once since the scandal, sharing a photo of her son's birthday cake without comment.
118	on the anniversary of joe paterno's death, around 40 fans braved single-digit temperatures to visit a mural of the penn state university football coach in state college, pennsylvania. paterno, who died in 2012 at age 85 due to lung cancer and a broken pelvis, held the all-time record for major college football victories at 409 before being stripped of 111 wins due to his ties to the jerry sandusky child molestation scandal. sandusky, a former penn state defensive coordinator, was arrested in 2011, and a graduate assistant had reported allegations of his abuse to paterno years prior. however, the university's handling of the situation resulted in paterno's firing, and he expressed regret for not handling the situation differently in an interview before his death. sandusky was convicted and sentenced to 30-60 years in prison on 45 counts of child sex abuse, and the mural was altered to reflect the controversy, with sandusky's image removed and paterno's halo taken down.
119	a photo of marine veteran jon hammar, who was held captive in mexico's matamoros state prison for four months, has been released. the photo shows hammar, 27, in a solitary cell with shackles on his ankle, a thin mattress, and a red blanket. his mother, olivia hammar, described his appearance as "lost" and expressed concern for his well-being. hammar was arrested in august when he was impounded at the border for carrying a shotgun, which mexican authorities deemed to be illegal. hammar and a friend were on their way to costa rica when they were detained. hammar served in iraq and afghanistan before being honorably discharged from the marines in 2007 and had a surfing trip planned to help him cope with ptsd. he could face 12 years in prison but is now fighting to have the charges downgraded. the mexican embassy stated that mexican law prohibits civilians from carrying certain types of guns, and hammar's family believes u.s. officials gave incorrect advice about bringing the gun across the border. hammar has been held in matamoros, which is known for its cartel activity and prison violence. the family has received death threats and extortion demands, but hammar is currently in a private cell to protect him from the cartels. supporters have set up a facebook page to rally for hammar's release. mexican officials have granted hammar consular assistance, and u.s. officials have visited him three times to ensure his safety. united states senator bill nelson and representative ileana ros-lehtinen have spoken out about the case and urged mexican authorities to release hammar.
120	in newtown, connecticut, nancy lanza was described as a friendly and outgoing woman who raised her quiet and socially awkward son, adam lanza. while she grew up shooting in new hampshire, she was responsible with the guns she collected. the circumstances surrounding how adam obtained the guns used in the sandy hook elementary school massacre remain unclear. authorities believe nancy was shot and killed by her son before the attack. neighbors described her as a "nice, normal family" who lived in a wealthy area with a big yard and huge homes. her ex-husband, peter lanza, paid her significant alimony and was responsible for adam's education. friends and acquaintances recalled nancy as social, charitable, and warm, often volunteering for people with aids and giving generously to those in need. she and her boys, including adam, frequently went target shooting for self-defense. nancy did not show any signs of fear or threat, despite owning a substantial collection of weapons. despite concerns about adam's social skills and potential isolation, nancy reportedly tried to mainstream him and bring him out of his shell. neighbors were shocked and devastated by the massacre, as they knew nancy as a responsible and kind woman. the three weapons found at the scene were legally purchased by nancy. friends and neighbors are struggling to understand how someone they knew could commit such a horrific act.
121	in this essay, buzz aldrin, the second man to walk on the moon during the historic apollo 11 mission in 1969, reflects on the 45th anniversary of the lunar landing and the need for continued space exploration. he describes the awe-inspiring experience of standing on the lunar surface and the connection to earth and humanity. aldrin emphasizes the importance of teamwork and collaboration in making the moon landing possible and calls for international and commercial partnerships to explore and develop the moon and, ultimately, establish a human presence on mars. he believes that america's future in deep space exploration lies in a bold commitment to a permanent presence on mars and invites the next generation of explorers to take up the challenge.
122	ray rodda, a 61-year-old retired graphic designer from sunderland, is losing his voice due to throat cancer and will have his voice box removed. to communicate with his family and beloved dog daisy, rodda has recorded messages on an ipad, including commands for daisy and greetings for his loved ones. the family is hopeful that the operation to remove his voice box, tongue, and glands in his throat will save his life, and rodda will use the ipad to speak after the surgery. rodda is keeping a positive attitude and will be able to teach daisy tricks and greet his family with his recorded voice. his daughter emma is raising funds for the northern centre for cancer care in newcastle where rodda received treatment.
123	a judge sentenced self-help expert james arthur ray to two years in prison for his role in the deaths of three people during a 2009 sweat lodge ceremony in arizona. prosecutors sought consecutive three-year sentences for negligent homicide but were denied. the victims were kirby brown, james shore, and lizbeth marie neuman, who suffered dehydration and heatstroke due to the perilously high temperature inside the lodge, which was heated with rocks and covered with tarps and blankets.ray did not monitor the temperature or the well-being of participants, disregarding those in distress, according to the prosecution. however, ray's attorneys argued for probation, stating it was a tragedy and not a crime. they claimed participants had signed waivers and suggested an unknown toxin in the lodge could have been the cause of death. ray tearfully addressed the court, accepting responsibility but also expressing remorse. in the end, the judge ordered concurrent sentences, stating the evidence showed "extreme negligence" on ray's part. relatives of the victims urged the maximum sentence possible, expressing deep grief and feeling that ray hadn't shown sufficient remorse.
124	tennessee whiskey must be fermented in tennessee with at least 51% corn, aged in new charred oak barrels, filtered through maple charcoal, and bottled at 80 proof to be labeled as such, according to a year-old state law. jack daniel's, the world's best-known tennessee whiskey, opposes a proposed change in the law that would allow distilleries to reuse barrels, arguing it would weaken the label and stifle competition. diageo, which owns george dickel, a rival tennessee whiskey producer, supports the change and accuses brown-forman, jack daniel's parent company, of trying to monopolize the title. the law's strict regulations are similar to those for bourbon, which is also made primarily from corn and aged in new oak barrels. the ongoing debate reflects the growing competition and commercial significance of the american whiskey industry.
125	a tennessee woman, catherine goins, 37, has been charged with murder for allegedly luring a young mother, natalia roberts, 30, from georgia to her death in a twisted plot to kidnap her two children and pass them off as her own. goins had pretended to be pregnant and claimed she had shot an intruder inside her ex-boyfriend's home in lafayette, georgia, on friday, but investigators discovered it was a lie, concocted to cover up the abduction plan. goins met roberts and lured her to the home under the pretext of giving her baby clothes. upon her arrival, goins allegedly shot roberts in the back of the head and took off with her two children, aged 3 and 3-weeks-old. when tony richards, the former paramour, returned home, he discovered roberts' lifeless body and contacted goins, who was later arrested in tennessee on charges of malice murder, felony murder, tampering with evidence, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime. roberts' children are currently with family members.
126	the uk government's plan to introduce a £26,000 annual cap on benefits is facing opposition from labour, church of england bishops, and rebel liberal democrats. the bishop of ripon and leeds tabled an amendment to exclude child benefit payments from the £500-a-week limit, which labour plans to support in a crucial vote on amendments to the welfare reform bill. iain duncan smith, the work and pensions secretary, described the amendment as "wrecking" and accused labour of inconsistency on the issue. the housing benefit bill is projected to rise by £4 billion over four years, with the government saving £2 billion a year and the previous labour government having doubled housing benefit. the cap would affect around 20,000 people, and homelessness is a concern. the debate trended on twitter, with criticism over the level being set at £26,000 and potential increases in homelessness. david cameron defended the cap as a fairness issue and promised a £35,000 equivalent wage was a good salary. the opposition's position was criticized for being ill-conceived. the centre for social justice think tank, founded by duncan smith, welcomed the reform as helping tackle child poverty and giving young people the chance to make something of their lives.
127	a sculpture of jesus as a homeless man sleeping on a bench outside st. alban's episcopal church in davidson, north carolina, has sparked controversy among residents. the bronze sculpture, titled "homeless jesus," was gifted to the church in honor of a deceased member and has been approved by pope francis at the vatican. reverend david buck, the rector at st. alban's, sees it as a reminder for christians to help the homeless and eliminate poverty. however, some residents, like cindy castano swannack, feel that the sculpture does not accurately represent jesus and portrays him as a helpless person. the artwork, depicting jesus with visible scars from the cross, costs up to $2,975 and is interactive, allowing people to sit next to it. pope francis has praised the sculpture and there are no plans to remove it from the church.
128	britain is experiencing an autumnal weekend with trees changing color and temperatures averaging 3 degrees above normal at 17 degrees celsius. however, the country is also bracing for rain, with up to 60mm expected in some areas such as tayside, scotland, and northern ireland. while the south east will see light rain, the north will experience heavier showers. the mild weather is expected to continue through sunday, with temperatures dropping slightly to around 16 or 17 degrees celsius in london, east anglia, and the south east. the north is expected to see more rain. autumn colors are emerging at national trust properties such as stourhead in wiltshire, with a spectacular display of leaves in red, green, and yellow. the weather will bring a light breeze, reaching up to 30mph in the south west, and occasional sunshine. wet weather and fog are expected in some areas, with lightning strikes in others.
129	al-qaeda in the islamic maghreb (aqim), al-jazeera reported, claimed responsibility for last week's kidnapping of five french nationals in niger. the spokesman for aqim, salah abou mohammed, made the announcement in an audio recording aired by al-jazeera, but cnn was unable to independently confirm the report. the hostages worked for french nuclear energy company areva and its subcontractor vinci. seven people were kidnapped in total, including an areva employee and his wife. it is unclear whether aqim also claimed responsibility for the other two hostages, who are not identified in the reports. niger is one of the poorest countries in the world, and areva has been mining uranium there for decades. aqim warned the french government against hasty actions in response to the kidnapping.
130	james murdoch testified before the leveson inquiry into press ethics, insisting he had little knowledge of the extent of phone hacking at the news of the world when he took over the british newspaper publishing arm of news corp. in 2007. former employees claimed they had informed him about the issue, but murdoch stated that they didn't want him to take action. murdoch also revealed deep connections between the murdoch family and british politicians, as well as a backchannel between government minister jeremy hunt's office and news corp. executives. the leveson inquiry has been investigating phone hacking, which has led to dozens of arrests and compensation payouts to victims, including celebrities, politicians, crime victims, and war veterans. rupert murdoch, the media mogul, will testify on wednesday and thursday, and several people have been arrested in connection to phone, e-mail hacking, and police bribery investigations. no charges have been filed yet. news corp. shut down the news of the world in 2011 after public outrage over the scale of illegal eavesdropping. the british government established the inquiry following the phone-hacking scandal, and parliamentary committees are also investigating media conduct. rupert and james murdoch have resigned from various management positions at british subsidiaries of their media empire, but both have denied knowing about the extent of phone hacking. clive goodman, the journalist who went to prison for phone hacking in 2007, was reportedly saying that phone-hacking went beyond his case, but murdoch was unaware of that at the time. the british lawyer representing several alleged phone-hacking victims is exploring potential cases against news corp. in the us.
131	diego simeone, the atletico madrid manager, has been charged with improper conduct by uefa after storming onto the field during the champions league final against real madrid to confront raphael varane. simeone was angered by varane celebrating real's fourth goal by kicking the ball towards him. xabi alonso, a suspended real madrid midfielder, has also been charged with improper conduct for joining his teammates in celebrating gareth bale's winning goal. both teams were also charged for receiving more than five yellow cards each during the match.
132	lincolnshire county council has spent £42,000 over six years on taxis to transport customer service workers 524ft across the river witham, citing safety concerns during winter months. the council defended its decision, claiming staff raised concerns about walking in the dark; however, reports indicate no serious incidents have occurred. critics argue it's an unnecessary expense and that employers should encourage employees to take responsibility for their safety. the council has also faced criticism for spending taxpayers' money on using modern chart songs as hold music, which has reduced hanging up calls but requires royalty payments.
133	the church of england has approved women bishops after a tense and historic vote at the general synod in york, ending 14 years of debates and disagreements. the move was welcomed by archbishop justin welby and most bishops but opposed by traditionalists, particularly anglo-catholics and conservative evangelicals. the compromise plan includes provisions for those opposed to women bishops, such as the ability to send resolutions to the bishop requesting male clergy, and an appeals system. the first female bishop is expected to be appointed early next year. conservatives argue that the bible and tradition do not permit women in these roles, while liberals believe in gender equality and have pressed for change. the debate over female bishops has been ongoing since women were ordained as priests 20 years ago. the vote overturned centuries of tradition and marks a significant moment for the church of england.
134	a government agency ordered the opening of sluice gates at a dam in kent, uk, to protect shops and businesses in tonbridge from flooding, but the resulting surge of water deluged the nearby village of yalding and flooded over 1,300 properties in the region. villagers claimed they were given only six minutes warning and were angered that their homes were sacrificed to save businesses. some flooding risks remain in southern england, with another storm approaching, and financial assistance has been promised to affected local authorities.
135	the summer break in america is cherished for its relaxation and opportunities for exploration, particularly for children. however, research shows that for low-income students, the long summer break contributes to the widening achievement gap between them and their more affluent peers, a gap that persists into adulthood. this issue, known as the "summer slide," can be addressed by extending the school year, as proven by schools like balsz elementary in phoenix and brooklyn generation school in new york. while there are challenges, such as the additional costs and resistance to change, the benefits for students' academic progress and future opportunities make the investment worthwhile. additionally, the notion that summer should be a time of relaxation for students is misguided, as many students from low-income families face boredom and lack of enriching experiences during summer vacation. instead, educators can use the longer school year to enhance the learning experience with hands-on activities, collaboration, and inquiry-based learning.
136	on new year's eve 2012, in the uk, south korean rapper psy's "gangnam style" became the most sung song on karaoke service lucky voice, surpassing the traditional new year's favorite "auld lang syne" by scottish poet robert burns. "gangnam style" accounted for 23% of the 100,000 songs sung that night, with auld lang syne accounting for only 4.5%. other popular choices included "someone like you" by adele and "call me maybe" by carly rae jepsen. the shift in preference signaled a departure from the usual traditions.
137	dean obeidallah expresses his feelings of guilt and discontentment with his long-term relationship with his iphone. he recalls the excitement and passion he had for the device when they first met in 2007, but now, with the release of the new iphone 5, he finds himself feeling pity instead of excitement. he acknowledges that the iphone has been loyal and hardworking, but he has started to explore other options, such as the samsung galaxy. he notes that he will honor his contract but is unsure if he will stay committed once it expires. he reflects on the impact the iphone had on his life and expresses his gratitude for its role in introducing him to the capabilities of smartphones.
138	the oscar pistorius trial in south africa is pending a ruling from judge thokozile masipa on whether the double-amputee athlete should undergo psychiatric tests. his lawyer, barry roux, claimedthat pistoriushas an anxiety disorder linked to his disability, which could delay the trial. prosecutor gerrie nel asked for the evaluation and judge masipa ordered an adjournment to rule on the request on wednesday. the psychiatrist, merryll vorster, testified that the disorder may have played a role in the fatal shooting of his girlfriend reeva steenkamp in 2013. nel suggested that the defense is trying to use the disorder as an excuse for pistorius' actions and to reduce his responsibility for her death. pistorius claims he mistook steenkamp for an intruder when he shot her through a closed toilet door, while prosecutors argue it was an angry response to an argument. the trial, which began on march 3, may be delayed due to the evaluation.
139	a new york city special education teacher, evelyn rogers, 34, received ten years of probation after admitting to having sex with a 15-year-old boy at least four times in her car outside of school. despite objections from prosecutors who argued for jail time, judge elizabeth foley decided against imprisonment. rogers taught at high school for innovation in advertising and media in canarsie, brooklyn. authorities would not reveal if the victim was a student or one of her students. rogers faced a maximum of 16 years in prison but received leniency. prosecutors cited a previous case involving a 'horndog high' teacher, erin sayar, who received probation for a similar charge but was granted leniency due to fighting cancer at the time. rogers must forfeit her teaching license and register as a sex offender.
140	a magnitude 7.4 earthquake occurred off el salvador's coast late sunday, according to the usgs. the epicenter was located 177 km (110 miles) southeast of san salvador, about 33 miles underground. some minor shaking was felt, but no damage or injuries were reported initially. a tsunami warning was issued for el salvador and neighboring countries including costa rica, nicaragua, honduras, guatemala, panama, and mexico. a small tsunami wave measuring about 10 cm (4 inches) was recorded in acajutla, el salvador. the country experiences frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions due to its location on the ring of fire.
141	petra kvitova, currently sixth on the wta leaderboard, discussed her sporting idol martina navratilova, her desire to be ice hockey legend jaromir jagr, and her career highlights and lowpoints in an interview with sportsmail's mike dickson. she named winning wimbledon twice as her highlight and losing in the first round of the australian open this year as her worst moment. if her house were burning down, she would save her passport or phone. her favorite possession. navratilova's advice to "treat it like any other match" before her first wimbledon final was the best advice she received. her least-favorite activity is karaoke, and her three most-listened-to songs on her ipod are "am i wrong" by nico and vinz, "rip tight" by vince joy, and "budapest" by ezra. she went out of the us open in the third round in 2014. her favorite pre-match meal is plain rice or pasta with parmesan cheese, and while she cannot cook, she enjoys sushi. she went on holiday to the maldives to play tennis with richard branson and her favorite holiday destination is anywhere with a beach. cameron diaz would play her in a film of her life, and the most expensive thing she bought was earrings after winning wimbledon this year. she admitted her room is untidy when she stays in hotels, even though it's better when she's at home.
142	a video documented the sudden rebirth of israel's zin river after a prolonged drought, as floodwaters from heavy rainfall in distant mountainous regions filled the dry riverbed in the negev desert. the two-minute video, recorded by omri ginzburg and gilad zwebner, showcased the dramatic spectacle of floodwaters gushing over a cliff, eliciting delight from onlookers. the zin river's source is located on the slopes of the ramon crater, one of three prominent negev craters, and is described in the old testament of the bible. the river, approximately 50 miles south of beersheba and ending in the dead sea, originates from the peak of mount negev, and its landscape is characterized by canyons, winding paths, and small waterfalls. the ramon crater, 24 miles long, up to six miles wide, and up to 1,640ft deep, resembles an elongated heart.
143	a group of mothers staged a mass breastfeed protest outside claridge's hotel in london in response to a staff member asking a woman to cover up while breastfeeding. around 40 mothers participated in the protest, organized by the group free to feed, which aims to normalize public breastfeeding. ukip leader nigel farage weighed in on the issue, suggesting mothers could "sit in the corner" to avoid offending people. however, his comments were met with backlash, with many arguing that breastfeeding is a natural and necessary process for mothers and babies. the equality act of 2010 makes it unlawful for businesses to discriminate against breastfeeding women. claridge's has said it "embraces" breastfeeding but requests discreetness towards other guests. the protest came after louise burns complained that she was asked to cover her baby's head with a napkin while breastfeeding in the hotel restaurant. downing street and shadow home secretary yvette cooper also expressed support for breastfeeding mothers and disagreement with farage's comments.
144	a judge in iowa has ruled that a mother serving life in prison for murder, tracey richter, must be allowed to have regular visits with her two minor children, despite the objections of their father, michael roberts, who wants to move to australia with them. the visits are intended to preserve richter's unique relationship with her children, who were present during the execution-style killing of her neighbor, dustin wehde, in 2001. richter had held sole custody of the children for ten years before her arrest and conviction for the murder in 2011. the judge's ruling allows roberts to disclose their new address in california so richter can send them mail, including tapes of her reading them books, and grants her 30-minute phone conversations on the children's birthdays. roberts' attorney is considering appealing the decision or exploring settlement options that would allow the family to move to australia, where he has employment opportunities and family support. the prosecutor, ben smith, expressed concern for the children's well-being and questioned richter's parenting abilities, given that she had executed her neighbor in front of them.
145	republicans and democrats in the us congress unveiled a $1 trillion spending deal on monday, ending three years of budget impasse and funding the government through september. the bipartisan bill includes a 1% increase in federal worker pay, protection of veterans' pensions, and funding for priority programs in education, mental health, and national security. for republicans, there are cuts to the irs and epa budgets, and new tsa policies to expedite airport security checks. the bill also includes controversial provisions such as stopping the implementation of new light-bulb standards and requiring certifications regarding the benghazi attack before libya can receive foreign aid. the house aims to pass the measure this week before the current bill expires.
146	a british company, seymourpowell, has developed adjustable plane seats called "morph" that can be customized to fit passenger shapes and sizes. this innovation aims to improve comfort for larger passengers without charging them extra or requiring them to move to business class. families can also enjoy more space as parents can expand their seats while smaller children can have smaller ones. the morph seat design uses a fabric hammock stretched over a frame and adjustable formers for recline, height, depth, and width, ensuring comfort without reducing legroom. the concept has attracted attention from plane manufacturers and promises to provide tailored seats for individual comfort, privacy, or other specific needs. however, it may take more than a decade before these seats are introduced in commercial aircraft, as they'll likely need to be custom-built. additionally, airlines have already adopted seating plans offering increased comfort, such as air new zealand's skycouches and airbus' expanded aisle seats. some experts suggest policies like "fat taxes" or customized pricing based on passenger size could be implemented in the future to accommodate larger passengers.
147	comedian stephen colbert encouraged his fans to make unnecessary edits to the wikipedia pages of possible vice presidential candidates for mitt romney as a way to sway their viability. in response, wikipedia locked the pages of several potential nominees, including tim pawlenty, rob portman, paul ryan, marco rubio, bobby jindal, and chris christie. political analysts have noted that a correlation exists between the number of recent edits to a candidate's page and their likelihood of being chosen as a vice presidential nominee. the trend began in 2008, when there was a significant increase in edits the day before sarah palin and joe biden were announced as their respective parties' vice presidential nominees. while the edit tally may not be an accurate indicator, the romney campaign has asked people to download their app for breaking news on the selection. the system has its limitations, as some edits may be made by individuals with ulterior motives, and the correlation does not account for context or the level of public scrutiny each candidate has faced prior to the potential nomination.
148	wealthy buyers purchased nearly all 220 luxury apartments, including four penthouses, in sydney's $250 million 161 clarence street development, named sydney by crown, within just four hours of its global release in sydney, jakarta, and singapore on saturday. prices for one-bedroom suites started at $826,650. the 27-story building, featuring a rooftop entertainment area, indoor pool, and gym, received over 500 attendees in sydney alone. crown group ceo iwan sunito reported it as the company's strongest launch day result in its history, with over $173.1 million in apartments sold. sydney by crown, designed by japanese-inspired architect koichi takada, launched with an overwhelming response due to the high demand for high-end properties and crown group's reputation. this success follows the quick sale of over $100 million in apartments at skye by crown in north sydney last year. the 416-apartment and 5,000sqm retail space project in green square by koichi takada's firm is currently in development.
149	a 23-year-old woman named christina morris has been missing since august 30, and authorities have arrested enrique arochi, 24, on an aggravated kidnapping charge in relation to her disappearance. arochi's bail was set at $1 million. security camera footage shows morris last being seen with arochi in a parking garage on the day she disappeared. dna evidence linked to arochi's vehicle, which was towed the day of his arrest, has been found, but police cannot yet release details. arochi previously faced charges for interfering with the investigation and is suspected of deception. authorities are seeking bodily fluids, hair, and dna evidence from his vehicle. morris' mother expressed hope for a resolution and continued worry.
150	the cummins family of virginia, consisting of ralph and carolyn and their five children: cecilia, charles, claudia, chris, and cheryl, all born on february 20 in different years, hold the guinness world record for the only verified family producing five single children with the same date of birth. the odds of this happening were estimated to be 17.7 billion to 1. carolyn, a former cake baker, ensures every february 20 their unique birthdate is recognized, making it a cherished family tradition despite the children growing up and living apart. each child's birthday cake depicted personalized themes based on their interests. the guinness world records does not display the family in every edition, so cheryl, the eldest daughter, carries a 2003 copy to prove the oddity to skeptics. the family values togetherness and celebrates with birthday phone calls and cards, as well as freezing ahead their individual cakes when they visit from college. despite catherine's claim that she "led the way," the record-holding parents, ralph and carolyn, could not be reached for comment.
151	ronn moss, who has played the role of ridge forrester on cbs' "the bold and the beautiful" since 1987, is leaving the show, and there are currently no plans to recast the character or write him off. the head writer, bradley bell, intends to focus on brooke's storyline and plans to bring ridge back at some point, although the timeline and the actor to be cast in the role have not been determined. moss' departure is considered unique and not part of a larger trend for unexpected exits.
152	the chicago bears, famous for their colorful players like "the fridge," "da coach," "sweetness," and a controversial quarterback, were invited to the white house next month to make up for a visit that was canceled 25 years ago due to the space shuttle challenger explosion. president barack obama, a native of chicago, is a big bears fan and expressed difficulty hosting their arch-rivals, the green bay packers, at the white house last year. the bears, who had a dominant 15-1 record in the 1985 season, will visit washington on october 7. the team's personalities, including coach mike ditka's midwest provincialism, added to their popularity, but they never became the dynasty many had expected. prominent bears players included quarterback jim mcmahon, lineman william "the fridge" perry, and all-time nfl rushing leader walter "sweetness" payton. in august 2011, obama jokes about the bears' loss to the packers in the nfc championship game, as they were invited to the white house to celebrate their super bowl victory.
153	approximately 4.7 million graco and century-branded strollers are being recalled due to potential fingertip amputation or laceration hazards caused by the side folding hinges. graco reported 11 incidents, including six full amputations and four partial amputations, to the u.s. consumer product safety commission. the recalled models, manufactured in china, include aspeen, breeze, capri, cirrus, glider, kite, literider, sierra, solara, sterling, and travelmate strollers and travel systems, sold at retail stores and online between 2000 and 2014 for prices ranging from $40 to $170. caregivers have been advised to exercise caution while unfolding the stroller and immediately remove children if the stroller begins to fold. a free repair kit will be available starting in december. the recall also affects around 202,000 strollers sold in canada and 10,300 in mexico. graco stated that safety is a priority and this is a voluntary recall to address the issue of hinges potentially pinching a child's finger.
154	tony kirwan, a former electrician from queensland, australia, founded destiny rescue in 2007 after being inspired by a deeply spiritual moment and a trip to cambodia. inspired by the plight of children in sex slavery in asia, kirwan has dedicated his life to rescuing them and providing them with a chance at a normal life. destiny rescue has successfully saved over 2000 children from brothels and sex slavery, with a plan to save 800 more this year. however, the rescue process is complex, as it often involves working with families and police to ensure the children's safety and future. kirwan's ultimate goal is to end child slavery and set up rescue operations in more countries, including china and india. destiny rescue provides education, employment, and emotional support to children to help them reintegrate into their communities. one such success story is srey toun, who was rescued from her abuser at the age of 15 and is now married with a small sewing business in phnom penh employing other rescued girls. kirwan envisions rescuing 100,000 children by 2020.
155	the geneva accord signed by russian foreign minister sergey lavrov on april 17 represents a major stand down by russia in the ongoing crisis in ukraine. however, given russia's past mendacity and slipperiness, the agreement is not binding and could be easily abandoned by president vladimir putin. at a press conference on the same day, putin denied the existence of ukrainians as a separate nation, claiming they are essentially russian. he also reserved the right to intervene in ukraine to defend the rights of russian-speaking citizens and hinted at armed intervention. putin's insistence on helping russian citizens in ukraine spooked ukrainians, especially with the continued massing of russian troops along ukraine's borders. the geneva agreement calls for all illegal armed groups to be disarmed and buildings and streets to be vacated, which applies mainly to the russian-supported commandos in eastern ukraine. while both the united states and ukraine have insisted that russia stick to the agreement, the response has been desultory, with some extremists abandoning buildings and others continuing their activities. it remains to be seen whether russia is serious about the agreement or if it is just a ploy to buy time while preparations for military action continue. some analysts suggest putin may have been influenced by international condemnation of russia's actions in ukraine and crimea and the potential for painful western sanctions. ultimately, the geneva accord provides a standard against which russian actions in ukraine can be measured, and the coming weeks will demonstrate whether russia is committed to de-escalation or further aggression.
156	floyd mayweather jr., an undefeated world champion boxer, was taken aback when a woman at a south london barber shop didn't recognize him. despite his attempts to convince her of his boxing fame, she remained unmoved and even questioned his biggest fight. mayweather's team argued that he was the biggest in the world, but the woman continued to challenge him, bringing up her familiarity with other high-earning athletes and usain bolt. although stunned, mayweather tried to use forbes magazine and his income as selling points, but the woman was unimpressed. the encounter left mayweather looking for comfort in the fact that she did know usain bolt. mayweather is currently on a european tour and is expected to return to the ring in may.
157	at least 14 people were killed and 60 others wounded on october 24, 2013, in batna, algeria, when a bomb exploded near a crowd waiting to see president abdelaziz bouteflika. the explosion occurred about 20 meters from a mosque and occurred 15 minutes before bouteflika's scheduled arrival. the cause of the bombing was unclear, with security officials saying a suspect person may have attempted to breach security measures but escaped immediately after the explosion. bouteflika made a stop at a hospital to visit the wounded before continuing his visit as planned. there was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, but algeria faces a continuing islamic insurgency and in july, 33 people were killed in apparent suicide bombings in algiers claimed by an al qaeda-affiliated group. bouteflika condemned the terrorist acts and stated they have nothing to do with the noble values of islam.
158	matthew quinn, 25, a repeat guest on the jeremy kyle show, is planning to sue the producers for making him look 'bad' during his most recent appearance. quinn, who has a history of domestic violence and has been engaged multiple times, went on the show to confront his ex-girlfriend laura lynskey over cheating but was instead portrayed as the villain. he claims the producers edited the footage to vilify him and wants compensation. quinn's previous girlfriends, alice peters and sonja colognori, have also accused him of physical abuse. the jeremy kyle show denies any wrongdoing and claims quinn signed a consent form and saw their aftercare team following the show.
159	the first test at lord's between england and sri lanka provided controversial moments for both sides. some saw it as a sign of the new era in test cricket, while others criticized alastair cook and the ecb. despite england's slow run-rate in their first innings and criticisms of cook's captaincy, they came close to winning the match, with stuart broad almost securing a victory. the second innings was also scrutinized, with some critics blaming cook for not declaring earlier to allow gary ballance to score a hundred. however, there were also positives, such as joe root's double-hundred and moeen ali's assured batting. there were also some misunderstandings of cricket laws, like angelo mathews' confusion over the regulation regarding a caught glove not connected to the bat handle. some criticized england's fielding and suggested they needed a proper spinner, but chris jordan and liam plunkett impressed in their debut performances. the test began with england written off as a rabble but ended with them coming within inches of a memorable win. england's new era was characterized by accommodating approaches towards their opponents and a willingness to learn from their mistakes. additionally, bangladesh's captain, mushfiqur rahim, sought to motivate his team with life coaching and a focus on playing well for the full 100 overs in odi cricket.
160	the advertising standards authority (asa) has ruled that a tv ad featuring a naked man strolling through a field with a group of naked people, promoting richmond ham, was not offensive, despite receiving 370 complaints. while the watchdog found the ad was not sexual in tone and demonstrated a "well-adjusted, comfortable, and completely non-sexual attitude to the human body," it deemed the claim that the ham was "britain's only ham made with 100% natural ingredients" misleading because the product is actually made in ireland by kerry foods. the asa concluded that the claim was likely to be interpreted as the ham being british in origin, which is not the case.
161	a muslim man identified as ahmad bashir, 57, was viciously attacked outside a mosque in flushing, queens, on sunday morning. the assailant, described as a hispanic male in his 40s, stabbed bashir in the mosque stairwell while shouting anti-muslim slurs. bashir suffered numerous stab wounds, including to his head, face, back, and leg, and was bitten on the nose. witnesses reported that the attacker fled the scene after the stabbing. the incident is being investigated as a hate crime, and bashir was later released from the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. police are currently searching for the suspect.
162	james van doren, co-founder of the iconic vans shoe brand, passed away on october 12, 2011, at the age of 72. he started the company with his brother paul in their family rubber factory in the 1960s, originally catering to the skateboarding community. vans' slip-resistant waffle sole design gained popularity due to its effectiveness on skateboards. after a significant boost from sean penn's character wearing vans checkerboard shoes in "fast times at ridgemont high" in 1982, the shoes became nationwide sensations and a staple in skateboarding culture. over the years, the company faced financial struggles from competition but later bounced back and has since been sold several times, with its current headquarters in cypress. van doren wore vans shoes daily and will be cremated with plans for a memorial mass in fullerton.
163	debenhams, a high-street retailer, has taken a significant step towards promoting body confidence by introducing size 16 mannequins in all its uk stores, making it the first mainstream retailer to do so. trialled three years ago, these mannequins will be displayed alongside size 10 models in women's fashion areas and will eventually be rolled out across all stores. the average british woman is a size 16, and debenhams aims to help consumers feel more comfortable with their bodies and inspire other retailers to follow. size diversity has been shown to boost sales, with research revealing that women are three times more likely to buy items when mannequins represent their body type. this move was backed by equalities minister jo swinson, who has advocated for body confidence and diversity in fashion advertising and media. debenhams has defied conventional fashion promotion in various ways, such as banning airbrushing in its swimwear campaigns and featuring disabled, older, and diverse models in its advertising. however, the introduction of larger mannequins has sparked controversy, with some arguing it undermines efforts to tackle obesity. debenhams responded to these concerns by emphasizing the importance of promoting body positivity and diversity in fashion.
