331	north korean officials unexpectedly allowed cnn to interview three american detainees held in the country - kenneth bae, matthew todd miller, and jeffrey edward fowle. each man had only five minutes to speak, and their statements seemed scripted. they expressed their hope that the u.s. government would send an envoy to help secure their release, similar to how former president bill clinton facilitated the freedom of two journalists in 2009. the motivation behind north korea's decision might be to negotiate for nuclear arms control or the lifting of sanctions. the detainees have confessed to their guilt, but their conditions are not independently verifiable. bae, serving a 15-year sentence at a labor camp due to allegations of a christian plot to overthrow the regime, pleaded for mercy due to his failing health. miller, accused of tearing up his visa and seeking asylum, grew frustrated over the lack of government response, and fowle, charged with leaving a bible in a hotel, described his desperate situation as his trial approached. u.s. officials have called for their release and urged north korea to grant them clemency.
332	enig hui, a petroleum engineer from miri, malaysia, has spent the past six years photographing unique underground stations from around the world as a hobby. his collection includes stations in england, vietnam, thailand, singapore, iceland, norway, denmark, czech republic, and italy. some of his favorite stations include praterstern station in vienna, which was opened in 1959 and has only one entrance due to its proximity to the vitava river, and ueno-okachimachi station in tokyo, which opened in 2000 and has four platforms with four tracks. hui believes that these underground hubs deserve a second look and wants to evoke a sense of drama in their extreme symmetry and contrast through his photographs. he has captured over 50 stations, and his list of places to visit and photograph includes new york, stockholm, budapest, kiev, and lisbon. some of the well-known stations he has photographed include bank station on the london underground, euston station in north london, and hotel de ville station in paris. hui's photographs have received mixed reviews, ranging from eerily empty and creepy to artistically beautiful.
333	ed miliband faced ridicule in the commons for campaigning as a teenager for britain to leave the european union during the 1983 general election, despite his current opposition to holding an in-out referendum on the issue. labour has refused to match david cameron's pledge for a renegotiation and referendum on eu membership, with senior figures privately admitting that being pro-europe is one of the party's few policies that businesses like. miliband's past campaigning efforts were mocked by cameron and tory mps, with cameron joking that miliband's youthful leafletting was not his idea of fun. unite union, a major labour donor, warned the party that denying a referendum could be an electoral millstone and leave the field open for ukip and other parties to exploit public concerns. however, some labour figures argue that supporting a referendum could alienate business supporters and labour's pro-europe stance. conservative mp bob neill is attempting to force a referendum bill through parliament, but labour has refused to support it. unite's general secretary len mccluskey urged labour to reconsider its approach to a referendum, stating that denying the british people a vote on eu membership would suggest that the party does not trust them and risks making labour appear anti-democratic.
334	house prices in the uk hit a new record high of £272,000 in july, with an 11.7% increase from the previous year. london led the way with a 19.1% price increase, while first-time buyers faced an average price of £209,000, a 13.5% rise since 2013. stamp duty became increasingly burdensome, with thousands of families paying 3% or more on the average property price of £272,000. house prices in england were £284,000, only surpassed by london's £514,000. scotland and wales saw 7.6% and 7.4% growth, respectively, while northern ireland had the lowest average price of £139,000. several regions reached fresh all-time highs in july, including the east and west midlands, and south west, as well as wales, scotland, and london. prices in england were 13% above their previous high, while scotland and wales had passed their pre-financial crisis peaks. homebuyers were resorting to longer-term mortgages and larger loans, with an average loan size of £127,500 for first-time buyers in july.
335	a man named john eamer, 29, was spared jail time despite admitting to punching a female cashier at a bookies in gloucester after losing a £1.30 bet on germany vs. portugal during euro 2012. in a fit of rage and frustration, eamer attacked leanne vallis, leaving her with heavy bruising, bleeding, and swelling below her eye. previously, eamer had served 15 months in prison for attacking a pensioner and forging cheques. he was given a 12-month community order, with a six-month drug rehabilitation requirement and 200 hours of unpaid work. eamer was also ordered to pay £150 in compensation to the cashier and £50 in court costs. the incident was captured on cctv, and police later arrested him.
336	luis suarez, the uruguayan striker, is facing a potential ban from fifa after biting italian defender giorgio chiellini during uruguay's victory over italy in the world cup. suarez has until 9pm to provide any evidence to defend himself, but his previous biting incidents will likely be considered. a six-member independent fifa disciplinary committee, chaired by claudio sulser, is expected to make a decision quickly due to uruguay's upcoming last sixteen match against colombia. the committee has requested audio and tv evidence, which is likely to clearly show suarez biting chiellini's shoulder for the third time in his career. suarez's ban could end his involvement in the tournament, but he may appeal if the punishment is for three or four matches. the complex disciplinary code allows for an appeal to the court of arbitration for sport, and sulser, who is also a swiss international, has recused himself from the case due to potential conflicts of interest. fifa has not specified the possible length of the ban, but article 118 states that no appeal is allowed for a ban of less than three matches or up to two months. adidas, suarez's sponsor, is holding a meeting to discuss the implications of the incident.
337	violent protests continued in srinagar, indian-controlled kashmir, with the death toll rising to 20 over the past two days. three critically injured protesters died on wednesday, and several thousand attended a funeral for one of the victims. the unrest began after hindu protesters blocked a highway, preventing muslim fruit growers from taking their crops to market. the indian government's attempt to transfer land to a hindu shrine triggered over a month of heightened tensions between hindus and muslims. curfew was temporarily lifted to allow residents to purchase essentials, but an angry mob attacked a policeman during this time. governor n.n. vohra appealed for calm and expressed sympathy for the families of the deceased.
338	a high school football player, charles youvella, from hopi high school in arizona, died from a traumatic brain injury sustained during a blowout playoff game loss on saturday. youvella, described as small and underweight but playing with heart, scored his team's only touchdown in the game. the death attracted national attention after arizona cardinals star wide receiver larry fitzgerald requested prayers for the teenager and his family. a community memorial is planned for wednesday evening at the high school auditorium. youvella's father, who is the school's athletic director, and the hopi community are grieving the loss. the death comes amid growing concerns about head injuries in football, as a recent report by the institute of medicine and national research council calls for a national system to address youth concussions, which affected 250,000 people aged 19 and younger in the us in 2009. an account has been established to help support the youvella family with expenses.
339	in july 2023, thousands of chickens were killed or left wandering on the streets of salem, oregon, after a truck transporting them overturned. the incident became a viral news story due to its oddity and potential for neglect. in response, peta proposed a giant, bloody chicken statue as a memorial and reminder to truckers to be careful. however, the statue was denied by the oregon department of transportation due to potential distractions. meanwhile, a shopper in arizona found a chicken foot in a package of chicken breast from safeway, leading to an investigation by the company. the month ended on a disturbing note for chickens, with one's foot discovered in a package of their own body parts.
340	a muslim activist, zaky mallah, from sydney, labeling islamic state militants as 'wankers' and urging authorities to lock up teenagers who join the terror group. mallah, who was previously charged with terrorism in 2003 and spent two years in prison, made these comments on channel ten's the project, after a propaganda video featuring sydney teenager abdullah elmir in islamic state emerged. elmir disappeared in june, claiming he was going fishing but later appeared in the is video. mallah discourages teenagers from joining is and stated that their actions harm the muslim community and australia. he also believes social media is a significant recruitment tool for the group. mallah, who fought with free syrian army rebels in 2012, said it was "very easy" to enter syria. he expressed his desire to see syria free from bashar al-assad's regime and suggested that australian authorities might consider letting community members go over to fight but not join is.
341	a christian pastor, youcef nadarkhani, has been imprisoned in iran for over 1,000 days and faces the death penalty for apostasy. he was born to muslim parents in rasht, converted to christianity at 19, and was ordained as a minister, leading a network of house churches in iran. he was arrested in 2009 after protesting against his child being forced to read the quran in school. despite iran's constitution guaranteeing religious freedom, nadarkhani's sentence could be overturned if he recanted, which he has refused to do. persecution of religious minorities, including christians, has increased since iran's disputed presidential election in 2009. the us and various human rights organizations have called for his release, with the us house of representatives passing a resolution condemning iran's actions and calling for his immediate release. nadarkhani's case has garnered international attention, with support from both christian and muslim organizations, and a twitter campaign reaching over 2.5 million accounts daily.
342	rosie huntington-whiteley, a british model and actress, has been in new york city to celebrate her new role as an ambassador for moroccanoil. however, she hasn't forgotten her british roots and is also the star of marks & spencer's autumn/winter 2014 campaign. in the new shots, she showcases her hourglass figure in a range of styles, including floral prints and androgynous looks. the 54-piece collection, which is in stores now, features smart tailoring, mannish coats, and structured knits. rosie, who has been a member of the m&s family for years, also designs a lingerie range for autograph. she opened up about her desire to build a brand using her name and reportedly has a beauty range in the works. currently, she is in new york for moroccanoil but will soon return to promote her m&s campaign and star in "mad max: fury road."
343	north korea's state-run media, kcna, has faced criticism from the white house's national security council for racist rhetoric towards former us president barack obama, referring to him as a "wicked black monkey" through a series of articles. this escalation of racist slurs is unexpected, as north korea frequently hurls vitriolic insults at us and south korean leaders. kcna has also targeted south korean president park geun-hye, calling her a "vile prostitute serving the us," and accused her of mismanaging the sewol ferry accident. the racist and misogynistic language towards obama and park follows a pattern of hostile propaganda from north korea, with both leaders being mentioned more frequently in recent months as north korea watchers anticipate a potential fourth nuclear test.
344	barbara taylor bradford, a 80-year-old author who has sold over 88 million books in more than 90 countries, has decided to auction off her £1.5million collection of jewellery, most of which were gifts from her husband bob. she initially considered giving the collection to two distant relatives, but realized they wouldn't want or wear the gems as they don't lead the same lifestyle. the auction, which includes a 14-carat diamond ring worth almost £500,000, a sapphire ring weighing 18.37 carats, and a pair of harry winston diamond and pearl earrings worth up to £75,000, will take place on december 5, 2013 at bonhams fine jewellery sale. bradford explained that her father had advised her to let jewellery breathe and not bury it away, inspiring her to auction the collection and use the proceeds as a little nest egg for the two women. her husband, a tv producer, was supportive and encouraged her to sell the jewellery, having bought it for her. bradford has written extensively about her family history and was shocked to learn in 2004 that her mother and aunt might have been the illegitimate children of the marquess of ripon. the author, who never had children, has candidly admitted having two miscarriages and stated that regrets are fruitless and one should cherish what they have.
345	five people, including a patient, a family member, two nurses, and the pilot, died when an air ambulance crashed and exploded around 12:18 a.m. ct near alpine, texas. the cessna 421 plane had taken off from alpine and was en route to midland, texas, when it crashed one mile south of the city. the faa and ntsb are investigating the cause of the crash. the victims were identified as ted caffarel, sharon falkner, tracy chambers, richard folger, and mary folger.
346	ashley bell, 27, was sentenced to four years and nine months in jail after being caught on a home security camera burglarizing a couple's home in solihull, west midlands. bell, wearing a grey hooded tracksuit and black gloves, stole thousands of pounds worth of jewellery, including a luxury £5,000 breitling watch, without realizing he was being recorded. the family passed on the footage to police, who quickly identified bell and charged him within 24 hours of the burglary. the sentence was handed down at leamington crown court and serves as a warning to would-be burglars that they will be caught and face imprisonment.
347	reality tv star amy childs, formerly of "the only way is essex," has shed her christmas indulgences to showcase her new figure in a beauty campaign for silk'n glide, an at-home permanent hair removal device. despite the busy holiday season, amy plans to get back into her fitness routine with three to four gym sessions per week. she balances her regime with a well-balanced diet, which includes healthy foods, water, occasional treats, and a daily cup of tea, and admires michelle keegan's toned figure. amy, who runs her own beauty salons and is the face of silk'n glide, is continuously expanding her career, with plans to open more salons and expand her clothing collection. she has also tried and loved various beauty treatments, including liposuction.
348	fifteen-year-old hadiya pendleton, an honor student and majorette who performed at president barack obama's inauguration last week, was shot and killed in chicago on tuesday. her death was brought up in a u.s. senate hearing and a white house press briefing as lawmakers and officials called for action to prevent gun violence. mayor rahm emanuel described pendleton as "what's best in our city," and no arrests have been made in the case. the park shelter where she was shot is just a mile from the obamas' home in chicago, and over 40 murders have occurred in the city this year. the non-gang affiliated teenager was likely not the intended target, and nearby residents expressed fear for their safety. white house press secretary jay carney described her death as a "terrible tragedy," and called for efforts to prevent gun violence.
349	viagra, the first oral medication for erectile dysfunction (ed), was approved by the us food and drug administration in 1998. before viagra, ed was a taboo subject, and men seldom talked about their sexual health issues. however, with viagra's introduction, discussions about ed became more open, and the topic entered the public consciousness. viagra works by increasing blood flow to the penis, allowing men to have erections when sexually aroused. it has revolutionized sexual health, and since its introduction, other ed medications like levitra and cialis have followed. viagra has helped millions of men overcome ed and transform their lives, but it doesn't work for approximately 25-35 percent of men. additionally, while viagra can improve romantic relationships, it can also lead to new challenges, such as feelings of inadequacy for partners who are not the recipient of the medication. doctors have also used viagra to identify underlying health conditions and studies continue to explore its potential uses in various fields, including sports and women's sexual health. overall, viagra has significantly impacted sexual health, relationship dynamics, and society.
350	steve mcclaren, derby county manager, shared an anecdote about giving louis van gaal a bouquet of flowers ahead of a crucial match between fc twente and twente in 2010. mcclaren hoped the gesture would soften up van gaal and his team, who were the reigning eredivisie champions, and help twente secure second place and a spot in the champions league. the "tulips trick" worked as twente won 3-0, and mcclaren credited van gaal for his successful tenures at az alkmaar and bayern munich, having faced him in holland and germany. mcclaren acknowledged van gaal as a great coach and a perfect fit for manchester united, adding that the dutchman laid the foundations for bayern munich's current success.
351	michael morton, a man from texas, had a double celebration on august 12, 1986, turning 32 and marking the end of his young son's heart surgery recovery. however, the following day, morton's life took a cruel turn when his wife, christine, was murdered at their home. morton, who was working at the time, was initially suspected but lacked solid evidence. despite the absence of any scientific evidence, eye-witnesses, murder weapon, or believable motive, morton was charged, tried, and convicted. he was separated from his son, eric, and spent nearly 25 years in prison. eric, who had no memory of his father outside of prison visits, stopped visiting him. morton wrote to him and asked to see him, but eric refused, finding it embarrassing. morton's story was one of the over 2,000 wrongfully convicted cases between 1989 and 2012, according to data compiled by the university of michigan law school. however, morton's case paved new ground, leading to unprecedented consequences for ken anderson, the prosecutor who withheld crucial exculpatory evidence. in 2011, a team of attorneys working pro bono on morton's behalf reviewed the case and discovered new evidence, including a blood-stained bandana found near the crime scene that contained the dna of another man, mark norwood. norwood was eventually convicted of the murder and also implicated in the killing of debra baker. anderson, now a judge, was found in criminal contempt of court for withholding exculpatory evidence. he served five days in jail and paid a $500 fine, 500 hours of community service, and lost his law license. the landmark decision marked the first time a prosecutor was criminally punished for failing to turn over exculpatory evidence. morton was eventually exon
352	michael klim, an australian swimmer and former olympic gold medalist, has pleaded with fans to help raise $100,000 for the medical evacuation of his friend nico white, who suffered a severe brain injury in a motorbike accident in bali. white, also an australian, is in an induced coma in a denpasar hospital and has been unable to regain consciousness. his melbourne family is currently paying up to $6,000 per day for his treatment. a fundraising page has been set up on youcaring.com, which has already gathered over $91,000 towards its goal of $250,000. the page was established by white's stepfather, ian mcgill, and his wife, lyn mcgill. white, who is originally from melbourne, also has a second home in bali where he designs jewelry. the accident occurred on may 16 in the town of kerobokan, and the other motorist involved in the crash is unable to contribute due to financial difficulties. white did not have medical insurance. attempts to wake him from the coma have been unsuccessful, and his family is urgently seeking to bring him home for further treatment. celebrities, including fashion designers alice mccall and nicholas morley, have donated to the cause. the family will hold a fundraising event at lacalaca bali in seminyak on thursday, with all proceeds going towards white's medical expenses.
353	in this mme special edition, sheikh mohammed bin rashid al maktoum, ruler of dubai and prime minister of the uae, discusses dubai's success in finance, tourism, and logistics, and the challenges encountered during the past six months, including restructuring dubai world's debt and handling the debt of other companies, in an exclusive interview with mme during his annual visit to royal ascot. tune in to mme on fridays at 09:15, saturdays at 04:45, and sundays at 06:15 and 17:45 (gmt) to watch the full interview.
354	a large wasp nest containing an estimated "more than a million" yellow jacket wasps was discovered on a privately-owned hunting ground in central florida. entomologist and bee removal expert jonathan simkins, who has been working in the insect business for over 20 years, was called to eliminate the nest and was met with thousands of wasps attempting to sting him. the nest, which was six and a half feet tall and eight feet wide, was approximately six times the size of a typical nest and contained numerous queens. simkins managed to kill the entire nest using a good spray and his own technique, but not before being attacked and sustaining only a single sting on his chin. he noted that if anyone else had encountered the nest, they likely wouldn't have been so lucky. two days after the extermination, simkins returned to the site to confirm that the nest was dead. the dangerous nest would have posed a significant threat to anyone who came across it. simkins described the experience as one of the most exciting in his career.
355	an 18-year-old student, isabella hankey (belle), is suing her former school and local authorities for $2 million after allegedly experiencing over a year and a half of bullying, including death threats and vandalism, which she claims the school did not sufficiently address. the bullying began on her 17th birthday and escalated to the point where she suffered a pulmonary embolism due to stress. her parents reported incidents to the school, but were often dismissed or ignored. the threats took place in the locker room, and the school did not install security cameras as requested. the student's attempts to seek help from school administrators were unsuccessful, and the bullying continued even when she was studying off-campus due to fear for her safety. despite numerous threats, no action was taken to identify the perpetrators or protect the student. the school district and three school administrators are being named in the lawsuit. principal peter badalament and deputy superintendent john flaherty have issued statements acknowledging their commitment to preventing harassment but declined further comment on the ongoing legal matter. belle plans to attend the university of mississippi and hopes the lawsuit will provide closure and help prevent similar experiences for other students.
356	kay tate, a 25-year-old woman from newcastle, stands at just 3ft9" tall due to a severe form of osteogenesis imperfecta, or brittle bones disease. her son, lewis, is only nine inches taller than her. every day, kay faces challenges, from the disapproval of strangers who think she's a child to the physical difficulty of carrying groceries. kay has endured numerous fractures since childhood and the frequent pain and frustration of her condition, but maintains a positive attitude and determination to live her life to the fullest. despite the challenges, she refuses to let her condition inhibit her from being a mother to lewis. she had to adapt to his needs and teach him to be independent while they navigated societal misunderstandings about her age. kay undergoes frequent operations to treat her condition, most recently an osteotomy, which is featured on channel 4's documentary series embarrassing bodies. kay's condition has been a lifelong challenge, but she remains optimistic and focused on living her life as normally as possible.
357	in sri lanka, a trail of pilgrims ascends the sacred mountain of adam's peak, a 2,243-meter (7,359 feet) high holy site for buddhists, hindus, muslims, and christians. with barefoot pilgrims, monks, and women in traditional attire, they all move towards the summit to see the 1.8-meter-long sacred rock formation and believe in its divine significance. legend states it was discovered centuries ago, and marco polo documented its challenging climb. pilgrims start at dalhousie, where basic facilities await, and endure the early morning ascent, culminating at the shrine at sunrise. this is not a leisure pursuit but a spiritual pilgrimage. the journey involves traveling from kandy to dalhousie, a five-kilometer climb starting at 3 a.m. a monk's blessing, warm tea, and a steep but rewarding trek lead to a spectacular sunrise and a sea of pilgrims surrounding the shrine. pilgrims can travel by train from kandy to hatton and then take a bus to dalhousie; during pilgrimage season, direct buses are also available from major cities.
358	the un report highlights the overlooked needs of approximately 1 billion people with physical and mental disabilities in disaster planning and emergency response, resulting in a disproportionate number of deaths due to the neglect of their requirements. disabled persons face numerous challenges such as inaccessible emergency response systems and shelters, lack of information, and inability to evacuate. in the us, about 37.2 million citizens have disabilities, yet millions are left without employment, education, and services before, during, and after a crisis. the exclusion of people with disabilities from the workforce deprives societies of an estimated $1.4 trillion in gdp. the us has a moral and economic obligation to address the needs of the disabled and lead in global efforts, despite not ratifying the un convention on the rights of persons with disabilities. the us has made progress in promoting disability inclusion through programs like the americans with disabilities act, usaid's universal design principles, and increasing representation in exchange programs. the 25th anniversary of national disability employment awareness month is a reminder to recognize the equal capabilities of people with disabilities and ensure their inclusion in all aspects of society.
359	nathaniel clyne, a 23-year-old right-back for southampton, is currently in talks with the club over a contract extension but is in no rush to make a decision. his improvement since joining from crystal palace in 2012 and breaks into the england team have attracted interest from clubs like manchester united. southampton manager ronald koeman would like to know about clyne's decision by april, but the player is still negotiating with his agent and the club. clyne's decision might be easier if southampton's remarkable third place standing in the premier league remains, with koeman's men facing tough battles despite a good run of form. clyne believes they can continue their top-four tilt.
360	an 18-year-old freshman at arizona state university, naomi mcclendon from manhattan, kansas, fell to her death from a top-floor balcony in an off-campus apartment complex early sunday morning. surveillance footage shows she appeared to be drunk and alone on the balcony before the tragic accident. authorities believe alcohol was the only factor and foul play is not suspected. mcclendon had spent the night at a party, and police are investigating how she obtained alcohol. the incident was captured on security camera, and her boyfriend posted an angry rant on social media before later expressing his grief. the community is mourning the loss of mcclendon, who only started college last year and was part of a band with her boyfriend.
361	nicolas and daow wegner, a courageous couple from casper, wyoming, chase extreme weather conditions such as tornadoes, hurricanes, and lightning storms to capture incredible photographs. they use forecast tools to anticipate storm locations and then wait for them to materialize. most of their images are taken in wyoming, but they have also ventured to neighboring states. daow, who often stands with her back to the camera, finds both fear and excitement in the dangerous conditions. lightning poses the most significant risk and has halted their shoots. the couple communicates and prioritizes safety over their passion for photography, admitting that there is an element of danger involved. daow's favorite subjects to photograph are storms and mountains. their stunning imagery captures the power and beauty of the elements.
362	a disgraced former police officer, gary thompson, who headed a £10 million cigarette smuggling operation and was jailed for six years last year, will only pay back £1 in proceeds of crime. thompson, a former acting sergeant with cleveland police, made around £90,000 from the scam but claims he is penniless and has debts over £120,000. two other individuals involved, anthony lamb and david lister, must also pay back nominal amounts of £1 and £5,000 respectively. the gang, which included over a dozen people, illegally imported 59.5 million cigarettes into the uk by hijacking businesses and concealing their transactions from the authorities. prosecutors estimate that the total value of the cigarettes evaded vat may never be known as eight of the containers were not found. thompson, lamb, and lister were jailed for six years, five years, and two years, respectively, for conspiracy to evade cigarette duty.
363	tragedy struck before the 2014 paralympic games with the death of australian para-snowboarder matthew robinson following a heart attack during a refueling stop in nairobi, kenya, on february 26. he had suffered neck and spinal injuries from a crash at la molina ski resort in spain on february 12 and spent eight days in a barcelona hospital recovering before being cleared to fly back to australia. robinson, who had arthrogryposis, competed in upper limb impairment disciplines but that category would not be contested at sochi. the australian paralympic committee and international paralympic committee expressed their deep sorrow for robinson's passing and extended their condolences to his family and loved ones. the sochi 2014 paralympic games are scheduled to begin on march 7.
364	prosecutors in the trial of jodi arias for the murder of travis alexander presented a grisly photograph, allegedly taken accidentally while arias was dragging his body through his home after stabbing him 27 times and shooting him in the head. the image depicts the back of alexander's head with his arm raised and blood trickling down his neck, with a leg in sweatpants in the foreground. prosecutors claim the picture was taken as arias, who was apparently jealous of alexander dating someone else, dragged his body through his home in mesa, arizona. arias' defense lawyers argue that the trickling blood in the image was from arias shooting alexander in self-defense after he had already been killed. the grisly image was discovered on alexander's camera, which had been put through a washing cycle with blood-soaked towels and clothes after the murder. in court, jurors have seen images of the crime scene, including blood-splattered scenes inside the home and wounds on alexander's body. arias, a photographer, wept in court as the medical examiner testified that alexander "may have" already been dead when she shot him in the head. this detail could be crucial in determining whether arias will face the death penalty. investigators found other lies told by arias during police interviews after the murder, including her denial of seeing alexander on the day of the murder and her claim that she saw two men kill him. arias and alexander had met at a work conference in las vegas in 2006 and began talking on the phone every day. they started dating in 2007, and arias chose to be baptized into the mormon church, but the couple broke up in june 2007 due to jealousy on both sides. alexander's friend and roommate found his body in the shower in june 2008 and told a 911 dispatcher that arias had been stalking and threatening him. arias originally claimed she had not seen alexander
365	in december, facebook's year in review feature reminded web consultant eric meyer of his tragic loss by featuring a photo of his late daughter. meyer, who lost his 6-year-old daughter rebecca in june, found the automated reminder painful. he acknowledged the algorithms aren't to blame, but suggested that facebook could have offered users an option to opt out of the feature. other users also shared similar experiences, expressing disappointment and distress. facebook apologized to meyer and acknowledged that the feature brought grief instead of joy. meyer later apologized to the year in review team and emphasized the need for anticipating and handling various use cases to improve design.
366	a person at goldman sachs, who has not been identified or charged, is accused of leaking secrets about intel and apple to raj rajaratnam, the founder of the galleon group hedge fund. the defense for rajat gupta, a former goldman board member on trial for insider trading, argued in court on friday that the real source should be identified instead. gupta denies the charges, which involve tipping rajaratnam with information from goldman and procter & gamble between 2007 and 2009. goldman sachs worker is believed to have leaked secrets to rajaratnam through wiretapped conversations, and prosecutors are reportedly investigating other goldman employees, including managing director david loeb and asia-based analyst henry king. goldman ceo lloyd blankfein has already been interviewed under oath as a witness in the case. the trials for both cases, usa v. gupta, are scheduled for may 2012 in the u.s. district court for the southern district of new york.
367	merrimack, new hampshire police have issued a tongue-in-cheek arrest warrant for punxsutawney phil, the famous groundhog from pennsylvania, accusing him of terrorizing the american northeast with his prediction of six more weeks of winter and causing over 4 feet of snow. the groundhog, known for his large teeth, has allegedly been hiding and refusing to reveal an early spring. wisconsin's groundhog, jimmy, also made headlines this year for biting the mayor of sun prairie.
368	andrew halls, the headmaster of king's college school in wimbledon, expressed concern about the negative impact of social networking sites on children, particularly in terms of bullying and body image concerns. he noted that constant scrutiny on platforms such as askfm, little gossip, facebook, and instagram leaves many teenagers feeling small and vulnerable, exposed to cruel and absurd slanders that can be life-ending. he urged schools to instill "grit" and emotional resilience in pupils to help them cope with the pressures of modern life. independent schools, including king's college, have been criticized for being reluctant to discuss mental health issues, which affect one in ten young people. the issues faced by teenagers in the 21st century, such as competition, self-consciousness, and mental health problems, cut across class and gender stereotypes and increase the risk of despair and suicide, particularly for children from unhappy or less affluent families. the conference, entitled "true grit," aims to help teenagers build resilience, focus on their strengths, and win the battle of life.
369	prime minister david cameron failed to secure support from his conservative party mps to make the government's commitment to spending 0.7% of the country's income on foreign aid legally binding. nick clegg, the deputy prime minister and liberal democrat leader, revealed this in a speech this morning, acknowledging the failure to convince the conservatives to pass the legislation. the liberal democrats had advocated for the law due to their manifesto commitment, but the coalition agreement was unable to include it this time. tory mp peter bone welcomed the decision to drop the planned legislation, but suggested the aid budget should be reduced. clegg defended the aid spending by emphasizing the benefits to the uk and dispelling myths about the money being wasted, as well as addressing the situation in nigeria and the need for ongoing international aid efforts.
370	a wooden steamship named city of chester, which sank in san francisco bay in 1888 after colliding with a larger ship, has been located 126 years later using sonar technology. the shipwas carrying 90 passengers and 16 people were killed in the accident, which was the second-worst maritime disaster in the bay's history. the incident took place during dense fog, and the cause was deemed the city of chester's skipper's mistake. sonar imaging revealed the upright wreckage with a gash in the hull that led to its sinking. the discovery was made during oceanographers' channel charting before the america's cup. no attempt will be made to raise the ship, but a display featuring the city of chester's history and new images will open in san francisco. the event received conflicting media coverage, with initial reports focusing on the tragedy and accusations against the chinese crew of the other ship, but later accounts revealed acts of heroism.
371	helen and armando rendón, californian residents and a teacher and civil rights lawyer respectively, participated in the june 29 candlelight procession at san pancrazio, italy, honoring world war ii massacre victims. armando was struck by the contrast between the beautiful sunset and the tragic history of the town, feeling no hatred but rather acceptance. for helen, remembering the experience brought forth memories of her experiences during wwii in baghdad, hiding her jewish neighbors from attackers. the procession shifted their perception of tuscany, revealing its difficult history but also the strength and resilience of its people. they left with a renewed appreciation for the innocent sacrifices made during war.
372	a raccoon in santa cruz, california, got its head stuck in a drain cover, and wildlife emergency services were called to assist. experts sedated and safely freed the animal using a grinder, shielding it from sparks and keeping the metal cool. the raccoon, which appeared agitated but otherwise healthy, received treatment for a superficial wound and was given food once out of sedation. the animal was released, seeming happy and unharmed post-rescuing.
373	a limousine caught fire on the san francisco bay's san mateo-hayward bridge in may, killing the bride-to-be and four other members of a bachelorette party. the fire was caused by friction between the car's drive shaft and the rear floor board, resulting in a "catastrophic failure" of the limousine's rear suspension system. the driver, who initially thought one of the passengers was asking to smoke, pulled over when he smelled smoke but was unable to save the passengers due to the rapid spreading flames. investigators have ruled the incident an accident and no criminal charges will be filed. the limousine was carrying two more passengers than allowed, leading to a fine for the owner of the company for failing to operate safely.
374	a former connecticut state police trooper, jeffrey laporto, 43, has been charged with raping an 81-year-old woman in a hotel room in windsor locks, connecticut. the victim's son reported the incident to police, who alleged that laporto and the elderly woman met at the quality inn hotel bar and went to her room after midnight on friday, resulting in her being taken to the hospital for treatment of extensive internal injuries. during laporto's arraignment, his attorney, donald papcsy, insisted that the encounter was consensual and that the two were seen drinking together in the bar beforehand. laporto, a self-employed real estate agent and u.s. navy veteran with no prior criminal record, is being treated for a health issue and faces two counts of first-degree sexual assault and one count of first-degree unlawful restraint. he is due back in court on june 23.
375	freddie hubbard, a five-decade jazz career legend and grammy winner, died at the age of 70 in california due to heart disease, following a heart attack in late november. native of indianapolis, hubbard made a significant mark in jazz history with his innovative and soulful trumpet playing, which set the pace for many trumpet players in the last three decades. in the 1970s, hubbard produced a series of funk- and fusion-oriented albums, including the hit "red clay" and the grammy-winning "first light." hubbard started his career in the late 1950s in new york, playing alongside jazz greats such as art blakey, oliver nelson, ornette coleman, herbie hancock, and wayne shorter. he was recognized as a national endowment for the arts jazz master in 2006. hubbard is survived by his wife, briggie, and son, duane.
376	sierra blair-coyle, a 20-year-old climber from scottsdale, arizona, has defied the odds to become a two-time us national champion despite battling a debilitating back injury since her teenage years. her determination and love for climbing have helped her overcome the pain and tackle boulders, caves, and climbing walls. despite her successful career, sierra also models for agencies such as roxy, spy, and sanuk. she started climbing at the age of eight and has since mastered techniques such as deep water soloing on the hawaiian island of maui. sierra's back injury involved a bulging, torn, and herniated disc, but she refused to give up on her dream of becoming a professional climber. despite her challenges, sierra embraces her role as a female icon in the sport and wants to expand her horizons beyond the climbing community. she trains intensely to improve her skills and plans to help climbing gain more mainstream recognition while also pursuing opportunities in modeling and public speaking.
377	a 12-year-old florida boy, zachary reyna, is in critical condition after contracting a rare and deadly infection caused by the brain-eating amoeba, naegleria fowleri. the infection, known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (pam), is contracted when the amoeba enters the nose and attacks the brain. only three people have survived the infection in the past 50 years, and zachary's family is hopeful he will be the fourth. the amoeba thrives in warm, stagnant water and can enter the body when the water is forcefully pushed up the nose. zachary fell ill after playing in a ditch with friends and has been sedated in intensive care at miami children's hospital. swimmers are advised to wear nose clips as a safety precaution to prevent further infections. symptoms of pam include headaches, fever, vomiting, and seizures, and it can take up to a week for them to appear. two other cases of the infection were reported last year in florida.
378	outside white hart lane, tottenham's merchandise vendors mocked manchester united with t-shirts featuring louis van gaal, wayne rooney, and angel di maria, referencing the bbc comedy "only fools and horses" and their famous quote, "this time next year, we'll be champions." the shop owners capitalized on united's poor start to the season, with van gaal struggling for results and di maria a record signing. rooney was made captain to turn things around. the t-shirts poked fun at united's misfortunes, but spurs beat nottingham forest 3-1 in the capital one cup, while united was knocked out in the second round by mk dons, losing 4-0. despite the setback, united fans can like the manchester united facebook page for updates on their team.
379	new zealand scrum-half aaron smith, who experienced his only defeat in an all blacks shirt against england in 2012, is using the pain of that loss as motivation for tomorrow's first test at eden park. england thrashed new zealand 38-21 at twickenham that year, a record defeat, but the all blacks avenged it with a 30-22 victory in the last november international. smith, who has 26 caps, carries the memories of that defeat strongly. england, with a much weakened side, will face the intimidating haka before the game and will have to respect the all blacks' 20-year unbeaten streak at eden park, where they have won 31 tests in a row. smith is looking forward to playing england on home soil after twice facing them at twickenham and is confident of a win, as the all blacks have not lost a test at eden park in 20 years.
380	nevada assemblywoman michele fiore, a republican from las vegas, has faced criticism for her comments regarding concealed weapons permits and sexual assault. fiore, who is the main sponsor of a bill that would allow concealed carry on college campuses, told the new york times that "hot little girls" can defend themselves from rapists with concealed weapons. she also suggested that sexual assaults would decrease once predators receive a bullet in their heads. women's groups and assembly leaders criticized fiore for objectifying women and her unrepresentative view of rape victims. fiore stood by her comments and vowed that the republican-controlled nevada legislature and governor would enact her bill. gun control advocates link the push for concealed carry on college campuses as a sexual assault prevention measure to recent attempts by the firearms industry to appeal to women. university presidents, college students, and domestic violence experts are opposed to the idea of allowing concealed weapons on school grounds.
381	geraint jones, a former english wicket-keeper, made history by earning his 50th one-day international (odi) cap for papua new guinea (png), eight years after his last one with england. jones, 38, had been playing for png for three years and recently played in their first two official odis against hong kong. previously, jones represented england in 34 test matches, most notably capturing the famous catch that won england the 2005 ashes against australia. jones plays as a batsman for png, passing on his experience while enjoying the lesser pressure compared to his england tenure. born to welsh parents who spent a decade in papua new guinea before settling in australia, jones came to england to explore his roots and built a successful county cricket career with kent. now, jones captains gloucestershire in four-day cricket and looks forward to proving himself at the physical level. jones has had an impressive career, having not played professional cricket until he was 24 years old.
382	a pastel drawing of london's waterloo bridge by claude monet, created during his stay at the savoy hotel in 1901, is now on display in the hotel room where it was originally made. monet had planned to paint the scene in oils, but his supplies were delayed. the drawing is one of 26 pastels of the river thames by monet and is temporarily on exhibit until december 16. the savoy, which has previously hosted artists like whistler and picasso, has showcased monet's works as its most famed association with art. the pastel is privately owned by the trinity house gallery and is available for sale for approximately $2.32 million. monet lived in london during the franco-prussian war in the late 1800s and was drawn to the city's architecture and fog.
383	a report by beirut-based newspaper al-akhbar claims that syrian first lady asma al-assad is pregnant, citing anonymous arab visitors who said bashar al-assad made the announcement. the bbc could not confirm the report with her father, but the al-akhbar article also discussed assad's confidence in the syrian army's success in the ongoing civil war. asma al-assad, a british-born mother of three, studied computer science and french literature at king's college london before working as a banker and meeting assad during his eye surgery training in london. rumors of her pregnancy have circulated before, with akhbar shabab soriyah reporting in november that she was five months pregnant. emails revealed that she spent £270,000 on furniture for one of her palaces while syria descended into civil war. meanwhile, a horrifying video emerged showing at least 65 corpses with their hands tied behind their backs lined up by a river in aleppo, with a man claiming they were killed because they were muslims. syrian rebels captured a government intelligence complex in deir el-zour, freeing detainees, but were met with intense government response. government forces have been accused of carrying out summary executions along with the rebels in the over two-year conflict that has claimed more than 60,000 lives and displaced over 700,000 people.
384	a man named christopher davies, 35, was sentenced to 12 weeks in suspended jail and barred from owning dogs after being caught on cctv repeatedly punching and kicking his staffordshire bull terrier, max, in a public park in chelmsford, essex. the incident occurred on april 7 and was witnessed by children. davies was also seen using his mobile phone to deliver upper cuts to the terrified dog. max was removed from his home the following day to protect him from further attacks. davies was found guilty of causing unnecessary suffering to a protected animal despite failing to appear for his trial at chelmsford magistrates' court. anne brewer, chairman of the bench, described the attack as "brutal." council officials are now pursuing davies through the animal welfare act 2006 for the assault on max, who is now in kennels awaiting a new home. chelmsford city council officials stated that the footage of the attack, which was captured on cctv, clearly showed the dog being beaten for no apparent reason and that the animal suffered unprovoked attacks. ian grundy, chemslford city council's cabinet member for safer communities, added that this prosecution sends a clear message that animal abuse will not be tolerated in chelmsford.
385	clint eastwood, the 78-year-old actor and filmmaker best known for playing tough-guy characters like dirty harry, received a lifetime achievement award at the cannes film festival last week. eastwood's career spans six decades, during which he has won five academy awards, five golden globes, and received many more nominations. he got his start in the 1950s with roles in tv westerns and spaghetti westerns, including "a fistful of dollars" and "the good, the bad, and the ugly." in the 1970s, he starred as inspector harry callahan in "dirty harry," which spawned four sequels. in the 1990s, he returned to westerns as a director with "unforgiven," earning nine oscar nominations, and continued to helm successful films like "in the line of fire," "bridges of madison county," and "true crime." eastwood's latest film, "gran torino," in which he both directs and co-stars, has been well-received. he is the second person, after ingmar bergman, to receive the palme d'or for lifetime achievement from the cannes film festival.
386	alfonso ribeiro, former "fresh prince of bel-air" star, revived his iconic "carlton" dance on "dancing with the stars" during week four's "most memorable year" theme. he and pro partner witney carson performed a jazz routine to tom jones' "it's not unusual," earning a perfect score. ribeiro expressed his love for the iconic dance, which helped cement his acting career but also left him pigeonholed. fashion designer betsey johnson was eliminated on monday night, becoming the latest celebrity to leave the competition.
387	a report by the global warming policy foundation, led by former conservative chancellor lord lawson, claims that the met office's global warming predictions are flawed and potentially biased, as a result of an issue with a computer programme used to predict temperature rises, hadcm3. the report alleges that this could result in millions of pounds being misinvested in renewable energy projects and other climate change mitigation efforts. the met office responds that it is confident in hadcm3 and uses data from multiple models, with figures being independently reviewed. critics argue that the report's release is intended to undermine the upcoming intergovernmental panel on climate change (ipcc) report, which is expected to reinforce the scientific consensus that human activity is causing temperature rises. the ipcc draft report states that it is at least 95% certain that human activity is the primary driver of global warming since the 1950s, a significant increase from the 2001 assessment.
388	in tunisia, hollywood stars antonio banderas and freida pinto continued filming "black gold" despite political turmoil and protests that led to the resignation of president zine el abidine ben ali. the drama, set in arabia during the 1930s oil discovery era, stars banderas, pinto, mark strong, and tahar rahim and is directed by jean-jacques annaud. the international cast and crew, including banderas, expressed concern but chose to continue production. they followed developments closely but remained calm and decided to stay. the film is being shot at empire studios, owned by tarak ben ammar, a prominent tunisian film producer, and was welcomed as an opportunity for democracy in tunisia.
389	amateur engineers in africa have built their own aircraft using scrap metal, old engines, and improvisation. notable examples include mubarak abdullahi, a nigerian physics undergraduate who built a helicopter from old cars and motorbikes, and gabriel nderitu, a kenyan who used aluminum bars, bolts, and plastic sheeting to create a plane. others, such as oonesmus mwangi in magomano and aminu abubakar, have also successfully built helicopters despite having no formal aviation training. these inventors showcase curiosity, problem-solving skills, and determination in the face of limited resources. success stories like mubarak abdullahi, who secured a scholarship to study aircraft maintenance in the uk after completing his helicopter, demonstrate the potential for innovation in the developing world. emeka okafor, curator of maker faire africa, highlights the growing number of aeronautical innovators in africa and the need for more support to bring their creations to life.
390	a diver named mark ellyatt has claimed to have discovered lord nelson's hidden sword, which is said to be inside the wreck of hms victoria in the mediterranean sea. the sword is believed to have been among a collection of nelson memorabilia belonging to vice admiral george tyron, who went down with the ship in 1893. the sword, estimated to be worth up to £1m, was hidden by ellyatt to protect it from looters. however, there are concerns about who would claim ownership of the artifact if it is recovered. ellyatt found the sword in tyron's cabin, which contained a number of items belonging to nelson. the british ministry of defense (mod) showed interest in the sword but seemed to back out when ellyatt offered to bring it up for them. ellyatt wants to bring the sword to the surface, but he is worried about it being seized by local authorities. the sinking of hms victoria resulted in 358 deaths, including tyron, and occurred during a military training exercise in 1893. reports suggest that tyron was an enormous admirer of lord nelson and had kept a large number of items on board the ship that once belonged to his hero. if the sword and other items are recovered from the shipwreck, ellyatt hopes to see them end up in a museum in the uk. previously, a sword belonging to nelson was sold at auction for £336,650. an mod spokesman stated that the royal navy would "welcome" any information about lord nelson. the sinking of hms victoria occurred during a fleet training exercise in calm and warm conditions, but the dangerous maneuver ordered by tyron led to the collision and the sinking of the ship. tyron's last words were "it's all my fault."
391	apryl brown, a successful hair stylist, went to a client's house in 2004 for illegal silicone injections into her buttocks, hoping to improve her appearance. after the first session, she had doubts but continued with three more sessions. years later, she fell ill with a staph infection linked to the injections, which resulted in the amputation of her hands, feet, and buttocks flesh in 27 surgeries. brown's story is an example of the growing issue of patients seeking cheaper alternatives to medical procedures by bypassing doctors. dr. richard glogau, a clinical professor of dermatology at the university of california, san francisco, warns against self-injecting non-fda-approved dermal fillers or having procedures done overseas. he recounts a patient who purchased an unapproved filler from a brazilian website and received it through the mail, leading to complications that required surgical intervention. brown urges others to think carefully before undergoing any cosmetic procedures and to be aware of the potential dangers.
392	heather cho, the elder daughter of korean air lines chairman cho yang-ho and former head of the airline's in-flight service, appeared in court in seoul on monday after her arrest on december 30, 2014, for demanding the removal of a crew chief due to the way she was served nuts on a new york flight. the incident, referred to as 'nut rage,' caused public outrage and led cho to resign from her positions at the airline and its subsidiaries. during the court hearing, her lawyers denied that she had violated aviation security laws, conspired with executives to coerce crew members to lie, or used violence against the crew chief. cho felt remorse for her actions but maintained that they did not warrant legal punishment. cho's lawyers argued that sensitive information was leaked to the press, causing harm to cho, her husband, and their twin boys. cho, wearing a light green prison uniform, did not speak during the hearing. she is the oldest of cho yang-ho's three children, and her siblings also hold executive roles within the airline.
393	matthew macklin, a 32-year-old boxer from ireland, suffered a devastating knockout loss against jorge sebastian heiland in the 10th round of their wbc world middleweight title eliminator at the 3 arena in dublin. macklin was left heartbroken but gracious in defeat, acknowledging that he may be nearing retirement without gaining a world title. he referenced boxing legends like jake lamotta who lost numerous times before winning a title and footballers who endure bad games. macklin's best chance to win a world title came in 2011 when he lost a controversial decision to felix sturm in germany. afterward, he acknowledged that heiland, a constantly busy 27-year-old argentine, was too much to deal with and that the pace of the fight seemed to suit him more. despite the prospect of additional fights against irish opponents lee and martin murray, macklin may be contemplating retirement due to the cumulative damage of a pro career that started in his teens and the toll it has taken on his body. his record now stands at 31-6. the fight saw other irish boxing prospects, such as luke keeler and gary o'sullivan, emerge victorious with early stoppage wins.
394	a federal court hearing for yongda huang harris, a us citizen of chinese descent, was postponed on tuesday, leaving unanswered questions about his intentions after he was arrested at los angeles international airport (lax) last friday with a variety of weapons and related items, including a smoke grenade, knives, a hatchet, billy clubs, body bags, and a bulletproof vest. harris, 28, had boarded a plane in kansai, japan, and made a stop in inchon, korea, before arriving in the us, where customs officers became suspicious and found these items in his luggage. he is scheduled for a detention hearing on friday and will enter a plea on october 29. harris faces up to five years in prison if convicted of transporting hazardous materials.
395	the defense advanced research projects agency (darpa) is working on a new project called phoenix, which aims to salvage and recycle valuable parts from decommissioned communication satellites. the agency plans to spend $180 million to test technologies such as a robotic mechanic and mini-satellites to mine and assemble old satellite parts in orbit. darpa aims to lower the cost of military space missions by increasing the return on investment. this is an interesting idea that may reduce costs in the long-term, but it will likely be more expensive in the initial stages. the first test will be launching a demonstration mission to breathe new life into a retired satellite's antenna in 2016. darpa has identified about 140 retired satellites as potential sources for parts. darpa has a history of funding innovative projects, such as the 100-year starship program and the robotic road race.
396	a study presented at the european congress on obesity suggests that crash diets, which involve rapid weight loss, lead to more muscle being lost than slow and steady weight loss. this loss of muscle results in less energy being used and eventual weight gain. the study, conducted by maastricht university researchers, showed that those on a very low calorie diet for five weeks lost three times as much muscle as those on a less strict diet for 12 weeks. crash diets, which often involve highly restrictive eating plans, can also result in significant muscle loss within just a few weeks, leaving dieters feeling weak and vulnerable to weight regain. the experts discussed other reasons for crash diets' ineffectiveness, including the loss of water weight, which is quickly regained, and a lack of education on healthy eating habits for sustainable weight loss.
397	according to a cnn/orc poll, democrats have a 2-point lead over republicans on a generic ballot among likely voters for the november midterm elections, with a 3.5% margin of error. this gain is primarily from the northeast and among men and independent voters, who have taken a 7-point swing toward democrats. the poll comes after us airstrikes against isis in syria and a week before the us launched a ground operation in iraq. despite the military action, the economy is still seen by most americans as the more important issue in their midterm votes, with only 32% considering military action against isis a war. us military action against isis has received low approval ratings, with 60% disapproving of congress's handling of the situation, compared to 83% disapproval of its overall performance three weeks ago.
398	my friend cayla is the world's first "living" doll with trendy clothes and long fair hair. she can chat about hobbies, help with homework, and syncs with a smartphone or tablet for simple conversations. cayla uses google software to recognize speech and search the web for answers, but her internet browsing is limited by google's safesearch technology and parental controls. the 18-inch tall doll, which costs £59.99, also encourages role play and dressing up. cayla's ability to surf the web is just one of her features, as she can also tell stories and play games without an internet connection. during the toy fair 2014 at kensington olympia, cayla was introduced alongside other hi-tech dolls, including the vtech little love baby doll, which grows up with the child, and the nenuco won't eat baby doll, designed to encourage eating habits.
399	cnn writes that the new pricing structure of mcdonald's "dollar menu and more" should not deceive consumers about the actual low cost of eating at mcdonald's in the past. the article argues that fast-food companies shift billions of dollars in hidden costs onto taxpayers through their business model of low wages, lack of benefits, and limited work hours. fast-food workers, as shown in a leaked recording from mcdonald's "mcresource" hotline, often depend on public assistance programs like food stamps and medicaid to make ends meet. the national employment law project reports that this business model costs taxpayers approximately $3.8 billion annually for the ten largest fast-food companies, with mcdonald's being the worst offender at $1.2 billion. the article advocates for fast-food workers to have collective bargaining rights to influence wages and working conditions, saving taxpayers money while offering fairer workplaces. the author also calls for a federal minimum wage increase to $10.10 an hour to generate economic growth through increased consumer spending.
400	a fertility doctor, dr. michael kamrava, implanted 12 embryos in nadya suleman, resulting in an unsafe octuplet delivery in 2009, a california medical board lawyer said monday. suleman, who is known as "octomom" and already had six children, still has 29 frozen embryos in storage. witnesses testified that suleman asked for all 12 embryos to be implanted, despite it being unsafe. dr. victor fujimoto, an expert witness for the medical board, stated that kamrava should have referred suleman to a mental health physician due to her repeated requests for treatments. kamrava, who was expelled from the american society for reproductive medicine, faces gross negligence and repeated negligent acts charges for the treatment of another patient as well. the medical board recommends implanting no more than two embryos for women under 35 and five for those over 40, but kamrava implanted 12 embryos in july 2008, which was deemed gross negligence, according to fujimoto. suleman's children, who all went home from the hospital after an extended stay, have faced risks such as complications with pregnancy, prematurity, and long-term consequences. kamrava is also accused of negligence in another case involving a quadruplet pregnancy with complications.
401	jp morgan chase, a subsidiary of the us banking giant, has reportedly closed hundreds of bank accounts belonging to people in the adult entertainment industry. the account holders received letters informing them of the closure, which took effect on may 11, with no clear explanation given other than a 'review' of their accounts. pornographic performers teagan presley and leyton benton are among those affected, with presley being told her account was closed due to her profession. chase bank's terms and conditions allow for account closure without notice and reason. the move has sparked outrage and accusations of discrimination, with some suggesting it could be part of a wider effort by the department of justice to prevent certain industries from accessing financial services. these allegations have been denied by the department of justice, and chase bank has yet to comment on the situation. some performers have taken to social media to express their frustration, with dakota skye launching an expletive-laden twitter rant against the bank. performer veronica avluv also accused the bank of discrimination, as all the work she does is legal. the adult entertainment industry generated close to $5 billion in revenue in the us last year.
402	a mormon bishop named kent hendrix in salt lake city, utah, helped save a neighbor from an attacker using a samurai sword that he had kept nearby. the attacker, grant eggersten, had been stalking the woman and was attempting to rob her when hendrix intervened. hendrix, a martial arts instructor and fourth-degree black belt, woke up to his son's warning and rushed outside to find the woman being attacked. he drew his samurai sword and yelled at the attacker to get on the ground, causing him to flee. eggersten turned himself in to police an hour later and was charged with robbery, attempted burglary, trespassing, and violation of a stalking injunction. hendrix, a pharmaceutical statistician and member of the church of jesus christ of latter-day saints, practiced martial arts for 30 years and has a collection of swords and weapons. hendrix's wife, suzanne, noted that he had been training with the sword used in the incident for 20 years. the attack occurred just before 7 a.m. when eggersten attacked the woman, who suffered minor injuries, while she was outside her house. several neighbors helped chase after the attacker and called the police. hendrix is proud of his son for quickly alerting him to the situation and helping call 911.
403	the famous abbey road zebra crossing in st. john's wood, london, where the beatles posed for their album cover in 1969, could soon have a lollipop lady or man to ensure the safety of the thousands of fans who visit the site every year to recreate the iconic image. westminster council is discussing options to manage traffic flow and protect pedestrians from drivers and buses causing chaos. the beatles' image, taken by iain macmillan, has brought hundreds of thousands of tourists to the crossing, given its grade ii-listed status for cultural and historical importance. westminster city councillor lindsey hall and local cafe owner richard porter have expressed concerns about traffic and safety issues caused by fans and tourists.
404	malcolm blackman, a 46-year-old anarchist and anti-capitalist activist, was cleared of rape charges during a high-profile trial at the old bailey after being accused of sexually assaulting a woman inside her tent during the occupy london protest outside st. paul's cathedral in january 2012. blackman, a street performer and self-proclaimed leader of the anonymous uk group, was alleged to have attacked the woman on two occasions, including when she was passed out drunk and had tied a belt around her neck and "throttled" her. blackman claimed his life had been put on hold for over a year, and expressed disappointment that the case had even gone to trial, stating that there was no evidence of a crime and feeling that his career had been ruined. the woman who accused him was not present for the verdict, but expressed disappointment by the police, who had commended her for her strength and encouraged other victims of sexual assault to come forward. blackman also expressed a desire for anonymity for rape defendants and called for a review of the law on anonymity in such cases.
405	a truck driver employed by lennons transport, zaens pty ltd, who was under the influence of methadone when he caused a fatal car accident that killed a family of three in sydney's southwest in 2012, has resulted in the company being fined $1.3 million – the biggest fine in australian transport history. vincent samuel george, 34, veered onto the wrong side of the hume highway near menangle and crashed into calvyn logan's sedan, killing him and his parents, donald and patricia logan. george was charged with three counts of manslaughter and found guilty in 2023. blood samples showed he had methadone in his system at the time of the crash. the trucking company and its director, anthony lennon, were also charged with nearly 200 speeding offenses committed between february 2011 and march 2012. in her judgment, magistrate lisa stapleton found that zaens did not hold drivers accountable for speed compliance and did not make management responsible for speed compliance. roads minister duncan gay commented: "this is the biggest fine in nsw history against a trucking company under chain of responsibility legislation. i hope this decision brings some comfort to the logan family following their tragic loss." george's sentencing is scheduled for september.
406	caroline wozniacki, the world no. 5 tennis player, took a break from her preparations for the dubai duty free tennis championships to try sandboarding in the desert. wozniacki, who is still seeking her first grand slam title, looked carefree and enthusiastic while sandboarding, posting a video of herself on social media with a smile. prior to her tennis career, wozniacki had a high-profile relationship with golfer rory mcilroy, but the two have since split. the tennis star, who graced the sports illustrated swimsuit 2015 edition, seems unfazed by her recent australian open loss to victoria azarenka and is enjoying her time off the court.
407	ahead of leicester city's home match against sunderland in the premier league this weekend, sportsmail provides team news, provisional squads, betting odds, and opta stats. leicester's defenders liam moore and wes morgan are fit, despite missing international duty due to illness and a heel problem respectively. ben hamer is also available after a finger injury, but dean hammond and matt upson remain out. sunderland's steven fletcher is fit after recovering from an ankle injury and lee cattermole is back from a one-match ban. sebastian coates and ricky alvarez have returned to training. leicester have not won in their last six premier league matches, failing to score in five. sunderland have won the last five league meetings with leicester but haven't played since 2007 in the championship. sunderland have won on their last two visits to the king power stadium without conceding a goal. wes morgan has blocked the most opposition shots in the premier league (17), while connor wickham has conceded the most fouls (27). vito mannone has made the most errors leading directly to goals (3). leicester odds: 11/10, draw: 23/10, sunderland: 5/2. kick-off: saturday 3pm, referee: robert madley, managers: nigel pearson (leicester), gus poyet (sunderland). head-to-head league record: leicester wins 30, draws 19, sunderland wins 29.
408	a 23-year-old student at the university of the incarnate word in san antonio, identified as robert cameron redus, was fatally shot by a campus police officer during an altercation on friday. the incident began when officer christopher carter saw redus driving erratically near campus and tried to pull him over for public safety. despite reporting the incorrect location to dispatchers, which caused a delay in assistance, carter attempted to restrain redus during the wait. however, redus took the officer's baton and struck him, prompting carter to use his firearm and shoot redus. there is no dashboard camera footage available as carter's vehicle's camera had fallen off the day before the incident. redus, who was known as a gentle and kind person by his peers, had made the dean's list and was co-valedictorian of his christian high school. his neighbors reported hearing a struggle and gunshots before police arrived on the scene. redus' family has released a statement expressing their grief and asking for prayers. the university and alamo heights police are investigating the shooting, which marked the first in the school's history. hundreds of people gathered for a vigil at the university over the weekend in support of redus.
409	apple has paid $60 million to a taiwanese firm, shenzhen proview, to acquired the trademark rights to the name "ipad" in china. proview had originally trademarked the name in 2001 but sold it to apple for around $55,000 in 2009. however, chinese authorities did not recognize the sale and ruled last year that proview still owned the name. the dispute, which did not impact the demand for apple products in china, had seen proview seeking up to $400 million. proview had accused apple of using a shell company and concealing its true identity during negotiations. the dispute saw several fake apple stores being discovered in china, but it's unclear if the gadgets they were selling were genuine or counterfeit. china is apple's second-biggest market and the dispute's resolution ends months of legal battles between the two companies.
410	harry derbidge, a former star of the only way is essex, revealed on itv's this morning that he has battled with "food phobia" issues for over a decade, leading him to starve himself and weigh just 7st 7lbs. derbidge, now 20, spoke openly about his struggle with fussy eating that turned into ocd, affecting his weight and overall health. he shared that his mother had always been concerned about his weight and doctors urged him to enter a rehab clinic if he continued losing weight. derbidge described feeling tired, lazy, and cold due to his lack of nutrients and energy. he started changing his eating habits, focusing on plain food and eating six small meals a day. with the support of doctors and therapists, he gained weight and is now a happier and healthier 10st. harry is now committed to helping children with eating issues and wants to visit schools to share his story and inspire positivity.
411	chechnya, as ruled by president ramzan kadyrov, has been declared safer than england by the chechen leader, despite the british foreign office advising against travel to the region due to terrorism and crime risks. the tsarnaev brothers, responsible for the boston marathon bombing, have links to chechnya, making international headlines and causing concerns about safety. chechnya, once known for violence during the civil war and declared the most destroyed city on earth by the un, has since undergone significant rebuilding and stability under kadyrov's rule but remains under criticism for alleged human rights violations and corruption. moscow continues to fight militants in the north caucasus region, where chechnya, dagestan, and ingushetia have seen sporadic attacks and militant clashes. chechnya sought independence from russia in 1991, leading to a war that displaced 250,000 people and lasted years, with rebel attacks and hostage-taking occurring around russia. rebels in chechnya are suspected of having ties to islamic terror groups but are considered less of a concern for travelers in other parts of russia.
412	queens park rangers have appointed former england manager glenn hoddle as their first-team coach, making a return to football after an eight-year absence. hoddle, who has managed his country and coached at swindon, chelsea, and england, will help implement a new 3-5-2 formation at loftus road, as qpr manager harry redknapp looks to stay in the premier league. hoddle, who worked as a television pundit since leaving wolverhampton wanderers, will also continue his punditry work while at qpr and will be allowed to leave should a management role arise. rio ferdinand, who played under hoddle for england, will likely play as a sweeper in the new system, with steven caulker and clint hill as centre-backs. qpr are still looking to strengthen their squad, targeting a defensive midfielder and considering moves for momo diame and lassana diarra.
