413	a nsw physiotherapist, youngjin jung, who was on bail for raping and indecently assaulting a patient was re-arrested after two more women alleged they were indecently assaulted during physiotherapy sessions at a central coast clinic. youngjin, 34, was originally arrested on june 7 for an incident at umina beach road physiotherapy clinic and was scheduled to appear in court on june 17. the new alleged victims, aged 47 and 52, contacted police following youngjin's arrest, and he was charged with four additional counts of indecent assault. he spent the night behind bars and appeared at gosford bail court on june 8, where he was granted strict conditional bail. investigations are ongoing, and police are urging anyone with information to come forward.
414	raif badawi, a saudi blogger, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and 1,000 lashes for "insulting islam" and "founding a liberal website." he endured the first 50 lashes in january, but due to his injuries, the next 50 was postponed. a medical assessment on wednesday found him too injured to receive the lashes, but amnesty international urged the saudi authorities to cease the flogging and release badawi immediately. the case has received international criticism, with some questioning if saudi arabia's human rights abuses, including lashes and beheadings, have bought the world's silence.
415	edward snowden, who leaked sensitive information about u.s. spy programs and currently resides in russia with a one-year asylum, stated in an online chat that he won't return to the united states unless laws are changed to provide better whistleblower protection. snowden criticized the current whistleblower protection act, arguing that it doesn't adequately protect individuals like him who leaked government information. he also maintained that the government's stance of not considering clemency for him remains firm. the u.s. government continues to insist that snowden should return to face charges of espionage and theft of government property. snowden's disclosures led to intense scrutiny of the national security agency's surveillance programs and spurred president obama to announce reforms. however, critics argue that the reforms do not go far enough and that bulk collection of phone records should end, as it has proven ineffective in thwarting terrorism and has allegedly violated the constitution multiple times. snowden, who claimed that "not all spying is bad," stressed that his issue was with mass surveillance and the indiscriminate collection of data on entire populations.
416	two fishermen had to abandon their sinking boat, snowdonia, and swim in the freezing irish sea 12 miles east of kilkeel harbor. the tribute, another fishing vessel, witnessed the incident and the crew watched in horror as snowdonia rapidly sank, forcing the two fishermen to escape. both men survived but one was briefly submerged in the water. the belfast coastguard was alerted and the rnli lifeboat from kilkeel rescued the fishermen, who were later airlifted to daisy hill hospital in newry for medical treatment. the coastguard urged the importance of wearing lifejackets and maintaining them in good condition.
417	the magnum entertainment group holdings' prospectus for a new stock offering in hong kong, which owns three nightclubs, has garnered attention for its humorous definitions of late-night lingo. the document defines clubs as establishments with a dance floor and high-energy music, where club-goers often buy alcoholic beverages like champagne and cocktails. there's a trend of "club-hopping," where customers visit multiple clubs in one night, and vips receive special privileges like free entry and storage of unfinished bottles. additionally, hong kong clubs require dancing endorsements to operate, and the document has already seen magnum shares trading near double the offering price.
418	lord charles brocket, a peer with a past including jail time and reality tv, attempted to reclaim valued family heirlooms and antiques worth millions from his leased estate, brocket hall in hertfordshire. he hired removal men to take the items, but was stopped by police on the a1m motorway, resulting in a investigation into a reported theft. the items, including works by van dyck and daniele mytens, had been licensed to a tenant since lord brocket was jailed in 1996 for a fraudulent insurance claim and could not afford to maintain the estate. the tenant, brocket hall (jersey) ltd, failed to return the items despite requests. the trustees of the first lord brocket will trust, which owns the property, ended the licence and took back the items through legal means. the incident was reported as a theft but was not one as lord brocket was entitled to the goods. the tenant did not comment on the matter.
419	cbs's crime series "48 hours" is airing parts of a haunting voicemail recorded during the last minutes of danielle thomas' life, despite her mother's objections. thomas was murdered by her live-in boyfriend, jason bohn, in new york in 2012. the voicemail, which includes danielle's screams and pleas for her life, was played during bohn's trial earlier this year but hasn't been heard publicly outside the courtroom. cbs obtained a copy through the freedom of information act. danielle's mother, janie bright, left the courtroom when the recording was being played during the trial and doesn't want to hear it on television. she has already heard part of it in a promotional video for the show. the recording is used sparingly and is intended to provide context to the case, which raises issues about mental illness, childhood trauma, and the importance of reporting abusive relationships. bohn had a history of violence and danielle had a protection order against him at the time of her death. his defense argued that his mental illness, caused by abandonment as a child, led him to commit the murder. the prosecution disagrees. cbs said they did not use the material randomly or gratuitously.
420	a three-year-old girl named audrey, with long dark hair and dark brown eyes, was abandoned at the valet parking area of the grove shopping center in los angeles on saturday. she was wearing purple pants and a pink shirt at the time. the girl's father contacted police on sunday after seeing a news report about her disappearance, and he was eventually identified as her father. the attendants had seen a woman believed to be a relative drop off audrey with a car seat but no one arrived to pick her up. the girl was in good shape when she was found and is currently being evaluated by children and family services to determine if she will be reunited with her father. the search for her family was hampered initially due to her inability to provide any information about her parents. there were reports of people offering gifts or a home to audrey, who was treated as a missing child by the police until her father came forward. her father had been looking for her at the grove until late on saturday night and assumed she had been taken home by the person she was with. audrey's grandfather spotted her picture on the news and informed her father. the case is currently being treated as a misunderstanding by the police.
421	david cameron appeared in the controversial top gear india special but did not enjoy the show, according to downing street sources. the bbc programme sparked anger from viewers and the indian high commission due to its insensitive and tasteless humor. the indian high commission demanded an apology from the bbc for the episode, which included jeremy clarkson stripping to his underwear in front of his indian hosts and offensive banners attached to trains. the show's producer had promised a light-hearted road trip focusing on beautiful scenery and local car culture, but instead, the team drove around with a toilet attached to their car and displayed offensive messages. the episode received over 23 complaints and was criticized for its lack of cultural sensitivity. clarkson, one of the bbc's highest-paid stars, has a history of making controversial statements.
422	a new documentary, "dead famous dna," claims that elvis presley's premature death may have been caused by an undiagnosed genetic condition rather than his lifestyle alone. scientists analyzed a sample of elvis' hair and found evidence of a gene mutation linked to heart muscle disease, obesity, glaucoma, and migraines. elvis, who suffered from addiction to junk food and prescription drugs, died of cardiac arrhythmia at age 42. the scientists extracted nearly 90% of elvis' genome, which revealed four major chromosome mutations. one mutation was linked to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which may have contributed to his symptoms such as irregular heartbeat, fatigue, and fainting. the documentary sheds light on elvis' early death and challenges the common belief that his lifestyle was solely to blame.
423	tetris, celebrated on its 30th anniversary on june 6 as world tetris day, is a popular game that hooks players with the satisfaction of tidying up and completing perpetual uncompleted tasks. dr. tom stafford, a psychologist from the university of sheffield, explains the game takes advantage of the zeigarnik effect, where unfinished tasks are easier to remember than completed ones. most players use visual comparison to fit falling shapes into rows rather than mentally rotating them, as it is more efficient and aligns with the principle of "thinking with it" rather than "thinking about it." this epistemic action keeps players immersed and addicted to the perpetual loop of completing and generating new tasks. tetris, the "granddaddy of addictive puzzle games," proves that graphics and realism are not essential for game addiction.
424	a study conducted by teeth whitening brand blanx found that the average woman will discard two unwanted beauty gifts worth £26.36 each this christmas, totaling £676 million nationally. women are particular about their beauty products, preferring tried-and-tested brands they trust, with 70% continuing to use the same products due to positive experiences. one in five admit to disposing of gifts costing £60 or more that don't meet their preferences. men are advised to safely choose bath and body products, make-up, or fragrances, but only if they know the preferred brand of the recipient. british women are known for their loyalty to their favorite brands and are not afraid to discard unused or inappropriate beauty items.
425	a woman identified as diamond lawrence, 25, was caught shoplifting $11 worth of frozen food at a walmart in dallas, texas. when confronted by an employee, she threatened to infect him with hiv and scratched his neck in an attempt to draw blood. lawrence was wearing a medical wristband identifying her as hiv positive. the employee was checked out by emergency crews but no bodily fluid was exchanged. walmart chose not to press charges for the small theft but asked lawrence to not return to the store. she had two outstanding arrest warrants and is now in the dallas county jail with a $1,500 bail. lawrence allegedly told the employee "you're welcome" after the attack.
426	juventus came from behind to defeat bologna 4-1, with alessandro del piero scoring twice to put pressure on inter milan at the top of the serie a table. massimo mutarelli put bologna ahead, but juventus dominated the second half for a win that puts them four points behind inter. elsewhere, genoa boosted their champions league hopes with a 1-0 win over 10-man cagliari, while milan crushed siena 5-1 with filippo inzaghi scoring his 300th career goal. roma were held to a 2-2 draw at sampdoria, with both teams missing chances to secure the champions league place.
427	former tennessee senator howard baker, who passed away recently, is best known for asking the vital question during the watergate scandal: "what did the president know and when did he know it?" the scandal, which began with a break-in at the democratic national committee headquarters in 1972 and subsequent obstruction of justice attempts, led to the supreme court ordering the release of white house recordings and the house judiciary committee's approval of three articles of impeachment against president richard nixon. the era was marked by intense distrust towards the government, revealed through the daily unfolding of the sordid activities of the nixon administration. in his book "the invisible bridge," author rick perlstein details the impact of watergate on american politics, which continues to reverberate through the political spectrum. for both democrats and republicans, the scandal has shaped the way they approach governance, as they grapple with the public's lack of trust in elected officials. political scandals continue to take up the washington's attention, sometimes leading to much-needed reforms but also diverting it from major issues. watergate's enduring legacy is a profound distrust of the government and the resulting decline in public faith. reforms, such as stricter campaign finance regulations and stricter restrictions on the revolving door between government and lobbying, are considered essential to rebuild trust in government.
428	danny blanchflower, who passed away 21 years ago, is best remembered for his observation that "the game is about glory. it's about doing things in style, with a flourish, about going out and beating the other lot, not waiting for them to die of boredom." this belief, shared by various revered figures in sport, including sir alex ferguson and brian clough, was considered romantic and idealistic by some, but essential to the spirit of sport. sport has been described as a "glorious irrelevance," and while it may seem trivial, it generates a sense of wonder and peak experiences for many. however, sport also faces challenges such as the use of performance-enhancing drugs and the concentration of wealth in certain leagues and sports. despite these issues, the majesty and brilliance of athletes and teams throughout history continue to make sport a worthwhile pursuit.
429	pragaat singh, a 35-year-old businessman, was shot and killed by armed robbers outside his food wholesale business in manchester, england. the incident occurred on friday night as singh was locking up with his nephew. the robbers made off with "tens of thousands of pounds" of company takings, shooting singh twice in the chest and stomach. witnesses described singh as a "true gentleman" who went out of his way to help others, and he leaves behind a wife and three young children. the offenders are described as a black male in his twenties or thirties, with spiky, knotted hair and a tall, slim build. police are appealing for information and have released cctv footage of the incident. detective superintendent jon chadwick condoled the family's loss, stating that singh had been trying to protect his livelihood. a visible police presence remains in the area to ensure public safety.
430	english cricket player kevin pietersen, currently with the england team in australia for the ashes series, was fined by australian police for speeding in a lamborghini given to him by former australian cricket star shane warne. pietersen was named man of the match after scoring a double century in the second test, which england won to take a 1-0 lead. warne, who retired in 2007, is the subject of comeback talk due to england's strong performance, and a website "bringbackwarne.com" has been set up to encourage his return. pietersen was fined $235 and lost three points for driving at 121 kph. another high-profile figure to face australian police was formula one driver lewis hamilton, who was fined for anti-social driving in march. in the uk, former england footballer paul gascoigne was given a suspended jail term for drink-driving.
431	blackburn rovers have experienced stability under manager gary bowyer, who has been in charge for 15 months and is the eighth longest-serving manager in the championship. the team has gone undefeated in five pre-season games and has not lost since march, finishing last season with a 12-match unbeaten run. in their latest match against stoke city, blackburn opened the scoring with a header from jordan rhodes, but stoke equalized through a fine strike from bojan. despite limited transfer activity, blackburn retain faith in rhodes, who is one of the most clinical strikers in english football. stoke, without a pre-season win, showcased patient and enterprising play with bojan proving to be a standout player. both teams displayed organized and committed performances, and the season opener against cardiff city at ewood park is met with optimism.
432	more than 2,000 protesters clashed with police in sao paulo, marking the beginning of demonstrations against the world cup tournament in brazil. locals are concerned about the financial strain on public services such as health and education. protesters chanted and carried banners, some engaging in violent acts including setting fires, smashing windows, and attacking atms. 'operation stop the world cup' was mentioned as the name of this and future protests. police were unable to prevent the attacks. protesters argue for spending on public services instead of the world cup. similar protests occurred in rio de janeiro and other cities last year with complaints about bus fares, poor public services, and corruption.
433	chris heaton-harris, the conservative mp for daventry, has agreed to help ian taylor, a local father, in his campaign to change "mother and child" parking signs to gender-neutral "parent and child" signs. taylor has been unsuccessful in getting the signs altered with the local council and car park operators, colliers international. heaton-harris intends to investigate if the current signs breach sex discrimination laws and will bring the matter up with the leader and chief executive of daventry district council on taylor's behalf. colliers international managing the car park on behalf of a client but have been in contact with taylor and are working to get the signs changed. taylor argues for sexual equality and considers the issue important, despite it not being priority over more pressing concerns.
434	a young couple, louis kefferty (20) and lauren white (18), were enjoying their perfect christmas together until a tragic car crash took the life of louis on christmas eve. the incident occurred when louis's red vauxhall astra left the road and collided with a tree near seafield, west lothian. lauren, who was seriously injured, paid tribute to her boyfriend to whom she attributed saving her life on social media. in her emotional post, she acknowledged their wonderful relationship and the unfillable void created by his loss. the crash occurred at around 11:05 am on tuesday on the a705 near seafield. police have requested witnesses to come forward and investigate the circumstances surrounding the incident. louis's family and friends, including his cousin, expressed their shock and sadness over his sudden demise. an appeal from sergeant brian jones urges anyone with related information to contact the police.
435	in tehran, iran, on tuesday, supporters of president mahmoud ahmadinejad and his main political rival, mir hossein moussavi, held separate rallies following last week's disputed presidential election. ahmadinejad's supporters gathered at vali asr square, while moussavi's followers assembled at a different location. the iranian government blocked international journalists from covering the rallies and banned them from leaving their hotels. iran's guardian council announced a partial vote recount in response to accusations of electoral fraud. however, moussavi rejected the recount and demanded fresh elections. three reformist politicians were arrested for their alleged involvement in post-election violence. protests and clashes between moussavi's supporters and security forces continued, resulting in several deaths. world leaders, including u.s. president barack obama, expressed concerns over the election outcome and the use of force against protesters. european ambassadors received protests from the iranian foreign ministry for interfering in iran's internal affairs.
436	a high court judge described a case where a father systematically abused and severely injured his four-month-old daughter in a series of "diabolical" and "macabre" attacks over a three-month period. the father admitted to the assaults but will remain unnamed due to a controversial decision by judges to protect his identity when he is released from prison. the baby girl sustained numerous injuries, including a broken neck, severe damage to her spine, five broken ribs, and multiple fractures to both legs. her mother, who was described as "controlling," "needy," and "dictatorial," was found guilty of neglect. the judge expressed shock at the father's admissions, which he found to be entirely unexplainable and a violation of societal taboos. the father was sentenced to 12 years in prison and will remain anonymous when released. the judge called for the crown prosecution service to decide on prosecuting the mother at the earliest opportunity. the case was considered the most chilling in the judge's 30-year career.
437	over 500 employees of nexen energy in calgary, canada, broke the guinness world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as batman. they donned full body outfits, capes, masks, and yellow belts to exceed the previous record of 250. the event, which took place on september 18, 2023, was part of nexen's annual united way campaign and aimed to promote unity and support for the united way of calgary and area. the record attempt featured various comic book characters, including batman, joker, and robin. nexen energy, which previously set the record for the largest gathering of people dressed as superman in 2011, continues to demonstrate its unique approach to charity initiatives.
438	nino selimaj, the owner of bellissima pizza in manhattan, has created a luxurious $1,000 pizza topped with high-end caviar, thinly sliced lobster, creme fraiche, chives, and wasabi paste. the pizza, which features two of the world's top caviar varieties, has been a hit among high earners, including politicians, wall street traders, and wealthy couples. hundreds of people have already purchased the decadent dish, making it one of the most expensive pizzas in the world. nino, who has been serving caviar in his restaurants for 33 years, spent three months perfecting the recipe. steveston pizza co. in canada also offers a caviar pizza for $450, but has only had one taker. the most expensive pizza on record was sold in malta for $2,380 and included white truffles, a 24-karat gold leaf, and buffalo mozzarella.
439	outgoing republican congresswoman michele bachmann, known for her religious beliefs, cited the ten commandments as the foundation of the us's prosperity and happiness during her final speech on the house floor tuesday. she referred to the country's motto, "in god we trust," and the statue of moses above the chamber doors. bachmann, a tea party ally, also expressed gratitude to her supporters, family, and god while touching on the limits of government and the divine origin of individual rights. bachmann is under investigation by the house ethics committee for campaign finance violations, which will end when she leaves congress in january.
440	a mentally disabled man, zhao yanli, was severely beaten by two nurses and an orderly at the shenyang people's military psychiatric hospital in liaoning province, china. cctv footage shows the hospital staff kicking and stamping on zhao in his bed before dragging him onto the floor. his brother discovered him injured and barely conscious in the television room, covered in bruises. zhao was immediately taken to the emergency ward but doctors said he was crippled and would likely never regain the use of his legs if he survived. the attack reportedly occurred in response to an offensive comment zhao supposedly made to a female nurse. the family has hired a lawyer, refusing the hospital's £37,000 compensation offer, and plans to sue the hospital for allowing the assault and failing to inform them of zhao's injuries. at least ten other people were present in the room during the assault, but none tried to intervene.
441	a recent discovery of new craters in siberia and "vast methane plumes" in the arctic ocean raise concerns about the release of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from thawing permafrost and collapsing methane hydrates. the released methane contributes to global warming, with airborne methane producing 86 times the heat-trapping effect of carbon dioxide. this process, known as a positive feedback loop, is escalating as warmer temperatures cause more methane to be released, which in turn leads to more warming. the increase in atmospheric methane started with human activities, primarily burning fossil fuels and extracting natural gas through fracking, which results in methane leaks. to reduce methane emissions and mitigate the consequences, individuals and governments need to acknowledge the human role in causing this issue and invest in cleaner energy alternatives, such as wind and solar power, instead of relying on natural gas.
442	silver could significantly increase the effectiveness of antibiotics against antibiotic-resistant bacteria. in experiments on mice, giving silver with antibiotics made them ten to a thousand times more effective. professors dame sally davies and jim collins have warned of the growing threat of antibiotic resistance, which could leave millions vulnerable to untreatable bugs. silver, with its long-known antibacterial properties, is generally ineffective when used alone due to high doses required which can be poisonous. the recent study suggests using silver in small amounts with existing antibiotics is safe and may revolutionize antibiotic treatment by enhancing their effectiveness against antibiotic-resistant strains. the researchers from boston university discovered that silver makes bacteria more permeable, allowing antibiotics to enter and kill them, as well as aiding the production of reactive oxygen molecules that help in bacterial death. this approach to antibiotic development could potentially tackle various infections, including stomach bugs, urinary tract infections, and films of bacteria on catheters.
443	george zimmerman's trial has ended with his acquittal, but he faces unclear financial prospects. donations totaling hundreds of thousands of dollars were raised for his defense, and critics accuse him of profiting from the case. zimmerman's legal team said the trial has taken a toll on him, making it difficult for him to find work in public without fear for his safety. zimmerman previously studied criminal justice and attempted to become a police officer but was rejected due to bad credit. reputation management expert mike paul advised him to choose a new career path that is more compassionate and not related to law enforcement. the future includes potential civil lawsuits, federal charges, and his ongoing defamation lawsuit against nbc. despite the ongoing debates and controversy surrounding the case, it remains unclear what this means for zimmerman's income.
444	water companies in the uk have imposed an 11-point restricted list to prevent 20 million people from exploiting loopholes during a hosepipe ban due to the drought-hit south and eastern regions. the ban includes using a hose or sprinkler to water plants, wash cars or boats, fill swimming pools, and clean patios, driveways, or windows. even keeping children cool with a hose or spraying them will be prohibited, with a £1,000 fine for violations. seven water companies, including anglian water, southern, southeast, thames, veolia southeast, veolia central, and sutton and east surrey water, have announced the temporary ban starting from april 5. the rules aim to close loopholes following accusations of cheating during the last hosepipe ban in 2006. the restrictions are necessary due to two years of chronically low rainfall that has left rivers dry and reservoirs at record low levels. the environment agency warned that without persistent above-average rainfall, the unpopular measures could last until the end of the summer, and more water companies and industries may be affected. forecasters predict low chances of heavy rain between march and may, and groundwater levels are lower than during the 1976 drought when taps were switched off in some cities. consumers' water use at home could lead to further economic consequences if not reduced.
445	on the 25th anniversary of the river thames marchioness pleasure boat tragedy that claimed the lives of 51 young people, their families and some survivors gathered at southwark cathedral in london to remember them. the names of the victims were read out, and flowers and candles were placed in their memory. the disaster occurred on august 20, 1989, when the marchioness collided with the dredger bowbelle and sank. among those who died was francesca dallaglio, the sister of former england rugby captain lawrence dallaglio, and antonio de vasconcellos, whose 26th birthday was being celebrated aboard the boat. the cathedral was filled with red roses and candles in honor of each victim, and representatives from the royal national lifeboat institution and port of london authority attended the service. families placed flowers at the spot on the river where the accident happened. it took ten years for a public inquiry to be held into the disaster following the first report from the marine accident investigation branch, which stated that both vessels failed to mount a proper look-out. however, critics felt that the report did not go far enough in assigning blame, leading to the eventual public inquiry in 2001. the inquiry concluded that the disaster was 'a catastrophe that should never have happened.' the families also had to cope with the decision to cut off the hands of more than 20 victims for identification purposes and criticism of the conduct of the captains and owners of the vessels. in 1996, the crown prosecution service determined that there was insufficient evidence to bring any further criminal proceedings against the captains.
446	protesters demonstrated outside the metropolitan opera against the production of john adams' opera "the death of klinghoffer," which dramatizes the hijacking of a cruise ship in 1985 and the subsequent killing of a jewish american passenger, leon klinghoffer. former mayor rudolph giuliani and others attended a rally against the opera, while 100 protesters sat in wheelchairs in front of the opera house in solidarity with klinghoffer. inside, some attendees disrupted the performance with shouts and heckling, leading to one arrest for disorderly conduct. the opera's depiction of the palestinians liberation front and their actions was criticized by some as making "false moral equivalencies" and legitimizing terrorism. the met's general manager, peter gelb, was a target of the protests and accusations of taking money from terrorists. klinghoffer's daughters have also decried the opera as romanticizing their father's murder. the met originally planned to broadcast the opera live in november but cancelled the broadcast after pressure from jewish groups fearing it could fuel antisemitism. the opera does not absolve the killers and ends with marilyn klinghoffer condemning both her husband's killers and the captain for accommodating them.
447	the toronto international film festival (tiff) featured five noteworthy takeaways. alexandra skarsgard received enthusiastic reception despite kirsten dunst's quip about his acting in "melancholia." woody harrelson gave a commanding performance in "rampart," earning him potential oscar consideration. the classics are going multicultural with "wuthering heights" casting black actors and "tess of the d'urbervilles" being set in modern-day india. michael fassbender continued exploring sexual themes in "a dangerous method" and "shame." ryan gosling's past roles, such as "breaker high," continued to follow him, with fans refusing to let him forget them.
448	in saudi arabia, where women require male permission to work, rent property, and travel, a small number of determined females are defying social constraints to establish thriving businesses. these women, including maria mahdaly, founder of media and publishing house rumman in jeddah, have achieved significant economic success, with an estimated $11.9 billion being held by women in bonds and bank accounts. the government's recognition of women's role in the country's economic development has led to legislative changes, enabling women to vote and work in various industries. mahdaly's business, rumman, includes a city magazine and a social network, and in 2010 was ranked as saudi arabia's fastest-growing start-up. despite facing challenges and cultural pressures, female entrepreneurs, driven by a desire for social change and a sense of patriotism, remain committed to building their businesses in saudi arabia, with some even displaying confrontational behavior to overcome obstacles. however, establishing a business as a woman in saudi arabia still requires significant resources and support from family and the community.
449	american freestyle skier heidi kloser suffered a devastating injury, fracturing her femur and tearing her acl during a training run before the moguls qualifying at the olympics. she was taken to a medical clinic in the olympic village and is expected to undergo surgery. her father described the incident on facebook, stating that she was bummed about not being able to compete and hoping to walk in the opening ceremony. the risk of knee injuries is a constant concern in the sport, and heidi, a five-year veteran of the us team with several top-10 finishes, was ranked fourth entering the competition. heather mcphie, who qualified 14th, acknowledged the disappointment but acknowledged that such injuries are part of the sport.
450	a 20-year-old man named viraj mashru, along with his co-conspirator amit patel, faked his own kidnapping in an attempt to swindle his wealthy businessman father rajendra mashru out of £620,000 worth of gold bullion. the father, who runs a logistics firm in mombasa, kenya with over 300 vehicles, was convinced that his son had been taken to the uk and would be harmed if the ransom was not paid. the two conspirators, who were hiding in bristol and a hotel in wembley, were arrested by police and later pleaded guilty to conspiracy to blackmail at southwark crown court. two other alleged co-conspirators, marcus bennett and liban mohamed, were also remanded in custody pending their next appearance in court.
451	former president bill clinton's monthly satellite tv bill, which includes premium motion picture channels and dvr service, is paid for by taxpayers to the tune of $184.26. his office in harlem, new york also receives government funding of $1 million for business-related expenses, which includes a $322.40 annual digital subscription to the new york times. the details of clinton's spending were revealed following a freedom of information act request and have prompted calls for changes in how government funds are distributed to former presidents. his predecessors, jimmy carter and george h.w. bush, received $517,000 and $835,000 respectively for their business expenses. clinton has earned $89 million since leaving the white house, while george w. bush has already made $15 million in speaking fees. the general services administration, which disburses the funds to the former presidents, stated that each office determines its own expenses and services.
452	an australian man identified as harrison williams from mindarie, near perth, in western australia, shocked onlookers when he jumped off a boat and climbed onto a dead humpback whale carcass in open waters, disregarding the presence of several tiger sharks and at least one white shark circling the body. the whale, reportedly the responsibility of the fremantle port authority, has been floating between rottnest and fremantle for several weeks, and western australia's surf life saving warned of numerous tiger sharks in the area. mr. williams, an extreme sports lover, confirmed to daily mail australia that he was the man seen sitting on the whale and stated that he had tried to help the apparently distressed whale but was too late. twitter users found the situation amusing, with some implying that such behavior was only possible in australia. however, authorities and experts advised against attempting to enter the water near a large food source like a dead whale, as the presence of sharks increases significantly. a recent incident involved a man being trailed by a three-metre great white shark while surfing near esperance. witnesses urged caution and reminded individuals of the risks associated with entering the water around large food sources.
453	shaun lacey, a 40-year-old man with a long history of violence, killed his mother's neighbor, damien fyson, 37, just three weeks after being released from prison early for beating another man with a baseball bat. lacey, who had 18 previous convictions for violence dating back to 1991, encountered fyson while drinking and stabbed him in the chest with a pair of kitchen scissors as he slept. fyson, who worked for a charity organization, suffered fatal injuries and bled to death at the scene. lacey was jailed for 17 and a half years after admitting manslaughter. the judge criticized the early release of lacey, expressing concern over his escalating violence fueled by excessive drinking. the family of the victim expressed their relief that justice was served.
454	former owner tony porter has criticized plans to install 200 solar panels on burgh island off the south devon coast, which was once a source of inspiration for crime writer agatha christie. the proposed solar panels, planned for a former tennis court, would be concealed by hedges according to the current owners. however, some opponents argue that the solar panels would spoil the island's beauty and be visible from miles away. tony porter, who sold the island in 2001, expressed his shock and disappointment over the application, while four objections have been submitted to south hams council, including one from a neighbor and hubert ashton, who writes, "putting solar panels where you suggest will be visible from all around on the mainland and ruin any walks that people might want to take on the island, thus presumably having a negative impact on visitor numbers." a spokesman for the council stated that every application is considered individually based on its merits.
455	the montana supreme court has reversed a lower court's decision and ordered the reinstatement of charges against christina nadine nelson, a 23-year-old married mother from billings, for allegedly fabricating multiple rape and assault claims between 2009 and 2012. the first instance involved a false report of rape during her prom night, and subsequent accusations included a claim of assault by her ex-boyfriend. police found inconsistencies in her statements, including fabricated evidence and conflicting accounts of her whereabouts. prosecutors argue that nelson had a pattern of accusing young men she had dated of rape or assault when no such incidents had occurred. her current whereabouts are unknown, as she had traveled out of the country after the charges were dismissed last july.
456	restaurants in britain have removed scottish lobster from their menus due to poor weather conditions and subsequent price hikes. fishermen in scotland have reported a 90% decrease in lobster catches and damage to their gear. the extended cold weather and storms have forced lobsters and other crustaceans to stay further out to sea. prices have risen significantly, causing restaurants like langan's brasserie and gamba glasgow to remove lobster dishes from their menus. lobster catches in scotland's clyde fisheries area have also decreased by up to 70%, and the scottish creel fishermen's federation estimates that overall creel fishing in scotland is worth around £39m a year. fishermen have been unable to repair their damaged gear or get far enough out to sea due to rough seas and storms, leaving them struggling financially. alternative seafood options, such as crabs and english asparagus, are being offered in affected restaurants.
457	ryan dunn, a "jackass" star, was driving drunk and at high speeds when his porsche 911 gt3 crashed and caught fire on a pennsylvania highway monday, resulting in his death and that of zachary hartwell, a former colleague in one of dunn's movies. police reported the vehicle was traveling between 132-140 mph, and dunn's blood alcohol concentration was 0.196%. dunn, who was 34, was known for his pranks and stunts on the show, and hartwell, 30, worked as a stunt car driver on a comedy film featuring dunn. the crash occurred near barnaby's bar, where dunn was drinking before the wreck, and he was not seen as intoxicated at the time he left. dunn appeared on nbc's "minute to win it" and hosted "proving ground" on the g4 channel.
458	a woman, molly shattuck, 47, has resigned from her position on the baltimore school for the arts board after being charged with third-degree rape, unlawful sexual contact, four counts of providing alcohol to minors, and three counts of rape in the third degree for performing oral sex on a 15-year-old boy. the relationship began when she contacted the minor on instagram and met him in person later that summer. they began meeting for private trysts in her cadillac escalade and later at her beach house, during which she allegedly engaged in sexual activities with him. the case came to light when the victim's father reported it to the police after finding evidence on shattuck's phone and computer, which were seized during a search warrant. shattuck is currently separated from her billionaire businessman husband, mayo shattuck iii, and they have three children. she is also a fitness consultant and author. she was released on $84,000 bond and has been charged with providing alcohol to three minors. the case is currently under investigation.
459	a six-year-old boy named joshua blackaby from derby, england, was amazed when he received a letter from a girl named millie in east kurrajong, new south wales, australia, who had found a helium balloon from his school project in her backyard. the balloon had traveled an impressive 10,545 miles during its journey. the school, wyndham primary academy, had launched 300 tagged balloons as part of a project, and joshua's balloon was the one that made it to australia. millie returned the balloon and tag to joshua, and the school was considering inviting a weather expert to help determine how the balloon had traveled such a great distance. the children were excitedly writing stories about the balloon's adventures and looking forward to writing back to millie. joshua's mother was also amazed by the balloon's journey. charlie powell from the met office was not surprised by the event, as such occurrences are not unheard of.
460	an amish man accused of cutting the beards and hair of fellow amish men in a series of hate crimes in ohio last year, levi miller, reportedly admitted regret for his involvement and claimed he would have cut off more if he had been caught earlier, according to a holmes county detective. the defendants, including miller, are members of a breakaway amish group and are facing charges of conspiracy, assault, and evidence tampering in the attacks, which were reportedly carried out as punishment and meant to humiliate amish members who believe in keeping beards and long hair as a sign of devotion to god. the defendants' defense team has tried to portray the attacks as internal church disciplinary matters, but prosecutors argue they are religion-based hate crimes. the trial, which started last week, could last several weeks and the defendants could face lengthy prison terms if convicted. the accused "ringleader," sam mullet sr., is also on trial but has denied ordering the attacks. the amish community has left the cleveland federal courthouse in support of the defendants.
461	an australian photographer, jane long, has brought back to life black and white images from the costică acsinte archive on flickr. the romanian photographer, costică acsinte, died in 1984, and his 5,000 images were digitized by photo enthusiast cezar popescu since 2013. long was fascinated by the post-war images and their subjects and created a new series called 'the dancing with costica.' long worked as a graphic designer for 20 years but shifted to photography two years ago. she admits to being drawn to the hauntingly beautiful original images and enjoys creating fantasy scenes around them. she restored and recolored the images and describes her concept as the complete opposite of the original images. long has a favorite image, "innocence," which took the longest to develop a story for. she plans to continue working on restoring images and is currently working on a similar project. the post-war images in the costică acsinte archive were digitized by cezar popescu. some of her favorites from the series are "singalong," "above," and "all hands on deck."
462	an irish catholic priest, father martin mcveigh, has asked to leave his parish and take sabbatical leave from the priesthood following an incident in which he accidentally displayed naked men's pictures to parents during a powerpoint presentation for children preparing for their first holy communion in march. the catholic church in ireland launched an investigation after parents expressed their horror and called for action against the priest. no crime was found to have been committed, but mcveigh apologized for the incident and admitted destroying the memory stick containing the images out of shock. the latest controversy comes after a series of child sex abuse scandals involving catholic clergy in ireland, with thousands of children reportedly abused over the last 80 years, and a major report from the vatican seeking forgiveness from victims. mcveigh maintains his innocence, but the incident has caused a traumatic time for the parish community, and mcveigh apologized for the hurt caused. the independent technical expert's examination of other computers used by mcveigh did not reveal any inappropriate imagery, but an additional laptop stolen from the local church sacristy was not part of the examination. the cardinal accepted mcveigh's request for leave, with the understanding he would return to the diocese upon its completion.
463	police in switzerland, france, and italy are searching for six-year-old twin sisters, alessia and livia schepp, who were abducted by their father, matthias schepp. the father was found dead on thursday in bari, italy, but there is no sign of the girls. interpol issued a missing persons alert for the girls on saturday, asking police in its 188 member countries for assistance. the father reportedly took the girls from their home in st. sulpice, near lausanne, switzerland, on january 30 due to personal problems. he was later seen driving through marseilles, france, and his body was discovered in italy on february 1. the girls are blonde, about 3 feet, 9 inches tall, and were last seen wearing specific clothing items. the investigation is currently focusing on switzerland, france, and italy.
464	a 24-year-old woman, katherine hooper, was accused of murdering her two young sons, joshua (5) and sam (2), after social services returned them to her care following her suicide attempt two weeks prior. hooper allegedly smothered sam in his bed and took joshua to a cliff on dartmoor, where she jumped off with him in front of horrified day-trippers. neighbor janette nolan expressed regret that social services did not protect hooper, describing her as vulnerable and innocent. hooper's estranged partner, neil patterson (52), faced charges of assaulting her, and hooper had been struggling financially and offered her cat to a neighbor due to her lack of resources. the house in paignton, devon, where the tragedy occurred was guarded by police, and a serious case review was planned. hooper had previously been identified as a vulnerable person by various welfare agencies.
465	thomas beatie, a transgender man who gained international attention in 2007 for giving birth after sex-reassignment surgery, was arrested in phoenix, arizona for stalking, allegedly placing a gps device on an ex-wife's car multiple times. he is currently held in maricopa county jail without bail on one charge of stalking. the victim is believed to be his former wife, nancy beatie, with whom he is in the process of divorcing. beatie kept his reproductive organs during the surgery and has three children with her. their earlier divorce attempt was denied due to arizona's ban on same-sex marriages, but a recent ruling recognized the hawaiian marriage as valid, allowing them to divorce within the state. judge kenton d. jones overturned the earlier ruling, granting the divorce without the couple having to travel to hawaii. beatie is now dating amber nicholas.
466	stephen sutton, the 19-year-old cancer victim and inspiration to the nation, was posthumously awarded an mbe for his selflessness and fundraising efforts for the teenage cancer trust. he was informed of the honor before his passing and expressed his excitement. stephen's mother, jane, was "truly delighted and immensely proud" of her son’s recognition. the birthday honours list included over 1,100 recipients, with about 11% for education and 8% for health workers. other notable honorees include martin lewis, ros altmann, dawn primarolo, bill cash, nicholas soames, and anthony seldon. professor colin blakemore, a neuroscientist who faced threats from animal rights activists, also received a knighthood.
467	the article discusses the growing threat of homegrown terrorists in the united states, radicalized by al qaeda's extremist ideology. some american citizens and long-term residents have traveled to pakistan to learn bomb-making skills and receive training from al qaeda. faisal shahzad and bryant neal vincent are two notable cases of americans radicalized in pakistan and accused of planning attacks against the united states. radicalization is on the rise in the us, and counterterrorism officials believe that interactive online social media sites and radical preachers spreading al qaeda's message in the us are contributing factors. two groups, the islamic thinkers society and revolution muslim, have come under scrutiny for attempting to spread al qaeda's ideology. u.s. counterterrorism officials are concerned that other americans may be radicalized through personal contact with proselytizers, and most serious plots directed at the west in recent years have seen plotters trained or directed by established jihadist groups in pakistan. videos have emerged of americans fighting with militants along the afghanistan-pakistan border, and counterterrorism officials worry about what happens when these fighters return to the us.
468	fans of hbo's "the wire" can re-experience the streets of baltimore through a five-day high definition remastered marathon of the series and a real-life location tour by baltimore sun reporter justin fenton. fenton has been visiting significant locations from the show, such as hamsterdam, and sharing pictures on twitter based on fan requests. some fans have also shared past and present images of places like the bar where frank and nick sobotka spent time with longshoremen. fenton has mentioned reviewing these submissions with a critical eye and encourages more fans to suggest scenes they'd like to see.
469	in this heartwarming article, published in november 2012, by adam shergold, 21 orangutans from the borneo orangutan survival (bos) foundation were released into the bukit batikap conservation forest in indonesia. the orangutans, including terusan, were filmed with great excitement as they explored their new environment for the first time, running and climbing trees. some of the orangutans had spent several years at the nyaru menteng orangutan rescue and rehabilitation centre before being prepared for release. among them were five mothers and their babies, who were not sedated during transport and walked calmly into the travel containers. the release marks a significant achievement for the bos foundation, which plans to release over 600 orangutans from nyaru menteng to meet a government target. the article includes several photographs of the orangutans, some of whom are seen looking unsure, while others are excited and curious about their new surroundings. the foundation plans to monitor the orangutans closely for up to a year to ensure they can fend for themselves in the wild.
470	us airways flight 1549, which crashed into the hudson river in 2009, resulted in all passengers and crew surviving due to quick rescue training and responses. the coast guard, ferries, and other boats, which were trained for water rescues, were at the scene within minutes. ferry captains like brittany catanzaro, who responded to the crash, train regularly for water rescues and were able to help bring 24 people aboard her ferry. the coast guard also coordinated with other maritime agencies and were able to rescue at least 35 people. catanzaro's quick actions and training possibly saved 24 lives, demonstrating the importance of water rescue training in saving lives, especially in cold water conditions where people can lose the use of their limbs within three minutes.
471	cat fletcher, a british woman from east sussex, has managed to furnish her three-bedroom semi-detached home with high-end items such as le creuset saucepans, a six-hob oven, a bosch dishwasher, and a 15ft palm tree completely free of charge. she has achieved this by scouring websites where people give away unwanted items, including charity shops and skips. fletcher, a mother of three, has also picked up second-hand sofas, cushions, cutlery, clothing, and linen. her unconventional approach has saved her at least £20,000 over the past five years. she is among the growing number of people in the uk using the online community freegle, which has 1.4 million members, to give and receive free items. fletcher, who was made redundant 18 months ago and used to work as a personal assistant to a university academic, is a keen environmentalist and believes there is no shame in taking free items. she is also working as a resource coordinator for brighton university. fletcher's favorite free item is a digital radio, and she only makes purchases of quality items that will last a long time.
472	commons speaker john bercow has criticized mps who have been critical of him, labeling them as "embittered and resentful" due to their own political career disappointments. bercow, a former conservative, accused some mps of sulking over his unexpected election to the position in 2009. he acknowledged losing his temper with critics but attempted to maintain self-control. bercow has faced accusations of unfairly favoring labour during commons exchanges and angered tory mps by hauling david cameron before the house for questioning. he defended his wife sally, a labour activist and reality tv star, from her critics, labeling them "no-hopers." bercow claimed to be uninterested in newspaper coverage and defended himself against allegations that he comes across as puffed up with importance.
473	two men, identified as william williams, 21, and richard cromwell, 20, have been arrested and charged with murder, robbery, and criminal possession of a weapon in the shooting death of corey mcgriff, also known as dj megatron, on staten island on march 27. mcgriff, 32, was best known for his appearances on bet's music countdown show, "106 & park," and had worked for the network since 2006. the bet networks released a statement expressing condolences to mcgriff's family and expressing sadness over his untimely death. both suspects are expected to be arraigned on thursday.
474	a syrian software engineer, dlshad othman, has developed an app called aymta (which means "when" in arabic) that alerts syrian residents if a scud missile is headed towards their location. the app calculates the trajectory and speed of the missile to determine its likely landing spot and sends warnings to subscribers to seek shelter. the technology was inspired by a friend's facebook post about a missile passing overhead in northern syria. the website, www.aymta.com, was launched in june and relies on seven volunteer spotters located in the hills outside damascus to gather missile information. the engineer, who had to flee syria in 2011 due to fears for his safety, hopes to adapt the app for other conflict zones. meanwhile, residents of the besieged syrian town of mouadamiya have appealed to the world for help, describing desperate conditions and the deaths of nearly 12,000 people due to the conflict which started in 2011 and has resulted in over 100,000 deaths overall. the government denies using chemicals weapons and holds opposition groups responsible for the suffering of residents. peace talks are planned in geneva next month, but so far the warring parties have shown little willingness to compromise.
475	kim watson, age 32, from clementon, new jersey, has been charged with stealing and selling $3.7 million worth of merchandise from sears, after allegedly taking it from the sears distribution center in logan township. a sears clerk, also unnamed, has been implicated and is under investigation. investigators believe the stolen items, ranging from bedding to kitchen appliances, were sold to a network of buyers in the new york tri-state area. the loss to sears is estimated to be around $2.6 million. watson was charged with second-degree theft and held at salem county jail on a $50,000 bail. the investigation, led by the gloucester county prosecutor's office, is ongoing as detectives search for the network of buyers and any potential accomplices.
476	john sweeney, a bbc reporter known for his angry outburst against scientology spokesperson tommy davis during a documentary interview in 2007, has published a new book claiming that the church of scientology believes the holocaust was planned and carried out by psychiatrists. his book, titled "the church of fear: inside the weird world of scientology," has placed him at risk of facing libel action from the cult. sweeney admitted his loss of temper during an exhibition on psychiatry at the church and wrote that scientologists believe psychiatry is "nazi pseudoscience" and that the holocaust was orchestrated by psychiatrists. despite the risks, sweeney has published the book with the help of a literary agent-turned-publisher. former scientology members mike rinder, tommy davis, and marc headley have reportedly supported sweeney and are also preparing to release books critiquing the church. the church of scientology, founded by l. ron hubbard in 1952, is known for its controversial beliefs that an ancient alien being named xenu brought billions of people to earth in spaceships and that psychiatry is responsible for the holocaust. the organization has faced numerous allegations of abusive practices, outrageous fees, and the abuse of followers, including reports of bizarre punishments and the vow to pledge allegiance for one billion years. the church courts hollywood stars like tom cruise and john travolta, but its beliefs are rarely spoken about publicly. cruise's marriage to katie holmes ended reportedly over her refusal to indoctrinate their daughter into scientology. the controversial beliefs and practices of scientology were also depicted in the recent cinema hit "the master." sweeney, prepared to face a legal battle, wrote, "you don't need capital to publish a book on scientology – you need courage."
477	arsenal's alexis sanchez and raheem sterling of liverpool will face off at anfield on sunday, with sanchez becoming a standout player since joining arsenal for £30m from barcelona. he brings a strong work ethic and finishing ability, reminiscent of liverpool's luis suarez and daniel sturridge. youngster sterling, who turned 21 this month, shares similar traits and has the potential to become a top player if he can develop his finishing skills, as suarez and theo walcott did earlier in their careers. both players exhibit impressive pace and potential, with sanchez contributing to arsenal's attack and sterling scoring twice in liverpool's league cup win over bournemouth.
478	tony scott, the british film director best known for movies like "top gun" and "beverly hills cop ii," died by suicide on sunday, september 19, 201queteen, by jumping from the vincent thomas bridge in san pedro, california. the medical investigators are still conducting an autopsy, but the apparent cause of death is suspected to be suicide. scott left two notes behind - one for his family, and the other for the investigators - but the content of the notes has not been disclosed. scott's wife, ridley scott's older brother, and the family disputed a report that he had inoperable brain cancer. the hollywood community mourned his death with an outpouring of tributes. scott began his career as an actor before transitioning to directing, achieving fame with "top gun" in 1986 and later directing several successful movies, including "days of thunder" and "enemy of the state." he is remembered for his distinctive cinematic style and his contributions to the film industry. the autopsy results are not yet available, and it remains unclear what led scott to take his own life.
479	sudanese government delegates are set to leave peace talks with darfur rebels in doha, qatar, but the presidential advisor in charge of the negotiations, ghazi salaheddin, stated that the government is not withdrawing from the negotiations. salahedin also mentioned that a draft peace deal could still be reached without the government delegation present. sudanese president omar al-bashir had previously stated that his negotiators would leave the talks if no agreement was reached by thursday, and that he would not negotiate with rebel groups bearing arms. the anti-government justice and equality movement, a rebel group in darfur, called al-bashir's statement a declaration of war and a limiting of future chances for peace. fighting in darfur, which began in 2003 between rebel groups and the government in khartoum, has resulted in over 300,000 deaths. the negotiators had previously set a december 31 deadline for agreement, ahead of a referendum on independence for southern sudan, which begins on january 9. the independence of the south may embolden rebels in darfur, as both conflicts in sudan involve ethnic and religious divides.
480	mcnally smith college of music in st. paul, minnesota, is the first accredited institution in the us to offer a diploma program in the study and performance of hip hop music. nineteen-year-old austen huls, who previously struggled with community college, has enrolled in the three-semester program with aspirations of becoming a professional hip hop drummer. critics argue that hip hop is a street music and doesn't belong in colleges. however, mcnally smith college president harry chalmiers believes that hip hop is an important art form and the birth of hip hop shares similarities with jazz music. the curriculum combines hands-on learning with textbook studies and features instructors from the local hip hop scene and internationally recognized names. the school, founded in 1985 and accredited by the national association of schools of music, has an enrollment of around 600 students and a faculty of 100 members. despite its location in the upper midwest, minneapolis-st. paul boasts a rich musical community.
481	this summer, gamers don't have to miss out on new releases as software publishers are releasing less high-profile games, including some promising ones for xbox 360 via xbox live arcade. "castlevania: harmony of despair" (july 28) and "hydro thunder hurricane" are two such games that offer multiplayer features. "lara croft and the guardian of light" is another multiplayer-ready title for pc and playstation network. retail releases include "madden nfl 11" for various platforms, "alpha protocol" for pc, playstation 3, and xbox 360, and "transformers: war for cybertron" for pc and all major consoles. xbox 360 gamers can also enjoy "crackdown 2," while "mafia ii" offers a mob yarn experience on pc, playstation 3, and xbox 360. handheld gaming enthusiasts have options like "puzzle quest 2" for nintendo ds and dsi, and "dementium ii" for ds. for ps3, "metal gear solid: peace walker" and "shin megami tensei: persona 3 portable" are noteworthy titles. overall, while the summer gaming scene might not match the holiday season in terms of volume, there are still plenty of games to keep gamers entertained.
482	brazilian soccer legend ronaldo, a three-time fifa world player of the year and a former corinthians player, announced on wednesday his intention to come out of retirement to play for north american soccer league (nasl) team fort lauderdale strikers. the 38-year-old, who last played professionally in 2011, recently became a minority owner of the fort lauderdale club. during a news conference, mayor of fort lauderdale and nasl leadership asked about his plans for a comeback. ronaldo expressed his love for soccer and his desire to help the team and the league, saying he would try to get in shape to play, should they reach a final. the world cup winner posed with a fort lauderdale jersey and mascot hot shot. ronaldo joined the ranks of other soccer greats, like george best, gordon banks, and gerd mueller, who previously played for the fort lauderdale strikers, which was part of the original nasl in the 1970s. the club, now playing at lockhart stadium, has had difficulty attracting large crowds, with attendances rarely exceeding 3,000 fans.
483	the mayan temple water slide at the aquaventure water park in the bahamas is a real-life temple of doom experience for thrill-seekers, where they can slide down a 60-foot mayan temple and plunge into shark-infested waters. reaching speeds of up to 35 miles per hour, the leap of faith slide sends riders through a 14- foot tunnel surrounded by nurse sharks and caribbean reef sharks, offering a unique and exhilarating experience. part of the larger 141-acre water park, aquaventure also includes a life-sized mayan temple replica, a 131-foot tall power tower, a 7-acre snorkeling lagoon, and more, making it one of the largest water parks in the world. visitors to the slide feel a mix of excitement, nerves, and adrenaline as they experience the thrilling ride.
484	a rapidly growing oil spill in the gulf of mexico, caused by a ruptured undersea well off the coast of louisiana, is threatening the commercial harbor in gulfport, mississippi, bringing back painful memories of hurricane katrina for residents. the spill has already forced a fishing ban in an affected area and caused concerns about commerce, as well as the impact on wildlife and the region's $2.4 billion fishing industry. federal officials are working on containing the spill, which is currently releasing about 210,000 gallons (5,000 barrels) of crude a day, but progress has been slow. bp, the oil company responsible for the well, is making efforts to deploy equipment to stop the leak but has not been successful and faces criticism for its response. the spill's economic and environmental impact is causing anxiety among residents in coastal communities in louisiana, mississippi, and alabama.
485	sidra fatima and her husband raja haider ali posed as prospective brides on an asian marriage website, scamming seven men out of over £35,000. fatima would meet the victims and eventually ask for large sums of money for her wedding and dowry. once they had paid, she would terminate the relationship and disappear. ali would often accompany fatima, pretending to be her cousin or brother. the victims were left humiliated and deeply in debt. the couple, who previously admitted to other fraud offenses, were sentenced to suspended and jail terms respectively, with judge colin burn remarking that the suitors "had to put up with humiliation, debt, and misery."
486	a 22-year-old woman named jennifer helen richmond has been sentenced to three years in prison after admitting her involvement in an upscale prostitution ring in orlando, florida. the ring, allegedly run by abdullah hamid through companies like platinum companions and ashley's playmates, reportedly involved 15 to 20 women who offered high-class escort services on various adult websites and facebook. prices ranged from $300 an hour to $1,800 for a five-hour dinner date. some of the earnings were hidden in air vents, under carpets, and in storage units. richmond reportedly earned $20,000 to $40,000 a month and had hid about $500,000, but the majority of the money remains unseized. an associate, christina lynn davis, who is said to have made up to $80,000 a month as an escort herself, has not been charged. hamid has not been apprehended.
487	a turkish businessman and landlord, cengizhan cerit, also known as jem cerit, was sentenced to 12 months in jail for attempting to rig a local by-election by forging signatures and applying for hundreds of postal votes in ashford borough council, kent, uk, in 2011. he pretended to have ten residents sign his nomination form to stand as a councillor, but faked their signatures and then submitted false lists of over 200 people requesting postal votes. his scheme was uncovered due to a simple spelling error, where a man was listed twice with different spellings of the name 'arnold.' all signatures on the nomination form were found to be false, and several individuals contacted confirmed that their signatures were forged. the court heard that cerit claimed he had spoken to the individuals and assumed their support, but none of the "guys" he mentioned could be identified as having helped him. police raided his office above perfect pizza in ashford and arrested him. the businessman, who denied the offenses, was convicted of three charges of election fraud. kent police expressed satisfaction with the outcome of the case and warned against interference with the electoral process.
488	indian sterilization clinics are under investigation after a doctor used a bicycle pump instead of proper medical equipment during a sterilization procedure, potentially putting the safety of 56 women at risk. dr. mahesh chandra rout, a retired surgeon, has been removed from the clinic and could face charges. the missing carbon dioxide insufflator, which should have been used for the procedure, is under investigation. the use of bicycle pumps in sterilization surgery is reportedly widespread, but it poses a significant risk as it can lead to an uncalibrated amount of pressure being applied to the abdomen and potentially causing it to burst. the incident comes after a surgeon was arrested for the deaths of a dozen women following sterilization procedures at a mobile clinic last month. critics claim that conditions at these mobile clinics, where sterilizations are often performed in poorer, rural areas, are unsanitary and dangerous due to a lack of resources and overcrowding.
489	a man from superior, wisconsin, identified as bryan james hathaway, who gained international attention in 2006 for molesting a dead deer, was arrested this week for allegedly assaulting a female police officer at a hermantown walmart. in the latest incident, hathaway, 25, is accused of assaulting officer kody vedder, obstructing legal process, fleeing on foot, and receiving stolen property. the encounter happened on monday night when vedder, who was off-duty and shopping with her 11-year-old daughter, observed hathaway acting suspiciously in a lincoln town car in the parking lot. when she approached the car and identified herself as a cop, hathaway attempted to flee, resulting in a physical altercation between the two. vedder suffered injuries requiring medical attention. the police found two android cell phones in the suspect's car during the arrest. in 2006, hathaway was convicted of having sex with a dead deer and previously pleaded no contest to shooting an arabian horse for the same reason. he is currently under probation supervision for these offenses and has a pending probation violation hearing for a 2008 theft conviction.
490	the duchess of cambridge's security was heightened during a recent appearance in london as her bodyguards were seen carrying tasers in addition to conventional firearms. the presence of tasers, which can deliver an electric shock to incapacitate a person, reflects the heightened threat level of international terrorism in the uk. the officers were also wearing stab vests and there were more backup officers and police outriders than usual. kate, who is six months pregnant, was unphased by the increased security and met with foster carers and social workers during the event. the use of tasers by police has been controversial, with human rights groups raising concerns over their potential to cause intolerable suffering and even death. the duchess has no official link with the fostering network but is keen to learn more about their work and may forge a relation with the organization in the future. the heightened security followed a series of security alerts, including an attack on prince charles and the duchess of cornwall during the london riots in 2010. tasers were first introduced to police forces in a limited way in 2003, and under the 1968 firearms act, they are considered prohibited weapons. civilians caught in possession of one can be punished by up to ten years in prison.
491	a jury in washington, d.c. convicted ingmar guandique of two counts of first-degree murder in the 2001 death of chandra levy, a 24-year-old california native who was working as an intern for the bureau of prisons when she disappeared. the verdict came after three days of deliberations and over 11 years since her remains were found in rock creek park. guandique, a reported member of the salvadoran gang mara salvatrucha, was serving a 10-year sentence for attacking two other women in the park when he was arrested in 2009 and confessed to the crime. levy's mother, susan, watched intently as the verdict was read, with several jurors wiping their eyes afterward. prosecutors argued that guandique had attacked levy while she was jogging in the park. the defense emphasized the largely circumstantial nature of the case, including a lack of dna evidence and witnesses. jurors were mindful not to rush a decision and expressed sympathy for levy's family. guandique faces a maximum sentence of life in prison without parole at his february 11 sentencing. the disappearance of levy drew national attention due to her connection with gary condit, a california congressman at the time, but he was never a suspect in the case. metropolitan police department chief cathy lanier defended the handling of the case and credited the u.s. attorney's office for their work on cold cases.
492	georgina bloomberg, a 31-year-old daughter of billionaire michael bloomberg, took her newborn son jasper to a florida equestrian center for an early introduction to horse racing. jasper, who was born on christmas eve in new york city, is already a jetsetter and was accompanied by his father, ramiro quintana, during the visit. the couple, who are both professional equestrians, met when they were teenagers and have no plans to marry. jasper is the first grandchild for michael bloomberg and the couple's first child together. georgina, who had previously revealed that she had always planned to rescue a mini pony for her future child, had one on hand for jasper and plans to involve him in the horse-racing scene. she has hired help but wants to be involved in raising the child and has already gotten back into the social circuit after giving birth.
493	according to a survey conducted by depression alliance during depression awareness week, one-third of workers struggle with depression, stress, or burnout, leading to isolation and loneliness for 83% of those affected. only half of these individuals have confided in a colleague, but 71% found discussing their condition helpful. companies like royal mail, barclays, and unilever are implementing new policies to support employees dealing with depression. unilever's vice president of hr, tim munden, encourages addressing depression through mental health policies. norman lamb, the care and support minister, aims for a 10% reduction in work-related mental health cases by 2015 and is investing in improving access to mental health treatment. the depression in the workplace in europe report highlights best practices by companies in addressing depression among employees. tns omnibus conducted online research on 1,215 british adults.
494	a french victims' association vice-president announced that 75 more bodies have been recovered from the wreckage of air france flight 447, which crashed into the atlantic ocean off the coast of brazil in 2009, doubling the number of identified remains. the latest discoveries bring the total number of bodies found to 127. the plane plunged 38,000 feet in three minutes and 30 seconds, with conflicting airspeed readings that may have led the pilots to make bad decisions. investigators are examining why the pilots responded to the stall warning by pulling the nose up instead of pushing it down to recover. french and brazilian authorities are continuing their investigation into the cause of the accident, with a focus on possible pitot tube malfunctions.
495	protests continue in tehran, iran, with clashes between protesters and motorcycle-mounted militia members. egyptian human rights activist walid abbas, inspired by the iranian protests, tweeted about learning from their activism, despite not supporting opposition candidate mir hossein moussavi. iraqi student taghlob salah admired the courage of the iranian youths and believed iraqis could learn from them, despite cultural differences and mistrust between the two countries. arab editor abdel bari atwan urged moussavi to avoid bloodshed and preserve iranian unity. other arab commentators saw the protests as a significant shift in iranian politics and a defiance of the theocracy. relations between iran and arab states have been tense due to differing religious and political affiliations.
496	a zoo worker named sarah mcclay, 24, was fatalty mauled by a sumatran tiger at the south lakes wild animal park in dalton-in-furness, england, while performing duties in the big cat enclosure. the enclosure has lockable doors to keep animals and keepers separate, but it appears that a failure in the system allowed the tiger and mcclay to come into contact. authorities are currently investigating whether this was due to human or technical error. zoo owner david s. gill asked for support and understanding from the public after the tragic incident, assuring that no other staff or visitors were in danger. in a separate incident, a worker was also mauled to death by her favorite lion at a california sanctuary.
