988	a 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck the pacific ocean near the solomon islands on tuesday, just one day after a series of earthquakes in the same region and another quake in the philippines. the epicenter of the quake was at a depth of 35 km (22 miles) and no tsunamis were expected. despite no reported damage from the latest quake, there were aftershocks, including a 5.5-magnitude aftershock. the solomon islands, located in the ring of fire, were hit by multiple earthquakes on monday, causing damage to at least one village with a strong 6.5-magnitude quake and a more powerful 7.2-magnitude tremor. the usgs has not yet received reports of damage from the earlier quakes and is waiting to hear from locals.
989	a new study published in the january 2008 issue of archives of general psychiatry found that the prevalence of autism cases in california children continued to rise after most vaccine manufacturers removed the mercury-based preservative thimerosal in 1999, suggesting that the chemical was not a primary cause of the disorder. the study, which looked at cases of autism in california between 1995 and 2007, found that the autism rate continued to increase from 3 to 4 per 1,000 children, despite a significant decrease in exposure to thimerosal during that period. a child psychiatrist who supported the study said it "very clearly shows that autism did not arrive through a vaccine." however, advocacy groups argue that it is too soon to determine whether autism rates were affected by removing thimerosal from vaccines, and point out that the study did not include children under the age of 3, who were still being exposed to thimerosal at the time. thimerosal, a neurotoxin, has not been used in childhood vaccines since 2001, except for some flu shots. no definitive cause for autism has been identified, but genetics and environment are believed to be contributors. autism rates have been on the rise, with as many as one in every 166 children in the us diagnosed with the disorder. symptoms include no babbling or pointing by 12 months, no single words by 16 months, no brief phrases by 24 months, and loss of language or social skills. companies began removing thimerosal from vaccines in the late 1990s due to concerns about its health effects and the addition of new vaccines to the routine shot schedule, as well as government pressure.
990	sarah palin, the republican vice presidential nominee, did not visit troops in iraq during a july 2008 trip as previously stated by her campaign. instead, she stopped at the kuwait-iraq border and made a refueling stop in ireland. palin aides also confirmed that her visit to ireland was not a full-fledged trip, but rather a brief stop for refueling. these revelations come as both the mccain and obama campaigns continue to engage in harsh attacks against each other in television ads and campaign speeches. in response to these developments, obama campaign spokesperson tommy vietor accused the mccain campaign of lying and deceit, pointing to palin's previous statements about opposing the "bridge to nowhere," her support for earmarks, and her claimed visits to iraq and ireland. "americans are starting to wonder, is there anything the mccain campaign isn't lying about?" vietor said in a statement. palin's trip to mexico on a personal vacation and her visit to canada were also confirmed by her camp. during an appearance on "the view," mccain was pressed on palin's qualifications and her record of reform. mccain defended palin, pointing to her efforts to sell alaska's state jet and fire the governor's chef, but was unable to provide specifics on how she would reform washington. palin's reputation for reform was also called into question when it was revealed that she had hired a lobbyist to secure millions in pork for her town and her state. both campaigns exchanged harsh attacks in tv ads and memos on friday, with the mccain campaign releasing an ad accusing the obama campaign of launching "desperate attacks and smears" against palin, and the obama campaign releasing two ads mocking mccain's age and lack of technological skills. obama campaign manager david plouffe issued a memo accusing the mccain campaign of engaging in "smears, lies, and cynical attempts to
991	scotland voted to reject independence from the united kingdom with a majority of 55% to 45% in a historic referendum. scottish first minister and leader of the scottish national party, alex salmond, announced his resignation following the defeat. prime minister david cameron welcomed scotland's decision, vowing to deliver on promises of shifting more autonomy to scotland. both sides expressed their pride in the campaign and urged unity moving forward. queen elizabeth ii also released a statement acknowledging various emotions, but remained hopeful for unity. stock markets and investors reacted positively to the result, with the pound and stocks rising. scottish politicians hailed the result and called for unity and change, while deputy prime minister nick clegg emphasized the need for constitutional reform across the uk. the party leaders face challenges in delivering promised changes on a tight timeline. cameron is also expected to face political fallout over the campaign.
992	paul pogba, a highly coveted midfielder for juventus and france, faced off against his manager massimiliano allegri in a mini goal challenge on thursday. in the game, they had to hit the back of the net without the ball bouncing. despite pogba's known passing range and accuracy, allegri easily took the lead with his impressive shots. pogba joked that it wouldn't be wise for him to beat his manager but ended up losing 5-2. allegri's winning mentality has contributed to juventus' dominance in serie a, where they currently have a seven-point lead over roma.
993	a new safety device called spotnsave, designed by indian engineer chirag jagtiani, is a bluetooth-connected bracelet that sends an sos text message to up to five emergency contacts when the sos button is pressed twice. the bracelet includes location data, which is updated every two minutes on google maps, enabling guardian angels to see the wearer's location. jagtiani created the bracelet after a friend was abducted and tortured, and targets women, senior citizens, and visually impaired people. it costs $45 (£27) and is made from waterproof rubber, with a free android app and a future iphone version. the engineer sold 880 units in the first two months. the bracelet also allows users to send an emergency message via a linked smartphone's power button or the app itself.
994	hsbc, the largest european bank by market capitalization, announced it will lay off 14,000 employees worldwide to save between $2 billion and $3 billion by 2016. this represents over 5% of its global workforce, adding to the 42,000 jobs cut in the previous two years. the layoffs are expected to mainly affect non-core markets like europe and south america, while asia will continue to be a growth market. this restructuring follows ceo stuart gulliver's announcement in march to focus on reducing costs. industry experts suggest other major banking corporations, such as dbs, ocbc, standard chartered, ubs, deutsche bank, merrill lynch, and credit suisse, might need to follow suit. the job market in banking is expected to shift, with an increase in wealth management, risk management, and regulatory compliance jobs, but a decrease in cash equity sales, structured products, and investment banking positions in asia.
995	barnes & noble's new e-reader, named "nook," was officially unveiled on tuesday after being widely leaked online. the device, which costs $260 and goes head-to-head with amazon's kindle, features a color touchscreen, a lendme feature for borrowing certain books, a 6-inch display, and a free 3g at&t connection. it also includes a virtual keyboard, support for epub, pdf, and fictionwise formats, and a battery life of 10 days. additionally, the nook has a wi-fi radio for use in barnes & noble stores, runs on android os, and can store up to 1,500 books with the ability to add more. the nook has a more fashionable design compared to the kindle with color icons, designer cases, and a customizable back panel. despite being leaked prior to the announcement, the pre-orders for the nook began on tuesday night.
996	kabul's police chief and chief of criminal investigations have resigned following friday's suicide attacks in the city, but the interior ministry has yet to approve their resignations and has ordered them to complete the investigation into the attacks first. at least 17 people were killed and many others were injured in the attacks near the safi landmark hotel in the shahr-e-naw neighborhood, where government offices, diplomatic facilities, and businesses are located. the taliban claimed responsibility for the attacks, which involved a suicide car bomb and three suicide bombers with explosive-laden vests. among the fatalities were at least eight indians and one pakistani, as well as an italian and four indians, according to reports.
997	the u.s. military prison at guantanamo bay, cuba, is unlikely to be closed by the january 2010 deadline set by the obama administration due to legal complications, according to two senior administration officials. the announcement is a blow to president obama, who signed the executive order to close the facility in his first week in office to restore due process and constitutional values. republicans, including former vice president dick cheney, have argued that closing guantanamo would make the u.s. less safe and called for a detailed plan before signing the order. the prison housed over 750 detainees at its peak, and over 500 have been released. the administration is working on finding third-party countries to accept the remaining detainees and approximately 2,200 staff members work there.
998	millie brown, a 26-year-old artist from england, has gained attention for her unconventional art-making process, which involves regurgitating tinted milk onto canvases and clothing. her work, which has been compared to jackson pollock's drip paintings, can be seen in the exhibition "muted chronology" at the strand gallery in london. brown's unique art style, which some find disturbing, has garnered her a following, including lady gaga, who featured her in a music video. brown's bohemian upbringing influenced her maverick tendencies, and she has embraced unconventional living, such as sleeping in abandoned buildings and traveling around europe in trucks. while some may find her work disturbing, critics have noted the abstract beauty of the finished canvases. one of brown's unique vomit-art canvases will be available for purchase at the exhibition.
999	a study conducted by the austin institute for the study of family and culture found a strong correlation between religious affiliation and happiness based on a survey of 15,738 american adults. the study revealed that 45% of those who attend religious services weekly described themselves as 'very happy,' while only 28% of those who never attend reported the same. the study attributed this connection to social support within religious communities, where individuals find friendship and a sense of belonging among like-minded individuals. past studies have also indicated that people with faith generally report higher life satisfaction and better coping abilities. the austin institute study controlled for various factors, including physical health, marital status, age, educational attainment, race/ethnicity, gender, and marital happiness, but the correlation between religious affiliation and happiness still held true.
1000	an iconic tennis dress worn by fiona butler in a 1970s photograph, which became a popular poster in the 1970s and '80s, sold at auction for £15,500 on sunday. the handmade dress with lace trim, created by fiona's friend carol knotts, was worn during a tennis match at the university of birmingham in 1976. the dress was part of a lot sold by fieldings auctioneers, which also included the tennis racquet from the image and two copies of the poster. the auction house confirmed that the sale far surpassed its £2,000 estimate.
1001	disney has reportedly sold over 3 million "frozen" role-play dresses based on its hit movie in north america this year. executive vice president of disney retail, paul gainer, described the connection between families and the movie's characters as a phenomenon that continues to grow. in addition to the dresses, other "frozen" merchandise is selling well, with a new film and an epcot attraction on the way. the movie, which earned about $400 million at the north american box office, shows no signs of slowing down.
1002	google's ad preferences page provides a glimpse into the extensive user profiles the tech giant has built based on users' interests, age, and gender. the profiles are constructed by harvesting user data from visits to sites within google's advertising network. alarmingly, age and gender are determined by demographic information of other google users who frequent the same sites, leading to inaccuracies and amusing mistakes. users have reported being identified with the wrong age, gender, and interests, raising concerns about privacy. rainey reitman, activism director for the electronic frontier foundation, expressed concerns over an unfathomable digital trail created every day, with privacy being under assault. users can opt-out or manually edit their details, while google also does not store information on controversial topics like pornography. google uses data from youtube, gmail, and search to create more accurate advertising profiles, which can result in personalized and seemingly accurate adverts for most users. however, some users have reported bizarre interests being identified, and manual changes can be made to the interests from the ad preferences page. google associates interests with ads preferences based on the types of websites visited and demographic categories of those visitors.
1003	kate moss, the 39-year-old supermodel, was spotted in highgate, north london, taking her dog archie, a staffordshire bull terrier cross, for a grooming session at the aptly named salon "hair of the dog." dressed in tight jeans, tasseled heels, a zipped jacket, and a black peaked cap, kate and archie's outing came after reports that they have a bedroom and walk-in wardrobe for their pampered pet. kate, who is an ambassador for mango and recently admitted that having a dog has forced her to make more sensible wardrobe choices, also made peace with actress gwyneth paltrow over a slice of pizza at a smart north london pizzeria. the argument between the two stars, who crossed paths at the pizzeria owned by the soho house group, reportedly ended with kisses and a friendly chat. meanwhile, hollywood fans were seen at the same crepe stand as kate and her husband jamie hince.
1004	a brazilian judge has commuted the prison sentence of two american pilots involved in a fatal plane collision over the amazon rainforest in 2006, ruling instead for community service to be carried out in the us. joseph lepore and jan paul paladino were originally sentenced to four years and four days in prison for their roles in the collision between a legacy 600 jet and a gol airlines boeing 737, which resulted in the deaths of all 154 people on board the larger jet. the pilots are accused of being imprudent and inexperienced in the report, which also states they turned off the legacy's transponder, an allegation denied by the pilots during a videoconference. the controversy led to confiscation of their passports, causing diplomatic tension between brazil and the us. their lawyers have not yet mentioned plans for an appeal.
1005	piers morgan, known for his probing interviews, is taking over larry king's prime-time hour on cnn starting in january. the new show will feature in-depth interviews with public figures and air live on cnn-us and cnn-international. morgan, who began his journalism career as a british newspaper reporter, has a history of posing tough questions to interviewees and will continue to do so from new york, los angeles, and london. he previously edited the news of the world and the daily mirror before leaving under controversy. morgan has also hosted interview shows on bbc and itv and served as a judge on america's got talent. he will continue his columns for the mail on sunday and provide regular columns to cnn.com.
1006	fiona woolf, the chairman of the government's child abuse inquiry, is facing mounting pressure to step down due to her connections with lord brittan, a possible key witness at the inquiry. survivors of abuse and their supporters, including an old schoolfriend of nick clegg's, have accused the deputy prime minister of being out of touch for offering his backing to woolf. woolf is being challenged in court for her appointment due to her connections with brittan, who denies failing to act on a dossier of pedophilia allegations in the 1980s. critics argue that her lack of experience in dealing with child abuse and her friendships with brittan make her unfit to lead an independent inquiry. woolf was asked to answer detailed questions from the house of commons home affairs committee about her relationship with the brittans and other matters related to the inquiry.
1007	karen perrin, a senior assistant at the bill and melinda gates foundation in washington, d.c., spent eight hours trapped in a restroom at work after getting locked inside on friday night. after attempting to draw attention by stuffing paper towels under the door and searching for an alternate escape route, she managed to break through the wall using a metal rod and escaped. her husband, former washington redskins running back lonnie perrin, and her daughter were worried when she didn't return home and were preparing to search for her before she contacted them. mrs. perrin suffered contusions to her hands but does not plan to pursue legal action. the incident drew comparisons to the scene in "shawshank redemption" where tim robbins' character uses a rock hammer to escape from prison.
1008	reports of more demonstrations occurred in iran on wednesday, following the death of grand ayatollah hussein ali montazeri, a prominent cleric known for his criticism of the government. montazeri, who was a key figure in the 1979 iranian revolution and a vocal critic of the hard-liner mahmoud ahmadinejad's re-election, died on sunday at the age of 87. two days after his funeral in tehran, where tens of thousands chanted anti-government slogans, reports of clashes emerged from isfahan and najafabad. montazeri was a major critic of the ruling establishment, including ayatollah ali khamenei, and had become the voice of the reformist movement on key foreign policy issues in recent months. his death was described as a significant blow to the reformist "green movement." montazeri was once a close associate of ayatollah ruhollah khomeini and played a key role in iran's constitution-writing and political leadership after the revolution. however, his political fortunes fell out of favor, and he was placed under house arrest for many years. montazeri had objected to khomeini's execution of thousands of leftist prisoners in 1988, among other issues.
1009	a maine mother, cheryl gilson, 26, of cornish, was sentenced to six months in jail for driving 124 mph with her two young children, aged five and three, in the car without proper car seats in april. the incident occurred on the maine turnpike in saco where she also had three young men in the vehicle, all with suspended licenses. state trooper roger teachout pulled her over and reported her behavior as dangerous. gilson has an extensive driving record with past offenses of speeding, driving with a suspended license, and driving under the influence. in a separate incident, she was also charged with operating under the influence with a child, a six-year-old girl, in the car in early july, but it's unclear if she was related to the girl. teachout stated that gilson's actions were "seriously negligent," risking her children's lives. gilson was found to be weaving and tailgating other cars during the initial stop. she was charged with additional offenses later in july for violating her bail conditions, endangering a child, and operating under the influence. gilson had numerous past driving infractions, including a drunken driving charge in 2006 and a suspended license in 2006 and 2007. her license was restored in 2010, but she was ticketed for driving 87 mph in a 65 mph zone in 2012.
1010	the environment agency in the uk has suggested building snowmen as a fun and functional way to prevent thousands of homes from being flooded during the expected thaw. snow and ice compacted into snowmen melt more slowly than that left lying on the ground, reducing surface water and lessening the likelihood of flood alerts. however, weather experts predict a sudden thaw as temperatures swing from -13°c to 13°c at the weekend, resulting in localized flooding and poor driving conditions. building snowmen may be enjoyable, but an environment agency spokesperson later stated it is unlikely to make a significant difference in the overall rate of snowmelt. the most effective way to protect against flooding is to check if one's area is at risk and sign up for free flood warnings on the environment agency website.
1011	the united states is reestablishing diplomatic relations with cuba, but american travelers are still subject to strict limits on what they can bring back from the country. they can only bring goods worth $400 and no more than $100 can be tobacco and alcohol. cigar lovers can bring back two cohiba corano especiales, priced at $34 each, and six bolivar coronas juniors for $16 each. rum drinkers can bring back three 750ml bottles of havana club rum at $31 each. only certain travelers, such as those with family in cuba, educators, aid workers, journalists, and those traveling for government business, athletics, cultural events, support for cuban people, and medical research are allowed to travel to cuba. approved travelers can use their credit and debit cards on the island, and americans can also send $2,000 to family every three months. however, internet access is very limited, with almost no ordinary cubans having access and very slow internet only available at hotels. the new rules allow u.s. companies to export telecommunications equipment to improve internet access for both cubans and americans. cuban cigars, famous for their distinct and expensive taste, will not be widely available in the u.s. anytime soon.
1012	new photographs of darren wilson, the ferguson, missouri police officer who shot and killed unarmed teen michael brown last month, have emerged, showing him at his wedding in 2011. the pictures, which include group shots and selfies, depict wilson as a sturdy, tall man with a brawny build. previously, only one picture of wilson was released, taken at a police award ceremony. supporters have defended wilson, claiming he was intimidated by brown, who was 6-foot-4 and 300 pounds, but the new images suggest wilson has a similar body type to the wedding photos. brown's death led to several protests in ferguson, with locals clashing with police for several nights. wilson was later cleared of any wrongdoing in the shooting.
1013	a 10-year-old boy scout named aj underwood accidentally hung himself while practicing knot-tying for a merit badge in his bedroom in oneonta, alabama. his mother discovered him on friday night and tried to resuscitate him, but he could not be saved. police believe aj's death was an unfortunate accident, as he had been in good spirits and making good grades. the community has come together to support the family through a gofundme page, which has raised nearly $10,000 of its $20,000 goal towards aj's funeral expenses. aj is described as a loving and kind boy who always put others before himself and will be deeply missed.
1014	brazil, a country known for its love for football, has produced five fifa world cup wins since 1958, with legendary players like pele, romario, ronaldo, and ronaldinho leading the charge. the game brings joy and happiness to brazilians, even in the face of poverty and inequality. however, brazil has yet to win an olympic gold medal in football, both for the men and women, adding pressure ahead of the 2014 world cup and the 2016 olympics. stars like neymar, dani alves, and david luiz are expected to represent brazil in the upcoming olympics, with manchester united's rafael da silva and fabio also hoping to secure a spot. the squad faces stiff competition, as other nations also aim for the medal. the brazilian football contingent at manchester united, including anderson, rafael, and fabio, are focusing on helping the team secure the english title before turning their attention to the olympics. legendary manager alex ferguson has provided guidance and support for these players during their time at manchester united. brazilian football chief ricardo teixeira recently resigned, adding to the volatility surrounding the sport in the country.
1015	a socialite named lauren silverman, who is pregnant with simon cowell's baby, allegedly cheated on her husband andrew due to feelings of loneliness and a lack of male companionship. her mother, carole davis, has a checkered romantic history, and stewart eisenberg, carole's second husband, claimed that lauren had broken many hearts in her youth due to her breathtaking beauty. according to eisenberg, lauren and andrew's marriage had been strained due to andrew's long hours and frequent business trips, leaving lauren feeling neglected and bored. she reportedly began spending time with cowell, who was a family friend, on his yacht and eventually had an affair. the scandal has caused a crisis in the silverman household, with andrew filing for divorce and accusing cowell of behaving "cruel and inhuman" for his involvement. however, some of lauren's friends claim that the couple were not actually estranged and that andrew knew about her socializing with cowell. the circumstances surrounding how lauren met andrew are unclear, but they have been married for over a decade and have a seven-year-old son named adam.
1016	kazakhstan's foreign minister, yerzhan kazykhanov, thanked sacha baron cohen for his comedy character borat, which portrayed kazakhstan and its people in a humorous and satirical way in the 2006 film "borat: cultural learnings of america for make benefit glorious nation of kazakhstan." the film, which initially sparked outrage, led to a significant increase in tourism as the number of visa requests grew tenfold. although the movie was initially banned in kazakhstan and caused diplomatic tensions, including the playing of a spoof national anthem during an olympic awards ceremony, kazakh athletes have since been trained to recognize and protest the incorrect version. the country's leaders acknowledge the pain caused by the film but view the resulting interest as a positive.
1017	eight people, including police cadets and staff members, were killed and three were arrested during an eight-hour standoff between gunmen and security forces at a police training center in lahore, pakistan. the militants, led by the pakistani taliban leader baitullah mehsud, stormed the academy's top floor while officers were undergoing their morning drill. police and paramilitary forces regained control of the building, but at least 78 people were wounded in the attack. the incident occurred in the same city where gunmen wounded members of the sri lankan cricket team earlier this year. security forces found grenades and a knife on a suspect they arrested.
1018	on may 5, 2013, in bangladesh, at least 37 people were killed and hundreds more injured in violent clashes between police and islamic hardliners demanding the death penalty for blasphemy. the hardliners, mostly from the hefajat-e-islam group, torched shops and vehicles, blocked roads, and engaged in fierce battles with police in the capital dhaka and its suburbs. the protesters, who were calling for harsh punishment for those who insult islam, clashed with police using sticks and rocks, and the police responded with tear gas, water cannon, rubber bullets, and batons. thousands of activists had gathered to push for a new blasphemy law and had blocked transportation between dhaka and other cities, causing significant disruptions. at least 200,000 people marched to central dhaka, where the situation escalated, with 11 people killed at a hospital, including a policeman, and eight people killed in the kanchpur district on the outskirts of dhaka. there were reports of police firing rubber bullets and live rounds, leaving over a hundred people injured, and at least five more were killed in a separate clash in hathazari, a town outside chittagong. the government rejected the protesters' demands for a blasphemy law and greater segregation of men and women, and several pro-islamist television stations were shut down. the leader of hefajat-e-islam, allama shah ahmad shafi, was put on a plane to chittagong, and the deputy chief was detained in the capital.
1019	labour mp tom watson claimed that conservative party officials accidentally sent him sensitive emails discussing plans to smear labour mps with paedophile allegations. the emails were allegedly intended for a national newspaper journalist. watson wrote to prime minister david cameron about the matter last month, but conservative party chairman grant shapps found no evidence to support the claims. however, a senior executive at the newspaper revealed that the emails were not about labour mps but about known links between senior labour politicians and the paedophile information exchange. the conservative party denied watson's allegations as "completely false and without foundation."
1020	daniel ricciardo, the 25-year-old australian formula one driver for red bull, celebrated his birthday on monday. contrary to his reputation as a partygoer when he first arrived in england at age 19, ricciardo said he has given up his "boogie days." he has surprised many by outperforming his more experienced teammate sebastian vettel this season, leading in the drivers' championship by 23 points. of their eight races finished together, ricciardo has finished ahead of vettel on each occasion. despite his professional demeanor on the track, ricciardo admits to enjoying practical jokes with his team away from the cockpit. ahead of the british grand prix, ricciardo is 83 points behind championship leader nico rosberg but believes the smartest driver will win the title.
1021	the uk's major airlines have warned of long delays at passport control during the easter holidays due to a shortage of border staff, with passengers experiencing two and a half hour waits at heathrow airport. the airlines, including british airways, virgin atlantic, and easyjet, have urged home secretary theresa may to expect "gridlock" at uk airports over the bank holiday weekend. the problem has been exacerbated by a return to 100% passport checks and staffing cuts, with queues excessively long at peak travel times, reaching up to four and a half hours. the british air transport association and virgin atlantic have written letters to may, expressing their concerns and urging her to abandon further cuts in border force staff. millions of passengers are set to be affected, with british airways expecting its busiest day over the easter holiday on april 15, and up to 123,350 passengers forecasted to arrive at heathrow alone on that day. airport staff unions warn of the potential risk to security from staff cuts and are calling for retired staff to be brought back to help manage the crowds. british airways has also had to cancel some flights to and from nice due to a looming strike by spanish pilots. passengers are urged to check for delays before traveling over the easter weekend.
1022	a large crowd gathered in london, uk for a "moonwalk" tribute to michael jackson, where они dance to his iconic songs and replicated his famous walk outside liverpool street train station. organized by milo yiannopoulos through social media, the event attracted a large number of fans, many of whom wore self-made t-shirts in memory of the singer. the crowd cheered, chanted, and danced to songs like "billie jean," "bad," and "thriller," with some fans even performing jackson's signature dance moves. the event started off with some challenges from the police, who were unsure about how to handle it and eventually allowed the crowd to gather outside the station, attracting even more people. similar tributes are expected to take place around the world, with austria already holding its own moonwalk event.
1023	bill cosby's social media invitation for fans to create memes using his photos resulted in a backlash as people focused on rape allegations against him instead. barbara bowman, a victim of cosby's sexual abuse, shared her story with mailonline after cosby's meme request blew up. cosby has been accused of rape by over a dozen women for incidents dating back to the 1970s. he reached a settlement with one accuser in 2006. hannibal buress' public denunciation of cosby as a rapist and comedian's refusal to laugh at his jests sparked outrage. cosby, best known for his role in the cosby show, has never been charged with rape in a court of law.
1024	a pennsylvania mother, identified as donna m. krupp, was arrested and charged with arson and referential endangerment after allegedly setting fire to a police detective's house as retaliation for her son's arrest. the house, located in montgomery county, was severely damaged, destroying nearly everything inside and killing the family's cat. krupp lived nearby and was reportedly captured on camera using a grill lighter to ignite the christmas decorations. no injuries were reported as the detective and his family were away at disney world at the time. despite the fact that detective ernie morris was not involved in krupp's son's arrest, she believed he had led police to her house and had been warned to stay away from him. krupp, who had expressed resentment since her son's arrest in june, was held on $1 million bail.
1025	a damning report by the independent police complaints commission (ipcc) revealed that scotland yard's sapphire unit, which investigates rape and sexual assault cases, failed to properly investigate a rape accusation against jean say in 2008. the victim was pressured into withdrawing her allegations, allowing say to later murder his two children. the ipcc found that officers prioritized meeting targets over focusing on the victims and protecting the public. deborah glass, deputy chairman of the ipcc, called the approach "wholly inappropriate." three officers facing allegations of failings in the investigation into serial sex offender kirk reid were not held accountable, leading to frustration from the ipcc. the ipcc also investigated apparent blunders and failings in the arrest of reid. the report comes as the sapphire unit is supposed to represent the gold standard for rape investigations in the country. the unit has been criticized multiple times in the past, and nineteen officers have been disciplined, including three who have been sacked. a scotland yard spokesperson acknowledged past failures and stated that changes have been made to improve rape investigations.
1026	in a landmark decision, a french court has ordered google to remove links to former formula 1 chief max mosley's sadomasochistic private life from its search engine. the ruling follows the publication of videos and photos of mosley participating in an s&m orgy by the defunct news of the world in 2008. although mosley sued and won damages from the paper, the images remain accessible online. google will now have to introduce a filter to prevent the material from appearing in search results, as mosley argued that sexual activity is a private matter. google's legal team called the request a "legal aberration," but the company must comply within two months or face a fine of €1 and €5,000 in court costs. daphne keller, google's associate general counsel, expressed concern over the ruling's implications for freedom of expression on the internet. mosley's legal team attempted to secure a broader ruling forcing google to block access to future extracts from the video, but failed. the case raises questions over the role companies like google should play in policing the internet, with google maintaining that a european union directive on e-commerce should take precedence over privacy concerns. mosley is the youngest son of the late british fascist sir oswald mosley.
1027	the miss world competition, which started in 1951, has undergone significant changes in fashion and beauty trends over the years. the first winner, kiki hakansson from sweden, was crowned in a bikini at the lyceum theatre in london. however, due to protests from several countries, the swimsuit round was eliminated for several years. the contest has since seen various fashion trends, from the big eyes and winged eyeliner of the 60s to the glitter-heavy gowns of the 90s, and slim frames in the noughties. notable winners include aishwarya rai from india and cindy breakspeare from jamaica, who went on to marry bob marley. this year, 125 contestants have arrived in london for the 2014 pageant, set to take place on december 14. contestants must survive elimination rounds in various categories, including beach fashion, "beauty with a purpose" presentations, sports, and talent. current miss world meghan young from the philippines is seen interacting with the contestants during a photo call.
1028	a zimbabwean court sentenced former us representative melvin reynolds to a $100 fine or five days in prison, along with immediate deportation, after he pleaded guilty to violating zimbabwe's immigration laws by overstaying his visa. the court dropped a second charge against him for possessing pornographic material due to the lack of authorization from the prosecutor-general. reynolds was arrested on monday in harare, having entered the country in november on a 14-day visa that had expired. police sources claimed they found encrypted files containing pornographic material on his computer, but reynolds refused to provide the passwords. reynolds, a democrat from illinois, was first elected to congress in 1992 but resigned in 1995 following his conviction on three charges related to sexual assault, obstruction of justice, and solicitation of child pornography.
1029	a us website, matchingdonors, which allows people in need of a kidney to directly appeal for a donor and interact with potential donors before deciding who to donate to, is launching in the uk. the nhs runs an anonymous organ donation scheme wherein altruistic donors are not informed about the recipient. however, matchingdonors allows patients to make personal appeals with videos and messaging services. the website has been criticized by doctors for not following the principle of organ donations being a freely given gift. saira khan, a mother-of-three from ramsgate, has become the first person in the uk to sign up as a patient on the website. the human tissue authority (hta), the uk's transplant watchdog, is reviewing the legality and operation of the website, as it could potentially charge up to $595 for patients to sign up. the hta is concerned about the legal implications and ensuring that donors give consent freely and that no reward is offered or sought for the donation. the hta is launching a new framework for the assessment of directed-altruistic donations on september 10.
1030	carlos moya, the first spanish player to reach the top of the tennis world rankings, announced his retirement from professional tennis at the age of 34 due to a foot injury. moya last played in the madrid open in may, and failed to reach the form needed for a farewell at the big tournaments. he won the french open in 1998 and spent two weeks as the world number one. over his career, he earned over $13 million in prize money and won 20 titles on the main circuit, reaching the finals of the australian open and the semifinals of the us open. he also helped spain win the davis cup in 2004 with victories against the united states. moya, who is from majorca but lives in switzerland, will retire in a farewell tournament in seville next month, and plans to focus on his gym in majorca, his sports business, and his family, including his newborn daughter.
1031	a seven-year-old girl from wales, lauryn robinson, is the first child in the world to be diagnosed with both acute lymphoblastic leukaemia and non-hodgkin lymphoma, a condition referred to as "dual hit leukaemia." lauryn's parents noticed strange symptoms in march, including a swollen face, and she was later diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. however, chemotherapy made her condition worse and caused seizures and a mini-stroke. further tests revealed she also had non-hodgkin lymphoma. doctors are treating her cautiously due to the rarity of her condition and are consulting with experts across the country. a bone marrow donor is urgently needed for a transplant. the chances of developing dual hit leukaemia are one in two billion, and neither of lauryn's parents is a match. they urge more people to sign up as donors to increase the chances of finding a match. lauryn remains upbeat and asks when she can return to school, but her condition is keeping her hospitalized.
1032	the mother of chandra levy, a congressional intern who was found dead in washington d.c.'s rock creek park in 2002, has been told by police that an arrest is imminent in her daughter's case. susan levy received a call from the washington police department informing her of a warrant for the arrest of suspected killer ingar guandique. guandique, a laborer from el salvador, is currently serving a 10-year prison sentence for two assaults in the area around the time of levy's disappearance. he has denied involvement in her death. chandra levy, a california native, had been working as an intern for the federal bureau of prisons before her disappearance on may 1, 2001. her remains were found in the park the following year. police have not yet finalized the arrest warrant, but a source close to the investigation has confirmed that guandique is the prime suspect. the investigation gained significant attention due to levy's connection to congressman gary condit, with whom she had an affair, and police questioned him numerous times in connection to her case. condit, who was not named as a suspect, lost the 2002 democratic primary and left office at the end of his term. his lawyer has criticized the media attention and police investigation for causing undue harm to the condit family.
1033	a french advertising campaign for eurostar, a high-speed train service, features spoof greek statues of naked, pot-bellied men representing english people engaging in pub sports instead of traditional athletic poses. these images, created by a french ad agency, aim to attract french people to take the train to the london olympics, poking fun at english olympic aspirations. the actors used in the campaign, including a former royal shakespeare company actor, were encouraged to embody the stereotype of a middle-aged englishman with a penchant for beer and snooker. the campaign has received positive responses, and previous campaigns included a redesign of a british banknote featuring mr. bean. the ads do not appear in england, and eurostar characterizes it as a tongue-in-cheek campaign playing on franco-british rivalry.
1034	fox is investing heavily in its new reality series "utopia," spending millions of dollars on the show that challenges 15 participants to create their own society from scratch on a secluded land in california. the contestants, who come from various backgrounds, will start with no infrastructure and only $10,000 to build their civilization. the show, which premieres on september 7, comes with a large production team and extensive video coverage, and is expected to replace "x factor" and "american idol" on fox's schedule. however, the production has faced internal challenges, with a high production cost and changes in network leadership. the dutch version of the show has had initial success.
1035	the duchess of cambridge, kate middleton, has been seen breast-feeding her newborn son, prince george, demonstrating her commitment to giving him the best start in life. she left kensington palace last week in a £50 breast-feeding dress from maternity wear specialists seraphine. the dress, designed for breast-feeding moms, has sold out and now has a waiting list. experts note that breast milk is easier for babies to digest and helps prevent various diseases. the duchess has continued to follow breast-feeding advice she received at the hospital. breast-feeding is recommended by the department of health for the first six months, but fewer than half of new moms continue to do so beyond that time. both princess diana and the queen have breast-fed their children. the duchess had an 11-hour labor without pain relief, according to sources.
1036	a new bar named fragrances at the ritz-carlton hotel in berlin, germany, is the first in the world to offer cocktails matched with guests' favorite perfumes. the innovative bar invites drinkers to smell bottles of perfumes, such as armani and yves saint laurent, and select a corresponding cocktail from the menu. the visual menu displays perfume bottles, and the drinks are served in unique ways to reflect the fragrance. non-alcoholic options are also available. fragrances' mixologist and perfume expert, henning heissen, created the menu with a focus on sensory experience, offering cocktails that smell just like the corresponding scent, and unique serving options. the bar also offers bar snacks from the ritz-carlton kitchen to complement the creative drinks. the bar features sleek decor, with some cocktails served in unusual containers, adding to the immersive experience. arnd heissen, from the ritz-carlton, emphasized the importance of the sensory experience and the discovery elements of the new bar.
1037	according to two new surveys, president barack obama's approval rating has reached an all-time low at 40% and 42% in the washington post/abc news and nbc news/wall street journal polls, respectively. the democratic party's favorability rating also hit a record low of 39% in the former poll. obama's sagging approval numbers, which have been linked to republican candidates in key races, are impacting the party, particularly among african-americans and women. obama will campaign for seven gubernatorial candidates in the final weeks of the campaign. some democratic senate candidates have tried to distance themselves from obama on key issues, while republicans have exploited his low approval ratings. both parties have low favorability ratings, with congress registering an 83% disapproval rating in a september cnn/orc poll.
1038	george carlin, a comedian known for his observational skills, language talent, and fearless use of profanity and irreverence, passed away at the age of 71 due to heart failure. he was remembered by fellow comedians jerry seinfeld, roseanne barr, and bill maher as a brilliant writer and performer with an amazing breadth of subject matter. his comedic routines covered mundane topics as well as controversial issues like religion and politics. he leaves a legacy of 14 hbo specials and books. despite his angry and indignant onstage persona, he was a kind and gracious person offstage, known for his kindness towards struggling comedians. his family is planning a private memorial and a public event in his honor. carlin's death came unexpectedly, even though he had been dealing with heart problems. the comedians and his family were caught off guard by his passing.
1039	bayern munich continued their dominant form in the bundesliga, extending their lead at the top to 13 points with a 5-0 thrashing of eintracht frankfurt. arsenal began their vital champions league defense with a 2-0 victory over crystal palace, momentarily taking the lead in the english premier league. arsenal manager arsene wenger praised the performance of returning midfielder alex oxlade-chamberlain, as manchester city host chelsea in a crucial matchup monday. liverpool lost ground after a 1-1 draw with west bromwich albion, while bayern's marco guizado put them ahead early and frank ribery, arjen robben, dante, and mario mandzukic added to the tally. bayern has not lost since the mid-season break, with pep guardiola's influence evident as thiago alcantara broke a bundesliga record for ball touches against frankfurt. in serie a, juventus strengthened their grip on the title with a 3-1 win over inter milan, moving nine points clear. the champions league will test bayern, with liverpool and arsenal presenting significant challenges in the knockout stages.
1040	woolwich terror suspect michael adebolajo was filmed encouraging 1,500 followers to turn against britain during a hate-filled speech outside a mosque in north london on the anniversary of 9/11 in 2009. the video, unearthed by the daily mail, shows adebolajo urging the crowd not to be afraid of non-believers, calling them "pigs," and encouraging them to please allah instead. after his speech, some in the crowd hurled bricks and fireworks at police. the emergence of the video adds to concerns about what mi5 knew about adebolajo and another terror suspect, michael adebowale, who was charged with the murder of drummer lee rigby and possession of a firearm. adebolajo remains in serious condition and it could be weeks before he is fit enough to be questioned. rigby was killed outside woolwich barracks last wednesday from multiple stab wounds. adebolajo, wearing a white skull cap and traditional black islamic robe, told the crowd during his 80-second speech that they should not be scared of the police or cameras. a witness said some in the crowd began running around and chasing members of far-right groups, leading to ten arrests. it is not known whether adebolajo was among the radicals who chased the far-right groups.
1041	oracle co-founder larry ellison, 70, is stepping down as ceo and will be replaced by safra catz and mark hurd as co-ceos. ellison will remain as the company's chairman and chief technology officer and will focus on product engineering, technology development, and strategy. ellison, who founded oracle in 1977, is worth $51.3 billion and owns most of lanai, hawaii's smallest publicly accessible island. catz will oversee manufacturing, finance, and legal functions, while hurd will manage sales, service, and other global business units. ellison and hurd have been working closely together for years and have a long business relationship, with hurd previously being hired by ellison after being let go from hewlett-packard due to expense report issues. a significant tech shift in the industry, with more companies moving towards leasing software applications in remote data centers instead of paying licensing fees for in-house installations, is causing a new phase in oracle's history. ellison started oracle with $1,200 and is now one of the world's five richest people.
1042	josé mourinho has defended chelsea players diesgor costa and cesc fabregas against criticism from sergio ramos for not playing for their national teams, stating that there are "double standards" at play. both players were ruled out due to injuries but played for chelsea against west brom. mourinho dismissed ramos' comments, as he was not a doctor, and pointed out that vincent kompany had played for manchester city after missing belgium's match against wales due to injury. mourinho also highlighted the numerous instances of players being injured for their national teams but recovering to play for their clubs.
1043	in february 2013, the royal bank of scotland (rbs) was fined £390 million for its involvement in the libor rate-fixing scandal. regulators released damning emails between rbs traders who joked about manipulating interest rates, with one trader asking to lower fixings and another boasting about the money they could make. the manipulation took place between 2006 and 2010, even after rbs received a £45 billion taxpayer bailout during the financial crisis. libor, the key interbank lending rate used to determine mortgage and savings rates, was manipulated by traders worldwide, leading to the exit of barclays' ceo bob diamond. rbs faced fines totaling £300 million from us and uk regulators, and the behaviour was described as "truly outrageous." chancellor george osborne promised those responsible would face legal action, while rbs ceo stephen hester expressed disappointment but refused to resign or return a £1.5 million bonus. six workers were sacked, while some were awaiting disciplinary action or had already quit. rbs faces potential criminal charges in the us. the revelations came after business secretary vince cable called for a return to traditional values in banks during a speech.
1044	in this article published on august 9, 2012, paul harris reports on keri-anne payne's fourth-place finish in the olympic 10km swimming marathon despite her best efforts and a tough, violent race. payne, a double world champion and favorite for a medal, was caught in a scrum and hit several times during the grueling two-hour race. she stopped at the feeding station on the third lap and dropped a bottle, losing valuable time. the race was not only physically demanding but also presented other challenges, such as jellyfish stings in past competitions and swimming in murky water or with floating debris at the olympics. payne's disappointing result mirrors the underperformance of the british swimmers at the olympics. she was encouraged by her fiancé, teammates, and family, including bridesmaid rebecca adlington, who expressed pride and support on social media. despite finishing fourth in the world, payne and her team know they will need to improve to secure the future funding of £25.1million for british swimming.
1045	carlo tavecchio, a 71-year-old italian businessman, was elected as the new president of the italian football federation (figc) despite heavy criticism for an allegedly racist comment he made during an address to amateur league delegates. in the third round of voting at the elective assembly in rome, tavecchio received 63.33% of the votes, ousting demetrio albertini. the controversy started when tavecchio used a fictional example during a speech about foreign players and mentioned "[fictional player] opti poba," who "previously was eating bananas and now is a first-team player for lazio," which drew condemnation from many in italian football, including serie a clubs fiorentina and sampdoria. tavecchio apologized and figc promised to investigate the comment on fifa's behalf. after being elected, tavecchio promised to unite the federation and work together to reform the system, and he will soon announce his choice for the italian national team head coach, with antonio conte and roberto mancini being among the leading candidates.
1046	bill roache, the 81-year-old coronation street star, pleaded not guilty to historic sexual offenses at preston crown court in lancashire on september 2, 2013. he was arrested in may and charged with two counts of raping a 15-year-old girl in east lancashire in 1967 and five indecent assaults involving four girls aged between 11 or 12 and 16 in the manchester area between 1965 and 1968. roache confirmed his name in the court, and the seven counts against him were read out. he denied all the charges and remains on bail with various conditions. roache, who has played ken barlow in the itv1 soap since its launch, will not appear in the programme while legal proceedings are ongoing. he made no comment to the media after the 30-minute hearing. roache's trial is scheduled to begin on january 14, 2014, and is expected to last four weeks. roache was initially 'astonished and deeply horrified' by the accusations and vowed to 'strenuously deny' them.
1047	new jersey governor chris christie is facing criticism from both the left and his own conservative base following the controversial closure of access lanes to the george washington bridge as political retaliation against the mayor of fort lee. the incident has revived long-standing concerns among conservatives about christie's embrace of president barack obama during superstorm sandy relief efforts and his willingness to work with democrats on issues like immigration reform. critics argue that christie has put his presidential ambitions above the interests of the republican party and that his handling of the situation lacks transparency and accountability. while some within the party are calling for accountability, others believe the controversy will not significantly harm christie's chances in the 2016 primary.
1048	a ship hull that was hidden beneath the world trade center site in lower manhattan for over 200 years has been identified as an 18th century hudson river sloop, likely originating from colonial-era philadelphia. researchers at the lamont-doherty earth observatory of columbia university used a process called "dendroprovenancing" to analyze tree rings and identify the oak used in the ship's frame, dating it to around 1773. the same oak trees were also likely used to build independence hall in philadelphia where the declaration of independence was signed. the ship was discovered approximately 22 feet below ground in 2010, and is currently being stored at texas a&m university, with the lower manhattan development corporation discussing potential plans for future preservation. the ship may have been sunk accidentally or deliberately and was buried under fill materials used to extend manhattan's shoreline. researchers believe it could provide valuable data for understanding past climate change and ecology. in other news, a u-boat and its american prey have reportedly been discovered at the bottom of the gulf of mexico, and an underwater pirate ship has been rediscovered after 125 years at the bottom of san francisco bay.
1049	country singer mindy mccready's body was sent back to the coroner's office for additional tests after her funeral, leading to speculation that drugs may have played a role in her suicide. mccready, who shot herself at her home in arkansas almost a month after her boyfriend's suicide, had been in a mental health substance abuse program following her boyfriend's death and had admitted to using alcohol to cope. there have been reports that she was put on medication while in the facility, some of which may have increased her suicidal thoughts. mccready, known for hits like "ten thousand angels" and "guys do it all the time," left behind two young sons. her funeral was held in fort myers, florida, where she was born and raised, and was attended by over 400 people. her mother and stepfather gave eulogies, and her brothers and ex-boyfriend spoke of their memories of her. mccready struggled with addiction and had previously attempted suicide several times, including while pregnant with her youngest son. her boyfriend, billy mcknight, believes she may have taken her children's lives with her if they had been present during her final suicide attempt. mccready's first suicide attempt was in 2005, following an altercation with her former fiance and father of her eldest son. she had also been dealing with legal troubles at the time. a second memorial service for mccready's professional colleagues is planned in nashville in early march.
1050	a study published in the journal of consumer research suggests that touching merchandise in stores can make shoppers more likely to overpay for an item due to a sense of ownership. retailers encourage customers to handle merchandise to increase sales. to save money, shoppers can avoid browsing both in-store and online as visualization can also lead to unnecessary purchases. behavioral economics, a field of study once discredited, is now important for helping people save money and spend less. compulsive spending can lead to financial difficulties and feelings of regret. to combat compulsive spending, individuals can implement self-imposed restrictions, such as banning themselves from stores or engaging in alternative activities when the urge to shop arises.
1051	american racer robby gordon faces potential disqualification from the dakar rally after stewards found his hummer's engine did not conform to regulations following modifications to its ventilation system. gordon, who was the main challenger to leader stephane peterhansel, won monday and tuesday's stages but must await a decision from the french automobile sport federation within two months before knowing his fate. his appeal allowed him to continue racing, although he lost over 15 minutes in the 10th stage due to car damage. peterhansel, bidding for a record 10th overall win, extended his lead over gordon to nearly 20 minutes. in the motorcycle section, ktm riders cyril despres and marc coma are separated by just 16 seconds, with despres winning wednesday's stage and coma finishing second. both riders have won the race three times.
1052	asteroid 2012 da14, moving at 17,450 miles per hour, is expected to fly past earth on february 15, coming closer than any known asteroid of its size in history. nasa is confident that it will not hit the planet, but it will give earth a closer shave than most gps or television satellites. star gazers in certain regions may be able to view it with binoculars or consumer telescopes. research is being conducted on this near-earth object to learn more about its composition, and nasa is considering the possibility of mining asteroids for resources. though asteroids can pose a threat, they can also provide valuable resources for scientific study and future space exploration. one asteroid of similar size collided with earth 50,000 years ago, creating a large crater in arizona, but an asteroid like 2012 da14 would do much less damage due to its composition of stone.
1053	akilah and kris lawrenceville, a constantly bickering married couple in georgia, had to re-evaluate their communication styles after considering divorce. they met in high school, where akilah was an extroverted cheerleading captain and kris was a serious artist. despite their different personalities, they connected and eventually married in 2002. however, their initial strengths became sources of irritation, as akilah preferred laying out problems while kris avoided conflict. one winter evening in 2009, their differences led to a heated argument during a kwanzaa celebration, prompting akilah to contemplate divorce. three days later, she informed kris of her intentions, but he was surprised and saddened. instead of arguing, kris began asking thoughtful questions and akilah realized he genuinely wanted to understand the issues. they discussed their communication styles, setting aside time to think before addressing problems and using simple gestures like holding hands to refocus on their relationship. today, akilah and kris continue to have conflicts but resolve them more effectively, understanding that marriage is a constant process of connecting with each other.
1054	brandie lane, an audio engineer recently joined the u.s. army, won a grammy award for best engineered album in the classical category forher work on quincy porter's album "the complete viola works" at the 62nd annual grammy awards. lane previously worked at sono luminus, a record label in winchester, virginia, where she mixed and mastered two other grammy-nominated albums. she is now an audio engineer for the west point band and attended the ceremony in a black gown, contrasting the flashy attire of stars, while she wore her formal army uniform to the special merit awards dinner. lane expressed gratitude for her experiences and was thrilled to meet iconic artist julie andrews, who received a lifetime achievement award. she plans to continue a career in the army but hopes to do freelance work in the commercial music industry and is undecided on where to display her grammy.
1055	sir cliff richard, 74, has added an extra date to his upcoming tour despite an ongoing child sex abuse investigation. police searched his £3.1million apartment in berkshire in august after receiving allegations he sexually assaulted a schoolboy at a christian rally in sheffield in 1985. sir cliff has denied the accusations and no charges have been pressed. the singer has extended his sell-out tour, which includes concerts in birmingham, liverpool, manchester, and sheffield, adding a date at the royal albert hall for his 75th birthday. the police investigation, which began six months ago, is ongoing, and sir cliff and his team are reportedly confident that the allegations will be dropped before the tour begins in september. sir cliff has previously denied the allegations through two statements on facebook. the police search of sir cliff's apartment was met with controversy, with some criticizing the way the search was handled and leaked information to the press.
1056	a dramatic and tragic event occurred in london when an off-duty soldier, lee rigby, 25, of the royal regiment of fusiliers, was brutally attacked and killed by two men in broad daylight on wednesday, may 22, 2013. the attackers, michael adebolajo, 28, and michael adebowale, 22, allegedly shouted "allah akbar!" as they used knives and meat cleavers to kill rigby. this senseless act of violence has shocked the nation and inspired an outpouring of grief from hundreds of strangers who left heartfelt tributes, poems, and notes near the scene of the crime at woolwich barracks in southeast london. the soldiers' comrades, fellow servicemen and women, and their families also paid their respects, leaving a sea of flowers, teddy bears, and messages of condolence. a focal point for the tributes, rigby became an instant symbol of courage and resilience, eliciting an outpouring of support from the community. the attack was reportedly an act of terrorism, and the suspected killers were known to mi5. the prime minister of the united kingdom, david cameron, strongly denounced the attack and condemned the killers as cowards. the event led to an unprecedented rise in donations and sales for the help for heroes charity. the incident also resulted in a number of suspected revenge attacks on mosques around the country, and two men were arrested in separate incidents in gillingham, kent, and braintree, essex. overall, the tragic death of lee rigby brought the british community together in the face of adversity, inspiring solidarity and fortitude.
1057	the manta resort on pemba island, off the coast of tanzania, has added a new underwater bedroom to its previous 16-room offering. designed by swedish company genberg underwater hotels, the three-story structure includes a rooftop deck, bathroom, lounge area at sea level, and an underwater bedroom with fish. at night, spotlights under the windows attract and illuminate squid and octopus. with a coral reef nearby, the resort is popular with divers. the underwater room can be booked for $1500 per night for a two-person stay or $900 per night for singles. the manta resort's underwater bedroom is the latest innovative design from the swedish company, joining their underwater room in a swedish lake, which was previously featured among unusual places to spend the night.
1058	iraq's oil production is expected to reach at least 3.5 million barrels a day by the end of 2013, despite ongoing violence and sectarian tensions that have resulted in over 6000 deaths this year. iraqi deputy prime minister for energy hussain al-shahristani cited increased production from two new fields in southern iraq as the reason for the increase. iraq's original goal of producing 6 million barrels a day by the end of 2013 has been revised due to difficult contracts and the need to prioritize long-term recovery over short-term production. criticisms over iraq's production fees and tight contracts have led to a reconsideration of existing deals. iraq has committed to producing just over 9 million barrels a day by the end of the decade, aiming to join the ranks of saudi arabia and russia as top producers. the international energy agency has expressed skepticism, suggesting iraq will only produce 6 million barrels in that time frame. iraq sits on 143 billion barrels of crude, with potential for discovering more. thawing relations between tehran and washington could impact iraq's production if economic sanctions on iran are lifted, but shahristani does not expect significant downward pressure on prices or noticeable production changes in the short term.
1059	gear, a midlands-based company, is selling a power plate with two uk 3-pin sockets and two usb ports for £20. this device, which can fit any backbox up to a depth of 25mm, allows users to free up mains sockets and charge up to four devices with micro-usb to usb cables simultaneously. the usb ports are surge and spike protected, delivering up to 2 amps to each device to ensure fast charging. the plate shuts off when no device is connected and is certified with european stand-by mode and bs and ce approvals. foxconn recently revealed images of a new usb type-c connector, designed for thinner devices, which will require an adapter for older devices.
1060	the lead singer of the metal band as i lay dying, tim lambesis, was arrested and charged with attempting to hire someone to kill his estranged wife. the san diego county sheriff's department announced the arrest on tuesday, stating that an investigation began on may 2 after learning of the solicitation for murder. the arraignment was scheduled for thursday afternoon. last september, meggan lambesis filed for divorce from her husband. the band, which has been nominated for a grammy award and has released eight studio albums, issued a statement expressing their support for tim and his family. the investigation took place without incident, and tim was arrested at a business in oceanside. the band had previously declined to discuss their spiritual beliefs or label their music as christian.
1061	cbc radio in canada is asking listeners to choose 49 songs that best represent the country for president-elect barack obama. canadians are voting on the songs, which range from classical to contemporary, from a list of 100, including acts like the montreal symphony orchestra, the band, rush, feist, and arcade fire. the voting ends this friday, and the chosen songs will be played on the day of obama's inauguration. denise donion, cbc's executive director, stated that "one of the best ways to know canada is through the depth and breadth of our artistic expression." obama's musical tastes include old-school r&b, blues, and classical, and cbc suggested that his playlist could benefit from canadian content.
1062	for the first time, a bionic hand with the ability to provide lifelike sensations is to be transplanted onto an amputee's arm. this hand, which is attached directly to the nervous system via electrodes on two main nerves, not only allows recipients to control it using their thoughts but also provides real-time sensory feedback. scientists believe this breakthrough will pave the way for more advanced artificial limbs with increased dexterity and feeling. an italian medical team plans to transplant the hand to a patient in rome later this year. additionally, researchers have found success in helping paralyzed individuals regain movement through a combination of drugs, electrical impulses, and training. although full human trials are still a few years off, they plan to stimulate the spinal cords of five patients with limited leg movement in the coming months.
1063	emmanuel petit, a former teammate of thierry henry at monaco, arsenal, and the french national team, has spoken out against the apathy towards henry in france and suggested that the country would be better led by germany. petit described the prevailing attitude towards the striker as hypocritical and cowardly. henry, who turned 37 on march 31 and is leaving new york red bulls, may return to arsenal in a non-playing role and has been suggested for a farewell match with the french team. petit defended henry against criticism for his handball in the 2009 play-off tie against ireland, which helped france qualify for the world cup in south africa. petit faced criticism himself for apparently praising nazi germany but said he meant only modern-day germany. petit expressed his frustration with the media's treatment of henry and likened it to wayne rooney's perception in england. petit described the french people as arrogant, smug, untruthful, and hypocritical.
1064	the maldives' gili lankanfushi resort was named the best hotel in the world by tripadvisor in their 13th annual travelers' choice awards. three maldives resorts - cocoa island by como (no. 6), and constance moofushi (no. 15) - made it to the top 25 global list. the awards recognized over 8,100 properties based on traveler reviews. the langham chicago was the top us hotel, with january being an ideal time to book due to lower rates. the inn above oak creek in sedona, arizona, was named the most romantic us hotel, and the luxury villas at the place in ko tao, thailand, was named the most romantic hotel worldwide.
1065	montreal resident david freiheit attached a gopro camera with a piece of bread to gain a squirrel's perspective, but was surprised when a curious squirrel ran off with the device. the squirrel carefully inspected the object, but when it realized it wasn't edible, it dropped the camera, which was safely returned to freiheit. the incident was captured on camera, providing viewers with a unique footage of the squirrel's exploration.
1066	a british woman is in critical condition after being stabbed several times by a 22-year-old british man in albufeira, portugal. the suspect is currently in custody and is due to appear in court tomorrow. the foreign office has confirmed they are providing consular assistance to the woman following the attack, which took place in the popular holiday resort city in the algarve region, known for attracting thousands of british tourists each summer.
1067	beverly hills police are urging justin bieber to address noise complaints from neighbors regarding his house parties at his condo, where officers have received multiple calls over the weekend. the singer hasn't been charged with disturbing the peace but neighbors could make a citizen's arrest. bieber, who is on probation for a vandalism conviction and egging case, recently moved into the condo after selling his calabasas mansion. police asked him to respect the community and consider the elderly and sleeping children when hosting parties. additionally, bieber recently avoided a felony robbery charge related to a cell phone altercation and was again involved in a racial controversy.
1068	nick clegg, the deputy prime minister of the united kingdom, announced in the commons on may 22, 2012, that a first-born daughter of the duke and duchess of cambridge would become queen even if the new laws regarding succession had not been passed yet. the agreement to change the current law of male primogeniture, which gives male heirs priority in the royal line of succession, was made during a meeting of commonwealth leaders in perth, australia, last october. the 16 countries where elizabeth ii is the monarch have agreed to eliminate this 300-year-old law to prevent a potential constitutional crisis if the first child of william and kate is a girl. the change in rules, however, raised concerns in australia about fueling the republican movement's efforts to remove the queen as their head of state. the current law only allows elizabeth ii to be queen due to her lack of brothers. additionally, the commonwealth leaders agreed to overturn the act of settlement of 1701, which restricts the monarchy to protestant heirs of the electress sophia of hanover, in order to accommodate potential future catholic monarchs.
1069	the uss ronald reagan aircraft carrier will replace the uss george washington at yokosuka naval base in japan. the move is due to the need for the us navy to station its most capable ships forward for quicker response times in the indo-asia-pacific region. the reagan, a nuclear-powered supercarrier, has a history in japan, having participated in relief efforts after the 2011 tsunami and with sailors suing the tokyo electric power company over fukushima radiation exposure. the george washington, which was the first american nuclear-powered carrier based in japan, will head to virginia for overhaul and refueling.
1070	a thief with a striking resemblance to the children's character burglar bill was caught on cctv stealing items from a waitrose store in southend, essex on christmas eve 2012. the real-life burglar, wearing a dark blue and white striped jersey and a black hat, bears a strong resemblance to the cartoon character known for his distinctive attire and catchphrase "i'll 'ave that!" the burglar bill character, from the popular children's book series by janet and allan ahlberg, followed the adventures of the mischievous burglar who stole food and goods undetected. the thief and an accomplice were caught on cctv and anyone with information about the burglary is asked to contact the police. burglar bill is a beloved children's character who has turned over a new leaf after accidentally stealing a baby. the books, published by penguin from 1977 to 1999, are still available for purchase online.
1071	emmett and owen ezell, conjoined twins who were separated at medical city children's hospital in dallas, texas, celebrated their first birthday at the hospital with the doctors and nurses who helped them. the boys, who share a liver and intestines, have since undergone rehabilitation and went home in june. they enjoyed their special day wearing matching outfits, surrounded by family and hospital staff. despite being separated, they are developing distinct personalities. owen is learning to crawl and attempting acrobatics, while emmett is more relaxed. the boys, who still rely on feeding tubes, will return home to guthrie, oklahoma, with their parents and two brothers.
1072	kishore nimmala, 32, is on trial at southwark crown court for stealing fakhara sultana's mobile phone during a date at the ruby blue bar in leicester square, london. nimmala asked sultana to pay for a third round of drinks, but she replied that she had no money. an argument ensued, and when they were leaving the bar, nimmala is accused of snatching sultana's mobile phone and running off with it. the court heard that nimmala kept badgering sultana for her share of the money spent on the date and became angry when she refused to pay. police officers caught up with nimmala on st martin's lane and witnessed him throwing the phone away. nimmala denies one count of theft and claims he took the phone because he wanted sultana to pay her share of the money spent on the date. the trial continues.
