1156	a three-week-old baby, eliza delacruz, who went missing after a shooting at her family's home in long beach, california, on saturday night, has been found dead in a dumpster in imperial beach, just south of san diego. the body was discovered on sunday afternoon, and detectives are working to confirm the identity of the baby. the shooting at the family's home left eliza's parents and uncle injured, and authorities believe the baby was kidnapped by the shooter. no suspect description has been provided, but police believe the kidnapping was not random. anyone with information is urged to contact the lapd at 565-435-6711. the child's parents have not yet made a public statement, and the father was released from the hospital but the mother and uncle remain in critical but stable condition.
1157	jon hamm, known for his signature slick-backed hair on "mad men," has confessed to disliking his hair, calling it "goofy" and a "pain." during the promotion of his new movie "the day the earth stood still," he revealed that he's had to cut his hair for roles and that it never looks good. despite his hair woes, hamm's acting career is thriving, with roles in "the day the earth stood still," "the boy in the box," hosting "saturday night live," and appearing on "30 rock." he has received numerous accolades, including emmy and golden globe nominations for "mad men," and is excited about the opportunities his success has brought him.
1158	former us vice-president al gore's 2007 apocalyptic warning that the north polar ice cap could be completely gone in seven years due to climate change was contradicted by recent data revealing an increase in arctic ice extent for the second year in a row. the mail on sunday reported that the ice had expanded by 43% to 5.62 million square kilometres last monday, august 25, which is the highest level recorded since 2006. this increase was substantiated by satellite images from the university of illinois's cryosphere project, which also showed more concentrated and thicker ice. although some scientists have predicted ice-free summers in the near future, experts now believe that natural variability, such as ocean temperatures, may be contributing to the arctic's ice recovery, and that more research is needed to establish the extent of this impact. polar bears, which were thought to be declining in number due to melting ice, have seen their population estimated to be higher than in the 1970s, and computer model predictions of declining bear populations caused by ice melt have also failed to come true.
1159	mauricio pochettino was disappointed with tottenham's 1-1 draw against fiorentina in the europa league as he believed spurs deserved more from their first-leg performance at white hart lane. roberto soldado opened the scoring for tottenham with a volley in the sixth minute, but jose maria basanta equalized for fiorentina in the 36th minute, securing a valuable away goal. pochettino sent on harry kane as a second-half substitute, but opted to rest several key players due to spurs' busy schedule. fiorentina boss vincenzo montella felt his team finished the stronger side and were unlucky not to win. spurs currently sit sixth in the premier league and face six games in 17 days, including the capital one cup final against chelsea. pochettino will have to make tough decisions on team selection to manage the upcoming fixtures, with both the europa league and premier league offering the possibility of champions league qualification.
1160	the australian government has classified the sydney siege, which occurred at the lindt chocolate cafe in december 2014, as a terrorist incident for insurance purposes. this ruling, made by treasurer joe hockey, means that insurers cannot refuse claims due to terrorism exclusion clauses in their policies. three insurance claims have been registered related to the siege. gunman man haron monis held 18 hostages and killed manager tori johnson and barrister katrina dawson. he displayed the islamic flag during the siege. some hostages are reportedly seeking large sums of money for media interviews. the government is conducting a review to learn lessons from the siege, and an inquest is scheduled to begin in january.
1161	fast food chains, including burger king, mcdonald's, subway, and kfc, offer secret menus with hidden items for customers in the know. hack the menu, a website, reveals these off-the-menu selections, such as burger king's suicide burger (four beef patties, four slices of cheese, and four rashers of bacon), mcdonald's monster mac (a big mac with six extra beef patties), subway's pizza sub (two pepperoni toasties stacked on top of each other), and kfc's triple down (a double-decker sandwich with fried chicken instead of bread). these secret menu items are not officially listed but can be requested at some outlets, and the price may vary. hack the menu claims to be the 'ultimate and complete secret menu resource' and covers both unofficial creations and diy inventions made by customers. a spokesperson for burger king denied the existence of a secret menu, while subway stated their stores are independently owned and offer choice by allowing customization.
1162	andrew hine, headteacher of benjamin britten high school in lowestoft, suffolk, has introduced "time out" cards that allow pupils to leave their classes when feeling overwhelmed. the scheme, deemed an 'admission of failure' by some, allows students to exit lessons with a card whenever they choose. only 4% of the school's pupils have the cards, and experts warn of potential misbehavior and undermining of disciplinary structure. critics argue it's a last resort to weak teaching and school issues. the school insists the cards are given to specific students after a review of their needs. frequent use triggers a review. the strategy aims to minimize classroom disruption. the school, which has about 950 students, was put into special measures due to weak teaching, low expectations, and bullying issues.
1163	joaquin "el chapo" guzman, the world's most powerful drug baron with an estimated fortune of over $1 billion, has eluded capture since escaping from a mexican prison in a laundry truck in 2001. recently, there were reports that guzman was killed in a shootout between two drug gangs in the guatemalan jungle, but guatemalan officials now call it a misunderstanding, as no evidence of his presence was found at the scene. guzman, who is accused of starting mexico's cartel wars and presiding over a $1 billion drug empire, has infiltrated the highest level of mexico's government and is a top drug lord wanted by both the us and mexico. the confusion arose from mistaken eyewitness accounts and guatemalan interior minister mauricio lopez bonilla apologized for the earlier reports. guzman, 5ft 2in tall, has evaded capture for over a decade and is the subject of a vast manhunt, known for his vast drugs operation that moves tons of drugs at a time from colombia into mexico and on to the us, and his involvement in the killings of his rivals. recently, he was officially recognized as chicago's public enemy number one by the city's crime commission, following a long history of crimes and violence, including the massacre of 27 ranch workers in 2011. guzman's cartel has been expanding internationally, and he is known to have a bounty of $7 million on his head.
1164	an instructor at fort sam houston army medical department center and school in texas was shot by a fellow serviceman outside her office on monday. the suspect, who is currently in police custody, later surrendered to authorities and was involved in a relationship with the victim, according to san antonio police chief william mcmanus. the victim, who was shot up to nine times, is in stable condition. the base was locked down for two hours while military police cleared the building where the shooting took place. fort sam houston, which hosts one of the nation's top burn units and most army medics undergo training there, has not had a shooting incident in 20 years.
1165	one year ago, a tunisian street vendor's self-immolation sparked a wave of protests that led to the downfall of oppressive governments in the arab world. digital activism through social media platforms like twitter, facebook, and youtube played a significant role in organizing these protests. however, a new threat to digital activism is emerging in the us with the house of representatives expected to vote on the stop online piracy act (sopa) and protect ip act. these bills would require social media platforms to proactively monitor and censor users to prevent copyright infringement, while website operators who fail to comply could be blacklisted and prosecuted. critics argue that these bills' legal and technical solutions resemble those used by authoritarian regimes to censor online dissent. sopa and protect ip could enable abuse of copyright law to stifle criticism, making online speech more vulnerable to censorship. existing copyright law has already been used to suppress critics, as seen in the case of security researcher trevor eckhart, who faced legal threats for analyzing a software program. the russian and chinese governments have used copyright claims to crack down on activists. the deeper issue is that some members of congress seek to regulate the global internet for the benefit of the us entertainment industry, while also expressing support for global internet freedom. rep. christopher smith has introduced a new version of the global online freedom act to punish companies that sell censorship and surveillance equipment to authoritarian regimes. the impact of sopa and protect ip on digital activism could be severe, making the world even more dangerous for bloggers and activists.
1166	isis militants in syria are reportedly undergoing training to fly three seized fighter jets at the al-jarrah military airport near aleppo. the jets, believed to be decades-old mig21 or mig23 models taken from the syrian military, have been used for short flight training, raising concerns about potential attacks on british, us, and french targets in iraq. isis has been building a full-equipped military, seizing large tanks, artillery, and heavy weapons, including several major airfields. it is unclear whether the jets are equipped with weaponry or if the pilots are able to fly long distances. isis has previously captured jets in other parts of syria, but they were not in flying condition. kurdish forces, backed by us-led air strikes, have been making gains in the fight against militants in the key northern syrian town of kobani, pushing them back from their positions. meanwhile, six senior figures in the pakistani taliban have pledged allegiance to isis and its leader abu bakr al-baghdadi, expanding the group's influence among islamist groups. this could have serious consequences for security in pakistan, particularly near the afghan border. isis has been making gains around ramadi in iraq and has imposed a curfew in the city's provincial capital over fears of an advance. capturing ramadi would give isis unbroken control of a massive stretch of the syrian-turkish border. isis leader al-baghdadi was described by the new un human rights commissioner, zeid ra'ad al hussein, as the antithesis of human rights and a potentially genocidal movement.
1167	an nhs dentist, dr. anand kamath, who took on a large number of patients to prevent them from paying privately, was driven to suicide after health chiefs threatened to strike him off due to record-keeping issues. despite his dedication to the nhs and a 10,000-strong patient list, the primary care trust launched an investigation when officials criticized his record-keeping. dr. kamath and his wife, dr. rajni prasad, had been working relentlessly for the nhs for ten years without holidays or lunchbreaks. the couple tried to take on as many patients as possible and were on a modest contract. after two minor complaints, an audit led to a meeting where they were threatened with severe disciplinary actions, and a letter warned them of potential suspension from the nhs-approved dental list. dr. kamath's wife, who was also a dentist, found him dead at their home shortly after the letter arrived. she described the health officials' behavior as bullying and the pressure as unreasonable. the british dental association called for an inquiry into his death, and his wife expressed frustration that they received no support during the process. the nhs england spokesman confirmed that the investigation followed national clinical assessment service advice. the inquest recorded a verdict of suicide, with the coroner noting that the unreasonable pressure from the trust was a significant contributing factor.
1168	high blood pressure, also known as the "silent killer," affects more than 12.6 million people in england, with over five million of them unaware they have the condition. it is a major cause of premature death and disability, leading to strokes, heart attacks, heart failure, and kidney failure. the latest data from public health england (phe) shows that the annual cost from diseases caused by high blood pressure is estimated at £2.1 billion. phe has set up a blood pressure system leadership board to encourage people to take simple steps to reduce their blood pressure, including changing their diet, keeping a healthy weight, and not drinking too much alcohol. regular blood pressure checks and alerting doctors of any changes are also essential. companies are being urged to offer high-quality testing for their staff, and the focus will be on the most deprived areas, where people are 30% more likely to have hypertension. getting the nation's blood pressure levels into the normal range could prevent over half of all strokes and many heart attacks.
1169	uruguay striker luis suarez is under investigation by fifa for an off-the-ball incident in which he allegedly bit italy defender giorgio chiellini during uruguay's world cup victory. witnesses and tv footage suggest suarez left a bite mark on chiellini's shoulder, with the italian defender reporting the incident to fifa. suarez has previously been banned for biting opponents, and fifa has opened disciplinary proceedings against him. suarez denied the allegations, insisting it was just a collision. uruguay coach oscar tabarez and team captain diego lugano defended suarez, with lugano accusing chiellini of exaggerating the incident. fifa could ban suarez for up to 24 matches or two years if he is found guilty. uruguay defeated italy 1-0 to advance to the knockout stage, while italy's coach cesare prandelli offered his resignation following the team's elimination.

1171	alabama's chief justice roy moore has ordered probate judges not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, opposing a federal court ruling that declared the state's ban on gay marriage unconstitutional. moore, known for his conservative views, claimed that probate judges should not issue licenses inconsistent with the alabama constitution. several couples had been camped outside courthouses, hoping to be the first to receive licenses. the american civil liberties union (aclu) set up a phone line for couples denied licenses and planned to visit courthouses across the state. it remains uncertain if moore's directive will delay same-sex marriage in alabama, as some probate judges have pledged to follow the federal court order. the state governor robert bentley's spokeswoman did not comment on the matter. the issue gains attention as the united states moves towards greater marriage equality.
1172	the article discusses how the world's wealthiest individuals, particularly the 9.5 million dollar millionaires, have the potential to significantly contribute to environmental preservation through their vast accumulated wealth. however, the extent to which they are effectively aiding the fight against climate change and environmental degradation depends on their philanthropic actions. some notable billionaires, including bill gates, warren buffett, and richard branson, have already donated billions to various causes. others, such as ted turner, george soros, and luciano benetton, have invested in land conservation. philanthropists have the advantage of being able to quickly fund and initiate projects, but their actions can also face backlash from local communities who question foreign interference and the potential for exploitation of resources. the article also highlights the concern of rainforest inhabitants regarding the displacement caused by philanthropists purchasing large tracts of land. the effectiveness of philanthropic efforts also depends on the wise use of resources and avoiding potentially harmful initiatives, such as george soros' biofuel production in the cerrado region, which is causing significant deforestation.
1173	a businessman named andrew chimboza, 35, from africa has confessed to committing an act of cannibalism, admitting to ripping out and eating the heart of mbuyiselo manona, 62, to prove his heterosexuality during a fight. chimboza, who hails from zimbabwe, stated in a warning statement that he sat upon the victim, stabbed him in the chest, and consumed his heart at the scene in the cape town township of gugulethu. however, during a bail hearing, chimboza disputed the veracity of the statement, claiming it was fabricated after his arrest and assault by police. according to investigating officer constable mphumelelo yengwa, manona's autopsy revealed that his heart was missing, and the victim was still alive when chimboza allegedly took it out and consumed it. at the scene, officers found chimboza chewing raw flesh and manona's neck half-eaten, with a large hole in his chest. chimboza now claims he only remembers stabbing manona to death but cannot recall consuming his heart. the incident occurred on june 10, 2023.

1176	prime minister david cameron rejected the suggestion by princess anne for the uk to consider eating horsemeat to improve animal welfare, stating that he is not keen on horse consumption and that the country should stick to its non-horse eating habits. this comes after horsemeat was found in various meat products earlier this year, leading to a report recommending identification and prosecution of those responsible for the scandal, but no action has been taken to date. environment secretary owen paterson has expressed his willingness to eat horse products.
1177	sony has unveiled the xperia z ultra, a new waterproof android smartphone that can be used underwater up to a depth of 1.5m for taking pictures and filming full hd videos. the handset boasts a 6.4-inch display, which is the biggest and the thinnest large-screen smartphone on the market. powered by a qualcomm snapdragon 800 processor, the xperia z ultra also has handwriting recognition software and is compatible with the sony smartwatch 2 sw2, allowing users to manage calls, emails, music, and take photos remotely. the phone and the smartwatch were introduced at the mobile asia expo in shanghai.
1178	formula one fans were disappointed as second practice for the monaco grand prix was marred by wet conditions, leaving drivers waiting in the garage for the streets of monaco to dry out. only fernando alonso managed to set a fast lap towards the end of the session, finishing quickest with a time of 1:18.482secs. lewis hamilton and nico rosberg remained the fastest from the first practice session. championship leader hamilton posted a time of 1:18.271secs, just 0.032secs ahead of rosberg. adrian sutil was the first driver to venture out on the track with intermediates, and only nine drivers had set a time by the end of the session. with just six minutes remaining, only nine drivers had set a time, with a gap of almost 20 seconds separating them. sebastian vettel was third on the timesheet, followed by jean-eric vergne, valterri bottas, and jenson button. kimi raikkonen brought up the rear due to a mechanical fault that restricted him to four laps and a large gap to teammate alonso. the teams will primarily rely on their data from the first practice session ahead of final practice on saturday.
1179	maria bartiromo, a veteran tv anchor and financial reporter, ended her 20-year tenure at cnbc with an emotional farewell on the floor of the new york stock exchange. she broke down in tears as traders applauded her in a rare "clap-off" ceremony, expressing her appreciation for her close relationship with the stock exchange community. bartiromo's departure comes after she announced her move to fox business network, which will begin after her cnbc contract expires on november 24. the dow jones industrial average reached a new record high of 16,064.7 on her last day with cnbc. the network will be replacing her with cnbc's rising star, kelly evans, who will anchor "closing bell" with bill griffeth on mondays. bartiromo has been called "money honey" for her good looks and finance savvy since joining cnbc in 1993 after five years as a producer and assignment editor with cnn business news. she was the first journalist to report live from the floor of the new york stock exchange and went on to pioneer daily live reporting and win an emmy award for a documentary on google. reports suggest that fox business has offered bartiromo a higher salary and a live sunday morning show, which cnbc was unwilling to offer her. she is required to wait 60 days before appearing on a competing network under her current contract.
1180	mark hibberd, 46, was sentenced to eight months suspended for a year and ordered to complete 200 hours of community work for stealing over £4,000 from the estate and charity funds meant for the five-year-old daughter of his deceased girlfriend suzanne clarkson. the theft included £3,000 that suzanne had left for her daughter and over £1,200 raised through community events. hibberd and suzanne started dating in 2008, but she was diagnosed with breast cancer soon after and died in 2010. her mother, lorraine clarkson, expressed her disregard for hibberd's punishment and stated that the stolen funds were meant for her granddaughter. suzanne had previously suffered from breast cancer and was in remission when it returned and she hid her illness from her family before her death.
1181	in new delhi, residents in unplanned neighborhoods endure long waits and chaos for weekly water deliveries from tanker trucks, as they lack access to piped water. with temperatures reaching 45 degrees celsius, a shortage of clean water leads to frustration and arguments. the delhi government has planned to set up 500 "water atms" in the city, dispensing solar-powered water using rechargeable smartcards for a minimal fee. the idea was initiated by the indian social enterprise sarvajal, which has installed 15 such atms in the sarva ghera resettlement colony. the project, which has made a significant difference to residents' lives, purifies groundwater at localized plants and aims to change the mindset that clean water should be free. however, implementation faces challenges, as many people expect water to be provided for free. sarvajal's team continues to educate the community on the importance and cost savings of accessing clean water.
1182	a husband in culleoka, tennessee, shot and killed his wife, patricia cothran, 59, after she threatened him with a knife when he refused to take off shoes that belonged to her father. the incident occurred on thanksgiving day, and the husband, james cothran, 70, claimed he acted in self-defense. police found both a gun and knife at the scene and released cothran pending further investigation. the couple had experienced multiple domestic incidents in the past year, prompting a call to the authorities, but no arrests or injuries were reported. an investigation is ongoing, and the case will be presented to the maury county district attorney's office.
1183	the oscar pistorius trial in pretoria, south africa is coming to an end, and judge thokozile masipa is set to deliver her verdict on thursday. the judge will determine if pistorius intentionally killed his girlfriend reeva steenkamp, and if so, whether it was premeditated or not. if pistorius is found to have known steenkamp was behind the bathroom door when he fired the shots that killed her, and that this was not a reasonable mistake, he will be convicted of murder. if the judge believes pistorius made a mistake, she will decide if it was a reasonable one and convict him of culpable homicide instead. there are no minimum sentences for culpable homicide, and masipa will decide the punishment herself. pistorius also faces three other weapons charges: two for recklessly firing a gun in public and one for possession of ammunition without a license. the maximum penalties for these charges are five years in prison each. the trial has attracted widespread international attention, with steenkamp's death prompting debate about domestic violence and gun control in south africa.
1184	johnny manziel, the rookie quarterback for the cleveland browns, ended his disappointing first nfl season on a controversial note by partying excessively in miami after oversleeping and missing a team treatment session. he was fined by the team for his behavior and apologized for his actions, but was soon spotted partying with lebron james, ryan phillippe, and his girlfriend at the delano hotel. this came amidst growing concerns from some in the sports world, including espn columnist skip bayless, that manziel has a drinking problem and needs help. the browns' executives and coaches have previously expressed disappointment over manziel's partying, which was a major reason for his poor performance. manziel, who has a four-year contract worth $8.25 million and lucrative endorsement deals with companies like nike and mcdonald's, has not responded to the criticism. the browns' training for the next season won't begin until the summer, but some have already called for the team to drop manziel for his "lack of professionalism." manziel's history of partying goes back to his college days at texas a&m, where he won the heisman trophy and was known for his love of a good time. he assured the browns during the draft that he had "grown up," but his off-field behavior has raised concerns about his ability to focus on football.
1185	researchers at washington university in st. louis have developed a new way of taking pictures called compressed ultrafast photography (cup), which can capture 2d color images at up to 100 billion frames per second. this is significantly faster than current phones and could have a large impact on various research areas. the team was able to capture laser light reflecting off a mirror using the new camera and demonstrated its use in imaging laser pulse reflection, refraction, faster-than-light propagation of non-information, and photon racing in two media. potential applications include forensics, biomedicine, astronomy, and detecting diseases based on fluorescence lifetimes. cup consists of special devices that encode the image using micromirrors and reflect it to a streak camera, converting time to space and storing the raw data in a ccd. the researchers envision applications in analyzing the temporal activities of astronomical events and tracking space debris.
1186	immigration minister mark harper resigned last night after it was discovered he had employed a colombian cleaner who was in the country illegally. harper, who may face a £5,000 fine for not keeping copies of her immigration papers, offered his resignation because he failed to carry out the necessary checks. his resignation triggered a mini-government reshuffle, with harriett baldwin being promoted to assistant whip and james brokenshire appointed as the new immigration minister. harper had employed the unidentified cleaner at his london second home in 2007, before he was ranked second only to theresa may in the home office pecking order. he claimed over £2,000 from his westminster expenses for her services before second home allowances were tightened up. the cleaner is now subject to "enforcement action" by border officials and is believed to have provided false details about her right to be in the country. harper, who was known for his tough stance on immigration and had previously defended the controversial "go home" vans, said he now accepted that he should have checked more thoroughly. he faced criticism for his handling of the situation from both within and outside of the government.
1187	a 45-year-old man named barry wilkes from birmingham underwent a six-hour surgery to remove a massive one and a half stone tumor from his abdomen, which was twice the size of his heart. the tumor was discovered after wilkes experienced nausea and stomach pain, and tests revealed it was caused by cancer cells that had spread from another growth in his bowel. wilkes did not need chemotherapy or radiotherapy as all the cancerous cells were removed during the surgery, but he did lose part of his bowel and now has to stick to a high-calorie diet. twelve months after the surgery, wilkes was told his latest scan was clear, and he walked over 1,250 miles for cancer research uk as part of their stand up to cancer campaign. wilkes is urging people to support the campaign by standing up for the whole of october 18 and raising funds for the charity. cancer research uk spokeswoman paula young encourages everyone to unite in the fight against cancer by joining the stand up to cancer campaign and donating to the cause.
1188	the syrian national council, the leading opposition movement in syria, warned of an impending government "massacre" in the city of homs, where military troops and vehicles have surrounded the western city and thousands of troops are manning checkpoints. the council warns of a potential massacre to crush activists and quell the revolution in homs, which has been a center of anti-regime unrest. at least 17 people were killed in homs and 29 elsewhere in syria on friday. the un estimates that over 4,000 people have been killed in syria since the government crackdown on protesters began in mid-march. syrian president bashar al-assad's regime is accused of driving sectarian incidents and has burned oil pipelines in the neighborhood of baba amr. the syrian national council and the local coordination committees of syria say the regime is trying to ignite sectarian feuds and blame 'armed gangs' for the violence. us and british officials express concern over the potential for a large-scale assault on homs. human rights watch and the international crisis group have reported systematic abuses against civilians in homs by syrian government forces.
1189	john mcafee, a software pioneer and former fugitive, is being deported from guatemala after being arrested for illegal entry last week. he had been in the country after evading officials in belize, where he is a person of interest in the murder of american greg faull. mcafee's lawyers blocked an attempt to deport him back to belize, but he was eventually ordered to be deported to the united states. his 20-year-old belizean girlfriend, samantha vanegas, was left behind in guatemala. mcafee claimed he cannot take a flight that stops in any other country and he is heading to miami, florida. belize police want to question him regarding the murder of faull, and the state department is working to confirm reports of his release from a guatemalan judge. mcafee has been chronicling his life on the run in a blog and denies any involvement in faull's killing.
1190	the article discusses the power struggle between the director of national intelligence (dni) and the central intelligence agency (cia) following the creation of the dni position in 2005 as part of intelligence reform, with denny blair appointed as dni and leon panetta nominated to head the cia. the article explores the historical context of the cia's dominance and the rationale behind creating the dni position to coordinate the activities of all intelligence agencies. however, the dni's powers are limited and vague, leading to tension between the two roles, with outgoing cia director michael hayden and dni mike mcconnell expressing concerns about the lack of clear authority and the potential for conflict. during his confirmation hearing, cia nominee leon panetta appeared to have conflicting views on the relationship between the cia and the dni, leading to questions about how the new leadership team will function.
1191	michael foley, the brother of american journalist james foley who was beheaded by isis, urged western nations to coordinate their efforts in dealing with kidnappers from militant groups like isis. foley expressed his hope that improved communication between governments and captors could lead to the release of hostages, and encouraged people to honor his brother's passion for journalism by donating to a scholarship fund set up in his name. he also spoke about the inconsistent message sent by some european nations paying ransoms while the us refuses to do so. the foley family has endured a long and terrible ordeal that began with james' disappearance in syria in 2012, and worsened with threatening messages and the eventual video of his killing. the us military campaign against isis in iraq continued without pause following foley's death, with the potential for increased efforts in iraq and neighboring syria. the foley family had believed they were making progress towards james' release until the us began airstrikes in iraq, which they knew would not help. michael foley believes more could have been done to secure james' release, and expressed a need for a more cooperative approach between nations in resolving such situations. us special operations units were sent to syria to rescue hostages including foley, but were unable to find them. the administration is currently considering options beyond airstrikes to deal with the isis threat.
1192	a 14-year-old special needs student and her 19-year-old boyfriend have been charged with the murder of her father, dennis lane, in ellicott city, maryland. morgan lane arnold allegedly coaxed jason anthony bulmer into stabbing her father to death multiple times in a planned attack over several months through facebook and skype. the pair also planned to kill lane's fiancée, denise geiger, but did not get the opportunity as she called 911 when she heard her partner's screams. both suspects were arrested on friday morning and have been charged with first and second-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder. lane was found dead in an upstairs bedroom, and bulmer was discovered in a nearby room covered in blood. charging documents reveal that bulmer had been instructed to bring his own knife and was sent a photo of a kitchen carving knife for approval from arnold. the motive for the killing is not clear, but investigators believe it was encouraged by arnold in order for the couple to run away together. arnold's mother, cindi arnold, has expressed that she will make a public statement when the time is right, and both suspects are scheduled for preliminary hearings in may and june, respectively. police believe that electronic communication played a significant role in the plotting of the murder.
1193	senior doctors have warned that over 500 gp surgeries could close in england due to the retirements of a large number of gps, many of whom are over 60. the royal college of gps identifies 543 practices where over 90% of gps are nearing retirement age, but there is a shortage of younger doctors to replace them. with david cameron's promise of weekend gp appointments by 2020, senior gps warn that the current shortage of doctors will make it difficult to meet this goal. gps also claim they are not being given enough funding to manage the demands of an aging population, leading some practices to strike patients off their lists and others to put patients at risk due to basic failings. the situation is compared to a dam that is being overwhelmed, and if the issue is not addressed, whole sections of the dam may collapse and cause significant damage.
1194	bayern munich secured a 1-0 victory against cska moscow in the champions league, despite the game being played behind closed doors as punishment for racist chants by cska fans during a previous match. thomas muller scored the winning penalty in front of a virtually empty luzhniki stadium, with igor akinfeev in the cska goal diving the wrong way. xabi alonso and thiago alcantara dominated the midfield for bayern, and despite some near misses from cska, bayern looked the more likely team to score. the absence of supporters did little to dampen the spirits of bayern's traveling fans, who rented an office in a nearby skyscraper for a bird's-eye view of the game.
1195	the board of immigration appeals rejected an emergency appeal for a stay of deportation filed by the lawyer for nazi war crimes suspect john demjanjuk, clearing the way for his deportation to germany where he is sought for alleged involvement in killings at the sobibor death camp during world war ii. demjanjuk's argument that deportation would constitute torture was rejected by the board. he suffers from various health issues and may make an additional appeal to the sixth circuit court of appeals. demjanjuk, 89, has been fighting war crimes charges for over two decades and was previously extradited to israel and the us. germany issued an arrest warrant accusing him of being an accessory to 29,000 counts of murder as a guard at the camp from march to september 1943. demjanjuk claims he fought in the soviet army and later was a prisoner of war held by the germans.
1196	during world war ii, the british developed a cunning deception plan called "starfish sites" to mislead the german luftwaffe into believing they had hit their targets. these decoy towns, named after the initials "sf" for "special fire" sites, were built miles away from real communities and cities. when the germans attacked a real target, emergency teams quickly extinguished the flames, then lit the decoy fires to create an convincing mock-up of a bombing raid. tanks filled with fuel were placed on towers and ignited, creating black smoke, while a valve system was used to create a column of steam. the decoy sites protected major cities, such as liverpool, bristol, and nottingham, from devastating attacks, with around 730 bombing raids being diverted to these dummy sites. starfish sites were one of several decoy projects used to mislead the enemy, with others including fake airfields and cardboard tanks.
1197	a federal jury in arkansas convicted dr. randeep mann of carrying out a car bomb attack on dr. trent pierce, the head of the state's medical board, in february 2009. mann faced up to life in prison when he is sentenced later. pierce suffered serious injuries, including losing an eye, after the explosion as he approached his suv. mann, who had disciplinary issues with the medical board, was also found guilty of possessing unregistered grenades and two counts of possessing machine guns. his wife, sangeeta mann, was convicted of conspiring with him to conceal evidence and obstruct the investigation and faces up to 20 years in prison. mann was initially interviewed by federal agents on the day of the bombing but was not arrested until a month later when explosive rounds were discovered in a wooded area. sangeeta mann was acquitted of lying to the grand jury investigating the unregistered firearms.
1198	the european space agency's large european acoustic facility (leaf) in noordwijk, netherlands, houses the most powerful sound system in europe. the facility's massive horn can generate over 154 decibels of noise, which is more than enough to permanently deafen a human. to prevent accidents, the sound chamber is enclosed in steel-reinforced concrete walls coated with epoxy resin and sits on rubber bearing pads to isolate it from its surroundings. the facility is used to subject satellites to acoustic noise similar to a rocket's takeoff and flight through the atmosphere. sound waves can disrupt or damage the eardrums and cause severe pain or disorientation, and high-amplitude sound can even cause internal injury and death. the use of sound as a weapon, such as acoustic grenades and sound cannons, has been explored for crowd control and to incapacitate individuals.
1199	a tragic avalanche in colorado on april 20, 2013, took the lives of five men and injured one survivor, identified as jerome boulay. the victims were identified as christopher peters, joseph timlin, ryan novack, ian lanphere, and rick gaukel. the group of experienced backcountry snowboarders were participating in a snowboarding event called the rocky mountain high backcountry bash to raise money for the colorado avalanche information center when the avalanche occurred. the slide, estimated to be about 600 feet wide and eight feet deep, occurred below colorado's loveland pass, which is a popular spot for backcountry snowboarders but known for dangerous conditions. the tragedy marked the deadliest avalanche in colorado since 1962, when seven people were killed in a slide that wiped out several homes. a total of 12 people have died in avalanches in colorado during the 2012-2013 winter season. the colorado avalanche information center warned of potentially dangerous backcountry conditions due to heavy snow that pushed the old snowpack to the breaking point.
1200	tina malone, a 51-year-old actress best known for her role in shameless, underwent ivf at 50 and gave birth to a daughter named flame. previously, malone had been sent to a home for unmarried mothers when she became pregnant at 18. she reflects on her experiences, stating that she would be open to having another child, preferably a boy. her eldest daughter danielle was initially apprehensive about her mother's ivf treatment but is now fond of her baby sister. malone has spoken publicly about her pregnancy and the birth of flame on this morning and in her new autobiography, titled "back in control". she gave birth to flame two weeks before her scheduled due date in december 2013.
1201	in this story from atlanta's cnn affiliate, a maintenance worker named ryan brunn was interrogated using a polygraph machine following the discovery of the mangled body of a seven-year-old girl, jorelys rivera, in a suburban atlanta trash compactor. during the interview, brunn initially answered truthfully but later showed signs of deception regarding his involvement in jorelys' death and the disposal of her body. the polygraph test results were a turning point, leading to brunn's arrest the following day. despite his denials during the polygraph test, he later pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. however, brunn hanged himself in a prison cell before his trial. forensic psychiatrist dr. peter ash emphasized that most people cannot beat a polygraph test due to the uncontrollable nature of sweat responses, and criminals often lack good judgment. brunn, who had admitted to smoking marijuana during the interview, initially lied about his usage and other details. during the test, sitton confronted brunn about his lies and accusations of sexual misconduct from virginia, which brunn also denied. despite brunn's insistence that he was a good person, his apology in court to jorelys' family was met with limited emotion. two days later, brunn took his own life.
1202	snoop dogg, the american hip-hop artist, posted pictures on instagram of himself wearing a barcelona soccer shirt, leading to speculation that he might be joining the team. however, his social media history shows that he has also been pictured wearing jerseys of various other football clubs including manchester united, liverpool, ajax, and juventus, among others. snoop dogg is known for posing with jerseys of different teams and has a history of supporting multiple sports teams.
1203	a 22-year-old french reality star and glamour model, nabilla benattia, also known as "france's kim kardashian," was arrested for suspected attempted murder after her boyfriend, thomas vergara, was stabbed repeatedly in the throat and chest during a heated argument at their hotel room in paris. the alleged incident occurred at around 2:30 am in the paris suburb of boulogne-billancourt. police were called to the scene after staff reported a major argument with loud screaming. benattia, who is of swiss, italian, and algerian descent, was originally arrested for assault and battery, but the allegation was upgraded based on vergara's injuries. the couple, both household names in france, were featured on the same reality tv show, "the reality tv angels." vergara has stated that he does not want to press charges against benattia, but police and hotel staff have cast doubt on her version of events, as they report no signs of a struggle outside the hotel, no cctv footage, and a knife that was thrown out of the window and seemingly wiped clean. benattia, who has a history of legal troubles, including a fraud conviction in switzerland, can be held for up to 48 hours.
1204	an alitalia jet landed safely but skidded off the runway at rome's leonardo da vinci airport after the right landing gear failed to deploy during a storm. about ten passengers sustained minor injuries during the incident. in a separate incident, a private jet crashed into a hanger at santa monica municipal airport in california, with no survivors expected. the cause of the alitalia jet's malfunction is being investigated. the santa monica jet, which had an unknown number of passengers on board, crashed into a hangar upon landing, causing a fire that destroyed the building and caused minor damage to nearby structures.
1205	luis suarez has completed a £75million move from liverpool to barcelona after productive negotiations between the two clubs. the uruguayan forward, who was voted liverpool's player of the year last season, has asked fans to understand his decision to join the catalan giants, who he saw as a lifelong dream. the transfer became a straight cash transaction after arsenal signed alexis sanchez, who was initially being considered as a makeweight in the deal. suarez, who is currently serving a four-month ban for biting italy's giorgio chiellini at the world cup, is expected to be confirmed as a barcelona player next week. his former team-mate and liverpool legend steven gerrard paid tribute to suarez on instagram, expressing his disappointment at the forward's departure. suarez's transfer comes after a controversial career at liverpool, during which he faced numerous bans for biting, diving, and racist abuse.
1206	an orlando abortion clinic run by controversial, unlicensed doctor james pendergraft, who has had his medical license revoked five times, has reopened and is offering discounted abortions on sundays through coupons. the clinic, orlando women's center, was shut down in june and had all its equipment seized due to an unpaid $36 million medical malpractice judgment. the most recent license revocation was for performing an illegal third-trimester abortion. pendergraft maintains he has done nothing wrong and is currently working with borrowed equipment while recovering both his equipment and medical license. the clinic's actions have sparked outrage from florida right to life and pro-life activists.
1207	a young television writer in new york, jon san, started an instagram account named "that j. crew gingham shirt" to document men wearing j. crew's popular navy gingham button-down shirt. he was inspired by the shirt's growing popularity and noticed it in various places, including movies, television shows, and on the streets. the account documents various men wearing the shirt, noting their styling and whether it has been washed and ironed before taking the photo. the shirt, called the "secret wash shirt in faded gingham," retails for $64.50 on the j. crew website and is described as a classic fit with a button-down collar and two-ply cotton. san aims to capture the shirt's presence everywhere and keeps the comments on his instagram photos fun and lighthearted. the account, which launched just two weeks ago, has gained popularity quickly, with even women starting to wear the shirt and take photos for the account.
1208	a 25-year-old man from sparta, missouri, identified as brian williams, has been charged with four counts of first-degree murder and armed criminal action for the killing of three people, including a pregnant woman and her unborn child. the victims are identified as 26-year-old casey maples, her pregnant belly, 27-year-old james marsh, and 40-year-old christina winden. williams reportedly confessed to the killings, stating that he only regretted not being able to kill winden's boyfriend, and that he acted "calm but with a purpose." the probable cause statement also reveals that williams disposed of the murder weapon and the jacket he wore during the crime. he is being held without bond and is additionally charged with two counts of manufacturing meth, tampering with a motor vehicle, and stealing a gun. williams has a criminal history dating back to 2008 and includes charges for theft and burglary. he is being charged as a prior and persistent offender, which could potentially increase his prison sentence if convicted.
1209	cristiano ronaldo scored two goals as real madrid reached the last 16 of the champions league with a 2-0 win over lyon, moving him to 100 goals since joining the club in 2009. lionel messi passed the 200 mark for barcelona with a hat-trick in their 4-0 win over ajax. marco reus scored a hat-trick as borussia dortmund won 4-1 at marseille to advance. bayern munich stayed atop group a despite a 3-2 loss to napoli, which featured three red cards and a broken collarbone for bastian schweinsteiger. manchester city moved up to second place in group d with a 3-0 victory over villarreal. inter milan won 2-1 at lille to stay atop group b, while cska moscow and trabzonspor played to a goalless draw. manchester united defeated otelul galati 2-0 to join benfica atop group c. benfica and real madrid drew 1-1.
1210	napoli moved level with juventus at the top of serie a after a 2-0 victory over catania, with marek hamsik and fabio cannavaro scoring the goals. in the other game, torino and sampdoria played goalless. roma sacked coach zdenek zeman and appointed aurelio andreazzoli as interim manager following a disappointing run of form that sees them eighth in the table, nine points behind lazio and without a win this year.
1211	north korea's 29-year-old leader, kim jong un, has escalated threats against the united states, declared a state of war with south korea, and warned diplomats to evacuate the peninsula over the past month. the obama administration has responded inconsistently, first deploying military assets and then calling for dialogue. historically, north korea has continued its nuclear weapons development despite dialogue and sanctions. the main priority for north korea is the capability to threaten the united states with nuclear-armed ballistic missiles, and it is unlikely to be swayed by offers of respect, aid, or the lifting of sanctions. the regime intends to establish itself as a nuclear weapons power and may continue to break agreements reached during negotiations. north korea poses a danger by pushing the brink of a nuclear weapons test or transferring nuclear technology to other countries. dialogue has not been effective in halting north korea's nuclear program, and sustained pressure is necessary with china's involvement. the united states must avoid making cooperation on north korea a litmus test for u.s.-china ties and instead persuade china to cooperate strategically and genuinely to address the north korean nuclear issue. allies, particularly south korea and japan, are crucial to deterring north korea and motivating china to take action. negotiations with north korea may eventually resume, but a more effective approach is to apply sustained pressure on the regime to constrain its nuclear weapons development and proliferation.
1212	nigel evans, the deputy speaker of britain's house of commons, was arrested on saturday over allegations of rape and sexual assault made by two individuals. he considered both accusers to be his friends and has denied the accusations, calling them false. the incidents are alleged to have occurred between 2009 and 2013 in pendleton. evans was released on bail and has been ordered to appear at the police station on june 19. the prime minister, david cameron, has been informed of the arrest. evans, a conservative member of parliament since 1992 and a prominent gay rights activist, thanked those who have shown support and expressed a sense of incredulity over the situation.
1213	the failed christmas day bombing of northwest flight 253 has led to increased air passenger screening, with a focus on passengers from countries considered to be state sponsors of terrorism or countries of interest. israel's airline, el al, is seen as a model for security, as they prevent terrorism in the air by interviewing every passenger before check-in. isaac yeffet, the former head of security for el al and now an aviation security consultant in new york, advises that technology should not replace well-trained human beings and that every passenger should be interviewed by qualified security agents. yeffet criticizes the current system, saying it is reactive rather than proactive, and calls for a complete overhaul of airport security, including extensive training and testing for security personnel. el al has had no airline tragedies in the last 40 years due to their rigorous security measures, and yeffet suggests implementing their system at one us airport as a trial. he is against the use of full body scanners, which he sees as a patch on top of a patch, and instead recommends increased interviewing of passengers and thorough training for security personnel. el al spends more money on security but passengers are willing to pay for it if they feel secure.
1214	monsanto, a leading genetically modified (gm) food company, is abandoning its efforts to promote gm crops in europe due to lack of interest from farmers and consumers. the decision comes despite the uk environment secretary owen paterson's attempts to override public skepticism and push for gm crop approval in the european commission. other gm companies, such as bayer cropscience, basf, and syngenta, have similarly scaled back or abandoned their efforts in europe. monsanto's spokesman confirmed there is no demand for gm crops in europe and that the company recognizes their lack of acceptance in european societies. the uk government, under pressure from us politicians, has lobbied for the acceptance of gm crops in the eu, but several countries have banned gm crops under the environmental protection provision, known as the "safeguard clause." the uk supermarkets are now allowing gm feed for animal production due to difficulty in sourcing non-gm feed, but they have not labeled the resulting meat, eggs, and milk. critics argue that the stores have effectively handed gm companies control over uk food policy rather than allowing customers to make informed choices.
1215	two victoria police officers have faced public scrutiny after being filmed enjoying an iced coffee at an outdoor café table with their marked police car parked in a no standing zone on hawthorn road, caulfield north. a disgruntled member of the public recorded the incident and shared it on the 'victoria police corruption' facebook group, accusing the officers of misconduct and hoping to shame them. the video, which has gained over 230,000 views, shows the officers giving the filmer a cold shoulder while he taunts them with his camera and questions their misconduct. victoria police confirmed that their employees are required to park police vehicles legally at all times, unless exempt under the road rules victoria regulation act 2009. many facebook commenters sided with the police in this situation, arguing that they need to be in close proximity to their cars for emergency situations. however, some believed that the officers should set a better example for other road users.
1216	lisa swinton mclaughlin, a 56-year-old woman from baltimore, maryland, passed away seven days after giving birth to twins, jordan and dylan, via cesarean section. mclaughlin, who had longed for children for over 30 years, had been in significant pain which she believed was related to the incision. she had a history of fertility treatments and developed gestational diabetes during her pregnancy, but her doctors closely monitored her condition. mclaughlin gave birth to the boys, who were premature but healthy, on december 27, 2022. she went home on new year's eve, but died a few days later from a bowel obstruction. her husband, mike mclaughlin, now faces raising their sons alone. the family had planned to move back to nebraska after the birth, where they have support from family and friends.
1217	nfl star david diehl of the new york giants was charged with dui after witnesses said he was heavily intoxicated behind the wheel of his bmw and crashed into three parked cars in queens, new york, on sunday night. diehl, who is 6'5 and 304lb, had been watching croatia's victory over the republic of ireland in the european championship at a local bar before the incident. his blood alcohol level was measured at 0.182 percent, more than twice the legal limit. diehl was arrested at the scene and spent the night in a cell wearing his croatian soccer top. he entered no plea at court on monday and his case was adjourned until july 26. diehl apologized on twitter for his actions and could spend up to a year in jail if convicted. he had previously been known for setting a positive example and had twice won the super bowl with the giants. diehl's agent, peter schaffer, called him "one of, if not the classiest, most humble new york giants ever."
1218	a story about pope francis allegedly saying animals can go to heaven went viral last week, but it was nottrue. many news reports, including one in the new york times, incorrectly quoted the pope as saying "paradise is open to all of god's creatures." however, the vatican clarified that the pope actually said animals are part of god's beautiful creation, but they do not possess immortal souls and cannot enter heaven in the same way humans do. despite the correction, the erroneous report continued to spread. the incident highlights the importance of fact-checking and the desire for francis, known for his compassion and prioritization of animals, to make theological statements that challenge traditional beliefs. additionally, the strong feelings people have about their pets and their desire for a reunion in the afterlife were also evident in the spread of the false story. ultimately, while caring for animals is important, they do not possess eternal souls and cannot enter heaven in the same way humans do according to the catholic church teachings.
1219	in a recent interview with entertainment tonight, sheryl crow, lance armstrong's ex-fiance, expressed her relief for him following his confession of using performance-enhancing drugs during his cycling career. crow believed that armstrong will find freedom through honesty, and carrying the weight of deceit would be devastating in the long run. despite reports suggesting that she knew about his cheating ways, crow remained silent on the issue until now. armstrong was stripped of his seven tour de france titles and faced widespread criticism and disappointment from fans. crow's interview will air on entertainment tonight on tuesday night, and she discussed her forthcoming role as a judge on abc's the voice during the show. crow had previously spoken about the pain and admiration she felt towards armstrong after his admission last year.
1220	in mumbai, india, at least 18 people died and nearly 50 were injured in a stampede during a large gathering of mourners for the 102-year-old spiritual leader of the dawoodi bohra muslim community, syedna mohammed burhanuddin. the stampede occurred outside his home in malabar hill as thousands came to pay their respects after his death on friday. the unexpected large crowd overwhelmed the authorities, and mourners were pressed against the gates. police commissioner satyapal singh stated that both the police and organizers had not anticipated such a large turnout. tens of thousands more attended the funeral procession on saturday, lining the streets towards a mausoleum where the leader will be buried. the dawoodi bohra community, originating from yemen, have large populations in gujarat, india, and are known for their prosperity and philanthropy. stampedes at religious sites are common in india but rare in large cities like mumbai with a greater police presence. the last major stampede occurred last october at a hindu temple in madhya pradesh, killing approximately 115 people. businesses of the bohra community were closed in saddar as a mark of respect.
1221	a u.s. citizen, daniel wani, rushed to sudan to save his pregnant wife, meriam yahya ibrahim ishag, from a death sentence for apostasy after she was charged for marrying him, a sudanese man with u.s. citizenship, in 2011. the sudanese court refuses to recognize their marriage due to ishag's muslim heritage, as her father was a sudanese muslim, despite her upbringing by her ethiopian christian mother. ishag, who is eight months pregnant and has a 20-month-old son, has been shackled in a prison cell and sentenced to 100 lashes for adultery. her death sentence for apostasy has been delayed until after the birth of her child. wani is now working with their lawyer to appeal the ruling, and both new hampshire senators, jeanne shaheen and kelly ayotte, have urged secretary of state john kerry to grant ishag political asylum. the case has drawn international attention and condemnation.
1222	pamela anderson was unexpectedly voted off dancing on ice during the first week of competition, despite finishing third in the leaderboard. she blamed her exit on a wardrobe malfunction that led to her breasts popping out of her dress while performing during the skate-off. anderson believes her outfit issue was the reason for her departure, calling it a "common" occurrence in her life. she was sad about being eliminated and expressed regret for her partner, matt evers. anderson also ruled out any future reality tv appearances, joking about a conspiracy theory involving the wardrobe assistant. she may consider performing in las vegas instead. during the skate-off, anderson's competitors, keith chegwin and olga sharutenko, were saved by the judges. anderson suffered from nerves during her first performance, and her scores were 18.5, while chegwin's were 15.5. the next week will see the remaining six contestants, including lauren goodger, oona king, and joe pasquale, make their debut performances.
1223	russia was suspended from the g8 group of leading economies on monday after leaders from the remaining seven countries, including britain, the us, germany, france, italy, canada, and japan, condemned russia's "illegal attempt to annex crimea" as a contravention of international law. the leaders agreed to meet again without russia until it was ready to engage in "meaningful discussion." british prime minister david cameron and u.s. president barack obama made it clear that this summer's g8 summit, scheduled to be held in sochi, russia, would be cancelled. instead, it will be held in brussels in june, and putin will not be invited for the first time since russia was admitted to the group in 1998. the move to isolate russia diplomatically came as the u.s. urged european countries to impose tougher economic sanctions, and russian military experts warned that putin could decide in the next two weeks to launch a large-scale invasion of mainland ukraine. the crisis was overshadowing a summit about nuclear security in the hague.
1224	four rhinos were discovered dead with their horns missing at the lalibela game reserve in south africa, making it over 400 rhinos killed in the country this year. in assam, india, two rhinos were also killed and dehorned, with one rhino surviving but ultimately succumbing to her injuries. both incidents sparked outrage and condemnation. the rhinos in south africa were possibly darted prior to their horns being removed in a "very professional" manner, while in india, the rhinos were shot and had their horns hacked off while still alive. the killings occurred during the same week and have raised concerns about the increasing poaching of rhinos for their horns.
1225	the johnsons, a marine corps couple from san diego, are both deploying to afghanistan, leaving their toddler son noah behind for up to a year. they are one of 681 marine corps couples to have deployed together since 2011. frances johnson, who is volunteering for her first deployment, describes the separation as challenging, with negative reactions from some people. her husband's deployment was scheduled but came with a promotion, and together they decided it was best for their careers. the couple's families are helping care for noah during their absence, and they are focused on the positive aspects of reuniting with him when they return.
1226	a detroit-area man, theodore paul wafer, 54, will stand trial on a charge of second-degree murder in the shooting death of 19-year-old renisha mcbride, who was intoxicated and disoriented following a car accident before being shot on wafer's porch in november. prosecutors argued that wafer made a "bad choice" by coming to the door with a shotgun instead of calling for help or answering the door. wafer's friend testified that they had been playing a drinking game with vodka and smoking marijuana that night. wafer, whose lawyer claims he shot mcbride in self-defense, is also charged with manslaughter and possessing a firearm during a felony. prosecutors maintain that there was no evidence of a break-in and mcbride was unarmed when shot from behind a locked door, making wafer's claim of self-defense invalid. wafer's next court appearance is scheduled for january 15.
1227	the syrian capital, damascus, is now divided between rival gunmen supporting and opposing president bashar assad. at least 74 people have been killed in two days of clashes between the syrian free army and government forces. damascus has been under the control of the free syrian army for the past 11 days, and the regime can only disrupt utilities and disrupt communications. cities like homs, hama, and idlib have experienced a significant escalation in violence since tuesday. the syrian observatory for human rights reported a "fierce military campaign" in hamadiyeh district of hama since the early hours of friday. however, the surge in rebellion has caused a spike in deaths, claiming the lives of women and children as well as soldiers. in homs, government forces have resorted to shelling homes and firing on crowds with machine guns. the syrian uprising, which began with peaceful protests last march, has become increasingly violent as army defectors clash with government forces, and some protesters have taken up arms to protect themselves. the violence has intensified the sectarian divide in the sunni-majority country, where assad's alawite sect dominates the regime. the un security council held a closed-door meeting to discuss the crisis and draft a possible resolution against the damascus regime, while the un reports at least 5,400 deaths since march. russia, a key ally of syria, has been criticized for failing to stop the violence and is accused of preventing regime change in syria. syrian rebels express anti-russian sentiment, accusing the putin government of keeping assad in power. russia's discomfort with the resolution's wording could be addressed if the document clearly rules out military intervention, but western and arab states are unlikely to dismiss the use of force entirely. with strong opposition from syria's allies and russia, a resolution that is agreeable to all parties seems unlikely.
1228	wales is considering becoming the first part of the uk to ban electronic cigarettes in enclosed public places due to concerns they glamorize smoking and act as a gateway to traditional cigarettes. ministers in wales, including health minister mark drakeford, fear e-cigarettes, which contain liquid nicotine and mimic the sensation of smoking, could reverse efforts made to discourage smoking. drakeford announced proposals to ban them in pubs, restaurants, and other indoor public spaces as part of a white paper on health reform. the labour-run welsh government believes e-cigarettes could normalize smoking and make it easier for people to transition back to traditional cigarettes. some experts agree, arguing that flavored e-cigarettes, which are often marketed to children, could lead to increased nicotine addiction. however, others think that if all smokers switched to e-cigarettes, it could prevent five million deaths annually. france has also pledged to ban e-cigarettes in public places due to potential health risks. the devices were first invented in 1963, but their popularity has grown significantly in the last decade. some studies suggest that e-cigarettes could be aiding the smoking cessation process, but other research indicates that they could encourage traditional cigarette smoking among teenagers.
1229	five areas in the uk, including aberdeen, bradford, brighton, middlesbrough, and milton keynes, have introduced the requirement for dialling the full area code when making local calls. this change, implemented by telecoms regulator ofcom, aims to create nearly one million new phone numbers and prevent the country from running out of numbers. people in these areas will now have to dial eleven-digit numbers to reach local homes and businesses. the shift is met with skepticism from the public, as demand for new landline numbers may be decreasing due to the increasing use of mobile phones and internet services. this change creates extra costs for small businesses and traders, who need to update their letterheads and signs to show the full number, including the national code. ofcom insists that the changes are necessary to ensure the continued availability of new landline numbers and maintain competition in the telecoms market. the implementation of this system has also been successful in bournemouth since 2012.
1230	in mexico city, monsignor victor rené rodriguez, a high-ranking official in the mexican catholic church, has expressed concern over the increasing threats, extortion, and abuse of priests by drug traffickers. some priests in violent states like chihuaha, where 40% of mexico's drug-related deaths have occurred in the past four years, have had to cancel early evening masses to protect parishioners. threats against priests have also affected evangelical churches, with pastors falsely accused of siding with drug gangs and forced to minister to traffickers. the families of priests are also being threatened. the mexican catholic church has implemented measures to minimize risks to priests, including asking them to wear religious clothing and avoid traveling to remote areas.
1231	george galloway, the bradford west mp, was interviewed by police under caution for declaring bradford an "israel-free zone" in protest against israel's actions in gaza. his remarks sparked outrage and hundreds of complaints, leading to a police investigation. galloway called the probe an attempt to curb his freedom of speech and vowed not to be silenced. the controversy escalated when israel's ambassador to the uk, daniel taub, visited bradford and unfurled an israeli flag, which was described as a deliberate provocation. the crown prosecution service will decide whether charges should follow. galloway won the bradford west seat in a by-election in 2012.
1232	barcelona, known for producing top football talent, has been hit with a two-year transfer ban by fifa for breaking rules on the international transfer of minors. the ban prevents the club from signing players in the next two windows, which could have significant consequences as it limits their ability to refresh their squads and maintain competitiveness, as well as for marketing purposes. fifa's investigation focused on several players under the age of 18 who were registered and played for barcelona between 2009 and 2013. the spanish football federation was also fined chf 500,000. the ban may affect transfer deals barcelona has in progress, such as a potential move for german goalkeeper andre ter stegen from borussia monchengladbach and the arrival of 17-year-old alen halilovic from dinamo zagreb. the ban comes after barcelona president sandro rosell resigned in january over the misappropriation of funds during the signing of neymar in 2013.
1233	christian eriksen credits mauricio pochettino's tough pre-season training regime for tottenhotspur's late-game resilience in the premier league. four of their nine late-game goals have resulted in crucial points, helping them climb up the table with arsenal being the only team snatching more. spurs have showed great character and belief, scoring two-goal salvoes in cup matches. eriksen found the net in the 89th minute against swansea, echoing his late goal against hull city in november. pochettino praised the team's efforts, while eriksen mentioned the grueling pre-season as the cause for their sudden fitness and determination to keep going till the end of games. despite inconsistent performances this season, which has seen them lose six league games, spurs are determined to improve and move up the table.
1234	thousands of protesters in montreal demonstrated against planned tuition hikes and bill 78, which requires demonstration organizers to provide advance notice of routes and details. despite tension from weekend clashes, tuesday's protest remained mostly peaceful, with no arrests reported during the afternoon event. however, six people were arrested later that night when some protesters wearing masks threw objects at police. at least 1,000 arrests have been made since the protests began. classe, a student association, plans to continue demonstrating without providing an approved itinerary. the protests began in response to a proposed tuition increase of $1,625, resulting in clashes between police and protesters, leaving over 300 people arrested and 20 injured. montreal police commander ian lafreniere noted the city is usually peaceful.
1235	sara x, also known as the "mozart boob twerking girl," is known for her unique way of celebrating holidays by twerking her breasts in time with iconic music. for valentine's day, she released a new video where she flexes her chest muscles to beethoven's "für elise," wearing a tutu skirt, angel wings, and a skimpy bra. last year, she went viral after twerking her breasts to mozart's "eine kleine nachtmusik," which received over 26 million views in a week. the former stripper had initially found the attention disconcerting but has since uploaded other videos, including one for christmas with jingle bells. historians appreciate her choice of classic themes for her performances. despite facing criticism and abuse from internet trolls, sara x continues to use her unique talent to entertain and delight audiences online.
1236	republic of ireland captain robbie keane was dropped from the starting lineup for the first time since 2001 for ireland's euro 2016 qualifier against scotland on friday. keane, ireland's all-time leading goalscorer, was among the substitutes during a 1-0 defeat against their group rivals at celtic park. the last time keane was started on the bench was in a world cup qualifier against estonia in june 2001, which ireland won 2-0. martin o'neill chose to start shane long instead due to long's pace, with the southampton striker scoring a couple of goals at the weekend and in good form. keane was brought on in the 78th minute to help ireland find an equaliser. o'neill praised keane before the game, acknowledging his contribution to the team and his goalscoring ability but ultimately deciding that long's pace was the deciding factor.
1237	a pit bull named mickey, who mauled a four-year-old boy in phoenix earlier this year, will spend the rest of its life in an animal shelter instead of being put to death. the dog was offered a home at the maricopa county animal shelter, run by sheriff joe arpaio, an animal lover who intervened in the case. mickey attacked the boy, leaving him with broken eye socket and jaw, requiring months, if not years, of reconstructive surgery. the incident sparked heated debates online, with some blaming the dog's owners and baby sitter for negligence, while others sympathized with the animal. donations poured in for the injured child, with animal advocates arguing both the dog and boy were victims. arpaio, known for his immigration enforcement efforts, testified at the hearing that he would ensure mickey's lifelong care at the shelter, and he expects to remain sheriff to fulfill that commitment. the judge denied a request to rescind the order for mickey to be defanged, stating that the cost of the procedure, $2,500, was a small fraction of the boy's medical bills.
1238	claire craig, a mother-of-two from surrey, ignored a numb, tingling sensation in her right hand, assuming it was caused by her new puppy's nipping. over the next three months, her hand became completely numb, feeling like she was wearing a thick ski glove. the symptoms eventually spread down her leg, but claire, an interior designer, didn't consider it serious as she had no other symptoms. her gp initially suspected carpal tunnel syndrome, but tests came back clear. an mri scan revealed a brain tumour the size of a small aubergine. despite symptoms escalating and a second mri, claire remained calm, unaware that cancer was the cause. the diagnosis changed her life in an instant. despite advancements in cancer research, brain tumours claim around 3,400 lives every year in england and wales. the symptoms are often vague and little is known about the causes or risk factors. brain tumours are rising in number, and although detection rates are improving, most patients still die within a year due to a lack of research and poor prognosis. brain tumours are challenging to remove because of their location, and no single risk factor can accurately predict who will develop one. claire's surgeon couldn't determine the exact type until surgery. she had a hemangioblastoma, a rare, benign tumour that was successfully removed. the three weeks leading up to the operation were the worst of her life. telling her children that she had an egg in her head and needed surgery caused them to be frightened. the operation took longer than anticipated, and she was left paralysed down one side. recovery was a long process, but she regained the use of her hand, walked, talked and ate again within a month. she faced few long-term problems. brain tumours cannot be treated with chemotherapy, and surgery carries risks because of their location and diverse nature. experts are working on using 3d technology to
