1320	caroline reinsch and christian williams, who were injured in the boston marathon bombing in 2013, have shared that despite their life-changing injuries, they will always remember the day as one of joy because they discovered that reinsch was pregnant with their first child. they had both attended the marathon to cheer for a friend and settled near the finish line. when the bomb went off, both suffered serious leg injuries, with williams also having damage to his right hand. reinsch was unaware she was pregnant at the time, but when she went to the hospital, an x-ray technician asked if she could be pregnant. she took a home pregnancy test, which was positive, and later confirmed it with another test in the hospital. the couple has since been recovering and adjusting to their new reality, with reinsch now more than two months along in her pregnancy. they must wear leg braces and have scars from their injuries, but williams has expressed that the pregnancy has brought him immense joy. the couple has shared their progress on a blog on their fundraising website.
1321	a group of workmen, while working on a construction site in maidenhead, panicked after one of their colleagues, ryszard karpuc, fell to his death from a ladder in january 2013. instead of reporting the death or calling emergency services, they carried his body away in their van and dumped it in nearby woodland, where it was discovered four days later. the men had been drinking vodka to keep warm during the bitter cold weather, which may have contributed to their high levels of intoxication. the coroner's inquest heard that mr. karpuc had fallen around two meters from the ladder and suffered an intrapulmonary hemorrhage in the presence of alcohol following the fall. a health and safety expert who investigated the death stated that the colleagues appeared to panic and decided to move the body into the countryside. the case resulted in legal proceedings against several individuals charged with obstructing the coroner and failing to report mr. karpuc's death. the coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death.
1322	senate republicans have threatened to block all legislative action in the lame-duck session until the dispute over extending bush-era tax cuts and funding the government is resolved. in a letter to senate majority leader harry reid, all 42 senate republicans vowed to prevent a vote on any legislation other than these critical priorities. the tax cuts, enacted by george w. bush in 2001 and 2003, will expire on december 31 if no agreement is reached. democrats and republicans disagree on whether the tax cuts should be extended for families earning $250,000 or less or for everyone. the ongoing talks between white house and congressional tax negotiators have been described as "civil" but have yielded no breakthroughs. a continuing resolution for government funding is also set to expire on friday, and democrats are trying to pass several pieces of legislation before the new, more republican-controlled congress is sworn in. republicans accused democrats of trying to "obstruct" and "delay" legislative progress and blamed them for failing to effectively govern. the house democratic leadership announced plans to move forward with a vote to permanently extend the tax cuts for families earning $250,000 or less.
1323	mitt romney wore a hawaiian shirt and beaded necklace to the rehearsal dinner of senator john mccain's son jack's wedding, which quickly went viral. meghan mccain, john's daughter, shared pictures of herself and romney on social media. the wedding took place at the fairmont hotel in san francisco, and jack is a helicopter pilot in the us navy who met his wife, air force reservist renee swift, in guam. john mccain, who lost the presidential race in 2008 and 2000, was married to cindy lou hensley in 1980. cindy, who is an heiress to her father's beer wholesale business, has poured a significant amount of her wealth into her husband's political campaigns. the couple has five children together, including meghan, jack, james, and their adopted daughter bridget. bridget's adoption was targeted during mccain's 2000 campaign due to her skin color.
1324	european clubs, including liverpool, monaco, and roma, are facing criticism from the european clubs' association (eca) for qualifying for the champions league without submitting accounts to comply with financial fair play (ffp) rules in the previous season. the eca expresses concern that these clubs have an unfair advantage in terms of spending limitations. liverpool is among those being investigated for ffp breaches and is currently disclosing losses as allowable stadium expenditure. uefa announced two weeks ago that seven clubs, including roma, monaco, and inter milan, are being investigated. the issue will be brought up at a uefa meeting with clubs next week, where the eca plans to push for the closing of this loophole. the meeting will also discuss tackling larger debts carried by clubs such as manchester united and real madrid more strictly, as only the interest on debts is currently considered in ffp calculations. manchester city and paris saint-germain, who were severely punished last season for ffp rule-violations, are also invited to the meeting. city's chairman, khaldoon al mubarak, and uefa general secretary, gianni infantino, have voiced differing opinions on debt sustainability and its consideration in ffp rules.
1325	the macy's thanksgiving day parade in new york went ahead as planned, with the giant balloons successfully flying over the event despite wind concerns. police asked for them to be flown five feet lower as a safety precaution due to past incidents. millions of americans traveled for the holiday weekend, with few major delays reported for planes, trains or automobiles. however, northern areas experienced significant snowfall and dangerous road conditions. retailers like kmart started their black friday sales on thanksgiving day to accommodate shoppers' demand.
1326	a 22-year-old australian mother has been charged with harming her four-year-old daughter by intentionally administering chemotherapy drugs as part of an internet scam to raise money. the little girl, who is fighting a lung infection in the royal children's hospital in brisbane, was systematically poisoned with the drugs over a 10-month period. the mother had posted on facebook, claiming her daughter was terminally ill with a rare disease and needed a bone marrow transplant, prompting thousands of people to donate money and toys. the mother was arrested and charged with inflicting grievous bodily harm on her child. the girl's medical condition remains serious, and her mother will remain in custody until her next court appearance on may 20th. doctors initially suspected leukemia or auto-immune disease but later discovered that the child was not actually ill, and she had been sent home, only to be readmitted to the hospital due to mysterious signs of bleeding.
1327	in a highly anticipated supreme court hearing, justices expressed divided views on the individual mandate provision of the 2010 federal health care reform law, which requires most americans to purchase health insurance or face a financial penalty. the fate of this provision and possibly the entire law's other sections hang in the balance as the government's authority to regulate health care under the commerce clause comes under scrutiny. the conservatives on the bench questioned the mandate's constitutionality, with some likening it to the government forcing individuals to buy broccoli. the oral arguments did not mention "obamacare" or president obama by name but were aware of the significant consequences of their eventual rulings. the debate continued outside the court with partisan rhetoric from congressional representatives and protests. while some officials expect the court to uphold the mandate despite challenging questions, opponents, such as sen. rand paul, are optimistic that it will be struck down as an unconstitutional infringement on personal freedom. the high court is expected to rule on all four related issues by late june.
1328	a 33-year-old man, mokthar hosseiniamraei, has been charged with murder and breaching an apprehended violence order (avo) following the death of his estranged wife, 26-year-old leila alavi, in an underground carpark at a shopping center in auburn, sydney. hosseiniamraei was arrested at a property on james street in guildford west on saturday evening after alavi was found stabbed to death inside her holden astra. her colleague discovered her body shortly after 10:00 am. alavi had previously applied for an avo against her husband. cafe owner zeynep zabinoglu was the last person to see alavi alive before her death. the investigation is ongoing, and a crime scene has been established at the shopping center. hosseiniamraei is due to appear at burwood local court on april 1.
1329	manchester united, under the leadership of sir alex ferguson, were known for their late-show comebacks, scoring many goals in the final moments to secure victories. this tactic helped them win numerous premier league titles, cup ties, and the champions league. opponents were always uncertain when the attack would come, as ferguson's team pressured until the final whistle. however, under current manager louis van gaal, the team's attacking players have been criticized for a lack of discipline, and their latest goal before the 62nd minute was one of their only 13 goals this season. in contrast, united have conceded eight goals beyond the 62 minute mark. the team's inability to score late goals is particularly alarming, considering their defense's porous nature. during ferguson's last decade at manchester united, 38.7% of their goals came in the final 27 minutes and added time. united even managed to keep this trend under david moyes last season, scoring 21 of their 64 league goals after the 63rd minute. to maintain competitiveness, it is crucial for united to rediscover their knack for scoring late goals.
1330	president barack obama took two official trips this year, costing taxpayers $2,952,278, where he spent more time golfing than attending government meetings, according to the government oversight organization judicial watch. the first trip, which cost $2,066,594.60, occurred over president's day weekend in february, and obama met with community leaders and king abdullah ii of jordan. the second trip, which cost $885,683.40, took place in march and included the first family. both trips included extensive flight expenses, with the cost per flying hour of air force one being $210,877, according to the department of the air force. obama's golf outings at exclusive, water-intensive golf courses drew criticism due to the region's water crisis, with each golf course using an average of one million gallons of water a day to keep the grass green. overall, the obamas have spent over $40 million on taxpayer-funded trips since 2009.
1331	syrian opposition forces, including the free syrian army (fsa), have reportedly taken control of the town of zabadani from government troops, but the authorities' tanks remain outside. activists said the army tried to disperse protests in the town, leading to clashes in which the opposition destroyed at least three armored vehicles. the syrian government has restricted access to journalists, making it impossible for cnn to independently verify the events. the arab league monitoring mission, which had been observing the situation in zabadani, is reportedly in talks with the syrian government over an extension. elsewhere in syria, at least 21 people were reportedly killed by government forces on wednesday, with the majority of deaths occurring in homs. the european union is considering new sanctions against the syrian regime.
1332	jacqueline kennedy's collection of personal letters to irish priest father joseph leonard, which provide insight into her marriage, faith, and thoughts following president john f. kennedy's assassination, will no longer be sold at auction, according to sheppard's irish auction house. all hallows college in dublin, which had consigned the letters, is currently working with the kennedy family to determine their future preservation. the correspondence, consisting of more than two dozen letters, reveal jack kennedy's concerns about her husband's flirtatious nature and his infidelities, as well as her own struggles with loneliness and the glamorous yet lonely life she led in the white house. jackie kennedy met father leonard during a trip to ireland in 1950 and continued writing to him until his death in 1964. the letters shed light on her early relationship with her future husband and her personal thoughts during her time as first lady.
1333	british detectives interviewed a second woman in australia regarding sex abuse allegations against entertainer rolf harris. she claimed harris sexually assaulted her when she was a teenager in the uk. the woman, who lives in wollongong, was questioned by scotland yard's operation yewtree team. harris, 83, was arrested in march and questioned in the uk, but no charges have been brought. he has denied any wrongdoing. the new allegations are not linked to the jimmy savile scandal. harris's friends defend him, stating that he is a clean-living man with no interest in children. scotland yard interviewed a second woman at her home in wollongong, following the interview of the first woman in march. harris, who has lived in the uk for over 50 years, denies any statements regarding the allegations. other popular figures arrested by operation yewtree include gary glitter, freddie starr, dave lee travis, and max clifford.
1334	boko haram's abduction of over 200 schoolgirls in northeast nigeria has gained significant global attention, with condemnation from u.s. president barack obama and uk prime minister david cameron. this publicity is valuable to boko haram, which sees itself as a militant islamic group on a suicide mission to wage war against the west. bornu state in nigeria, one of the poorest and most neglected areas in the world, is now the new battleground between militant islam and the western world. the nigerian government's neglect of the northeast and its people, as well as its lack of response to the abduction, has fueled anger and despair. the remote, dry, and dusty region, rich in oil but lacking in basic services and infrastructure, has become a place of concern for the us and its allies. the u.s. secretary of state, john kerry, has criticized nigeria for ignoring previous offers of help to address the security situation in the northeast. the nigerian authorities' lack of democratic relationship with the people of the northeast, combined with high levels of poverty, unemployment, and lack of education and health services, creates a volatile situation. boko haram began as a fundamentalist movement in 2002, gaining momentum after the death of its leader, mohammed yusuf, in police custody. the ineffective security forces, deep-rooted corruption, and lack of governance have given boko haram an opportunity to expand its influence. the military's heavy-handed approach to dealing with the group has failed to address the underlying causes of the conflict, and a long-term plan for development and investment is needed to bring peace and stability to the region. the u.s. faces a challenge in balancing military intervention and development assistance to make the people of the northeast feel part of a booming nigerian economy. a failure to address the root causes of the conflict could lead to more violent uprisings in the future.
1335	the iconic photograph of three firefighters raising the american flag at ground zero after the september 11 attacks almost didn't make it into the 9/11 memorial museum due to some staffers believing it was too "rah-rah" american. creative director michael shulan and others thought the image was too kitsch and favored showing the event from multiple angles instead. however, chief curator jan ramirez proposed a compromise, suggesting that the flag-raising be "minimized" in favor of three different photographs of the scene. shulan later told the new york post that reducing the historical event to one picture was oversimplifying it and could distort the complexity of the event. the franklin image, first published the day after the attacks and compared to the iconic flag-raising image from iwo jima during world war ii, has become an enduring emblem of hope for americans and has been reproduced on over 255 million "heroes" postage stamps, raising over $10 million for 9/11 families and rescue workers.
1336	a cnn journalist, jessica ravitz, asked a colleague, jarrett bellini, to fart in front of her to test the effectiveness of shreddies, a new flatulence-filtering underwear. the conversation took place after bellini received a pair of shreddies from the uk, and although it was trending online, he wanted to write a serious article about it. shreddies were invented by british industrial designer paul o'leary and use zorflex, an activated carbon cloth, to filter out stink particles. bellinni consumed various foods known to cause strong flatulence during his three-day trial, and reported that the underwear was effective in masking the smell. the conversation ended with ravitz expressing her amusement and support of his experiment.
1337	a plan is underway to build a £10 million open-air swimming pool in the thames river in central london, near temple stairs on the embankment. the water in the thames is currently cleaner than it has been in living memory, and german purification specialists have designed a system to ensure the water is safe for bathing, using reed beds and secondary filtration devices. the lido will include a main lap pool, plunge pool, children's paddling area, changing rooms, and a ramp leading from the shore to the water. health concerns have been raised due to sewage overflows and the experience of comedian david walliams, who suffered from "thames tummy" during a charity swim in 2011. the project's backers, including british firm gartenart and london architects studio octopi, hope to raise initial funding through crowd-funding and open the lido late next year if planning permission is granted.
1338	nato-led troops engaged in a firefight with insurgents in afghanistan, resulting in the deaths of 12 insurgents and a civilian woman. the incident took place in the eastern province of logar, during an operation to disarm insurgents involved in civilians' murders. troops found weapons at the militants' compound. meanwhile, in helmand province, four militants were killed in an operation against a mid-level taliban commander responsible for civilians' deaths. nato reported the death of a soldier in an eastern afghanistan incident. both isaf and afghan security forces are making progress against insurgents while taking measures to minimize civilian casualties.
1339	gunmen have abducted a chinese tourist and a hotel receptionist, who is also filipino, from a dive resort in eastern malaysia's sabah region. the group of six armed men stormed the hotel at around 10:30 pm local time on wednesday and escaped by sea. the resort is near the southern philippines where militants and kidnap gangs have long found safe haven. the missing tourists come from shanghai, and malaysian security services are investigating the incident. this incident is likely to increase negative sentiment in china regarding the safety of its citizens in malaysia, and tensions may be heightened due to the ongoing search for malaysia airlines flight mh370, which disappeared on march 8 with 153 chinese people on board. some reports suggest the women were snatched while one was taking a bath in her room. the attackers are believed to be from the abu sayyaf group, a militant muslim organization that has carried out similar kidnappings for ransom before, and tensions between the groups on both sides of the border remain high. the malaysian military and police are increasing security measures in response to the incident.
1340	same-sex couples in seattle, washington celebrated their newfound right to marry on sunday after voters in the state approved same-sex marriage in november. atcity hall, 133 couples exchanged vows at five stations and were greeted outside by cheers, confetti, and a brass band. couples were among the first to obtain marriage licenses on thursday. the day was marked by celebrations, volunteer services from local businesses, and interviews with couples on a city website. on friday, the supreme court announced it will hear arguments on challenges to state and federal laws regarding same-sex marriage. same-sex marriage is recognized in six states and the district of columbia. president barack obama became the first president to openly support same-sex marriage. the political shift comes as a majority of americans support same-sex marriage and increasing acceptance of gays and lesbians in society. some couples, like keith bacon and corianton hale, have had to deal with family acceptance. bacon and hale felt a sense of history being made and expressed hope for favorable supreme court rulings.
1341	snapchat began showing ads on its app last october with a minimum fee of $750,000 despite the ads being ephemeral and self-destructing at the end of each day. this high price tag is more than the cost of advertising during american idol or a 30-second super bowl slot, and even higher than youtube's daily masthead charge. snapchat's demographic is primarily teenagers, making it an attractive advertising platform for firms seeking to reach this group. the limited reporting capabilities due to the app's ephemeral nature means advertisers will receive limited demographic feedback about ad reach. snapchat's first ads appeared on its "recent updates" page in the us, with universal pictures being its first ad partner. other firms that have advertised on the app include mcdonald's, samsung, and electronic arts. snapchat has remained firm on the high minimum price, and mailonline has contacted the firm for more comment.
1342	sgt. dakota meyer, a 23-year-old marine who recently received the medal of honor for his bravery in afghanistan, expressed his desire to join the new york city fire department (fdny). however, he missed the application deadline, which is generally open every four years. a federal judge agreed to reopen the application window for one day to allow meyer to apply, but he declined the offer, believing in no special treatment. the fdny previously stated they would welcome meyer due to his exceptional military service. the city filed a motion to reopen the application period for meyer and others, but only meyer's application was accepted due to his recognized military service. the judge denied the request for the general public and cited special recruitment efforts for underrepresented minorities in the fdny. meyer accepted responsibility for missing the deadline and will not apply if the filing period is not open to everyone. sgt. meyer earned the medal of honor for saving the lives of 13 american and 23 afghan troops during a six-hour firefight in afghanistan.
1343	ray lambert, the father of england and liverpool soccer star rickie lambert, has been fired from his job at clothing retailer matalan's distribution warehouse in merseyside after accidentally breaking a glass panel on a drinks machine. the incident reportedly caused "substantial damage" to company property, resulting in lambert's dismissal. although the incident was unintentional, matalan has confirmed the termination in accordance with their disciplinary policy. lambert, a ten-year employee, is said to be popular among colleagues and will soon travel to brazil with his wife to watch rickie play in the world cup. ray, who had been earning £20,000 per year, has reportedly considered appealing the decision.
1344	ac milan suffered a disappointing 2-1 defeat to fiorentina at san siro on saturday, squandering their chance to maintain their lead in the serie a standings. juventus capitalized on milan's loss by defeating palermo 2-0 and taking the lead with leonardo bonucci and fabio quagliarella scoring in the second half. milan coach massimiliano allegri acknowledged the tough week following their elimination from the champions league by barcelona, but remained optimistic about their chances with seven matches remaining. udinese moved up to fourth place with a 3-1 victory over parma, while lecce shocked sixth-placed roma with a 4-2 upset. inter milan drew 2-2 with cagliari, leaving them two points behind roma.
1345	aaron hernandez, the former new england patriots player, is being sued for $12 million by the families of daniel abreu and safiro furtado, who were shot and killed in boston in 2012. hernandez is a suspect in their deaths, but no one has been criminally charged. hernandez is currently held in jail on murder charges in the unrelated death of odin lloyd. he is also facing a lawsuit from lloyd's family and another former friend who alleges hernandez shot him in the face. recently, hernandez was allowed to leave his cell and allegedly beat up another inmate who was handcuffed and unable to defend himself. the sheriff is investigating the incident and determining if any disciplinary measures or criminal charges are warranted. hernandez has been moved to a different unit in the jail.
1346	prince charles has shown interest in saving wentworth woodhouse, britain's largest stately home, which was purchased by the newbold family in 1999 for £1.5 million but requires extensive restoration. the house, built in the early 18th century and located in south yorkshire, is 606ft wide and has over 1,000 windows. it has a rich history, but was damaged by extensive coal mining in the late 1940s. the newbold family has already spent £5 million on upkeep and legal fees and is seeking compensation of £100 million from the coal authority. they plan to turn part of the building into a hotel, spa, and conference center, while leaving other wings open to the public. prince charles has expressed his interest in the project and has received a proposal from save britain's heritage to establish a trust for the restoration. he has not yet made a direct involvement or pledged funds towards the project. the house was previously owned by the fitzwilliam family, who were subject to numerous scandals, including allegations of being changelings and illegitimate children, and spent most of their time away from the estate.
1347	two mothers who underwent ivf treatment at care fertility nottingham to prevent passing on incurable diseases to their children suffered shocking blunders resulting in the birth of babies with sickle cell anemia and neurofibromatosis. the human fertilisation and embryology authority (hfea) classified these incidents as grade a errors, describing them as devastating for the families involved. one mother aimed to screen out sickle cell anemia, and the other sought to prevent neurofibromatosis, but both were pregnant with children carrying the respective conditions after mistakes at the genesis genetics europe (ggeu) laboratory used by care fertility nottingham for pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (pgd). the hfea stated that although these incidents were isolated and no evidence of poor practice was found, improvements have been made to prevent future occurrences. the mothers' identities were not disclosed, and both were undergoing pgd as they were at high risk of passing on serious genetic disorders. care fertility nottingham charges £4,840 for single gene disorder screening and treats both nhs and private patients. the families affected were deeply distraught upon receiving the news of their children's diagnoses.
1348	swedish artist carl michael von hausswolff has caused outrage after exhibiting a painting created using ashes he claims to have stolen from majdanek concentration camp in poland over two decades ago. he gathered the ashes in 1989, during a visit to exhibit his art near the camp, but did not use them for the exhibition at the time. in 2010, he mixed the ashes with water and used them as paint for a new artwork, which has sparked public outcry and criticism from art critics. the use of human remains as art has been called "nauseating" and "necrophilia." local police are investigating the matter under swedish burial protection laws. the painting is currently on display in a gallery in lund, and the majdanek concentration camp museum has condemned the artwork as a "barbaric action." von hausswolff has yet to comment on the controversy. majdanek was a concentration and extermination camp in poland during world war ii, where an estimated 79,000 people, including 59,000 jews, died. the camp is now a museum.
1349	a 42-year-old middle school teacher, felicia a. smith, is facing charges for giving a lap dance to one of her students during class at stovall middle school in houston, texas. according to court documents, smith performed a "full-contact" lap dance for the boy, hugged him, and told him "i love you baby, happy birthday." students reportedly convinced smith to do it, and the dance, which lasted almost four minutes, was allegedly captured on video. smith has been removed from the campus, and bail has been set at $30,000. the aldine independent school district has cooperated with prosecutors and prioritized student safety. smith has been charged with having an improper relationship with a student.
1350	caroline welker, a university basketball player at ohio wesleyan, was hit by a police car while crossing a road in delaware, ohio. officer mark jackson, who was responding to a disturbance call at a nearby restaurant, failed to see ms. welker in the crosswalk and hit her, causing her to tumble down the street with bruises and a concussion. officer jackson admitted to not seeing her and was charged with failure to yield. he was described as a dedicated officer serving with the delaware police department for ten years. ms. welker received immediate medical attention, and the department stated that officer jackson acted appropriately after the incident. a urine sample was collected from him for analysis, but alcohol or drugs were not anticipated to be involved. officer jackson paid a $135 fine for the incident and waived his court appearance.
1351	a california mother accused of stabbing to death her three young daughters has had her husband speak out in her defense, claiming her undiagnosed postpartum depression was the cause. carol coronado, 30, is currently in custody for the murders of sophia, 3, yazmine, 1, and xenia, 2 months, as well as attempting to kill her own mother. her husband, rudy coronado, has shared that there were warning signs but he was not aware of postpartum depression. the defense team has retained a psychologist to evaluate her for signs of the condition. rudy insists his wife was a "great woman" who would have never hurt anyone without the disease. the family has set up the coronado angel fund to raise awareness of postpartum depression and its impact on new mothers. according to a cdc survey, 8-19% of women experience frequent postpartum depressive symptoms. the accused mother has never been diagnosed or treated for postpartum depression. the family is in mourning, with her husband describing the loss as a "demon possessed" event. police have not released a motive for the murders and continue to investigate.
1352	mitchell johnson, the australian left-arm paceman, made a dramatic return to the test team after a year-long absence due to injury and loss of form, terrorizing sri lanka's batsmen and claiming six wickets in the melbourne test to help australia clinch a 2-0 series win. johnson also scored a crucial 92 not out, leading to injuries of key batsmen kumar sangakkara and prasanna jayawardene. johnson passed the milestone of 200 wickets in his 49th test, and his fiery spell led to sri lanka's third worst reverse in the five-day game. johnson is not guaranteed of playing in the third test due to the return of mitchell starc and the impressive debut of jackson bird. in twenty20 cricket, india leveled the series against pakistan after an 11-run victory in the second match. yuvraj singh scored a quick 72 off 36 balls for india, and ashok dinda took 3-36 for pakistan. the three-match one-day series will start on sunday.
1353	demarcus cousins, a us basketball player, quipped back at a reporter who asked him if he knew where slovenia was located. in response, cousins asked the reporter if he knew where alabama was. cousins and the us team are set to play against slovenia in the quarterfinals of the basketball world cup on tuesday. fans have praised cousins for his cheeky reply on social media. the teams met in an exhibition game before the tournament, with the us winning comfortably. cousins, a powerful player off the bench for the us team, has not spoken about slovenia's size advantage, but has acknowledged that their playing styles differ. the winning team will face either lithuania or turkey in the semi-finals. krzyzewski, the us coach, has said the us team has improved since the exhibition game and that slovenia has not grown bigger. the teams had a significant points in the paint advantage in the first game, with the us having a 50-22 advantage.
1354	the family of sergio molina, a teenager who was critically injured when ethan couch drove drunk and caused a crash that killed four people last june, has reached a settlement of over $2 million. the case gained national attention due to the use of the term "affluenza," which was suggested as a reason for couch's privileged upbringing and lack of accountability. couch, who was 16 at the time of the accident, was ordered to a lockdown treatment facility and given 10 years' probation instead of jail time. most of the payment in the settlement will come from a liability insurer. couch's lawyers denied using the term "affluenza" in their defense during the trial. the accident occurred when couch's truck plowed into a group of people, including molina, who were helping another vehicle with a flat tire on a road in burleson, texas. molina suffered a brain injury and is now minimally responsive. his family sued the couch family and the father's company due to ethan being behind the wheel of a company-owned truck.
1355	every saturday night on x factor, cheryl fernandez-versini is known for her unpredictable and frequent tears. from the first episode, she has shown an emotional response to various factors such as contestants' performances, their resemblance to her past, and even a contestant's sister singing. her reactions range from silent tears to full-blown sobbing fit for a "sequined semtex." her tears have been a consistent theme throughout the series, leaving many to question why the well-paid judge is so easily moved. some episodes have triggered her tears more than others, including performances by monica michael and andrea faustini, as well as the judges' house selection process. despite the criticism, cheryl continues to cry and has even caused other judges, like mel b, to join in.
1356	four firefighters were seriously injured in campbellsville, kentucky, while helping with a group's ice bucket challenge for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als) awareness. according to police chief tim hazlette, the firefighters were shocked by electricity from a power line after they had sprayed water on students. two firefighters, captain tony grider and firefighter simon quinn, were inside the bucket, while captain steve marrs and firefighter alex johnson were on the ground when they received electric shocks. grider and quinn were taken to the burn unit at the university of louisville medical center, where one is in critical condition and the other is fair. marrs and johnson were released from the hospital, but johnson was admitted for observation. the incident is under investigation, and authorities believe the ladder never touched the nearby power lines, but was close enough for the electricity to arc over. the campbellsville university community held a prayer service for the injured firefighters, and the university president expressed sympathy and prayers for their families. the ice bucket challenge is a social media campaign aimed at raising awareness and funds for als, and has raised over $41.8 million, compared to $2.1 million during the same time last year. celebrities have also embraced the campaign.
1357	black friday, the day after thanksgiving, is known for intense shopping deals but is not among the top 4 best days for holiday bargains, according to a study by savings.com. the analysis of over 1.5 million deals from the past 5 years revealed that the best days to buy specific items vary. for toys, it's november 26 (two days before black friday); for fashion, cyber monday (december 1) is the recommendation. electronics had the best sales on november 1, with november 26 as the second best, while novelties (books, candy, wine, flowers) are best bought on december 15. december 22 and 23 are also good for deals. meghan heffernan, a savings.com spokesperson, explained that deals start earlier due to increased competition and that some gifts (novelties) peak closer to christmas. despite the earlier sales promotions, some stores, like costco and nordstrom, have chosen to remain closed on thanksgiving to allow employees to spend the holiday with their families.
1358	a u.s. army report released on friday found that fort hood did not have a system to anticipate the deadly rampage that occurred on april 2, 2023, where spc. ivan lopez killed four soldiers and wounded 16 before taking his own life. the report concluded that there were no clear warnings of the attack and that lopez's supervisors would have had difficulty recognizing his personal problems, despite his undiagnosed ptsd. lopez had recently faced financial difficulties, lost family members, and was denied leave. the investigation noted that risk assessment at fort hood relies on self-reporting and that lopez could sometimes be misleading or deceptive. recommendations in the report included exploring whether soldiers should register privately owned weapons with their commanders. previously, the army stated it was logistically impossible to search all 80,000 people on the sprawling base every day.
1359	the uk experienced one of its hottest and driest summers on record in 2013, resulting in near-perfect grape growing conditions and a bumper harvest for british vineyards. the camel valley vineyard in cornwall enjoyed one of its best-ever harvests due to temperatures above 30 degrees during the critical flowering period in late june and early july. despite a cold and wet start to the year, the warm weather conditions will also help with next year's crop. the met office reported that approximately 189mm of rain fell over the summer, and temperatures remained above average throughout the country. although some rain and cloud were predicted for the following days, temperatures were expected to remain above average for the rest of the week.
1360	tugay kerimoglu, a former midfielder with great experience in both the premier league and turkey's super lig, is prepared to manage galatasaray after serving as assistant coach under roberto mancini for eight months. galatasaray fans are known for their passion and intimidating atmosphere during games, especially against fierce rivals fenerbahce. tugay warns that their intensity can be "scary," but is determined to succeed in football management despite the stress it brings. he began his career with galatasaray in 1987 and has seen both british and turkish football cultures clash during his career. galatasaray fans famously planted a giant flag in the center circle to celebrate a win over fenerbahce in 1996, causing a riot. tugay faced his former club galatasaray in the champions league after moving to glasgow rangers in 1999 and spent eight years at blackburn rovers with wife etkin and their two children. he has coached in turkey's national academy as well as at galatasaray since retiring in 2009 and hopes for a management role in britain, as he holds a british passport and his children study and were born there. tugay admires pep guardiola's coaching style as a role model, having studied his playing style as a player.
1361	dr. alister mackenzie, the renowned golf course designer behind augusta national, famously asked for $500 to avoid poverty just before his death in 1934. mackenzie, a scottish physician turned golf architect, had created some of the world's most famous courses, including augusta national, which he designed for bobby jones to provide him sanctuary from fame and income. however, despite jones's delight with the finished product and mackenzie's belief that it was his finest creation, mackenzie struggled financially, as many of his projects, including augusta, were slow to pay him. although he halved his fee to $5,000, mackenzie only received $2,000 before his death, which came less than three months before the first masters tournament. mackenzie's early years included a stint in the boer war, which influenced his designs, and a pilgrimage from his hometown in northern england to the pacific coast in california. in his manifesto for designing alwoodley golf club in 1907, mackenzie believed a good golf course should present a stern test for good players but be accessible to average ones. he is considered a pioneer in golf course architecture and designed many courses that are still famous today, including augusta national, cypress point, and royal melbourne.
1362	former "hollywood madam" heidi lynne fleiss, who was convicted of charges related to a prostitution ring in 1995, has endorsed democratic presidential candidate hillary clinton. fleiss, who now lives in nevada and runs a laundromat called "dirty laundry," tried to attend a clinton campaign rally in pahrump but was turned away due to capacity. fleiss, who has previously expressed admiration for clinton's intelligence, is also attempting to open a brothel in nevada that is a replica of the white house. other former madams, including deborah jeanne palfrey (the "d.c. madam") and jenna jameson, have also endorsed clinton. the clinton campaign declined to comment on fleiss' endorsement.
1363	thomas eric duncan, the first person to die from ebola in the united states, was remembered at a memorial service in salisbury, north carolina on october 18, 2014. duncan, a compassionate and caring man, is believed to have contracted ebola while helping a pregnant woman in his native liberia. family and friends gathered at a small southern baptist church with a primarily liberian congregation to remember his life. duncan attended high school in neighboring ivory coast and provided a telephone connection for refugees to contact family abroad. he left for the united states to work multiple jobs, save money, and build a future. he is survived by his mother, four children, and many loved ones who mourned his loss during the memorial service. duncan's nephew, josephus weeks, spoke fondly of his uncle's caring nature, soccer skills, and love for his pet dog. retired united methodist bishop arthur kulah also spoke about duncan's compassion and respectfulness. the four individuals who had been in contact with duncan in dallas and were in quarantine were due to be released soon.
1364	matthew scheidt, a 21-year-old from florida, confessed to abc's "20/20" that his history of lies and impersonations began in his teenage years, as a response to his mother's arrest for crystal meth possession and his own shame about his impoverished lifestyle.scheidt, who was compared to leonardo dicaprio's character in "catch me if you can," began inventing stories in elementary school and lied about living in a nice house and going to a fancy school. he had a passion for medicine and volunteered at a florida hospital when he was only 11, lying about his age. at 13, he was caught pretending to be a nurse but no charges were filed.at 18, scheidt was convicted of working as a physician's assistant at the osceola regional medical center in florida for weeks, changing bandages, handling intravenous drips, and conducting physical exams without a license. he even performed cpr on a patient who unfortunately died the next day.in january 2012, scheidt was arrested again for impersonating a miami police officer and carrying actual police weapons. he told investigators he had gone to the hospital to get a badge for his job as a clerk at a doctor's office, but was mistakenly entered as a physician assistant into the computer system instead. scheidt was convicted of practicing medicine without a license and impersonating a physician's assistant in august 2012, and was sentenced to a year in jail and eight years' probation. scheidt's passion for medicine began early, but his lies and impersonations put people's lives at risk.
1365	seven japanese women went diving off the indonesian island of bali last friday, but five of them failed to return to the surface. they were found alive and rescued on monday, while the body of one woman was recovered the same day. four of the survivors were taken to bali's sangla hospital, where they are in good mental and psychological condition, being treated for light burns. the search continues for the sixth woman, who is still missing. the divers were grouped together on some rocks when they were found, dehydrated and in shock. the weather was reportedly good when they entered the water, but heavy rains and strong winds hit the area later, making the search and rescue operation challenging. the captain who accompanied the divers on a hired boat was not an employee of the diving company, and local authorities are investigating the incident.
1366	newcastle united defender steven taylor is feared to have suffered a ruptured achilles tendon during their 3-3 draw with burnley, which could end his season. taylor scored the opening goal for newcastle before limping off the pitch an hour into the game. acting manager john carver revealed that taylor's injury is not related to his previous one, and he is unlikely to return this season. burnley also suffered injuries, with jason shackell, dean marney, and kevin long all leaving the field of play. carver took charge of his first game since alan pardew's departure.
1367	the article reflects on the tragic death of soccer referee ricardo portillo, who was volunteering despite retiring from coaching due to missing the camaraderie and development of young players. the author, who grew up with a father who was a volunteer referee, shares concerns about the potential for aggression in youth sports and the importance of teaching children to deal with frustration and anger to prevent violent incidents. dr. patrick cohn, a youth sports psychologist, offers tips on cultivating resilience and separating self-worth from performance. the article emphasizes the importance of parents, coaches, and leagues in modeling positive behavior and enforcing acceptable conduct. additionally, dr. cohn provides pre- and post-game checklists for parents to encourage balance and positivity in their child's athletic experience.
1368	emotional intelligence (ei), self-worth, authenticity, and employee meditation rooms are no longer just concepts associated with new age healing centers. mainstream corporations are starting to recognize the benefits of employees' emotional happiness. brochner hotels, a successful boutique hotel chain in copenhagen, is one business implementing ei strategies to shift its culture. their ceo, karim nielsen, noticed a reluctance among staff to engage with customers and sell products, so he introduced ei training for all employees. the training aims to make employees more open, confident, and comfortable with themselves and others. the program includes a full ei profile to help understand emotions and relationships, empathy, authenticity, and leadership abilities, as well as meditation or visualization practices. dan iversen, a behavior change specialist who helped customize the brochner hotels training programs, emphasizes the importance of feelings in business and the need for training to effectively use them. companies like saint-gobain and wuerth denmark have also adopted ei training to improve cooperation and teamwork. ei pioneer john mayer defines it as the capacity to reason about emotional information and the capacity of emotional information to enhance thinking. historically, placing weight on emotions has been dismissed, but mayer believes that ei is crucial for relationships and provides an adaptive advantage. iversen suggests implementing ei in the workforce by using feelings actively in personal and team development, acknowledging and strengthening self-worth, and constructing an open culture for dealing with conflict. brochner hotels embraces this approach, making it okay to express emotions and be authentic as a leader. ei is gaining acceptance in business, with mayer predicting it will become a second measure of intelligence in the future. however, it is not a substitute for standard intelligence.
1369	ruth jones, the actress and co-creator of the popular british comedy "gavin & stacey," received an mbe (member of the most excellent order of the british empire) from queen elizabeth ii during a windsor castle investiture ceremony. jones, 47, who is currently filming the latest series of her sky comedy "stella," described the honor as the "icing on the cake" of her career. she began her career on itv's "fat friends" and joined james corden to create "gavin & stacey," which made jones a star by co-writing and playing the larger-than-life character nessa. she currently plays the title character in "stella," which she co-writes and produces with her husband, david peet. jones expressed her gratitude and surprise at receiving the award and her brief interaction with the queen.
1370	a newlywed, identified as michael boyce, 33, allegedly shot and killed his pregnant wife, alexis boyce, 23, in their orlando, florida home, leaving one of their twin babies dead and the other fighting for his life. the victims' parents were present during the shooting but did not witness the incident, having been in their bedroom at the time. michael initially told police that his wife had shot herself in the head but later changed his story, claiming it was an accident. upon further investigation, he was arrested on first-degree murder charges and taken to the orange county jail. the family had been married for approximately a year and, according to police, did not have a history of domestic violence. both were previously servicemembers in the u.s. navy.
1371	robin stearns, a frustrated wife in san francisco, created a website, myhusbandneedsajob.com, to help her jobless husband, michael, stand out in the tough job market. michael, who holds a master's degree from georgetown university, has been unsuccessful in his job search despite sending out numerous resumes. the site features his resume, a profile interview, and a plea from robin, along with her picture holding a sign asking for an employer. the internet and creative approaches, such as this unconventional method, are becoming essential tools for job seekers in the midst of high unemployment rates. the site has already attracted dozens of e-mails from potential employers and those in similar situations, highlighting the power of networking and reaching out to employers directly. the u.s. department of labor reports that california, where the stearnses live, has one of the highest unemployment rates at 10.1 percent, while the national rate is 8.1 percent.
1372	two mormon missionaries, yu peng xiong, 24, from taiwan, and connor benjamin thredgold, 19, from springville, utah, were found dead in their apartment in taipei, taiwan on saturday due to carbon monoxide poisoning, according to new taipei police. xiong had been serving as a missionary since march 2013 and thredgold since march 2014. authorities believe a faulty indoor water heater caused the leakage. their deaths were not considered suspicious. the new taipei fire department issued a warning about carbon monoxide poisoning and advised keeping windows open to prevent it. thredgold's family expressed their sympathies and said he was happy in taiwan and had made close friends. thredgold was the only family member to go abroad for a mission trip.
1373	a soldier named duane fahy was refused cigarettes at alpha news in st. helens, lancashire because he and his colleague were wearing their military uniforms. the shop assistant claimed it was due to a misunderstanding of the law, but it was later discovered this was not the case. the army initially criticized the newsagent's actions but later said the incident should not be used to cause division. the newsagent has since apologized and the shop was closed temporarily due to protests from locals. police are investigating offensive comments made online about the incident.
1374	kelly furlonger, a 31-year-old mother from godalming, surrey, shared her harrowing experience of battling anorexia and how her recovery should serve as inspiration for young people struggling with the same condition. furlonger's fixation on calorie consumption and excessive exercise caused her to lose over four stone in just five months, leading doctors to fear for her life just days before her wedding. her weight continued to drop, and she hit a low of 7st. her addiction to control through food and exercise began during her teenage years when she turned to sports as a form of escapism after her best friend's death and her parents' divorce. furlonger's daughter jasmine's arrival helped her shift her focus to a healthier perspective and recover her strength. having gained some weight and built muscle tone, she now encourages others to talk openly about their struggles and to harness the same determination they used to harm themselves to get better. furlonger now owns a cleaning company and is studying sports science while striving to maintain her healthy weight and serve as a positive role model for her daughter.
1375	the uk's competition commission has ordered airport operator baa to sell three of its seven airports, including gatwick and stansted in london, and either edinburgh or glasgow in scotland, within two years. the sale aims to encourage competition and reduce prices and improve customer service. baa owns seven airports in the uk, including heathrow, and the commission finds competition problems at all of them. baa believes the commission's analysis is flawed and may be impractical in current economic conditions. the competition commission, an independent public body, was asked to investigate airport competition by the office of fair trade in march 2007. baa was privatized in 1986 and is now owned by spanish property group ferrovial.
1376	model myla dalbesio has made history by becoming the curviest woman to appear in a calvin klein underwear campaign, despite being classified as a size 10 (uk size 14) which falls in between traditional size categories. dalbesio, who stands at 5ft 11in and describes her body type as "in the middle," expressed feelings of intimidation due to being larger than all previous calvin klein models. some critics have taken to twitter in outrage over her being labeled as a "bigger" girl, with some arguing she doesn't fit the plus-size model category. myla says she's hopeful that this campaign marks a step towards reducing size discrimination in the fashion industry, as calvin klein did not distinguish her as a plus-size model. the fashion house released a statement expressing their aim to cater to different women's needs and sizes. myla has a history of struggling with body image issues and has spoken about her past experiences with eating disorders and pressures to conform to standard modeling sizes.
1377	the new district attorney of boulder county, colorado, stan garnett, plans to reassess the investigation into the 1996 murder of jonbenet ramsey, who was found dead in her family's home at the age of 6, with a ransom note left behind. the case, which has gained national notoriety, has been under the jurisdiction of the da's office since 2002. although there have been new developments, such as dna tests and the clearing of a suspect, the case remains unsolved. garnett aims to determine whether it's more efficient for his office or someone else to handle the ongoing investigation, which involves checking new tips and information. he clarified that the case was not closed and that it's important to keep in mind the limited resources of his office. the investigation has faced criticisms for the handling of past dna evidence and the suspicious circumstances surrounding the ramsey family, but garnett commended the boulder police department for their work. the department, which has 24 investigators, has four times as many investigators as the da's office. garnett, who was sworn in on january 13 and has previous trial lawyer experience, was elected to replace mary lacy, who couldn't run again due to term limits.
1378	liberal democrat mp david ward faced international backlash after he tweeted that he would consider firing rockets at israel if he lived in gaza. his comments sparked outrage and calls for his expulsion from the party and investigation for encouragement of terrorism. ward issued a statement condemning the violence on both sides and apologized if his comments gave the wrong impression. however, he continued to speak out for the rights of palestinians and called for an end to the humanitarian crisis. nick clegg launched an investigation and conservative party accused him of being unfit for office. ward's controversially comments came as conflict escalated between israel and gaza, with militants firing rockets into israel and israeli military responding with airstrikes. ward's previous comments about israel and jews resulted in his suspension from the liberal democrats last year.
1379	olympic heptathlon gold medalist denise lewis received an honorary degree from the university of wolverhampton, her hometown university. the 42-year-old athlete, who won bronze in the atlanta olympics and has a total of six major championship medals, expressed her joy and appreciation for the recognition 14 years after being granted the freedom of the city. she continues to be a regular pundit on bbc sport's athletics coverage.
1380	a 19-year-old kentucky woman, brittney kustes, who had been missing for two weeks, was found and is recovering from being held captive by a registered sex offender, roy vernon elwell. witnesses reported seeing elwell, who has a history of kidnapping and unlawful confinement, near kustes' grandparents' home on the day she disappeared. elwell allegedly befriended kustes and had a history with her, and she was last seen with him willingly before her disappearance. kustes was found on friday and is currently receiving medical attention due to her traumatic experience. elwell, who is described as "very dangerous," is a known noncompliant sex offender and has evaded police. he is wanted for questioning in relation to kustes' disappearance and could face up to five years in prison for violating the sex offender registry.
1381	president obama marked lgbt pride month at the white house on monday, comparing the fight for gay rights to the civil rights movement for african americans. he pledged to work towards repealing the defense of marriage act and ending "don't ask, don't tell" in the military. the president also called for passing laws guaranteeing full benefits for lgbt couples and their families, and stronger hate crime and employment discrimination laws. obama acknowledged the pain and heartbreak experienced by the lgbt community, but expressed optimism that progress will continue. he referenced the stonewall riots, which sparked the modern lgbt rights movement 40 years ago.
1382	a man named lawrence gaskell is on trial for murdering his ex-wife, katarina gaskell, in october 2011 during a violent argument at their home in brisbane, australia. gaskell told the supreme court jury that katarina, who came to pick up some belongings, became angry when he refused to give her one of their houses. he claimed she threatened him with kitchen knives and hedefended himself by grabbing a hammer and hitting her repeatedly. gaskell stated that katarina was acting irrationally and was trying to kill him during the altercation. the case was adjourned, and no comments are currently being accepted on the article.
1383	seven teachers were kidnapped in peshawar, pakistan, for supporting a polio vaccination campaign, but they were not directly involved in the vaccination process, according to a local official. the teachers, from hira public school in the volatile khyber agency, were taken from the sipah area of bara district in the federally administered tribal area. the world health organization (who) clarified that the teachers were not part of the recent campaign. at least 16 polio cases have been reported in khyber agency this year, with security issues making it particularly vulnerable to the disease, which was declared eradicated from neighboring india. anti-polio campaigns in pakistan have been targeted by militants since a fake vaccination program was used by us intelligence to help hunt for osama bin laden in 2011. the who reported at least 63 polio cases in pakistan this year as of november 19, an increase from the 54 cases reported during the same period last year. the organization expressed concern over the potential spread of polio from pakistan to other parts of the world. the kidnapped teachers were being negotiated for release through local efforts and a jirga led by a tribal elder.
1384	a 22-year-old rutgers university student from edison, new jersey, named darsh patel, was killed by a bear in the apshawa preserve last month, making it the first fatal bear attack in new jersey history. the bear was acting in a "predatory" manner and showed "stalking type behavior," according to officials. patel and his friends had been hiking when they noticed the bear following them. the bear mauled patel, leaving his body with numerous bites and claw marks. authorities later destroyed the bear. the bear could have been searching for food, but officials believe it was more likely predisposed to attack. residents in northern new jersey, where the dense forests may house as many as 2,400 bruins, are often spotting bears, but attacks are rare. the safest way to handle a bear encounter is to move slowly and avoid direct eye contact. authorities euthanize "category i" bears that are deemed an immediate threat to human safety. bear sightings are common in new jersey, and black bears typically do not pose a threat to humans and often retreat when confronted.
1385	a cancer patient named lindsey miller, diagnosed with pancreatic neuroendocrine cancer, created a youtube video asking hollywood star joseph gordon-levitt out on a date after being inspired by his role in the film "50/50" about a man dealing with cancer. the video, entitled "will joseph gordon-levitt have coffee with me?" received over 250,000 hits, and lindsey expressed her identification with the actor and the difficulty of explaining her diagnosis to potential dates. despite the video's popularity and lindsey's attempts to connect with him through social media, there was no response from joseph gordon-levitt at the time of the article, published on november 18, 2011.
1386	california is currently experiencing one of its worst droughts in decades with roughly 58% of the state facing "exceptional" drought conditions. climate scientists warn that the chances of a drought lasting more than a decade in the southwest have reached 50%, and the chances of a "megadrought" lasting over 30 years are between 20-50%. this is due to the continuing rise in temperatures caused by man-made climate change. the researchers from cornell university, the university of arizona, and the us geological survey predict that these droughts would be the worst in the last 2,000 years and pose unprecedented challenges to water resources in the region. shasta lake in california, which is now several hundred meters from its former banks, is a stark reminder of the severity of the situation, and experts cannot predict when the drought will end. they warn that the current conditions offer a glimpse into the future of the southwest.
1387	andy shallal, owner of popular bookstore cafes "busboys and poets" in the washington d.c. area, sees annual revenue of over $14 million but faces difficulty getting a business loan from his bank due to economic conditions. banks are reportedly hesitant to lend, despite billions in relief funds and pressure from lawmakers to boost small business lending. president obama plans to address this issue with bank leaders on monday, pushing for increased lending and financial reforms. analysts suggest banks remain cautious due to regulatory scrutiny and tighter credit standards. small business expert anne mathias states regulators are compelling banks to be more careful with their capital and liquidity, while scott talbott from the financial services roundtable notes banks are still lending but are more selective about borrowers. the house has passed a financial reform bill, and the senate is working on similar legislation. white house officials believe these reforms are necessary to prevent another financial crisis, and shallal urges lawmakers to act quickly to help small businesses stimulate economic growth.
1388	ray lewis, a football player who won the super bowl with the baltimore ravens, escaped a child support lawsuit days before the championship game. his ex-partner, sharnika kelly, wanted him to pay more money for their 11-year-old son in a legal battle that lasted over two years. the lawsuit was dropped on february 1, 2013, in florida, two days before the super bowl in new orleans. the details of the case dismissal remain unclear, with some reports suggesting financial issues on ms. kelly's part may have factored into lewis's reluctance to pay more. the victory marked lewis's second super bowl ring, and he retired from the game after the win. having joined the ravens when they moved from cleveland in 1996, he was a star attraction at the team's homecoming celebration in baltimore.
1389	in a news conference in greensburg, pennsylvania, democratic presidential candidate hillary clinton distanced herself from the controversial remarks of rev. jeremiah wright, stating that she would not have chosen him as her pastor. this is the first time clinton or her campaign has commented directly on the issue, which has been a topic of controversy for rival senator barack obama's campaign. obama's campaign spokesman criticized clinton's comments as a "transparent effort to distract attention" from her earlier remarks about dodging sniper fire in bosnia. clinton referenced a speech she gave last year on the issue of degrading remarks and urged turning a culture of degradation into one of empowerment. she added that everyone would have to decide for themselves on the matter, but that if wright had been her pastor, she would have made a different choice. obama, in a previous speech, acknowledged hearing controversial remarks from wright but strongly disagreed with many of his views.
1390	a liberal democrat counselor, david fuller, from fareham, hampshire, has been accused of hosting sex parties at his home for around a year. the parties, reportedly attended by scantily-clad women and men in leather, featured sex games using ropes, chains, and electrical equipment. local authorities are investigating if the parties have breached licensing or planning regulations. fuller, a member of portsmouth city council's licensing committee and care home manager, declined to comment but acknowledged he was a freemason. fareham conservative leader, sean woodward, has initiated an investigation into the matter, with portsmouth council remaining uncertain about the application of licensing and planning regulations in this private capacity issue.
1391	tesco apologies and offers a £5 voucher to a customer, chris mcgarry, after he was wrongfully accused of shoplifting at one of their stores in northumberland. mcgarry, who was with his mother, paid for his shopping but was confronted by a staff member as he was leaving the store. the incident left him and his mother feeling uncomfortable and humiliated. tesco has since spoken to mcgarry and resolved the issue. the incident occurred when mcgarry's card was declined at the checkout, forcing him to leave the trolley behind and get cash from another account before returning to pay for his groceries. mcgarry was later accused of shoplifting when he returned to the store. tesco expressed their apologies and stated that the matter has been resolved.
1392	boris berezovsky, a russian politician and businessman, died under mysterious circumstances, likely by suicide, in england. known for his inventiveness and tenacity, he played a significant role in the privatization of russian industries in the 1990s after the fall of the soviet union. he amassed great wealth and influence but lost much of it when he went into opposition. berezovsky helped halt the first chechen war and attempted to unite the commonwealth of independent states (cis), but his efforts were criticized by the press. in his later years, he went to court against his former partner roman abramovich for allegedly selling a stake in sibneft for a fraction of its true value. the court ruled against him and impeached him for deception and self-deception. berezovsky died without recognition or justice, but during his lifetime, he was a controversial figure who escaped russia and lived in self-imposed exile.
1393	the centre for social justice (csj), a think tank founded by former work and pensions secretary iain duncan smith, has proposed a plan to help the long-term unemployed move house to find work by providing financial aid. anyone out of work for over a year would be eligible for assistance with moving costs, such as hiring a removals van or paying a deposit on a new home. the csj argues that people on benefits in social housing are less likely to be employed and fewer are likely to move to find work. critics may compare this plan to norman tebbit's 1980s suggestion for the jobless to "get on their bikes," but the term was actually used in a different context. the pilot scheme, which could use funds from discretionary housing payments, would only apply to those with a concrete job offer that requires a longer commute. the csj acknowledged the need for a managed approach to prevent population imbalances. critics have stated that current rules discourage the unemployed from seeking work in areas with booming labor markets due to financial barriers. people in social housing are less likely to be employed and more likely to remain in the same house for extended periods due to the cost of moving. a representative from yarlington housing group stated that a £250 moving assistance fund can make a difference for residents looking to move to take up a job. the department for work and pensions indicated that the plan is not currently under consideration but will be reviewed by ministers.
1394	tv host josh gates of destination truth received hamburger earmuffs instead of a $9.99 t-shirt he ordered from amazon on december 6. he initially found the mix-up confusing but soon saw the comedic potential and shared photos of himself wearing the earmuffs on twitter, creating a viral campaign. the earmuffs, sold by that's rad!, quickly became a highly sought-after christmas gift, leading to a sell-out of their stock. gates has gained thousands of new followers and expressed gratitude for the unexpected gift, with owner todd herriott unlikely to restock due to post-christmas demand.
1395	a gold coast helicopter pilot narrowly avoided disaster while transporting a heavy water tank from the roof of contessa holiday apartments on main beach. with ten years of experience, the pilot decided to drop the tank on the river bank instead of ejecting it from the chopper due to added weight from damp insulation material. although the event was given the all-clear by the city of gold coast and civil aviation safety authority, onlookers were terrified as they watched the helicopter swing heavily from side to side while attempting to deposit the tank on the river bank. no injuries were reported, and no investigations are ongoing.
1396	real sociedad president jokin aperribay has revealed that the club is in talks with former manchester united manager david moyes about taking over as their new manager. moyes has been without a club since leaving manchester united in april 2014, but sociedad are hoping to lure him to la liga. the basque club sacked their manager jagoba arrasate after just one victory in their first 10 games this season, and aperribay mentioned moyes and pepe mel as potential replacements. sociedad have a history of appointing british managers, with previous ones including chris coleman, harry lowe, and john toshack. coleman was the most recent british manager to have been in charge of sociedad, between 2007 and 2008. moyes could surprise some fans, but he could be the next british manager to manage the spanish club.
1397	at least nine suspected illegal immigrants were caught after emerging from a german lorry covered in flour on the m26 motorway in kent, england. the immigrants had sneaked into the tanker in france before being brought to england without the driver's knowledge. four of the men were released on immigration bail, and the others remain in detention, pending removal from the country. the incident, which occurred near the m25 junction during rush hour, was captured on photograph by a daily mail reader. the local police reported receiving an average of one report a day regarding clandestine immigration over the past two years. the border agency claims to have tightened security checks, but the incident highlights the continued flow of people entering the uk illegally. the four men who were released are expected to be housed in a hostel and given information on how to apply for asylum and benefits.
1398	on september 11, 2001, melbourne, australia, evacuated its world trade center due to a perceived terrorist threat, despite its remote location and significant distance from the actual attacks in new york. australia's isolation has historically defined its identity with an undisturbed aboriginal population and unique flora and fauna. however, despite this distance, australia has not been immune to terrorism, with previous attacks on bali in 2002 and recent police sweeps in australian cities. the article reflects on how australia's sense of separation from global events began to change after 9/11 and how technology has made the world appear smaller, making it easier for ideologies and violent acts to reach australian shores. despite this, australians continue to value their unique way of life, even as the world grows more interconnected.
1399	lloyd's of london, the oldest insurance market in the world, broke the glass ceiling by appointing industry veteran inga beale as its first female ceo in january 2013, with over 30 years of international experience. indonesian minister of finance and coordinating minister of economic affairs sri mulyani indrawati moved to the world bank as managing director and coo, providing financial capital to developing countries. christine lagarde became the first female managing director of the international monetary fund in 2011, having previously served as france's minister of finance, economy and trade. janet yellen is set to become the first female chair of the us federal reserve in january 2014, with extensive experience as a public servant and a long career in academia. ngozi okonjo-iweala, a nigerian finance minister and graduate of harvard and mit, has served several roles including managing director at the world bank, and continues to fight corruption and institute reforms as nigeria's current finance minister.
1400	monopoly, the classic board game, has introduced a new token - a cat - while removing the iron, based on fan votes conducted on facebook. the iron, which has been a part of the game since the 1930s, received just 8% of the votes. the cat, which was a fan favorite and secured 31% of the votes, will make its debut in mid- to late 2013. the decision was met with mixed reactions, with some voters expressing their disappointment and others expressing their delight. hasbro, the game's manufacturer, announced the new token on february 6, 2013, after a public poll that attracted millions of fans from over 120 countries. other tokens that were in the running included a robot, diamond ring, helicopter, and guitar. the company stated that the online contest to change the tokens was intended to keep the game relevant to fans. monopoly's iconic tokens originated from charms on the game creator's niece's bracelet and include a racecar, scottie dog, shoe, thimble, top hat, wheelbarrow, battleship, and iron. the wheelbarrow and shoe were added in the early 1950s. numerous companies, including ames true temper inc. (garden tools) and zappos (online shoe retailer), campaigned to save their respective tokens. versions of monopoly with the new cat token will be available later in 2013.
1401	the attorney for the two women who have accused wikileaks founder julian assange of sexual crimes in sweden denied rumors that the pentagon or cia were involved in the case on tuesday. claes borgstrom said the allegations against assange are "complete nonsense" and that his clients have nothing to do with any kind of conspiracy. two women, aged 25 and 35, have reported independent incidents of sexual misconduct against assange during his visit to sweden last year. a warrant for assange's arrest was issued last week on charges of rape and molestation, but it was revoked the next day by chief prosecutor eva finne after she reviewed more information. finne has not spoken to assange, and assange's lawyer, leif silbersky, said his client strongly denies all the accusations. silbersky also criticized finne for identifying assange to the media. wikileaks has recently published thousands of documents related to the war in afghanistan, which has drawn criticism from the u.s. and afghanistan. assange told al-jazeera that the allegations against him are "a smear campaign" and suggested that the pentagon or cia could be involved. however, pentagon spokesman bryan whitman and justice department spokesman dean boyd both denied any involvement in the situation. borgstrom said the women have been subjected to intense media attention and that their experiences were unrelated to each other. assange is currently in the uk, and it is unclear whether he will travel to sweden to face the allegations. if convicted of molestation, assange could face up to a year in jail in sweden.
