1402	john terry is set to captain chelsea for the 500th time in his career against crystal palace on saturday. the 33-year-old center back, who has been a legendary figure at stamford bridge, has been praised by former chelsea stars marcel desailly and ron "chopper" harris. desailly, a french international and chelsea legend, recalled terry's early days at the club, praising his motivation, leadership skills, and work ethic. harris, chelsea's record appearance holder, also had kind words for terry and described him as a proud moment for him, having come through the ranks and gone on to captain the club to win major honors. terry, who has won 13 trophies as chelsea captain, leads the list of top captains in the club's history and has been in the thick of things since his debut in 2001. he was the first chelsea captain to lead the team at the age of 21 and has dealt with issues away from football with grace and resilience. terry previously faced crystal palace at selhurst park in march, where he scored an own goal, and will be eager to leave south london with a better result this time around.
1403	hannah kritzeck, a 19-year-old teen from minnesota, was born with primordial dwarfism, making her just 39 inches tall and affecting only about 100 people in the world. despite her rare condition, which causes short stature and health issues like brain aneurysms and a shortened life span, hannah loves singing, ballet, and hip-hop dancing. her loving family, including her adoptive parents, jackie and larry kritzeck, and siblings, have adapted to her needs, ensuring she had a normal childhood. however, hannah faces unique challenges like shopping for clothes and the perception of being a child when interacting with others. her dreams include falling in love, starting a family, and becoming a dancer. hannah's condition comes with several medical issues, requiring regular monitoring, dental implants, and scoliosis correction. she remains determined and focused on her passions while looking for love. a new film, "little and looking for love," follows her journey. hannah's mother, jackie, worries about her future but encourages her to live each day to the fullest. hannah's advice to others with her condition is never to give up on dreams. the film airs on tlc on february 11, 2023.
1404	david cameron is considering holding a referendum on britain's eu membership during the next general election in 2015, according to senior conservative sources. the prime minister has indicated that he agrees with the majority of the british people who are unhappy with the uk's relationship with the eu, but critics say his stance is unclear and vague. some conservatives argue that a referendum would help energize party support and secure a commons majority, while others suggest delaying it until after the next election. the liberal democrats, who are part of the coalition government, have expressed opposition to a referendum while they are still in power. william hague, the foreign secretary, has indicated that there may be a strong case for a referendum if europe moves towards a more federal system. however, the government is currently trying to negotiate a better relationship with the eu before putting the matter to a vote. some conservatives are pushing for a legally-binding commitment to holding a referendum after the next election, but the prime minister has a history of making vague commitments on europe that have not materialized. the last time the question of europe was put to the public was in 1975, when voters backed the uk's continuing membership of the bloc.
1405	fifty years ago, laika, a stray dog from moscow, became the first living creature in space when she was sent aboard sputnik 2. although her mission ended tragically with her death due to insufficient provisions for her return, her historical significance is undeniable, sparking the space race between the soviet union and the united states during the cold war. dr. stanley coren, a psychology professor at the university of british columbia, highlights the role of ten influential dogs in history. laika was preceded by strelka and belka, the first dogs to orbit and return alive, whose mission yielded valuable data. other notable dogs include peritas, who saved alexander the great from an elephant, charles kennedy's therapy dog during the cuban missile crisis, and jofi, the first therapy dog who appeared in sigmund freud's psychotherapy sessions. other contributions by dogs include saving napoleon bonaparte from drowning, helping to establish the church of england, and aiding in the discovery of robert the bruce during the american revolution. dogs have played crucial roles throughout history.
1406	former first lady laura bush praised president obama's performance in office during an interview with cnn, commenting that he has faced tough circumstances and is doing a good job. she defended his upcoming back-to-school speech to students, despite some conservative concerns. bush also criticized the political divide in washington, echoing her disappointment with the polarization during her husband's administration. she defended the former vice president dick cheney's right to speak out in defense of the bush administration's national security record. despite criticisms of her husband's impact on the world, bush maintains that he stood for freedom and the security of the country. she expressed concern for the situations in afghanistan and myanmar, and her hope for peaceful transitions to democracy in both countries.
1407	a couple who were accused of battering their month-old baby and had the child taken away for adoption due to suspected abuse now have a chance to get him back. the baby's injuries were originally assumed to be caused by horrific abuse, but new evidence suggests he had a vitamin d deficiency which led to rickets. although the parents were originally found responsible in court, a judge has intervened and ordered a fresh medical review by a leading endocrinologist. the parents have 28 days to obtain a report supporting their case, and if the expert confirms the vitamin d deficiency theory, the boy may be returned to his parents. the adoption process has been put on hold. the case may set a precedent for future infant injury cases.
1408	in kasane, botswana, humans and elephants coexist in close proximity, leading to tension over limited space. researcher tempe adams is studying the effectiveness of small-scale wildlife corridors, including those near a busy highway where many accidents occur. her findings suggest elephants adapt to human behavior, avoiding the area on weekends when it's busiest. the conservation group elephants without borders (ewb) emphasizes the importance of providing corridors for wildlife to access vital resources and reduce human-wildlife conflict. they are advocating for legislative protection and stricter terminology for wildlife corridors, creating set paths for elephants as towns grow and eventually lessening the impact of their expanding numbers. botswana, with around 130,000 elephants, is the continent's largest elephant population, creating a need for safe passage and corridors to alleviate conflict and repopulate low-density areas. research from ewb led to the creation of the kavango-zambezi transfrontier conservation area, the largest wildlife preservation in the world, protecting key corridors and habitats.
1409	rielle hunter, john edwards' former mistress, reveals in her new book that elizabeth edwards, john's cancer-stricken wife, tormented herself by watching video footage of them together as her computer screensaver. john edwards was unapologetic about the affair and is seen in new pictures enjoying a beach getaway with hunter and their daughter quinn, just before the release of her tell-all memoir. in the book, hunter describes the couple's sexual encounters, including an "extraordinary" night she "surrendered" to edwards hours after meeting him. she claims she wrote the book for quinn, but also as her duty to edwards' other children. elizabeth edwards is mercilessly criticized in the memoir, with hunter describing her as controlling, abusive, and a "witch on wheels." the book offers details of the affair that publically destroyed the edwards family, including how hunter met edwards' children and won them over. john edwards is described as cowed by his wife, an accomplished lawyer, but eventually took control of his life and formally separated from her in 2009.
1410	south korea is a global leader in identifying and treating gaming and internet addiction, with about 8% of its population aged 9 to 39 suffering from these issues according to a 2010 government study. the country has invested heavily in broadband infrastructure and spends millions annually for treatment. the american psychiatric association is considering listing "internet use disorder" as a warranted study for the next revision of the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders. dr. han doug-hyun from chung-ang university hospital in seoul is a leading figure in treating internet and gaming addiction and uses techniques similar to those for alcoholics, including counseling and virtual-reality therapy. his top five warning signs of addiction are: disrupted life pattern, job loss or education abandonment, needing a longer fix, withdrawal symptoms, and cravings.
1411	the article reports that the strong pound against the euro presents an opportunity for britons to save money on holiday purchases at european resorts, specifically in portugal's algarve region, where the cost of a basket of typical holiday items has dropped by 50% since january 2009. however, the article also warns that prices have risen significantly in destinations such as thailand and dubai, where the pound buys less than in the past. the research by post office travel money reveals that costs in the algarve are now 50% cheaper than they were in 2009, making it an attractive destination for british tourists. other european resorts, such as sunny beach in bulgaria and spain's costa del sol, also offer good value for tourists. however, it is advised that those planning trips further afield should be cautious as sterling's falling value in some countries could result in lower spending power. the article suggests potential swaps for tourists, including mexico instead of the dominican republic, jamaica in place of barbados, egypt instead of dubai, or indonesia's bali instead of thailand. additionally, uk drivers traveling to europe during the school half-term holiday can benefit from plunging petrol prices, with diesel as low as 80p a litre in austria and 83p a litre in france and spain.
1412	aung san suu kyi, a nobel peace laureate and political activist in myanmar (formerly known as burma), was reunited with her younger son, kim aris, after a decade-long separation, at the yangon international airport on tuesday. aris, who had been in bangkok, thailand, waiting for a visa, was escorted by security officials without going through standard immigration procedures. suu kyi, also accompanied by security personnel, greeted her son and the two left the airport together. suu kyi was released from house arrest in november after spending most of the past 20 years under house arrest or in prison. the military regime had held the country's first elections in two decades, which were criticized as a sham and led to the junta's landslide victory. suu kyi and her national league for democracy (nld) party boycotted the elections due to a new law that forced them to choose between recognizing suu kyi as their leader or being declared illegal. the nld won the 1990 elections, but the military junta rejected the results. myanmar has been under military rule since 1962, and suu kyi, the daughter of gen. aung san, a hero of burmese independence, has consistently challenged the regime.
1413	the uk could legally launch a military strike against syria without the support of the united nations, according to a released government legal advice. the advice suggests that britain could use military intervention to deter and disrupt further use of chemical weapons by the syrian regime, which is believed to be responsible for a chemical attack in damascus on august 21, killing at least 350 people. russia and china have vowed to veto any un resolution backing military action, and the uk is preparing to go it alone. the joint intelligence committee has also concluded that it is "highly likely" that the syrian regime was responsible for the attack. the cabinet was briefed on the latest intelligence and six raf typhoon jets were deployed to cyprus to protect uk interests. prime minister david cameron is battling to get a consensus for military action in the house of commons debate.
1414	thousands of people in the uk are receiving disability benefits, costing the taxpayer £54 million, due to obesity-related illnesses such as diabetes and high blood pressure. the number of beneficiaries has more than doubled in five years, with around 12,000 people receiving disability living allowance (dla) in 2020. obesity is a significant burden on the nhs, costing over £9 billion a year. critics argue that the government should take more action against the food industry and implement measures such as calorie reduction and clear labeling to help people make healthier choices. some dla recipients have jobs, but the majority are out of work, and they can receive up to £138 a week. the government aims to cut the welfare bill by phasing out dla and replacing it with a new personal independence payment, while also launching initiatives to tackle obesity and reduce calorie consumption by 2020. food manufacturers and the public health sector are encouraged to play a role in this effort. some experts suggest that obesity should be considered an addiction, affecting a quarter of british adults and nearly one in five secondary school pupils. by 2050, the annual bill for obesity-related illnesses is predicted to rise to £50 billion, with almost two-thirds of the population projected to be obese.
1415	a report by the national audit office (nao) has raised concerns over the value for money of the uk government's £3.7 billion help to buy scheme, which assists first-time buyers in purchasing homes priced up to £600,000. margaret hodge, the public accounts committee chairman, questioned the need for such high purchase prices. for every completed case assessed by help to buy agents, the government paid a fee of £1,000, which has since been reduced to £600, but resulted in additional expenditures of £600,000 during the first three months. while nearly 13,000 families have bought properties through the scheme during its first nine months, the average income of applicants is only slightly higher than the average government loan provided. the nao has also criticized the lack of a coordinated approach to evaluating the scheme's overall impact and the potential for buyers having purchased properties without assistance. the help to buy scheme offers assistance through two programs, one for new-build homes and one for all properties, providing a government mortgage guarantee. the program has been more popular in the northern regions and has resulted in more new homes being bought in the midlands, the north east, yorkshire and the humber than other regions. kris hopkins, the housing minister, maintains that the help to buy scheme provides "indisputable value for money" and will generate £4.8 billion over its lifetime.
1416	a senior consultant, david sellu, is on trial for manslaughter and perjury at the old bailey after a patient, james hughes, died following a routine knee operation in february 2010. hughes, a retired builder, developed unexplained bowel pain and called his doctor friend for help due to communication issues with the on-duty hungarian doctor. sellu, who had a specialty in colorectal conditions, diagnosed a ruptured bowel but did not perform immediate surgery. instead, he ordered a ct scan for the next day, but then failed to operate even after receiving the results. the delay in treatment led to a fatal heart attack. it is also alleged that sellu lied to the coroner about when he first viewed hughes' scan results. the trial is expected to last three to four weeks, and sellu denies both charges.
1417	secretary of state john kerry visited the mekong delta in vietnam, where he once patrolled for communist insurgents during the vietnam war. while the region now faces new challenges such as rising sea levels and dam development, kerry pledged a $17 million contribution to help farmers adapt. he also emphasized the importance of sharing the mekong's resources and urged nations not to exploit the region at the expense of others. kerry returned to the delta for the first time since 1969 and recalled the impact of his military service on his anti-war activism. he also discussed economic opportunities and human rights during his visit to vietnam.
1418	comedian rory bremner paid tribute to his mentor and comedy partner john fortune, who passed away at the age of 74. fortune, known for his satirical sketches on politics and military top brass, met bremner and john bird at cambridge university in the 1960s. they gained fame together on the channel 4 show "bremner, bird and fortune." fortune, a father of three, was a veteran actor who appeared in numerous british comedy programs and won a bafta for his work on bremner's bbc two comedy "now something else" in 1997. friends and colleagues paid tribute to fortune, describing him as fearless, unique, and the funniest person they had ever met. fortune passed away peacefully with his wife and dog by his side.
1419	convicted felon jeremy meeks became an overnight celebrity after his chiseled face and blue eyes went viral on social media following his arrest. his new manager, gina rodriguez, has received harassing phone calls and a death threat due to the controversy surrounding meeks' criminal history, which includes theft, gun possession, and gang membership. meeks' family hired rodriguez after being overwhelmed by the sudden attention, and they have received numerous modeling offers, as well as interest from production companies and a reality tv show. meeks, who remains in jail, was pulled over during a gang sweep in stockton, california, and faces new charges related to weapons possession and probation violation. he has a prior criminal record, including a two-year stint in prison for grand theft in 2002. some people have criticized the attention meeks receives, arguing that he shouldn't be celebrated for his looks while he has a criminal background. meeks' bail was set at $1 million during his arraignment.
1420	today's cnn student news covers the upcoming u.s. elections and the reasons behind their annual november date. the show also includes science stories about cloud computing and the prospect of establishing a human colony on mars. the transcript from the program and a roll call feature for schools to request mentions are available on their website. cnn student news is produced by journalists considering common core, national, and state standards. to be mentioned on the roll call, comment with your school name, mascot, city, and state, and be a teacher or student aged 13 or older.
1421	ibrahim afellay, a dutch midfielder who joined barcelona from psv in 2010 but made only 35 appearances due to leg injuries, has been loaned to greek champions olympiacos for the 2018-19 season with an option to extend the deal by two more years. afellay was replaced by joel campbell, who was loaned from arsenal last season, after the costa rican impressed at the world cup and returned to his parent club. afellay, who has 44 caps for the netherlands and five international goals, will join another former barcelona player, javier saviola, at olympiacos, and his contract with barcelona expires next june.
1422	firefighters in western australia fought bushfires in perth on monday, which destroyed at least 59 homes and led to a natural disaster declaration by premier colin barnett in the perth hills region. residents can now qualify for emergency assistance, including accommodation, food, and other necessities. a total fire ban was declared for perth, perth hills, and surrounding areas due to 75 kph winds. the cause of the fire was accidentally started by sparks from an angle grinder, according to initial investigations.
1423	on a sunny day in 1991 at the rose bowl aquatics center in pasadena, california, photographer kirk weddle captured an iconic image for nirvana's "nevermind" album cover. he chose 4-month-old spencer elden, son of his friend and artist rick elden, who brought him to the pool for the shoot. weddle had been working on an idea by nirvana's frontman kurt cobain, which involved a mother giving birth underwater. however, a compromise was made, and a baby swimming underwater was proposed instead. dozens of infants, including spencer, were signed up for the photo shoot that week. rick elden recalled how spencer was a good swimmer, even at 4 months old. only 18 frames were taken before spencer was pulled out of the water. the eldens received $200 for the shoot. years later, spencer returned to the same pool complex as a high school graduate and swimmer on the club team.
1424	ariel castro, who pleaded guilty to kidnapping and murdering three women and holding them captive in his home for nearly a decade, has been described as belonging in prison for the rest of his life by his son, anthony castro. in an exclusive interview with nbc's "today" show, anthony expressed his belief that the recommended life sentence without parole, following the plea deal, is the best possible outcome. he also revealed that his father has been lying to their family for years and he has no intention of visiting him. castro kidnapped michelle knight, amanda berry, and georgina "gina" dejesus between 2002 and 2003 and held them in a 1,400-square-foot home. they were rescued in may 2013, after amanda managed to escape and summon help. the community rallied around the women, offering support and assistance in their recovery. anthony castro grew up in a violent household and had been physically abused by his father, who also kept him and his mother in fear. though his family has been deeply affected by the events, anthony expressed gratitude for everyone's continued support.
1425	former ira commander martin mcguinness described the deaths of two boys, tim parry (12) and johnathan ball (3), who were killed by ira bombs in warrington in 1993 as "shameful" during a peace lecture in the town. mcguinness, northern ireland deputy first minister, was invited by tim parry's father to speak at the tim parry-jonathan ball foundation for peace. a small group of protesters objected to his presence, including julie hambleton, whose sister was killed in the birmingham pub bombings. mcguinness, who joined the ira as a teenager and was second in command of the ira in derry during bloody sunday, later served six months in prison for explosives possession. he has been accused of attending the interrogation of a british government informer, but always denied those allegations. in 1998, he was a member of sinn fein and was the political party's chief negotiator when the good friday agreement was signed. mcguinness had an open door policy at the foundation and spoke of his own journey to peace, acknowledging the suffering caused by the conflict and expressing remorse. tim and johnathan were killed by bombs planted in litter bins in the town's main shopping area, leaving 56 people injured. the foundation has become an internationally recognized center for conflict resolution and victim support. protesters gathered outside the venue, with some comparing mcguinness giving a speech on peace to myra hindley giving a talk on child protection.
1426	a new ct scanner, worth £600,000 and considered the world's quickest and most detailed, has been installed at bradford royal infirmary. the scanner, which uses x-rays to create 160-slice images in just 0.35 seconds, is said to revolutionalise medical technology. the machine, which accommodates obese patients and has a television, can perform up to 50 scans a day, and can show relaxation videos to patients. it also uses a lower dose of radiation than older ct scanners. the hospital has been designated a world reference site by manufacturer toshiba, making it a center of excellence in the uk. with increased imaging speed, staff can spend more time with patients and scan more people daily. the machine provides near-instant, high-resolution images of organs like the heart and lungs, allowing for more accurate diagnoses and faster interpretations by radiographers.
1427	linkedin identified the most overused professional buzzwords in us job listings for 2011, which include "creative," "organizational," "effective," "extensive experience," "track record," "motivated," "innovative," "communication skills," and "dynamic." repeating from the previous year are "extensive experience," "innovative," and "motivated," while "team player," "results-oriented," "entrepreneurial," and "fast-paced" dropped off the list. nicole williams, linkedin's connection director, advised against using these buzzwords and encouraged job seekers to provide specific examples of their unique accomplishments and experiences instead. the study also examined the top buzzwords for other countries, with "creative" being common in several countries and "multinational" being particularly popular in brazil.
1428	a hiker, martin kaiser, aged 54, was stuck for three hours in a cattle grid while hiking up hochkoenig mountain in austria with his dog. when he lost his footing trying to call the dog back, one of his legs became trapped. unable to free himself, he yodeled for help due to being in a remote area and concerned about the sun or injury. a cyclist eventually heard his yodels and called emergency services, who sent firemen to rescue him. kaiser received first aid and continued his alpine hike after being unhurt, vowing to be more aware of cattle grids in the future.
1429	reality is mirroring fiction in the illegal drug world as distributors in new mexico are selling methamphetamine tinted blue, resembling the blue meth depicted in amc's hit tv show "breaking bad." homeland security investigator kevin abar says dealers are advertising and branding their product by tinting it blue, but it is not the pure meth portrayed on the show. in fact, the blue meth is making users violently ill due to the chemicals added to achieve the color. authorities are concerned about its addictive qualities and the potential increase in users despite the health risks. jose plata, a meth addict, shared his regret of trying the drug once when he was 14 and the devastating consequences he has faced since. blue meth has also been found in other regions such as kansas city and oklahoma city. although "breaking bad" has ended its run after five seasons, the blue meth trend continues to gain popularity.
1430	twitter, once seen as a platform for sharing trivial content among friends and minor celebrities, has evolved to become a tool for organizing campaigns and revolutions. politicians, including uk labour leader ed miliband and prime minister boris johnson, use twitter for self-promotion and to follow a mix of expected and surprising individuals. miliband follows reality tv star joey essex, while johnson gets updates from x factor judge nicole scherzinger. other politicians follow a range of people, including fellow politicians, celebrities, and comedians. for example, boris johnson follows comedian ricky gervais and x factor judge nicole scherzinger, while foreign secretary william hague keeps up with jimmy carr and victoria coren mitchell. labour deputy leader harriet harman follows speaker's wife sally bercow, and labour peer oona king follows one-time tv star keith chegwin. ukip leader nigel farage follows model imogen thomas and strictly come dancing's aliona vilani, while respect leader george galloway follows right said fred. lib dem treasury secretary danny alexander is a fan of geri halliwell, and deputy prime minister nick clegg follows blue singer duncan james, leading the way with nearly 28,500 followers.
1431	conor mcgregor, an irish featherweight in the ultimate fighting championship (ufc), downplayed concerns about a scratch on his nose amidst preparations for his fight against dennis siver on january 18, 2015. he insisted it was just a minor graze from a velcro strap during training, claiming the cold weather had made it seem worse. mcgregor was reacting to comments from a dublin senator who labeled mixed martial arts "vile" and called for it not to be licensed, but he said it was an educational process for some to learn about the safety in the sport. mcgregor is looking forward to possibly earning a world title shot against champion jose aldo, with hopes of having the fight take place in front of 80,000 fans at croke park later in the year.
1432	tensions have emerged between the legal team of accused murderer gable tostee and police investigators over delays in gathering evidence in the case of warriena wright's death. tostee's new lawyers, robertson o'gorman solicitors, expressed concern over police delays and sought an adjournment in southport magistrate's court. only limited evidence, including the preliminary autopsy report, mobile phone records, witness statements, and photographs, is available. magistrate kerry magee remanded tostee, who has been in custody since august 15, until january 12. the court also heard that tostee is facing four other charges related to drunken incidents and a car pursuit. new zealand tourist warriena wright met tostee on tinder before allegedly falling to her death from his high-rise apartment on august 8. the court previously rejected tostee's bail application due to allegedly prejudicial evidence, including transcripts of an alleged tape recording of wright's final hour and a half in tostee's company. the recording reportedly includes sounds consistent with wright being held down and her airway restricted, as well as tostee making aggressive statements and the pair engaging in heavy drinking and a violent argument. tostee maintains his innocence.
1433	a five-month-old baby died tragically at alicante-elche airport in spain after his mother lost her grip and he fell onto a baggage carousel. the incident occurred when the mother, a 32-year-old american tourist who had just arrived from gatwick with her canadian husband and two children, allegedly climbed onto the conveyor belt to retrieve a pushchair that had become stuck in a chute. the luggage belt, meant for larger items, started moving, and the mother dropped the baby carrier. witnesses reported hearing the mother's screams and saw the baby being trapped in a 10cm hole where two belts converge. emergency services attempted to save the child but were unable to revive him. police questioned the parents and are investigating the incident, with the results of the autopsy not expected for two weeks. the family were reportedly staying in the nearby resort town of denia. easyjet, the budget airline the family flew with, and the british red cross have provided support to the grieving family. the circumstances of the accident remain unclear, with some sources suggesting that the baby carrier's weight triggered the belt, while others claim the mother intended to activate it manually. the airport management company, aena, stressed that the baggage belt is explicitly for larger items and should not be used for passengers or their belongings. spain's sixth busiest airport, alicante-elche, is a popular destination for british tourists.
1434	florence, known as the birthplace of the renaissance in italy, is a culturally rich city in tuscany famous for its art and architecture legacies left by masters such as leonardo da vinci, giotto, michelangelo, dante, and brunelleschi. with a high concentration of unesco world heritage sites, the city attractions include the iconic duomo with its teracotta-and-white dome and giotto's campanile, the uffizi gallery with its extensive collection of renaissance art, and michelangelo's statue of david, among other notable landmarks. visitors can also explore museums dedicated to leonardo da vinci, palazzo vecchio, and the bargello national museum. for relaxation, the pitti palace and boboli gardens offer tranquility overlooking the city. florence is also home to several fashion brands like gucci, prada, and armani, along with designer outlets. for something offbeat, the museo la specola showcases wax models of corpses, stuffed animals, and other oddities. the city is a must-visit for art lovers and cultural enthusiasts, but be aware that the high number of tourist attractions can be overwhelming.
1435	a leaked document from a korean financial services firm suggests that samsung's upcoming galaxy s4 smartphone could feature a 5-inch 1920x1080 display, quad-core processor, 2gb of ram, and run android jelly bean. the phone is rumored to be released as soon as march, and could also include an eight-core qualcomm processor, a 2mp front-facing camera, and a 13mp rear-facing camera capable of shooting hd video in 1080p at 30 frames per second. samsung is also reportedly working on a "galaxy watch" or fitness device as part of a secret project. production for the galaxy s4 is expected to begin in march for an expected april release date. the design of the phone, which includes a nearly button-less design, has been dismissed as a fake in the past. apple, samsung's arch-rival, is also reportedly working on new versions of the iphone, including a cheaper plastic-bodied model, and ceo tim cook has hinted at making apple products more affordable.
1436	a retiree named george wall from shrewsbury, shropshire, was surprised to discover two tomatoes in the shape of rubber ducks in his greenhouse. the unusual produce, which resembled little red and yellow ducks, made him a local celebrity, drawing numerous visitors from his neighborhood. george and his wife mary kept the tomatoes hidden to prevent george from eating them before they were fully ripe. they have since stored the tomatoes in their fridge, although they are beginning to spoil. the couple expressed their amazement over the peculiar occurrence, as they had never grown anything like them before. in 2008, there were similar reports of people finding strange-shaped tomatoes and vegetables in their gardens. john owen from staffordshire grew a duck-shaped tomato with added eyes, while patricia bragg from essex found a courgette that looked like beatrix potter's jemima puddleduck.
1437	police in roseville, michigan, conducted a search for missing labor figure jimmy hoffa on friday, but found no discernible remains. two soil samples from beneath a storage shed were taken for further testing at michigan state university. the tip leading to the search came from a former gambler who feared for his safety and believed he had witnessed a body being buried at the site the day after hoffa disappeared in 1975. despite the tip and the alleged ties to organized crime figures, it is doubted that any remains found would be those of hoffa. police described the soil samples as murky and will continue investigating, with possible further excavation if human remains are identified in the lab tests. the mysterious disappearance of hoffa, a one-time powerful union leader, has confounded investigators for nearly four decades. he went missing in 1975 amidst rumors of a feud with union officials and organized crime figures over union pension funds. numerous theories about his disappearance and possible locations of his body have emerged over the years, but there is still no definitive answer.
1438	the ongoing ebola outbreak in west africa, mainly in guinea, sierra leone, and liberia, has surpassed previous records with over 330 reported deaths. doctors and health organizations are urging for more health experts and increased public education messages to combat the disease, as it continues to spread and overwhelm the current response efforts. the outbreak, which began late last year or early this year, has been described as "totally out of control" by senior medics and a "second wave" by doctors without borders. the challenges include the disease's movement across borders and its impact on fragile public health systems in the affected countries. international organizations and governments are struggling to contain the outbreak, with some officials criticizing the world health organization for not doing enough. the world health organization did not respond to requests for comment.
1439	travelers across the us faced minimal issues during the pre-thanksgiving rush on wednesday, despite slightly increased passenger numbers and declining air travel, according to the american automobile association (aaa). new jersey's newark international airport and o'hare international airport in chicago reported some delays, but overall, the federal aviation administration (faa) reported few incidents. approximately 38.4 million people are expected to travel during the holiday, a slight increase from last year, with 33.2 million choosing to drive. some roads experienced heavy traffic, and accidents caused closure of parts of interstate 35 in oklahoma and the golden gate bridge in california. around 2.9 million people will travel by train, watercraft, or bus, and 2.3 million will fly. while some, like jack demanche, braved the drive and traffic on wednesday, others, like heather mckinnon, chose to stay home.
1440	hurricane gordon passed over the eastern azores in the north atlantic on monday, bringing dangerous surge and rip current conditions. the hurricane's center was expected to pass between santa maria island and san miguel island. as of monday morning, gordon was moving east-northeast at about 20 mph (32 kph) with maximum sustained winds of 75 mph (120 kph). the storm was forecasted to weaken into a tropical depression after leaving the azores, which are roughly 950 miles (1,529 kilometers) west of lisbon, portugal.
1441	patrick "salvado" idringi, a comedian from uganda, gained a significant following with his unique blend of humor and charisma, both in uganda and abroad. despite an unconventional career path, having spent years working as a switch engineer for a telecom company, salvado discovered his comedic talents when he entered a comedy competition at the encouragement of his sisters and finished second. realizing he could make a living from his funnyman persona, he left his job in 2011, but the transition was challenging. salvado faced tough financial situations, and the initial months were particularly difficult. however, he remained persistent and attributed his success to his openness to discuss taboo topics like sex, love, and death. comedy allowed him to discover untapped talents and has significantly impacted his life.
1442	a large family was killed in the pakistani tribal region of tirah valley when an artillery shell stored in their home exploded. the valley, located along the afghan border and a former stronghold for islamic militants, has seen similar incidents before due to villagers keeping unexploded munitions in their homes. the volatile region is still seen as a potential flashpoint in pakistan's relations with neighbors india, and there is ongoing debate over the role of the military in dealing with internal security threats in disputed territories like kashmir.
1443	a wisconsin billionaire, curt johnson iii, whose family has run home-products giant sc johnson for five generations, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of having sexual contact with a teenage girl. johnson, 59, was convicted of fourth-degree sexual assault and disorderly conduct and sentenced to four months in jail and fined $6,000, short of the one-year maximum. he apologized to the victim and her mother in court. the case had been delayed due to a request by johnson's defense team to access the victim's therapy records, which were denied, making it unlikely for them to secure a conviction. johnson is estimated to be worth about $3 billion and was not affiliated with the sc johnson company at the time of the incident, having left the company in 2010. he resigned as chairman of the subsidiary diversified, which was later bought by sealed air in 2011. the incident resulted from johnson's statements to his own therapist, who was required by law to report potential child abuse to authorities.
1444	a two-year-old english bulldog named hugo has formed an unusual bond with two young cubs, a white lion named igor and a white bengal tiger named ice, whom he has adopted as his own pups. the cubs, who are being hand-reared by their owner, or lazmi, a former vet assistant, live together with hugo in port elizabeth, south africa. igor and ice, who weigh around two-and-a-half stone each, are rapidly growing and will eventually weigh over 28 stone and almost 40 stone, respectively. hugo, who can currently still bully them around, plays and interacts with the cubs regularly, even disciplining them when necessary. the three animals go on family outings to walk and swim together, and the cubs spend their days at seaview predator park before returning to live with hugo and or lazmi in the evenings. their relationship will be closely monitored to ensure that the cubs do not see hugo as prey, as they will need to interact with park vets when they grow up.
1445	u.s. rep. allen west, a florida republican, made controversial comments during a town hall meeting when he suggested that there are around 78 to 81 communist members in the democratic party in congress. these accusations drew little criticism from fellow republicans, and west even raised funds off the comment. the number was likely based on the congressional progressive caucus, a liberal organization. the comparison of liberal democrats to communists is inappropriate as communists have caused millions of deaths throughout the 20th century. this type of rhetoric, equating political ideologies, is a worrying sign of the polarized political climate, with extreme statements being employed for fundraising purposes. the text emphasizes the growing polarization in american politics, in which ideas to the left of center are often demonized as extreme, while members of one party are compared to dangerous ideologies like communism or fascism. this leads to a distorted perspective and a cycle of incitement. the author calls for condemnation of extreme comments from both sides of the political spectrum to prevent further polarization. the comparison of allen west to joe mccarthy is made, yet west's remarks are seen as less extreme and not as powerful as mccarthy's witch hunts. however, the increasingly divisive rhetoric in american politics is a serious concern and requires attention.
1446	jim murphy, the frontrunner to be the new labor leader in scotland, has announced his support for full devolution of income tax to edinburgh, including a proposed 50p top rate for the wealthiest scots. this move comes despite objections from senior labor figures, who fear it could undermine the integrity of the uk and potentially bar scottish mps from voting on uk tax affairs in the future. the smith commission, tasked with recommending additional powers for the scottish parliament following scotland's rejected independence referendum, is expected to propose devolving more control over income tax. the labor party has previously advocated for control over 75% of the basic rate of income tax in scotland, but murphy's announcement could lead to major constitutional and economic implications for the entire uk.
1447	the deepwater horizon disaster of april 20, 2010 resulted in the loss of 11 lives and the trauma of many survivors, including doug brown and dan barron. both men have been diagnosed with ptsd, depression, and other mental health issues from the horrors they experienced on the rig. their wives, meccah brown and amanda barron, have seen their husbands' lives changed forever, with near-constant anxiety, frustration, anger, and depression affecting their families. dan barron, who witnessed a friend's death in the second explosion, even attempted suicide. both families are suing transocean for pain and suffering and loss of wages. the wives say their children, particularly the older ones, are being affected by the fallout from the disaster. the barrons' 15-year-old son's academic performance has dropped, while meccah brown's 11-year-old daughter kirah seems to be unaware of the changes in her father. transocean has stopped paying both men, but they still receive some health benefits.
1448	meat from british horses was sold as beef in schools and fast food outlets across the country, including in caerphilly, wales. the award-winning burger manufacturing company, bmc, purchased the suspect meat from farmbox meats in wales, which was raided two weeks ago by the police and the food standards agency (fsa). the meat came from an abattoir operated by peter boddy in west yorkshire, and owners dafydd raw-reese and colin patterson, along with boddy, have been arrested and questioned. tests carried out by powys county council found horsemeat in three burger samples taken from bmc's factory, with the level ranging between 1% and 100%. bmc supplies burgers to hundreds of fast food outlets, cafes, restaurants, hotels, and leisure outlets, and had a contract with holdsworth to supply burgers to 43 primary and secondary schools in caerphilly. bmc prides itself on using the finest cuts of uk and irish farm-assured beef and claims to have taken manufacturing burgers to a "craft level." the fsa is still conducting further tests to determine the exact amount of horsemeat and the presence of veterinary medicine in the products. bmc has withdrawn the affected products and contacted its customers to inform them of the test results. bmc bought meat from farmbox because they wanted to support a local business.
1449	barcelona have criticized cesc fabregas for not scoring enough goals during his three-year stint with the club, despite his impressive tally of 42 goals in 151 matches. the midfielder, who recently joined chelsea in a £30million deal, experienced a "downward trend" in his statistics each season and "was never as good in the second half of a season as in the first." barcelona's statement on their website also noted that fabregas primarily played in the "false center forward" role, suggesting his goal-scoring contributions were a result of this positioning. fabregas' former spain teammate xavi acknowledged his friend's departure from barca but remained optimistic, adding that spain will continue to play their signature passing style at the world cup, come what may.
1450	a growing number of stores are selling "zombie bullets" manufactured by hornady, a company that was inspired by the cultural phenomenon of zombies and the walking dead series. the bullets, called z-max, are live ammunition intended for target practice only. simultaneously, there have been reports of cannibal attacks in the us, with suspects allegedly under the influence of a drug called "cloud nine." this drug, which is marketed as bath salts, is a synthetic stimulant that can cause violent and erratic behavior, hallucinations, and a strong compulsion to take more of the drug. the attacks include rudy eugene, who ate most of a homeless man's face, and brandon de león, who threatened to eat two officers in miami and bit an officer's hand during custody. another attacker, carl jacquneaux, allegedly bit off a chunk of todd credeur's face during a domestic dispute in louisiana. the police have issued a warning regarding the dangers of cloud nine and urged officers to exercise caution when dealing with suspicious individuals, pointing out that it resembles the incidents in miami and in a separate case involving canadian man luka rocco magnotta, who is accused of killing and dismembering his partner before posting body parts to authorities.
1451	a judge, nigel peters qc, who described a 13-year-old victim of child sexual abuse as a "predator" and allowed a paedophile, neil wilson, to walk free with a suspended sentence last week, was forced to alter the sentence due to a technicality but did not apology or jail him. investigations are ongoing as to whether the sentence is too lenient. the prosecution barrister, robert colover, who described the victim as "predatory" and "sexually experienced" during the trial, has been suspended from prosecuting sexual offence cases. colover's comments were condemned by child protection campaigners and former prime minister david cameron, who urged the courts to "stand up for victims." wilson, who admitted possessing extreme pornographic images and one count of sexual activity with a child, was given a 12-month suspended sentence, with consecutive terms for the image charges. the prosecution and judges' comments about the victim sparked outrage and investigations from the attorney general's office, charity victim support, and the bar standards board.
1452	windy hill, 38, described feeling like her heart was in a vise grip and being "punched in the chest" after giving birth six months earlier. despite no clear heart issues being detected, she experienced a sudden loss of color and reported the sensation again, leading to a heart attack. doctors believed her history of high blood pressure caused her left heart hemisphere to tear, resulting in a large portion of her heart dying. windy was offered a temporary heart pump while waiting for a transplant but received a surprise call during surgery that a matching donor heart had been found against all odds. the transplant was successful, and hill was grateful for the organ donor, allowing her to be with her newborn daughter and making up for lost time.
1453	a small group of people rallied outside the japanese embassy in washington d.c. on saturday to support american man christopher savoie, who is currently jailed in japan after being accused of trying to kidnap his own children. savoie, a tennessee native and naturalized japanese citizen, allegedly took his two children, aged 8 and 6, when they were being walked to school by their mother in rural japan in august. he attempted to obtain passports for them at the u.s. consulate in fukuoka but was arrested by japanese police before he could enter the consulate compound. savoie's wife, amy, along with members of the children's rights council of japan, called for his release during the demonstration. the couple, who were married for 14 years and had joint custody of the children, are currently going through a complicated custody battle because they are still considered married in japan due to their lack of divorce. japanese law follows a tradition of sole-custody divorces and does not recognize the u.s. court's decision of granting savoie sole custody. the case is further complicated by the fact that the children have japanese passports and japan is not a party to the 1980 hague convention on international child abduction. savoie is currently jailed for at least 10 days while japanese prosecutors investigate the case. savoie's wife amy expressed her hope for her husband's release and her desire to be able to speak with him.
1454	chelsea new signing cesc fabregas, who was acquired from barcelona for £27 million before the world cup, is set to join the team immediately and fit in seamlessly due to his previous experience of living and playing in england. fabregas, who was told he was not needed by arsenal manager arsene wenger before leaving for barcelona, will be a "perfect fit" for chelsea, according to manager jose mourinho, who has been in africa as a un world food programme ambassador instead of watching the world cup. mourinho and fabregas have a history of opposition, due to their time with real madrid and barcelona, respectively. fabregas and the spanish team have had a disappointing world cup, already being knocked out.
1455	new york city's luxury "billionaire building," one57, located at 157 w. 57th street in midtown manhattan, is experiencing high demand for its apartments despite the recent housing crisis. with only about 40 units remaining out of the 92 living spaces, the buyers are primarily wealthy individuals paying millions of dollars for sleek, modern apartments with high-end finishes and top-of-the-line appliances. the identities of some buyers, including significant forbes billionaires and celebrities like denzel washington and sting, have been kept under wraps. the building, which is expected to be completed next year, is the tallest residential building in the city and will offer unparalleled views of central park. the interior features include gourmet kitchens, two refrigerators, and even televisions in the bathroom. one penthouse suite was sold for over $90 million, and the building's prime location and exclusivity make it an attractive investment for foreign buyers due to economic uncertainty abroad. despite concerns about design flaws and potential impacts on nearby buildings, high-rolling buyers are investing significantly in real estate at one57.
1456	a tape from 2007 has emerged where president barack obama made controversial remarks about the government response to hurricane katrina in new orleans, implying that the people there were not prioritized due to a lack of care. the speech was filmed at hampton university and previously aired, but an unedited version with obama's ad-lib remarks about new orleans was recently released. critics claim obama was trying to incite fear and hatred, while supporters said it's an old issue being brought up to deflect attention from mitt romney before the presidential debate. the speech contained a shout-out to controversial pastor jeremiah wright, who was also in attendance. the tape caused a divide between right-wing and liberal media, with some criticizing obama's remarks as racially-charged and others dismissing it as old news. the stafford disaster relief and emergency assistance act, which coordinates the federal response to natural disasters, was criticized for its bureaucracy and delay in relief efforts during katrina. obama made these comments a year before wright's infamous 'god damn america' remarks surfaced during the 2008 campaign. romney has also been the subject of a secretly-recorded tape where he spoke disparagingly about 47% of americans who depend on government. both campaigns have stepped back from the campaign trail as they prepare for their first debate on wednesday night.
1457	in mosul, northern iraq, at least 16 people, including 10 al-qaeda-linked islamic state in iraq and syria militants and three police officers, were killed on wednesday in armed confrontations and roadside bomb explosions. iraqi army and federal police conducted a security operation in southern mosul, detaining 16 militants. the violence comes as iraq endures increased fears of sectarian war, with 8,000 civilians killed in violence during 2013. mosul, about 400 kilometers north of baghdad, has seen ongoing clashes and is the capital of nineveh province, where iraq's security forces have been battling for control against al-qaeda-backed militants. cnn's jason hanna contributed to the report.
1458	fans of the "fifty shades of grey" novel are expressing their disapproval of the casting choices for the upcoming film adaptation, with charlie hunnam as christian grey and dakota johnson as anastasia steele, and are pushing for matt bomer and alexis bledel to be recast instead. a change.org petition has been created to support this cause. the casting decisions have sparked strong reactions on social media, with some fans being serious and others joking about the issue, as seen with the controversy surrounding ben affleck's casting as batman.
1459	an elderly man, ronald buckley, 93, of geelong, was sentenced to three months in prison for indecently assaulting disadvantaged and disabled boys at the hillside boys home in melbourne during the 1960s. prosecutors requested leniency due to buckley's advanced age and prison vulnerability, but judge mark dean deemed jail the only appropriate response for preying on vulnerable children to satisfy his sexual desires. buckley, who ran the orphanage for 26 years, targeted boys with behavioural issues, mental and physical illnesses, and intellectual disabilities, leaving four victims with complex depressive illnesses, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation. buckley showed no remorse, leading to an initial sentence of 18 months; however, 15 months were suspended. resources for mental health support are available by calling lifeline at 13 11 14.
1460	a man identified only as andy slipped and became trapped between a train and the platform at a perth railway station on wednesday. dozens of commuters and staff helped free him by pushing the 90-tonne train to create enough space. andy, who was on his way to work, was unharmed but amazed by the rescue effort when he saw footage on the news later. quick thinking and teamwork allowed the man to be freed in about 10 minutes without serious injury. transperth spokesman david hynes spoke highly of the crew and passengers involved, praising their actions and calling it "people power" that saved the day.
1461	hundreds of patients and staff were evacuated from bellevue hospital in manhattan on wednesday due to a prolonged power outage caused by hurricane sandy. the public hospital, which had lost power on monday and was running on generators, faced chaotic conditions as members of the army national guard brought fuel to power the generators and medical staff carried infants down the stairs and carried patients out on gurneys. the rescue effort, which included 150 national guard members, saw the most critical patients being transferred to nearby medical centers while others were discharged. bellevue, located near the east river on 1st avenue and 27th street, is the second manhattan hospital to evacuate patients following hurricane sandy, with nyu's langone medical center also having to move patients due to failed backup generators. millions of gallons of water had flooded into the basement of bellevue hospital.
1462	mary saba, a 27-year-old woman from sydney, australia, undertook a year-long challenge to wear a different fancy dress outfit every day for her 26th birthday. she spent only $400 on costumes and made many of them herself, often with the help of friends and family. mary wore various costumes to her office job and on public transport, including mermaid, oompa loompa, and mad scientist. she planned the costumes and themes a month in advance and celebrated her 27th birthday with a costume party. mary's collection included costumes based on singers, characters, and famous blondes, and she also wore elaborate hair and make-up in creating a new look each day. after completing her challenge, she celebrated with a party where she made her friends and family dress up in the costumes. some outfits required more creative flair, such as wearing a king kong costume to her nan's house.
1463	chris tarrant, the former "who wants to be a millionaire" presenter, was rushed to charing cross hospital in london after experiencing an asthma attack on a flight from bangkok. tarrant, who is 67, had told cabin crew aboard the flight that he required an ambulance upon arriving at heathrow. his manager, paul vaughan, spoke with tarrant in the hospital and reported that he sounded tired. vaughan believed that the asthma attack might have been triggered by a night-time stopover in bangkok, which has poor air quality. an ambulance from the london ambulance service transported tarrant from the tarmac at heathrow to the hospital. tarrant had been in burma filming a new channel 5 travel series prior to the incident.
1464	a survey conducted by online art retailer artfinder revealed that a significant number of young people in the uk lack basic knowledge about art and artists. three in ten 16-24-year-olds did not recognize pierre-august renoir as a painter, while some mistakenly believed he was a football player, prime minister, or eurovision song contest winner. additionally, some young people thought "impressionism" was a comedy sketch and "al dente" was an art term. the study also found that britons generally prefer buying mass-produced prints over original art pieces. the research identified bristol as britain's artest city, as almost half of its residents owned authentic art, while belfast had the least art ownership with only 19%. artfinder's ceo, jonas almgren, emphasized that one doesn't need extensive art knowledge to enjoy fine art.
1465	a nine-year-old boy named jermaine colver from staten island, new york was walking to school when he was suddenly stalked, grabbed, and stabbed in the neck by an unidentified man. the attack occurred around 7:55am on a snow-covered street in the mariners harbor neighborhood. surveillance footage shows the man approaching from behind, grabbing jermaine, and swinging a bladed weapon three times around his head and upper body. jermaine managed to flee from the scene, but the attacker did not follow him. jermaine described the attacker to police as an old man wearing a blue hoodie. he was taken to richmond university medical center with non-life-threatening wounds, including a graze to the shoulder. his family is hoping he will be able to go home the following day.
1466	in early 1982, british diplomats considered the possibility of allowing argentina a naval base on the falkland islands just two weeks before the invasion, according to newly declassified documents. chilean diplomat raul schmidt revealed argentina's desperation for a secure southern port as the cause of their sovereignty disputes with both chile and the uk. the british were open to the idea of negotiations for an argentine naval base on the falklands, suggesting handwritten notes in a march 1982 report titled "a common burden with chile?" however, the war between argentina and the uk broke out on march 15, 1982, and the possibility of a naval base agreement was never pursued further. argentina had long disputed chilean sovereignty over the beagle channel islands but eventually recognized their ownership in 1984 following papal mediation.
1467	natasha richardson, a british-american film and stage actress and member of the redgrave acting family, died on wednesday at the age of 45 following a skiing accident in quebec, canada. she had fallen during a beginners' lesson and was taken to hospitals in montreal and new york city before passing away. richardson's acting career included roles in films such as "gothic" and "patty hearst," as well as notable stage performances, including a tony-winning role in "cabaret" opposite her mother, vanessa redgrave. she is survived by her husband, liam neeson, and their two sons. friends and colleagues paid tribute to richardson's talent and warmth, and her family released a statement asking for privacy during this difficult time. richardson's first film role was in her father's "the charge of the light brigade," and she went on to break through in the industry with her performance as mary shelley in "gothic." despite the challenges of growing up in a famous acting family and the pressure that came with it, richardson continued to excel in her craft. her family has requested privacy during this time.
1468	chelsea advanced to the fifa club world cup final with a 3-1 win over monterrey, setting up a match against corinthians. goals from juan mata and fernando torres, along with an own goal from darvin chavez, secured chelsea's victory. monterrey scored a late consolation goal through jesús de nigris. rafael benitez coached chelsea to the final after succeeding roberto di matteo last month. benitez, who previously lost the final as liverpool manager in 2005 and won it with inter milan in 2010, is seeking to win over chelsea supporters following di matteo's departure. chelsea opened the scoring with a slick team move, and the second half saw additional goals from torres and an own goal from chavez. corinthians will be chelsea's opponent in the final after defeating al-ahly, who qualified despite football being suspended in egypt following a stadium disaster. monterrey will face al-ahly in the third-place playoff.
1469	a newly released isis video showcases jihadist propaganda and footage from a drone, providing a bird's-eye view of a syrian military base in northern syria that was attacked by the terror group on august 7. isis' use of a drone for military reconnaissance signifies the proliferation of advanced technology amongst terrorist organizations and militant groups, like hezbollah, hamas, and libyan opposition fighters. this trend highlights the urgency for international regulations governing the use of drones by non-state actors, preventing the transfer of sophisticated drone technology to terrorists and setting guidelines for their lawful deployment. currently, only three countries, the united states, united kingdom, and israel, have used armed drones in combat, but the new america foundation counts 80 countries with drone capabilities. nations with drone arsenals but no combat deployments include russia, china, and iran.
1470	lord ahmed, a labour peer, has been suspended from the party after allegedly blaming his prison sentence for dangerous driving on a jewish conspiracy. ahmed, who has represented the labour party since the late 1990s, claimed that jews who own newspapers and tv channels pressured the judiciary to sentence him due to his support for palestinians in gaza. the allegations stem from a pakistani television interview where ahmed made these comments in urdu. ahmed was sentenced to three months in jail for sending text messages while driving at high speeds, resulting in the death of a 28-year-old slovakian motorist, martyn gombar, in 2007. the labour party leader, ed miliband, has initiated an investigation into ahmed's remarks, which are considered extremely anti-semitic and could potentially incite racial hatred. these comments have received strong condemnation from organizations such as the community security trust and the jewish chronicle. ahmed has a history of controversial statements and was previously suspended from the party following allegations that he offered a $10 million bounty for the capture of former us presidents george w. bush and barack obama. he was reinstated after an investigation found the comments attributing the bounty offer to him were misquoted.
1471	six months after a go-kart accident at whiteland raceway park in indianapolis left her with severe injuries and the loss of more than half her scalp, shelbi crouch is undergoing numerous painful surgeries and treatments to repair her damaged skin. the 20-year-old had beautiful long, strawberry blonde hair before the accident, which caught in the go-kart's axle and was essentially ripped off. crouch suffered a skull fracture, traumatic brain injury, broken temporal bones, and paralysis on her face. her mother, sherri crouch-wilson, shared that the most challenging aspect for her daughter is coming to terms with her identity without her own hair. crouch, who was famous for her long, curly locks and was voted "best hair" in her high school class, now wears hats and scarves to hide her healings and often faces questions about undergoing chemotherapy. she has already undergone several surgeries and skin grafts and anticipates more in the future. the accident occurred when crouch's hair got caught in one of the go-kart's axles.
1472	boko haram, a terrorist group based in nigeria, has reached a new low with the use of schoolgirls as suicide bombers. over the weekend, at least 43 people were killed and over 70 were injured in three separate bombings in maiduguri and potiskum, with girls as young as 10 being used as suicide bombers. this comes after amnesty international reported that boko haram caused the "largest and most destructive" assault in their organization's history with indiscriminate massacres in the towns of baga and doron baga, resulting in thousands of homes, schools, churches and shops being destroyed and over 150 deaths. the group has also abducted 40 boys and young men earlier in the year and has a history of invading villages and killing civilians of all ages. the international community is urged to increase efforts to pursue and surveillance of boko haram and coordinate action against their cross-border incursions. in response to previous attacks, a safe schools initiative was launched to improve security around schools and make them a haven free from terrorist attacks. $23 million has been raised so far, and more support is needed from the international community to help protect children's right to education free from fear and intimidation.
1473	a former labour mp, stephen timms, has voiced concerns over the violent effects of high-stakes casino-style gambling machines (fobts) in betting shops, warning that it can lead to brawls and anti-social behaviour on the high street. he testified at thames magistrates’ court where paddy power is contesting a newham council decision to deny a license for a new shop due to the shop's association with violent crime, underage gambling, and street drinking. timms claimed that angry users, who have become addicted to the fobts, often damage the machines and take their frustrations out on the high street. he also criticized the labour government for underestimating the addictive potential of the technology in the 2005 gambling act. despite his past role in supporting the act, timms stated that the industry's sense of responsibility has been lost since the introduction of these machines. the newham council, aiming to make the licensing decision a precedent, employed a private investigator to gather evidence from betting shops in the borough, revealing that 82% of customers use fobts, but the judge declined to consider this evidence, instead focusing on their profitability for any betting shop.
1474	ohio, known as the "buckeye state," is a heavily contested battleground state in the 2012 election with 18 electoral votes up for grabs. with a population of 11.5 million, ohio is home to famous personalities like katie holmes, halle berry, and lebron james, as well as historical sites like the rock and roll hall of fame and the wright brothers national museum. ohioans have a median income of $46,752 and median home price of $136,900. the state is politically significant, with 7.7 million registered voters and a history of influencing presidential elections. in the latest poll, president obama leads challenger mitt romney 50%-44% with strong support from 60% of ohioans. ohio also has a higher percentage of blue-collar workers and union members than the national average. the economy in ohio is important to both campaigns, with major employers including wal-mart, general motors, and ford. unemployment in ohio is at 7.2%, but over 2 million residents live in poverty and 1.8 million are uninsured. both candidates have visited ohio multiple times, and the state has a rich political history, with no republican president elected without winning ohio and 8 presidents hailing from the state. ohio is also known for its sports teams, having won 7 world series titles and counting.
1475	a dundee plumber, mark topen, also known as "toby," became an overnight sensation when a co-worker filmed him dancing enthusiastically to a robert miles song during a job, instead of working. initially embarrassed, mark soon embraced his newfound fame and acknowledged it was a way to relieve stress on the job. the amusing video went viral, leaving mark surprised and delighted by the outpouring of support and recognition from the community. since then, he has received numerous messages, and even been stopped for autographs in public places. mark, who has a known for having a playful character, admitted that while he wouldn't normally dance on the job, the empty house made it an appropriate moment for some entertainment.
1476	australians are bracing for an early and devastating bushfire season, with half the country considered to be at above average risk. two years of persistent droughts in eastern states, coupled with predicted hot weather for spring and summer, have increased the bushfire threat in new south wales (nsw), victoria, queensland, south australia, and large parts of western australia. the bushfire and natural hazards co-operative research centre published a study revealing the regions at 'above normal' risk, with the eastern seaboard and western australia being the most affected. in nsw and victoria, above-normal temperatures and lack of rainfall indicate a slightly more active bushfire season than the one experienced in 2013-14. high-fire danger zones have been declared in nsw's coastal tablelands and central slopes, while victoria's central wimmera and mallee regions face significant risk. densely populated areas with dry forests are most at risk, as rainfall deficits over an extended period have increased potential for fire. it is recommended that australians prepare early for the bushfire season, including physical preparation and having fire plans in place.
1477	a 62-year-old man, patrick smith, from texas, has been charged with bigamy after his second wife, janet mills maun, called his first wife, toni marie zimmerman, from his cellphone in 2012. zimmerman, who had legally separated from smith in 2006 and believed in not getting divorced due to her catholic faith, claimed she reported him to authorities because she thought bigamy was a crime. however, smith's attorney, john venza jr., argued that zimmerman was motivated by "greed" as she received part of smith's retirement benefits in the divorce settlement from maun when their marriage ended in 2013. smith, who married maun in 2009, could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted, but his attorney hopes the case will be dismissed due to his belief that he "reasonably believed" he was divorced. the indictment against smith was handed up by a fort bend grand jury on february 10, 2014.
1478	the 2012 paralympics came to a close last night with 2.7 million tickets sold and increased global interest, according to media commentators. the games received positive reviews, with many highlighting the inspiring performances and achievements of the athletes. sir philip craven declared them the greatest paralympics ever, and the washington post hailed the closing ceremony as a "three-hour party" that "wrapped up an unforgettable summer of sports" in britain. china's xinhua news agency also praised london for pushing the paralympics to new heights and increasing understanding of disability. germany's der tagesspiegel and bahrain's gulf daily news were among several publications that expressed their admiration for the games. canada's vancouver sun reflected on the country's poor performance, but still expressed appreciation for the "stunning performances of disabled athletes" and the "mind-expanding, soul-lightening, spirit-igniting summer" of sports. overall, the paralympics received widespread praise for their successful execution and the inspiring stories of the athletes.
1479	an outspoken conservative mp, mark pitchford, aged 48, was arrested on suspicion of rape in london and released on bail. the allegation, which took place earlier this year, was made to scotland yard and the mp was interrogated for four hours. pitchford is a prominent eurosceptic mp and former secretary of the 1922 committee of conservative backbenchers. he had a public falling out with commons speaker john bercow in 2010 and was involved in a bitter divorce battle with his american-born wife in 2013. the arrest was made public through an order paper in the house of commons. pitchford has been a colourful figure in parliament since his election in 2005 and has had several high-profile clashes with colleagues and journalists. he has denied editing his wikipedia page during the 2013 divorce dispute.
1480	spencer pratt and heidi montag, famous for their controversial behavior on mtv's "the hills," admitted they faked their villainous personas on celebrity big brother uk to entertain and secure their place in the show. during their last night in the house, they cried and made sympathetic speeches, but some housemates were skeptical and believed they were only doing it for votes. rylan clark won the competition, leaving pratt and montag in second place. the american couple, who had a history of causing drama, insisted their tears were real and that they didn't come to make friends, but to be entertaining and win the competition. the final three contestants consisted of one british and two american stars.
1481	two bombs exploded in baghdad, iraq, killing at least 22 people and injuring 55 just hours before the city's curfew was due to be lifted. the deadliest attack occurred in the predominantly shi'ite neighborhood of new baghdad, where a suicide bomber detonated inside a restaurant killing at least 12 people and injuring 30. shortly afterwards, two more bombs exploded at the sharqa market district, killing 10 more people. neither attack has been claimed by any specific group, but suicide bombings are commonly used by armed groups such as isis and the levant. the curfew, which has been in place since the us-led invasion in 2003, restricts citizens between midnight and 5am. baghdad has been relatively calm in recent years compared to the height of sectarian violence in 2006 and 2007, but recent bombings have primarily targeted shiite-majority areas in the capital. officials continue to assure the public that the city is secure despite occasional attacks.
1482	previously unseen photographs of the british rock band the who performing at a small gig in surrey, england in december 1966 have emerged. the 14 black and white snaps, taken by concert promoter danny parker, show the band members, including pete townshend performing his iconic "windmill" arm technique, roger daltrey singing, and keith moon on drums. the candid photos were taken before the who became superstars. the pictures, which are expected to fetch around £1,000 at auction, offer a rare "behind-the-scenes" look and will appeal to rock and roll memorabilia collectors, fans of the who, and dealers. the photographs will be auctioned on november 15, 2012, at catherine southon auctioneers in surrey.
1483	graham norton earned £2.61million from the bbc last year for hosting "the graham norton show" and his radio programme. this information was revealed amidst the bbc's cost-cutting campaign aimed at saving around three percent by reducing fees paid to top entertainers. norton is one of 14 top bbc talents who received between £500,000 and £5million a year. financial records show that his production company, so television, had increased profits of £2.31million and revenues of £13.59million. norton, who split from his partner trevor patterson, has been known for his obsession with his pets, going as far as chartering a private jet for them. the bbc declined to comment on individual salaries but has saved almost £3m on talent pay in the past year and £30m since 2008. patterson previously revealed norton's heavy drinking habits, including consuming up to four bottles of wine a night.
