1484	the bird flu crisis in china continued to grow with two new fatalities reported in anhui and jiangsu provinces, raising the death toll to nine. the h7n9 virus, which has been found in pigeons but not previously in humans, has caused over 28 confirmed infections, with five of those occurring in shanghai. the chinese government has culled over 100,000 live birds and suspended trading in several cities in an attempt to contain the outbreak. the world health organization (who) and chinese health officials have stated that there is currently no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission. vice premier liu yandong urged for more transparency in information about the virus and earlier detection of new infections. china has been criticized for its handling of information during past outbreaks, such as the sars epidemic in 2003.
1485	manchester city under-19s, led by development coach patrick vieira, finished the uefa youth league group stage with a perfect record after a late flurry of goals, netting four times in the final 20 minutes in italy. city's youngsters, who were kept in the match by goalkeeper angus gunn, progressed to the knockout stages with six wins from six. brandon barker scored the fourth goal in the remarkable comeback, with bersant celina, jack byrne, and thierry ambrose also adding to the tally. gunn made several key saves in the first half to keep city in the game. city subsequently advanced to the champions league round of 16 with a 2-0 win at as roma.
1486	a london court heard an apologetic statement from kwaku adoboli, the ubs bank trader accused of fraud in connection with a $2.3 billion unauthorized trading loss at the swiss banking giant. adoboli, who faced charges of fraud by abuse of position, false accounting, and a newly added charge from 2008 to 2010, did not enter a plea and was remanded in custody until october 20, 2021. adoboli's lawyer stated he "went to ubs himself" to report the unauthorized trades. ubs mentioned that no client positions were affected by the loss, but the incident could result in a potential loss for the bank in the third quarter of this year and may rank among the largest unauthorized trading losses for a bank. several regulatory bodies are investigating the case.
1487	a marcos mantis sports car worth around £150,000 was left with damaged bright yellow paintwork and covered in dirt and dust after being parked under scaffolding on london's mayfair exclusive street, next to roadworks. the british brand, founded in 1959 by jem marsh and frank costin, is known for its performance engine, a supercharged 4.6 litre v8. the name mantis signifies the insect's agile and powerful nature. the car was parked near the brown hart gardens, which had recently been reopened as a rooftop communal space. unfortunately, someone spilled white paint on the car while it was parked, causing significant damage.
1488	a weight loss expert, steve miller, known for presenting the tv show "fat families," has criticized homer simpson for contributing to britain's obesity crisis due to his love for donuts and beer, which according to miller, sends the wrong message about unhealthy eating leading to happiness. miller, who has worked with overweight families for eight years, has written to the simpsons creator, matt groening, urging him to put homer on a healthier eating plan to set a better example for viewers, particularly children. miller suggested homer follow his 80/20 eating plan, where one eats healthily 80% of the time and has indulgences the other 20%. miller emphasized the importance of promoting a healthy lifestyle and avoiding the notion that being fat and happy are synonymous, as it could lead to serious health issues like diabetes and cancer.
1489	nato and russia believe the syrian regime's defeat is imminent, with nato secretary-general anders fogh rasmussen urging the regime to stop violence and initiate peace talks. russian deputy foreign minister mikhail bogdanov also acknowledged the possibility of a rebel victory. the syrian opposition seized a military base near damascus and called for a decisive push against the regime. diplomatic efforts to end the conflict, which has reportedly claimed over 42,000 lives, have failed. the use of scud missiles by the regime against rebels inside the country has been condemned by nato and the us. amnesty international urged rebel leaders to respect human rights as fighting subsides, and the friends of syria group pledged $110 million in humanitarian aid. rebels have made significant advances, capturing major military facilities, but face complications in governing and providing aid to the shattered country. state department spokeswoman victoria nuland urged russian officials to withdraw support for the regime.
1490	prince charles, accompanied by his sons william and harry, attended the funeral of his close friend and long-time confidant, hugh van cutsem, at brentwood cathedral in essex on september 11, 2013. the prince of wales, camilla, duchess of cornwall, and the brothers spent a few moments speaking with clergy before the service began. van cutsem, who passed away at the age of 72, had known charles for over 50 years and was an important figure not just to him, but also to his sons. the service was attended by around 700 people, including the duke and duchess of gloucester and camilla's former husband andrew parker bowles. the funeral mass lasted around 90 minutes and featured traditional hymns and readings from van cutsem's four sons. van cutsem and charles shared a passion for rural life, field sports, and conservation and were former cambridge university peers. the two families were close, with the van cutsems being neighbors of the royal family at sandringham and later at hilborough. the private catholic mass was expected to last three hours.
1491	the guardian accused the sunday tabloid of giving false hope to milly dowler's parents by hacking into her phone and deleting messages, leading them to believe she had cleared her voicemail and was still alive. the allegation, which turned out to be untrue, was a major factor in the closure of the news of the world and the launch of the leveson inquiry. however, it was later discovered that the messages were automatically erased by the mobile phone provider. a metropolitan police officer, dc peter cripps, was arrested on suspicion of leaking information to the guardian, but no evidence of financial inducement was found and he was not charged. the investigation of the guardian and amelia hill was criticized as an attempt to chill public interest journalism. milly dowler went missing in 2002 and her body was found six months later, with levi bellfield serving life sentence for her murder.
1492	an investigation is underway at the north west ambulance service (nwas) after a photograph surfaced of performance manager kim fullerton allegedly napping on the job during a night shift. the picture, taken at the control base where staff answer emergency calls, also showsdispatcher daniel manning. it is unclear whether fullerton was on a work break or if she was supposed to be monitoring 999 calls at her computer. nwas confirmed they have launched an inquiry into the incident, and it was taken during a time of increased pressure on the service due to a significant rise in emergency calls. the union representing ambulance staff has called for urgent action and assurance that staff are properly supervising their employees. nwas emphasized that performance managers' jobs involve monitoring call activity, but dispatchers and call handlers are allowed to take breaks and move around during their shifts. fullerton declined to comment when approached by the daily mail.
1493	a team of international researchers has found that partly melting ice in greenland is caused by heat from the earth's mantle, making it the first known connection between the melting greenland ice sheet and high heat flow from the earth's interior. this discovery, which could have implications for future climate change predictions, comes as the greenland ice sheet loses about 227 gigatonnes of ice per year, contributing to about 0.7 millimeters to the current sea level rise per year. researchers at the gfz german research centre for geosciences suggest that the earth's mantle's effect on current climate modeling is too simplistic. by modeling the earth's mantle against the ice sheet, they discovered that melting occurs in specific areas due to the mantle's composition beneath it. additionally, two studies propose a technological solution to the problem of global warming melting the ice caps on the north pole. david keith, a professor at harvard university, suggests injecting reflective particles into the atmosphere or using a few modified gulfstream jets to restore the polar ice, which could cost around $8 billion a year. however, keith doesn't yet fully advocate for this solution, emphasizing the need to tackle pollution instead. overall, these findings contribute to a more accurate understanding of the processes contributing to the melting of the greenland ice sheet.
1494	stratomic armored and fortified environments (safe) is a u.s. company that claims to build disaster-proof homes equipped to protect against bio-chemical attacks, pandemics, and natural disasters. the corbis, the company's founders, own a fortified home in washington, d.c., featuring ballistic vault doors and facial recognition software, a helipad, an underground bunker, and a panic room with communication systems and blinding fogs. safe has previously worked with oprah winfrey and currently caters to extremely successful business people, with some spending over $10 million on home security. the company also fortifies yachts with fortified hulls and underwater lighting to detect divers.
1495	lewis hamilton, the five-time formula one world champion, expects a tougher title fight this year as he believes ferrari and red bull will provide stronger competition. during the second test in barcelona, he was third-fastest with pastor maldonado setting the pace for lotus, while max verstappen was second-fastest for toro rosso. hamilton, who won the title by 67 points last year, claims he has not been closely following his rivals but anticipates a challenging season, particularly from ferrari and red bull. mclaren-honda faced issues with a recurring faulty seal on their mgu-k energy recovery system, resulting in reduced power for the team during testing.
1496	a record number of britons are saving into workplace pensions, with six in ten people now enrolled, up from half three years ago. this represents a total of 15.7 million people saving into pensions, a 2.7 million increase from the previous year. the rapid increase is due to the government's automatic enrolment scheme, which requires employers to enroll staff. the latest pension figures show that this scheme has reversed the long-term decline in people taking out pensions. however, fewer workers are being offered final salary pensions, which now represent less than half of all workplace pensions. public sector workers receive far higher employer contributions, resulting in more generous pensions upon retirement. minister for pensions, steve webb, stated that the rise in pension saving is "stunning" and that automatic enrolment is "changing the culture of pension saving in britain."
1497	a 25-year-old oklahoma prison inmate, philip thomas burris jr., is suing the state corrections department, alleging he was forced to have sex "50 to 100 times" with his caseworker, kasey mcdonald, between 2010 and 2012. burris, who is currently serving a 13-year sentence for attempted robbery and burglary, claims the sex was non-consensual. mcdonald, 38, was arrested in 2012 on rape charges and contraband smuggling. burris is the fourth to five cases of sex between prison workers and inmates the state prison system handles each year. burris began serving his prison term in 2007 and has three swastikas tattooed on his body. mcdonald admitted to having sex with burris during an interview but contests the criminal charges in court.
1498	bonnie neighbor, 50, spent the first four decades of her life feeling sorry to be alive due to mental health issues. she experienced depression and mania cycles, often going for months without leaving her house. neighbor was diagnosed with bipolar disorder at age 30. the us department of health and human services' office on women's health (owh) released a report emphasizing the importance of women's mental health and advocating for specific actions to address disparities. women are more likely to suffer from major depression, attempt suicide, and experience anxiety disorders. socio-cultural and biological factors contribute to the gender difference in mental health. the report suggests improving the interface between primary care doctors and mental health professionals, recognizing the role of trauma and violence against women, and addressing cultural biases. neighbor's experience is not uncommon, with many women feeling societal pressure to accept mental illness as "just how things are." recent developments in female-specific care, such as trauma-informed services, have led to improved outcomes. neighbor found recovery through self-awareness and a network of peers.
1499	a palestinian man drove his minivan into a crowded train platform in east jerusalem on wednesday, killing one person and injuring 13 before being shot dead by police. hamas, a militant group that controls the gaza strip, claimed responsibility for the attack, which deepened already heightened tensions between arabs and jews in the city. clashes broke out between palestinians and israeli police in the old city over a planned visit by jewish activists to a contested holy site. the attack was the second such incident in east jerusalem in the past two weeks and echoed tensions in the area, which has been unrest since the summer. israel captured east jerusalem from jordan in the 1967 war and palestinians demand it as their future capital. the fate of the area is an emotional issue for both sides and lies at the heart of the israeli-palestinian conflict. israeli police used stun grenades to disperse palestinians protesting the visit by jewish activists to the old city's noble sanctuary, which is holy to both muslims and jews. violence in the area had led jordan to call back its ambassador to israel for consultations in protest.
1500	in pretoria, south africa, oscar pistorius is on trial for the murder of his girlfriend reeva steenkamp on valentine's day last year. prosecutor gerrie nel spent most of march trying to prove that pistorius intended to kill steenkamp, while defense lawyer barry roux will argue that it was a case of self-defense. the trial, which began on monday, will focus on two questions: did pistorius know steenkamp was behind the bathroom door when he fired four hollow-point bullets through it, and if he didn't, did he act as a reasonable person would have? key testimony will come from pistorius himself, who is expected to take the stand on tuesday or wednesday. the athlete has maintained that he woke up in the middle of the night, heard a noise in the bathroom, and fired through the door in fear. the ballistics evidence, particularly the order of the gunshots and the time of steenkamp's last meal, is expected to be crucial in determining the outcome of the trial. psychiatrists may also testify on pistorius' state of mind at the time of the shooting, potentially taking into account his disability and the fear he felt.
1501	researchers at pennsylvania state university have discovered a molecule called tic10 that activates a protein called trail, which helps the body fight cancer by suppressing tumor development during immune surveillance. trail is not toxic to the body like chemotherapy or radiotherapy, and its small size allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier to target brain tumors. the "bystander effect" of trail means it kills not only cancerous cells but also nearby healthy cells, increasing cancer-killing trail receptors on their surface. the findings have led to ongoing clinical trials using artificially created versions of trail, which have shown to be safe in early trials. the study was published in the journal science translational medicine.
1502	the author describes her frustrating experience of trying on various clothing items from marks & spencer's (m&s), finding that the same size did not fit consistently across different collections. she tried on green jeans in size 14 that wouldn't go past her knees, and sizes 16 and 18 that were too big. she also noted inconsistencies with a burgundy pencil skirt, a pair of m&s's classic trousers, and several dresses, including a per una print skirt and a lace russet dress from the autograph collection. the author ended up purchasing a pair of size 16 jeans from per una and a striped top from the limited edition collection, which were the most comfortable and flattering options for her. overall, she was disappointed with the sizing inconsistencies within m&s and had to try multiple sizes to find the best fit.
1503	bill clinton, the democratic party's elder statesman, responded to criticism from republican strategist karl rove about hillary clinton's health, defending his wife's health and fitness. rove had previously suggested that hillary clinton may have suffered a traumatic brain injury from a concussion in 2012. bill clinton dismissed these claims, expressing surprise and mocking the republicans for their attacks. hillary clinton, who has remained above politics as she weighs a potential white house run, did not address the rove comments at two events in washington. bill clinton's role in politics has recently included endorsing candidates, such as maryland gubernatorial hopeful anthony brown, and defending his wife against opponents' attacks. democrats argue that bill clinton's influence and understanding of political issues make him an asset to a potential hillary clinton campaign, while some republicans view him as a liability.
1504	in the aftermath of the charlie hebdo terror attacks in paris and new threats from al-qaeda, the tsa announced increased security measures at all us airports. this comes after the latest edition of al-qaeda's english-language, online magazine, inspire, published instructions on how to make a bomb from household goods that could be difficult to detect at airport security checks. al-qaeda on the arabian peninsula (aqap) urged "every determined muslim" to build and detonate the device on high-profile airlines such as british airways, easyjet, aa, delta, united, and air france to "crush the enemy's economy." the magazine has been connected to several terror plots, including the boston marathon bombings and the attempted bomber umar farouk abdulmutallab. police are investigating the latest edition, which also calls for a new generation of "lone wolf" terrorists. an explosives expert expressed doubts about the effectiveness of the bomb design and questioned its ability to evade detection. the last issue of inspire contained a notorious explosives guide that was suspected to have been the template for the boston marathon bombings.
1505	a volcanic ash cloud from chile's puyehue-cordon caulle volcano, which had grounded commercial flights in australia since tuesday, began to thin over australia on wednesday. qantas and virgin australia resumed some domestic and international flights, but trips across the tasman sea to new zealand remained cancelled indefinitely due to the ash cloud's presence in the region. the ash cloud, carried by the jet stream, had also forced major flight cancellations in australia over a week and a half ago. the advisory center explained that volcanic ash can remain suspended for long periods, and the june 4 eruption of the chilean volcano sent smoke plumes over six miles into the air, causing widespread disruptions. chile, located on the pacific "ring of fire," is prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.
1506	a controversial nhs scheme paying gps £55 for every new dementia case has resulted in a surge in incorrect referrals and potential misdiagnoses, researchers warn. the initiative, meant to boost low dementia detection rates, has doubled the number of "inaccurate" gp referrals to memory clinics, with 52% of these patients later found not to have dementia. this compares to previous rates of 25-30%. many of these patients had temporary memory problems due to aging or depression rather than dementia. researchers at the university of sheffield warn of the "devastating consequence" of false diagnoses on patients and families, as gps strive to meet targets. longer waiting times for accurate diagnosis are also a concern, as more patients are sent for tests. the study, uncovered by pulse magazine, found a seven-fold increase in diagnosed dementia cases since the scheme's inception. around 850,000 adults in britain have dementia, but only 45% have been formally diagnosed. nhs england insists the scheme is only a temporary measure to improve detection rates and will stop after march 2015. they maintain there is no evidence of incorrect diagnoses by gps. meanwhile, concerns have arisen about gps prescribing fewer antibiotics due to cash incentives, potentially endangering public health.
1507	three canadian prisoners, yves denis, denis lefebvre, and serge pomerleau, who escaped from the orsainville detention center in quebec using a helicopter on june 7, have been recaptured in montreal two weeks later. the trio, who were awaiting trial on charges including murder and gangsterism following a 2010 drug bust, had been granted permission to be in the courtyard together on court days due to complaint about harsh security conditions. their escape launched an international manhunt and added them to an interpol red notice list. the capture took place early on a monday morning at a montreal residence, and the men are scheduled to appear in court in quebec city on monday. no information was given about how they were caught or who was operating the helicopter, and more arrests are expected. an investigation into the incident has been ordered, along with a review of a similar escape that occurred in 2013. notable helicopter escapes include those of a greek prisoner in 2006 and 2009, and joel david kaplan from a mexican jail in 1971, which inspired a book and a movie.
1508	i. tehran, iran: president mahmoud ahmadinejad defended his relationship with supreme leader ali khamenei amidst allegations of a political rift. ii. ahmadinejad, who won two-thirds of the votes in the june 12 election according to the government, dismissed claims of a strained relationship, stating it is based on love and faith, and compared it to a father-son bond. iii. controversies include ahmadinejad's appointment of esfandyar rahim mashaie as his first vice president, despite khamenei attempting to nullify the appointment, and mashaie's controversial statements about israel and women dancing. iv. protests occurred in tehran on thursday, commemorating the 40th day since the death of neda agha-soltan, who became a symbol of post-election unrest, resulting in clashes between police and mourners. v. mir-hossein moussavi, the main opposition leader, attempted to attend the mourning ceremony but was denied access, and released a video defending the opposition movement and calling for a return to the principles of the 1979 islamic revolution.
1509	at least six security personnel were killed and eight members of sri lanka's cricket team were injured, including two with gunshot wounds, in an attack by gunmen on their bus in lahore, pakistan, as they were traveling to gaddafi stadium for a test match against pakistan. the attackers are still at large and no group has claimed responsibility. sri lanka's foreign minister said the squad would be flown home to colombo later tuesday. the incident is the first international cricket match in pakistan since 2007 and comes as the country battles islamist and taliban insurgents in its northwest frontier province. pakistan had hoped sri lanka's tour would help it recoup some of the losses from the cancellation of previous tours due to security concerns. the international cricket council (icc) has condemned the attack and canceled the remainder of the tour.
1510	incumbent nigerian president goodluck jonathan is likely to win the presidential election based on preliminary results from 28 states and the capital, according to a cnn tally, with over 19 million votes compared to main challenger muhammadu buhari's close to 9 million. formal announcement of results could come as early as monday. jonathan, a christian southerner, assumed office after umaru yar'adua's death and is popular in the south. buhari, a muslim northerner and former military ruler, is the candidate for the congress for progressive change. saturday's voting was largely peaceful but marred by logistical problems in earlier elections, which resulted in a delayed vote. over 73 million people registered to vote in the presidential, parliamentary, and gubernatorial elections. human rights violations and violence have occurred, and the electoral commission has faced criticism for previous elections marked by vote rigging, theft of ballot boxes, and intimidation. nigeria, africa's most populous country and largest oil producer, is a major crude oil supplier to the united states and hosts western oil companies and workers.
1511	over 1,000 protesters gathered in kuwait on friday, calling for greater rights for long-term non-citizen residents. the initially small crowd swiftly grew, leading to clashes with security forces who used water cannons. a kuwaiti government spokesperson, col. adil al-hashash, claimed the forces acted in self-defense after protesters began throwing rocks. al-hashash added that the protest was peacefully dispersed, and several protesters were arrested and questioned. the demonstration took place in al jahra province, north of kuwait city. kuwait has long struggled with the issue of non-citizen rights, with an estimated 100,000 such residents in the country. reporting by saad al-enzi.
1512	a new fat-dissolving injection called aquadxy has been invented, which its makers claim can dissolve fat cells and allow them to be passed out of the body through urination. sharon donaldson, 39, from liverpool, was one of the first women to try the treatment, paying £1000 for injections on her face and midriff before her wedding. the procedure involves injecting a water solution into stubborn fat areas, which then dissolves the fat cells, which are eliminated over a three-week period through urination. aquadxy is marketed as an alternative to liposuction and claimed to be less invasive. however, experts have warned of potential health risks, including increased cholesterol and blood sugar levels, and the possibility of becoming diabetic. the procedure is not recommended for weight loss but for contouring the body and reducing stubborn fat deposits. sharon had already lost weight through dieting and exercise but wanted to look her best for her wedding and opted for the less invasive option over liposuction. however, the safety and efficacy of the treatment are yet to be proven, and alternatives such as diet and exercise are advised.
1513	gabby giffords, the former arizona congresswoman who was shot in the head by jared loughner in tucson in 2011, recalled facing him at his sentencing hearing and describing his "beady eyes." six people were killed and 13 were injured during the incident. giffords and her husband, mark kelly, are now living together as they navigate the aftermath of the shooting and advocate for gun control. giffords, who suffers from aphasia and has limited sight, is determined to get better and has a renewed purpose in life. the couple's relationship with each other and giffords' stepdaughters has improved, and they have moved into a new home together. the shooter's parents were aware of his mental illness but struggled to find him appropriate treatment before the shooting. giffords and kelly have not had contact with the parents since then. giffords' father, who taught her about humor, strength, and responsibility, died suddenly a few months ago. she continues to bond with her mother and there is a possibility they may have a child through a surrogate using frozen embryos. giffords expressed that she has no resentment towards the shooting and wants to move forward.
1514	charles saatchi booked a suite at the savoy hotel under a pseudonym and smuggled a kitten into the berkeley hotel while trying to impress nigella lawson during her husband john diamond's illness in 2000, according to a former chauffeur. saatchi and lawson began their relationship during diamond's last six months alive, contrary to lawson's court testimony, and went on shopping trips to selfridges and harrods. john diamond reportedly gave his blessing for lawson to have a father figure for their children. saatchi and lawson married in 2003, two years after diamond's death, and had elisabetta and francesca grillo act as their witnesses. saatchi and diamond had met during gambling games of scrabble in the late 1990s. saatchi had previously been married to kay saatchi, and had a child with her, while lawson was married to diamond. the timing of saatchi's statement confessing to the affair infuriated lawson's friends.
1515	a london resident named oli beale was kept awake by a loud karaoke session from his neighbors at 3 a.m. instead of just complaining to them, beale, who works in advertising, decided to write a detailed review of their performance and post it on the communal board in his hackney block of flats, as well as on twitter. he criticized specific songs and their performances, giving them ratings out of 10, with the who's "pinball wizard" and aerosmith's "walk this way" receiving the lowest scores. beale noted that the neighbors had the perfect stage since their terrace faced 115 windows. after the performance ended at 9.10 a.m., beale ended his review with the message "i hate you." beale's creative complaint letters have gained attention before, as in 2009 when he wrote to sir richard branson about poor food on a virgin flight, which was called the funniest complaint letter of all time. beale was so unhappy with his meal between mumbai and london that he wrote six pages of complaints and included pictures of his food, comparing it to a hamster in a box that wasn't breathing.
1516	tanya brookes, a former chief inspector for surrey police, was sentenced to two and a half years in jail for carrying out a refund scam involving high street stores. the scam involved her buying discounted luxury items such as breast pumps, fertility tests, and cashmere blankets and then using false bank statements to claim full refunds. among the stores she targeted were the white company, micro scooters, and boots. she also fraudulently obtained a discount on a holiday by claiming she was a counter-terrorism officer and used forged proof of purchase from john lewis to claim for damaged buggies from british airways and monarch airlines. her husband, also a senior police officer, lost his job due to the case, and she may also lose her pension. brookes previously had a brain injury which psychiatric assessments suggested may have affected her judgments. the court was told she had "thrown it all away" despite her and her husband's healthy salaries. the judge condemned her actions as bringing "shame" on the police service.
1517	a crime-scene officer who worked for staffordshire and cleveland police between 1996 and 2011 is under investigation for carrying out "substandard" work that may have affected up to 90 criminal cases, including one investigation into a death. the independent police complaints commission (ipcc) is examining the officer's work and qualifications, and families affected by the cases have been notified. the officer resigned from his post last october and is currently on police bail for suspicion of perverting the course of justice. the investigation began in february 2011 and major incident teams from both staffordshire and cleveland police have been working on it under the direction of the ipcc. the officer worked for staffordshire police from 1996 to 2002, cleveland police from 2002 to 2011, and for a short period at northumbria police in 2002. no concerns have been found in relation to his employment with northumbria police. ipcc commissioner nicholas long stated that the investigation is complex and serious, involving three police forces and covering a period of 15 years. the families affected by the cases were notified rather than making it public earlier to avoid unnecessary concern. the specific details of the cases are not being released as it remains a criminal investigation.
1518	rutgers athletic director tim pernetti resigned on friday after coming under fire for his handling of basketball coach mike rice's abusive behavior towards players, which was caught on video in november 2012. pernetti initially wanted to fire rice but was persuaded against it by university officials, including interim senior vice president and general counsel john wolf, who also resigned on friday. the video, which showed rice pushing, shoving, and using homophobic slurs towards players, prompted outrage both on and off campus and led to calls for president robert barchi's resignation. barchi, who originally supported pernetti's decision to suspend rice rather than fire him, expressed regret for his decision after viewing the video in full this week. rice was fired on april 3, 2013. pernetti, a rutgers graduate and former football player, apologized for his role in the situation and stated that his decision was a failure of process. the incident comes at a time when rutgers is set to join the big ten conference and move to the division i athletic association, which is expected to bring in additional revenue for the university. pernetti was praised for his role in the university's move to the big ten and the hiring of rice in 2010.
1519	former footballer phil neville, known for his 59 caps for england and six premier league titles with manchester united, has shared a picture of himself surrounded by cleaning supplies on twitter after his wife revealed he had never done household chores like mopping, vacuuming, or even making a cup of instant coffee. his wife, julie, described him as "britain's most hopeless husband," stating he had never used a dishwasher, washing machine, or oven, and had no idea where the ironing board was kept. neville, who had always relied on his wife for household tasks, has now expressed his intent to learn, but the difficulty remains whether he will be able to do it effectively. the revelation comes after bbc reported in june 2023 that during neville's commentary debut during england's first world cup game against italy, more than 400 viewers complained about his "robotic" and "monotonous" commentary, with neville joking afterward that he had helped everyone "get to sleep." manchester united players' inability to cope with everyday tasks was previously revealed in 2004 by former coach brian mcclair, who stated "none of the players can change a tyre on their cars." neville retired from football at the end of the 2012/13 season and is now a pundit for the bbc. neville's siblings, gary and tracey, both have successful careers in football and netball, respectively.
1520	india urged sri lanka's tamil rebels to release an estimated 70,000 civilians trapped in the war zone, as the conflict between government troops and the rebels enters its final phase. indian external affairs minister pranab mukherjee called on the liberation tigers of tamil eelam (ltte) to release civilians and lay down arms, as some have been used as human shields or prevented from escaping. government forces and rebels are battling over the rebels' remaining territory in the vanni region, and tens of thousands of people have fled the area. the tamils have been fighting for an independent homeland since 1983.
1521	professional footballers are being advised against signing for serbian clubs due to severe financial problems, with eight out of sixteen teams in the superliga unable to pay employees after having their bank accounts blocked. the world players' union (fifpro) and the serbian players' union have warned players of the financial instability, with several clubs, including fk radnicki 1923, having threatened players who went on strike due to unpaid salaries. players at radnicki have reportedly been struggling to pay for food and some have been evicted from their homes. fifpro and the serbian players' union have offered financial support, but it is not a long-term solution. some players have already left radnicki out of concern for their basic needs, and fans have reportedly threatened and insulted the players. one player at radnicki has only received one month's salary in four months, and the situation is described as alarming with additional concerns over respect for players' rights.
1522	nine experienced skydivers from wisconsin survived a terrifying collision mid-air between two planes at 12,000 feet, which left one in flames. the skydivers, who described the moment as "jump-for-your-life," were unphased and expressed that skydiving is "part of who they are." one skydiver tried to help the pilot of the burning plane, while another managed to fly the damaged plane safely to the ground. despite the incident, all nine skydivers expressed no fear of jumping again. the cause of the collision remains unclear, and the federal aviation administration is investigating. fortunately, no one on the ground was injured by the falling debris.
1523	a female patient of britain's first transgender doctor, dr. richard curtis, has expressed regret for undergoing gender-changing treatments under his care. dr. curtis, a former woman, is being investigated by the general medical council (gmc) for allegedly allowing patients to rush into sex-change procedures without proper counseling or second opinions. he is also accused of prescribing hormones at the initial consultation and referring patients for surgery before living in their desired gender role for a year as recommended by international guidelines. dr. curtis, who charges up to £240 per hour for consultations, had undergone gender reassignment himself in 2005, transitioning from vanda zadorozny. he was born in britain to an english mother and polish miner father and studied medicine before feeling "trapped in a woman's body" and undergoing gender-specific counseling and surgeries. dr. curtis is currently under investigation, and if found guilty, could be struck off the medical register. neither dr. curtis nor the medical defense union wishes to comment during the ongoing investigation.
1524	the prime minister, david cameron, plans to re-introduce a bill committing the government to holding a eu membership referendum by 2017, after it was blocked in the house of lords. the legislation, which was backed by the house of commons with a big majority, was criticized by labour and the liberal democrats as an attempt to bypass the house of lords. french president francois hollande also rebuffed cameron's calls for fundamental eu reform before the referendum. the conservative party imposed a three-line whip on mps to support the bill, but it was effectively killed off in the house of lords. ukip leader nigel farage and conservative mp james wharton criticized labour and the liberal democrats for blocking the legislation, with wharton calling them "enemies of democracy." the labour shadow foreign secretary, douglas alexander, raised questions about cameron's approach to the constitutional matter. despite the setback, cameron remained committed to giving the british people a referendum. hollande stated that changes to eu treaties were not a priority for france at this time.
1525	the crown prosecution service (cps) is reviewing the convictions of three pakistani cricketers, salman butt, mohammad amir, and mohammad asif, who were jailed for spot-fixing in 2011 following doubts over the credibility of undercover reporter mazher mahmood, also known as "fake sheik." the cricketers were banned from cricket for five years and were convicted of conspiracy to cheat at gambling and to accept corrupt payments based on evidence from mahmood's sting operation in the news of the world. amir's five-year ban for spot-fixing during a test against england will end in august 2022, and tv footage showed him bowling a no-ball during the lord's test in 2010. butt was jailed for 30 months, asif for one year, and amir for six months. however, concerns over mahmood's evidence led to the collapse of a recent trial involving former x factor judge tulisa contostavlos, and the case is one of 25 being reviewed. mahmood testified extensively for the prosecution in the trial of butt and asif, while amir and agent mazher majeed pleaded guilty. all three admitted guilt to the international cricket council, with team captain butt receiving an additional five-year suspended ban. amir has since been cleared to return to cricket and could play against england in october 2021.
1526	a snowmobiler from arizona, identified as lawrence orduno, 48, was rescued on monday after being lost for nearly two days in a remote canyon in northern utah. orduno's snowmobile got stuck in a canyon on saturday night, and he built a makeshift snow cave using pieces of the snowmobile to protect himself from the freezing temperatures. his friend, courtney wood, 27, made it back to the parking lot but couldn't find orduno due to his unfamiliarity with the area. search and rescue crews from cache, rich, box elder, and franklin counties, led by the cache county sheriff's office, searched for orduno all day sunday but had to halt their search due to the blistering snow. orduno survived by building a small fire and collectingsmelting ice from his bottles of gatorade. he was found alive around 10 a.m. on monday in a different location than where he and his friend had ventured. orduno sustained mild frostbite to one toe but is expected to make a full recovery.
1527	an 18-year-old man named skylar murphy from edmonton, alberta, accidentally brought a functional pipe bomb filled with black powder to the edmonton international airport on september 20. airport security screeners discovered the bomb in murphy's luggage but did not detain him or alert the royal canadian mounted police immediately due to their lack of authority to do so. the rcmp were not contacted until four days later, and murphy was arrested upon his return to edmonton on september 27. the incident caused a significant security breach, with transport minister lisa raitt expressing her disappointment and calling for improved procedures. the lack of public comment on the incident from various agencies and officials has drawn criticism from security experts. murphy pleaded guilty to possession of an explosive substance last month.
1528	the kc-97 stratotanker simulator, built in 1953, was one of only eleven ever made and was used to train pilots on flying the wartime-era military aircraft. weighing nine tonnes and costing £520,000 ($853,000), the simulator was a massive and complex machine, with four analog computers controlled by stacks of resistance cards and requiring three technicians for maintenance. the kc-97 stratotanker was a refueling variant of the c-97 stratofreighter, with piston engines and the ability to transfer fuel in mid-air. the simulator was used to teach pilots proper pre-flight checks, take-off procedures, and emergency flight operating procedures, and was operated until the early 1970s. the 128th air refueling wing of the air national guard, which still uses a training simulator on base, now has a digital, full motion kc-135r simulator made by boeing.
1529	the 87th academy awards had a mix of light-hearted moments and serious discussions on various controversial topics. alejandro gonzalez iñarritu won best picture for "birdman," with sean penn's green card joke causing controversy. patricia arquette called for wage equality for women, creating an uproar and social media debate. graham moore gave an emotional speech about suicide awareness, encouraging people to stay different and call their loved ones. reese witherspoon promoted the #askhermore campaign, urging red carpet interviewers to ask more meaningful questions. j.k. simmons won best supporting actor and urged viewers to #callyourmom. issues addressed during the ceremony included immigration, wage inequality, and suicide.
1530	aformer porn star, tom 'billy' o'connor, from colchester, uk, has a tattoo boasting about his large manhood, but he did not always have such confidence. o'connor is one of many british men opting for penis enhancement surgery, with leading surgeon dr. roberto viel reporting a 40% increase in demand over the past year. the trend is driven by the prevalence of sexualized images in media, according to viel, who performs over 300 penoplasties a year. men, like women, seek improvement in areas they perceive as falling short, and the pressure to meet industry standards and societal ideals is a significant factor, particularly in the porn industry. while some men, like o'connor, are satisfied with the results, only 35% of men are happy with the outcomes, according to the nhs. viel offers two ways to enlarge a penis: cutting the suspensory ligament for an increase in flaccid length and using fat injections for an increase in girth. these procedures do not affect the size of an erect penis.
1531	the removal of the photo-sharing app 500px from apple's app store has raised concerns over review equity and fairness, as the company cited violation of content policy due to easy access to nude images. the app's coo, evgeny tchebotarev, received calls from media outlets after the app was taken down despite its difficult interface for accessing nude content and the availability of similar apps with easier access to nudes. apple later clarified the removal was due to pornographic content and possible child pornography, a claim that 500px executives deny receiving prior to the removal. the incident highlights issues with apple's app-review process and the inconsistent application of content ratings, as well as questions about the role of apis in the app-review system.
1532	in the balkans, a three-month-old baby is rescued by the slovenian military from heavy flooding in the bosnian town of šamac, as the region faces the aftermath of the heaviest rainfall recorded in over a century. the flooding and landslides have killed at least 40 people, displaced half a million, and affected over one million. authorities are also dealing with the harrowing sight of thousands of dead animals and the threat of disease from their carcasses, as well as potential mine hazards dislodged by the flooding. the slovenian military helped evacuate 52 people and delivered food and equipment during the rescue mission. the floods in serbia, bosnia, and croatia have caused widespread destruction and declared days of mourning. international help is being sought to deal with the aftermath.
1533	a mystery illness, referred to as the 'plague,' has infected over 700 students and staff members at richardson high school in north texas, causing vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and weakness. the source of the illness is still unknown, with health officials ruling out the cafeteria as a possible cause. extra cleaners have been brought in to sanitize the school premises, and some students have taken to wearing masks and carrying disinfectants. the situation started last week, and by friday, about a quarter of the school's students were absent. symptoms include vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and weakness, and health experts advise general hygiene, specifically diligent hand washing, to prevent its spread. students have started a twitter hashtag, '#rhsplague,' and are trying to make light of the situation with jokes. the illness has caused concern among parents, with one father describing it as 'very scary.'
1534	the relationship between president obama and republicans in congress has reached a new low point after the fiscal cliff negotiations, with house speaker john boehner confirming that he will no longer negotiate legislative deals with the president. senator john cornyn of texas criticized the president for fiscal brinksmanship since 2010 and suggested the possibility of a government shutdown. julian zelizer, a cnn contributor and princeton university historian, described the situation as tense and strained, with the real negative being the president's relationship with house republicans, which remains as bad as ever. obama's combative approach towards congress was criticized by ruben navarrette, who suggested that the president's recent election victory does not give him license to engage in "defiance politics" and that he needs to recognize his responsibility to lead. the gop is also facing internal struggles to define its message, particularly on spending and income inequality. former white house press secretary bill burton countered that the problem lies with republican leadership, specifically boehner's inability to control his caucus. the debt ceiling and funding the federal government are expected to be the next battles between congress and the president.
1535	four immigrant rights groups, including the mexican american legal defense and educational fund, the american civil liberties union, the aclu of arizona, and the national immigration law center, announced on thursday that they will challenge arizona's new immigration law, which allows police to ask anyone for proof of legal u.s. residency. the groups say the law is discriminatory and unconstitutional. arizona governor jan brewer signed the law last week and it is set to go into effect 90 days after the end of the legislative session. the law requires immigrants to carry their alien registration documents at all times, makes it a state crime to live or travel through arizona illegally, and targets those who hire or transport illegal immigrants. critics argue that it will lead to racial profiling and trample civil rights. the law has drawn condemnation from the federal government, the organization of american states, and various advocacy groups. some cities and businesses have also expressed their opposition to the law. president obama has called on congress to pass comprehensive immigration reform this year, but republican leaders say arizona is filling a void left by the federal government. opponents of the law plan to demonstrate against the arizona diamondbacks baseball team and hold rallies. according to federal estimates, there are about 460,000 undocumented immigrants in arizona and over 10 million in the united states. the pew research center survey found that americans believe latinos are discriminated against and about one-third of latinos report experiencing discrimination.
1536	a mother, natalie allman, who was tortured and had her throat slashed by her ex-fiancé, jason hughes, in front of their twin sons, is being forced to write to him from prison three times a year or face being jailed herself. hughes, who was sentenced to nine years in prison for the attack in 2011, is demanding updates on their sons' school progress, health, and emotional development through parental rights laws. allman, who still bears the scars from the attack and has rebuilt her life with a new partner, feels wronged by the law that continues to grant hughes control from behind bars. the children act of 1989 requires disagreements between parents to be resolved through court-ordered residence or contact orders. hughes was given permission to send one letter a year and cards at birthdays and christmas, but allman is obligated to respond with three letters. she finds the letters frustrating and has been advised to keep them for potential future reference for her sons.
1537	billie jean king, a tennis legend and openly gay athlete who was initially part of the u.s. presidential delegation to the olympics opening ceremony but had to withdraw due to her mother's illness, has been reinstated for the closing ceremony. king has expressed concerns about the treatment of the lgbt community in russia and called the inclusion of openly gay delegates a statement for human rights and equality. president barack obama also named deputy secretary of state william burns, u.s. ambassador to russia michael mcfaul, and former gold medal olympians bonnie blair and eric heider to the delegation. the delegates will attend the final ceremony and meet u.s. athletes. russia has faced criticism for its anti-gay propaganda law which prohibits positive discussion of homosexuality in front of children.
1538	prime minister david cameron attended a performance of the controversial west end musical "book of mormon," which is known for its satirical take on mormonism and its explicit content. the musical, written by south park creators trey parker and matt stone, along with robert lopez, has been critically and commercially successful in the united states, garnering numerous awards. the church of jesus christ of latter-day saints, to which mormonism belongs, did not comment on the prime minister's attendance, and it remains unknown if he enjoyed the show. the church released an official statement expressing the belief that the book of mormon as a religious text will change people's lives, while matt stone described it as an atheist's love letter to religion. the musical contains explicit language and themes, including a character named "f*** frog" and a scene with a singing clitoris. cameron attended the eu summit in brussels earlier in the day.
1539	michael pollara, a 46-year-old shoplifter from florida, served two years in jail for stealing over $1 million worth of merchandise from various stores including toys r us, pharmaceutical stores, department stores, and shopping mall specialty stores, with his mother serving as his accomplice. pollara's signature shoplifting move involved taking a box, emptying its contents, and filling it with expensive items before purchasing the box. he confessed to using "fences" and selling stolen items on ebay. the broward sheriff's office arrested pollara in 2012, and he served about two years in jail for shoplifting from over 20 stores in florida. pollara gained the nickname "toys "r" us" in jail, and his mother was put on probation but not jailed. pollara has since been released from jail and is no longer sharing information about his shopping destinations. pollara claimed he used travel points to visit 25 countries but also confessed to stealing goods from stores in all 50 states during an 11-year period.
1540	a food factory worker, tomas suchy, was tragically killed when a wall of frozen fish pallets fell on top of him while he was trying to re-stack them in the store room of interfish in plymouth, devon. the incident occurred despite warnings from employees about the poor condition of the pallets and the instability of the stacks. the boxes, each containing 52 boxes and weighing 25 kilos, gave way, causing 'catastrophic' head injuries and other fatal injuries for the slovakian-born worker. the inquest heard criticisms of the company's health and safety practices, with some former employees stating that it was not an isolated incident. interfish received four prohibition notices and one improvement notice from the health and safety executive following the incident, and complied with each. the coroner returned a verdict of accidental death.
1541	amazon raised its minimum order requirement for free shipping from $25 to $35, marking the first price increase in a decade. the company has been encouraging consumers to consider signing up for its $79-per-year prime subscription, which offers unlimited free two-day shipping on products and access to streaming media. the move comes as amazon, which has become a global retail powerhouse since its founding in 1996, has been losing money due to its constant diversification. analysts anticipate amazon will report another loss when it releases its third-quarter results on thursday, yet the stock is at a record high. in addition to raising the minimum order for free shipping, amazon has also increased fees for prime members who need faster delivery of certain items.
1542	in adidas' latest multi-million pound marketing campaign, lionel messi is presented as more than just a football player as he transforms into a tiger. after missing out on the world cup with argentina, messi returns to barcelona for pre-season training and unveils his new golden adizero f50 boots. in the advert, messi emerges from a wall mural to join children playing football, laces up his new boots, and morphs into a tiger before reaching the nou camp. messi ended his holiday in capri with girlfriend antonella rocuzzo and will wear his new boots in both la liga and the champions league, with an alternative pair for european matches. adidas also released blackout versions of their copa mundial boots along with updated predator and f50 studs. messi received the golden ball for the best player at the world cup, and he scored a stunning goal against manchester city in the february.
1543	the most-watched television moment on christmas day 2013 was the regeneration sequence of doctor who with 10.2 million viewers on bbc one. the most-watched program overall was mrs. brown's boys christmas special with an average of 9.4 million viewers. doctor who and itv's coronation street both had an average of 8.3 million viewers. eastenders, which had lost the top spot to mrs. brown's boys, had 7.8 million viewers on average. bbc took six places in the top ten, but the queen's christmas broadcast and the bbc news did not make the cut. the itv news took the place of the bbc news in the top ten. danny cohen, director of bbc television, expressed pride in the quality and popularity of the shows aired on bbc during christmas 2013.
1544	kobani, a city in syria, has been devastated by intense fighting between the kurds and isis. the streets have been reduced to ruins, and essentials such as food and heat are scarcely available. indiscriminate mortar attacks and air raids continue to afflict the city. the front lines are closer to the city center than some reports suggest, and isis positions are nearer than advertised. meedya raqqa, a 22-year-old kurdish female fighter and unit commander, leads the defense and recounts the significant loss of friends in the unending battle. raqqa's closest friend, reeban, sacrificed herself to save her comrades in a heroic yet chilling act. despite the hardships, raqqa resists to avenge her friends' deaths and rebuild their land. the resistance of kurdish women, who defy traditional norms, adds a new chapter to women's history. the fighting continues, with the kurds using aged and scavenged weapons while relying on coalition airstrikes for support. isis and the kurds hold starkly different views of civilization, separated only by a stretch of mud and rubble.
1545	outgoing massachusetts governor deval patrick criticized president barack obama for failing to effectively communicate his message leading up to the 2014 midterm elections, which he believes contributed to the democratic party's losses. patrick noted that obama doesn't communicate his accomplishments well and urged democrats to stand up for their beliefs. while patrick acknowledged some responsibility for the defeat of massachusetts democratic candidates, he didn't take blame for the loss of the governor's seat himself. looking ahead to the 2016 democratic primaries, patrick voiced concerns about the perception of hillary clinton as the inevitable nominee, stating that regular voters are turned off by entitlement and wanting candidates to "sweat for the job." patrick has considered a 2016 run for president but ruled it out, stating that he didn't enter politics to seek another job.
1546	zsa zsa gabor, the hungarian-born actress and famous for her multiple marriages, is recovering from hip replacement surgery, according to conflicting reports from her husband and daughter. prince frederic von anhalt stated that his wife of 24 years is in critical condition, while daughter francesca hilton reported that her condition is guarded. gabor, 93, suffered a broken hip after falling at her bel air home nearly a week ago. her husband claimed that she was confined to a wheelchair since a 2002 car accident, but she was able to sit up in bed and talk following a blood transfusion and the removal of her morphine drip over the weekend. the actress, who has been in the intensive care unit at ronald reagan ucla medical center, is expected to be discharged as soon as thursday. gabor, who has been married multiple times, is best known for her roles in films like "moulin rouge," "the story of three loves," and "touch of evil." she was sentenced to jail time in 1989 for slapping a beverly hills police officer. zsa zsa's two older sisters, magda and eva, also had notable acting careers. magda, who died in 1997, married oscar-winning actor george sanders at one time, while eva, who died in 1995, is best remembered for her role on "green acres."
1547	rebecca adlington, a double olympic gold medalist in swimming, has shared photos of her decorated room in the olympic village where she is staying during the london 2012 games. the room, adorned with team gb paperchains, is reportedly furnished with a bed that is only 5ft 8in long, which is shorter than adlington's 5ft 10in frame. she has posted pictures of her new accommodations, jokingly commenting about fitting in and getting a good night's sleep. british athletes have taken to twitter to comment on the size of the beds and express support and amusement at adlington's predicament. adlington has also tweeted about her addiction to the "mummy-porn" trilogy "fifty shades of grey," sharing her copies with fellow swimmer joanne jackson.
1548	manchester united issued an "unreserved apology" for using a swastika-like logo in a newsletter to fans, which featured the headline "new order" and images of emerging youth players. the logo, which spelled out mufc, caused widespread outrage on social media, as the term "new order" also has links to nazi ideology. an internal investigation was launched to determine how the email was approved for distribution. senior figures at old trafford were taken aback by the incident, which came as the duke of cambridge spoke out about the lingering problem of racism in football. the fa fined goalkeeper mark bosnich for delivering a nazi salute to tottenham hotspur supporters in 1996, and spurs have been at the center of recent race-related controversies involving chants of "yid."
1549	sharon content, the founder of the children of promise organization in brooklyn, new york, helps children cope with the emotional struggle of having a parent in prison. with about 200 kids aged between 6 and 16, the organization addresses the mental health issues the children face, including depression, anxiety, and anger. these children are often left behind with caregivers who are already struggling below the poverty line, and they experience a sense of shame and embarrassment due to their parents' actions. content emphasizes the need for more support for these "silent victims of incarceration," as they are not the direct victims but bear the consequences of their parents' actions. christopher walter, who runs the harlem community justice center, focuses on helping inmates reintegrate into society upon release. his organization offers reentry services such as job placement, mental health treatment, and support for families to create a smoother transition back into their communities. they primarily focus on young adults, who are at the highest risk of recidivism. both content and walter aim to strengthen family bonds and reduce the recidivism rate by addressing the specific challenges faced by children and parents during and after incarceration. the issue of support systems for children with incarcerated parents affects over 2.7 million children in the united states and millions more around the world, highlighting the need for more programs like these to break the cycle of incarceration.
1550	the ayr gold cup favorite watchable, trained by david o'meara, was drawn in stall 5 in the sprint race despite bookmakers believing a low draw would not disadvantage the favorite. high stands' side stalls were popular at the draw, but statistics for the last 20 years show a near even distribution of winners. watchable, a sibling to john gosden's 2008 1,000 guineas fourth infallible, is the 8-1 favorite in the race. o'meara also enters royal ascot winner and last year's runner-up louis the pious, highland acclaim, and is aiming for his first ayr gold cup win. jump jockey jason maguire returns from a six-month injury layoff with rides at newton abbot and worcester. donald mccain's stable jockey is also returning after an injury, missing six months due to a fall at stratford. trainer david o'meara is hoping for another win. fire fighting won the william hill handicap stakes during day one of the ayr gold cup. colin tizzard's cue card, last season's king george vi chase winner, underwent an operation to aid his breathing and missed the cheltenham gold cup due to a pelvis stress fracture. his early season target will be the betfair chase at haydock.
1551	sheikh ahmed al-gamdi, a former head of the saudi religious police, faced death threats and condemnation from the grand mufti and a saudi group after appearing on tv with his wife, who was not wearing a niqab or veil. al-gamdi stated that islam does not require women to hide their faces in public, citing ancient texts and jurisprudence. his views created controversy as he was previously responsible for enforcing strict islamic rule on the streets and checking dress code and separation of genders. the host of the tv show, badria al-bishr, also appeared unveiled during the interview. al-gamdi received numerous death threats, with some radical clerics urging him to repent, and a saudi group threatening legal action. the debate over the niqab and hijab remains a sensitive issue, and women in saudi arabia are not required by law to wear the niqab but may face harassment if they appear in public without a face covering. al-gamdi has previously faced criticism for advocating for women to be able to go out in public without a male guardian and mix with the opposite sex in appropriate environments.
1552	germany dominated the netherlands in a euro 2012 warm-up match with a 3-0 victory, as miroslav klose set up two goals and scored the third. klose is just five goals shy of gerd muller's all-time international scoring record. spain struggled to a 2-2 draw against costa rica, as iker casillas made costly errors leading to both goals. england won 1-0 against sweden at wembley, while uruguay stunned italy 1-0 with sebastian fernandez's goal in rome.
1553	during a six-hour spacewalk at the international space station on tuesday, astronauts fyodor yurchikhin and mikhail kornienko encountered two mysterious objects that floated away. nasa was unsure of what the first object was, but it did not pose a threat to the station. it was later identified as a possibly a clamp from a previous spacewalk. the second object, a small round one, was also identified as a washer or similar item. the astronauts completed their assignment, replacing a video camera and connecting cables, and nasa will conduct a photographic analysis to identify the objects further. these occurrences are common during long spacewalks outside an orbiting space station.
1554	the church of england is at risk of extinction due to a lack of investment in younger generations, according to former archbishop of canterbury george carey. he and current archbishop of york john sentamu warned that the focus on internal debates and arguments is detrimental, while the country's christian population and the church's autonomy face challenges. lord carey emphasized the need to bring young people into the church and involve them, warning of significant decline if not addressed. the synod acknowledged the urgency of addressing this issue amidst declining congregation numbers and external pressures.
1555	london's technology industry is experiencing rapid growth, with new studies showing that it will contribute £12 billion to the economy and create 46,000 jobs by 2024. london's tech sector is growing faster than silicon valley and is a global leader in financial technology. major tech companies like microsoft, google, and samsung, as well as homegrown successes such as mind candy and spareroom, will attend the inaugural london technology week. tech city uk, located in old street and shoreditch in east london, is home to many successful digital businesses including tweetdeck and last.fm. the term silicon valley, coined in 1971, refers to the area around san francisco bay where many tech giants like apple, google, and facebook are based. london is becoming a "digital powerhouse," accounting for 27% of new job creation in the uk, and attracting numerous overseas tech companies like linkedin and solocal. swedish firm klarna, an online payment service, is also expected to invest over £100 million in london.
1556	exxonmobil ceo rex tillerson acknowledged that fossil fuels contribute to climate change but disputed the dire predictions of environmentalists and journalists, stating that humans will adapt to the impacts and the industry will provide reliable energy solutions. tillerson criticized the "illiterate public" for not understanding the risks, while scientists and environmental groups disagreed, claiming that extreme weather events like record heat, severe thunderstorms, wildfires, and drought are evidence of climate change. over 42 million americans are traveling for the fourth of july holiday, while millions more are experiences power outages, heat waves, and drought. severe weather conditions, including thunderstorms and excessive heat, are predicted for much of the country.
1557	google announced the closure of its "google reader" service, which allows users to view updates from their favorite websites in one place, due to declining usage and the company's focus on fewer products. the announcement led to a significant online backlash, with thousands of users expressing their disappointment on social media. alternative rss readers such as feedly, rssowl, and newsblur have seen an increase in interest as users look for alternatives. google is allowing users to export their data, including subscriptions, from google takeout over the next four months. google has also announced the closure of seven other products and services. the closure of google reader, which uses the rss format for creating newsfeeds, has sparked concerns about the risks of relying on a single provider and the difficulty of monetizing rss feeds. google has not disclosed the number of google reader users, but a petition to save the service on change.org quickly gained over 54,000 supporters in about 16 hours. change.org is a for-profit platform that has been effective in facilitating online campaigns, as demonstrated by pepsico's recent removal of a controversial chemical from its gatorade drinks following consumer concerns and an online petition.
1558	bret michaels, the rock singer and reality tv star, is in critical condition after suffering a massive brain hemorrhage at his home in phoenix, arizona, last week. his neurosurgeon, dr. joseph zabramski, announced that michaels' determination to stay conscious during the hemorrhage and get to the emergency room played a crucial role in saving his life. michaels, who has a history of type 1 diabetes and underwent an emergency appendectomy 11 days prior to the rupture, is also dealing with complications from hyponatremia and severe pain. the doctor expressed confidence in michaels' will to recover fully. michaels is currently able to talk and his band is planning to resume their concert tour as soon as may 26, depending on his health.
1559	the article describes the experience of getting a mammogram, a breast cancer screening test, during which a woman's breast is compressed between two panels to take x-rays. mammograms can be uncomfortable, but they are crucial in detecting breast cancer early with a false positive rate of 2-4 per 1000 and a requirement for further testing for approximately 10%. the accuracy of a mammogram depends on the technician and radiologist reading the results, and missing cases of breast cancer is a concern, with doctors missing an average of two per 10. mammograms require women to undress from the waist up and avoid caffeine, deodorant, and other substances that might interfere with the test results. women should schedule their mammograms in the week after their period when their breasts are less tender and visit reputable facilities certified for mammograms for accurate results. patients should also disclose any family history, unusual symptoms, or conditions before the test. mammograms are recommended annually for women over 40, and younger women with a family history of breast cancer may need earlier screening. all mammogram facilities are required to issue results within 30 days.
1560	a new study by herbal stress remedy brand kalms found that women aged 25-34 in britain experience the most stress due to balancing career, family, and personal finances. two-thirds of brits (67%) suffer from stress weekly, and on average, a brit gets stressed 208 times per year. women report more anxiety (five times a week) than men (four times), and women also struggle more with coping mechanisms, such as losing sleep, comfort eating, and drinking alcohol. women are more likely to stress about household chores and relationships, while men worry more about long work hours and getting stuck in traffic. some common ways people cope with stress include spending time with friends, exercising, and ensuring a good wind-down routine to get a good night's sleep. women, particularly those aged 25-34, are the most stressed demographic in britain due to various pressures and challenges in their personal and professional lives. women in this age group are more likely to worry about bills, juggling time, and household chores, while men are more concerned about long work hours and debt. coping mechanisms for stress include avoiding stimulants like technology or alcohol close to bedtime and practicing relaxation techniques.
1561	a young woman named cara reynolds, aged 24 and a size 10, died after taking an overdose of raspberry ketone supplements, which contain over two-and-a-half times as much caffeine as a can of red bull. reynolds had purchased the pills online to help her lose weight, despite not being overweight. the pills, marketed as natural, have been targeted at vulnerable young women and were allegedly endorsed by celebrities on social media. the family called for retailers such as holland and barrett to stop selling these supplements due to the potential dangers. reynolds took the pills in february 2013, and after taking an excessive amount, she had a seizure and died five hours later from cardiovascular collapse caused by caffeine toxicity. this tragic incident highlighted the potential dangers of untested over-the-counter supplements.
1562	hull kr have released forward jonny walker from his contract, effective immediately. walker, a 23-year-old former huddersfield and castleford player, was let go for disciplinary reasons, along with overseas player wayne ulugia last month. ulugia was terminated with over a year left on his deal. in a statement, hull kr expressed well-wishes for walker's future without disclosing the reasons behind his departure. walker, who joined the club from castleford in the offseason, made only eight appearances due to injury.
1563	a 59-year-old grandfather died while saving his 15-month-old grandson from falling into a 30ft well during a nighttime walk. duan shuyo grabbed the boy as he slipped through a crack, but both fell in and became wedged. they were not found until the following morning, with the grandpa still holding the child. the boy had minor injuries, while paramedics believe the grandfather died of a heart attack but continued to grip the child due to muscle spasms and rigor mortis. rescuers had to dig under the gap to free the boy, who is now recovering with his parents. the tragedy occurred near their home in henan province, china.
1564	eleven-year-old paris jackson shocked and moved attendees at michael jackson's memorial service with a tearful tribute to her father. her appearance was a surprise, as she has spent most of her life out of the public eye. paris spoke about her father being the best father one could imagine and expressed her love for him before breaking down in tears. the speech was a rare glimpse into jackson's private life as a father. members of his family, including his siblings and children, went onstage for the last songs, and paris was encouraged by her aunt, pop star janet jackson, to deliver her heartfelt message. paris' tribute touched the hearts of many in attendance and around the world, reminding people of jackson's role as a loving father.
1565	in the digital age, mobile devices are becoming the primary way people access the internet in the us. despite the decline of traditional news outlets, especially those providing local or regional news, mobile news apps offer an opportunity for the ad-supported news business to thrive. according to a study by localytics, people spend around 115 minutes per month on news apps, which attracts advertisers as it increases app engagement. however, not all news organizations directly benefit from ad revenue as many popular news apps are not operated by traditional news brands, but rather by aggregators like flipboard and third-party platforms. this shift in the mobile advertising landscape, which is expected to grow significantly, could provide a lifeline to local news outlets, but only if they adapt to mobile and find innovative revenue models.
1566	the brazilian supreme court ruled in favor of an american father, david goldman, in an international custody battle with his son's brazilian relatives. the ruling comes after a lower court's decision to return the 9-year-old boy, sean, to his father in new jersey was delayed due to a stay. david goldman arrived in rio de janeiro to be reunited with his son, but one justice issued a stay, keeping sean with his brazilian relatives. the high court's ruling lifted the stay, allowing the father to be reunited with his son. the boy's grandmother, silvana bianchi, plans to appeal the decision. the custody battle began in 2004 when the mother took the child from new jersey to brazil for a vacation and never returned. she died last year in childbirthing. goldman has argued for his right to custody as the surviving parent, but the brazilian family argues that removing the child would traumatize him, given that he has lived in brazil for five years. the case garnered media attention and political intervention, with us senator frank lautenberg placing a hold on a trade bill benefiting brazil over the issue, which was later lifted after the court's decision. brazilian attorney general luis inácio adams sided with goldman, stressing the reciprocal nature of international obligations and the potential repercussions for brazil's reputation and access to international assistance if they failed to comply with the decision.
