1567	a new airport plan in the thames estuary, called the thames hub, has gained political backing from senior figures close to british prime minister david cameron, including his strategy chief steve hilton and chancellor george osborne. the £40 billion project, which would include a high-speed railway station and replace heathrow as the largest airport in the uk, has the support of london mayor boris johnson and architect lord norman foster. the airport would be built on a sparse strip of land on the isle of grain in kent and would include four runways, capable of handling 150 million passengers a year. however, opponents argue that the location is not suitable due to the presence of a liquefied natural gas terminal and a power station on the island.
1568	muhammad ali, once a reviled figure in america for his controversial stance against the vietnam war and his association with the nation of islam, is now celebrated as a hero and a cultural icon. a new documentary, "trials of muhammad ali," explores his transformation from a pariah to a revered figure. the film includes footage of ali's 1968 appearance on television where he was criticized by host david susskind. ali was banned from boxing and faced prison time for refusing military induction. he spent his time off from boxing as a speaker on college campuses and in the documentary, his wife khalilah camacho-ali discusses the challenges of that period. the film also includes clips of ali's famous quotes, such as "i don't have to be what you want me to be." ali was eventually exonerated by the supreme court in a landmark decision in 1971, and went on to regain the heavyweight title and become the most famous athlete of his time. the documentary premieres in selected theaters.
1569	a team of palaeontologists in myanmar discovered a tooth belonging to a pre-human ancestor named afrasia djijidae, which is a missing link between africa and asia.the tooth, estimated to be 37-38 million years old, is similar to another early ancestor found in libya, and its discovery confirms that early human ancestors lived in asia before moving to africa in the process of evolution. this find adds to the evidence that asia is the starting point for the human species. the discovery of afrasia's tooth also suggests that our anthropoid ancestors migrated to africa around the same time as the first anthropoid fossils appear in the african fossil record. the team, led by jean-jacques jaeger of the university of poitiers, spent six years sifting through sediment to find the tooth near nyaungpinle in central myanmar. the tooth's similarity to a north african primate, afrotarsius libycus, indicates that these animals ate insects and weighed around 3.5 ounces. this discovery provides critical data for researchers in understanding the evolution of early anthropoids and helps pinpoint the date of asian anthropoids' colonization of africa.
1570	dr. anthony garcia, 40, was arrested by illinois state police on monday in union county on suspicion of carrying out two double homicides in omaha between 2008 and 2013. the victims, creighton university medical school pathology professors roger brumback and william hunter, and brumback's wife mary, had ties to the medical school where garcia was fired in 2001 for erratic behavior. garcia is accused of breaking into the brumbacks' home in may 2013 and fatally shooting and stabbing them. in 2008, he is suspected of stabbing to death hunter's son, thomas hunter, and the family's housekeeper, shirlee sherman. the police believe garcia acted alone and are conducting searches at places where he lived since 2001. a task force of local, state, and fbi investigators have been working on the case, which was featured on "america's most wanted," and $54,000 reward was offered. the families of the victims declined to comment.
1571	tracey connelly, the mother who failed to act while her boyfriend and his brother tortured and killed her 17-month-old son, baby peter, in 2007, could be released on parole within weeks. connelly, 32, has served five years in prison, having been jailed indefinitely in 2009 for doing nothing as her son suffered a catalogue of horrifying injuries, including a broken back. the news of her possible release has horrified baby peter's grandmother, mary o'connor, who stated, "she should never come out." connelly, who has expressed hope of starting a new life in kent with o'connor, was condemned for her role in her son's death and the deaths of two other children on the haringey child protection register. despite her denial of knowing who caused her son's injuries, social workers, health visitors, and doctors had seen the family 60 times before his death. sharon shoesmith, the former children's services chief at the london borough of haringey, has been cleared of personal responsibility for the tragedy. steven barker, the abuser, was given a life sentence, including a 20-year minimum, for raping a two-year-old and causing peter's death. connelly received an indeterminate sentence for her role in the crime. the parole board has confirmed a review of her case has been launched, having previously refused to allow her release from prison.
1572	the international olympic committee (ioc) has suspended the indian olympic association (ioa) over planned elections where an official accused of corruption was set to be appointed. the suspension means indian athletes cannot participate in games and the ioa loses funding. the ioc took this action due to the ioa's failure to inform them in a timely manner and as a protective measure against government interference. ioa shooter abhinav bindra and sports lawyer rahul mehra called for root and branch reform in the ioa. bindra also expressed disappointment in the lack of development of olympic sports in india. mehra welcomed the ioc's decision and emphasized the need for transformation in indian sports.
1573	a scrap yard worker, lee roberts, from wigan, suffered severe burns in 2010 when an electric spark from a drill ignited fuel he was draining from a van, turning him into a human fireball. the incident was captured on cctv footage, showing roberts running for his life as the flames engulfed his legs. roberts received 22% burns to his hands, legs, and nose and was put in a medically induced coma. his former employers, douglas valley breakers, were fined £65,000 for health and safety failings and £25,000 in costs. it was common practice for the company to remove engine and gear box oil from vehicles by puncturing holes in the fuel tanks and draining the flammable liquid into open containers. however, on the day of the accident, there was petrol in the pit, which caused the fire to spread rapidly. the court heard that the company failed to properly consider the risks its employees faced and did not take necessary precautions, allowing workers to drain fuel in a pit surrounded by fuel vapors where a spark from electric equipment could ignite the fuel. hse inspector david myrtle said roberts was lucky to have survived the incident and criticized the company's overall attitude towards health and safety as poor.
1574	joan jett, a rock star and vegetarian who is an advocate for people for the ethical treatment of animals (peta), was removed from a parade float representing south dakota in the macy's thanksgiving day parade after ranchers protested her appearance due to her criticisms of their livestock production. jett is a supporter of peta, which promotes a vegetarian diet and condemns factory farms and ranches. south dakota cattlemen's association expressed concerns about jett representing their state due to its heavy reliance on agriculture and livestock production. macy's announced that jett and her band, the blackhearts, will be moved to another float, and an undetermined performer will take jett's place on the south dakota float. peta celebrated the controversy, with senior vice president dan mathews stating that the meat trade cannot handle scrutiny of its cruelty. several celebrities who support peta have appeared on previous macy's parade floats or performed without controversy, including lea michele, jay mcguiness, jay sean, alan cumming, and carrie underwood.
1575	a large footprint with distinctive ridges and white-gray hairs was discovered by peyton lassiter in vicksburg, mississippi, in august 2023. the footprint, which measures nine inches long and six inches wide at the toes, was not made by a bear, as its color and ridges do not match. lassiter contacted paranormal investigator david childers, who had reported seeing a large grey figure in the same woods the previous november. childers described the creature as six feet tall with a shaggy gray-brown coat. the delta paranormal project is now investigating the area further, as both men believe the creature is likely intelligent enough to avoid detection. similar sightings have been reported in the area since 1721.
1576	a metropolitan transportation authority (mta) spokesperson confirmed that the metro-north train involved in a fatal derailment on sunday was equipped with safety mechanisms, including a "dead man pedal" and an "alerter" system, designed to prevent unresponsive engineers. however, it's unclear if these mechanisms were activated before the crash. the engineer, william rockefeller jr., allegedly fell asleep at the controls and was unable to prevent the train from derailing while it was in "push mode," with the locomotive at the rear pushing the train. a retirement colony resident, denise williams, and another passenger have filed lawsuits against metro-north for negligence in connection to the accident, which killed four people and injured 67 others. the national transportation safety board (ntsb) has excluded the rail union from its investigation due to a confidentiality violation. mta began working on implementing positive train control technology in 2009 and has budgeted nearly $900 million for its installation. the deadline for full implementation is 2015. mta spokesperson salvatore arena stated that the technology is still under development and implementation by the deadline is uncertain. the ntsb's earl weener suggested that positive train control could potentially have prevented a derailment involving a high-speed train.
1577	venezuelan president hugo chavez has traveled to cuba to begin radiation treatment for cancer, following surgery he underwent last month. the expected duration of his treatment is about a month, according to chavez's statement on state media. in february, doctors removed a tumor, and chavez has not disclosed the type of cancer he is battling. his trip to cuba coincides with pope benedict's visit to the island. chavez, a socialist leader since 1999, intends to seek re-election in october. the government has been tight-lipped about the details of chavez's health condition, fueling speculation. cnn's patrick oppmann contributed to this report.
1578	energy secretary ed davey stated that britain has a moral duty to contribute £720 million to a un fund designed to help poor countries adapt to low-carbon energy and tackle climate change in the third world. critics of the foreign aid spending were dismissed as "little englanders" by davey. the fund helps protect sea and flood defenses in less-developed areas, with much of the money being spent in this area. tory backbenchers suggested the money would be better spent on flood defenses in the uk, particularly in the wake of last year's flooding in somerset and lincolnshire. conservative mp sir edward leigh emphasized the need to consider the interests of taxpayers and the uk's borrowing situation. lord stern, a former government adviser on climate change, encouraged policymakers to reduce risk and manage the effects of climate change concurrently. the us, japan, germany, and france have offered substantial pledges to the fund. oxfam gb's mark goldring lauded the uk's contribution as evidence of its leadership in tackling poverty.
1579	a turkish son-in-law, enkar gol, killed his british wife michala, 28, and mother-in-law julie sahin, 50, in a premeditated murderous rampage in thame, oxfordshire, in 2011. gol had met michala during a holiday in bodrum and they eventually married and had two children, despite disapproval from her family. mehmet, julie's husband, expressed shock and grief, saying his wife and daughter-in-law were his only reasons for living. the relationship between michala and gol became controlling, with him physically and verbally abusing her and cheating on her. after reaching a breaking point, gol planned to return to turkey but was persuaded to stay by michala. in the weeks leading up to the murder, he repeatedly boasted on facebook about his plans to "cover london in blood." on the night of the attack, gol stabbed michala and then turned on julie, who had been watching tv downstairs. he escaped with their four-year-old daughter, still holding the murder weapon. gol was found guilty of the murders and attempted killing in may 2012 and sentenced to 36 years for each murder and 12 years for attempted murder to be served concurrently. michala's family, including her uncle, wade anderson, spoke about the tragedy in the new series of "britain's darkest taboos" on the crime + investigation channel.
1580	emily sukiennik and her fiancé mark solper, an experienced base jumper and skydive instructor, performed a death-defying tightrope walk and simultaneous base jump stunt 450ft above a canyon to keep the excitement alive in their two-year-old relationship. the couple, who have a shared passion for adrenaline-fuelled activities, planned and executed the photoshoot in utah, which included multiple attempts at sunrise and sunset for the best lighting. emily focused on crossing the 65ft long wire while mark yelled and screamed with enjoyment during his jump past her. the unforgettable experience left them both feeling "absolutely incredible."
1581	chinese rock icon cui jian, known as "china's father of rock," has declined an invitation to perform on state broadcaster cctv's annual lunar new year television extravaganza. cui, who adopted the hit "nothing to my name" as a protest anthem during the 1989 tiananmen square demonstrations, has had a contentious relationship with the chinese authorities due to the political themes in his music. in the past, he was banned from performing in big venues. lunar new year, or spring festival, is a major holiday in china, and cctv's "spring festival eve gala" was once the country's most-watched variety show. however, the marathon broadcast has lost some of its appeal in recent years and organizers have attempted to revitalize it by inviting international stars like celine dion to perform.
1582	netflix, a california-based streaming service, has launched a new website called "living with spoilers" that allows users to watch short video clips revealing major plot points of popular tv shows and movies, both old and new. the website includes a section called "spoil yourself" where users can play a game with a russian roulette-style interface that randomly reveals spoilers, which are voted on by the public. the site aims to be entertaining rather than a serious attempt to ruin enjoyment of a story. according to netflix's chief product officer neil hunt, the online video market could undergo significant changes in the next decade, with personalized services providing dedicated channels to users based on their preferences, eliminating ads and menus. the website includes a quiz to help users determine their "spoiler type." the survey for the website was conducted in the uk and us, revealing that a smaller percentage of brits accept spoiling shows for others compared to americans, and a larger percentage of brits feel guilt for doing so.
1583	a 9,000-year-old well-preserved bison carcass was discovered in russia in 2011. scientists are performing an autopsy on the specimen, believed to be the first on such an old bison, to gain insights into the causes of the extinction of bison species around 9,000 years ago. the anatomic autopsy includes removing and describing every organ, microbiological and genetic tests, and looking for parasites. histology samples, which show the microscopic anatomy of the animal's cells and tissues, are expected to provide the most interesting findings as they will allow scientists to study parasites attached to ancient bison for the first time. researchers from various russian and u.s. institutions are collaborating on the project. the hope is to map an ancient pasture by studying the remains of foods in the bison's digestive organs, and to publish the findings next year.
1584	prime minister julia gillard's partner, tim mathieson, made an insensitive joke about prostate exams during a lecture to the west indian cricket team at their leader's residence in canberra. he suggested that men should look for a small asian female doctor for a more comfortable experience during the digital examination. gillard, who was present, was not amused and later condemned mathieson's remarks as in poor taste. mathieson, a real estate agent and former hairdresser, apologized and acknowledged that the joke was inappropriate, but defended his commitment to promoting men's health. the incident sparked criticism from some, including shadow attorney general george brandis, who suggested that the joke would have resulted in legal consequences if it had been made after an anti-discrimination bill had passed. the controversy drew mixed reactions on social media.
1585	a german nurse, claus reinauer, returned home in january to find his flat trashed and covered in nazi slurs after a burglary by three neighbors, paul crowther, jamie hooper, and sarah ellis. the trio, who had a longstanding grudge against reinauer, destroyed furniture, defecated on his bedding, and stole sentimental items, including his only memento of his grandfather, a penknife. the attack was racially aggravated, with the words "nazi **" and "kraut nazi b******" written on the walls.the trio were arrested and admitted burglary with intent to commit criminal damage. the judge ruled that the offense was racially aggravated, and all three were sentenced to a year in prison. the defendants' lawyers claimed they were not racist and that the incident was due to previously exchanged insults or being influenced by alcohol.
1586	a cumbrian couple, paul and clare coulston, face the challenging task of making guardianship arrangements for their young children, evelyn, 4, and finlay, 6, as both have been diagnosed with life-threatening conditions. clare, a police sergeant, was given a 30% chance of surviving an aggressive form of oesophageal cancer, which she was diagnosed with in 2009. paul, a deputy headteacher, was diagnosed with motor neurone disease (mnd) in april, which progressively attack the nerves in the brain and spinal cord, and affects every individual differently as it can lead to various degrees of disability. facing these harsh realities, they have been focusing on the importance of their amazing support network and are grateful for the community's efforts, such as a fundraiser tonight, to help them cover costs for their children's holiday, home adjustments, and future financial support. both clare and paul remain positive and resilient, focusing on living in the present moment despite the uncertainty of their health conditions.
1587	protests over a spike in gas prices due to the sudanese government's subsidy lift continued for a fourth day in khartoum and other cities, resulting in gunshots, violence, and looting. high school and college-age youths played a significant role in the initial protest on sunday in wad madani, where one student was killed. police responded with tear gas, but the origin of the fatal shot was unclear. hundreds gathered for similar demonstrations across the country, leading to attacks on gas stations, damage to buses, and looting. the ruling party's offices in khartoum came under attack as well. the internet was out and gunfire could be heard around the capital on wednesday night. the unrest began in response to the government's economic plan, which includes lifting subsidies on gas, causing prices to nearly double, and leading to an anticipated increase in food prices. an aid worker was reportedly killed in an attack in south sudan.
1588	honey boo boo, also known as alana thompson, gained fame from the reality tv series "toddlers & tiaras." her mother, june shannon, who is often referred to as the "coupon queen," saves money through extreme couponing. in a recent episode of the spin-off series "here comes honey boo boo," the family was seen using coupons to redeem free groceries, including 14 packets of chocolate milk powder and ten packages of ramen noodles. june expressed her addiction to couponing, even comparing it to sex. the family's shopping haul included several items that worked out to be free through the coupons. while some critics have accused june of "doping" her daughter with caffeinated drinks and high-sugar snacks, she defends the child pageant industry and insists that it does not sexualize children. the family's unique antics, including their love for couponing and redneck activities, continue to grab headlines as they enter into a new reality tv series.
1589	eric moussambani, a swimming novice from equatorial guinea, made history at the 2000 sydney olympics when he became the slowest swimmer ever to compete in the men's 100 meters freestyle event. with both his competitors disqualified for false starts, moussambani was left alone in the pool, resulting in a memorable two-minute performance where he struggled to keep going, even stopping momentarily to catch his breath. initially a soccer and basketball player, moussabani took up swimming after hearing an advertisement on the radio for tryouts. despite having no formal training, he managed to secure a place on the equatorial guinea olympic team through the international olympic committee's wildcard system. his time of one minute 52.72 seconds was significantly slower than the gold medalist pieter van den hoogenband's time of 48.30 seconds, and moussambani was dubbed "eric the eel" by the media. despite the criticism, moussambani symbolized the olympic spirit and heart, determination, and a never-say-die attitude. the international olympic committee later tightened the rules for wildcard entries to prevent similar situations from happening. however, hamadou djibo issaka, a rower from niger, was hailed as the "new eric the eel" in 2015 when he finished 100 seconds behind his nearest rival in the men's single sculls repechage. moussambani currently serves as the national swimming coach of equatorial guinea and hopes to compete in the 2016 olympics in rio de janeiro before retiring.
1590	ally mccoist managed rangers in their match against queen of the south, where they suffered a 2-0 defeat, with goals from kevin holt and gavin reilly. mccoist faced speculation about his future as the team's performance was underwhelming and they could not afford to lose, given hearts' lead in the title race. the home side was more organized and dangerous, with rangers looking disorganized and demoralized. mccoist stayed on as manager throughout the day, but there were doubts about his ability to turn things around and save the team's season. the defeat was a significant blow to rangers' title hopes and may have sealed mccoist's fate as manager.
1591	a georgia woman, amy seiber, was fired from her job at a wendy's after a customer found a half-smoked marijuana cigarette in her cheeseburger. seiber admitted to police that she had "misplaced" the joint inside the burger after smoking half of it at work. the customer, shalon travis, discovered the marijuana when she got home and noticed an odd odor and a partially smoked cigarette on her burger. travis was taken to the hospital after experiencing symptoms similar to food poisoning. seiber was arrested for possession of less than an ounce of marijuana and was also fired by wendy's management on the same day. the company offered to help travis with her medical bills and provided her with a $50 gift certificate. seiber was able to bond out of jail.
1592	west ham's proposed £3.5million transfer for diafra sakho from metz has been revived after complaints from the french club following the hammers' last-minute change from a permanent deal to a loan move. metz criticized west ham for a lack of respect during the transfer process and threatened to file a complaint with uefa. meanwhile, west bromwich albion are set to bid £7.25million for matt jarvis, who has failed to regain his form at west ham and will likely be sold. jarvis made one appearance for england in 2011 while playing for wolves.
1593	headmistress jayne triffitt of woldingham school in surrey has warned parents that their daughters asking for healthy meals may be signs of early eating disorders due to social pressure and the desire to be thin. she also mentioned that exam stress and heavy workloads in girls aged between 14 and 18 can trigger mental health issues that may lead to eating disorders. research suggests that teenage girls are more prone to depression and anxiety due to increased blood flow to the brain from hormone oestrogen. according to nhs choices, social pressures to be thin, family history of depression, and various age groups can cause different types of eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, bulimia, and binge eating. the study by the university of pennsylvania revealed that blood flow to the brain is higher in women during adolescence compared to men, which might result in disparities in psychiatric disorders. eating disorders affect people of all ages but often develop in teenagers. anorexia affects 1 in 250 women, 1 in 2,000 men, and bulimia affects around 5 times more females than males, typically developing around ages 18 and 19, respectively. binge eating affects males and females equally and usually occurs between ages 30 and 40. one in ten individuals admitted to hospital with an eating disorder were female and aged 15.
1594	a two-year-old syrian boy named bushr al-tawashi was reunited with his family in cyprus after they accidentally left him behind when they fled shelling in damascus. bushr's parents thought he had died when their house was bombed, but he was found alive by rebel fighters and taken care of by family friends. the family, who had believed bushr was dead and had arrived in cyprus seeking asylum, were informed of his survival and underwent a long legal process to be reunited. bushr's father traveled to lebanon to bring him back to cyprus. the family was overjoyed at being reunited, with bushr pulling faces at the cameras and calling out to his older brothers. at least five people were killed and 32 wounded in a car bomb attack in damascus on the same day the syrian government agreed to a four-day ceasefire during eid al-adha. the ceasefire was reciprocated by rebels but warned against past government lies. over 35,000 people have been killed in the syrian conflict since the uprising began in march 2011.
1595	in the 13-minute silent movie "barney oldfield's race for a life" from 1913, oldfield, the most famous auto racer of his time, saves a damsel in distress from a railroad track. one hundred years later, danica patrick, the most famous female auto racer of her day, aims to make history as the first woman to win the daytona 500. despite her renown and wealth, patrick faces criticism and resentment from some who question her abilities as a driver. the daytona 500, which started in 1959, has been dominated by notable racers like richard petty, dale earnhardt, and their families, but no woman has yet won the race. some believe that patrick winning the daytona 500 would make a significant statement for women's sports. the article expresses the writer's belief that a victory for patrick would be a noteworthy accomplishment, despite her controversial past and criticism from some drivers.
1596	moogoo, an australian natural skincare brand, has introduced a line of edible lip balms made with entirely chemical-free, vegetarian, and edible ingredients. the brand opted for red beetroot extract instead of cochineal insect dye, known as "natural red coloring" or "carmine," which is commonly used in cosmetics. red beetroot extract offers a more natural and healthy color when ingested, without the use of insect residue. the balms, available in cow lick, tingling honey, and strawberry tinted flavors, taste of natural strawberry instead of beetroot. moogoo was inspired to create edible lip balms after being dissatisfied with the chemicals used in their previous lip balms and their potential health consequences.
1597	a woman from darwin, australia, and her family were surprised when they discovered a dried cane toad in a packet of beef jerky instead of the expected meat. her father took a bite from the toad without realizing it, describing the experience as "really crunchy and having a nasty taste." cane toads produce poison through their parotid gland, but the family fortunately didn't report any ill effects. due to the abundance of cane toads in the northern territory, some cooks have started using their legs to create new dishes, such as six different recipes developed by a food blogger and her community. the cooks aim to minimize the release of poison while preparing the toads for consumption.
1598	a volcano in guatemala, named volcano de fuego, saw a diminishing eruption on friday, according to emergency officials. the government reported weak and moderate explosions and shorter lava flows. around 5,000 people were affected by the ash and smoke, but only 800 sought refuge in shelters due to fear or prior evacuation. authorities kept a heightened "orange" alert in place. the eruption, the strongest of six this year, started around 10 a.m. thursday and caused respiratory issues for three people. volcano de fuego is known to be one of central america's most active volcanoes. no reports of looting have been made. in other news, no threats have been identified following the eruption of a volcano in nicaragua.
1599	protesters from the occupy wall street movement, who have marched on broadway and stormed the brooklyn bridge in new york, have raised concerns for the world series starting in st. louis, missouri, on wednesday. the first lady and dr. jill biden are expected to attend the game, and police fear potential plans for protests, including setting up tents around busch stadium or having a streaker at the event. the world series opener between the texas rangers and st. louis cardinals will honor military veterans, and approximately 30 protesters have been camping in a nearby park, leading to concerns about "lone wolves" causing trouble. additional security measures have been put in place, and fans have been advised to arrive early. occupy st. louis is part of the larger international movement against the u.s. political and economic systems.
1600	a new zealand tourist named ryan became stranded on governor island off the coast of western australia for two weeks after being stalked by a 20ft-long crocodile. he had intended to explore the island in his canoe but was forced to remain at his hilltop campsite out of reach of the monster reptile. local man don mcleod spotted a light from the island and heroically rescued ryan by boat. the tourist was left relieved and shocked by the encounter and eventually given shelter at a church mission on the mainland. each time ryan tried to leave the island, the crocodile made its presence felt. don mcleod had previously sailed past the crocodile and estimated its length to be 20ft. the tourist had initially tried to paddle back to the mainland for more supplies but abandoned the attempt upon seeing the crocodile.
1601	a 17-year-old named tyler holder is accused of abducting, raping, and killing 6-year-old alanna gallagher in july. her body was found under a tarp with plastic bags over her head, causing asphyxiation. holder acted alone, according to police, and may have used his mother's car to transport the child's body. he is currently in jail on $1 million bail, charged with capital murder and attempted capital murder. holder is also suspected of leaving behind a note for his mother saying "i love you, i'm sorry." he had a history of trouble-making behavior and was described as anti-social. police believe he bound and gagged alanna before raping and killing her, using red duct tape, latex gloves, and a belt with his dna on it. evidence from the scene and holder's home included girls' jewelry, computers, digital cameras, and a journal. he was seen pacing near the scene of the crime the day of the murder and had a history of carrying knives and pulling them on others. holder was shot by police when they attempted to arrest him, and a dna sample taken from him matched evidence found on alanna's body and the belt.
1602	a particularly virulent strain of seasonal flu has caused the deaths of three children in minnesota, with seven others currently receiving intensive care treatment. the dominant strain, h3n2, has proved deadly even for children with no underlying health issues, including 17-year-old shannon zwanziger, who died at mayo clinic in early december after a week-long illness. the cdc has issued an advisory, stating that one component of this year's flu vaccine offers limited protection against the h3n2 strain due to its mutation. the cdc's dr. thomas frieden advises getting vaccinated, as it can still offer partial protection and good protection against other circulating strains. the worry is that the current flu season could be severe without a good match in the vaccine, as past seasons dominated by h3n2 have been particularly challenging.
1603	a volcano named mount tavurvur in papua new guinea erupted on friday, shooting ash up to 60,000 feet into the sky. the eruption occurred on the island of new britain and produced a thick ash plume that was visible from miles away. the volcano is located near rabaul township, and previous eruptions in 1994 destroyed the town due to simultaneous eruptions with nearby mount vulcan. an aviation alert over an iceland volcano was lowered, and restrictions were lifted.
1604	the ballinasloe horse fair, one of europe's oldest and largest horse fairs, is underway in ireland with 80,000 visitors expected. held annually in county galway since the 18th century, the fair has a long-standing association with the irish traveling community and is a significant social and economic event for them. thousands gather in ballinasloe to buy and sell horses, as well as participate in racing competitions. new rules requiring every sale to be declared and registered are in place this year, with high compliance. in addition to horses, livestock like cattle, sheep, and poultry are also sold. the fair attracts vendors from all over the area, and estimates suggest hundreds of horses change hands during the eight-day event. traditional events like horse and buggy racing are also a part of the fair, which draws in large crowds. the fair is held in ballinasloe, the second largest town in county galway, and is a major celebration in the irish traveling community.
1605	blue light-emitting diodes (leds), which were awarded the nobel prize in physics last week for their energy efficiency and longevity, have been found to attract more insects than sodium-vapour lights, according to a new study by new zealand-based institute scion. while leds are more environmentally-friendly than traditional incandescent bulbs, insects, particularly moths and flies, are more strongly attracted to the blue spectrum of light emitted by leds. the study, which involved catching and labelling over 20,000 insects, revealed that simply changing the spectrum of leds did not reduce their attractiveness to insects. three japanese-born scientists, isamu akasaki, hiroshi amano, and shuji nakamura, were awarded the nobel prize in physics for inventing leds in the 1990s. nakamura, who invented the blue led while working for the nichia corporation in japan in 1993, was initially awarded only 20,000 yen (£125 or $200) for his invention, despite its potential worth of £50 billion ($80 billion) by 2020. the concern is that the increased use of led lighting could have negative impacts on insect populations, disrupting the food chain and causing flies to be thrown off their usual paths into the jaws of predators. the study also raised concerns about the potential attraction of led lighting near ports, where flying pests, such as the gypsy moth, could be accidentally transported by ships.
1606	a yemeni official accused houthi rebels of attempting to assassinate him on the same day a cease-fire agreement was supposed to go into effect. gen. mohammed bin abdullah al-qawsi, the deputy interior minister, claimed his car came under heavy gunfire while he was inspecting security forces in the city of saada. troops and rebels exchanged fire there, resulting in one death and injuries, despite both parties signing off on the truce. the official acknowledged that "few skirmishes" were expected in the early stages of the peace deal, citing uninformed militia fighters and tribal revenge killings as possible reasons. the houthi rebellion, which began in 2004, is both separatist and sectarian, and centers around power and the dominance of shiite islam in the region. the peace agreement includes conditions for both parties to respect yemeni law, end attacks within yemen, release captives, and clear mines. the houthis are expected to free seven saudi soldiers on saturday.
1607	burkina faso's hopes of reaching the quarter-finals of the african nations cup are uncertain after a 0-0 draw against hosts equatorial guinea. burkina faso, who lost their opening game 2-0 against gabon, have one point from two matches while equatorial guinea have two due to a 1-1 draw against congo. burkina faso had the better chances but hit the woodwork twice, while equatorial guinea relied on counter-attacks. the home team was saved by the post several times, and diodado mbele escaped a red card for a dangerous tackle on jonathan pitroipa. both teams struggled to find the back of the net, with equatorial guinea's kike being their standout player before being subbed late in the game.
1608	a us airways flight from glasgow to anchorage, alaska, was evacuated and inspected at philadelphia international airport on august 5, 2011, after a threatening note suggesting explosives were on board was received. the meticulous examination by officials and explosives experts found no problems, and the plane continued its journey. passengers were taken to terminal a for questioning, and the plane, which also carried commercial cargo, underwent a thorough search of its cargo and cabin areas. the airport, which handled 31 million passengers in 2010, was not significantly delayed. similar incidents have occurred at other airports, such as reagan national airport in june 2011, where a woman grounded a plane after reporting a bomb threat, which was later determined to be false.
1609	a landlord in stoke-on-trent is facing prosecution for allegedly neglecting repairs on a rental property where a 25-year-old pregnant woman, stacy bowman, died from inflammation to the heart and lungs in december 2011. the landlord, saint pir pandariman, was ordered by the council to complete repairs by november 25, 2011, but inspectors found he had not done so when they visited the property two days before stacy's death. her husband, lee bowman, and previous tenants had reported damp and mould issues. stacy's family and friends have expressed their grief on facebook, with over 400 people joining a tribute page. the council is preparing to prosecute the landlord for failing to make necessary repairs.
1610	an australian special forces soldier from the defence support team drew a loaded gun on an australian secret intelligence service (asis) agent during a drunken encounter in afghanistan last year, according to an intelligence report. the incident occurred despite asis policy prohibiting agents with a blood alcohol content above zero from carrying weapons. a review found that asis had failed to implement adequate controls to prevent the intoxicated agent from accessing a gun. the incident, which had the potential to cause serious injury, was exposed in the annual report by inspector general of intelligence and security dr vivienne thom. she had previously conducted a six-month inquiry into asis' use of weapons before the incident occurred. asis, a highly secretive agency, was previously banned from carrying arms from 2003 following a serious incident in 1983 where trainee spies threatened staff at the sheraton hotel with submachine guns.
1611	a man named bruce dusting, 65, from melbourne, australia, presented his former dance instructor and friend, marie lacombe, 42, with a bill totaling over £115,000 after she rejected his marriage proposal. dusting claimed that lacombe led him on, and he had spent the money on various things like zumba classes, shopping trips, cosmetic surgery, dental appointments, and birthday parties for her and her children. however, lacombe insists they were never romantically involved and that he had given her the money as gifts out of kindness. the situation soured after she declined his proposal, and dusting believes she is trying to extract revenge by billing him for the money. lacombe denies asking him for money for her cosmetic surgery and never received payment for her work as his office assistant. dusting, who met lacombe four years ago, says the emotional stress has caused him to give up dancing.
1612	shane warne, a former australian spinner, has expressed surprise over england's decision to select matt prior as their wicket-keeper for the upcoming test series against sri lanka instead of jos buttler. warne believes that buttler, who averages only 36 in county cricket but recently scored a brilliant one-day hundred, should have been selected due to his batting prowess. england dropped buttler earlier due to his poor keeping performances, but warne suggests that prioritizing batting ability could benefit the team. warne compares buttler to adam gilchrist, who was not a complete keeper when he first joined the australian team but was eventually embraced for his exceptional batting abilities.warne urges alastair cook's men to adopt an exciting brand of cricket during the series.

1614	a ten-year-old girl named latoya smith was killed by a lorry while trying to cross the road on her way to school in peckham, london, in 2010. she was wearing earphones at the time and was changes buses due to heavy traffic. the usual pedestrian crossing was closed, and a sign read 'no crossing here'. witnesses testified that she was hit almost halfway across the road and the lorry did not stop immediately. latoya, who was from penge and attended camelot primary school, was taken to king's college hospital but died of her injuries. she was described as a talented athlete who wanted to be a teacher and a caring girl who volunteered in fundraisers. the inquest is ongoing and is expected to last for five days.
1615	the food and drug administration (fda) is urging vigilance for signs of meningitis among individuals who have used any product from the new england compounding center (necc) after may 21, 2012. at least 233 people have fallen ill, and fifteen have died, primarily after receiving steroid injections for back, neck, and joint pain. the necc produced more than 2,400 drugs and other products, making it difficult for patients and doctors to determine if they were exposed. the fda has not released a list of hospitals and doctors who received necc products, making it impossible for patients and doctors to obtain necessary warnings and treatments. the steroid in question, methylprednisolone acetate, was used in heart and eye surgeries, and another steroid and heart surgery drug may also be linked to new infections. doctors want more specific information to warn and treat potentially affected patients. the fda is working on providing more details and urging swift action.
1616	dan paquette, a builder from davidson, north carolina, gained internet fame after a video of him flipping his hammer in the air and catching it perfectly in his belt holster went viral. the handyman, who specializes in building miniatures and runs a company called tiny house customs, has received praise for his impressive party trick. the clip, which was uploaded to facebook and later to youtube in slow motion, has garnered numerous positive comments. paquette was contacted by the late show with david letterman for his "stupid human tricks" segment. when not performing stunts, paquette can be seen in his youtube videos doing various handyman tasks on tiny houses.
1617	in kinshasa, democratic republic of congo, a group of men known as "les sapeurs" stand out with their eccentric and expensive fashion sense amidst poverty-stricken surroundings. led by papa griffes, a shoemaker, they proudly don designer clothes, including three-piece suits, shiny leather shoes, and accessories. the high costs of these items are kept hidden through trading and repair work, as the sapeurs want to maintain an appearance of wealth and challenge the status quo. this trend, born in the 1960s post-independence era, represents a nod to the congolese elite's newfound empowerment and pride in dressing up after centuries of colonial subjugation. the sapeur movement has garnered international recognition, inspiring books, music videos, and documentaries, providing a refreshing and peaceful outlet for pride and conflict resolution in a country grappling with poverty, political instability, and a complicated history.
1618	meredith hendrix, a 25-year-old graduate student, married her girlfriend kat jackson in october, despite her religious parents refusing to attend. after the wedding, hendrix shared beautiful photographs of the day on tumblr and received overwhelming support from tens of thousands of users. the stunning images show the couple getting ready and exchanging vows, with no negative or homophobic messages received. hendrix and jackson met in college and had faced negative reactions to their relationship, with jackson even being fired from a job after her boss saw them kissing. however, the couple's wedding received an outpouring of love and acceptance online, with hendrix expressing her gratitude in a heartfelt post. the wedding, which took place in arkansas, was filled with personalized details and unique style, and was attended by jackson's parents and other family members. hendrix later thanked tumblr users for their support and acknowledged that not everyone in the world is as accepting as they are.
1619	facebook is considering expanding its facial recognition database by incorporating the profile photos of its 1 billion-plus members to enhance the performance of its 'tag suggest' feature. this feature uses facial recognition technology to help users tag friends in photos. facebook users have the option to remove tags and opt out of the tag suggest feature if they are uncomfortable with facial recognition technology. the database would enable facebook to provide better control over personal information and make it easier to identify posted photos with users in them. however, the company has not guaranteed that it will not use the database for other purposes in the future. facebook also amended its data use policy and statement of rights and responsibilities regarding its use of personal information for ads for users under 18 years old. this change was the result of a recent legal settlement. facial recognition technology remains a sensitive issue due to privacy concerns, and it is not available in europe due to regulatory concerns. google and other companies have implemented different approaches to facial recognition technology in their products.
1620	a georgian-era medicine chest, dating back to the reign of george iii and containing 29 exotically named bottled remedies, is expected to fetch over £3,000 at auction. the chest, which comes complete with an instruction book, includes concoctions made from opium (laudanum), turkey rhubarb, and cream of tartar, among others. some of the "miracle potions" include manna, steer's opodeldoc, peppermint water, lavender, epsom salts, best double-distilled cardamon, and turkey rhubarb. the chest also contains scales, mixing bowls, and a scalpel. the handbook promises that the medicines, while not professional in size, are of the best quality and selected for their efficacy. the chest, which was discovered in a house in derbyshire, was made a year before the first successful blood transfusion and 30 years before the first painless surgery with general anesthetic. mr. hanson, who will oversee the sale in derby on saturday, suspects that the chest may have been used by a doctor on call or owned by the family of a large country house for long journeys.
1621	south korea is revoking the "honorary consul" title from jill kelley, a socialite in florida who became embroiled in a scandal that led to the resignation of cia director david petraeus. kelley will lose her designation due to accusations that she tried to use the title to solicit business and influence, south korean deputy foreign minister kim kyou-hyun told yonhap news agency. kelley was not a diplomat and the title carried no diplomatic immunity, but could be used to promote trade and economic cooperation between the two countries. kelley, whose husband is a doctor, had hosted parties for top military officers, and after petraeus' resignation, she made a call to police claiming she was an honorary consul general and demanding that reporters be kept off her property. a new york businessman claimed that kelley asked him for a $80 million commission if she secured a south korean business contract, and kelley reportedly claimed to be a high-level representative of the south korean government. general john allen, the current commander in afghanistan, is under investigation after allegations of inappropriate emails with kelley, but has denied any wrongdoing. kelley has kept a low profile and has not commented on the situation. the investigation into allen's emails is ongoing and his nomination to become nato's supreme allied commander has been put on hold.
1622	andrew chan, an australian among 20 death row prisoners in indonesia, is on a list for execution this year, despite not receiving a formal rejection of his clemency bid. his fellow conspirator, myuran sukumaran, had his bid officially rejected last week, bringing him closer to facing the firing squad. both men, part of the bali nine group sentenced for heroin trafficking in 2005, have made efforts to rehabilitate in prison through art, cooking, and mentoring programs. a potential new appeal avenue hinges on a dispute between indonesia's constitutional and supreme courts regarding how many times prisoners can seek judicial reviews. the president is expected to uphold his pledge to deny mercy to drug smugglers.
1623	the large hadron collider (lhc), the world's largest particle accelerator located on the border between france and switzerland, is about to begin experiments to explore the universe on a smaller scale than ever before. with a $10 billion investment, the collider is expected to start circulating a beam of protons around the 17-mile tunnel this week, marking a major step towards discovering new information about the universe's formation and possibly finding the elusive higgs boson. skepticism and fears of earth's demise have surfaced, but scientists assure that any potential risks, such as creating tiny black holes, pose no real danger. the lhc, consisting of six detectors, has the potential to confirm long-standing theories about extra dimensions, the birth of the universe, and the origin of matter. collaborators around the world are excited for the first beam test, which is expected to run at higher energies and intensities in the coming months, potentially generating groundbreaking discoveries by 2009.
1624	the uk has experienced extreme weather conditions over the past few days, with the hottest halloween on record being followed by heavy showers, plummeting temperatures, and a tornado in coalville, leicestershire. the tornado caused significant damage to buildings, uprooted trees, and damaged cars. residents reported hearing a loud rumbling sound and seeing debris flying through the air. meanwhile, stormy seas submerged a yacht in the new forest, and the met office predicted cold and unsettled weather for november with bands of rain moving across the country. in contrast, the first day of hunting season proceeded as usual with hounds and horses gathering in the thousands across the uk countryside, taking advantage of loopholes in the law to continue the sport. temperatures are expected to remain close to the average for the time of year, but gritters have been placed on standby for icy climates. meanwhile, a search continued for the missing crew of a fishing trawler off the north-east coast.
1625	former cia deputy director michael morell criticized edward snowden in a recent 60 minutes interview, labeling him a traitor and the most serious intelligence leak in us history. snowden's actions disclosed sensitive information, including the cia budget, which opposing forces could use to their advantage, potentially endangering american lives. the disclosures received similar criticism from the head of britain's intelligence agency, mi5, who called it a 'gift' to terrorists and claimed that thousands of uk-based terrorists have benefited from the leaked information. morell also expressed concern that snowden's files may have been compromised as he traveled from the us to russia. snowden, currently in russia with temporary asylum, has been referred to as a hero by some, while the us government views him as putting americans at greater risk.
1626	aaron jackson, a 21-year-old promising boxer and doorman from leicester, sustained a horrifying injury when thug sanchez moore bit off a chunk of his nose in a row outside a nightclub in june 2022. jackson underwent five painful operations using skin grown on his forehead to reconstruct the missing organ, but his face will never be completely restored. he fears his boxing career and door work are over, as the incident has left him unable to work for six months and filled with doubt. sanchez moore admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent at leicester crown court and will be sentenced on february 27. detective inspector chris hitchin from leicestershire police called the assault "nasty" and "the most horrific" he had seen in his career, leaving jackson scarred for life.
1627	american baker debbie goard creates deceptively delicious cakes that look like savory dishes such as roast ham, tacos, fried chicken, and pizza. her creations, which include a ham cake requested by a comedy club and a chinese noodle cake, are made with basic slab cakes and require long hours of carving and detailing. goard, who has been making cakes for 25 years, is known for surprising customers with her hyper-realistic food-themed cakes that range from simple chocolate cakes to complex dim sum and french bread creations. her recipe for creating realistic textures is a closely guarded secret, but she reveals that her buffalo wing sauce is made from corn syrup and sugars used in old horror films for blood effects. goard, who enjoys the challenge of creating hyper-realistic food cakes, continues to strive for improving her craft and creating more convincing pieces.
1628	communities secretary eric pickles emphasized the importance of speaking english in british society and announced initiatives to help individuals improve their language skills, including supermarket staff serving as "sympathetic listeners" and language classes in mosques, churches, and gurdwaras. over £6 million will be allocated for these projects, targeting areas with high numbers of non-english speakers. the projects include practical language classes and voluntary conversation partners. asda and co-op stores in manchester and yorkshire will offer in-store language help. traditional english language classes were deemed unsuitable for the most isolated individuals, so these projects were prioritized. the schemes aim to increase self-confidence, enable communication with neighbors and friends, and provide opportunities for employment. additionally, pickles hopes to reduce translation and interpretation costs for local services.
1629	esas astronauts are undergoing unusual training for their space mission in dark, damp caves in italy. the "caves" mission, a cooperative adventure for testing human behavior and performance skills, allows astronauts to practice space-like procedures while exploring uncharted caverns. climbing down to basecamp using safety tethers and ensuring the safe transfer of equipment are similar to spacewalks. this year, the astronauts will set up an outpost further from basecamp to spend the night, testing their abilities. additionally, the trainees will measure carbon dioxide and radon levels, take microbiological samples, and test new technology for cavers, including a system combining 3d cameras, laser mapping, and a wearable computer. astronaut tim peake, the first british astronaut in 20 years, recently completed challenging training, including a week in an underground cave and 12 days on the bottom of the sea, to prepare for his mission to the international space station, which includes the potential use of a didgeridoo.
1630	mary portas, a retail expert, was accused of misleading parliament about a £500,000 fee she received from channel 4 following her government-backed review of britain's high streets. during a parliament hearing last week, portas denied receiving the sum, but later admitted in a letter to the communities and local government committee that her contract with channel 4 for two years with a requirement to make 20 episodes amounted to £500,000. portas' review, published in 2011, led to 12 towns receiving £1.2million for renewal schemes, but 700 shops closed and only 600 opened during 2012, with some critics comparing it unfavorably to a gcse student's report. portas could not be reached for comment.
1631	in a study, girls aged three to five consistently preferred thin barbie-style dolls over dolls with larger bodies. the thin doll was considered prettier and happier, while the larger doll was perceived as sad, tired, and having no friends. researchers speculate that this preference may be influenced by their mothers' anxiety about weight and body image. the study's results underscore the need for young children to learn that diverse body sizes do not determine happiness or success.
1632	durex, a condom company, has introduced "fundawear," a line of wearable technology designed for long-distance lovers. this lingerie features vibrators that can be remotely activated through a smartphone app, allowing couples to simulate touch over the internet. the underwear is part of durex's "durexperiment" team's goal to unveil more innovative foreplay products. couples can sign up on facebook to test the prototype. technical director ben moir described the project as "awesome" and believes it will be popular.
1633	alastair cook, the england captain, has faced criticism for his team's poor performance in the ashes series and personal distractions off the field, including expecting his first child and buying a £1.2million farm. cook's negotiations for the farm, which includes a country mansion and extensive equestrian facilities, have been a source of stress. colhin graves, yorkshire chairman and deputy chairman of the ecb, has also had a difficult year, as his house was raided by armed robbers and £220,000 worth of jewellery was stolen. relationships between the english and australian teams improved at a reception hosted by the australian prime minister, but the ecb remains angry with cricket australia's use of social media. piers morgan continues to seek attention with his self-promotion tour down under, and ian ward is being considered as a potential successor to david gower as lead presenter for sky sports.
1634	angel di maria, a manchester united soccer player, was the victim of a burglary attempt at his cheshire mansion on saturday night. three thieves used scaffolding poles to try and break through patio doors while di maria, his wife jorgelina cardoso, and one-year-old daughter mia were having dinner. the alarm went off before the intruders entered, and the family was whisked away by united's security team and taken to a hotel by police. di maria, who joined united in a £59.7 million deal from real madrid, was playing for the team earlier that day in their 3-1 win over leicester city. police are investigating the incident.
1635	a 25-year-old mother from leeds, lissani, regrets getting a giant tattoo on her chest at the age of 18 as an act of rebellion against her strict catholic upbringing. she now wishes she had thought more carefully before getting inked and regrets the permanent reminder of her past. the tattoo is hard to conceal and has caused her embarrassment and feelings of being judged. the mother of three intends to go back to university to train as a midwife but fears the tattoo could hold her back due to her uniform. despite undergoing painful laser removal surgery, the tattoo is only becoming faint, and lissani urges young people to carefully consider the lifelong commitment of getting a tattoo. bodyshockers: nips, tucks, and tattoos airs on channel 4 wednesdays at 10 pm.
1636	branislav ivanovic shared that jose mourinho scolded chelsea players during halftime for their slow and unimpressive performance against maribor in the champions league. the team managed to equalize with a goal from nemanja matic but failed to secure a win. mourinho was reportedly furious with the italian referee's decision on a diego costa goal that was ruled offside. chelsea still leads group g and faces liverpool in the premier league on saturday. mourinho expressed disappointment in the team's stability and the need for them to play for the full 90 minutes to improve results. chelsea's upcoming champions league match against schalke will determine their qualification to the last 16.
1637	andy leeks, who is 5 ft 11in tall and weighed 16 stone, was mortified when colleagues started calling him "big man." he was determined to lose weight but had struggled to keep up with diets in the past due to boredom. to combat this, he decided to try ten different diets in 50 days to see if changing diets regularly would help him lose weight without losing interest. andy underwent a health screening with his gp before starting the challenge and began with the 5:2 diet, restricting calories for two days and eating normally for the rest of the week. he lost 5 lb after completing the first diet but found the following special k diet boring, and the juicing diet difficult to prepare and follow. he lost less weight on diets with calorie tracking, grapefruit, and baby food, opting instead for a raw food diet that required consuming only uncooked, unprocessed foods. however, this left him feeling run down and eventually resulted in an infection. he lost the least weight on the cabbage soup diet, which he found unappetizing. after losing a total of 30½ lb, andy realized that the nhs-recommended diet was the only one he could stick to long-term. he learned that daily weigh-ins and strict diets could be demotivating, while the variety of the ten-diet challenge helped him focus on other changes like a reduced double chin, clearer skin, and easier weekly runs. however, his gp expressed concern about the increase in his "bad" ldl cholesterol and urged him to keep the weight off for improvements to occur.
1638	a growing number of doctors, dentists, vets, and lawyers are struggling with alcoholism, but are able to function in their professional lives, earning the label "functioning alcoholics" from addiction specialists. this trend is particularly evident in the uk, which has the highest rate of oesophageal cancer in europe due to binge drinking and obesity. demand for rehab treatment abroad is increasing among professionals to avoid recognition in local hospitals or clinics. uk experts estimate that one in 15 doctors and three times the general population will develop addiction, while up to 24% of lawyers may struggle with alcoholism during their careers. however, many professionals find it difficult to seek help due to the stigma attached to addiction. at an international conference in ireland, calls were made to address the growing issue and improve access to appropriate treatment for health professionals.
1639	fulham owner shahid khan is expected to announce kit symons as the new manager this week, after the caretaker boss led the team to five wins from eight games and lifted them out of the championship relegation zone. symons took temporary charge in september and has overseen better results than any other team in the month following, with only bournemouth and derby county having a better record. previous candidates, such as steve bruce, chris hughton, and steve clarke, had been considered but symons' success with fulham seems to have sealed his appointment.
1640	tom brady, the new england patriots quarterback, expressed that the allegations of football tampering in the ongoing deflate-gate controversy, where 11 of the 12 footballs used by the patriots offense during the afc championship game were found to be under-inflated, had personally hurt his feelings. brady denied any involvement in the incident and attempted to move past it. critics have suggested that team owner bob kraft could influence the nfl investigation due to his close relationship with commissioner roger goodell, and seattle seahawks cornerback richard sherman has criticized the potential lack of punishment for the patriots due to this conflict of interest. brady has now blocked out the deflate-gate speculation and is focusing on the super bowl against the seahawks, denying contact from investigators and claiming he didn't expect to be contacted until after the game. the patriots' historically low fumble rate is considered statistically improbable, and critics suggest that under-inflated balls could have contributed to this.
1641	celebrity chefs heston blumenthal and peter gilmore spoke at the launch of perth's margaret river gourmet escape food festival, expressing concerns about the rising cost of food in australia. gilmore, the executive chef at sydney's quay restaurant, emphasized the exceptional quality of dining but acknowledged that it's not cheap. blumenthal agreed, stating that people need access to affordable food but should not expect prices to go down when other costs are rising. he warned that reducing food prices would damage the food and agriculture industries, as producing and distributing food involves various costs. both chefs believe that consumers must understand and accept the need for higher food prices. for instance, blumenthal's restaurant, the fat duck, will charge $525 a head during its temporary location in melbourne's crown casino. the margaret river gourmet escape is a three-day food and wine festival held annually in perth.
1642	according to an article published by anna hodgekiss on may 17, 2013, cities in the uk have become hay fever hotspots, with london, birmingham, and manchester leading the way in demand for hay fever treatments. experts believe the increase in urban hay fever sufferers could be due to pollution making symptoms worse. oak or plane tree pollen, which normally peaks in march and april, has been delayed this year, creating a higher allergy risk in late spring. pharmacists are also advising patients to differentiate between hay fever and the common cold, as symptoms and treatments vary. hay fever symptoms include itchy and watery eyes, runny nose, and clear discharge, while a cold typically causes a runny nose with thick and colourful discharge, sore throat, cough, and headache. pharmacists recommend antihistamines, showering and changing clothes, and wearing wraparound sunglasses to help manage hay fever symptoms.
1643	photographer ed james has captured a series of striking images showcasing 10 seemingly ordinary objects that have been used as murder weapons in real-life crimes. these objects range from a stiletto heel, an electric guitar, a jar of pickled cucumbers, and a crucifix to more unusual items like a spoon, ballpoint pen, and a toilet tank lid. the photographer intentionally lit and presented each object out of context, to mirror the bizarre way they were used in the killings. the images are meant to unsettle and provoke, yet intrigue viewers. notable cases include a texan woman murdering her boyfriend with a stiletto heel and a ohio male killing a man with a jar of pickled cucumbers. james wanted to explore the dark subject while maintaining an artistic approach, without naming the perpetrators in the images. his favorite type of photography is conceptual and the series began when he discovered numerous online articles about murders committed with "strange" weapons. as a professional advertising photographer, ed james lives in athens, georgia, with his family and dog. he previously worked as a roofer but found his passion for photography after quitting and pursuing a foundation course, eventually studying photography, film, and television for five years. notable murder cases include a 44-year-old man using a house brick to kill another man in hartford, england, and a 31-year-old man killing a man with a teaspoon in st. albans, england.
1644	a group of friends had an unforgettable night a year ago in a queens basement during the economic downturn, listening to records and eating muffins. vinyl is experiencing a resurgence as an alternative to digital music, with warner music executive mike jbara noting its passionate appeal. to throw your own record party, obtain a record player and speakers, start a collection affordably by shopping at record stores or thrift shops, keep the guest list small and have everyone contribute food and drinks. establish rules and traditions for requesting songs.
1645	a 13-year-old boy, cameron crossan, racked up a £3,700 bill on his father's credit card while making in-app purchases on games like plants vs. zombies, hungry shark, gun builder, and nova 3 on his ipad. his father, doug crossan, who is a police constable with avon and somerset police, was shocked by the amount and contacted his credit card company to file a fraud complaint against his son. however, crossan admitted he could have punished his son himself and filed the complaint in the hope of getting the money refunded from apple. apple has refused to cancel the charges, and crossan is considering taking legal action. crossan claimed that cameron was unaware he was being charged for the purchases and that there was no indication in the games that he was being charged. the incident is among a growing number of cases of children racketing up large bills on apps without their parents' knowledge. apple has faced criticism for not providing clearer warnings about in-app purchases and for not automatically refunding unintended charges.
1646	the u.s. secret service and connecticut state police are searching for a silver 2014 volkswagen jetta with connecticut license plates, believed to be driven by a man who may have threatened president barack obama. the secret service received information about a potentially suspicious person and vehicle, and the person of interest is believed to be armed with an assault rifle. obama arrived in rhode island on friday for a fundraiser, and the search is ongoing while the president is in the area. the threat appears to have originated from new york. obama safely departed rhode island and returned to washington d.c. later that evening.
1647	in the round of 16 match between the united states and belgium at the world cup, tim howard made a record-breaking 15 saves, keeping his team in the game until extra time. however, two goals from belgium's romelu lukaku and kevin de bruyne secured a 2-1 victory for the europeans, sending them through to the quarter-finals against argentina. united states coach jurgen klinsmann praised howard's "phenomenal" performance and expressed pride in his team's efforts despite their loss. obama watched the game from the white house and acknowledged belgium's dominance, while lukaku downplayed his impact on the game. marc wilmots, belgium's coach, acknowledged the difficulty of the match and expressed relief at the outcome.
1648	in new delhi, india, the competition to get children admitted into reputed nursery schools is intense, with many schools receiving thousands of applications for limited spots. the kumars, a married couple, had applied to salwan montessori school for their three-year-old daughter, janhavi, but were rejected ten times. schools are conducting informal interactions with parents, which they claim is for the child's benefit, but parents see it as a tests for the parents. the pressure to get their children into the best schools is high, and the competition is especially fierce in new delhi. salwan montessori school received 2,500 applications for 150 spots, with only 6% of applicants getting in. the importance of nursery school admission is significant because students often spend 14 years in one school. at salwan montessori, children learn public speaking, music, several sports, and social skills along with their basic education. however, many parents reject government schools due to concerns over infrastructure, running water, and teacher attendance. despite these challenges, the headmistress of salwan montessori urges parents to remember that not getting into their preferred school does not mean their child will be unsuccessful. the kumars, disappointed and frustrated, were forced to enroll janhavi in a lesser-known private school but plan to try the admission process again next year.
1649	israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu met with us lawmakers, including democrat steve israel, to discuss ways of avoiding war crimes charges at the international criminal court (icc) for israel's actions in gaza. palestinian officials are considering joining the icc to have israel investigated for alleged war crimes during the recent fighting. netanyahu maintained that israel's military strikes, resulting in civilian deaths from palestinian rocket attacks by hamas, were in self-defense. approximately 1,900 palestinians have been killed, three-quarters of whom were civilians, according to the united nations. israel said 900 palestinian militants were also among the dead, along with 64 soldiers and three israeli civilians. the conflict was triggered by the abduction and killing of three israeli teens and retaliatory attacks on palestinians. netanyahu and israeli officials argued that israel has the right to defend itself but criticized the destruction of several un schools in gaza. hamas militants, on the other hand, have been using civilian areas for launching attacks against israel and hiding in tunnels. the militant group claimed that 23 of its fighters were freed from an underground tunnel three weeks after being trapped in an israeli strike. the disasters emergency committee launched an appeal for aid to help hundreds of thousands of displaced palestinians in gaza, with up to 1.5 million lacking access to water, sanitation, or medical care.
1650	a pensioner, david mcmahon, is suing professional golfer gavin dear for £50,000 after being blinded in one eye by a golf ball during the scottish amateur champion of champions event in 2009. mcmahon was on the course looking for strayed balls when he was hit by a shot from dear's club. the pensioner claimed he had asked a couple to move from a dangerous area before being struck, but dear denied seeing anyone in the path of his ball. the case is ongoing, with both parties disputing liability. mcmahon, 70, suffered a traumatic rupture of the right eyeball and is seeking compensation as the golfer is alleged to have known or ought to have known that mcmahon was in the line of the ball's path. the case continues in court.
1651	the georgian kings mill house in great shelford, cambridgeshire, which inspired the beloved children's novel "tom's midnight garden" by philippa pearce, is on the market for £3.45 million. the 3.5-acre property, where pearce spent her childhood years, includes a five-bedroom main house and a two-bedroom cottage, as well as sprawling grounds with a walled garden and medieval fish ponds. pearce's idyllic childhood experiences and deep love for the house influenced her 1958 novel, which tells the story of a boy, tom, who escapes into the garden nightly and plays with a girl who ages rapidly, actually an elderly and reclusive landlady. pearce's daughter, sally christie, who now lives near the house, expressed her mother's affection for the place and noted that she would be surprised by its hefty price tag. james barnett of savills, the estate agency handling the sale, said interest in the house has been significant due to its connection to the literary work. the reasons for the current owners' decision to sell are unknown.
1652	president barack obama paid a visit to the henry ford museum in michigan to reflect on the significance of the bus where rosa parks, a civil rights icon, had refused to give up her seat for a white passenger in 1955. the event took place during obama's campaign trip and occurred exactly 60 years after rosa parks' arrest, which sparked the montgomery bus boycott and played a pivotal role in the civil rights movement. the boycott led to the desegregation of the montgomery bus system and the end of jim crow laws. parks received numerous accolades, including the presidential medal of freedom in 1996, and died in 2005 at the age of 92. obama shared a moment of contemplation on the bus, acknowledging the courage and determination of everyday americans in driving change. he spoke to 600 guests at the museum, some of whom had paid to attend, reaffirming the need for persistent effort in achieving societal progress.
1653	sir christopher meyer, a former uk ambassador, criticized the leveson inquiry into press standards, labeling it a "show trial, seminar, and truth commission" with a "whiff of totalitarianism." he warned against censorship of newspapers and expressed concerns that the inquiry might prejudice ongoing police investigations. sir christopher defended the press complaints commission (pcc) and argued against its abolition, stating that it should be strengthened instead. he also expressed concerns about the inquiry's ambitious remit and possible interference with journalists' freedom of speech. lord justice leveson has made it clear that new regulations are coming, and sir christopher urged him to be wary of those advocating for a singular version of truth, which could potentially endanger the open society.
