1654	a florida doctor threatened to call the police and have them forcibly bring a pregnant woman to the hospital for a cesarean section after she refused to undergo the procedure despite her high-risk pregnancy and the baby being overdue. dr. jerry yankowitz, the head of obstetrics at the university of south florida hospital, had initially agreed to help lisa epstein, 35, try for a vaginal birth for her fifth child. however, after her pregnancy complications worsened, including gestational diabetes, he sent her an email stating he would have law enforcement take her away if she did not come in for delivery. epstein, who had four previous cesareans but wanted a natural birth, reportedly feltthis was a threat and called a support group, national advocates for pregnant women (napw), for assistance. napw's attorney, farah diaz-tello, contacted yankowitz and advised him to stop the threats. epstein eventually scheduled a cesarean section for her baby, who was not in an ideal position for a vaginal birth. this incident brought up concerns of past controversial cases, such as the one involving laura pemberton in the 1990s, who wanted a vaginal birth at home with a midwife and was forcibly taken to the hospital for a cesarean. some experts say that while having a vaginal birth after cesarean is possible in some cases, having multiple cesareans can pose risks to both mother and baby.
1655	leaders from afghanistan, turkey, and pakistan have agreed to hold joint military drills in april 2011, following a meeting in istanbul. turkish president abdullah gul expressed his satisfaction with the development, stating that it would contribute to stability and security in the region. during a news conference, afghan president hamid karzai suggested that hosting a taliban office in a neutral country, such as turkey, could help bring about peace. turkey's president gul was unaware of the suggestion but expressed a willingness to support efforts towards afghanistan's stability. former taliban ambassador to pakistan, mullah zaeef, had earlier suggested this idea in an article published in the daily telegraph.
1656	health experts advise against washing chicken before cooking as it can spread harmful bacteria, such as campylobacter, which is responsible for around 280,000 food poisoning cases in britain each year, with contaminated chicken causing four out of five cases. rinsing chicken can spread bacteria on kitchen surfaces and equipment, increasing the risk of infection for those who come into contact with it. the most common symptoms of campylobacter food poisoning are abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, and vomiting, but in severe cases, it can lead to hospitalization, dehydration, and even life-threatening complications like reactive arthritis, irritable bowel syndrome, and guillain-barré syndrome. the bacteria costs the uk economy hundreds of millions of pounds each year in sick leave and healthcare treatment. although most harmful germs are killed by cooking chicken thoroughly, washing it under a tap can spread bacteria up to three feet. the fsa recommends following safe handling practices, such as washing hands after touching raw chicken and ensuring it is cooked properly, but avoiding the unnecessary step of washing it before cooking. former campylobacter food poisoning survivor ann edwards urge people to take care when handling chicken, as she was left paralyzed from the chest down after contracting the bacteria in 1997.
1657	choirmaster barry todd, 64, regained consciousness from a 10-day coma caused by a ruptured aortic aneurysm after his wife, carol, played a recording of his singers for him. todd, who had spent his career in the entertainment business, started whistling along to the pinocchio song "give a little whistle" while he was semi-conscious. he survived the initial rupture but needed 12 surgeries and had a leg amputated and most of his bowel removed. the incident occurred despite todd being at a relatively young age for an aortic aneurysm and not having any known risk factors. todd hopes to conduct his choir again later this month.
1658	novak djokovic, the world number one tennis player, eased past diego schwartzman in the us open first round with a 6-1 6-2 6-4 victory. djokovic had concerns over his form and mindset after a busy summer personal life, which included marriage and the upcoming birth of his first child. he had a sluggish start to the hard-court season, losing early in toronto and cincinnati. in the match against schwartzman, djokovic raced to a 4-0 lead, with schwartzman only winning a game until he was 2-0 down in the second set. djokovic's precision on shots was too good for schwartzman, and he served out the victory after an hour and 37 minutes. djokovic, who next plays paul-henri mathieu, said he was pleased with his performance and enjoyed playing under the lights on arthur ashe stadium.
1659	pippa middleton, duchess of cambridge's sister, has been appointed as a contributing editor for vanity fair magazine, where she will share her thoughts on classic british pastimes. her first piece for the magazine is a guide to wimbledon, offering advice on experiencing the tennis championships, such as arriving early and avoiding long walks in stilettos. middleton gained global attention following her sister kate's wedding to prince william in 2011 and secured a book deal on entertaining. however, her previous attempts at writing, including a cookery column for waitrose, were met with criticism. vanity fair expressed enthusiasm for middleton's appointment, highlighting her observations of british traditions and her love for sports.
1660	diver eli martinez has built a unique relationship with a group of tiger sharks in the bahamas, where they now allow him to touch and even roll over for him. after a decade of visiting the same location, martinez, from alamo, texas, can identify individual sharks and has named some of them, including "hook" and "alex." despite the level of trust he has established, martinez remains cautious, as the tiger sharks are still dangerous predators and deserve respect. he is surrounded by several tiger sharks, as well as lemon sharks and reef sharks during his visits to the beach.
1661	a hospital patient in hereford, uk, is being tested for ebola as a precaution after showing early symptoms and a travel history to west africa. a gp clinic was sealed off as a result, causing concern among patients and the public. the risk of ebola spreading in the uk is considered very low, but authorities are taking precautions and advising frontline medical practitioners to be alert for symptoms in travelers. a group of nhs volunteers have been sent to west africa for training to help combat the ongoing ebola outbreak, and the uk government has pledged an additional £1.34 million for research on fighting the virus.
1662	julian assange, the founder of wikileaks, lost his bid to avoid extradition to sweden to face sex charges. he grew up with parents in australia's theater business and was driven from a young age by a sense of fighting for justice. assange has been a global figure since wikileaks began releasing classified us documents in 2010, sparking debate over free speech and global security. his parents describe him as intelligent and driven to do what he perceived as just. assange started hacking as a teenager and went on to focus on government wrongdoings. he founded wikileaks in 2006 and has been the organization's public face, taking on the role of a lightning rod for criticism. his mother fears the challenges he's taking on have become too big for him.
1663	the extreme sailing series is a high-speed, extreme sailing event that features catamarans reaching top speeds of 30 knots (35 mph/56 kph). races take place across the globe and attract well-known sailors such as america's cup winners ben ainslie and ernesto bertarelli. the short, sharp races last only 10 to 12 minutes and can be hectic due to close competition and occasional crashes. crews consist of five members, including a vip or guest, and there are eight rounds, or "acts," in each season, with racing taking place in stadiums and open waters. with its unpredictable sailing and occasional collisions, the series has been described as the formula one of sailing. ben ainslie, a four-time olympic champion, is participating in the 2014 season to quench his racing hunger and prepare for a potential british entry into the america's cup. competition is fierce, with leigh mcmillan, a one-time olympian, currently considered the one to beat. the series begins in singapore and ends in sydney, with visits to st. petersburg, russia, and istanbul, turkey, among others.
1664	chloe mccardel, an australian long-distance swimmer, gave up her quest to become the first person to swim from cuba to florida without a shark cage on june 12, 2013. she was forced to abandon her attempt after 11 hours due to painful jellyfish stings, which left her in excruciating pain during her rescue and trip back to key west. mccardel had picked june for the swim due to the supposedly low risk of jellyfish, but found herself in a swarm that left her with no recollection of the moment. she suffered stings to her mouth, arms, and other parts of her body. experts believe she was attacked by a box jellyfish, which is common in the florida straits. her failed attempt was the fifth in the past three summers, with jellyfish stings and strong currents being the main impediments. mccardel spent nine and a half months planning her trip and studying others' attempts, but ultimately spent only 25 hours continuously in the water. she had intended to follow english channel marathon rules, which meant no touching the support boat or holding on to anything, and no full-body wetsuit to protect against jellyfish. despite the failed attempt, mccardel vowed never to return to the infested waters of cuba. her previous longest swim was for 25 hours, and the cuba-to-florida swim, which is stretching the physical limits of elite endurance athletes, covers a distance of around 160 km (100 miles) in the challenge of battling the jellyfish and strong currents. dr. clifton page, a sports medicine specialist, believes the swim is doable but has several physical obstacles to overcome, including hypothermia, malnutrition, dehydration, and sleep deprivation.
1665	retail company big w is facing criticism for selling christmas shirts with inappropriate slogans, specifically one with the phrase "nice baubles." an outraged shopper, rebecca holloway, started a petition to have the shirt removed, arguing that it sexualizes young girls and teaches them to objectify women. collective shout spokesperson coralie alison supports the campaign, stating that such products can be harmful to young girls and drawing attention to big w's past controversies involving sexualized products for children, such as scratch-and-sniff underwear. big w has faced backlash on social media, with parents expressing their concerns and calling the products inappropriate and unnecessary. the retail giant has been urged to enter into discussions with collective shout about adhering to a corporate social responsibility pledge to avoid objectifying women and sexualizing children.
1666	a teenage boy named kanhaiya kumari, born in an indian prison where his mother vijaya kumari had been held since 1993 due to inability to pay 10,000 rupee bail money, managed to secure his mother's release. vijaya, 48, was arrested in relation to a murder case in aligarh district, but gave birth to kanhaiya while incarcerated. after being granted bail in 1994, she was unable to obtain her freedom due to her husband's abandonment. kanhaiya, who spent seven years in a juvenile remand home after being sent there at the age of 11, got a job in a factory following his release last year and worked to gather the necessary bail money. with kanhaiya's lobbying efforts, the allahabad high court granted vijaya's bail, and mother and son were finally reunited on may 5, 2013.
1667	at least 181 people have died and thousands have been left homeless due to flooding and mudslides in rio de janeiro, brazil, after a record-breaking 11.3 inches (287 millimeters) of rain fell within 24 hours tuesday. at least 161 people were injured and over 30 homes were destroyed in a mudslide wednesday, with more than 80 people dead and dozens missing in niteroi and sao goncalo. the government has set aside $9.8 billion to help cities deal with flooding and poor infrastructure, with an additional $11 billion made available by president luiz inacio lula da silva to improve drainage infrastructure across brazil. about 4,000 homes can be rebuilt, along with roads, schools, and health centers to provide better living conditions. minister of cities marco fortes said, "you can't correct the past, but you can fix the future."
1668	an african-american couple, charles and te'andrea wilson, were forced to change the venue of their wedding at the first baptist church of crystal springs in mississippi due to opposition from some congregants because of their race. the pastor, stan weatherford, made the request to move the wedding to avoid controversy within the church. while some church members have since offered apologies, the couple is deeply hurt and disappointed, with te'andrea wilson expressing regret about not being able to have her wedding as she had planned. the incident has raised questions about the church's stance on racial inclusion and equality. the north dakota paper also recently reviewed a ban on same-sex wedding announcements.
1669	debbie goard, a cake maker from oakland, california, has been creating stunning shoe replicas out of cake for over a decade. her highly detailed and accurate shoes, which sell for upwards of $350 each, take hours to make and range from sneakers to designer labels. goard, who has been baking for over 25 years, uses templates and blueprints to ensure accuracy and goes to great lengths to make her cakes as realistic as possible. her shoe cakes, which are made of fondant, buttercream, and cake, have become a hit among clients for birthdays and other special occasions. goard, who is inspired by the sculptural nature of shoes, has also made cakes in the shape of other objects, such as pigs. despite the challenges of making closed shoes out of edible materials, goard has sold over 2000 cakes in her 25-year career and continues to amaze clients with her creations.
1670	royal ascot's ladies day was filled with color and excitement, as the queen attended the event for a fourth day, wearing a radiant blue outfit and joined by her second son, the duke of york, and daughter-in-law, the countess of wessex. the day was marked by lavish hats, glamorous outfits, and the return of monochrome trends. racegoers were seen in all kinds of ensembles, from delicate floral prints to bold brights, while the fashion police were out in force. jockey richard hughes won the coronation stakes on horse sky lantern, and the crowd cheered on top fillies and paid tribute to legendary trainer sir henry cecil. the queen's vase was run in his memory, and his wife, lady cecil, temporarily took over his training license. racegoers dressed in various designs, from simple white dresses with union jack fascinators to elaborate hats and nude tones, creating a truly diverse and colorful scene. a group of chelsea pensioners posed with members of the armed forces outside the royal enclosure, while other racegoers donned navy blue sailor dresses and sought refuge from the fashion police in cardboard wine carriers disguised as designer handbags. the atmosphere was filled with excitement, with racing action and fashion taking center stage at this year's royal ascot.
1671	a 33-year-old florida man, jason lucas revis of oviedo, was found guilty of molesting a 10-year-old girl after a four-hour trial. the victim's mother stabbed revis when she walked in on the abuse but did not report it until the girl confided in a friend two years later. the girl testified that revis had asked her to touch him inappropriately in september 2011, and despite the defense attorney's suggestion that she was making up the story, she insisted that it was true. revis is set to be sentenced on monday.
1672	a tennessee woman, identified as julia shields, 45, is facing multiple charges including three counts of attempted first-degree murder, seven counts of aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during a felony, felony evading arrest, and felony reckless endangerment, after she drove around in a dark-colored sedan dressed in body armor, randomly shooting into vehicles and pointed her gun at drivers in a chattanooga neighborhood on friday afternoon. witnesses reported that shields approached vehicles with her window down, poised to shoot, and fired into at least two vehicles. police responded to the scene and saw shields in a church parking lot, leading to a brief police chase where she allegedly pointed her gun at motorists and an officer. shields was taken into custody without incident or injury and is currently being held at the hamilton county jail.
1673	a tuft of blonde hair was discovered about a mile from where 10-year-old jessica ridgeway's dismembered body was found in colorado, prompting speculation it may be related to the case. however, investigators are dismissing the claim as erroneous and misleading, stating they have yet to determine if the hair is even human, let alone belonging to jessica. a wooden cross, which may be a vital piece of evidence in the case, was also found recently. the investigation has shifted from finding jessica to identifying the unknown suspect, with the community rallying around the family in support. over 1,500 tips have been received and authorities have searched over 500 homes and 1,000 vehicles, but they continue to need the public's help. the focus has changed to ensuring justice for jessica, as the predator responsible for her abduction and murder remains at large.
1674	lee harvey oswald's 14-karat gold wedding ring, engraved with hammer and sickle symbols, will be auctioned off along with over two dozen other personal items belonging to the notorious assassin on october 24, 2013. the ring, which was purchased in minsk, belarus, before oswald's marriage in 1961, was returned to his widow, marina oswald porter, in 2012 after it was discovered among the files of a fort worth lawyer. the ring, accompanied by a five-page handwritten letter from marina, is one of the priciest items in the auction, with a starting bid set at $2,500. other items in the collection include oswald's first handgun, marine corps knife, correspondence, chess set, weapons, and clothing. marina is selling the items to let go of her past connection to the kennedy assassination. the auction, being held by rr auction in boston, will feature items with starting bids ranging from $200 to $2,500.
1675	a jetblue passenger jet was forced to abort its take-off at new york's john f. kennedy international airport after a caribbean airlines plane suddenly crossed the runway without authorization. jetblue flight 1295 was rolling down the tarmac at full speed when the caribbean airlines boeing 737, which had just landed from guyana, appeared in its path. both planes avoided a collision, and no injuries were reported. the caribbean airlines flight crew were on the wrong frequency and did not receive tower instructions to stop, according to wabc-tv. the faa is investigating the incident, which occurred more than 2,800 feet away from the jetblue plane, and jetblue's plane eventually took off for austin, texas, three hours late.
1676	a 12-year-old girl named katie webb from evesham, worcestershire, took her own life after reportedly being bullied online and at school over her hairstyle and clothing. friends paid tribute to katie on social media, condemning the bullies and expressing their condolences. a tribute page gained over 2,000 followers, and floral tributes were left in the town center. the police are investigating the circumstances of her death, which is not being treated as suspicious. katie's former headteacher remembered her as a vibrant and happy pupil, and the school and police declined to comment on the incident. friends and community members expressed their shock and sadness at the loss of the young girl.
1677	a socialite named nancy pfister, 57, was found dead at her home in aspen, colorado, on february 26 with a blunt force injury to her head. the pitkin county coroner, j. steven ayers, revealed the cause of death on wednesday. the investigation led to the arrest of three individuals: william styler iii, 65, and his wife, nancy styler, 62, and katherine carpenter, 56, pfister's assistant and a bank employee. prosecutors have charged them with first-degree murder, and they are being held without bond. pfister had accused them of failing to pay rent and utilities on her property. the stylers had reportedly moved out of the house around february 22, and carpenter was the one who discovered pfister's body in a closet. pfister's death marked the first homicide in pitkin county since 2001. her family and friends are struggling to understand why someone would kill her over a rent dispute. a court order has sealed key documents in the case, but prosecutors have asked for their release as no more arrests are expected. pfister's facebook posts showed that she had been dealing with issues with her tenants before her death.
1678	a magnitude-7.1 earthquake struck the central philippines on tuesday, leaving at least 99 people dead and 276 injured, and causing widespread damage in bohol and cebu provinces. the earthquake, which struck early in the morning during a religious holiday, crumbled buildings, causing panicked people to stream into the streets. most of the casualties were due to falling rubble. nearly 2.9 million people were affected, with dozens missing and reports of people trapped in collapsed buildings. power was restored to most areas, but outages persisted in bohol, cebu, and part of iloilo. the earthquake, which was centered about 620 kilometers south-southeast of manila, was felt in tokyo, and caused damage to schools, churches, hospitals, bridges, roads, government buildings, and residences. it was felt as a strong tremor even by those accustomed to earthquakes. tourist robert michael poole reported cracking roads and a decimated church in the area. no tsunami threat was reported, but smaller aftershocks continued to occur. the earthquake was centered in catigbian, bohol, and had a depth of 20 kilometers according to the usgs. the philippine disaster council gave it a slightly higher rating of 7.2 magnitude.
1679	in the small town of dumas, texas, a fatal collision between a sport utility vehicle and a gas tanker left six teenagers dead and two injured. the teens were all passengers in the suv, and the truck driver was seriously injured. the crash was one of two deadly motor vehicle accidents involving teenagers that occurred on the same day, the other in warren, ohio. motor vehicle crashes remain the leading cause of death for teens in the us, accounting for about a quarter of the 15-24 year-olds who died in 2010, according to the centers for disease control and prevention. however, overall traffic fatalities have been dropping in a historic downward trend, with 32,367 traffic deaths in 2011, the lowest level since 1949. in warren, ohio, six teenagers died when their overcrowded suv struck a guard rail and flipped into a pond. none of the teens were wearing seat belts. the crashes are a tragic reminder of the dangers that teens face on the roads.
1680	an eight-year-old boy, jakari pearson, was killed and his mother was injured after gunfire struck their detroit home while they slept. the shooting occurred around 1:15 am on wednesday, and jakari was pronounced dead at the hospital. neighbors reported hearing several rapid gunshots and seeing bullet holes in the house. the shooting is believed to have resulted from a domestic situation between jakari's mother and a man other than jakari's father. police have a "good idea" of who they are looking for in connection to the shooting and are working to apprehend the suspect. a candlelight vigil will be held at the complex to honor jakari's memory.
1681	mohamed navid bashir, a chef from west yorkshire, was wrongfully detained in prison for three days after being mistakenly identified as a man wanted on fraud charges in scotland. despite repeatedly asserting his innocence, bashir was arrested after a routine traffic stop and taken to halifax and later glasgow police stations, missing his son's first nativity play. it was only when the real wanted man appeared in court that the mistake was acknowledged. bashir is now suing the police for his ordeal. assistant chief constable mark milsom of west yorkshire police admitted the error but claimed it occurred "in good faith" and said they were not responsible for the circulated error. prime minister david cameron promised to discuss the case with home secretary theresa may.
1682	a 25-year-old woman died from injuries sustained during a stampede at germany's love parade music festival in duisburg on wednesday, raising the death toll to 21. the crash occurred in an underpass that was overcrowded with people pushing from both sides, leading to a dangerous situation where people began to lose consciousness and panic ensued. approximately 511 were injured, with 283 requiring hospitalization. chancellor angela merkel called for a thorough investigation into the incident and expressed her sadness and horror at the tragedy. an estimated 1.4 million people had attended the event, which featured techno music, despite organizers expecting only 700,000 to 800,000 attendees. police had 1,400 officers on site and 4,000 provided security. witnesses reported that police were warned of the dangerous crowds before the incident. the police are now investigating the cause of the backup in the underpass.
1683	a study suggests that wearing a simple t-shirt with a large black "t" printed on it can make a man up to 12% more attractive to women, as it creates an illusion of a more masculine and v-shaped body. the effect is most notable for men with a waist width similar to their shoulder width. the research also indicates that an inverted "t" on a t-shirt can make a man up to 12% less attractive. this study highlights the influence of body shape and fashion on perceived attractiveness and health. the study involved 30 female undergraduates, and the results indicated that upright t-illusions increased the perceived attractiveness and health of the male models. the horizontal bar on the t-shirt must be as equal or longer than the vertical bar for optimal effectiveness.
1684	arsenal players jack wilshere and calum chambers have adopted a new charity challenge called "uppies for autism," which involves doing kick-ups for the autism trust. the challenge was initiated by wilshere, who nominated danny welbeck, wojciech szczesny, nathaniel clyne, and harrison reed. chambers completed the challenge after being nominated by wilshere and is now a prominent figure for arsenal due to mathieu debuchy's injury. arsenal has enjoyed a mixed start to the season with unconvincing defensive displays, and their next champions league match is against galatasaray. supporters can donate to the autism trust by texting "ufaf14" followed by £2, £5, or £10 to 70070.
1685	paralympic sprinter sally brown is determined to compete in the 2016 rio games despite injuries and the loss of funding, leading her to work part-time at a supermarket. brown, 19, has endured foot injuries and surgeries over the past three years, causing her to miss out on funding and forcing her to find a job to support herself. she remains focused on competing in the 100m and 400m events, but balances her training with working 12 hours per week at sainsbury's. brown, who grew up with a passion for running, is grateful for the support of her boyfriend, t44 100m london gold medalist jonnie peacock, and their new puppy luna, as she works towards her goal of competing in rio. money raised by the national lottery has contributed over £32 billion to various causes in the uk since its inception.
1686	women's health magazine faced backlash for having topless, body-painted models pose alongside real athletes on the red carpet at the women's health i support women in sports awards in sydney. critics argued that the inclusion of the nude models distracted from the achievements of the female athletes and sexualized women in sports. board director at the australian women's sport and recreation association, danielle warby, expressed her outrage and questioned why nude women were present at the event. critics also raised concerns over the sexualization of women in sports and the objectification of female athletes. gold medallist hurdler sally pearson was named the sports woman of the year at the awards. editor of women's health magazine felicity harley defended the decision by stating that the night was about recognizing and telling the stories of australian sports women. however, many were left baffled by the decision and the inclusion of the topless models.
1687	a bosnian woman in st. louis was dragged out of her car and attacked by a gang of black teenagers who threatened to kill her because of her ethnicity, according to police. the incident comes five days after a bosnian man, zemir begic, was hammered to death nearby. the victim, 26, was allegedly ordered to stop by one of the teenagers who pulled a gun, and the gang went through her empty purse and stole her cell phone. they asked where she was from, and when she said she was european, one man shouted that she was lying and a bosnian, and threatened to kill her. the woman was found unconscious by passers-by but opted not to go to the hospital. in a separate incident, begic, 32, was driving home with his wife when his car was approached by a group of teenagers who vandalized it. begic tried to stop them, and was attacked with hammers, sustaining fatal injuries. his wife escaped unharmed. robert mitchell, 17, has been charged as an adult with first-degree murder and armed criminal action in connection with begic's death, and two suspected juvenile accomplices have also been arrested. police are investigating both incidents as hate crimes.
1688	rebecca benson and her best friend reece brenan are constructing australia's first moveable tiny house, which will be completed by september. the tiny home, which measures two meters wide, 3.6 meters long, and 3.8 meters tall, will cost around $15,000, and has a wardrobe space of only 30 centimeters squared. the friends from south sydney, new south wales, are designing the house using a "three uses" principle, meaning each object must have at least three functions. the house, which is built onto a custom-made trailer, has a kitchen, bedroom, and bathroom in miniature proportions and is all about smart design and functionality. the duo plan to live in the tiny house while traveling, with the goal of reducing their environmental footprint and completing a self-set challenge. they encountered legal challenges in designing the house, which varies in requirements between states and councils, and faced difficulties trying to make it an environmentally sustainable, off-grid home due to the limited availability of technology in australia.
1689	the fbi is investigating an arson fire at the chinese consulate in san francisco, which china's diplomats have urged the us to protect against. the fire, which occurred on wednesday night, is not believed to be an act of terrorism. surveillance footage shows a person pouring gasoline on the door of the consulate and igniting it. no injuries were reported, but some employees were in the building at the time. a person was seen on video standing near the consulate before the fire, and a parked mini-van was later seen driving away from the scene. there have been no claims of responsibility for the attack, and the us is taking it seriously while expressing concern.
1690	a nurse at a london hospital, jacintha saldanha, allegedly committed suicide after being duped by two australian radio djs from 2dayfm who impersonated queen elizabeth and prince charles to obtain information about the duchess of cambridge's condition. the djs, mel greig and michael christian, have since apologized for the prank, but the fallout has been immense, with many criticizing the radio station for the hoax. king edward vii's hospital condemned the prank as "truly appalling" and expressed grief over saldanha's death. the british and australian police are investigating the incident, and several large advertisers have pulled out of 2dayfm. saldanha's husband and daughter mourned her passing, and the hospital where she worked reported that she had been an excellent nurse for over four years. the royal family also expressed their condolences. some listeners applauded the prank, but many were outraged, leading to severe backlash against the radio station. greig and christian have taken down their twitter accounts and gone off the air indefinitely. the australian communications and media authority is also engaging with the licensee about the incident.
1691	andy murray and ivan lendl met at flushing meadows for the first time since their coaching partnership ended in march. they celebrated murray's historic us open victory two years ago before lendl's unexpected departure due to insufficient time commitment. lendl revealed that murray required more time and attention after winning major tournaments, and his personal circumstances made it impossible for him to fulfill the role effectively. lendl believes murray has the potential to win more grand slams with amelie mauresmo as his coach and praised dani vallverdu, murray's assistant coach. lendl did not rule out returning to coaching in the future but acknowledged it wasn't the right time for him. he is convinced of murray's ability to win more majors.
1692	russian military aircraft flew dangerously low over two us navy ships participating in joint exercises with south korea in the sea of japan this week. on monday, two russian ilyushin il-38 maritime patrol aircraft flew about 500 feet over the uss stennis aircraft carrier, while on tuesday, two russian "bear" long-range bombers overflew the uss blue ridge and uss stennis multiple times, at about 2,000 feet. us navy fa-18 fighters met and escorted the russian planes until they left the area, but attempts to contact them on international radio channels were unsuccessful. the last time russian planes flew over a us navy ship was in 2008, and these overflights are seen as muscle-flexing by the russian military, nothing illegal.
1693	the u.s. navy is deploying a warship and a sea-based radar platform closer to north korea to monitor its military moves and potential missile launches. the decision comes after weeks of belligerent rhetoric from north korea, including threats to use nuclear weapons, and follows recent joint military exercises between the u.s. and south korea. north korea has declared a state of war with the south and warned of retaliation. the u.s. has emphasized that the ship deployment is unrelated to recent tensions and has called for calm from north korea's traditional allies, china and russia. the coming weeks may see more saber-rattling due to upcoming north korean events and the ongoing u.s.-south korean military exercises. analysts believe north korea may be trying to establish itself as a nuclear weapons state.
1694	residents in the village of finghall, north yorkshire, are considering moving due to an overwhelming fly infestation. the problem has been so severe that some residents have counted up to 40 flies in their kitchens and 30 in their dining rooms. fly papers and industrial catching bags are full, and environmental health has been contacted. some villagers blame nearby poultry farms for the problem. at a residents' meeting, it was discussed that doors and windows are kept closed constantly to keep flies out. a blind relative accidentally consumed flies, and recent holiday cottage visitors refused to return due to the issue. an officer from the environmental health unit left fly papers with residents for testing, and richmondshire district council has been notified and will investigate. residents are determined to address the problem.
1695	the author, a medical professional, recalled his experience holding a preterm baby over two decades ago in medical school and how the nicu nurses handled the situation with care and precision during transports. he described the numerous risks premature babies faced including unstable heart rate, oxygen needs, and temperature regulation issues. on monday night, nyu langone medical center experienced generators failing and internal flooding, resulting in the evacuation of 64 patients, including three mothers in labor and seven newborns. one of them was a 13-day-old baby, emma, weighing only 2 pounds. her parents were stranded in new jersey and helpless as they watched their baby being evacuated to mount sinai, where she arrived and was stabilized. despite the traumatic experience, the author described emma as resilient. the transport of these premature babies involved meticulous planning and precautions due to their vulnerable health condition.
1696	ten americans, consisting of five men and five women, have been detained in haiti for allegedly trying to transport 33 children to the dominican republic without proper documentation. the group insists they intended to house the children in a shelter but haiti's prime minister, jean-max bellerive, described it as a kidnapping case. five of the children have been identified as not orphans, according to georges willeit of sos children’s villages. the group believed they had obtained necessary documents but were later arrested at the border for lacking some paperwork. new life children's refuge, an idaho-based charity, had planned to house the children in a converted hotel in the dominican republic and build an orphanage there, but the construction hadn't begun yet. the group is being held in a jail near port-au-prince and received support from the u.s. embassy.
1697	president barack obama made history on monday by announcing the creation of the cesar e. chavez national monument, the first in the national park service system to honor a latino born after the 1700s. the monument, located in keene, california, includes 120 acres and was established on land where chavez lived and led his farm worker movement in the 1970s and 1980s. chavez, a labor and civil rights activist who died in 1993, is known for his peaceful protests and boycotts that resulted in some of the first farm worker contracts in history. obama acknowledged that there is still work to be done and urged visitors to honor chavez's memory and follow his example. the monument includes chavez's home with his wife, helen, a visitor's center, and other buildings. environmentalists, a key voting group, welcomed the move, which sends a political message of obama's commitment to protecting historical sites. the chavez family donated certain properties to the federal government to make the monument possible. the monument is expected to become a popular tourist destination and part of america's shared cultural heritage.
1698	in the past few months, the us has seen multiple shooting sprees resulting in the deaths of numerous innocent people, leaving millions feeling shocked and terrified. the latest episode in southern california involves a former los angeles police officer, christopher jordan dorner, who allegedly seeks redress for perceived mistreatment by the lapd. dorner, who lost his badge in 2008 for lying about a fellow officer, saw murder as a necessary means to address racism and injustice. mass murders, such as this one, are often methodically planned and involve people targeted for specific reasons. they are typically middle-aged men who feel wronged and seek revenge on those they blame for their miserable existence. the workplace is a common venue for these incidents, with former employees seeking to regain a sense of power. in the ongoing l.a. manhunt, five people have already been shot, including the daughter of a union representative and her fiance, and one of three police officers. these victims are known as "surrogates" and are targeted because of their association with the primary target. the alleged gunman, dorner, gained access to powerful weapons through his careers in the navy and law enforcement, adding to the danger. mass murderers often find satisfaction in payback and may be thrilled by the attention, but the real concern is the number of people who may be harmed in their methodical and deliberate quest for revenge.
1699	a report by the rac foundation suggests that young driver fatalities in the uk could be reduced by up to 60% if graduated licensing restrictions are implemented. young drivers (ages 15-24) are four times more likely to die in a road crash than from drug, alcohol, gun, and knife-related incidents combined. furthermore, 1 in 5 young drivers (17-24) will be involved in an accident within six months of passing their test. the report calls for a one-year minimum learning period, a one-year post-test period with passenger and late-night driving restrictions, and a two-year probationary period for a full license. the rac foundation also supports reducing the drink-drive limit for all drivers to 50mg/100ml. the uk government is set to publish a consultation on young driver safety in the autumn. graduated licensing has previously shown success in reducing fatal collisions and overall casualties in countries such as america, australia, canada, and new zealand.
1700	two first class passengers on a qantas flight from los angeles to melbourne caused a delay after refusing to fly without the right size luxury pyjamas. the crew could not resolve the issue before take-off, so the angry couple left the plane and their baggage was unloaded. the delay was 30 minutes, but other passengers found the situation amusing. qantas confirmed that first class passengers are usually provided with pyjamas and described the first class cabin as a "private sanctuary in the sky."
1701	mental illness affects approximately 25% of adults in the united states, with many not receiving adequate treatment. smartphone apps have emerged as a popular tool to help individuals cope with various mental health issues or enhance positive thinking. apps range from informational resources and interactive mental wellness programs to comprehensive tools for specific disorders. for instance, the "live ocd free" app, priced at $79.99, uses exposure and response prevention techniques to help individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder face their fears and practice enduring unwanted thoughts, with a version for children and adults. on the lower end of the spectrum, there are apps like "moody me by medhelp," which costs less than a dollar and offers mood tracking features, social support, and access to doctor forums, as well as body tracking apps like "bmi by nutrisystem," which can be helpful for understanding the mind-body link in certain mental health conditions. the "live happy" app, costing 99 cents, offers happiness-boosting activities and a gratitude journal to help users enhance their overall well-being. free tools, such as "depressioncheck," can help users assess their potential risk for anxiety or depression, and other apps like "bipolar disorder connect" serve as a community for individuals with that disorder. for those seeking relief from stress, apps like "tactical breather" offer simple guided relaxation exercises. with mental health care remaining costly and limited for many people, these apps represent a promising, accessible, and convenient solution.
1702	in anhui province, china, dozens of elderly people have taken their own lives to ensure burial before a june 1 deadline, as authorities plan to close all cemeteries due to space concerns. those who die after this date will be required to be cremated. the drastic measure, which has received extreme opposition in rural areas, has only accelerated the suicide rate among the elderly. notable suicides include zhang wenying, 81, and wu lixiu, 97, who both left notes expressing their desire for a decent burial. the sudden implementation of the policy has left many elderly people unprepared and upset, with some taking their own lives to guarantee a burial. the government is facing criticism for the short notice and the perceived insensitivity to the elderly population.
1703	the cnn article criticizes fox's tv show "glee" for using sexually explicit content with teenage characters to boost ratings during sweeps month. co-creator ryan murphy defends it as a "teachable moment" for parents and teens about safe sex, but the article argues that presenting teen sex as normal marginalizes teenagers who choose to remain abstinent and increases pressure on them to become sexually active. television acts as a "sexual super peer," influencing teens' sexual behaviors, and research shows heavy tv viewing correlates with positive attitudes toward casual sex and negative attitudes toward abstinence. studies also link child exposure to adult media content to early onset of sexual activity and teen pregnancy. the article advises parents to have honest conversations with their teens instead of relying on hollywood to teach sex education. the piece concludes that this trend is expected to continue and warns against letting hollywood be the primary source of sex education for teens.
1704	tennessee titans running back shonn greene was arrested on multiple charges after ignoring parking enforcement officers and speeding away in his bmw m6 while being issued a citation for parking in a handicapped spot in franklin, a nashville suburb. greene initially refused to show a handicap placard and ignored requests to speak with the officer before speeding off, almost hitting her car. the officer pursued the vehicle and later identified greene as the driver based on information from the bmw. greene was charged with misdemeanors of driving on a suspended license, reckless driving, failure to stop, and illegal parking. he surrendered on friday and was released on $2,000 bail, facing a court appearance on november 13. the titans released a statement expressing disappointment with greene's behavior and promising to handle the matter internally. greene, who has been nursing a hamstring injury, is second on the team in rushing with 190 yards on 44 carries.
1705	a 45-year-old man identified as benito gonzales was shot and killed by police after crashing his pick-up truck into the san patricio county sheriff's office in sinton, texas, and opening fire with a .45-caliber pistol. deputy returning fire hit gonzales twice, once in the chest and once in the head. sheriff leroy moody believes gonzales may have intentionally sought a violent confrontation with law enforcement in a case of "suicide by cop" following recent bad news. no one inside the building was injured. the texas rangers are conducting an investigation.
1706	james cameron is currently working on the scripts for "avatar 2" and "avatar 3" in new zealand, and he's been describing the process as both challenging and enjoyable. he acknowledged the pressure of following up such a successful film but remains confident in his ability to deliver. production timelines for the sequels have not been disclosed, and a release date will depend on when he completes the scripts.
1707	an expat named "jeff," identified as an english teacher wearing a pink shirt and three-quarter length shorts, was slapped by a buddhist monk on a train in thailand after an apparent misunderstanding over seats. the incident went viral after a video showing the assault was posted on facebook. the man, who is originally from australia, appeared to speak with an australian accent and claimed he was hit "three times." the police arrived and removed the monk from the train carriage, and "jeff" stated that he was "sabai, sabai," which means he was fine in thai. the situation arose when jeff offered his double seat to two women and sat next to the monk to resolve a delicate situation. however, the monk took offense to jeff's words "fine, fine," interpreting it as a deeply offensive term "kwai, kwai" in thai slang, resulting in the assault. the facebook user who posted the video, pui pupriew, wrote that the incident occurred on december 7 on a train traveling from bangkok to phitsanulok. jeff expressed his love for thailand and said he appreciated the support he received online.
1708	the search for missing malaysia airlines flight 370 resumed on sunday despite potential weather issues. ten planes and eight ships are participating in the search over 123,167 square miles of water located about 1,150 miles west of perth, australia. the battery life of the flight data recorder is estimated to last only about 30 days, so time is of the essence. debris sightings reported over the past two days have been investigated, but no confirmed pieces of the plane have been found yet. families of the 239 missing passengers have expressed frustration with mixed messages from authorities and access to information. relatives of chinese passengers in kuala lumpur reported restrictions on their movement and communication. the new search area, 1,100 kilometers northeast of the previous one, is closer to australia's coast and has calmer waters. the latest data analysis indicates that the plane might have ended up in the southern indian ocean, which is where the search is currently being focused. the cause of the plane's disappearance remains unknown, and it is unclear when or if it will be found. the malaysian authorities have faced intense criticism and skepticism from the families and the international community regarding their handling of the crisis.
1709	a sydney woman, fatima elomar, who is married to an isis fighter in syria, has been ordered by a magistrate to appear in court next week over charges she was preparing to join her husband in syria. elomar, 30, has had her case mentioned seven times in court since her arrest last may, but her request for a further adjournment was rejected as "unacceptable." elomar, a mother of four, was arrested at the airport while allegedly trying to leave the country with cash and camouflage clothing to join her husband, mohamed elomar, who has become a 'poster boy' for isis in syria. she has maintained she was going to malaysia for a holiday with her children. the case has been described as serious and over-zealous by her lawyer through media releases. elomar's husband is the nephew of a convicted terrorist and was believed to have traveled to syria with a convicted terrorist, khaled sharrouf, who also posted photos of his children with severed heads. the magistrate ordered elomar to be arraigned on february 3.
1710	atlanta police officers bryan ernest and bernatt collins respond to an increasing number of burglaries in vacant homes, which are often stripped of copper and other valuable materials. the officers are part of a special burglary detail formed to address this issue. thieves are targeting empty houses due to the nation's foreclosure crisis and rising copper prices. police departments across the country report an increase in burglaries of vacant homes, with banks and homeowners incurring significant damage and costs to replace stolen items and repair the damaged properties. neighborhoods previously not targeted are now seeing more burglaries, with criminals using various methods to steal the materials. house owners and investors face ongoing challenges in securing their properties.
1711	a woman, veronica valdez, underwent a minor surgery at torrance memorial medical center in california in 2011. during the procedure, her anesthesiologist, dr. patrick yang, decorated her face with stickers, including a black mustache and teardrops, while she was unconscious. a nurse's aide then took a photo of valdez and showed it to her when she woke up. valdez, who had worked at the hospital for 13 years, was "ridiculed and humiliated" and was forced to quit her job. the incident was reported as a potential violation of medical privacy, and the hospital suspended the employees involved but ultimately allowed them to keep their jobs. valdez is suing the hospital, the anesthesiologist, and his medical group for violation of privacy, emotional distress, and other allegations. the trial is scheduled for january 2014. in her lawsuit, valdez also alleges that there may be a sexually suggestive photo of her taken during the procedure. the hospital contends that valdez is trying to "play litigation lottery" against a "deep-pocket defendant."
1712	moscow police are questioning a suspect in connection with the acid attack on sergei filin, the artistic director of russia's bolshoi ballet, in january. filin was severely burned in the face and eyes after a masked assailant throw concentrated acid at him on a moscow street. doctors fought to save his sight, and he may take six months to recover. filin had reportedly endured months of intimidation, including threatening phone calls, slashed car tires, and attempted hacking of his facebook page. filin took up the position at the bolshoi ballet in 2011 after directing moscow's stanislavsky and nemirovich-danchenko music theater for three years. russian authorities have given few details on the investigation.
1713	scientists at bangor university have defended their decision to kill the world's oldest-recorded animal, a 507-year-old clam named ming, amid criticism that they did so to determine its age. ming was discovered on the coast of iceland in 2006 and was initially believed to be around 400 years old based on the number of rings in its shell. however, after further analysis, researchers determined the clam was actually 507 years old, making it the oldest recorded animal. the researchers, including climate scientist dr. paul butler, have noted that large creatures generally live longer than small ones, and ming's long life may be attributed to its slow metabolism. ming was part of a larger study on climate change and was frozen and transported to the lab for examination. the findings mean that ming was born seven years after columbus discovered america and lived through historical milestones such as the english civil war and two world wars.
1714	a family court judge in london has allowed a mother to change the surname of her three-year-old twin sons due to the "bizarre conduct" of their father on his blog. the father, who is embroiled in litigation about contact with his children, has created a protest blog which he updates daily, referring to his estranged wife as a "drug-addicted alcoholic" and posting extensive details of their litigation and their children's names. judge ross duggan ruled that the desire to preserve the paternal link through the children's surname must give way to their protection from their father's publications. the judge noted that at an older age, the children may encounter web-based insults to their mother or other harmful material associated with their names. the father's activities cannot be stopped at the source, but the harmful consequences can be prevented by allowing the children's name change in their best interests.
1715	a new study by researchers at illinois university has found that physically fit nine and ten-year-olds have more white matter in their brains, which is associated with better memory and attention. the study, which used brain imaging, showed that those with higher levels of aerobic fitness had brains with more fibrous and compact white matter. previous studies suggest that children with higher levels of aerobic fitness have larger gray matter brain regions important for memory and learning. the researchers analyzed data from 24 children using diffusion tensor imaging and found significant fitness-related differences in the integrity of several white matter tracts in the brain, which play a role in attention and memory. the research builds on previous work showing that fitness is linked to white matter integrity in older adults, suggesting that the benefits of fitness for the brain may extend throughout the lifespan. the team is now conducting a five-year trial to determine whether white matter tract integrity improves in children who begin a new physical fitness routine and maintain it.
1716	inflation-ravaged zimbabwe lifted cash withdrawal limits on thursday, leading to armored cars patrolling the streets of the capital and long lines at banks. the reserve bank of zimbabwe raised the weekly maximum withdrawal limit from 50 cents to $50. the country faces soaring prices and economic instability, with zimbabwe's inflation rate reaching a record 231 million percent. the government also declared a national emergency over a growing cholera outbreak, which has killed at least 565 people and sickened more than 11,000. medical professionals blame the outbreak on the lack of safe water in many parts of the country. protests against the withdrawal limits led to the arrest of union leaders and 69 protesters on wednesday. human rights activist jestina mukoko was also reportedly abducted. unpaid soldiers clashed with foreign currency exchangers on monday.
1717	prince harry's naked photos from a las vegas hotel were published on entertainment site tmz and quickly spread to numerous other websites worldwide, despite being banned in britain due to privacy concerns from the royal family. the images were widely disseminated on the internet and social media, with many popular blogs and news outlets sharing them. the pictures received mixed reactions online, with some seeing harry's actions as "awesome" and others "disgraceful." despite threats of legal action from harry's father, prince charles, the photos continued to be available online, making a mockery of british privacy laws. the incident echoed the way edward viii's affair with wallis simpson was kept secret in britain while being openly reported in other countries in 1936. the pictures were discussed and debated on social media platforms such as facebook and twitter, making them a trending topic on those networks as well.

1719	manitoba mother kristen bartkiw was fined $10 by her kids' daycare after they determined her home-cooked lunches, consisting of leftover roast beef, potatoes, carrots, milk, and oranges, were unbalanced as they lacked ritz crackers, which the daycare workers considered a grain. bartkiw, who was also on the daycare board at the time, found the fine absurd as it flew in the face of what she believed was a healthy and well-rounded meal for her children. the incident, which occurred in late 2012, highlighted a disconnect between the canadian food guide's requirements and what is considered nutritious for kids. according to the guide, daycare meals must include one milk, one meat, one grain, and two fruits or vegetables, with parents being charged $5 per child for each missing item. bartkiw noted that processed and junk foods are still considered acceptable under the guide as long as they adhere to the specified food groups, which led to her criticizing the system and encouraging parents to consider more real food options. manitoba has since implemented a hot lunch program in daycares to address the issue of less-than-balanced lunches.
1720	as the g20 leaders' summit approaches, protests and security measures are increasing in brisbane. on sunday, up to 200 indigenous activists from the brisbane aboriginal sovereign embassy held a traditional welcoming ceremony at musgrave park to prepare for their protest on monday, calling for indigenous rights and decolonization. they also highlighted ongoing issues like the removal of children, high imprisonment rates, police violence, and land destruction. separately, 100 anti-poverty activists peacefully protested on the brisbane river on deckchairs, dressed as accountants, to bring attention tomultinational tax dodging. hundreds of surveillance cameras have been installed across the city to monitor the event, and thousands of police from australia and new zealand will be on duty until november 17. a security zone has been declared covering a large portion of central brisbane, granting police the power to search people for prohibited items. the size of the leaders' motorcades is still being negotiated.
1721	the article by amy gahran on cnn.com discusses mobile data usage and provides estimates on data consumption for various mobile activities based on research from maravedis. activities like sending or receiving emails with no attachments and visiting web pages use significantly less data than streaming videos or music. an average residential smartphone user consumes around 255.5 mb (0.25 gb) of mobile data per month, but signaling traffic from smartphones, which is necessary for keeping in touch with wireless networks and moving between cells, can contribute significantly to data usage as well. consumers cannot control signaling traffic, but they can limit mobile content usage to manage their wireless bills effectively.
1722	manchester united and arsenal have reached an agreement for the transfer of robin van persie, subject to a medical and personal terms. the dutch striker, who scored 30 goals for arsenal last season, will travel to manchester on thursday to finalize the move. in july, van persie announced his intention to leave arsenal after a meeting with manager arsene wenger and chairman ivan gazidis, citing disagreements on the team's direction. manchester united's wayne rooney has praised van persie as a fantastic player and expressed excitement about potential collaboration. arsenal lost two key players last summer, samir nasri and cesc fabregas, who had both been captains, and van persie was appointed the new captain. van persie's move to manchester united follows fabregas' transfer to barcelona on the same date last year.
1723	dennis deleon, a former new york city human rights commissioner and long-time aids activist, passed away at the age of 61. deleon, who was openly hiv-positive and one of the first latino leaders to publicly disclose his status, was hailed as a "pioneer" and a "visionary" by the latino commission on aids, which he helped launch. deleon served various civic roles throughout his life, including serving as the director of the mayor's commission on latino concerns in 1986 and being appointed by then-mayor david dinkins to head the new york city commission on human rights in 1990. in 1994, he returned to the private sector and co-founded the latino commission on aids, serving as its president for 15 years. the organization issued a statement praising deleon's lifelong commitment to public service, and new york mayor michael bloomberg also issued a statement praising deleon's work. deleon's work with the latino commission on aids was dedicated to fighting the spread of hiv/aids in the latino community. current latino commission on aids president guillermo chacon expressed his condolences and said that it would be a challenge to fill the void left by deleon at the commission.
1724	a jilted woman identified as tracey ann ortion, 42, caused significant damage to a building in hull, uk, after driving her car into it in a jealous rage. ortion, who operated a fish and chip shop with her husband kevin, discovered he had moved in with another woman, sarah carroll. despite their separation, ortion believed they were reconciling and was shocked to find out otherwise. in a fit of anger, she drove her car into the garage next to carroll's home, causing an estimated £12,290 in damage and £200 worth of damage to bikes inside. witnesses reported that ortion had sent abusive text messages and had confronted her husband in the weeks leading up to the incident. ortion pleaded guilty to destroying property but maintaining it was an accident. the judge expressed skepticism towards her explanation and granted her six months to prove she could stay out of trouble before passing sentence, warning her of possible jail time if she failed to do so.
1725	nba four-time all-star chris paul was traded from the new orleans hornets to the los angeles clippers, with eric gordon, al-farouq aminu, chris kaman, and a first-round pick in the 2012 draft being sent to the hornets in return. the hornets, who are currently owned by the league, were eager to trade paul, whose contract expires at the end of the upcoming season. nba commissioner david stern approved the deal and paul's arrival is expected to invigorate the clippers, who have had a struggling franchise compared to their long-standing local rivals, the lakers. paul, who leads the league in steals on four occasions, will team up with blake griffin, last year's nba rookie of the year, and the two will average a combined total of 33.9 points and 12 rebounds per game, significantly improving the clippers stat line. gordon, aminu, and kaman head to the hornets as part of the deal.
1726	britney spears is under accusation from her fans for lip-syncing to her song "perfume" during her las vegas show. sia, who is credited as a writer of the track, is believed to be the source of the audio being played instead of spears' live vocals. spears has been previously criticized for lip-syncing in her vegas residency. in a review for the los angeles times, mikael wood described her performance as "diminished" and her vocals as apparently lip-synced for the majority of the show. spears' manager adam leber initially denied the claims but later admitted that she isn't able to sing live for the entire show due to the demanding nature of her performances.
1727	a violent brawl broke out in the boxing ring at the octagon theatre in sheffield during a fight between uzair "the nightmare" najib and muheeb "flashy" fazeldin for the central arena title. the violence began seconds after fazeldin stopped najib in the first round and continued despite the ring announcer's attempts to restore order. the animosity between the two fighters had been building ahead of the event, and najib later described the scene as "over-passionate fans who got a bit crazy." promoter dennis hobson condemned the brawl and promised it would never happen again, as the night was headlined by ross burkinshaw's knockout victory for the european title.
1728	ten-month-old oscar tasker, who was born with a heart defect and spent his entire life in the hospital hooked up to an artificial heart, has made an incredible recovery and is finally able to spend his first christmas at home with his parents and siblings. doctors were amazed when oscar's heart healed itself after being on the transplant list for 100 days. his parents, jason and lois, are overjoyed to have their family together and are grateful for the holiday season to be spent under one roof. dr. richard kirk, the consultant paediatric cardiologist in charge of oscar's care, believes the time on the artificial heart gave oscar's own heart time to rest and recover.
1729	the parents of trayvon martin, sybrina fulton and tracy martin, have continued their fight for justice a year after their son's shooting death, despite the waning national attention on the case. they became prominent figures in the debate on racial profiling and gun violence after their unarmed 17-year-old son was fatally shot by neighborhood watch volunteer george zimmerman in florida. the upcoming trial on second-degree murder charges against zimmerman in june will determine the outcome of the case, as the two versions of what happened that night differ significantly. while they have gotten what they asked for by having zimmerman arrested, the parents continue their activism through their foundation, speaking out against gun violence and holding events in honor of their son. they still grieve over the senseless violence and the pain caused by the mass shootings and everyday murders, particularly in chicago. while acknowledging the limitations of their influence in the case, the parents expressed hope for a fair trial and vowed to accept the jury's decision, whatever it may be.
1730	a highly respected religious studies teacher, stuart kerner, 44, was convicted of having a sexual relationship with a 16-year-old pupil at a south east london school. kerner, who was also a vice principal, had sex with the girl in empty classrooms and cleaning cupboards. his defense attempted to blame the victim, claiming her allegations were based on the novel "fifty shades of grey," but kerner was found guilty of two counts of sexual activity with a child by a person in a position of trust. the victim, now 19, had a "troubled" past and was described as "besotted" with kerner, who "gave in to temptation." the victim's relationships with her family were also tumultuous, and she had a history of telling lies for attention. kerner sent the girl messages and arranged to meet her during school hours, taking her virginity in a classroom and continuing the relationship at his home when his wife was at work. the victim kept a detailed diary of their encounters and even received a souvenir from kerner related to the novel. kerner denied all the charges and blamed the victim, but evidence such as phone records and detailed descriptions of his home provided by the victim contradicted his denials. jurors cleared him of some charges but found him guilty of the most serious offenses. kerner sobbed in court as the verdict was delivered, and his wife was inconsolable. the victim was supportive of the verdict but expressed remorse for what had happened.
1731	lance armstrong, a seven-time tour de france champion and cancer survivor, had a bike stolen from a team truck during the california amgen tour of california. the bike, which is used only for time trials, was one of five bikes taken from the astana team's truck parked behind a hotel in sacramento. armstrong, 37, finished fifth in sunday's testing first stage won by francisco mancebo despite a puncture and freezing conditions. armstrong, who made his comeback after retiring in 2005, is aiming for another tour de france victory this summer. he finished 29th in the tour down under last month and is currently in second place in the california race, one minute five seconds behind mancebo. fabian cancellara, who started the day in the yellow jersey, pulled out midway through the stage feeling unwell.
1732	chrysler is recalling approximately 870,000 jeep grand cherokee and dodge durango suvs from model years 2011 to 2014 due to a defect that may cause the brakes to become harder to use. the issue is caused by corrosion in the brake boosters when exposed to water, which can prevent the boosters from aiding braking as intended if the water freezes. chrysler first investigated the issue after receiving complaints of excessive brake-pedal firmness, and has since confirmed one accident without injuries. dealers will install shields to protect the boosters and replace those that are not functioning properly for free. chrysler also changed the design of the boosters to make them more resistant to corrosion. the company became aware of the problem last spring but initially believed vehicles would still comply with regulations and began adding a coating to new parts. however, after receiving more warranty claims than expected and realizing the extent of the issue, chrysler decided to initiate a recall.
1733	goldman sachs, the world's most generous big bank, paid its staff an average of £246,000 last year, including salary, bonuses, and benefits, according to recent reports. this is a small pay cut compared to the £248,000 average in 2013 and almost ten times the average salary in the uk. critics have accused the bank of being "oblivious" to public opinion regarding large bonuses, which some believe encouraged reckless behavior leading to the financial crisis. goldman's profits for 2014 rose by 5%, amounting to £5.6 billion. top executives, including ceo lloyd blankfein and uk supremo michael sherwood, are expected to receive multi-million pound bonuses in the coming weeks. despite showing more restraint since the financial crisis, with staff receiving a smaller percentage of earnings, goldman continues to pay more than its rivals. the average pay package of £246,000 dwarfs those offered by banks like jp morgan, which paid £135,000 on average for 2014. labour has pledged to reintroduce a tax on bankers’ bonuses if they win the general election in may.
1734	michael clarke, the australian cricket captain, arrived in macksville, northern new south wales, on monday to help prepare for the funeral of his best friend and teammate, phillip hughes, who died after being struck by a ball during a cricket match in sydney. clarke has been providing support to hughes' parents, greg and virginia, during this difficult time. the first test match of the summer is expected to be held in adelaide next week instead of brisbane due to the rescheduling of matches following hughes' death. clarke and hughes had a close bond both on and off the field, as evidenced by numerous photos and social media posts. hughes' passing has been described as the biggest tragedy clarke has ever had to endure, and many in the cricket community have paid tribute to him on social media. greg inglis, another macksville native and rabbitohs player, also paid tribute to hughes with a heartfelt birthday message. a night vigil was held in hughes' hometown of macksville on saturday, and his life support was turned off on thursday.
1735	yasir, a 15-year-old boy, was once an isis child soldier in deir ezzor, syria. he was forcibly recruited after isis took over his area following his father's allegiance. isis isolated the children, providing them with intense religious indoctrination and military training for a month. yasir endured grueling physical exercises, including firearms training and running long distances. isis showcases their child soldiers as "cubs of the islamic state," and the un reports children as young as 12 undergo military training. yasir expressed confusion and psychological damage from his experiences, initially wanting to return because of friends but eventually expressing regret. his father successfully defected, rescuing yasir, but many other children remain under isis rule, susceptible to their manipulation and indoctrination.
1736	an eagle scout named zach wahls challenged the boy scouts of america's anti-gay policy during their annual conference in orlando by delivering a petition signed by 275,000 people, including ellen degeneres, jesse tyler ferguson, and ricky martin, calling for an end to discrimination against gay youth and leaders. the petition was launched in response to the ousting of jennifer tyrrell, a former den leader from ohio, due to her sexuality. the boy scouts appeared receptive to wahls' statements but did not indicate a change in policies. the boy scouts of america, with over 2.7 million youth members and 1 million adult volunteers, has been under criticism for its policy since the 2000 supreme court ruling allowing the organization to ban gays. local leaders and parents have reportedly accepted gay members and leaders without issue. critics of the policy argue that it diminishes the accomplishments of gay scouts and goes against the organization's values of respect and courage.
1737	detective mario muniz, a 45-year-old nypd officer and married father, left bellevue hospital in manhattan on wednesday after undergoing surgery for wounds sustained in a shootout with a pedophile, charles richard mozdir, in the west village on monday. hundreds of officers gathered to cheer him on. muniz and two u.s. marshals were injured when they tried to serve mozdir with a warrant at a smoke shop. mozdir, who was wanted for child sexual assault charges, was killed in the confrontation. the officers' protective vests likely saved their lives. mozdir had a long criminal history and was accused of molesting children and possessing child pornography and bestiality material. he had been the target of a nationwide manhunt since 2012. the shooting occurred near several elementary schools and caused chaos in the area. the officers are expected to recover.
1738	president barack obama, through a tweet from his official account signed "bo," urged the uk to remain "strong, robust, and united" ahead of the scottish independence referendum, calling it an "extraordinary partner" and a "force of good" in the world. obama's comments came after former president bill clinton also urged scots to reject independence due to concerns over currency and international organization membership. the interventions may have infuriated scottish first minister alex salmond, who has invited obama to events in the past but has not met him. both the us and australia have spoken out against scottish independence, with concerns over its impact on international alliances and britain's nuclear capabilities. obama's maternal ancestry can be traced back to william the lion, who ruled scotland in the late 1100s.
1739	the last official photograph of film legend james dean, taken on september 30, 1955, shows him looking relaxed and happy in the driver's seat of his porsche 550 spyder with mechanic rolf wuthrich alongside him on a sunny california morning. taken by sanford roth for a photo feature on a race dean was attending, the poignant image will be auctioned by julien's auctions in beverly hills. dean, who had made just three films before his fatal head-on car crash at the age of 24, was a hollywood icon, earning two posthumous academy award nominations for "east of eden" and "giant." the photograph captures the moment before the tragically short-lived star's untimely death on route 466 near paso robles.
1740	a group of approximately 40 mothers and their young children, including a distressed woman with swollen eyes and a crying six-year-old daughter, were deported from the united states to honduras on a chartered flight on monday. this was the first of many planned deportations as part of stepped-up u.s. efforts to crack down on illegal immigration. the group had recently crossed the u.s.-mexico border and had been detained in a temporary immigrant detention facility in new mexico. before the deportation, they were held until their legal cases were decided in two to four days. the facilities aim to process cases more quickly using video conferences with judges. authorities expect more families to be deported in the coming days and weeks. homeland security secretary jeh johnson met with house democrats on monday and announced that additional detention centers were being built to house adults traveling with children. the first lady of honduras, ana garcia de hernandez, expressed concern about the deportation of children and called for support from her fellow citizens. president obama has requested $3.7 billion in emergency funds to address the situation at the u.s. border, but the republican-led house has not moved quickly on the measure. the white house has labeled the situation a "humanitarian crisis," while republicans blame the administration for not being prepared and for an underwhelming response.
