1826	a massachusetts state police trooper, sgt. sean murphy, who was suspended for giving boston magazine unauthorized photos of the hunt and capture of one of the boston bombing suspects, will face a hearing tuesday to determine his future with the agency. the images, which depict dzhokhar tsarnaev looking bloody and with a laser sight on his forehead, were published by the magazine in an article where murphy expressed his opposition to the rolling stone cover showing the suspect with a doe-eyed look. the controversy has garnered significant support on social media for murphy, with some praising him for standing up for the victims, while others acknowledge his actions were illegal. businesses such as cvs pharmacies, stop & shop, and tedeschi food shops have announced they will not sell the magazine's print edition, while rolling stone defends its decision, citing the importance of examining the complexities of the issue and gaining a better understanding of how a tragedy like the boston bombings happens. dzhokhar tsarnaev has pleaded not guilty to federal charges in connection with the bombings, and his brother tamerlan, who is suspected of helping carry out the attack, was killed during a gun battle with police.
1827	in the wta sydney international tournament, top-ranked danish player caroline wozniacki and second-ranked russian vera zvonareva were both eliminated in the second round. wozniaki, who had won her last nine sets against her slovakian opponent dominika cibulkova, lost 6-3, 6-3. zvonareva, who won the hong kong classic exhibition last week, put up a fight against flavia pennetta but ultimately lost 7-5, 7-5. both players' preparations for the australian open have been affected by their early exits. cibulkova will face kim clijsters in the quarterfinals, and zvonareva could drop to world number three. in the men's draw, past sydney finalist juan ignacio chela won his first match in eight years, defeating radek stepanek. guillermo garcia-lopez, potito starace, and andreas seppi also advanced to the next round. in the atp event in auckland, new zealand, former world number three david nalbandian won his first match of the 2011 season against fabio fognini. he will face philip petzschner in the second round. juan martin del potro also returned to winning ways in the sydney international with a victory over feliciano lopez.
1828	justice secretary chris grayling announced plans to ban police officers from giving repeat warnings, or cautions, to offenders for similar crimes within two years. the move comes after it was revealed that nearly 5,000 adults had received multiple cautions for identical or similar offenses, such as common assaults, drugs offenses, shoplifting, and criminal damage. the current system is overly bureaucratic and confusing, according to grayling, who intends to ensure that the system is consistent, straightforward, and confident for victims and the public. changes to the law next year will allow magistrates and victims groups to inspect how cautions are given out and limit their use in certain circumstances. additionally, spot fines and cannabis warnings are under review. the review is expected to conclude in spring 2014.
1829	ferrari president luca di montezemolo has confirmed that fernando alonso will leave the team at the end of the 2014 formula one season, citing alonso's desire for a new environment and his age as reasons for the departure. alonso has been at ferrari since 2010 but has never won a championship with the italian team, and he is currently sixth in the drivers' championship. the spaniard has been linked to a move to mercedes but has expressed doubt about the likelihood of that happening. he has also denied any interest in driving for a team with a mercedes engine, leaving mclaren as a possible option. alonso's contract runs until the end of 2016, but he is expected to be replaced by four-time champion sebastian vettel, who announced his departure from red bull last week. kimi raikkonen, ferrari's 2007 champion, is also a possibility for a seat at the team, but negotiations are ongoing. alonso has expressed a desire to help the future of ferrari and has maintained that he will make an announcement when the time is right.
1830	michele bachmann, a minnesota republican congresswoman, believes hillary clinton won't be the next u.s. president because americans aren't ready for a female president and didn't have the same "guilt" factor for electing a woman as they did for barack obama due to his racial background. bachmann, a 2012 gop presidential hopeful who dropped out due to debilitating migraines and ethics controversies, noted clinton's lengthy political career and her involvement in the benghazi scandal. clinton, who has faced criticism over her handling of the 2012 libya terrorist attack, is currently a favorite for the democratic nomination in 2016. bachmann accused clinton of being "obama's third and fourth term" due to her role in passing obamacare during her tenure as secretary of state. clinton, now 66 years old, will likely face a crowded democratic primary field in her bid for the presidency.
1831	tim reddish, a former paralympian with over 50 swimming medals, went blind 17 years ago due to a degenerative eye condition. he recently received a bionic eye with a revolutionary retinal chip, enabling him to see shapes and read a clock face. the procedure costs up to £100,000 and uses a 1,500 pixel chip that sends electrical signals to the optic nerve and brain upon light entering the eye. this technology, which has restored some sight to tim and other previously blind participants in the trial, is a significant step forward but still requires further development. tim, who lost his sight due to retinitis pigmentosa, competed in three paralympic games and was honored with an mbe and an obe for his services to disabled sport.
1832	gary rogers, a father of two, will celebrate his first christmas since 1994 after suffering a brain injury caused by a heart attack and being left in a coma. he does not remember his own daughters, olivia and lilly, or the past 17 years. the family is looking forward to a memorable christmas together, as gary's memory is improving. he previously had no recollection of the family's christmas celebrations or his life as a father. doctors believed his brain damage was caused by a lack of oxygen to the brain while he was on holiday in turkey last summer. the family has been working hard to help gary rebuild his life, and he has made some progress in regaining some memories.
1833	sandra lertzman, a dedicated animal rights executive and mother of one, was found dead in her garage in moreland hills, ohio, alongside 31 rescued dogs. a suicide note and vials of prescription pills were found in her car, while her body was discovered inside the house. friends believe she killed the dogs out of concern for their future, unable to care for them properly herself. lertzman, who lost a son in a car accident ten years ago and had written a book on dogs, had been increasingly depressed. her husband is currently caring for the surviving puppy and 20 cats. the animal rights community is mourning the loss of a passionate advocate for animal welfare.
1834	danish photographer daniel rye ottosen was held by isis for 13 months and was released after a secret fund was raised by his family and friends to pay a ransom. his older sister, anita rye ottosen, revealed his overwhelming debts in a facebook campaign. the release of ottosen and four other hostages, who included american journalists and british aid workers beheaded by isis, was controversial as the u.s. and u.k. governments had previously refused to pay ransoms but it is reported that a large sum was paid for ottosen's release. the u.k. foreign office stated it is against international law to pay ransoms to terrorists. the campaign aims to raise around £86,000 to help ottosen repay the debts incurred during his captivity. ottosen was one of the few isis hostages released, having been held alongside several other hostages who were later executed. he had been in syria to document the suffering of refugees and witnessed the torture of fellow hostage james foley, who was beheaded shortly after his release. the families of foley and other hostages had received threats if they paid ransoms. the danish embassy in the u.s. declined to comment on the legality of the ransom payment.
1835	a large sunspot, named ar 1476, with a diameter of 60,000 miles (many times the size of earth) has emerged on the sun's surface, potentially leading to powerful solar storms. this sunspot was spotted by nasa's solar dynamics observatory and can be viewed with home telescopes, but requires sun filters to prevent eye damage. sunspots are darker areas on the sun caused by its magnetic field becoming twisted, which can result in coronal mass ejections (cmes) containing billions of tons of solar gases, x-rays, and ultraviolet radiation. these storms can cause magnetic storms, disrupting satellites and power grids, and have been known to leave millions without power, such as in quebec, canada, in 1989. solar activity increases during an 11-year cycle, peaking in 2013, meaning more solar storms are expected in the next two years. dr. matthew penn of the national solar observatory in arizona warned that sunspots cause the biggest and most damaging space storms and that the upcoming peak in sunspots may result in an increased number of solar storms at earth.
1836	amanda knox, who was acquitted of the murder of meredith kercher in 2011 after spending four years in an italian prison, gave her first live television interview on british television, defending her decision not to return to italy for a retrial and expressing her desire to take a lie detector test to prove her innocence. knox claimed she has been "hunted down" over the murder and is now trying to fight back against her accusers. she stated that she is unable to afford to travel to italy for the retrial and is trying to rebuild her life in seattle. her former boyfriend, raffaele sollecito, is also facing a retrial next monday. knox has always maintained her innocence and believes that kercher's family could help with the grieving process by allowing her to visit her grave. she also denied cashing in on kercher's death by writing her book. sollecito, who was also acquitted of the murder, claims the police handled his case incompetently and that he was blackmailed into framing knox for the crime.
1837	a young british civil engineer named sebastian john, 26, who had been working for bp in algeria for only one week, was one of six uk nationals killed during a terrorist siege at a desert facility. his wife, nicola, 29, paid tribute to her "amazing" husband, describing him as a fantastic father, husband, son, and brother. john had recently moved from nottingham to surrey and was privately educated and had a first class honors degree in civil engineering. his colleagues lauded him as a talented young civil engineer with a promising future. the families of the other victims, including garry barlow, paul morgan, kenneth whiteside, and carlos estrada, have also paid tribute, with some requesting prayers for their loved ones. british hostage lou fear has returned home safely after hiding during the siege. the british government is considering increasing logistical support for the french-led military campaign against rebels in mali, but david cameron has insisted there will be no combat role for uk forces. bp ceo bob dudley fears for the safety of four missing employees and is supporting their families while forensic experts work to identify the bodies found at the site.
1838	the global economy has become interconnected, and economic health depends on cooperation among countries. the economic community is becoming closer, requiring a balanced approach to financial stability and global unity. the current global crisis presents opportunities but also challenges, and europe, in particular, requires careful attention to ensure continued prosperity while accommodating cultural differences. donald trump expresses his belief in the importance of a cohesive global economy and the potential for investment opportunities in europe.
1839	pope francis commemorated jesus' crucifixion by lying prostrate at the center of st. peter's basilica during the good friday "passion of the lord" service at the vatican. during the marathon service, vatican preacher fr. raniero cantalamessa criticized modern society's obsession with large salaries, drawing parallels to judas betraying jesus for 30 pieces of silver. cantalamessa denounced the "cursed hunger for gold" as the root cause of societal evils, including the financial crisis, and the scandalous salaries and pensions of some executives. pope francis will later lead a candlelight "way of the cross" procession around the colosseum and will canonize popes john paul ii and john xxiii on may 27, making it the first time two former popes are made saints on the same day.
1840	sgt. andrew tahmooressi, a 25-year-old marine veteran, is currently jailed in mexico on weapons charges after accidentally crossing the border with a shotgun, handgun, and rifle in his vehicle. tahmooressi, who was heading to meet friends in a border town, claimed he took a wrong exit and failed to notice, intending to call the authorities once he realized his mistake. previous cases of us citizens being jailed in mexico for similar reasons have occurred, including an army soldier in 2008 and a marine in 1999. tahmooressi faces up to 21 years in prison if convicted and has received visits from an english-speaking chaplain while in detention. rep. duncan hunter (r-ca) has requested the secretary of state's intervention to secure his release. tahmooressi served four years in the marines, including two tours in afghanistan.
1841	a care worker sustained two broken vertebrae in her spine and other injuries after jumping from a bathroom window to escape a schizophrenic man, craig cantwell, who was threatening to kill her at a birkenhead home. the 29-year-old cantwell had locked the bathroom door and demanded the care worker bend over while making sexual advances. desperate to escape, the care worker broke the window and managed to call for help but cantwell threatened to kill her as she tried to leave, damaging a van and a car when the milkmen tried to intervene. cantwell denied charges of grievous bodily harm, affray, and sexual offenses, but was convicted after a four-day trial. the judge expressed concern over the care home's handling of the situation and remanded cantwell in custody until sentencing, noting that the care worker should not have been placed in such danger.
1842	suni faith anderson, a personal trainer, was sentenced to 15 years in jail for having a two-year sexual affair with a 14-year-old boy during workout sessions at his home. the victim's mother spoke in court and held up a photo of her son, criticizing anderson for corrupting her child. anderson fainted after hearing the sentencing and was later revived by court staff. her husband pleaded for leniency, but the victim testified about the affair and how he had lost the respect of his peers. the case resulted in several job losses for the couple as they were no longer allowed to work with youths. anderson pleaded guilty to two counts of forcible sexual abuse and will be listed as a sex offender.
1843	surrey county council has obtained a license to conduct weddings in the victorian courtroom where the trial of downton abbey character john bates was filmed. the ornate room, located in surrey's kingston-upon-thames headquarters, has been used for filming shows such as downton abbey, poirot, and eastenders since 2006. die-hard downton abbey fans may opt to get married in the same courtroom where mr. bates' trial took place. the cost for a day's exclusive use of the courtroom for the ceremony and one of the other grand chambers for the reception ranges from £3,000-£3,250. other shows filmed at the location include lewis, endeavour, midsomer murders, and silent witness, among others. downton abbey's fifth series premieres on sunday night, and fans can look forward to the return of characters such as lady mary and tom branson.
1844	nadine dorries and john redwood, both conservative mps, have called for more power for english mps to decide on laws that only affect england if scotland votes for independence on thursday. redwood suggested that the house of commons should function as an "english parliament" most of the week, while dorries criticized scottish mps for alleged misuse of funds. scottish labour mp dame anne begg warned against hasty changes to the constitution and urged a coherent approach to more devolution for scotland and wales. redwood also envisioned keeping some policy areas, like foreign affairs, under the uk parliament's remit.
1845	in a tv talk show years ago, four men claimed reverse discrimination against them due to affirmative action programs and blamed "black women" for stealing their jobs. the speaker questioned their entitlement and title of the show, arguing men felt they owned the positions. suzanne venker's piece condemned feminist women for unhappy male-female relationships, contending women have emasculated men and destroyed the relationship between the sexes. venker's argument mirrors historical anti-feminist claims that women are responsible for men's unhappiness, despite lack of empirical basis. the speaker criticized venker's piece for perpetuating the harmful "good women/bad men" notion. the real situation, they asserted, shows men adapting to gender equality and evolving roles, and the evidence suggests that men are not as unhappy or resentful as venker suggests. men demand equal respect and equal treatment, rather than being portrayed as biologically predetermined beings. the gendered roles perpetuated in venker's argument are damaging, and men refuse to accept male-bashing or the notion that they cannot be happy in an equal society. the speakers advocate for men and women as allies and the ongoing progress towards gender equality.
1846	a new perfume line called the library of fragrance, based in new york, is launching in the uk next week with unusual scents including play-doh, pizza, beeswax, and clean skin. the company, founded in 1996 by mark crames, offers over 100 fragrances, some of which are household smells or unusual odors. the line caters to various budgets, with a 30ml bottle priced at £15. crames, who started with three scents (dirt, grass, and tomato), explained that scent is a strong memory trigger and offers a fragrance for every memory. some of the other scents include chocolate chip cookie, hay, lavender, and ocean. the full range of 101 smells will be available online and at boots stores starting tuesday, with plans to launch uk-specific smells in 2023.
1847	the nypd has launched an internal investigation after officers were found to be posting pictures of themselves in uniform on dating websites, violation of the department's social media policy. several profiles have been taken down, but some officers continue to look for love on sites like match.com and okcupid. this is not the first time uniformed personnel from other services, such as the u.s. marines, have been discovered using dating websites in uniform. while some argue that resources could be better used fighting cybercrime, the departments have different policies regarding uniform appearance on dating sites, with disciplinary action taken against offenders.
1848	ringo starr and his wife, barbara bach, are selling their 200-acre rydinghurst estate in surrey, england, which they purchased for £2 million in 1999. the grade-ii listed jacobean mansion offers a glimpse into their luxurious lifestyle, featuring a music room for starr's gold records and drum kits, a ballroom-sized music room, a kitchen with specific food requirements, and beautifully landscaped gardens. the couple, who have five children between them, are selling the property as they spend most of their time in london and the united states due to work commitments and charitable endeavors. starr is also planning to move to california to maintain a healthy lifestyle and be closer to his family. the sale ends a nearly five-decade association of the beatles and surrey, which began when they moved to the area to escape the press in 1965. the estate includes a cinema, entrance lodge, cottage, coach house, indoor pool, gym, paddock, helipad, and stables.
1849	the un intergovernmental panel on climate change (ipcc) has issued a new report urging governments to phase out the use of fossil fuels by the end of the century to limit global temperature increases to 2°c. the report warns that continued greenhouse gas emissions will cause "severe, pervasive and irreversible" impacts worldwide, and urges a 70% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2050. however, critics warn that relying on renewable energy sources to replace fossil fuels could increase the risk of power blackouts and soaring energy bills. britain, which currently depends on fossil fuels for more than two-thirds of its electricity, faces particular challenges in making the switch. the ipcc report suggests that fossil fuels could continue to be used beyond 2100 if carbon capture and storage technology is developed on a large scale. however, critics argue that this is an expensive and unproven solution, and that phasing out fossil fuels before reliable green energy sources are available could negatively impact living standards. the report also suggests various adaptation measures, including changing diets and growing new types of food, to mitigate the impacts of climate change. it will act as a guide for governments as they prepare for un climate talks in paris next year.
1850	a 16-year-old high school sophomore named anthony burruto, who is a talented baseball pitcher with a 80-mph fastball but struggles to field bunts due to not having legs and using prostheses, was cut from his baseball team at dr. phillips high school. burruto, who has been playing baseball since he was 8 and has played in the fall league and junior varsity team, felt the coach's rejection was unwarranted as bunts were not even part of the tryout. burruto's mother, diane, expressed her disappointment and stated that her son was a good athlete and pitcher, and that he worked hard to improve. the school spokesman stated that burruto was given the same opportunities as other players and that he, along with 22 others, did not make the team due to limited roster spots. however, burruto is unsure if he will try out again next year due to the coach's remarks and the support of his teammates.
1851	twitter reported a significant increase in government requests for content removal in the second half of 2014. turkey filed the most requests, with over 477, a 150% increase compared to the first half of the year. russia and germany followed with 91 and 43 removal requests respectively. overall, requests for removal of material grew by 40% globally. the interactive map from twitter's transparency report reveals that turkey filed more than five times the number of requests than any other country. twitter's first annual transparency report was filed in 2012, designed to "shine a light on government requests for customer information."requests from turkey predominantly focused on accusations of violation of personal rights and defamation. in russia, requests included promotion of illegal drugs and attempts to suppress non-violent demonstrations. most german requests dealt with alleged hateful and discriminatory content. compliance rates globally increased 8%, with the highest in france, where 43% of requests were withheld. some countries, such as the us, uk, australia, colombia, cyprus, hong kong, indonesia, italy, norway, united arab emirates, and venezuela, did not file any removal requests during the second half of the year. the report concludes by encouraging more companies to publish government removal demands for transparency.
1852	the fbi announced today that they believe they have identified the criminals responsible for the $500 million art heist at boston's isabella stewart gardner museum in 1990. the thieves, who disguised themselves as police officers, stole 13 masterpieces by artists including rembrandt, vermeer, and degas. authorities believe the art was taken to connecticut and the philadelphia region and offered for sale in philadelphia around a decade ago. the fbi has not released the names of the suspects but stated they belong to a criminal organization based in the mid-atlantic states and new england. the empty frames from the stolen works remain on display at the museum as a reminder of the missing masterpieces, which include rembrandt's 'storm on the sea of galilee' and vermeer's 'the concert.' the fbi is actively offering a $5 million reward for information leading to the safe return of the stolen art.
1853	dr. john king, a dedicated family doctor and senior partner at biddulph medical centre in cheshire, took his own life on september 11, 2012, just ten days before his son michael was due to undergo a kidney transplant. dr. king, 51, had become severely depressed over his son's diagnosis and had suicidal thoughts. despite having no prior mental health issues, he was taken to a health center in march 2012 where he admitted to developing suicidal thoughts and displayed signs of stress and cognitive difficulties. he was hospitalized and later discharged on may 30, but did not engage in continued treatment, preferring to spend most of his time in bed. dr. king's wife, dr. pamela king, who is also a gp, discovered his body in the garage of their congleton home. the hearing at macclesfield magistrates' court was told that dr. king was described as an 'old school' doctor who talked extensively with patients about their conditions and was particularly anxious about michael's kidney transplant. dr. pamela king said her husband felt hopeless about his own condition and did not engage with mental health treatment. coroner dr. janet napier recorded a verdict of suicide by hanging and offered her condolences to dr. pamela king. if you need confidential support, call the samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local samaritans branch. see www.samaritans.org for details.
1854	nani, a portuguese winger who was signed by manchester united from sporting lisbon for £20 million in 2007, has returned to his native country on a season-long loan as part of a deal that sees marcos rojo move in the opposite direction for £16 million. nani, who made a total of 230 appearances and scored 40 goals for manchester united, fell out of favor last season, making only 13 appearances and scoring once. new manager louis van gaal was willing to let nani leave to join his former club in an attempt to resurrect his career. nani's return was met with excitement by sporting lisbon fans, as he was welcomed back at the airport and hordes of supporters gathered to greet him. argentine defender marcos rojo is set to join manchester united from sporting lisbon in a £16 million deal.
1855	the obama administration is enhancing security for certain flights coming to the united states from europe and the middle east due to concerns over the development of advanced bombs by terrorists. the tsa will implement additional security measures at selected overseas airports, primarily focusing on those in europe and the middle east. passengers may encounter additional inspections of shoes and electronics, more extensive use of scanners, and further screening at boarding gates. the changes do not apply to domestic flights and could take effect as early as next week. the decision follows new intelligence on terror groups attempting to create new types of explosives that are more difficult to detect. the uk has also announced increased aviation security measures without disclosing specific details. since the 9/11 attacks, us aviation security efforts have focused on hijackings and plastic explosives that can be carried aboard a plane or hidden in baggage, particularly concerns over al qaeda in the arabian peninsula.
1856	prior to the junior rugby league test between the junior kangaroos and junior kiwis at mt smart stadium in auckland, tensions rose during the pre-match haka. no tackles were made, but players from both teams clashed heads and pushed and shoved, leading to referees intervening to prevent further escalation. following the incident, the kiwi team went on to win the game with a field goal in the last minute. coach brent gemmell of the junior kiwis expressed that the situation had the potential to turn sour but ultimately calmed down. some rugby fans shared their opinions on social media about the pre-match haka.
1857	two catholic bishops, bishop of shrewsbury and bishop of plymouth, have criticized the bbc drama "wolf hall" for allegedly painting an inaccurate and perverse picture of thomas more, a revered english catholic saint. the bishops took issue with the portrayal of more as a scheming villain, while thomas cromwell is presented as a flawed hero. they warned about the anti-catholic theme in the series and called for historical accuracy. thomas more was a lord chancellor of england during henry viii's reign, who held protestant heretics prisoner, opposed the reformation, and was later beheaded for treason. catholic church considers him a martyr, and he was beatified in 1886. thomas cromwell, henry viii's favorite, was instrumental in arranging the executions of more and anne boleyn, and played a central role in the dissolution of the monasteries. he was later beheaded for treason.
1858	a video of two women in british airways uniforms filming themselves showering together and stripping off in a bathtub has gone viral on youtube, with over 140,000 views. the airline is currently investigating to determine if the women are actually employees. the footage, which contains explicit content, was recorded in a hotel bathroom during a stopover between flights and has been widely circulated among ba employees. the identities of the women remain unknown, and the airline has stated that they have no evidence to suggest that the women are or have ever been ba employees.
1859	a new study from the university of buffalo suggests that watching reruns of favorite tv shows can improve self-control. psychologists believe that people with limited impulse control are more likely to give in to temptation, and watching tv shows can help restore a good mood and boost self-control. participants in the study found it easier to maintain self-control after describing their favorite tv shows during experiments. researcher jaye derrick describes this phenomenon as "social surrogate restoration," and while exercise and reading can also improve mood, watching tv should not be dismissed as a source of unexpected psychological benefits.
1860	the author describes their experience at the constance moofushi resort in the maldives, starting with being offered a cold towel upon arrival. they were impressed with their overwater bungalow's rustic-posh design and personal amenities. they explored the island, enjoying various activities like swimming, snorkeling, and visiting local sites. the all-inclusive package offered fine dining, premium drinks, and no wristbands or exorbitant mini-bar prices. the author was surprised by how engaged they were in the offerings and ended their stay with a sunset cruise, a try-dive, and a kayak ride. turquoise holidays offers seven nights at the resort from £2,624pp, including flights, transfers, and all-inclusive accommodation.
1861	seventeen students from haralson county, georgia, were taken to hospitals after their school bus collided with a pickup truck around 7:20 a.m. on state highway 120. the pickup truck driver was seriously injured and airlifted to grady memorial hospital in atlanta. none of the students sustained serious injuries, according to school official kersha cartwright. video from cnn affiliate wsb depicted the bus being towed, and this incident comes following reports of other school bus accidents where buses have flipped over, with one reportedly occurring in new york city and another going off a bridge.
1862	a crowd of 300 protestors blocked three buses carrying 140 undocumented migrant children and their parents in murrieta, california, on tuesday. the protestors, who held banners that read 'return to sender' and 'go home,' forced the buses to turn around and head back to a customs and border facility in san diego. the protest came after mayor alan long urged residents to resist the federal government's plan to transfer central american migrants to california. the migrants, who had been flown from texas to ease overcrowding of facilities along the border, were primarily children fleeing violence and extortion from gangs in guatemala, el salvador, and honduras. the protestors' strident opinions were unequivocal, with some questioning who would pay for the migrants and expressing concerns about criminality. mayor long and mayor pro-tem harry ramos warned that busloads of migrants were expected to arrive every 72 hours for the next several weeks, leading to potential protests. u.s. authorities have announced that they will fly migrants to other cities and facilities in texas and california to help relieve the crunch at the border. the plan has sparked controversy and protests in several communities.
1863	the article highlights the significant impact of apple's iphone, which was launched on june 29, 2007, and revolutionized the mobile phone industry. initially priced at $600 and lacking a physical keyboard, the iphone introduced a new way of interacting with computers through touchscreens and revolutionized mobile communications. the iphone's app store, released in 2008, brought about a new economy and enabled users to customize their phones with various applications. the device also heralded the age of constant internet access, blurring the lines between work and home life. additionally, the controversy surrounding the manufacturing conditions of the iphone's components led to increased awareness of electronic supply chains and corporate responsibility. five years after its launch, the iphone has sold over 217 million units and transformed the tech industry with its innovative features and applications.
1864	a pharmacist named sarah sellers warned congress in 2003 about non-sterile conditions in compounding pharmacies, expressing concern over the absence of federal guidelines. ten years later, in 2012, a meningitis outbreak linked to contaminated steroid injections from the massachusetts-based new england compounding center (necc) resulted in 137 cases and 12 fatalities. the steroid, methylprednisolone acetate, was used for pain and inflammation treatment and was contaminated with a fungus. more than 75 medical facilities in 23 states received the potentially contaminated drug. due to a lack of federal jurisdiction, compounding pharmacies like necc have been largely self-regulated with inconsistent application of professional standards. rep. edward markey (d-massachusetts) and rep. rosa delauro (d-connecticut) plan to introduce bills to strengthen the fda's oversight of compounding pharmacies. current guidelines are outdated, and the fda has been working on new ones since at least 2006, but the process is still ongoing. compounding pharmacies originally served to create custom medications, but have evolved into large-scale operations. nearly 10 percent of drugs administered in the u.s. come from compound pharmacies, with some shipping thousands of custom drugs across the country. the fda urges anyone who has experienced any issues following an injection with the necc product to report it.
1865	a us researcher, ken buesseler from the woods hole oceanographic institution, reported that radiation levels in fish caught near the fukushima daiichi nuclear power plant remain elevated, indicating ongoing contamination of pacific waters. the majority of fish caught off japan show no sign of radiation at levels dangerous to humans, but close to the plant, cesium-134 and cesium-137 levels imply continued release of cesium into the food chain. the sources are likely sediment on the sea floor or groundwater seeping into the ocean, and researchers can't definitively determine which is the cause. the plant is no longer venting radioactive steam, but not all contaminated water is being recovered, and mutant butterflies have also been linked to the nuclear disaster. the operators have admitted downplaying the risk in the past. japanese authorities have banned fish with cesium levels above 100 becquerels per kilogram, but levels between 1,000 and 10,000 have been found, and two greenling fish tested above 25,000 bq/kg. the tokyo electric power company, the operator of the plant, said it is monitoring radiation contamination and has implemented preventative measures, but there is uncertainty and fear in the japanese public regarding the truth about the situation.
1866	australian federal police (afp) officers are being sent to the mh17 crash site in ukraine as part of a dutch-led humanitarian mission, after russian separatists permitted access. currently, there are 11 afp officers at the site with an additional 170 on the way. unarmed, their mission is to search for unrecovered bodies and remains, and conduct a forensic examination. the team aims to stay for two to three weeks and will bring back the remains for repatriation. the mission, prime minister tony abbott stressed, has "absolutely nothing to do with the politics of eastern europe." the prime minister held discussions in donetsk regarding team security, acknowledging potential risks to ensure the dignity of the deceased and their grieving families. the latest afp team deployment has the primary objective of securing the site and bringing back any remains. mh17 was shot down over ukrainian airspace on july 17 and killed 298 people, including 38 australians. the australian federal police mission is to recover human remains and bring them back home. the service for victims liam and frankie davison, who lost their parents on mh17, attracted a huge crowd of mourners. the couple, who met following a teenage surfing trip, were passionate about traveling, literature, and the beach. their family spent their last day together having a picnic in the forest, and their loved ones fondly remember their shared devotion.
1867	the search for 14-year-old autistic boy avonte oquendo, who went missing two weeks ago in queens, new york, focused on the sunnyside east rail yard on october 18 due to avonte's fascination with trains. bloodhounds lost and regained his scent in different areas, leading to extensive searches of subway stations, tunnels, and trains. the metropolitan transportation authority (mta) and nypd, along with various agencies, have worked together to search the city's infrastructure, including the sewer system and fresh direct truck depots. avonte's mother, vanessa fontaine, believes someone is holding him, and there is now a $77,500 reward for his safe return. the school safety officer on duty when avonte went missing is not being held responsible, but the family, represented by attorney david perecman, intends to file a lawsuit against the city. avonte was last seen wearing a gray striped shirt, black jeans, and black sneakers, and anyone with information is asked to contact the nypd.
1868	men's health magazine challenged three of its editorial team members, david morton, jamie millar, and mark sansom, to transform their bodies in just 10 weeks while juggling full-time jobs and family commitments. david, who was overweight and out of shape, lost 2st, 3 inches off his waist, and halved his body fat by incorporating morning cardio and weekend weight training. jamie, who was already in decent shape but wanted to add muscle, lost 7kg of fat and gained 7kg of muscle with intense and varied workouts. mark, who was encouraged by a loss to his father in tennis, added 10cm to his chest, lost 11kg of fat, reduced his body fat by 13%, and finished with 19-inch biceps through nutritional science and heavy lifting. each of the men adopted a dedication to fitness and lifestyle changes to achieve their goals. the full story of their transformations and a guide to transforming one's own body in 10 weeks is in the men's health june issue.
1869	netflix, an american media giant known for streaming blockbuster movies and tv series over the internet, is entering the uk market with plans to offer tens of thousands of films, including exclusive early access to new releases. the company has signed deals with leading film studios for first rights to offer blockbuster movies post-cinema runs. netflix faces competition from lovefilm, a uk on-demand service owned by amazon, and the pricing details for the uk market have not been announced yet. netflix started as a dvd rental business in 1997 and has since grown into the world's largest supplier of web downloads of films and tv with 25 million subscribers worldwide. the company, which revolutionized entertainment by giving members access to a vast selection of films and tv shows on demand, has embarked on a major international expansion that includes canada, 43 countries in latin america and the caribbean. paramount pictures, mgm, lions gate entertainment, sony pictures, walt disney motion pictures group, anchor bay entertainment, nbc universal, and 20th century fox are some of the studios netflix has deals with in the us, but the company is negotiating with them to secure rights for the uk and ireland market. the subscription-based service will be available on tvs, pcs, macs, mobile tablets and phones. netflix has lost 800,000 subscribers in the us due to price hikes and a disastrous attempt to split off its dvd rental business. the company's watch instantly service currently holds first-run rights to films from several studios, including paramount, mgm, and lions gate entertainment.
1870	an 80-year-old charity worker named ron hands, who had raised over £100,000 for bournemouth general hospital in dorset, was left neglected in a waiting room for hours after fearing he was having a stroke. the retired hotel doorman, who started the mary hands trust in 1989 after his wife's death from pancreatic cancer, phoned an ambulance and was taken to the hospital but was then made to sit in a wheelchair in the waiting room for most of the night. he was eventually diagnosed with a dental abscess and discharged after being kept awake watching drunk patients being attended to. angered by his experience, mr. hands wrote to the hospital's ceo requesting better treatment for pensioners and asking for an investigation into the incident. he had previously raised funds for hospital equipment at the hospital in his wife's name and was disappointed with the care he received. no reply has been received from the ceo yet.
1871	nancy stowe, a 75-year-old former female officer from belmont, north carolina, demonstrated her bravery once again when her grandson was robbed at a gas station in gastonia. despite not having a weapon, she intervened and confronted the robbers, scaring them off by pretending to have called 911. her son and grandson were injured during the incident, but they are recovering. the suspects are still at large, and police are using surveillance footage from the gas station to identify them. stowe previously served with the county sheriff’s department and the police department in coats, north carolina.
1872	the victorian government is under scrutiny for appointing dr. sonia sharp as a senior education official, who was the director of children's services in rotherham, england, during a 16-year child abuse scandal. between 1997 and 2013, hundreds of children as young as 11 were sexually exploited by gangs of men of pakistani origin, with authorities failing to take action due to fear of being labeled racist. dr. sharp, who left rotherham in 2006, has been praised for her work at the time but opposition leader daniel andrews has questioned her recruitment to victoria's education department. the uk national society for the prevention of cruelty to children (nspcc) criticized the "collective blindness" of authorities towards the exploitation, which resulted in devastating consequences for the victims. dr. sharp has taken responsibility for the failings during her tenure but faces calls for her resignation and a criminal investigation from some quarters. the report discovered that over 1,400 children were sexually exploited in rotherham and at least six victims have launched a class action against the council for potential millions in compensation.
1873	the article discusses the upcoming 20th anniversary of the murder of stephen lawrence, an 18-year-old aspiring architect who was stabbed to death by a group of racist thugs in eltham, london, in 1993. his parents, doreen and neville lawrence, have vowed never to give up their quest for justice, as two of the five original suspects have been convicted, but three others continue to evade justice. the article highlights how stephen's murder led to significant changes in the way authorities handle and investigate racist crimes in the uk, particularly the macpherson report which identified the metropolitan police as institutionally racist. the article also mentions how the police have become more sensitive to race issues and that there is still work to be done to achieve a police force that treats all members of the community fairly. the stephen lawrence charitable trust has been set up to provide opportunities for disadvantaged young people in his memory.
1874	this article highlights five destinations, currently under u.s. travel warnings, that offer unique experiences despite their unfavorable reputations. the first is band-e-amir lakes in afghanistan, a chain of six mountain-rimmed lakes known for their sapphire waters and local families' weekend visits, offering a peaceful respite. the second destination is ciudad perdida in colombia, a jungle trek to ancient ruins often marred by past cocaine production and violence. however, improving security situation and increased tourism have boosted its popularity as the next machu picchu. the third is mount damavand in iran, the highest volcano in asia and a popular trekking peak with a rich cultural history. kashmir in india, scene of violent protests and military presence, attracts roughly 20,000 foreign tourists and 500,000 indians each year to its attractions, including the gulmarg ski resort. lastly, mount nyiragongo in congo, home to the world's largest lava lake, remains closed due to conflict but will reopen to offer visitors an unforgettable experience once it does. each destination offers unique treasures beyond their negative headlines.
1875	authorities in oklahoma are investigating the potential use of the deadly russian drug krokodil, also known as desomorphine, in the deaths of two men, including justin mcgee, a father-of-four, and his unidentified friend. both men displayed horrific skin damage, which led to their hospitalization in the burns unit. mcgee's autopsy revealed evidence of krokodil use, and his family reported that he had been using the drug for some time. krokodil is an extremely potent drug that damages the body from the inside out, causing symptoms such as scaly, reptilian-like skin and eventual gangrene. it is made from readily available ingredients and is up to 10 times cheaper than heroin. the oklahoma bureau of narcotics (obn) is actively investigating the spread of krokodil in the us, with at least eight reported cases and at least two confirmed deaths. the drug is highly addictive and can lead to death within a few years, making it a last resort for users. officials believe that krokodil may be spreading across the nation, with confirmed cases in oklahoma, arizona, illinois, and new york city.
1876	photographs have emerged on a blog allegedly run by the terrorist group isis, showing women working in a hijab factory in iraq, covered from head to toe in black clothing while children play nearby. the factory, which is believed to be located in the nineveh province, is believed to be manufacturing and distributing hijabs to muslim women as per sharia law. over 10,000 hits and numerous shares on social media have been recorded since its posting on january 30, 2023. isis has taken control of mosul and imposed strict islamic dress codes, including the wearing of hijabs, niqabs, abayas, and gloves by women. however, critics view the enforced modesty requirements as a method of control. previous blogs by the same organization have featured images of public executions carried out by isis.
1877	a 20-year-old british soldier, cameron laing, died after being crushed between a vehicle and an uncoupled trailer during a military exercise on dartmoor. he was expecting a baby boy with his partner. the accident happened at bracken tor youth hostel near okehampton, devon, and the soldier suffered a traumatic head injury and cardiac arrest. an investigation is ongoing, involving both local police and military personnel. lieutenant colonel ian poole of 7 theatre logistic regiment paid tribute to laing, describing him as a "rising star" and a "true character" who was "always ready to help others."
1878	on february 10, 2014, during a live tv interview on ktla in los angeles, entertainment anchor sam rubin mistakenly identified samuel l. jackson as laurence fishburne while discussing their super bowl commercial appearances. jackson, clearly angered by the mistake, accused rubin of racism and insisted "we don't all look alike." despite rubin's attempts to apologize, jackson continued to express his disbelief and frustration. the confusion began when rubin asked jackson about reactions to his super bowl commercial, and jackson responded, "what super bowl commercial?" the incident has generated significant conversation, and both ktla and sam rubin have yet to respond to requests for comment. jackson became famous for his role in "snakes on a plane," while fishburne appeared in a matrix-inspired super bowl commercial this year. rubin, who has been the entertainment reporter for ktla since 1991, is known for going beyond the entertainment headlines and exploring the deeper meaning and impact of stories within the industry.
1879	a tomahawk missile successfully punched through a moving shipping container during a test off the coast of california, demonstrating its capability to hit moving targets and potentially extending the reach of the us navy's guided destroyers by over 1,000 nautical miles. the tomahawk block iv missile, which can adjust its flight path based on new information, hit the container with such force that it emerged on the other side and bounced along the surface of the water. this success could lead to the development of long-range anti-surface missiles to boost the navy's fleet capabilities. footage of the test shows the missile being launched from uss kidd and hitting the moving container with explosive force, creating a large hole. the navy had previously attempted to develop a tomahawk missile with a 200-nautical mile range in the 1980s, but its limited success and potential danger to friendly ships led to its development into land-attack tomahawks.
1880	northern ireland's first minister peter robinson drew criticism for backing a pastor who labeled islam as a "doctrine spawned in hell" and expressed distrust towards muslims in britain. robinson defended the pastor's right to free speech, while apologizing in private to muslim leaders who were offended. the controversial remarks came at a time of increasing race hate attacks in northern ireland. robinson insisted his words were misinterpreted, with his original intent being to say he trusted muslims in everyday life but not for religious advice. he also suggested that his view of not trusting muslims who strictly follow sharia law was common in the western world. despite apologizing in private, robinson's initial public support for the anti-islamic pastor caused outrage.
1881	cristiano ronaldo and lionel messi are once again leading contenders for the fifa ballon d'or award as the world's best player, with both stars named on the three-man shortlist along with manuel neuer. ronaldo, who won the award last year, has scored 50 goals in 46 appearances for real madrid and portugal, helping them win various titles. messi, who has won the award four times, led argentina to the world cup final and scored 30 goals in la liga. neuer, who won the golden glove at the world cup, established himself as bayern munich's number one goalkeeper and added two more medals to his collection. ronaldo, messi, and neuer were also nominated for the fifa fifpro world xi, along with coaches joachim low, carlo ancelotti, and diego simeone, and several barclays premier league players like thibaut courtois, branislav ivanovic, vincent kompany, pablo zabaleta, angel di maria, cesc fabregas, eden hazard, mesut ozil, yaya toure, sergio aguero, and diego costa. the winners will be announced at a ceremony in zurich on january 12, 2016.
1882	a giant yellow rubber duck created by dutch artist florentijn hofman, currently on display at taiwan's keelung port, burst and deflated on new year's day, leaving locals disappointed. the cause of the incident is under investigation, with possible theories including an eagle attack or sunshine overheating the duck after weeks of cold, rainy conditions. the duck, which arrived in taiwan in september for a multi-city tour, has previously faced misfortunes in hong kong, beijing, osaka, sydney, sao paolo, amsterdam, and taoyuan. the damaged duck will be replaced with a borrowed copy as soon as possible. previous incidents include the duck's unexplained deflation in hong kong and explosion in taoyuan, as well as a vandalism incident in belgium where it was stabbed 42 times. the duck has gained significant attention and community support following various unfortunate incidents.
1883	david bez, a graphic designer and salad enthusiast, transformed his lunchtime routine over the past four years by making a salad every day at his office. with no cookery training, he became determined to debunk the idea that salads are unsexy or unappetizing. having moved from italy to london and gained weight due to unhealthy eating, david was inspired by friends' health struggles to reconsider his relationship with food. he began experimenting with salads, eventually publishing a blog featuring 365 unique salad creations that attracted a large following and became a book, "salad love." with his wife vera and three-year-old son nico, david continues to explore the world of salads and inspire others to discover their potential.
1884	two young men, max cave, 21, and luke harty, 19, were shot with a pellet gun while "free running" or climbing on a rooftop in horsham, sussex. a 47-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of grievous bodily harm. the incident occurred while they were taking pictures of the view after climbing scaffolding. the group, which includes members aged between 14 and 24, had faced criticism earlier for their dangerous stunts, including climbing a 100ft crane without safety equipment. a month before the shooting, a fire department official stated the group's actions were "irresponsible and reckless." the group had insisted their stunts were safe due to their intensive training.
1885	a city lawyer, margaret rowe, 65, claimed she was sacked from her £184,000 a year job at fidelity worldwide investment after objecting to her boss, james bateman, sharing a nude portrait of his wife with junior women staff. rowe believed the gesture was objectifying and disrespectful. fidelity maintains the portrait was meant as a challenge against the objectification of women, but the tribunal heard that rowe was labeled "aggressive" for her forthright emails and was accused of playing the "woman card" when she disagreed with business decisions. rowe, who earned bonuses of up to £49,000 annually, claimed she was dismissed before her intended retirement age, ending her career abruptly. the tribunal continues.
1886	crystal palace manager neil warnock has admitted that the club will face a hectic transfer deadline day after putting recruitment plans on hold for their premier league trip to newcastle. warnock secured wilfried zaha's return from manchester united on a season-long loan deal and is still keen on signing southampton's jack cork and norwich's gary hooper. palace have started the season with back-to-back defeats and are desperate for points and morale boosting signings, but warnock has revealed he did not even discuss budget or transfer targets with co-chairman steve parish before taking the job. warnock is looking to add three or four players to his squad before the transfer window shuts on monday, with tottenham defender ezekiel fryers also a target. palace take on newcastle on saturday, and warnock is urging the team to pull together in the face of recent turmoil.
1887	a new york city cab driver, koffi komlani, 53, who struck and killed 9-year-old cooper stock and injured his father, dr. richard stock, on the upper west side in january, has been charged with failing to exercise due care. komlani was initially given a ticket for failure to yield to a pedestrian and was not charged with vehicular homicide due to a law requiring two separate citations. at the time of the crash, komlani had been driving on an expired tlc license for six months. cooper's mother, dana lerner, expressed dissatisfaction with the charge against the cabbie, stating that "he hit two people and a child died. that’s not a traffic violation. that’s a crime." if convicted, komlani could face up to 15 days in jail and a fine of $750, as well as losing his driver's license. the case sparked an outrage in new york city, leading to the implementation of the vision zero program, a citywide initiative to end traffic deaths by creating "slow zones." cooper's law, which automatically suspends taxi drivers' tlc licenses if they kill or injure a pedestrian due to failure to yield, was passed in his memory.
1888	a ups plane crash near dubai international airport on friday resulted in the fatalities of two crew members, identified as captain doug lampe of louisville, kentucky, and first officer matthew bell of sanford, florida. both were en route to cologne, germany, and had been with ups since 1995 and 2006, respectively. the cause of the crash remains unclear, but the 747-400 aircraft had undergone a major inspection in june 2010. ups expressed deep sympathy for the families and friends of the crew members and stated that thoughts and prayers would continue to be with them. the national transportation safety board has dispatched an aviation investigation team to assist the general civil aviation authority of the united arab emirates in the investigation, with the gcaa leading the process.
1889	an apartment complex, 40 riverside boulevard, is being developed on manhattan's upper west side by extell, with plans for 55 low-income homes. however, these units will be separated from the luxury river-view condos with a different entrance at the rear of the building, sparking controversy. new york city's inclusionary housing program allows developers to access tax breaks for creating or preserving affordable housing units. the 33-story tower will house 530 units, with the affordable units priced at $845 for a studio and $1,099 for one and two-bedrooms, while luxury seven-bedroom homes in the neighboring building sell for $15.9 million. extell stated that the separate entrances are due to efficiency, cost, and financibility, and aim to meet neighborhood housing needs.
1890	a small plane crashed at cork airport in southern ireland on thursday, resulting in the deaths of six people and injuries to six others. the survivors were taken to a local hospital, where four of the injured were listed as serious but not critical and the other two were described as comfortable. the crash caused a fire and scattered debris over a large area, and the plane, which was coming from belfast in northern ireland, had been attempting to land in low visibility on its third attempt. the airport and surrounding roads were closed. irish and british experts will investigate the cause of the crash, which involved a metro liner leased from flightline bcn in spain and operated by low-cost airline manx2. the irish and northern irish governments expressed their condolences to the families of the deceased and wishes for a speedy recovery for the injured.
1891	two inmates, jeffrey skeele, 27, and spencer mclaughlin, 46, have died by suicide at licking county jail in newark, ohio, within a week of each other. both men were discovered with bed sheets tied around their necks. skeele had been checked 30 minutes before his death on charges of credit card theft, while mclaughlin was checked just seven minutes prior to his suicide after being arrested on a felony count of telephone harassment. the jail has a history of inmate suicides, with six deaths since 2011, including that of stanton deeley in 2014, who killed himself just before accepting a plea deal for burglary charges. in response to previous suicides, staff were found to have not done their mandatory bed checks and lied about doing their rounds, resulting in job losses for five staff members. the jail has now added a mental health staff member to prevent future suicides. the families of the latest victims are seeking answers and expressing concern for the care of inmates. the sheriff finds the suicides frustrating and is committed to finding a solution.
1892	the world health organization (who) estimated that approximately 7 million people died from air pollution globally in 2012, with over half of these deaths linked to indoor smoke from cookstoves. air pollution is now considered the "single largest environmental health risk" by who. the vast majority of deaths associated with air pollution were attributed to heart disease, stroke, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and lung cancer. the western pacific and southeast asian regions were the hardest-hit, with an estimated 2.8 million and 2.3 million deaths, respectively, due to polluted air. indoor air pollution, primarily from the use of coal, wood, and open-air fires for cooking, was responsible for a majority of the deaths in the southeast asian region. around 3 billion people globally rely on these fuels for cooking, with 63% of india's population using such fuels. poor women and children are disproportionately affected as they spend more time at home breathing in harmful pollutants. outdoor air pollution killed an estimated 3.7 million people, mostly in low- and middle-income countries, and was primarily linked to cardiovascular diseases. sources of outdoor pollution include diesel engines and industrial emissions. china is considering car bans and other measures to address worsening smog levels.
1893	the fbi has arrested and charged california state senator leland yee with accepting money and campaign donations in exchange for providing official favors and helping broker an arms deal. the case has shed light on the underworld of chinatown in san francisco, where the leader of a powerful asian gang, raymond 'shrimp boy' chow, is accused of running a criminal enterprise. chow, who was previously convicted of gun charges and spent years inside san quentin prison, is said to have used his position as the dragonhead of the ghee kung tong to launder money, receive and transport stolen property, and traffic in contraband cigarettes during an fbi sting. chow, who rose to power after surviving a shooting at a chinatown restaurant in 1977, has posed for photos in expensive suits and traditional chinese clothes, and has previously been associated with prominent politicians such as gavin newsom. the complaint also alleges that yee's campaign consultant, keith jackson, was involved in the criminal enterprise and was arrested alongside chow. yee has withdrawn from the race for california secretary of state and has been suspended by the state senate. chow and jackson are being denied bail and face a busy near future in court. yee's allies have questioned why he was targeted in the sting and have cautioned that he is innocent until proven guilty. the allegations have shocked the chinatown community, which is known for its tight-knit network of fraternal organizations and history of gambling houses, opium dens, and gangland-style murders.
1894	a beach cleanup event in cornwall, uk, allows children to enjoy finding lego pieces that have been washing up on the shores since a container ship named tokio express was lost at sea with nearly five million pieces in 1997. during the storm, 4,756,940 pieces, including sea-themed items like cutlasses, octopuses, scuba tanks, and flippers, fell into the ocean. some collectors have found theseitems on the beaches, making them highly sought-after treasures. oceanographer curtis ebbesmeyer suggests that theoretically, these lego pieces could have ended up on any beach around the world. however, the most significant concentrations have been found in cornwall, and many are considering the impact of such marine litter on the environment and wildlife. an estimated 2,683 containers are lost at sea annually, posing unresolved consequences for the marine ecosystem.
1895	there have been a series of overdoses related to synthetic marijuana, also known as k2 or spice, in both austin and dallas, texas. in 2011, the texas department of state health services made it illegal to possess marijuana-like substances commonly found in these products. last week, austin police responded to 15 possible k2 overdoses within a 23-hour period. dallas hospitals reported at least 40 overdoses in the last 48 hours. no arrests have been made for k2 possession alone, but narcotics arrests have been made and some suspects had k2 on them. dallas police are following leads to determine the source of the overdoses. no deaths have been reported yet, but toxicology results from the medical examiner's office usually take several months.
1896	cnn's annual "cnn heroes: an all-star tribute" willfeature grammy award winner john legend performing "wake up everybody" with hip-hop artist common and canadian r&b singer melanie fiona. the event, airing on thanksgiving night, will also include presenters halle berry, demi moore, jessica alba, kid rock, ll cool j, renee zellweger, gerard butler, kiefer sutherland, marisa tomei, and aaron eckhart. bon jovi will perform a new song "what do you got?" from their greatest hits album. country music duo sugarland will perform "stand up" from their new album. anderson cooper will host the show from the shrine auditorium in los angeles, showcasing the top 10 cnn heroes of 2010. the program, which highlights everyday people changing the world, has received over 10,000 nominations from 100 countries. past performers include nicole kidman, glenn close, and mary j. blige. the miner who were trapped in chile for 69 days and their five rescuers will attend the event as special guests. the 2009 cnn hero of the year, efren peñaflorida, received $125,000 for bringing education to poor children in the philippines.
1897	cnn student news from november 9, 2012, featured maps related to greece, guatemala, japan, michigan, and utah. no specific news stories or details were provided in the given text, so it's hard to summarize beyond mentioning the countries and states mentioned in the maps. to access the transcript of the show, please click the link provided. there may be a delay between the video's availability and the publication of the transcript.
1898	a bus explosion in nairobi, kenya, killed one person, believed to be a tanzanian man with suspected ties to the militant group al-shabaab, and injured at least 40 people, most of whom were ugandans returning home for the holidays. the attack occurred on a uganda-bound bus in the central business district, leaving blood stains and luggage scattered at the scene. the suspect, who resisted having his luggage examined, dropped his bag which then exploded. authorities suspect al-shabaab involvement due to the suspect's nervous behavior and the group's previous threats against uganda and burundi, both of which contribute troops to the peacekeeping effort in somalia. the bus was bound for kampala, and kenyan and ugandan authorities are investigating the attack together and increasing security along their borders following warnings of holiday terror attacks by al-shabaab. the group has previously claimed responsibility for july bombings in kampala that killed over 70 people.
1899	a 13-year-old white girl named amy wrote a letter to herself at the age of 14, expressing her feelings of being hated and despised by the asian men who had exploited and raped her. amy had been groomed and introduced to older men, drugs, and alcohol by the group, and wrote about the shame and confusion she felt about her ordeal. south yorkshire police had previously known about a crime pattern involving the sexual exploitation of young white girls in rotherham by asian men, but no action was taken against the perpetrators. confidential documents reveal that the authorities ignored warning signs, including a british pakistani man found with a 12-year-old girl, a bottle of vodka, and pornographic images of her, and a 14-year-old girl who had been missing for a week and was found under the influence of drugs with a man 20 years older. only the victims were taken into custody, and no one was prosecuted for the alleged crimes. south yorkshire police discovered evidence of thousands of similar crimes and described "networks of asian males exploiting young white females," but there have been only two prosecutions of groups of men for sexual abuse since 1996. calls for a public inquiry into the sex grooming by gangs and the trafficking of girls have grown in the wake of these revelations.
1900	jared powers and winona valdez of sacramento, california, a happily married couple since 2009, were shocked to discover suspicious posts and their own photographs on cheaterville.com, a website that claims to expose cheaters. the couple claim that the photos were stolen from valdez's facebook page and that they are unaware of the person responsible for the malicious posts. cheaterville's founder, james mcgibney, claims the site was not intended to harm but to provide information about unfaithful partners. despite this, powers and valdez have filed a defamation lawsuit against the site's owners, claiming severe distress, loss of reputation, and economic damages. an attorney for cheaterville argues that the site is not legally responsible for third-party content, stating that liability lies with the person who made the statements, similar to how facebook is not held accountable for defamation on its platform. however, the couple contends that cheaterville goes beyond allowing users to air their grievances and actively encourages slanderous and libelous comments as part of its business model.
1901	birmingham city council's £65 million wheelie bin scheme has been criticized for using google street view to determine which homes are suitable for the new bins. great barr resident dorothy bradbury, 79, was told she must exchange her black sacks for a wheelie bin, despite having to negotiate ten steps to leave her rubbish outside her home. google images of her property allegedly failed to show the steps and the slope, making it impossible for her to use the bin. councillor jon hunt, who opposes the scheme, said many properties in the area were on steep slopes and unsuitable for wheelie bins. residents can appeal against the imposition of a bin, but the process is not obvious from the letters they received. around 95% of homes have been deemed suitable for wheelie bins, with the others continuing with their current arrangements. assistant director of bins kevin mitchell defended the use of google street view, stating it was helpful in assessing properties with large gardens, but in marginal cases, officials would visit properties for a more accurate assessment.
1902	a lorry driver named bob baker, who weighed 18.5 stone (123 kg) and led an unhealthy lifestyle, faces losing his hgv licence due to high blood pressure. determined not to lose his livelihood, he began an extreme health-kick, cycling 18 miles daily to work and overhauling his diet. within nine months, he lost five stone (31.8 kg) and 10 inches (25.4 cm) from his waistline. bob continued to adopt a healthy lifestyle, taking up running and kick-boxing, and even competed in a 45-mile bike ride and a triathlon. his latest challenge is participating in the clipper venture yacht race, where he plans to lose nine pounds during the nine-day training trip and complete two legs of the round-the-world trip on a racing yacht. bob, who still drives lorries, also aims to trek to the north pole and take part in a six-day race across the sahara desert to push his boundaries and live life to the full.
1903	this cnn article describes how the increasing polarization of the 2012 presidential campaign between mitt romney and barack obama is leading to a rise in unfriending, blocking, and hiding people on social media due to their political posts. many people have grown tired of the hateful tone and constant political debates on platforms like facebook and twitter, leading some to take steps to limit their exposure. surveys show that nearly one-fifth of people have blocked, unfriended, or hidden someone on social media due to political reasons, with the biggest complaints being about frequent postings, disagreements with others, and bothersome partisan political postings that involve mutual friends. some people have even gone as far as muting or blocking hundreds of accounts until after the election, while others have taken more drastic steps like decreeing their facebook page as a no-politics zone or threatening to report and silence opposing views on twitter. the article also provides some advice for navigating political conversations on social media, emphasizing the importance of being aware of your audience and considering having conversations in person rather than online. additionally, there are facebook pages for those tired of political posts, where users can express their frustration and vent their feelings. overall, thearticle highlights the growing trend of people using social media to distance themselves from opposing political viewpoints and the negative impact it can have on relationships.
1904	an iraqi immigrant, majid hussain, from exeter, claimed £35,000 in benefits for 13 years while having a secret bank account worth £36,000. he argued in court that he did not consider the money to belong to him under islamic law and his cultural beliefs, citing extracts from the koran. hussain stopped receiving income support in 2010 but still gets disability living allowance due to health issues. he faces charges of false representation and obtaining money transfers for not disclosing his assets to the department for work and pensions when applying for benefits. hussain claimed he received thousands from his father and was duty-bound to save it for his children. the trial is ongoing, with hussain insisting he had no intention to deceive and had been taught to obey his parents in islamic teachings. the prosecutor accused hussain of lying and dishonestly claiming benefits by not disclosing the account.
1905	a new outbreak of a gastrointestinal illness on the crown princess cruise ship is suspected to be caused by norovirus, according to princess cruises spokeswoman karen candy. at least 83 people, including passengers and crew members, have fallen ill with the virus, which causes symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. the ship, which has a capacity for over 3,000 passengers, left los angeles on saturday for a seven-day pacific cruise. norovirus is easily contagious and has infected people on multiple cruise ships in recent months, including the holland america ms veendam and coastal caribbean ships. the virus can spread quickly in closed quarters and through person-to-person contact. the navy has implemented strict sanitation procedures to prevent norovirus outbreaks on its ships. despite the prevalence of norovirus on cruise ships, the centers for disease control and prevention (cdc) reports that overall cruise ship-related outbreaks have decreased in recent years. passengers are encouraged to practice good hygiene, such as washing hands frequently and avoiding close contact with those who are ill, to minimize the risk of contracting norovirus or other illnesses on cruises.
1906	claire davis, a 17-year-old senior at arapahoe high school in colorado, remains in critical condition after being shot in the head by a classmate, karl pierson, during a shooting at the school on friday. pierson, who reportedly sought revenge against a librarian and couldn't find her, killed himself as police closed in. davis' friends describe her as sweet, spunky, and bright, and hundreds attended a vigil for her on saturday night. her father said she is not doing well and doctors are worried about swelling to her brain. the piersons, pierson's family, have expressed their condolences to davis' family and prayed for her recovery. police believe pierson and davis did not know each other. previous school shootings, such as columbine, influenced the response to this incident. pierson was known to act strangely at times.
1907	the liberal party's federal treasurer, phil higginson, has expressed his concerns about the prime minister's chief of staff, peta credlin, and her husband brian loughnane, who is the party's federal director, in two explosive emails. higginson described their relationship and their influential roles within the party as a "most serious current dilemma" and an "immensely serious issue." he believed it would never be allowed in the corporate world and accused those responsible for their appointments of causing in-house fighting and a lack of open communications within the party. higginson also claimed that he had only signed off on the party's accounts recently due to a significant delay in financial information from loughnane and the party's secretariat, and expressed concerns over financial reporting standards within the party. higginson threatened to step down from his role before june.
1908	the uk government is under pressure to increase high-speed internet access across the country, as more and more services are offered digitally. new data from the office for national statistics shows that 6.4 million adults in the uk, or 13% of all adults, have never used the internet, with older people and those on lower incomes being less likely to be online. lord neville-rolfe, a tory peer, has urged the government to make broadband an essential utility like water or power, as it has become "impossible to function" without it. the government insists that good progress is being made to roll-out superfast broadband, with over 4 million premises expected to benefit by the end of the programme. london has the highest proportion of web users (90%), while northern ireland has the lowest (79%). the government also aims to improve mobile services for 98% of uk premises by 2015. lord gardiner of kimble, the culture minister, acknowledges the importance of ensuring that those without internet access can still conduct business traditionally.
