1909	the peanut corporation of america (pca) shipped tainted peanut butter that tested positive for salmonella, despite previous discoveries of salmonella in their blakely, georgia, plant, according to the food and drug administration (fda). according to the fda report, pca found salmonella in various products including peanut paste, peanut butter, peanut meal, and oil-roasted, salted peanuts at the georgia plant multiple times in 2007 and 2008. proper practices demand that if a food product tests positive for salmonella, it should be destroyed, but in this case, it was not. when salmonella was found at the plant last september, no cleaning or cross-contamination measures were taken. violations also included contamination of plant surfaces and equipment, discovery of roaches near production areas, and an inability of the company's ventilation system to prevent salmonella contamination. the fda investigation began in january after pca was implicated in a salmonella outbreak linked to 502 illnesses in 43 states and canada, resulting in eight deaths. pca has recalled peanut butter and paste produced since july 2007, and the fda urges consumers to check their websites for updates and not consume any unverified products. pca denied allegations of "lab shopping" to get negative test results in order to ship the product. the investigation involved pca's production of peanut butter sold to institutions and peanut paste used in cookies, crackers, ice cream, and pet treats.
1910	new jersey democratic assemblyman john wisniewski, leading an investigation into republican governor chris christie's administration, believes laws were broken when christie's aides ordered lane closures at the george washington bridge for political retribution against a mayor who refused to endorse christie. the documents released by the state assembly committee suggest politics was behind the lane closures and top christie aides tried to stonewall media inquiries. governor christie, who is a potential presidential candidate in 2016, has strongly denied involvement, but wisniewski finds it hard to believe he had no knowledge of the ordeal. christie fired his deputy chief of staff, bridget anne kelly, for her role in the lane closure, and legal woes may continue for the governor regarding the scandal. christie is scheduled to visit florida next week to raise money for governor rick scott's re-election campaign, despite the ongoing investigation in new jersey.
1911	defense secretaries chuck hagel of the united states and chang wanquan of china held a tense meeting in beijing over the ongoing territorial dispute in the east china sea, with hagel warning china against unilaterally establishing an air defense zone and threatening japan. chang responded by stating that china is prepared to defend its territory and urged the u.s. to be vigilant against japanese actions. hagel also toured china's sole aircraft carrier earlier in the trip, making it the first time a u.s. defense secretary has been given access to the symbol of china's military power. the dispute centers on the east china sea's disputed islands, known as the senkaku in japan and the diaoyu in china, which china claims have been part of its territory since 1534 but were officially assimilated into japanese control in 1895. the u.s. has criticized china's recent declaration of an air defense zone over the area and has urged more transparency from china regarding cyberattacks and military operations. hagel also discussed the ongoing threat from north korea and the importance of denuclearizing the korean peninsula. the meeting came after reports that china had warned of unspecified retaliatory measures against u.s. aircraft that do not comply with its air defense zone demands.
1912	a humpback whale, approximately 32 feet long, washed up and beached itself in a public swimming pool by newport beach in sydney, australia, while on its northward journey to warmer waters. the cause of the whale's death is unknown, and it is currently lying in the stillest of waters, with a nervous wait to see if the next high tide will restore it back into the pacific ocean. if not, wildlife authorities will need to find a way to remove the rotting carcass, which is already emitting a putrid smell. whale beachings are common in australia, and humpbacks are regularly sighted along the east coast, often coming close to shore while feeding during their northward migration in june and july. humpbacks usually return to feeding waters in antarctica between september and november. a swimmer reported seeing the whale before it beached itself.
1913	thirty-eight australians who died when malaysia airlines flight mh17 was shot down in eastern ukraine in july have been formally identified, according to the federal government. operation bring them home is expected to conclude in the coming weeks when the final remains are returned to their families, accorded the dignity and respect they deserve. mh17 went down in rebellion-torn eastern ukraine, killing all 298 aboard, including 38 australians, who were believed to have been hit by a surface-to-air missile. the dutch safety board and public prosecution service are leading the international investigation into the disaster, which has been extended until august 2015 due to the ongoing civil war and russian intransigence. the australian and dutch governments continue to press for full implementation of united nations security council resolution 2166, which supports an independent investigation into the disaster.
1914	boris johnson, the mayor of london, blocked a campaign by christian groups from using london bus advertisements to promote their message that homosexuality can be cured. johnson personally vetoed the campaign, which mimicked a previous pro-gay initiative by stonewall, because he found it offensive and believed it suggested that being gay is an illness. the campaign, which was intended to run for two weeks on five bus routes covering top tourist destinations, was backed by the core issues trust and anglican mainstream. the advertising standards authority had previously approved the campaign and considered it did not infringe any advertising rules in the uk. however, johnson used his powers as chairman of transport for london to instruct the body to abandon the campaign, stating that london is a tolerant city and intolerant of intolerance, and that it is offensive to suggest that being gay is an illness that can be recovered from. the christian leaders were surprised by the censorship and expressed their disappointment at the decision.
1915	a new york city police officer has been accused of using excessive force during an incident at the myrtle avenue subway stop in brooklyn. in a video taken on thursday, the officer can be seen repeatedly hitting 20-year-old donovan lawson with his baton, causing a gash to his head that scattered blood onto bystanders, including his girlfriend. witnesses described the incident as brutal and violent, with lawson also being pepper sprayed before the attack. the nypd's internal affairs unit is investigating the incident, and lawson was later hospitalized and charged with several offenses, despite having no prior arrests. the incident occurred just hours before a separate incident in which an innocent man was killed by an nypd officer in a housing project stairwell in brooklyn, and the internal affairs unit is also investigating that incident.
1916	botox, a popular wrinkle treatment using purified botulinum toxin, has been hailed as a miracle by many celebrities. however, the idea of having it injected into one's face isn't appealing to all. a new toxin-free alternative, iovera or "frotox," promises instant results with no toxins left behind. the treatment, which uses cryoneuromodulation to freeze away forehead wrinkles, is available in the uk for the first time. unlike botox, which takes four days to work, the effects of frotox are immediate and last for up to four months. it has been hailed as a quick, painless alternative to botox by those who are needle-phobic. initial trials showed promising results, but some doctors caution that more studies are needed before it can be considered a safe alternative to botox. a 15-minute session costs £300. some experts argue that frotox should be seen as an additional option rather than a replacement for botox.
1917	the apollo theatre in london's west end, which was once owned by composer andrew lloyd-webber and criticized for its poor condition over a decade ago, experienced a ceiling collapse during a performance of "the curious incident of the dog in the night-time," injuring around 80 audience members on thursday. the cause of the collapse is being investigated, with excess water during heavy rain being one theory. nimax theatres, which currently owns and operates the venue, has a limited budget for restoration work and had been addressing damp issues before making improvements. past plans for interior renovations, including lord lloyd-webber's proposal for a black-box auditorium, have faced opposition. the investigation into the incident is being handled by the council, with criminal involvement ruled out. performances at the apollo have been canceled until january 4, and the london mayor praised the emergency services' response.
1918	a british actor named ricky sekhon, who is of indian descent and six feet four inches tall, plays osama bin laden in the upcoming movie "zero dark thirty," which tells the story of the manhunt for bin laden after the september 11 attacks. sekhon was nervous about taking on the role, as he had previously been cast as terrorists, drug dealers, or henchmen due to his appearance. he prepared for the part by reading books about terrorism, learning basic arabic, and slimming down. sekhon signed a non-disclosure agreement but told his family and girlfriend about the role. the film, which has limited release on december 19 and full nationwide showings beginning on january 11, has been nominated for four golden globe awards. sekhon spoke about the difficult process of preparing for the role, admitting that the news of bin laden's attacks was disturbing.
1919	kfc's campaign to encourage fans to vote for taylor swift in the triple j hottest 100 by offering a $19.89 voucher as a reward may have resulted in swift's disqualification from the annual alternative music poll due to the station's strict policy against incentives. the fast food chain's post asking fans to share their favorite taylor swift song for a chance to win a voucher caused controversy and division on social media, with some expressing disappointment and others pleased by the seemingly unintended outcome. the triple j hottest 100 poll's twitter account revealed that taylor swift's song "shake it off" came in at number 75 in an unofficial poll, and swift fans had been boycotting the australia day tradition and trending the hashtag "#tay4hottest100" as a response to the perceived bias against her. some extreme alternative music fans took to social media to intimidate taylor swift supporters, making violent threats. the triple j spokeswoman couldn't comment on the movement due to the open voting period.
1920	help for heroes, a british charity, unveiled 20 transparent statues of injured servicemen in trafalgar square on october 17, 2012, in honor of those wounded in conflicts such as afghanistan, iraq, kosovo, and bosnia. the statues, each inspired by a real person, will travel to the local communities of the servicemen they depict, raising awareness of their sacrifices and the ongoing challenges they face in rebuilding their lives after devastating injuries. simon brown, a reme mechanic who lost most of his sight when shot in the face in iraq in 2006, expressed the hope that these figures help the public realize that "normal guys" are making sacrifices. the statues, created by sculptor stuart murdoch, are sponsored by bell's whisky and aim to raise £1m for the charity. each figure represents the individual's bravery and resilience in the face of extreme war conditions. helping to maintain awareness of their ongoing challenges, as some may not receive the support they need once they leave the services.
1921	philip lemonheigh, 59, converted his wife's renault laguna estate car into a fake ambulance using a flashing blue light and emergency response stickers. he was caught speeding through a red traffic light at 73mph in llantrisant, near cardiff, while running errands for his bed-bound wife, noreen, who has a chronic medical condition. despite not having a driving license, lemonheigh disguised the blue renault as an ambulance and spent three months breaking traffic laws. he was eventually caught on camera and arrested for dangerous driving and perverting the course of justice. lemonheigh, who arrived at court in a wheelchair, admitted the unusual offenses but expressed that he didn't think he was doing anything wrong. judge peter heywood was baffled by the situation and said that he would ask for medical and psychological reports before sentencing lemonheigh on march 20. the fake ambulance case was a cautionary reminder from teresa healy, operations manager at gosafe, who is responsible for speed cameras in wales, encouraging everyone to be truthful with the authorities. lemonheigh described the incident as going "a bit far" and laughed about it after being caught.
1922	south sudan, which gained independence from sudan in 2011 and has since experienced ethnic violence and political instability, topped the list of the world's most fragile nations according to the fund for peace's annual report. the us, the uk, and france were among the countries that have worsened the most in the past year. the index ranks countries based on 12 indicators, including demographic pressures, human rights, and political impasse. south sudan's ranking is due to its fractious leadership, mass killings, and ethnic violence. other fragile countries include central african republic, democratic republic of congo, sudan, chad, afghanistan, yemen, haiti, and pakistan. iran led the list of most-improved countries, with zimbabwe, cuba, bolivia, and china also improving. the us, france, and singapore made the list of worsened countries, alongside central african republic, due to political and economic issues. the report emphasizes that instability is not exclusive to developing countries. south sudan's chaos began after president salva kiir accused vice president riek machar of plotting a coup in 2013. hundreds of thousands have been displaced as a result of the continuing conflict between their forces. the report covers the past year and excludes a few countries with inadequate data.
1923	a new conspiracy claim regarding the death of princess diana in 1997, involving the british military, has resurfaced 16 years after her fatal car accident in paris. the claim originated from the parents-in-law of a british special forces sniper, who allegedly boasted to his wife about the elite british special air service (sas) unit's involvement. the london metropolitan police stated that this is not a re-investigation, but military authorities have been made aware of the claim since a 2011 court-martial of the soldier's former roommate. no evidence or details about soldiers' involvement in the deaths were provided in the report, and the family of dodi fayed, diana's boyfriend, remained silent. the conspiracy theories surrounding princess diana's death have persisted, with allegations directed towards british and french intelligence services and members of the royal family, however, none have been proven.
1924	save the children's christmas jumper day campaign sees celebrities, including myleene klass and julie walters, proudly wearing naff christmas knits with snowmen, reindeers, penguins, and elves to promote the event and support vulnerable children. the fundraiser, which takes place on december 13th, aims to build on the success of the previous year's campaign, where over 275,000 people participated and raised £1 or more. celebrities, such as lorraine kelly, dom joly, and gok wan, have united behind the campaign. additionally, brands like john lewis are collaborating to increase fundraising. the charity offers group fundraising packs and encourages people to join the festive fun within their communities. celebrities, such as myleene klass and arlene phillips, will be leading initiatives like a pop-up shop for customizing christmas jumpers and attempting to break a guinness world record. donations, primarily through individual £1 text donations or the campaign website, are the primary source of funds. #christmasjumperday #savethechildren
1925	nottinghamshire county council has issued a safety warning over counterfeit frozen-themed snap bracelets sold on ebay, which are made of cut steel measuring tape instead of the expected plastic material. the bracelets, decorated with characters from the film, could cause children's wrists to be cut when worn. nottinghamshire county council received multiple complaints from parents who were concerned about the dangerous fake merchandise being sold online. julie brooks, a mother from nottinghamshire, discovered her purchased bracelets were made from metal after noticing poor quality and reported it to trading standards. officials urge parents to avoid purchasing these cheap and potentially dangerous counterfeit items as they pose a serious risk to children's safety.
1926	a 17-year-old girl named cassidy hooper, who was born without a nose or eyes, is set to undergo her final surgery to receive a nose made from bone and cartilage grafted from her body. the high school senior has already gone through two surgeries this summer to prepare for this procedure. she has had numerous surgeries since she was 11 years old, but has remained positive and determined. the operation will take place on september 18, and cassidy is excited to finally be able to breathe and smell through her own nose. cassidy's family has established a website (www.cassidyhooper.org) to help cover the mounting medical bills. cassidy's condition left doctors baffled, especially since she leads a healthy life with no other medical issues. doctors believe that she did not develop her nose or eyes in the first two weeks of pregnancy in her mother's womb. her surgeon, dr. david matthews, has been working on expanding her face to create a bony opening for the past five years. the surgery to replace her nose will involve placing the inner membrane first, followed by using cartilage and bone to create a nose structure, and then covering it with skin. experts explain that the nose is not necessary for breathing or smelling, but is mostly for appearance. cassidy hopes to one day have a career in radio and has recently spent time at her local radio station for experience. she has dealt with social difficulties, but has been attending a specialist school for the blind (governor morehead school) since the fifth grade and has learned to handle taunts from children well.
1927	australians have spent over $280 million on weight-loss products this year, with 75% of individuals aiming to be 'skinny.' however, being skinny does not always mean being healthy. in fact, around 1 in 4 skinny people are 'metabolically obese' and have pre-diabetes, a condition referred to as 'skinny fat.' these individuals may have a normal weight, but have excess body fat and poor health habits. the focus on appearing thin over being healthy can lead to unhealthy choices, such as poor diets and a lack of exercise. people who are 'skinny fat' are at risk for health complications such as high cholesterol, poor blood circulation, and insulin resistance. it's important for individuals to regularly visit their doctor and focus on overall health, rather than just weight loss. some simple ways to improve health include avoiding artificial sweeteners in soft drinks, incorporating more weight training into their fitness routine, consuming more omega-3 fat rich foods, drinking more tea to reduce stress, and getting enough sleep. a balanced diet and regular exercise are key to maintaining good health, regardless of weight.
1928	the financial industry is facing a new investigation as traders from barclays and royal bank of scotland have been suspended over allegations of fixing the currency markets. the global probe, involving regulators in britain, switzerland, the us, and hong kong, is looking into reports of traders sharing information and manipulating foreign exchange rates during a 60-second window. six traders at barclays and two at rbs have been suspended, with both banks declining to comment but confirming investigations. the foreign exchange market, worth £3 trillion daily, is under scrutiny for potential rigging, which could significantly impact the value of investments worldwide. this scandal comes at a time when many financial institutions are still dealing with the aftermath of the libor rigging scandal and record-breaking global foreign exchange activity of $5.3 trillion daily.
1929	the ainu museum and cultural village in hokkaido, japan, is dedicated to preserving the culture of the indigenous ainu people, who number around 24,000 and have a critically endangered language spoken by only 10 native speakers. the museum, located in the small town of shiraoi, features thatched houses, botanical gardens, and demonstrations of traditional practices such as singing, dancing, and mouth harp playing. visitors can learn about the ainu's animistic beliefs, use of natural materials for clothing and home decoration, and hunting methods, which may be considered brutal by modern standards. the ainu faced a harsh life in the past, and while they were not recognized as an indigenous group with a distinct language and culture by the japanese government until 2008, they continue to face economic and social challenges. plans for a new cultural center are underway in time for the 2020 tokyo olympics, with ongoing debate over its focus on presenting ainu history versus their current situation. the museum is open daily from 8:45 a.m. to 5 p.m. and costs jpy800 ($7) per adult.
1930	in brazil's arisvaldo de campos pires maximum security penitentiary, inmates are focused on producing high-quality crochet work as part of a collaboration with brazilian fashion designer raquel guimaraes. the prisoners have earned one day off their sentence for every three days of knitting they complete. guimaraes turned to the prison for help in 2009 when she couldn't find enough knitters for her doiselles label. now, the hand-made pieces are sold in 70 stores in brazil and exported globally. inmates are paid a starting salary of 75% of brazil's minimum wage, with a quarter saved for their release. the project gives inmates confidence and skills for the outside world, raising their self-esteem and opening the door to employment opportunities. around 100 inmates have been trained since the initiative started in 2009. the knitting project is seen as a way to help prisoners be viewed as more than just criminals and earn redeeming freedom, integrity, and confidence. the prison is located in juiz de fora, minas gerais, and the work gives inmates something to focus their energies on while also earning wages to ease their release into society.
1931	a man identified as jesse dahlstrom, 35, was charged with premeditated first-degree murder for the fatal stabbing of sally marie pionk, a 75-year-old grandmother from minnesota, in a duluth grocery store on december 11. witnesses reported seeing dahlstrom enter the store with a steak knife, and he allegedly attacked pionk from behind in the bakery section, killing her with sharp and blunt force trauma to the neck. dahlstrom told investigators he went to the store intending to either shop or kill someone. he appeared in court, requesting to represent himself and was bail was set at $1 million. the case will be reviewed by a grand jury, and if they decline to indict, dahlstrom may face second-degree murder charges. pionk's family and friends described her as a loving mother and grandmother who dedicated her life to helping others. a candlelight vigil will be held in her honor. dahlstrom's family previously attempted to have him committed for psychiatric treatment seven years ago but were unsuccessful.
1932	raheem sterling, an english soccer player, grew up near wembley stadium and dreamed of representing england in international competitions. he has a tattoo of a young boy looking towards wembley stadium with a football. sterling, who rose to fame at liverpool, made an impressive debut in the world cup, scoring no shots against italy and even dispossessing andrea pirlo. sterling grew up in the stone-bridge park estate and used to play football in the car parks there. he was thrust into the starting lineup after an impressive performance against italy and will face his liverpool teammate luis suarez in the upcoming match against uruguay. sterling's mother has been a source of support for him and advised him to "make everyone in the country proud." frank lampard, a former england player, has praised sterling for his instincts and ability to think on the pitch. england's head coach, roy hodgson, shifted wayne rooney to the left to accommodate sterling in the central role against italy.
1933	reality tv star kim kardashian addressed the backlash over her quick divorce from nba player kris humphries, filed just 72 days after their highly-publicized wedding. in a blog post on her website, kardashian defended her decision to marry for love and admitted struggling with the pressures of reality television. she acknowledged feeling unable to end the relationship without disappointing fans, but accepted full responsibility for her actions. despite this, kardashian faced criticism, with some calling for boycotts of shows featuring her and her family. she emphasized the authenticity of their experiences and openness as a cornerstone of their brand.
1934	david beckham, the retired english football icon, has expressed his potential interest in returning to the pitch after a tough retirement from paris saint-germain (psg) last year. in a new bbc documentary titled "david beckham: into the unknown," beckham admits feeling an itch to play again after watching top athletes perform, and he might consider joining his proposed major league soccer (mls) team in miami. the former manchester united and real madrid midfielder embarked on a journey to the amazon rainforest with three friends for the documentary, which premieres on bbc one next monday.
1935	phil mcentee, a newmarket trainer, travels to california with european filly "living the life," who has been making waves in british all-weather racing, aiming to win the $1 million filly & mare sprint at santa anita racecourse. mcentee and owner hank nothhaft acquired living the life in the hope of introducing european blood into their north american operation. the filly's recent success can be traced back to her performance in the £91,000 fillies’ & mares' championships conditions stakes at lingfield. since moving to the united states, she has won both her races, both on synthetic surfaces. tomorrow's race will mark her first start on traditional dirt, and mcentee remains optimistic. living the life is a 10-1 shot. the european challenge for the breeders' cup begins tonight, with autumn stakes winner commemorative leading the charge for the juvenile turf. charlie palmer's solario stakes winner aktabantay was scratched due to a sore foot, replaced by faithful creek. aidan o'brien's qualify and richard hannon's osaila are other contenders. the all weather championships have received a boost with living the life's success. the second year of the program saw charlie appleby's tearless winning the listed fleur de lys fillies' stakes at lingfield. innovations this year include qualifying races in dubai, france, and ireland, as well as a new three-year-old sprint category. roger varian won his fifth group one race of the season with vert de grece in the criterion international at saint-cloud.
1936	emma parker bowles, a dog rescuer in los angeles, shares her experiences of rescuing dogs from homelessness and danger. she wears military fatigues and a bullet-proof vest while creeping through compton to rescue a brown terrier mongrel. emma volunteers with dogs without borders, saving dogs from pounds and finding them new homes. she also takes in strays and abandoned pets. she describes the saddening reality of dog pounds and the euthanization process. despite the heartbreak, she finds joy in rescuing and rehabilitating dogs, and believes every one of them deserves love and a forever home. she strongly recommends microchipping pets and advocates for adopting instead of buying. her passion for dogs drives her, and she believes a rescued dog loves its owner with every fiber of its being.
1937	in london, where space is limited and property prices are high, some homeowners are building underground extensions, known as "iceberg homes," causing controversy among neighbors. hans rausing, a tetra pak heir, is the latest to join the trend with plans for a double basement. neighbors complain of noise, vibration, and road closures during construction, as well as concerns about the impact on the water table. ersin sirer, a property developer and owner of the chelsea bun cafe, successfully built a basement extension in a south kensington mews house, now on the market for £5.95 million. despite digging 23ft down, he only faced one objection and completed the project with significant expenses for parking, sealing, and water management. the challenge of bringing natural light into the basement and desire for a warm, cosy yet chic feel led to the creation of four bedrooms, a media room, three en suite bathrooms, and abundant entertaining space. simon rose of selling agents strutt and parker believes this unique property will be attractive to potential buyers in belgravia or mayfair areas, seeking security and discretion. ersin will continue to operate the chelsea bun cafe, ensuring the family's culinary tradition persists.
1938	a mother named claire shares her experience of her son elliott's debilitating irritable bowel syndrome (ibs) symptoms that started when he began full-time school at the age of four. his symptoms included frequent tummy aches, diarrhea, and fear of using the bathroom at school. after undergoing various tests and elimination diets, a friend with ibs helped claire make the connection. ibs affects approximately 20% of children, and causes include stress and diet, although the underlying cause is unknown. symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea, and can be managed through diet modifications, stress reduction techniques, and medication in severe cases. children with ibs may also benefit from therapy or counseling. common foods to avoid with ibs include those high in fodmaps, such as apples, pears, onions, and garlic.
1939	a 58-year-old woman named roberta packman was sentenced to 28 weeks in jail for defrauding the uk government of over £38,000 in disability benefits. she claimed she couldn't walk unaided but was caught on camera playing a full round of golf at stony holme golf club in cumbria. the department for work and pensions (dwp) investigated her case and discovered her deceit, leading to her conviction for two counts of falsely claiming disability benefits from 2006 to 2011. dwp minister for welfare reform, lord freud, commented on the case, emphasizing the need for welfare reform initiatives, such as universal credit, and their intent to simplify the system and reduce fraudulent claims. the dwp also stated their commitment to combatting benefit fraud through frontline investigations.
1940	in "the cat's out of the bag: truth and lies about cats," author max cryer pays homage to the enigmatic and mysterious nature of cats through a collection of feline trivia and folklore. ambrose bierce's satirical definition of a cat as a soft, indestructible automaton is debunked, and the innate grace and aloofness of cats are celebrated. cats have left indelible marks on language, literature, movies, and music, and some beloved literary cats include the cheshire cat from alice's adventures in wonderland, mehitabel from don marquis' columns, and tobermory from saki's short stories. cats have also appeared in unexpected places in history, such as shakespeare's works, and in films like the bond films, breakfast at tiffany's, and inside llewyn davis. cats have proven to be intrepid companions throughout history, with famous examples like windy, a cat who flew with wing commander guy gibson, and simon, a cat who served on hms amethyst and was awarded the pdsa dickin medal. cryer's anthology serves as a heartfelt reminder of the bond between humans and cats, while also recognizing their nonchalant attitude towards their human companions.
1941	in mexico, at least 22 people, among them two federal police officers, were killed in clashes between criminals and federal police in michoacan state. the authorities reported that the other 20 fatalities were suspected criminals. the violence on tuesday resulted in 15 injuries and followed six planned attacks, which included gunbattles on blocked streets. federal police are currently searching for those responsible and have reinforced security in the area to maintain peace.
1942	british vogue published a burberry advertising campaign featuring 10-year-old romeo beckham despite editor alexandra shulman stating he is too young to appear in the magazine due to its model health initiative, which prohibits the use of models under 16. shulman tweeted about the controversy but clarified that she has no control over advertising features. burberry placed romeo on a billboard in los angeles. vogue launched the health initiative in 2012 to protect young models from exploitation and promote healthy body image. the magazine previously featured child actors, including chloe moretz, in editorial content. shulman responded to criticism by explaining that different rules apply to child actors and that she meant exactlu that vogue editorial would not employ under-16-year-olds to model adult fashion.
1943	jerry hall, the legendary supermodel known for her long golden locks and never-ending legs, surprised fans by cutting her hair into a chic new shoulder-length style, referred to as a "lob," during a l'oréal photo shoot. at 57, hall had kept the same long hairstyle throughout her 40-year career until this impulsive decision. actress and model loan chabanol also underwent a hair makeover with l'oréal during the same shoot. hall has previously cited hollywood glamour icons veronica lake and marlene dietrich as inspirations for her previous glamorous looks, but is now toning down the glamour as she approaches her 60th birthday. hall had a long and high-profile relationship with mick jagger, with whom she has four children, and has launched various products and attended numerous events during her career.
1944	a grand jury is set to consider charges in the death of eric garner, a 43-year-old black man who died after being put in a chokehold by an nypd officer, daniel pantaleo, on staten island in july. the district attorney, daniel donovan, announced the decision on monday, stating that the death was ruled a homicide caused by neck compressions from the chokehold, chest compression, and garner's prone position while being restrained. pantaleo, an eight-year veteran, was stripped of his gun and badge, and two paramedics and two emergency medical technicians were suspended without pay. civil rights leader al sharpton and garner's family are calling for federal involvement in the investigation, and a grand jury investigation is expected to begin soon. several members of new york's congressional delegation have also called for a federal investigation. garner's body was laid to rest on july 23, and tensions remain high in the community. grief and protests continue as the situation unfolds.
1945	george michael, the british singer-songwriter, performed in munich, germany, on november 17, 2011, but fell seriously ill afterward and was rushed to the akh hospital in vienna, austria, where he was diagnosed with severe community-acquired pneumonia. he has been treated with a triadynes proventa bed, which mimics natural movements to improve blood and lymph flow, and reduces lung pressure. the singer's condition stabilized but remains critical, and he is reportedly responding to treatment. the futuristic bed, which holds the patient securely while enabling medical staff to take chest x-rays and providing skin temperature control, has likely saved his life. the singer's family is believed to be by his bedside. michael, who has been in intensive care since november 20, is facing a long recovery process and his 14 remaining tour dates have been postponed. the illness has potentially affected his singing capacity, and his condition remains critical, with the next 48 hours crucial to his recovery. michael fell ill in his suite at vienna's imperial hotel on monday and was transferred to the akh hospital, which has advanced specialist facilities. the singer has been inactive on his twitter page since november 17. doctors have cautioned that a comeback in the new year is unlikely, as michael will need months of rest and recuperation. the illness could have a terrible effect on his voice depending on how long he spends on the ventilator, and in the worst-case scenario, it could seriously affect his singing capacity.
1946	a remote tropical beach in northern queensland, old mapoon beach, was hit by a three-tonne wave of marine debris last month.indigenous rangers and workers from tangaroa blue foundation spent five days clearing the seven-kilometre shoreline, finding an array of plastic waste, including fishing nets, plastic bottles filled with urine, false teeth, and an army of toy soldiers.much of the waste was traced back to southeast asia, adding to the problem of marine debris harming marine life in the area. heidi taylor, co-founder of tangaroa blue, said the organization's local contacts alerted them to the issue. mapoon beach is on the gulf of carpentaria, which receives stray waste from the arafura sea. the problem is expected to worsen as the world's population increases and more waste is produced. tangaroa blue has reportedly removed 3 million pieces of marine debris from the australian coastline since 2004. the organization's approach to tackling the issue is two-fold, with ongoing clean-up efforts and pressure on waste-producing companies to take more responsibility.
1947	new data obtained by the times reveals that rape and sexual assault are widespread in the british armed forces, with at least three reported rapes and 22 sexual assaults between men occurring over a two-year period. one former officer admitted that sexual assaults are used as bullying tactics, often involving penetration with objects. two shocking incidents include a 20-year-old soldier being assaulted by seven colleagues and a 28-year-old serviceman attacked by a gang of seven. the figures, which only include reported cases, may not be the full extent of the issue. critics argue that the way the military investigates sexual assaults internally leads to fear and mistrust, allowing the crimes to continue without offenders being brought to justice. the ministry of defence states they need more time to determine if anyone was prosecuted for the 25 alleged assaults and claims these types of incidents are no more common in the military than in wider society. the family of a royal military policewoman who committed suicide after being raped by colleagues accused the mod of a cover-up and called out the military for failing to address the issue effectively. since the case, the government has announced plans to reform the way sexual assault and bullying are handled in the military.
1948	an american man, steven neal greenoe, is under investigation by british authorities for allegedly smuggling over 60 firearms from north carolina to england on at least nine occasions. greenoe, a native of new orleans who lived in shrewsbury, england, is suspected of selling the firearms after they were imported. the guns were bought by an undercover police officer for £10,500 (around $16,500). a federal grand jury in the united states indicted greenoe on 43 counts, including smuggling firearms outside the country and falsifying documents. some of the firearms are unaccounted for, and ballistics tests showed one was used in a shooting in manchester, england. british authorities are working closely with their counterparts in the u.s. on the investigation, and greenoe is currently being held in north carolina. he had previously told airport officials that the firearms were non-working samples, but they were fully functional and had been disassembled and disguised to appear as something else. greenoe was arrested at raleigh-durham airport on two occasions, and the tsa declined comment on the case citing pending litigation. he is also charged with failing to notify a common carrier of an arms shipment and exporting firearms from the u.s. without a license.
1949	a 14-year-old girl named ayvani perez was abducted from her georgia home on tuesday, september 17, 2013, during a home invasion. the incident initially appeared random, but new information came to light about the girl's mother, maria magdalena corral, being arrested in 2012 on charges of drug trafficking with juan alberto contreras-ramirez, one of the suspects arrested in connection to perez's kidnapping. two men, contreras-ramirez and wildrego jackson, were taken into custody on wednesday, but the police are still looking for two african american males who matched the sketches of the abductors. perez was safely reunited with her family, but the investigation is ongoing. contreras-ramirez remains in custody on immigration-related charges, while jackson faces a conspiracy to kidnap charge. the girl's kidnapping sparked concern and a manhunt involving state, federal, and local officials. the community held a prayer vigil, and perez's classmates and family were relieved when she was returned home.
1950	a housekeeper, kim roberts, 58, from colyton, devon, has been charged with stealing around £500,000 worth of antiques and art, including a picasso sketch, from the dowager countess bathurst, during her employment at her cotswolds estate and kensington home. roberts appeared at gloucester crown court on friday and faces three counts of theft, including charges from a previous employer. she allegedly stole the valued items between april 30, 2013 and august 20, 2013 from the dowager countess's homes. roberts is also accused of stealing a £10,000 volvo xc90 from another previous employer. a trial with a three-day duration has been scheduled to begin in the week of november 3. the majority of the alleged thefts took place at the dowager countess's cirencester park estate. roberts was released on bail with conditions that she resides in her devon home and notifies the court of any address changes.
1951	thusha kamaleswaran, a six-year-old girl from london, spent her morning off school watching cartoons but switched to the lunchtime news against her parents' wish. they had urged her not to hear about the gangland shooting that left her paralyzed from the chest down. last week was a turning point for thusha as she returned to school for the first time since the incident and the three convicted men were sentenced to lengthy prison terms. thusha, who dreams of becoming a doctor, wanted to know the length of their sentences. she misunderstood the concept and requested confirmation if they would die in jail. her mother explained that the men would be released after many years, but thusha was relieved that they would not harm anyone else. thusha was playing in her uncle's convenience store when she was shot and paralyzed in march 2011. the three men were given life sentences with minimum prison terms of 17½, 14½, and 14½ years. her parents believe the sentences were lenient as thusha will be in a wheelchair probably for the rest of her life. they expressed frustration that the offenders wouldn't face the same struggles as their daughter. the family has received over £140,000 in donations from well-wishers to help cover future medical costs. thusha has returned to school, with a new uniform, and is determined to learn and eventually pass her tests to become a doctor.
1952	dr. leila denmark, the world's oldest practicing physician when she retired at the age of 103, has passed away at her home in athens, georgia, at the age of 114. denmark began her medical career in 1928 as the first resident physician at henrietta egleston hospital for children in atlanta and admitted the first patient there. she opened her pediatrics practice from her home in 1931 and continued until her retirement in 2001, treating children in need regardless of their ability to pay. denmark, who loved medicine more than anything else, volunteered at the central presbyterian baby clinic in atlanta and received several awards during her career, including the fisher award in 1935. she is survived by her daughter, two grandsons, and two great-grandchildren.
1953	a romantic couple, darren and katherine yates, surprised their friends and family by inviting them to a fake movie premiere at a cinema, which turned out to be their wedding day. the pair sent out invitations claiming darren had a cameo role in a hollywood film called "match made in heaven." at the cinema, guests watched a short film called "haribo man," featuring darren proposing to katherine with a haribo-sweet ring. after the film, the cinema transformed into a wedding venue, and the couple tied the knot in front of their shocked and delighted guests. the surprise element made their wedding day even more memorable for the couple, who had been planning the prank for six months. the newlyweds, who met at work, had a more traditional evening party at a converted barn.
1954	a screenshot of a new york city street on apple maps, which was posted online, resembles a post-apocalyptic scene with desolate roads, abandoned yellow cabs, and empty buildings. apple maps, introduced in 2012 as a replacement for google maps in ios 6, has been criticized for inaccuracies and errors such as misplaced landmarks, incorrect business listings, and incorrect directions, leading to potential dangerous situations. some examples include wrongly placing the lions gate bridge in vancouver, identifying an entire city as a hospital, and leading users looking for gas stations far from their actual location. apple acknowledged the issues and has been working on fixing them, but the app continues to face criticism. the errors have led to apple maps being listed among the top tech fails of 2012. despite the problems, apple continues to invest heavily in the development of apple maps.
1955	a father, saleem tahir, allegedly forced his way into a hotel room in hanley, staffordshire, and took his two young children, a 2-and-a-half-year-old daughter named na'llah khan and a 10-month-old son named sulaiman khan, from their mother's care on october 18, 2013, at around 5 pm. they were later spotted in the selly oak area of birmingham around three hours later, believed to be with their 67-year-old grandmother, denise smith-sellers. staffordshire police are urgently seeking the safe return of the children to their mother's care and ask anyone with information to contact them on 101. the children were taken by their father, saleem tahir, who is originally from the nottingham area.
1956	canterbury cathedral broke a 1,000-year-old tradition by allowing a girls' choir to perform during evensong for the first time, ending an all-male chorister tradition. forty local girls auditioned and sixteen were selected to sing when the boy choristers, who are boarders at st. edmund's school, are on their twice-termly breaks. canterbury cathedral had resisted change for a long time, but the role of women in society and the church has evolved and progressed, leading to the decision to form a girls' choir. the girls celebrated their successful debut performance following the service.
1957	real madrid coach carlo ancelotti is not bothered by his team's three losses in us friendly matches, including a 3-1 defeat to manchester united in the international champions cup. ancelotti is confident real will perform better in the european super cup against sevilla on august 12. cristiano ronaldo, who is recovering from a knee injury, made a surprise appearance against manchester united and will be ready for the super cup. ancelotti explained that the team's current poor form in friendlies is due to the absence of key players and the fact that they have only started training together recently.
1958	a man named stephen rakes, who was prepared to testify against reputed boston mob boss james "whitey" bulger in his ongoing trial, was found dead on wednesday in lincoln, massachusetts. rakes, 59, was reportedly dropped from the prosecution's witness list the previous day, and a friend stated that he was devastated by the news. an autopsy was conducted on thursday, but no signs of trauma were found, and toxicology tests are pending. rakes had allegedly been forced to sell his liquor store to bulger in the 1980s, and bulger is charged in his murder, along with extortion, racketeering, and money laundering. rakes' attorney, who last saw him at the trial on tuesday, was shocked to learn of his death. the us attorney's office declined to comment. rakes, who had been waiting decades to tell his story, last appeared at the trial on tuesday.
1959	ferguson city leaders have announced plans to raise funds for vest and patrol-car cameras for their police officers in response to the fatal shooting of michael brown and resulting community unrest. the promise comes amid a decrease in complaints against the police in rialto, california, where officers use vest cams. protests in ferguson were calmer on tuesday night but turned violent with 47 arrests due to clashes between protesters and police. malik zulu shabazz, president of black lawyers for justice, and other community organizations are working to ease tensions. brown's funeral and memorial service are set for monday. despite the turmoil, ferguson mayor james knowles maintains there is no racial divide in the city.
1960	the centre for social justice (csj), a think tank led by iain duncan smith, has criticized the british government's efforts to tackle family breakdown and strengthen marriage. the csj gave the government a score of four out of ten for its measures to reverse family breakdown and a dismal two out of ten for its approach to the voluntary and community sector. the report highlights policy failures and omissions, such as the lack of progress in introducing transferable tax allowances and eliminating the "couple penalty" in the welfare system. the csj also criticizes the government's decision to impose a cap on tax relief for charitable giving, which has damaged morale and demonstrated a lack of appreciation for non-state agencies' contributions to tackling poverty. the report accuses the coalition of a frustrating lack of coherence in addressing family breakdown due to differences between the conservative and liberal democrat parts of the government. it warns that last summer's riots underscore the urgency of dealing with social challenges and warns that the cap on charitable giving tax relief has damaged morale and could be dropped. the csj acknowledges the government's progress in areas such as welfare reform, education reforms, radical welfare reform, and addiction treatment strategy but calls on david cameron to back up his promises to bolster marriage and tackle the "couple penalty" in the benefits system.
1961	florida lieutenant governor jennifer carroll resigned on wednesday following investigations into an alleged corrupt veterans' charity, allied veterans of the world, in which she had consulted for in 2009 and 2010 while serving in the florida house of representatives. fifty-seven people were arrested that day on racketeering and money laundering charges, with accusations of little proceeds going to veterans and instead used for personal gains. governor rick scott demanded the funds be donated to charity and had zero tolerance for such criminal activity. carroll, a republican and the first african-american elected to florida statewide office, has been appreciated for her service in the state and was elected with scott in 2010. no further connection between carroll and allied veterans of the world was elaborated by scott.
1962	the duke and duchess of cambridge, prince william and catherine, began their nine-day tour through southeast asia and the pacific to celebrate queen elizabeth's diamond jubilee in singapore on wednesday. hundreds of spectators welcomed them at the gardens by the bay, where they were greeted by members of singapore's parliament and watched a cultural performance. they also visited a new rolls-royce factory and the rainbow center, a school for children with special needs. the royal couple previously honored queen elizabeth ii with the names of areas and buildings in singapore, such as queenstown and margaret drive. tuesday, they visited the singapore botanic gardens and were presented with orchids named after princess diana and queen elizabeth ii, and in their honor, the "vanda william catherine" was named. they were also hosted to a state dinner by president tony tan and prime minister lee hsien loong. the tour continues with visits to malaysia, the solomon islands, and tuvalu.
1963	an investigation into last week's fatal bus crash in northern california in which 10 people, including the drivers of the truck and bus and five teenage students, were killed, has found "no evidence" of a pre-collision fire, contrary to witness reports. the national transportation safety board (ntsb) is now looking into driver fatigue as a possible cause of the crash. a witness had reported seeing flames shooting from underneath the truck before the collision. however, further investigation revealed no evidence of this, according to ntsb member mark rosekind. the crash occurred when the fedex truck crossed a median and collided with a bus carrying students from los angeles to humboldt state university in arcata. the truck also struck a nissan altima before hitting the bus. the bodies of the victims are being identified using dental records and dna testing due to the intense fire that engulfed both vehicles. the ntsb plans to release a preliminary report on the crash within 30 days.
1964	an 8.0-magnitude earthquake struck off the solomon islands in the south pacific on wednesday, causing a tsunami that killed five people in the santa cruz islands. the tsunami caused damage and disruption in the area, including at the local airport and nearby villages. the pacific tsunami warning center initially issued a warning for several countries in the region, but later canceled it after assessing the data. preventive measures were taken in other regions, including new zealand and japan. the epicenter of the quake was near the santa cruz islands, and its depth was initially reported as 3.6 miles but later revised to 17.8 miles. the region had experienced a 6.3-magnitude quake before the larger one and several aftershocks, one of which had a magnitude of 6.6. in 2007, an 8.1-magnitude quake struck in the western part of the solomon islands, resulting in at least 52 deaths and thousands of homeless people.
1965	a nurse educator from the small queensland town of clermont, lee garrels, and her husband, michael, were devastated when they arrived at the hospital to find their 21-year-old son, jason, critically injured after being electrocuted at a local building site. two years have passed since the incident, and the family still does not have a clear understanding of what happened due to the delay in holding a coronial inquest. section 29 of the coroners act in queensland prevents an inquest from being held until all outstanding court matters are resolved. in jason's case, this involves a case involving his employer, daytona trading. jason was remembered as a polite and "typical young australian," who was well-liked by those trying to save him. the lack of answers regarding his death has hindered the healing process for the garrels family, and they have gathered over 70,000 signatures on a change.org petition to have the law changed. the attorney-general of queensland, jarrod bleijie, has acknowledged the tragedy and issued fines and suspensions following an investigation, but no comment was given on the matter before the court. garrels is hopeful that the law will be changed.
1966	michael poyzer, 65, from nottinghamshire, finally graduated from the open university with a bsc honors degree in science and technology after 43 years. he began studying in 1971 at the age of 22, but had to balance his degree with running a business, raising three children, and later, four grandchildren. he persisted in his studies despite the challenges and passed with a 2:2 qualification. now, he plans to pursue a master's degree in creative writing. it took him nearly as long to complete his degree as it did to build famous landmarks like the taj mahal, hadrian's wall, and the humber bridge. if he had started his degree with current average university costs, he would have paid the equivalent of £387,000 in tuition fees. mr. poyzer, who left school at 16 to become an apprentice at the raleigh bike factory, married susan in 1974 and had his first child in 1975. he started his business, super cycles, in 1977 and renamed it rock 'n' roll bikes in 2001, which he still runs. the open university spokesperson congratulated mr. poyzer on completing his long-term goal and recognized the progress the university has made in delivering courses across all media. students now have a maximum of 16 years to complete their studies.
1967	jason mraz, a san diego-based singer-songwriter, recently went through the difficult process of selecting members for his new band, leading to comparisons of heartbreaking goodbyes. after splitting from his fiancée tristan prettyman in june 2011, mraz released his fourth studio album "love is a four letter word," which is primarily about love in various forms, not just romantic. he will embark on his "tour is a four letter word" starting in june, and during his downtime, he recently founded the jason mraz foundation. the organization supports multiple causes and mraz has been vocal about his advocacy for marriage equality. "i won't give up," the lead single off the album, emphasizes perseverance and refusal to give up on dreams or personal values.
1968	"how to think like einstein" by daniel smith argues that anyone can think like the renowned physicist, despite his brain being slightly smaller than average. einstein was not an infant prodigy, graduating fourth out of five from zurich polytechnic and taking a lowly position at the patent office before making groundbreaking scientific discoveries. he believed in the inner harmony of the world and the importance of imaginative thinking and inner curiosity. despite being unconventional and rebellious, einstein made science accessible to the public by sharing his discoveries, such as the theory of relativity and the famous equation e=mc². smith suggests that slow and steady progress, passion for knowledge, and the ability to see beyond the obvious can lead to extraordinary insights.
1969	texas is set to execute edgar arias tamayo tonight for murdering houston police officer guy gaddis in 1994, despite last-minute appeals for clemency from his lawyers and the mexican government. tamayo was not fully advised of his consular rights under the 1963 vienna convention upon his arrest. secretary of state john kerry had requested a delay to tamayo's execution, arguing it could impact the way american citizens are treated abroad, but this was rejected by texas officials. tamayo, a mexican national, was in the u.s. illegally and had a criminal record in california. he is one of more than four dozen mexican nationals awaiting execution in the u.s. following a 2004 international court ruling that they hadn't been properly advised of their consular rights.
1970	hampstead garden suburb, a low-density housing area in north london built to accommodate people from all social classes, is now home to pricey properties and famous residents like harry styles and the ross and finnigan families. wyldes farm, a historic five-bedroom house in the suburb, has a rich history with past residents including charles dickens, who wrote "the pickwick papers" and "oliver twist" there in the 1830s, and romantic painter john constable. the house, which features historic features and modern renovations, is on the market for £3.65 million, and the current owner, yamuna sharma, is selling due to plans to live abroad. previous tenants, scott finlay and catherine, a businessman and teacher with artistic children, found inspiration for their careers while residing in the house. wyldes farm's historic residents include sir raymond unwin, who designed the suburb, and the poet william blake.
1971	roger daltrey, the frontman of the who, expressed his anger towards the labour party for their handling of mass immigration during their 13-year reign, accusing them of destroying jobs for the indigenous working-classes by allowing in thousands of eu workers without proper regulation. daltrey, 69, stated he will never forgive the labour party for this mistake and has not ruled out voting for ukip in the next election. in the past, he has criticized politicians for using social media instead of focusing on their jobs and has been a patron of the teenage cancer trust. he has previously voiced his concerns over the treatment of the british working class.
1972	big brother winner helen wood inadvertently led police to her firearms fugitive ex-lover, louis larsson, who had fled to cyprus after breaching the terms of his prison license. larsson, who was serving a five-year sentence for firearm offenses, was arrested in april 2014 after police followed wood to his hideout during her holiday. larsson was also found to have possessed ammunition and other firearm components as part of a separate investigation. he was given an additional 20-month sentence for these charges, which related to a raid at a house in 2013. wood, who won the big brother contest last month, is no longer in a relationship with larsson.
1973	a 20-year-old woman, desiree phillips, from llanelli, south wales, died from liver failure following an accidental overdose of paracetamol after undergoing breast surgery. despite taking just "a few extra tablets" each day to manage pain and discomfort as prescribed by doctors, desiree's liver failed nine days after the operation. her family was shocked and saddened by her sudden death and urged caution with paracetamol use. doctors have warned of the potential dangers of a staggered overdose, where people take a few extra tablets each day over a longer period. although an inquest is yet to be held, desiree's family is calling for awareness of this risk, as her one-year-old son is now being cared for by his father. dr. kenneth simpson, who led a study on paracetamol-induced liver injury, reported that 161 of the 663 patients in his study had taken a staggered overdose and had worse outcomes than those attempting suicide. the medicines and healthcare products regulatory agency emphasized the importance of properly following the recommended dosage and warnings on paracetamol packaging.
1974	secretary of state john kerry, just nine months into his tenure, successfully negotiated an interim deal with iran regarding its nuclear program, marking the most significant cooperation between the u.s. and iran in decades. the deal, which includes other world powers, has been criticized by israel and some members of congress but praised by kerry as a positive first step. previous efforts towards a nuclear agreement, such as a tentative deal in 2009 and economic sanctions, had stalled. private, clandestine discussions between u.s. and iranian officials resumed after hassan rouhani's election as iranian president, culminating in a telephone conversation between barack obama and rouhani. kerry's diplomatic efforts have yielded success in syria and iran, making him an "activist" negotiator. the real challenge begins now in securing a long-term nuclear agreement with iran, and the impact on the middle east peace process remains to be seen.
1975	lewis hamilton claimed the most important race of his formula one career at the abu dhabi grand prix, defeating teammate and rival nico rosberg before the first turn. the title decider was defined by the fraction of a second between hamilton's car making its move and the encouragement from the final go light. despite losing the race after turn one, rosberg's mechanical failure resulted in him finishing in 14th place, unable to share the glory with hamilton. hamilton secured his second championship title with a victory, finishing with 384 points to rosberg's 317, and eleven race wins to rosberg's five. hamilton was praised for his bravery and determination in securing the championship while rosberg was criticized for his weekend performances. despite technical issues, hamilton's sheer will and daring eclipsed rosberg's german efficiency, resulting in a visceral and unforgettable finish to the season.
1976	u.s. president barack obama and his family arrived in berlin on tuesday for a 24-hour visit, which includes a speech at the brandenburg gate. the obamas were welcomed with a guard of honor upon their arrival, while michelle and her daughters malia and sasha dressed casually during their previous stop in ireland for sightseeing. obama's speech will be compared to jfk's iconic 1963 address in front of the berlin wall. the trip comes amid growing criticism in europe over the nsa surveillance scandal, with protesters demonstrating against obama's visit. the president is expected to hold meetings with german chancellor angela merkel and other government officials.
1977	former prime minister tony blair received a briefing from the ministry of defense (mod) about unidentified flying objects (ufos) due to concerns over the disclosure of classified information regarding extraterrestrial life forms. the briefing came in 1998, as the freedom of information act was being introduced, allowing public access to information on ufos and alien mysteries. reports of ufo sightings, including a police officer's account of a mysterious object hovering over stamford bridge during a chelsea vs. manchester united fa cup quarter-final replay in 1999, are among the over 6,700 pages of mod files being released by the national archives, following the closure of the mod's ufo desk in 2009. nick pope, a ufo expert, believes aliens may be visiting earth for purposes such as military reconnaissance, scientific research, or to enjoy the scenery. whilemanchester united player andy cole was busy with the game, a 'credible witness report' describes a police officer's sighting of a ufo during the match. pope, who worked at the mod for 20 years, began his research as a skeptic but later became convinced of the potential implications for national security and air safety. he predicts mass summer events like the london olympics could be a prime time for extraterrestrial beings to reveal themselves to humanity.
1978	the international consumer electronics show (ces) has seen at&t and sprint announce plans for new, faster 4g long-term evolution (lte) networks, leaving some customers with last year's 4g smartphones feeling outdated. both at&t and sprint have previously marketed their 4g networks, with at&t adding the moniker to many phones since early last year and sprint announcing its first 4g device in 2010. verizon wireless has also had an lte network since 2010, but is currently matching the coverage of its 3g network and kept a low profile at ces this year. at&t introduced eight new lte products at the show, including the world's first lte windows phone, while sprint announced three devices and expects its new lte network to match its older one by the end of 2012, after which it will stop selling devices that support the old network and turn it off in 2015. apple refuses to label the iphone 4s as a 4g device despite using hspa+ technology that at&t also calls 4g. at&t executive glenn lurie and sprint product chief fared adib declined to comment on marketing plans, while lurie stated that the name doesn't matter and verizon technical chief david small emphasized the importance of clarifying the difference between 4g and 4g lte.
1979	in washington, d.c., a mother, banita jacks, is charged with killing her four daughters, aged 5 to 17, whose decomposing bodies were discovered in her apartment. jacks told authorities that the children had been possessed by demons and died during a seven- to 10-day period in their sleep. the bodies had been undiscovered for at least 15 days, according to the chief medical examiner. jacks is being held without bail and faces life in prison if convicted. preliminary findings indicate that brittany was stabbed to death and aja died from blunt force trauma and possible strangulation. all four children were found in unfurnished bedrooms, two in one room and one in another, with white t-shirts on. a witness reported seeing jacks withhold food from her older daughter, brittany, and once leaving her on her mother's porch unattended for more than 10 hours. authorities are investigating how the children's absences went unnoticed. the family had had contact with child welfare caseworkers and the police. mayor adrian fenty said, "there may be other contacts with the government in the case of the jacks family."
1980	a tragic accident occurred during an airshow at the tampa north flight center in florida when experienced skydiver mark curto, 62, fell to his death after his parachute failed to open during a wing walking stunt or a skydiving jump, according to conflicting reports. witnesses and neighbors reported seeing curto falling from the bi-plane in front of horrified spectators, including children, and his body landed in the backyard of a house in the grand oaks subdivision in land o'lakes. the sheriff's office and the federal aviation administration are investigating the incident, which is the third fatal skydiving accident in the tampa bay area in the past three years. curto's body was discovered shortly after the incident, and no medical condition is believed to have caused his fall. curto was an experienced skydiver and had lost his wife to breast cancer earlier this year.
1981	housing and urban development secretary shaun donovan, in charge of long-term sandy recovery, has caused controversy by suggesting that some areas devastated by the storm may not be worth rebuilding. donovan made the comment during a news conference on december 13, 2012, stating that a "very small share" of homes "may not make sense to rebuild at all." thousands of homes were destroyed and billions of dollars in damage were caused when sandy struck on october 29, 2012. the governors of new york, new jersey, and connecticut, along with over 125 prominent ceos based in new york, have urged congress to quickly approve $60 billion in aid for the affected states. in an op-ed, the governors wrote that americans come together in times of crisis, and it's time for congress to do the same. they noted that the region is critical for american business and the largest contributor to federal tax revenues. donovan also mentioned the need to consider sea barriers and other protective measures for low-lying areas. the aid package requested by president obama includes about three-quarters of what the states had requested. congress is currently in budget negotiations, making the request more challenging. senator charles schumer (d-ny) and rep. peter king (r-ny) are advocating for the aid package to be a bipartisan priority.
1982	a new study published in the archives of internal medicine found that older women taking multivitamins or certain dietary supplements, particularly iron, may have a slightly increased risk of earlier death. the study included data from 38,772 women in iowa over a 22-year period. while calcium was linked to a lower risk of death, folic acid, vitamin b6, magnesium, zinc, copper, and multivitamins were associated with an increased risk. the researchers point out that the findings are association, not causation, and have some limitations, including self-reported supplement intake and the potential for underlying health conditions influencing the results. it's unclear if these findings apply to all older women and if additional research is needed to clarify the role of dietary supplements in health and mortality.
1983	police in ticknall, derbyshire, have asked volunteers armed with a speed gun to stop clocking drivers breaking the law due to overwhelming paperwork. the group, who have carried out 10 speeding operations on the a514 main road, have caught around 200 motorists exceeding the 30mph limit. however, the police can no longer handle the resulting administration and have announced a new road safety scheme with a crackdown on problem areas, including the a514. the volunteers will stand down, but their efforts have contributed to the identification of the road as a focus for the partnership. the increased workload from the speed watches has resulted in the police asking for reasonable limits on their frequency and duration.
1984	england's soccer team, led by captain steven gerrard and players like daniel sturridge, alex oxlade-chamberlain, james milner, joe hart, ross barkley, and phil jagielka, arrived in rio de janeiro, brazil to begin their world cup campaign. after an eight-and-a-half hour flight from miami, they checked into a hotel near ipanema beach, taking in the stunning views and sharing them on social media. players were seen standing on their balconies, taking photos, and admiring the scenery. england's first match is against italy on june 14.
1985	a report by the hollywood reporter alleging that the american humane association (aha), which is responsible for animal welfare in the film industry, turns a blind eye to abuse due to its close relationship with hollywood, has been criticized by the aha as misleading. the report highlighted incidents of animal cruelty on films such as "life of pi," "the hobbit," "pirates of the caribbean," and "war horse." however, aha senior advisor karen rosa defended the organization, stating that the report distorts its work and that the allegations about specific incidents were either exaggerated or taken out of context. the aha confers the "no animals were harmed" stamp on films it has monitored and has a high safety record. however, veteran animal protection prosecutor bob ferber criticized the aha's relationship with the industry, suggesting a conflict of interest.
1986	rep. john boehner (r-oh) was sworn in as the 61st speaker of the house on wednesday, marking the republican party's takeover of the chamber after a four-year democratic hold. ninety-four new house members and 13 new senators were also sworn in, making the house the largest freshman class with no previous elective office experience since 1948. boehner, first elected in 1990, rose to the top position after being voted out of the house leadership in 1998. he promised "an honest debate" and "a fair and open process" while acknowledging the need for "hard work and tough decisions." minority democrats, led by outgoing speaker nancy pelosi, vowed to work together on issues such as helping the middle class, creating jobs, and reducing the deficit. the new rules governing the house require constitutional authority statements for all new legislation.
1987	taco bell's new breakfast menu has been launched in the u.s., and its president, brian niccol, has jokingly stated that it will come to canada if justin bieber is taken back. the fast food chain hopes to compete with mcdonald's in the breakfast market, which dominates with a 31% share. niccol revealed during a reddit ama that sales in colorado have increased by 420% since marijuana was legalized. to promote its breakfast menu, taco bell ran ads featuring men named ronald mcdonald, who are not affiliated with mcdonald's. the chain aims to boost sales by opening most of its u.s. stores earlier at 7 a.m., but has a long way to go to catch up with mcdonald's in the breakfast market. niccol expects to increase breakfast sales to a level "much greater than 4%," and the ads feature ronald mcdonalds expressing their approval of taco bell's breakfast menu.
1988	president barack obama hosted the first-ever white house summit on community colleges on tuesday, aiming to explore ways to reach his goal of an additional 5 million community college degrees by 2020, and discuss the role of community colleges in developing the u.s. workforce. the bill and melinda gates foundation announced a $34.8 million investment over five years for a program called completion by design, while the aspen prize for community college excellence will award $1 million to colleges with outstanding academic and workforce outcomes. the summit brought together 150 people, including community college leaders, students, philanthropists, businesspeople, and policy leaders. community colleges have seen enrollment surge, but have been forced to cut back due to the recession, with only about 30% of students finishing associate degrees within three years. obama announced on monday the skills for america's future initiative, offering more than $2 billion in competitive funds over four years, in partnership with corporations to develop job training programs.
1989	a terrorist group called isis has caused distress for businesses in the united states and elsewhere that have the same name. options for businesses include changing the name, suing the group for trademark infringement, or keeping the name and hoping customers don't get spooked. many businesses have opted for the first option. for instance, the fx cartoon series "archer" has dropped "isis" as the acronym for its spy agency. the mobile payment service "isis wallet" has also changed its name to "softcard." small businesses are also being affected, such as the "isis hookah cafe" in queens, new york. however, some argue that the fear caused by the terrorist group's name is unwarranted and that businesses should keep their names to avoid being dictated to by the group. some suggest using the name isil instead of isis to avoid confusion. isil stands for the islamic state of iraq and the levant. california-based isis pharmaceuticals has decided to keep its name, stating that people can distinguish between the two.
1990	in london's financial district, bankers heeded warnings to dress down to avoid attention from g-20 protestors, opting for jeans and sneakers instead of suits and ties. some banks advised employees to wear casual clothing or even stay home, but some refused to succumb to the pressure. despite attempts to blend in, bankers were still easily identifiable, often seen reading the financial times or dressing in a business casual look. protests remained tense, with thousands of anti-capitalist demonstrators converging on the city and clashes resulting in smashed windows and arrests. police remained on high alert in large numbers.
