1991	manchester united executive vice-chairman ed woodward emphasized the influence of social media on players' popularity, using the example of daley blind's 73% increase in twitter followers (173,000 new followers) since joining the club. however, this argument may be questionable as cesc fabregas (900,000 new followers at chelsea) and mario balotelli (462,000 new followers at liverpool) have attracted more followers. the most significant percentage increase was seen by calum chambers, who joined arsenal, with a 203% rise (142,000 new followers). other notable mentions include ayoze perez (197% increase and 28,000 new followers at newcastle) and andrew robertson (123% increase and over 12,000 new followers at hull). woodward may argue that percentage increases are a better measure, but it remains unclear if players join clubs based on social media popularity or if they gain followers as a result. some summer signings, such as james mcarthur at crystal palace (2,900 new followers) and marc albrighton at leicester (1,500 new followers), have not experienced significant growth. ultimately, the impact of social media numbers on premier league points remains uncertain.
1992	spicejet cabin crew members were filmed dancing in the aisles during a holi celebration on a goa-bangalore flight, with two pilots taking photographs. the directorate general of civil aviation (dgca) has issued a show-cause notice to the airline, claiming that the mid-air entertainment endangered aircraft safety and created an "unruly environment." the dgca is threatening to suspend spicejet's license, citing possible effects on the aircraft's center of gravity and potential distraction of crew members. the airline has 15 days to respond to the notice.
1993	the author, a lifelong new england patriots fan and cnn anchor, expresses shame and anger towards the team if reports of deflating footballs during the afc championship game are true. he has invested heavily into being a sports fan and rooting for boston teams, and feels cheated and betrayed by the potential cheating. the author questions how he can continue to root for the patriots and tom brady, who he admires, if they have indeed cheated. he is struggling with the moral implications of condoning cheating and fears he may have led his sons, who are also patriots fans, down the wrong path.
1994	the secret service, once considered the gold standard in law enforcement, has come under criticism for security lapses and budget constraints. the agency's responsibilities have expanded significantly since 9/11, including protecting more people and new tasks like tracking online threats and monitoring large crowds. the secret service had 1,420 uniform division officers needed to protect the white house, but only currently has 1,320. agents are often asked to work overtime and training sessions have been canceled due to a shortage of funds. the secret service was rolled into the department of homeland security after 9/11, leading to competition for resources with larger agencies in the department. despite calls for more resources, some argue that the secret service has never lacked for funds and must learn to cut unnecessary expenses. recent high-profile security breaches at the white house, including the entrance of an intruder with a knife, have led to resignations within the agency. a report from homeland security criticized the agency for poor budget management, as officials were unable to provide a figure for the cost of protecting the white house.
1995	in the aftermath of the devastating ef5 tornado that struck moore, oklahoma, on may 20, 2013, leaving at least 24 people dead and over 237 injured, a heartwarming moment of reunification emerged between neighbor jim routon and his seven-year-old friend hezekiah darbon. both were at briarwood elementary school where the tornado had destroyed the building, reducing it to rubble. routon, filled with terror and desperation, discovered that hezekiah, whom he affectionately called "little dog," had survived. in a spontaneous display of relief and joy, routon hugged hezekiah tightly, with the young boy expressing his happiness and relief in return. the pair, who shared a close bond playing basketball and football, and referred to each other as "big dog" and "little dog," were overjoyed to be reunited amidst the chaos and destruction surrounding them. hezekiah's parents, who were working at the time, were unable to be present during the rescue efforts. the tornado obliterated much of moore and left many families searching for their loved ones, using the hashtag #okmissing. emergency workers saved more than 100 survivors from the wreckage, treating injuries ranging from minor to major, including degloving injuries. the tornado, which travelled through the oklahoma city suburb for 17 miles, was confirmed to be an ef5, the highest category on the tornado scale. the incident served as a beacon of hope amidst the devastation and tragedy endured by the community.
1996	olivia prokopova, an 18-year-old czech minigolf player and double masters champion, dreams of making the final putt on the iconic 18th hole of the masters tournament at augusta national golf club, but this is not the masters in georgia. instead, she is standing over a putt on the final hole of myrtle beach's hawaiian rumble mini golf course, where she has won the masters tournament for the last two years. born into a golfing family, prokopova began playing minigolf as a young child and has since become a dedicated member of the global minigolf community. the game, also known as crazy golf, originated in scotland in 1867 as an alternative for women who wanted to play golf but were discouraged by the violent swinging required in the full-size version. minigolf has evolved over the years and now boasts more than 38,000 registered players competing in over 1,300 annual tournaments. bob detwiler, founder of the us pro minigolf federation and owner of the hawaiian rumble course, began hosting minigolf tournaments in the late 1990s. the masters, held annually at detwiler's course, has become a magnet for dedicated minigolf athletes from around the world. the last two masters winners, prokopova, have taken home a total prize fund of just $12,000, a far cry from the $1.44 million earned by major champion adam scott. prokopova's commitment to the sport is unwavering. with her parents, coach, and even a masseuse in tow, she travels 4,500 miles to compete in us masters tournaments. the minigolf community, largely comprised of middle-aged men, is supportive but at times finds it difficult to accept defeat at the hands of a young woman. prokopova's success has p
1997	the 2014 international earth and sky photo contest showcases stunning images of the night sky, captured by photographers despite challenges like light pollution. the contest, organized by the world at night since 2009, features winners from ten countries, including italy, france, and iran. the first prize went to giorgia hofer for her photo 'light in the sky,' while the 'beauty of the night sky' prize went to luc perrot for his image 'over the top' of a volcano in the southern indian ocean. the goal is to produce breathtaking nightscape photographs, highlighting astronomical perspectives and celestial phenomena, and encouraging imagination and technical skills. the competition promotes the importance of preserving the night sky as part of our natural heritage. the sixth international earth & sky photo contest is expected to be announced in late february 2015.
1998	nine black former contestants of the reality show "american idol" are suing the production company and fox for racism, alleging they were forced off the show to boost ratings. producers nigel lythgoe and ken warwick are named as defendants in the lawsuit. the singers claim they were confronted about undisclosed criminal records, with jermaine jones and corey clark being among the most prominent cases. all nine contestants were black and had been publicly disqualified from the show. the lawyers argue that asking for criminal records during the application process is a violation of employment law. the producers defended their actions, stating that they cannot allow contestants with active warrants on the show. the lawsuit also accuses the show of humiliating black contestants and perpetuating destructive stereotypes. american idol's response was that they treat all contestants equally and have always had a diverse pool of talent.
1999	girlguiding uk, an organization that empowers young girls, has voiced its support for the "no more page 3" campaign calling for the abolition of the sun newspaper's long-running topless model feature. the campaign received overwhelming backing from girlguiding members aged 16 to 25, with 88% agreeing that the paper should end the provocative editorial that has been a staple since 1970. launched during the london olympics, the campaign aims to challenge the objectification of women in media and received 90,000 signatures as of 2013. rupert murdoch, ceo of news corporation that owns the sun, has hinted at considering the end of the feature, citing a potential "halfway house" alternative with tasteful fashion models. the campaign emphasizes that women should not be treated as sex objects and criticizes the negative impact on young girls' self-esteem and perceptions of their bodies.
2000	romania's ambassador to britain, dr. ion jinga, reported that only two or fewer than 25 romanians have entered the uk since labor market restrictions were relaxed on january 1, 2014. he also mentioned that ten companies had contacted his london embassy seeking romanian workers but were directed to the jobcentre. dutch authorities reported that 21 romanians and 15 bulgarians had arrived in the past two weeks, and dr. jinga expected similar numbers for the uk. british border officials have not released immigration figures. victor spirescu, a romanian man, arrived in england on new year's day, but his job at a car wash lasted only one day before he quit and disappeared. there was controversy over eu migration, with some suggesting it was causing unsustainable levels, while others believed the issue was being exaggerated. former tory chancellor kenneth clarke dismissed the idea that the eu was responsible for "unacceptable waves of migration," while foreign secretary william hague insisted the lifting of controls had led to "large-scale migration" and was a "mistake." eu social affairs commissioner laszlo andor thought britons were being emotional and misguided about the issue and urged them to focus on facts rather than fear.
2001	gareth bale is unlikely to play for real madrid against liverpool in the champions league due to a muscle strain, specifically in the pyramidalis muscle. he missed the league game against levante and carlo ancelotti confirmed it was not due to being benched. bale had previously started all eight league games for real madrid this season before being sidelined after returning from international duty. isco gave a standout performance against levante and is expected to start against liverpool as bale works on recovering in time for el clasico at the weekend. real madrid won impressively against levante without bale.
2002	a deceased body was discovered in a well in warlingham, surrey, during garden renovation works. the victim, damian chlywka, was identified and reportedly assaulted and tied up before being dumped in the well two years ago. police have arrested two more men on suspicion of murder, and seven other men previously arrested have been released on bail. damian was believed to have lived at the property at one point and police are seeking information from anyone who knew or worked with him to help build a picture of his life in the uk. the investigation is ongoing and no cause of death has been determined.
2003	a 29-year-old florida woman, aimee lee weiss, who made national news when she was accused of strangling her newborn son in a bathroom and disposing of his body in a canal at the age of 17, has died. weiss, who was charged with first-degree murder in 2001, pleaded no contest to manslaughter charges in 2006 and was sentenced to three years' probation. she gave birth to a daughter during her imprisonment, who is now living with her paternal grandparents in texas. weiss' parental rights were terminated, but she was allowed to nurse the baby for six months. weiss was arrested twice after her initial conviction, once on insurance fraud charges in 2007 and once on prostitution and lewdness charges in 2010. the cause of her death is being determined by a medical examiner.
2004	veronica rivas, 28, of san diego has confessed to police that she drowned her 22-month-old son, elijah, on wednesday night. officers were called to rivas' condo on woodpark way when the child's grandmother reported an emergency. emergency responders attempted to revive elijah, but he was pronounced dead on the scene. rivas was discovered unconscious in a separate room and was taken to the hospital for treatment, which is believed to have been an attempted suicide. she was later arrested on a first-degree murder charge and is currently housed at the vista detention center. witnesses and neighbors have reported that rivas had been going through a custody battle with her child's father, a marine, for the past two months, and that she appeared depressed. a makeshift memorial, including a yellow teddy bear, flowers, and lit candles, has been set up outside the family's home. police are conducting an investigation into the incident and rivas may face additional charges. she is scheduled to be arraigned on monday.
2005	a pregnant woman, shelli eldredge, 40, from south jordan, utah, miraculously recovered from severe injuries and is now walking again after being in a coma for weeks following a moped accident in hawaii. she shattered her pelvis, fractured her skull, and had thousands of small strokes in her brain, causing her to fall into a coma and miscarry her baby. her husband, stephen eldredge, refused to turn off her life support despite doctors' recommendations and was amazed when she started responding to stimuli, speaking, and moving. she now requires a wheelchair but is making progress with speech and occupational therapy. doctors were initially pessimistic about her chances of survival, but she has since undergone 17 surgeries and is expected to make a full recovery. her sons are amazed by her strength and determination.
2006	the population in britain rose by 419,900 in the year to mid-2012, the highest increase in europe, according to official estimates. this was driven by a higher birth rate and immigration. london and the south saw the biggest population increases. the population of the uk has grown by 6.1 million since 1992, with around 4 in 10 of the additional people being immigrants. six out of ten were due to rising birth rates, which brought a record 254,400 births. immigration, particularly from eastern europe, has been a major factor in the population increase. the population of the uk is currently 63.7 million and is expected to surpass 70 million in the early 2020s. the figures come despite efforts by the government to reduce net immigration to 1990s levels. the population increase was higher than in other eu countries such as france, germany, belgium, sweden, and holland. london accounted for a quarter of the population increase and saw the greatest rise, despite 51,000 people leaving the capital. the growing population is putting pressure on public services and infrastructure, with some commentators warning of the impact on housing, transport, and the nhs. ukip leader nigel farage criticized the government's failure to address immigration issues. paul vickers of the office for national statistics stated that 'together, london, the south east and east of england accounted for over half the growth.' the population pyramid shows a large number of 'baby boomers' and a low birth rate a decade ago. international net migration was 69,000. population matters, a pressure group, urged the government to promote smaller families as a way to address population growth and its consequences.
2007	police in omaha, nebraska, are investigating if two cases of double homicide, which occurred six miles apart and five years apart, might be linked. both sets of victims had ties to the pathology department at creighton university medical school. on tuesday, roger and mary brumback, both 65, were found dead in their home. roger was a professor in the pathology and neurology departments and was set to retire and move to west virginia. when a piano mover arrived, he discovered an ammunition clip in the doorway and mary's body inside, with roger found nearby. in 2008, 11-year-old thomas hunter and his family's housekeeper, shirlee sherman, were found dead in their home. thomas's father, william hunter, is still a faculty member in creighton's 12-person pathology department. he has expressed concern that the same person may be responsible. the cold-case unit is assisting in the investigation. the brumbacks were described as popular and dedicated colleagues, while the hunters' neighbors and colleagues said they were kind and family-oriented individuals. a prayer service was held at the school for the brumbacks, and tributes were paid by students.
2008	senate majority leader harry reid plans a vote on tuesday to renew unemployment benefits for approximately 1.3 million americans who lost them when the program expired at the end of december. democrats, including president barack obama, support extending the benefits, while republicans generally oppose them. the issue may be contentious as democrats control the senate and republicans have a majority in the house. roughly 1.3 million long-term unemployed individuals relied on this federal program, and without it, they will find the check missing in their mailboxes on monday. this is a repeating theme in congressional debates, with arguments made for and against the program's necessity to sustain economic recovery and provide financial support to struggling individuals, versus arguments that it is an economic drain and disincentive to work. the legislative battles take place against the backdrop of a midterm election year, and the white house has shown firm support for extending the benefits, setting the stage for potential future conflicts on funding the federal government, raising the debt ceiling, and addressing other contentious issues.
2009	in russia's vologda region, a ban on selling fizzy, caffeinated drinks to minors took effect on january 1, 2023. this includes international brands like coca-cola, sprite, and fanta, as well as domestic products such as baikal. the ban also extends to sales in specific institutions like children's, educational, and medical facilities, and cultural and sports centers. the law aims to protect minors' health, with deputy yevgeny korotkov of the parliament's economic policy and property committee citing negative health effects from these drinks. the ban was announced as deputy prime minister igor shuvalov expressed russians' support for president vladimir putin in the face of foreign pressure at the world economic forum in davos, switzerland. he stated that russians are prepared to sacrifice their wealth to back putin, as the country grapples with economic recession and western sanctions.
2010	google's chairman, eric schmidt, defended the company's low tax bill in the uk, stating that google helps the economy through online advertising sales and hiring over 2,000 employees who pay income tax. however, critics label google a parasite and argue that the company should pay a fair share of corporation tax, as it reported small profits in the uk and funneled most of its profits to ireland and bermuda to avoid taxes. google paid £7.3 million in corporation tax on £3.1 billion in uk sales in 2012, while opponents such as starbucks and amazon faced similar criticisms for their tax practices in the country. google's tax avoidance tactics cost global governments at least £1 billion in lost tax revenue, and google's chairman admitted it was a "very, very good business environment" for the company in britain.
2011	katey sagal, known for her roles as peg bundy on "married with children" and current role as gemma morrow on "sons of anarchy," reflects on her experiences as a mother both on and off screen. she acknowledges the difference between her own thoughtful and well-spoken demeanor and peg's uneducated and uncouth character. sagal discusses the dedication and devotion all mothers have, noting that even peg was devoted to her children. she also highlights the challenges and rewards of mixing family with business as she works with her husband, "sons of anarchy" creator kurt sutter. the article touches on the growing opportunities for older women in hollywood, specifically on cable, and mentions sagal's character on "lost," helen, whose supposed death has left fans wondering if she could still make an appearance.
2012	joseph pedrero, a 46-year-old fisherman from tacloban, philippines, lost 11 family members during typhoon haiyan last year. he was not adequately warned of the storm surge that took their lives and is now evacuating inland with the remaining family members. tacloban's mayor, alfred romualdez, has ordered evacuations of coastal neighborhoods as a precaution for the approaching typhoon hagupit. last year, romualdez faced criticism for his response to haiyan, as many displaced people were not properly identified due to lack of documentation or identification, making it challenging to ensure they received adequate assistance. this time around, he has closed schools to give people time to prepare and evacuate, with over 450,000 people moved to safety across the country according to the un office for the coordination of humanitarian affairs. the city is eerily subdued ahead of the storm, with people heeding evacuation orders and taking preparations seriously to avoid the devastating impact of last year's typhoon.
2013	reese witherspoon, known for her million-dollar smile and bubbly persona, was arrested for disorderly conduct last friday in atlanta after her husband, talent agent jim toth, was pulled over for driving under the influence. in her mugshot, reese had her head down and a slight smirk on her face, a far cry from her red carpet appearances. she reportedly failed to look up due to being "wobbly." the video footage of her arrest shows her in handcuffs, calm and cooperative, but adding to the public embarrassment for the actress. her husband's mugshot showed him looking at the camera. the couple has been given bail until their may 22 court hearing, and reese has since issued a public apology for her behavior.
2014	the bbc's editorial compliance unit has criticized the today program for giving equal weight to minority views on climate change during a debate featuring climate scientist sir brian hoskins and lord lawson, a founder of the global warming policy foundation. the complaint was made by former green party councillor chit chong, who argued that broadcasting shows questioning the existence of climate change is irresponsible and confusing. the unit's head, fraser steel, stated that minority opinions should not be treated as equal to the scientific consensus and that lord lawson's views, which deny the severity of climate change and question the need for investment in renewable energy, were not made clear as not being supported by the majority of climate scientists. the today program's editor ceri thomas admitted that they could have offered a clearer description of lord lawson's position in the introduction.
2015	britain experienced an unprecedented achievement in the 2012 tour de france as bradley wiggins became the first british tour winner, while chris froome finished second. team sky, backed by significant government funding and a strong organizational effort, dominated the race. robert millar, a former british cyclist who finished 4th in the 1984 tour, reflected on the dramatic change in road cycling in the uk since his days of racing, attributing it to a lack of investment and support in the past. wiggins, with the help of froome and mark cavendish, excelled through tactical support and consistent performances. millar believes wiggins' switch to the american garmin slipstream team was key in his development as a road racer. team sky's meticulous planning and supportive team dynamic allowed wiggins to thrive, pushing him to his limits and earning him a place in cycling history. millar expressed that the commitment and dedication required to become a professional cyclist, despite the challenges and mental fatigue, are worth it for the satisfaction of achieving something remarkable.
2016	the 2014 federal budget, as announced by treasurer joe hockey, includes significant cuts to foreign aid, welfare, and increases in tertiary education fees. the government aims to raise up to $20 billion for a medical research fund by 2020 through a $7 gp co-payment and other measures. families will be affected by frozen assistance rates, a freeze on private health insurance rebates, and changes to the paid parental leave scheme. businesses will benefit from a 1.5 percent company tax cut, infrastructure programs, and incentives for older workers and apprentices. however, there are increases in petrol prices and excise, and cuts to public service jobs, public broadcasting, science funding, and foreign aid. specific groups such as sick people, pensioners, high-income earners, and unemployed people will also be impacted by various measures in the budget.
2017	andrew fuller, a 25-year-old former college football player and financial aid adviser, is now a teacher at tri-cities high school in east point, georgia, as part of teach for america (tfa), a non-profit organization that recruits non-traditional teachers to improve education in low-income communities. fuller, who grew up in a special education program and felt stigmatized, wants to make a difference for underserved students. he played football at the university of oregon and portland state university, where he discovered a passion for academics. after earning a master's degree in special education, he joined tfa and moved to georgia to make a difference in high-need schools. tfa was founded in 1990 by wendy kopp to address educational inequality, and the program prioritizes recruiting successful individuals, often recent graduates, to commit at least two years to teaching in impoverished communities. corps members, like jared gourrier and mini'imah shaheed, may not have studied education but possess traits that make them effective teachers and leaders. tfa provides a summer training institute and offers opportunities for corps members to move into administrative roles. the model faces criticism for a lack of a rigorous teacher preparation program and low retention rates, but tfa argues that its long-term goal includes developing a leadership force to become principals, superintendents, and policymakers. fuller plans to become a principal and eventually a us senator to address educational issues through national policy.
2018	a russian woman named alina bogdanova, 28, took her own life after having drunken sex with her ex-boyfriend, aleksandrs zuks, behind her new partner's back. bogdanova was found hanging in her brother's house where zuks also resided in spalding, lincolnshire, the morning after they rekindled their romance on october 25, 2013. bogdanova was in a relationship with arturas pakalniskis at the time and had informed him that she was visiting her brother. an inquest into her death held on february 20, 2014, recorded a verdict of suicide. her friend paid tribute to bogdanova as a beautiful and full-of-life person, although it is unclear if guilt over cheating played a role in her suicide.
2019	the world cup has begun with exciting matches, but football fans in england are already looking forward to the 2014-2015 premier league season. last year's league was dramatic, and with new managers like louis van gaal at manchester united, expectations are high. van gaal will not face top six teams until october and begins with a relatively straightforward schedule. promoted teams leicester city, queens park rangers, and burnley are excited for their premier league debuts. the opening fixtures include leicester hosting everton, qpr entertaining hull, and burnley playing chelsea, with dyche facing mourinho in an intriguing match. chelsea has new signings diego costa and cesc fabregas, while arsenal fans will be unforgiving towards their old rival. liverpool aims for another title challenge, but manchester city will put up a fight. the premier league is where every player, manager, and fan wants to be. the new season is about to begin.
2020	abubakar shekau, the leader of the nigerian extremist group boko haram, has vowed to sell more than 270 schoolgirls kidnapped from chibok village as sex slaves. shekau, dressed in combat fatigues and speaking in the local hausa language and arabic, declared in a video obtained by french news agency afp that "i abducted your girls. i will sell them in the market, by allah." the group, which means "western education is forbidden," seized the girls, aged 16 to 18, during a raid on a school last month. the brazenness and brutality of the kidnapping have shocked nigerians and drawn international condemnation, with former british prime minister gordon brown leading calls for military assistance from western governments. president goodluck jonathan pledged to find and release the girls but admitted he has no idea where they are. thousands of nigerians have taken to the streets in protests demanding their safe return. unconfirmed reports suggest some of the girls have been taken across nigeria's borders with chad and cameroon and sold as brides for as little as $12. boko haram is africa's leading security threat and is growing bolder and extending its reach. the group opposes western education and the education of women under its version of sharia law.
2021	the annual readers' choice survey by condé nast traveler listed the friendliest and least friendly cities in the world based on travelers' experiences. the most welcoming cities include floriaopolis, brazil, hobart, australia, and thimphu, bhutan. in contrast, the least friendly cities are newark, new jersey, islamabad, pakistan, and oakland, california. bhutan, known for its policy of "gross national happiness," has two cities in the top 10. charleston, south carolina is the friendliest city in the us, and the deep south dominates the list of friendliest american communities. the survey also included a list of the friendliest cities in the us, with charleston at the top. the least friendly cities in the us are los angeles, anaheim, sacramento, new haven, detroit, and atlantic city.
2022	south suffolk mp tim yeo, a pro-eu and gay marriage supporter, has warned tories against allowing eurosceptic "obsessives" to drive policy out of fear of ukip, leading to possible defeat in the 2015 general election. he criticized the shrinking party membership becoming more "extreme" and urged the tories to instead broaden their appeal, opposing ukip policies as "incoherent and inconsistent." yeo, who previously faced deselection, also expressed his support for coalition with the liberal democrats and the hs2 rail project.
2023	the fia, motor racing's governing body, is planning to trial speed limits during races in response to the horrific crash at the japanese grand prix that left marussia's jules bianchi fighting for his life. bianchi veered off the track under double yellow flags, colliding with a recovery vehicle. race director charlie whiting presented a report on the accident to fia president jean todt this weekend. a suggestion to impose a speed limit under yellow and double yellow flags is expected to be tested in practice at the next race in austin, texas, in three weeks. lewis hamilton, a formula one driver, revealed that the drivers had discussed safety measures during a meeting and supported the idea of limiting engines when flags are displayed, a practice used in go-karting.
2024	at the german grand prix, lewis hamilton of mclaren secured his second formula one victory of the season, defeating fernando alonso and mark webber in a fierce battle. hamilton took the lead off the grid and traded positions with webber several times during the race. alonso finished second, and webber third, while sebastian vettel suffered an error-filled afternoon to finish fourth, maintaining his 77-point lead in the drivers' championship. hamilton, who called the race one of the best of his career, passed alonso with a perfectly timed pit stop to take the checkered flag 3.9 seconds ahead. jenson button, hamilton's teammate and the 2009 world champion, retired due to hydraulic issues for the second consecutive race. in motogp, casey stoner won the u.s. grand prix and increased his lead in the world championship standings to 20 points over jorge lorenzo.
2025	mark fear, 55, committed suicide at his £500,000 home in cowes four months after the death of his civil partner kenneth kendall, 88, who left him assets worth £408,285 in his will. kendall, best known for presenting treasure hunt with anneka rice, died of a stroke last december. fear, who had met kendall in london and entered into a civil partnership in 2006, was devastated by kendall's death and left a note addressed to his friend vicki wyatt expressing his inability to face the future without him. the former interior designer also left instructions for wyatt to access his will and documents on his iphone. kendall and fear had opened the kendall fine art gallery on the isle of wight together following kendall's retirement.
2026	a possible prototype of the next generation iphone, which is believed to have a flat, ceramic back and other upgraded features, was obtained by the technology blog gizmodo for $5,000 from a source who found it in a bar. apple requested the return of the device, and gizmodo complied. the authenticity of the phone was widely confirmed in the tech community, and its appearance alignment with rumors of a new iphone design. apple has not confirmed the existence or details of the new iphone, but analysts anticipate its release in the summer. the obtained prototype's features include a front-facing camera, larger rear camera, and a flatter design.
2027	an expert predicts that lake superior, the largest freshwater lake in the world with a surface area of 31,700 square miles, will completely freeze over before the arrival of spring. the ice cover currently stands at around 91%, surpassing the previous record of 89% set in 1994 and exceeding the 40-year average annual ice coverage for february which is just 30%. this winter has had among the most rapid ice buildups in recent history due to extreme temperatures that have been below freezing for an extended period in the region, with duluth, minnesota, experiencing 23 consecutive days without the mercury rising above zero. while there have been warnings of climate change causing the lake to become warmer, this winter's widespread ice contradicts that trend.
2028	british prime minister david cameron announced that the uk will hold a referendum on european union (eu) membership if his conservative party wins another election. in a speech in london, cameron raised concerns about britain's membership in the eu and asserted the right of the british people to decide whether to remain with a renegotiated settlement or leave. some commenters praised cameron for protecting uk interests and asserting its power, while others saw it as a populist move to pander to skeptics and an unfair attempt to dictate terms. the "europe question" has long been a contentious issue in uk politics, with cameron facing pressure from his own party and concerns about timing given the country's economic struggles. some feared instability and economic uncertainty if the uk leaves the eu, while others believed the union needed change. critics also questioned the fairness of a unilateral decision and doubted the outcome would be genuine given the uk's financial troubles. other commenters were more cynical, dismissing the move as mere politics or a sign of imminent collapse for the eu. overall, there were mixed reactions to cameron's announcement.
2029	andrey lugovoy, a russian parliament member and former secret services operative wanted for the murder of alexander litvinenko in london, is offering edward snowden, the american whistleblower hiding in moscow, a job as a co-host on a russian tv show about intelligence and spy agencies. snowden, who is wanted in the us for leaking classified information, has been granted asylum in russia since 2013. lugovoy is accused of poisoning litvinenko with radioactive polonium-210 but has not been extradited to the uk. snowden has not yet responded to the offer. the ldpr tv channel, run by lugovoy's ultranationalist political party, believes snowden's experience and knowledge will provide insight into the sphere of secret services for their audience. both men are on international wanted lists and cannot travel freely to western countries.
2030	brian harman, a local resident of sea island, shot a 5-under-par 65 in the first round of the mcgladrey classic in georgia, leading a crowded leaderboard alongside michael thompson, erik compton, and will mackenzie. harman, who won his first pga tour tournament at the john deere classic in july, expressed relief to be back in action after sitting out the first two tournaments of the season. the conditions were tough with wind and cold temperatures, but harman managed to outlast them. compton, another local favorite and university of georgia alumni, also had a strong round with six birdies and a bogey to share the lead. mackenzie joined them after birdieing seven of the final 12 holes. other contenders included chesson hadley, webb simpson, and matt kuchar, while padraig harrington and russell knox were further back. mark anderson made the longest shot of the day with a hole-in-one on the third hole.
2031	the mayor of nanjing, ji jianye, was recently arrested on suspicions of accepting bribes worth approximately $3.3 million since taking office in march. this arrest is part of chinese president xi jinping's high-profile anti-corruption campaign, known as "catching tigers and flies," which targets both high-ranking and low-level corrupt officials. corruption is a deeply ingrained problem in chinese society, where the concept of "guanxi" or connections play a significant role in personal and business dealings. as a result, many view xi's campaign as an uphill battle. guanxi is a network of connections, and its importance is exemplified by the story of the narrator, who was unable to get promotions or secure hospital beds without it. businesspeople are required to spend a significant portion of their operating costs on guanxi to ensure survival and advancement, resulting in a corrupt system where officials and business elites have patron-client relationships. the problem of corruption in china has its roots in china's long tradition of rule by men rather than the rule of law and extends to the political sphere, with the country's leaders mostly being "princelings" or children of senior leaders. to effectively combat corruption, genuine political reforms, such as checks and balances, transparency, and independent scrutiny, need to be introduced alongside the observance of the rule of law. however, these remedies may be challenging for xi to implement. while xi's campaign has resulted in the arrest of several high-ranking officials, it is unlikely to eliminate the rampant corruption in every corner of society. the arrested nanjing mayor is reportedly under investigation for ties with suzhou's richest businessman, zhu xingliang, and other top leaders.
2032	a previously unheard recording of martin luther king jr. discussing his relationship with john f. kennedy will be played for the first time on monday at the lorraine motel in memphis, where king was assassinated in 1968. the recording, discovered in a tennessee attic several years ago, includes king discussing kennedy's role in securing his release from a georgia prison in 1960. kennedy called king's wife, coretta, and expressed his concern, and his brother robert kennedy also contacted the judge. king's release was attributed to the kennedy family's intervention, which helped shift support of black voters in northern states to kennedy and away from richard nixon. the recording includes king's definition of nonviolence and his thoughts on the importance of the civil rights movement in the united states and abroad. the entire recording will be played in the room where king spent his last hours. the tape was sold to illusionist david copperfield, who donated it to the national civil rights museum.
2033	lord peter mandelson's consulting firm, global counsel llp, made over £500,000 in its first year (november 2010 to december 2011), according to recently published accounts. the company, located in london's knightsbridge, accumulated net assets of £560,000 during this period. mandelson, a former cabinet minister and european commissioner, also earns a significant income from his role as a senior adviser to investment bank lazards, speaking engagements, and sales of his memoirs. the firm has been able to maintain secrecy regarding its clients until now, but new house of lords rules require mandelson to disclose them starting from next march. the company has been criticized for taking on controversial clients, such as asia pulp and paper (app), accused of illegally deforesting rainforests in indonesia. mandelson has used his extensive business and political connections, gained during his time in office, to build the international profile of his firm. the former hartlepool mp has faced speculation regarding his earnings and the purchase of his £7.6 million london property since leaving office two years ago. mandelson and global counsel declined to comment on the matter.
2034	al-qaeda's english-language online magazine "inspire," which has been a significant source of concern for counterterrorism officials in the us and europe, may have come to an end following the death of its american-saudi editor, samir khan, in a drone strike. khan, who was radicalized while living in the queens area of new york city, had previously attracted attention for publishing sympathetic content to al-qaeda on his blog. al-qaeda's english-language propaganda output is expected to be significantly reduced as a result of the loss of both khan and anwar al-awlaki, who gained a large following in the us and europe due to his charisma and ability to transmit religious teachings in a way young muslims could understand. other english-language propagandists for al-qaeda include oregon-born convert adam gadahn and saudi-born american adnan shukrijumah, who is believed to have taken on a senior role for the group. however, neither of these individuals have the religious knowledge or following that al-awlaki did among militant islamist circles in the west. al-qaeda has used english-language propaganda as a factor in increasing radicalization in the us, and the death of al-awlaki is expected to have a significant impact on this trend. several individuals who have been convicted of plotting terrorist attacks in the us and europe were followers of al-awakai, including those involved in the plot to blow up trans-atlantic airliners and the fort dix military base. while al-awlaki was a key driver of al-qaeda in the arabian peninsula's ambitions to launch attacks against the us, counterterrorism officials are concerned about potential revenge attacks by his followers in his name.
2035	birmingham football club is under investigation by the football league over potential involvement of carson yeung, who is serving a six-year prison sentence in hong kong for money-laundering, in the club's affairs. birmingham's parent company, birmingham international holdings limited (bihl), made a statement to the hong kong stock exchange regarding changes yeung wants to make to its board, which have raised concerns about his influence. the football league has written to the club for clarification on whether yeung, who owns 27.9% of bihl, should be considered a "relevant person" under the owners and directors' test. the league has the power to take action against the club if yeung is found to be significantly involved, including fines, points deductions, or a transfer embargo. bihl's statement named three individuals, including yeung's common-law wife and bodyguard, as his nominees for the board. yeung, a former hairdresser, denies the money-laundering charges.
2036	a nepalese farmer, mohamed salmo miya, took revenge on a venomous common cobra that bit him by killing it with his own teeth while near his village southeast of kathmandu. the incident occurred during the summer monsoon season when snakes are active and nepal experiences around 20,000 snake bites each year, causing approximately 1,000 deaths. miya, who was treated at a local clinic and is recovering at home, explained that he followed the snake and killed it out of anger after it bit him while he was farming. the common cobra, which is worshipped by hindus in some parts of nepal, is one of the deadliest snakes in the region.
2037	a woman named tavish smith, 45, who works for a judge in florida, was arrested for driving under the influence and leaving the scene of an accident last thursday. after being placed in handcuffs, smith, who was described as being giggly and flirtatious with officers, managed to slip her cuffs and eat a bag of marijuana found in her car. this led to additional felony charges for consumption of marijuana and destruction of evidence. surveillance footage from the trooper's squad car shows smith munching on the marijuana after grabbing it from the front seat. she allegedly crashed her car, drove the wrong way up a highway, and rolled it over in a ditch, leaving residue on her face and in the car. smith has been suspended from her job following her arrest.
2038	the nba is expanding its reach in africa, viewing the continent as a source for future basketball stars and fans. amadou gallo, managing director of nba africa, is currently touring the continent to promote the "basketball without borders" program, which invites top youth players from around the world to train with nba stars and coaches. the program aims to make basketball accessible, increase participation, and develop life skills and education. the nba signed a multi-year deal with south african broadcaster supersport to televise games in 47 sub-saharan territories, and incoming commissioner adam silver sees enormous opportunities for basketball growth in africa, as well as in china and india. despite soccer's popularity in africa, gallo sees potential for both sports, citing the success of african players such as dikembe mutombo, manute bol, luol deng, and luc mbah a moute. to fully realize africa's basketball potential, infrastructure and instruction for young players must be established at an early age. the nba believes there is a huge business opportunity in africa, with its billion-plus population, and plans to cultivate talent and create a younger fan base.
2039	some leading british charities have faced criticism for giving their chief executives excessive pay raises. thirty executives at the country's 14 major international development charities now earn over £100,000, with 11 of these ceos earning more than the prime minister's salary of £142,500. the charity commission has accused these charities of bringing the charitable world into disrepute. conservative mp priti patel voiced her concern over the use of public funds on highly paid executives and urged charities to be more accountable to the public. william shawcross, the chairman of the charity commission, warned charities to control boardroom pay or face harm to their reputations. the charities involved, which have received over £1.1 billion of public funds over the past three years, insisted their pay was in line with other charities of comparable size. however, the charity commission emphasized that trustees should carefully consider whether such high salaries are appropriate and fair to donors and taxpayers.
2040	chelsea climbed five points clear at the top of the english premier league with a hard-fought 2-0 win over wolverhampton, who remain in the relegation zone. nicolas anelka and florent malouda scored for the champions, while everton and tottenham played out a 1-1 draw. arsenal and manchester united face challenging matches against manchester city and stoke respectively, with arsenal traveling on sunday. west brom moved up to fourth place with a 2-1 victory over fulham. sunderland won 1-0 against aston villa, while bolton and birmingham both picked up crucial points in their respective matches against wigan and blackpool. newcastle defeated west ham 2-1.
2041	a egyptian court has sentenced 10 islamist supporters of deposed president mohammed morsi and members of the muslim brotherhood to death for inciting violence and blocking a road last july. the sentence, which was handed down in absentia, includes brotherhood supreme guide mohammed badie, former lawmaker mohammed el-beltagui, salafi preacher safwat hegazy, and bassem ouda, the supplies minister under morsi. the trials are part of a government crackdown against the group, which was outlawed and declared a terrorist organization after morsi's ouster in 2013. hundreds of morsi supporters have been killed, thousands detained, and hundreds referred to trial in the months following his removal. in related news, an appeals court overturned the sentences given to four police officers for the deaths of 37 detainees, mostly morsi supporters, in an overcrowded police truck. the sentences are the first against police officers in connection to the crackdown on islamists since morsi's ouster. elsewhere, retired field marshal abdel-fattah el-sissi is set to be inaugurated as egypt's new president tomorrow. those sentenced in absentia will have a new trial if they are arrested or surrender to authorities.
2042	the supreme court ruled that labor unions must provide nonmember workers with "fresh notice" before imposing unplanned increases in fees or assessments for political purposes. the ruling was in response to a case brought by dianne knox, a california state employee who objected to a $12 million assessment imposed by the service employees international union (seiu) for political spending without her consent. the court found that nonunion employees were not given a choice to opt-in to the special political fund and that the fees were taken directly from their paychecks and pensions. the ruling is a victory for knox and 28,000 other current and former workers who sued the union. the court held that public-sector unions must provide fresh notice and obtain affirmative consent before extracting funds from nonunion members for any fee increases or assessments. dissents were filed by justices stephen breyer and elena kagan, who argued that the union's administrative system did not violate the constitution, and that the majority went too far in extending the requirement to all opt-out fee collections, not just political lobbying.
2043	moscow, russia's vibrant capital city, is a blend of old and new. the iconic st. basil's cathedral, a symbol of russian cultural heritage, coexists with modern amenities such as internet cafes, 24-hour bookstores, and cell phones.however, some conveniences, like using credit cards or buying a simple item like a nail clipper, can be challenging. the city is also expensive, with high fees for using atms and dining out. gogol cafe-club, named after the famous russian writer, is a popular hangout for locals and expats. although moscow has progressed since the soviet union fell, it retains its unique character. some of its monuments come to life at night, and nightlife venues like propaganda and the real mccoys offer cultural experiences. however, navigating the city's unspoken rules, such as not talking in dorm elevators or hallways, can be perplexing for visitors. one memorable experience was finding a secret two-story ballroom in a dorm filled with tables, chairs, and a piano, where a russian student and i shared a musical moment. overall, moscow offers an enchanting mix of history, culture, and modernity that is both exhilarating and mystifying.
2044	a massachusetts high school student, phoebe prince, committed suicide after being bullied by her classmates in south hadley in 2010. her parents received a $225,000 settlement from the town after filing a complaint with the state's discrimination commission, arguing that the school failed to address the hazing that preceded her death. the settlement included a confidentiality agreement, which was used by the town to keep the record sealed. however, a reporter from slate magazine, emily bazelon, successfully sued to make the settlement public, with assistance from the aclu, arguing first amendment rights. a judge ordered the records be made public, stating that the confidentiality clause does not make a public document private. civil rights groups hailed the decision, stating that public records remain public even with confidentiality clauses. the settlement prevents phoebe's parents from suing the town again but binds them to confidentiality, prohibiting them from disclosing the agreement's details.
2045	three afghan national army officers who went missing from a military training exercise in massachusetts spent the night before they disappeared at a local strip club, according to the club owner. the men, identified as maj. jan mohammad arash, capt. mohammad nasir askarzada, and capt. noorullah aminyar, were seen at zachary's pub in mashpee on the night of september 23. they reportedly stayed for a couple of hours and left at 1 a.m. the following morning, military officials contacted the club to report the men missing. the officers were later found on monday in the custody of canadian border guards at the rainbow bridge, and are now being charged with immigration violations. the men had arrived in the u.s. on september 11 for an annual military exercise and were quartered at joint base cape cod. us immigration and customs enforcement (ice) took custody of the three officers on tuesday and they are being charged with administrative immigration violations and placed into removal proceedings.
2046	an american man, gary giordano, who was held in aruba for nearly four months in connection with the disappearance of his traveling companion, robyn gardner, insisted on abc's "good morning america" that he had nothing to do with her disappearance but felt guilty for not being able to prevent it. giordano, 50, had been released from custody earlier in the week after the aruban judges denied a request to extend his detention. he told authorities that they were both snorkeling in august when he signaled to gardner to swim back, but she was nowhere to be found when he reached the beach. despite repeated requests for an extension of his detention, aruban judges upheld his release after a three-judge panel review. however, aruban prosecutor taco stein stated that he would seek extradition if needed. giordano's u.s.-based attorney, jose baez, explained that the couple were both single and that their sexual activities, which had been widely speculated about, were irrelevant to the case. the lawyer asserted that the two were not exclusive and that they had engaged in open relationships. giordano denied that he and gardner had been drinking before the incident and that he took her to a remote location. he also disputed allegations that he appeared dry in a surveillance video after gardner went missing, explaining that he was exhausted from swimming back to shore. giordano acknowledged that he had inquired about a $1.5 million life insurance policy he had taken out for both himself and gardner before their trip, but he denied any involvement in her disappearance and stated that he would not have come to aruba if he could have prevented it. baez claimed that critics were looking for a scapegoat and that everything negative being said about giordano was based on speculation. the unresolved case has raised significant questions regarding the relationship between giordano and gardner, as well as the events leading up to her disappearance.
2047	in mogadishu, somalia, at least 39 civilians were killed and one soldier was injured when a roadside bomb targeted a convoy of african union (au) peacekeepers, prompting the troops to open fire. deputies and eyewitnesses condemned the attack, with the deputy mayor accusing the peacekeepers of deliberately killing civilians, an allegation au denied. the incident occurred on maka al-mukarama road in southern mogadishu, as somalia's newly elected president, sheikh sharif sheikh ahmed, attended an au summit in addis ababa. the u.n. secretary-general ban ki-moon urged continued international support for somalia's reconciliation efforts at the summit, while the u.n. pledged to provide logistical support to the au's amisom force and help develop somali security forces. amisom was established to take over from ethiopian forces, who invaded somalia in 2006 to depose an islamic government led by ahmed, but the country has been without an effective central government since 1991 and has seen ongoing conflict with islamist groups like al-shabaab. ahmed was elected president on saturday, and many somalis view him as a final hope to challenge the militia and its extremist ideology.
2048	dr. shakil afridi, a pakistani doctor who helped the cia locate osama bin laden, was offered an opportunity to leave pakistan with his family after the may 2011 raid, but he declined the offer. afridi, who ran a fake vaccination campaign to gather dna samples from bin laden's children, was later jailed for 33 years on treason charges. u.s. officials believe that pakistan had ample time to help afridi leave the country if he had wanted to do so. the doctor's imprisonment has strained u.s-pakistan relations, with some u.s. senators cutting aid to pakistan as a result. president obama and his administration are making efforts to secure afridi's release. however, pakistani officials have given conflicting explanations for afridi's imprisonment, most recently stating that he was jailed for aiding militants and not for his links to the cia. afridi's family has described the treason charges as baseless and has received no help from the u.s. government. the u.s. sees afridi as a hero who helped bring an end to bin laden's reign of terror, while many pakistanis view him as a traitor who conspired against the state. pakistan has rejected u.s. criticism of afridi's imprisonment.
2049	officer joel zwicky, 40, from green bay, wisconsin, has become the world's first skateboard cop. he patrols parks and pavements on a customized longboard while wearing his police gear. if he receives a 'hot call,' he can place his skateboard in his unmarked dodge patrol car to race to the scene of a major incident. officer zwicky started this innovation two years ago, and after receiving support from his chief, he now hopes to expand the program and create a full unit of skateboard cops. green bay police captain bill galvin stated that officer zwicky's skateboard patrol is an extension of the one-man cars, and his colleagues were initially skeptical but came around when understanding officer zwicky's intention of engaging with kids.
2050	capital one is under scrutiny for wanting to know debtors' addresses to potentially visit them if they owe money. the fair debt collection practices act (fdcpa) generally prohibits debt collectors from intrusive collection activities, but it does not apply to original creditors like capital one. the article raises concerns about modern contract law and consumers unwittingly agreeing to terms such as "personal visits" when signing up for credit cards or making online purchases. the article questions whether contract law should intervene to prevent corporations from imposing one-sided terms on consumers, while also considering the implications of citizens not being able to take responsibility for the contracts they enter into. the article also mentions capital one's statement denying the practice of sending debt collectors to homes and their consideration of creating separate agreements for cardholders due to a misplaced provision in their contracts. the article suggests that all the misunderstandings appear to benefit capital one.
2051	the jewish museum in berlin has launched an exhibit featuring a jewish man or woman seated inside a glass box for two hours a day to answer visitors' questions about jews and jewish life. the exhibit aims to educate postwar generations who may not know any jews or much about them, but has drawn criticism from some within the jewish community for putting a jew on display. critics argue the exhibition is degrading and may perpetuate harmful stereotypes. museum officials believe the provocative approach is necessary to overcome emotional barriers and deal with a painful topic for both jews and non-jews. the exhibit includes questioning displays that have raised controversy, such as a placard asking 'how you can recognize a jew?' the exhibition, which runs until september, has proven popular among visitors but has also sparked debate and criticism within the jewish community.
2052	a connecticut woman, mariantonia morales, was arrested and her pet marmoset monkey, aladdin, was confiscated after the monkey accidentally scratched morales' 10-year-old daughter on the face. morales, who brought the monkey from her home in south carolina to help her recover from cancer, was charged with risk of injury to a minor and owns an exotic pet, as it is illegal to keep a marmoset monkey like aladdin as a pet in connecticut. the girl was playing with the monkey when the injury occurred. although morales maintains that it was an accident, authorities insist that she is required to abide by connecticut's monkey laws, which were instated in response to a 2009 chimpanzee attack that left a woman with horrific injuries. mariantonia hopes the charges against her will be dropped and her beloved monkey will be returned to her, but it seems unlikely as the monkey has been taken to a zoo in bridgeport.
2053	a tragic speedboat accident occurred during the south australian ski racing titles on the murray river on saturday afternoon, resulting in one fatality and another man being rushed to the hospital with severe burns. the two victims, both 57-year-old males from victoria, suffered a massive cardiac arrest for the passenger and severe burns for the driver. the police spokesman confirmed the tragic event, stating that the passenger was revived at the scene but passed away later. the driver was airlifted to the royal adelaide hospital for treatment, and ski racing south australia is expected to release a statement regarding the incident on sunday.
2054	a great white shark nicknamed "gilbert" surprised tourists in south australia when it attacked and killed another great white shark that was half its size while feeding on bait near the neptune islands. witnessed by boat passengers, including 33-year-old adam malski, the larger shark burst from the water and sank its teeth into the smaller shark's head. malski, originally from london but now residing in sydney, was diving in the area and had seen gilbert earlier in the day during a multi-day diving trip. despite the brutal attack, malski expressed respect for the sharks and their behavior towards humans. since the incident, gilbert has been spotted around the neptune islands, but the smaller shark has not been seen.
2055	a man in his thirties was stabbed in the shoulder with a bayonet on the set of the world war ii epic "fury" starring brad pitt and shia lebeouf in oxforshire, england. the victim was taken to the hospital, but his injuries are not considered serious. it is believed he was hurt accidentally and not in an attack. thames valley police were called to the scene and are not treating it as a crime. the health and safety executive has been notified and is investigating the incident. "fury," which is expected to be released next year, tells the story of a tank crew taking on a dangerous mission in the final weeks of the war. villagers in the area have been warned to expect noise from filming, including gunfire and explosions. pitt was recently seen getting tank driving lessons for his role as a battle-hardened sergeant. filming began last year.
2056	kim ferguson, given a 12-month prognosis after being diagnosed with cancer, chose to document her outfits daily on instagram as an outlet for her love of fashion and to inspire herself and others. her account, @kimlouiseferguson, began in 2017 and has since become a support network for those affected by cancer. kim, a mother of two and passionate about healthy living, has undergone several surgeries and treatments throughout the years. despite facing multiple challenges, she continues to inspire through her fashion choices and determination to live life to the fullest. along with her daughters elle and lucie, she keeps modeling outfits, sharing her story, and promoting positivity.
2057	li na, the sixth seed and first asian female to win a grand slam singles title, defeated maria sharapova 6-2, 6-2 to set up a final against defending champion victoria azarenka at the australian open. li broke sharapova's serve six times and dominated the match, while sharapova had six double-faults and 32 unforced errors. in the other semifinal, azarenka narrowly won against american teenager sloane stephens, who saved five match points and broke back in the second set. azarenka, who raised concerns about nerves during her on-court interview, later explained that she had been dealing with an injury, and clarified her comments at a press conference. stephens, who rose to a career-high 17th in the rankings, gained a large following on social media after her impressive performance.
2058	a study published by the university of edinburgh reveals that large city hospitals act as breeding grounds for the superbug mrsa before it spreads to smaller regional hospitals. researchers found genetic evidence that variants of mrsa in smaller hospitals likely originated from larger cities. the study involved analyzing the genetic makeup of around 80 mrsa variants and traced their spread around the uk. the findings suggest that the referral of patients to different hospitals is a major cause of mrsa transmission and could help prevent the spread of infections. mrsa, a bacteria resistant to antibiotics, has been present for over 50 years and became increasingly common in the 1990s, reaching a peak of 7,700 cases in 2003-2004. a hand-washing campaign launched in 2004 resulted in a significant decrease in mrsa cases to 1,481 in 2010-2011.
2059	a three-foot cement replica of the great sphinx by british street artist banksy appeared in new york on tuesday, but was swiftly sold by the business owner before the day ended. the sculpture, which was surrounded by a moat of stagnant water, was sold to an eager art collector for an undisclosed sum, causing a commotion among onlookers. the latest addition to banksy's new york residency, "better out than in," has seen many works vandalized or sold, with some people even charging for viewers to see them. banksy's website documents each of his one-per-day pieces, with the site describing the sphinx as a 1/36 scale replica made from smashed cinderblocks and warning against drinking the replica arab spring water. the previous day, banksy painted a picture of a boy smashing a water sprinkler with a hammer on the upper west side, which has already been defaced. banksy's monday offering was a young boy writing graffiti in the south bronx while being served by a waiter in tails. in greenwich village, two of banksy's works, "sirens of the lambs" and "shoe shining ronald mcdonald," temporarily appeared together outside a mcdonald's.
2060	career criminal noel 'razor' smith, who has 58 convictions and spent 32 years in prison, believes the current prison system in the uk is failing. with high re-offending rates, increasing violence and suicides, and a steady rise in prison populations, many argue that the prisons are in crisis. smith, who started a life of crime at a young age, has experienced the prison system firsthand, spending time in 34 different prisons, including notorious ones like whitemoor and belmarsh. he emphasizes that the prison population should only be for the most dangerous individuals and proposes that those with issues like alcohol or drug addiction or homelessness should be dealt with outside of prisons. he believes the answer is providing proper vocational and educational training, reducing the re-offending rate, which is currently at 46%. smith also criticizes the harsh prison conditions of the past, believing they do not work to prevent re-offending and encourages focusing on therapy and victim empathy, as he found at hmp grendon, which has the lowest re-offending rate in the uk. however, smith takes a controversial stance on drugs in prisons and is skeptical about mandatory drug testing, as it may result in more prisoners taking heroin instead of cannabis. he also criticizes ched evans' efforts to return to football despite being a convicted rapist. in recent years, the prison population has more than doubled, causing overcrowding and budget constraints, making it increasingly difficult for the national offender management service to provide effective rehabilitation programs. smith advocates for a system that focuses on rehabilitation, proper education, and providing resources for those leaving prison to prevent them from returning.
2061	elliot yeo, a west coast eagles midfielder, suffered the loss of his two front teeth during a collision with collingwood ruckman jarrod witts in a game at melbourne cricket ground on saturday. the teeth were knocked out when yeo failed to take a mark and the ball slipped through his grasp just before halftime. despite the pain, yeo continued playing and finished the game with 19 disposals and a goal. he tweeted afterwards, "all i want for christmas is my two front teeth...". trainers were unable to locate the teeth and yeo is expected to have them capped this week, as long as there is no nerve damage or splintering. the last similar incident occurred five years ago when lance franklin of hawthorn lost a tooth in a game. yeo is expected to play again on sunday against north melbourne.
2062	paola delgado-polanco, a 21-year-old pregnant woman originally from mexico, was allegedly beaten to death by her boyfriend fernando flores using a baseball bat at her trailer park home in delaware. delgado-polanco was found unconscious by paramedics and died hours later on october 29, 2020. she gave birth to a baby girl before her death, who is currently in critical but stable condition at christiana hospital in newark, delaware. flores was arrested the same day and initially charged with assault but has since been charged with manslaughter. the victim's family in mexico has set up a fundraising page to help cover funeral expenses and bring delgado-polanco's body back to her hometown. as of now, the page has raised $1,095.
2063	indonesian justice system faces criticism as local drug manufacturer avoids death penalty despite similar crime, while australians myuran sukumaran and andrew chan, who are on death row for attempting to smuggle drugs into australia from bali, are expected to be executed. hangky gunawan, an indonesian ice manufacturer, received a reduced sentence and was saved from execution in 2011, despite lodging his appeal after sukumaran and chan's. president joko widodo maintains his hard-line stance against drug dealers, despite appeals for clemency for the australians. the unfair treatment of the bali nine pair has led to calls for boycotts of indonesia from australians, and prime minister tony abbott has criticized the indonesian justice system for its hypocrisy. sukumaran and chan have rehabilitated themselves in prison and their families continue to plead for their lives.
2064	in his new memoir "this is your captain speaking," gavin macleod reflects on his long acting career with positivity and humor, sharing stories about encounters with hollywood legends like cary grant, gregory peck, and frank sinatra, as well as less-than-gracious guests like bette davis. macleod, who rose to fame as the even-keeled newswriter murray slaughter on "the mary tyler moore show" and later as captain merrill stubing on "the love boat," recounts the challenges and rewards of his life in show business. despite setbacks, including the loss of his father at a young age, years of alcoholism, and unexceptional early roles, macleod's enthusiasm and generosity shine through. in interviews, he emphasizes the importance of staying upbeat in the face of rejection and following one's instincts in pursuing a career in acting. macleod also discusses his faith and long marriage as sources of strength.
2065	thailand's february 2 general election has been declared invalid by a court due to disruptions caused by anti-government protesters in around a fifth of constituencies. the election, which was aimed at forming a new government after months of protests against prime minister yingluck shinawatra, was prevented from being held in 28 constituencies. the crisis, which has been ongoing for eight years, pits bangkok's royalist establishment and middle class against supporters of the shinawatra family, with protesters shutting down government offices and blocking major thoroughfares to force out yingluck. the violence and political paralysis have resulted in 23 deaths and hundreds of injuries, and have dented economic confidence, leading to cuts to growth forecasts. yingluck, who had called the election in december to try to defuse the protests, currently heads a caretaker government with limited powers. the main opposition democrat party, which had demanded electoral changes to reduce the influence of thaksin shinawatra, yingluck's brother and a former prime minister who was ousted in 2006 and lives in exile to avoid a jail term for corruption, threw in its lot with the protesters. the judges voted 6-3 to declare the february vote unconstitutional, but it is unclear when a new election will be held.
2066	mexico advanced to the knockout stage of the world cup after a 3-1 win over croatia, thanks to a late goal by andres guardado and a captain's goal by rafael marquez. mexico needed a favor from the us team to reach the finals and have taken advantage of that opportunity, impressing many with their performance against croatia. the game was fierce and feisty, with both teams playing aggressively and several fouls testing the patience of the referee. mexico's defense, led by the veteran marquez, kept croatia's forwards at bay and prevented luka modric from influencing the game. mexico came close to scoring several times but were unable to break croatia's goalkeeper stipe pletikosa. in the second half, mexico took control, with marquez scoring the first goal and guardado the second in a rapid counter-attack. javier hernandez added a third goal to secure their progress, although ivan perisic scored a consolation goal for croatia. mexico has the potential to make the most of this unexpected opportunity in the knockout stage.
2067	a man named malcolm holland, 56, went on a violent rampage at st barnabas church in st paul's cray, kent, last july, armed with a meat cleaver and a lock knife, grieving the loss of his wife. he smashed windows and assaulted several churchgoers, including an 84-year-old woman named yvonne burr, and a member of the local music group, velvet harmony, named gillian page. during the attack, steven izeghu, 28, who had become a british citizen just hours before, bravely intervened and managed to wrestle holland to the ground until the police arrived. holland, who had a history of mental illness, was sentenced to a hospital order under the mental health act and a restriction order after a psychologist assessed him. the judge praised izeghu's bravery and considered paying him £500 from public funds. several people were injured, and the church was cordoned off with damaged windows.
2068	a mother shares her personal experience of deciding whether or not to circumcise her two boys. even though she initially hoped for a girl to avoid the decision, she and her partner carefully considered the pros and cons of circumcision based on medical evidence, individual rights, and personal beliefs. they weighed the potential health benefits against the possible trauma and cultural considerations, ultimately making the decision to circumcise both sons based on the medical evidence supporting std and hiv prevention, penile cancer, and urinary tract infection reduction. despite being in the minority and facing criticisms from family and friends, the parents felt confident in their decision, which has been reinforced by the american academy of pediatrics. they made this decision based on their research and professional advice, rather than societal pressure or tradition.
2069	chinese new year is expected to bring a large number of tourists from china to thailand, but locals have expressed complaints about their behavior, leading the thai tourism office to distribute etiquette manuals to all chinese tourists. the manual advises against using public property as lavatories, defacing tourist attractions, reckless driving, and disrespecting local cultures and museum etiquette. complaints include defecating in public places, causing traffic accidents, and ruining toilets at the buddhist white temple in chiang rai. chinese tourists have also been banned from the temple following instances of inappropriate behavior. the chinese government has also taken steps to educate chinese tourists about international etiquette through television programs. an incident involving a chinese tourist draping her underwear in chiang mai airport sparked outrage and added to the controversy. thailand's government spokesman urged thai citizens to extend patience towards the visitors. this is not the first time a country has produced a guide to tourist etiquette, with thailand's embassy in japan creating one last year to address complaints about the behavior of thai tourists.
2070	egypt's military endorsed field marshal abdel-fattah el-sisi to run for the presidency, despite not officially announcing his candidacy. el-sisi, who helped oust egypt's first democratically elected president mohamed morsy in july, is considered a mandate and obligation by the military council. he must retire from the military before running for president and the interim government has yet to announce election dates. morsy's removal from power following mass protests led to political instability, with frequent protests from his supporters demanding his reinstatement, which often resulted in violence. egypt held a constitutional referendum in january with overwhelming approval, but the muslim brotherhood, which was banned in late 2013, boycotted the vote due to the crackdown against them. morsy, a member of the muslim brotherhood, was elected in 2012 after the ouster of former president hosni mubarak. his supporters claim he didn't get a fair chance and that the military has returned to authoritarian practices.
