2071	twenty years ago, linux creator linus torvalds announced the development of a free computer operating system using the linux penguin logo. while the linux brand failed to go mainstream after the dot-com bubble burst, the software's influence has grown significantly, with android, chrome os, webos, and others adopting its technology. linux contains 14 million lines of code and is protected by over 520,000 patents, making it pervasive in various industries, from appliances to cars, despite facing challenges in gaining desktop market share. microsoft recently revised its competition statement to acknowledge that linux is no longer seen as a significant threat to windows. despite being an underground movement, linux users, mainly male and nerdy, hold strong principles about collaborative development and ethical use of technology. the linux community continues to thrive and evolve, with dedicated followers maintaining its ethos and secret handshake represented by the linux penguin tattoo.
2072	sean fitzgerald, a 43-year-old drummer and son of singing legend tony christie, avoided a driving ban despite having 25 penalty points due to his need to transport his drum kit to gigs. he was caught speeding twice on the a38 near weeford in staffordshire in november 2011, and magistrates in cannock heard that he drives 20,000 miles a year for his father and other bands, earning between £18,000 and £25,000. fitzgerald, who is behind on mortgage payments, told the court that it was "either feast or famine" in the music business, and that he would lose his job if he lost his licence. he was fined £335 and given an additional eight points on his license. despite the seriousness of the situation, fitzgerald wept when he was spared a ban.
2073	two turkeys, cobbler and gobbler, pardoned by president obama in 2012 from certain death at the annual presidential turkey pardoning ceremony, have both passed away. cobbler, who was reportedly fond of cranberries and carly simon, died in august, and gobbler, described as a "patient but proud bird," passed away suddenly in february. the tradition of pardoning turkeys dates back to 1963 when president john f. kennedy sent the gift turkey back to the farm. president george h.w. bush was the first to grant an official presidential pardon to a turkey in 1989. despite being sent to live at george washington's mount vernon estate, their lifespans were short as they were bred for eating and their health couldn't keep up with their rapid growth. president obama will continue the tradition on wednesday and grant two more turkeys their freedom.
2074	fbi files reveal that the us law enforcement agency monitored and scrutinized dozens of african-american writers, including lorraine hansberry, langston hughes, james baldwin, and claude mckay, among others. the authors were subjected to extensive surveillance, with file sizes ranging from hundreds to thousands of pages. the fbi was particularly interested in their potential political views, especially those associated with socialism and communism, during the mccarthy era. black writers were aware of this surveillance, which influenced their works, such as richard wright's "fb eyes." the files shed light on the fbi's deep-seated hatred of the civil rights movement and dr. martin luther king jr. the average length of the files was around 300 pages, and some, such as hansberry's, were more than 1,000 pages long. the files contained detailed information about the writers' travels and contacts. while the surveillance was disabling for some authors, it also inspired creative experiments. prof. william maxwell, who discovered many of these files while researching claude mckay, wrote a book, "fb eyes," detailing this history of fbi surveillance of african-american writers from 1919 to 1972.
2075	a convoy of 280 white-painted trucks carrying relief goods or potential military supplies from russia towards the ukrainian border has raised concerns of a russian invasion in eastern ukraine. ukraine's deputy foreign minister, danylo lubkivsky, accused russia of using humanitarian aid as a pretext and inventing new excuses for their policies. the international committee of the red cross (icrc) denied any agreement with russia on such a convoy and expressed uncertainty about its role and the modalities of the aid handover. skepticism towards russian president vladimir putin's motives was rampant in kiev, with many fearing a possible escalation of the ongoing conflict, which has left over 2,000 people dead and nearly 5,000 wounded since mid-april. ukraine has vowed to stop any uncertified aid convoy from russia and received support from the us and nato in their opposition to such intervention. the fight for control of donetsk, the largest city in the eastern region of donbas, has intensified, with ukrainian forces pressing to recapture the city by ukraine's independence day on august 24.
2076	a new study by scientists at kobe university warns that japan could be wiped out by a massive volcanic eruption in the next century, potentially killing 95% of its population. the researchers analyzed the eruption patterns of volcanoes on the island nation and stated that it is not an exaggeration to predict extinction. they identified a massive volcanic crater on kyushu island as a particular concern and predicted an eruption could bury 7 million people under lava flows and create an uninhabitable toxic cloud on honshu, affecting the remaining 120 million people. the risk of such an event occurring in the next 100 years is estimated to be around 1%, but the researchers warn against ignoring the risk given the surprise 7.2-magnitude quake that struck kobe in 1995, which had a similar chance of occurrence. this warning comes after mount ontake erupted in september 2014 and killed 51 people, and signs of increased activity have been observed at a volcano in southern japan that poses a risk to a nuclear plant and at ioyama volcano in the southwestern part of kyushu.
2077	a planned three-day strike by london underground workers over tube ticket office closures was called off after last-minute talks between the rail, maritime and transport union (rmt) and london underground (lu). the industrial action was suspended due to substantial progress made in negotiations, with real movement on the core issues of job cuts, service reductions, and safety concerns. london mayor boris johnson described it as a victory for common sense and londoners. the dispute revolves around lu's intention to close 260 ticket offices and save £50 million per year for network improvements. the parties will now continue talks regarding the fundamental issues and the rmt's commitment to work with lu and the three other unions involved. londoners and businesses can now operate without the threat of unnecessary industrial action. the government will also announce its support for mayor johnson's proposals on ballot thresholds to limit union power to disrupt the capital.
2078	archaeologists in salekhard, siberia, discovered an ancient bronze ring dating back 2,000 years with images of a bear's head and paws. the ring, which was too small to fit on a woman's finger, was likely attached to the claw of a slain brown bear as a sign of respect in a bear cult. the ring, along with other precious objects like a carved figure, a pendant of an animal biting a bird, and a bronze bird with a mask, were found at an ancient spiritual site called ust-poluo. archaeologists believe that bear festivals were held to honor the memory of the slain bears, who were considered sacred ancestors by the ancient khanty tribes. the site was first excavated in the 1930s but was halted due to stalin's arrest of the chief archaeologist, vasily andrianov, on false charges. new discoveries in the area include other bronze objects, such as a bird with a mask and a pendant of a fur animal biting a bird, all believed to date to around the late bc or first ad.
2079	a halloween attraction at the scare kingdom scream park in lancashire, england, called "psychomanteum," which simulates a sexual assault experience, has been criticized by rape charity bosses as "degrading and humiliating." visitors are strapped to a bed, have cushions placed on their faces, and are manhandled and verbally abused. critics argue it normalizes violence against women and victims of sexual abuse. the attraction lasts about three minutes and requires an additional charge, with a disclaimer warning of explicit content. visitors are given a "safe word" to halt the experience. psychomanteum has received positive feedback from some guests, but many find it distressing.
2080	google introduced the nexus 7 tablet at a competitive price of $199 in the us and £159 in the uk, making it a bargain compared to apple's ipad which starts at $399 in both countries. the nexus 7 features a high-definition screen, quad-core processor, and long battery life, and hopes to challenge the ipad, microsoft surface, and current android tablets. two versions will be available, with 8gb and 16gb storage. google also revealed the nexus q, a spherical computer for streaming media, and improvements for existing google devices, including the new version of android, "jelly bean," and the ability to create events on google+. additionally, google co-founder sergey brin debuted google glass, wearable internet glasses, and announced they will be made available to developers for $1500 early next year.
2081	a british soldier, david lee collins, was stabbed to death by mohamed abdulkadir osman in a nightclub in ayia napa, cyprus, following a previous altercation. osman, along with tukki abbas shah and umar anwar, all from london, were arrested andremanded in police custody on suspicion of premeditated murder. the incident reportedly stemmed from a north-south rivalry and a previous argument in a pub. osman claimed he acted in self-defense and was high on drugs at the time. the soldier's family paid tribute to him, expressing their pride and sadness over his death. the three suspects have not been formally charged but could face life sentences if convicted. british military personnel and their families are stationed in cyprus, with soldiers often encountering restrictions in the ayia napa area due to previous incidents involving british soldiers.
2082	the international champions cup match between manchester united and liverpool in miami is expected to be a fierce rivalry between the two english football teams. manchester united, under new manager louis van gaal, will enter the match from a less favorable position as liverpool, who have lost luis suarez, but are acquiring new players. van gaal has imposed a 5-3-2 formation on united, and pre-season indications suggest he has the charisma and ingenuity to turn the club around. the best starting line-ups for both teams include key players such as david de gea for manchester united, who is known for his shot-stopping abilities, and simon mignolet for liverpool, who needs to increase his command of the liverpool box. other notable players include chris smalling and jonny evans for manchester united, and mamadou sakho and steven gerrard for liverpool. wayne rooney and daniel sturridge are expected to lead united and liverpool's attacks, respectively. van gaal has been impressed with his squad's pre-season performances. additionally, both teams have had successful pre-seasons with manchester united beating roma, drawing with inter milan, beating real madrid, and liverpool beating olympiacos, drawing with manchester city, and beating milano. liverpool will be without luis suarez following his sale to barcelona, but have made several acquisitions to compensate. the match marks an opportunity for both teams to flex their muscles and gain an early boost ahead of the season proper.
2083	the speaker, who was a friend of philly, a young cricket player from macksville who passed away at the age of 25, delivered a touching tribute at sidney cricket ground (scg). philly left an indelible mark on the game and the community, and the speaker recounted moments they shared at the scg. the speaker believed philly's spirit was still connected with the land and the game, and felt his presence at the scg. he encouraged the cricket community to cherish philly's spirit and use it to bring people together, as it always did. the speaker concluded by expressing his belief that philly's spirit will continue to act as a custodian of cricket and inspire generations to come.
2084	this article discusses the health benefits and potential risks of coffee consumption based on various studies. coffee has been linked to a lower risk of type 2 diabetes, with each additional cup reducing the risk by 7%, and may contain magnesium and chromium necessary for insulin regulation. studies have also shown that coffee drinkers have a lower risk of developing oral cancer, liver disease, and alzheimer's disease. coffee may boost athletic performance due to its effect on the central nervous system and may reduce the risk of developing alcohol-related liver cirrhosis by up to 80%. however, some studies suggest that coffee may increase the risk of developing depression, and it may not be beneficial for heart health as it raises blood pressure. the article includes expert opinions on the health benefits and risks of coffee consumption.
2085	scientists have cast doubt on the identification of jack the ripper by dr. jari louhelainen, as he may have incorrectly placed a decimal point in calculations leading to the belief that a specific dna sequence was rare and could be matched to suspect aaron kosminski and victim catherine eddowes. louhelainen, a molecular biologist, claimed to have found a global private mutation in dna from a shawl found next to eddowes and matched it to her descendant karen miller and a descendant of kosminski's sister. however, experts sir alec jeffreys, mannis van oven, and hansi weissensteiner argue that the mutation in question is more common than previously thought, and the mistake in decimal points makes the sequence far less significant for identifying jack the ripper. the controversy arose from a book published by businessman russell edwards, who bought the shawl at auction and hired louhelainen for dna analysis.
2086	fashion designer alexander wang and others, including balenciaga's new creative director, believe that the music played during fashion shows is crucial to the overall experience. during new york fashion week, wang used an industrial soundtrack for his edgy fall 2013 show at the cunard building. rag & bone collaborated with radiohead front man thom yorke and producer nigel godrich for a custom track. carolina herrera teamed up with composer tom hodge and the london contemporary orchestra to create an original score. michael kors, who compares fashion shows to broadway productions, often selects popular music to match the collection's theme. designers including altuzarra, diane von furstenberg, oscar de la renta, and rebecca taylor also chose specific songs to set the mood for their shows. the article includes a list of songs played during new york fashion week by various designers. the piece also previews cnn national correspondent alina cho's latest installment of "fashion: backstage pass from new york fashion week," which includes interviews with naomi campbell, sarah jessica parker, drew barrymore, diane von furstenberg, and micahel kors, among others.
2087	cnn asked readers for their recommendations on activities in new orleans beyond food and drink after a indulgent mardi gras season. suggestions included visiting the barataria preserve in marrero for a nature walk, taking cooking classes at the new orleans school of cooking to learn cajun and creole dishes, and taking a festive river ride on the steamboat natchez to enjoy live dixieland jazz music. other options included visiting the audubon zoo, the national world war ii museum, and experiencing authentic live music at preservation hall or frenchmen street. all activities offer unique experiences and are open to the public, but some do have admission fees and operating hours.
2088	this report details the secretive ways in which veterans affairs employees have shared information with cnn about the poor treatment of american veterans. meetings took place in clandestine locations, and documents were delivered anonymously to avoid retaliation. employees feared speaking out due to potential career-ending consequences and financial harm. the office of special counsel (osc) announced it is investigating allegations of retaliation against 37 va employees in 19 states. the osc has previously intervened to block disciplinary actions against employees who spoke out about wrongdoing. in the past year, the osc has protected 14 va employees from retaliation for criticizing the agency. several va doctors described instances of patient harm and delays, but were met with harsh treatment when they attempted to report their concerns. employees were warned against speaking to the media, with threats of legal repercussions and financial penalties. the fear of retaliation is so pervasive that sources met with cnn in secret locations and used coded language to communicate. the office of the inspector general conducted an investigation in december 2022, but the issue persisted. doctors and whistleblowers reported a culture of fear within the va and were reluctant to speak out publicly due to potential consequences. despite the fears, one doctor came forward publicly and revealed the existence of a secret list in phoenix that had led to delayed care and the deaths of veterans. the osc is now investigating allegations of attempts to silence whistleblowers within the va. additionally, the senate has reached a deal on a va bill concerning bonuses and wait times.
2089	j.k. rowling, the author of the harry potter series, has acknowledged that she will never surpass the success of her beloved books, which made her a multi-billionaire. in an interview with sky news, she revealed that by 2000, she knew she would never write anything as successful as harry potter again. instead, she chooses to focus on continuing her writing and making a difference through her philanthropic efforts, particularly through her charity lumos, which fights against the institutionalization of children. rowling, who has made an estimated £1billion from her harry potter books and has given millions to charity, lives in edinburgh with her husband, neil murray. she published her latest work, a crime novel under the pseudonym robert galbraith, in april 2023, and revealed herself as the author after sales declined, leading to a surge in sales.
2090	"jackson 5ive" was a 1971 saturday morning cartoon series based on the jackson 5's rise to fame, co-produced by rankin/bass and motown records, and aired on abc. bob balser, the animation director, who had co-directed "yellow submarine," ensured that the show did not include violence or stereotyping, as it was one of the first cartoon representations of a black family. each episode featured two musical numbers by the jackson 5's cartoon counterparts, using hand-drawn animation, and the songs were woven into the plotlines. balser commissioned european studios to create the graphics, believing in giving artists complete freedom to create. the show's production was fast-paced, and balser, who was concerned about not delivering on time, reassured him with a message from chuck jones, who was in charge of children's programming at abc. balser believes hand-drawn animation has a soul and has communicated effectively through stories and ideas, even as animation techniques have changed.
2091	in the ongoing trial of michael jackson's doctor, conrad murray, a cocktail waitress named sade anding testified that murray was on the phone with her around the time jackson stopped breathing on june 25, 2009. their call was suddenly interrupted, and anding couldn't reach him again. prosecutors claim this was because murray had discovered jackson's heart had stopped but didn't call for an ambulance until later. murray's current girlfriend, nicole alvarez, testified that he called her while en route to the hospital with jackson. other girlfriends, including a stripper and his live-in partner, also took the stand, detailing their relationships with murray and his behavior on the day jackson died. murray is charged with involuntary manslaughter for administering jackson a fatal dose of propofol and is on trial for allegedly neglecting jackson's care. the defense argues his girlfriends' phone calls did not distract him from his duties.
2092	a man is being hunted by british transport police after he forcibly entered a closed london victoria tube station, wrenching open the gates with brute strength and disregard for staff orders. the incident was captured on cctv footage, which shows the man shouting and pointing at a station worker before forcefully pulling the gates from the ground, bending them apart, and entering the station. the man was told the station was closed for cleaning but disregarded the instruction. he is wanted for questioning about the incident, which occurred around 2 am on june 20, a few hours after england played uruguay in the world cup. his actions have been compared to the incredible hulk, the strong marvel comics character. anyone with information on the man's identity is urged to contact british transport police.
2093	traci vaillancourt, the long-term girlfriend of timothy walker, who was sentenced to life in prison for murdering police officer derek johnson, has spoken out for the first time since the verdict. in a letter to walker, vaillancourt, 35, forgives him for shooting her in the back but not for taking the life of the officer. they met at the age of 12 and had been together for over 22 years, but vaillancourt described their relationship as a 'mess.' she admitted to loving walker despite the years of physical, mental and emotional abuse and still prays for him. vaillancourt also apologized to the johnson family and eulogized the slain officer, expressing her fear that her daughter, currently living with walker's mother, might reject her. walker faces obstruction of justice charges and pleaded guilty to aggravated murder, attempted murder, and several other charges. johnson, 32, was a married father of one when he was shot during a traffic stop. walker had previously shown signs of erratic behavior, leaving his sister-in-law startled when he displayed weapons and asked for money just hours before the shooting.
2094	a caregiver, jennifer marley, 53, was convicted of stealing over £1,000 from her housebound pensioner, mavis pately, 79, who later died from the stress caused by watching the cctv footage of marley stealing. the incident occurred between september 2012 and january 2013. marley was a trusted carer for six months, and was even asked to become mavis's preferred carer. she was arrested after the family installed cctv cameras in the property and set up an envelope containing fake notes to catch her in the act. marley was acquitted of the theft of two further envelopes containing £1,000 but was found guilty of two counts of theft. mavis's family installed the cameras due to suspicious behavior from marley and had become concerned about her trustworthiness. marley, who had worked for the agency first call since 2003, resigned after her arrest. she was released on bail pending a probation report and could face jail time. the family believes that the shock of discovering that her trusted carer was a thief contributed to mavis's death months later.
2095	an embarrassing mix-up occurred when the australian newspaper, the age, printed a photo of comedian nazeem hussain, who is of sri lankan descent and looks similar to waleed aly, the new co-host of the project. leigh sales, the host of abc's 7.30, was temped to open her show last night by introducing herself as waleed aly. the tweet suggesting this received great popularity, with many commenting on the similarity between the two men and the lack of diversity in tv. hussain himself joked about the resemblance on twitter. aly, who is of egyptian descent, is a frequent commentator on australian muslim affairs and has spoken on the topic on abc's q&a. he will join carrie bickmore and peter helliar on the project's panel next year. the newspaper later corrected the error on their website, but not before it caused a social media stir. aly will be the first muslim to co-host a major prime time television show in australia. hussain is the creator and star of the australian television show 'legally brown' and is also a presenter on triple j radio. aly will begin his new role on the project on january 26.
2096	tom magliozzi, one half of npr's popular "car talk" radio duo with his brother ray, passed away on monday at age 77 due to complications from alzheimer's disease. the brothers, known for their laid-back and humor-filled show, entertained audiences with their insights on car-related queries and uproarious laughter for over two decades. tom's infectious laughter defined the show, which debuted in 1977 on boston radio station wbur and was picked up by npr in 1987. despite retiring from original broadcasts in 2012, archival shows continue to be a top-rated program on the network, with an estimated 4 million listeners. tom and ray's cambridge, massachusetts garage was not only a business, but also the backdrop for their show and personal lives. both graduates of mit, tom left his engineering job to open a do-it-yourself auto repair shop and met his wife. the show inspired television programs and books, as well as a website featuring daily car questions and automotive information. npr is currently airing archival shows in memory of tom.
2097	the fda and interpol announced a crackdown on thousands of online pharmacy websites for selling counterfeit or substandard medications or operating without appropriate safeguards. of the 1,677 sites shut down, 58 people were arrested and over $41 million worth of illegal medicines were seized. several sites had deceptive names and appearance, such as walgreens-store.com instead of walgreens.com. counterfeit drugs can contain no active ingredients or toxic substances and are difficult to detect, leading to potentially serious health risks. experts estimate it's a multibillion dollar industry, and most of these sites are based overseas. consumers should be cautious and ensure the websites ask for a valid prescription and have a licensed pharmacist available for consultation. the fda and customs agencies use scanners to detect suspicious packaging and ingredients, but confirmation of counterfeit ingredients requires laboratory testing. the national association of boards of pharmacy features a list of approved online pharmacies and those to avoid.
2098	pepsico has dropped the use of the term "natural" in some of its product labels, including its frito-lay chips and quaker granola, and instead is using the term "simply." the change came after a number of lawsuits against food and beverage companies for misrepresenting the "natural" labeling of their products, which do contain added color, artificial flavors, or synthetic substances. pepsico agreed to remove "all natural" from its naked juices last year following a lawsuit. the word "simply" also faced controversy in the past as the center for science in the public interest expressed concerns about its use on general mills' "simply fruit" label, which contains oil and juice but not just fruit. pepsico stated that it regularly updates its marketing and packaging, but did not provide further comment on the change. other companies, such as ben & jerry's, breyers, and campbell soup, have also faced lawsuits over "natural" labeling in the past.
2099	health secretary andrew lansley has paved the way for the british government to require tobacco companies to sell cigarettes in plain packaging, aiming to reduce smoking. this follows the recent law requiring shops to hide tobacco products from public view. plain packaging would be the next step in regulating the tobacco industry after bans on tobacco advertising, promotion, and sponsorship. some, including conservative mp mark field and the international chamber of commerce, oppose the plan, warning it could erode intellectual property rights, create a dangerous precedent, and lead to increased smuggling and counterfeit tobacco. opponents also argue it could potentially breach world trade organization rules. the association of convenience stores and pro-smoking group forest have also voiced their opposition. the move comes after evidence showed that cigarette displays in shops can encourage young people to take up smoking. australia approved similar laws last year but three tobacco companies are challenging them in court.
2100	malala yousafzai, the youngest nobel peace prize laureate, survived a gunshot wound to the head inflicted by the taliban in october 2012 for advocating for girls' education in her native swat valley, pakistan. the attempt on her life occurred two years ago and left her critical, yet miraculously alive with no major brain or nerve damage. after undergoing surgeries and extensive rehabilitation in the uk, malala went on to become a global symbol for girls' education, inspiring people around the world and generating widespread outrage against the taliban. the attempted assassination sparked the "i am malala" campaign, which became a day of action for education, a un campaign, a fund for educational initiatives in pakistan, nigeria, kenya, and jordan, and various other accomplishments. despite continued threats from the taliban, malala has continued her activism, focusing on education for girls and advocating for their right to learn. she was previously awarded pakistan's first-ever national peace prize and the sakharov prize for freedom of thought from the european parliament, and she published her autobiography, "i am malala."
2101	new york state police superintendent pedro perez announced his retirement on wednesday, becoming the third high-ranking official to step down in the wake of ethics scandals surrounding governor david paterson. perez denied that his decision was related to the ongoing investigation into the governor, but his resignation comes after his predecessor harry corbitt quit less than a week prior over allegations of misleading the deputy public safety secretary. paterson is under investigation by the new york state commission on public integrity for allegedly accepting free world series tickets, which he denies. the commission also accused paterson of lying under oath about intending to pay for the tickets, and he could face fines for violating the state's gift ban. the governor has abandoned his re-election bid, citing a series of obstacles. the scandals have raised questions about paterson's future in office and speculation about who might replace him.
2102	the duke and duchess of cambridge, prince william and kate middleton, have decided to spend christmas with the middleton family at their home in bucklebury, berkshire. this comes after speculation over whether kate would join the royal family at their annual gathering at sandringham. the couple spent last christmas at sandringham but kate missed the formal gathering due to her severe morning sickness, which forced her to cancel several engagements. kate left the hospital earlier this month after being treated for hyperemesis gravidarum and made her first public appearance last week. the decision to join the middleton family has been taken with the approval of the queen and the duke of edinburgh. kate's siblings, pippa and james, are also expected to attend the festivities. michael middleton, kate's father, is known for wearing fancy dress on christmas day, and prince william will get a humorous insight into family life. prince harry, who is serving as an apache helicopter pilot in afghanistan, won't be attending any festivities but is expected to engage in some christmas cheer by serving dinner to soldiers at the base.
2103	a three-minute video titled "anthropocene" created by canadian anthropologist felix pharand showcases the extent of human presence on earth by overlaying satellite images of cities illuminated at night with data on major road and rail networks, underwater cables, and air traffic routes. pharand used an ordinary home pc and data from various agencies to create an accurate illustration of how one species has "domesticated" the planet. the video highlights the contrast between developed and developing regions and shows how human activities have transformed the earth, covering about 3% of its land surface. according to the un, the earth's population will reach an additional billion people by october 2022 compared to 1999. pharand sought to create realistic renderings of earth using real data, inspired by science-fiction movies. he sees the earth's current global civilization as a legacy of billions of people throughout history, the result of much effort and change. despite the challenges, pharand remains optimistic and encourages awareness of the human impact on the planet.
2104	gavin clark, a 41-year-old primary school caretaker at eaton primary school in norwich, was sentenced to 12 months in jail and put on the sex offenders' register for 10 years after admitting to possessing over 1,700 indecent images of children. the pictures were discovered on clark's computer and personal storage devices in a cupboard where he had been secretly living at the school for an extended period after his marriage collapsed. the most serious images, 491 in total, featured children under 13. clark told police he found the images accidentally, but the court was skeptical of this explanation. he was also fired from his job. the judge acknowledged that clark had not produced or distributed any indecent images and expressed difficulty understanding his reasons for committing the offense. the school, norfolk county council, and norfolk police cooperated to address the situation and prioritize children's safety. clark abused his position of trust by storing the offensive material in a school environment where young children were present, using a cupboard to conceal it. detective constable pippa hinds from norfolk police commented that clark's offending should serve as a warning to others considering similar actions.
2105	seven presidential candidates, including newt gingrich, jon huntsman, mitt romney, rick perry, ron paul, michele bachmann, and rick santorum, each own unique and distinct homes. gingrich's house in mclean, virginia, boasts an extravagant master bathroom with a chandelier, marble floors, and multiple mirrors. huntsman resides in a five-bedroom townhouse in washington d.c., which was previously used on the television show "top chef." romney, the wealthiest candidate, owns the most houses, including a lakefront property in new hampshire and an oceanfront house in california. perry's gated home in austin, texas, features a balcony and is worth around $2 million. paul's ranch house in lake jackson, texas, with a u-shaped design and pool, is on the market. bachmann's house in minnesota, bought for $760,000, was originally listed for $1.75 million, and features a sunroom, breakfast room, and large living room. santorum's traditional 1970s colonial-style house in great falls, virginia, cost him $2 million.
2106	a former first-grade teacher, ann urwiler, 50, and her husband, jon urwiler, 48, from omaha, have been sentenced to 39 days in jail, two years of probation, and fined $1,000 each after pleading guilty to contributing to the delinquency of a minor. the incident occurred in july when police found minors drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana at their papillion home. police were originally called due to illegally parked vehicles. although initial charges of procuring alcohol for a minor were dropped, among the items taken from the home were water pipes, marijuana, and alcohol. ann urwiler resigned from her position as a teacher at trumble park elementary school shortly after the incident. the urwilers will serve their jail time on weekends at the sarpy county jail. their lawyer stated that they have taken "extreme steps" to prevent any future occurrences and are diligent about monitoring their home.
2107	michael jackson's iconic album "bad" is being reissued in a deluxe edition to celebrate its 25th anniversary on september 18. the "bad 25" set includes three cds, a dvd, and two booklets. the dvd features jackson's personal recording of his 1988 wembley stadium concert, which is the first full performance from the bad tour to be commercially released without cuts. a cd with professionally recorded audio from the wembley concert and a remastered version of the original "bad" album are also included. a third cd features unreleased demos and new remixes of material from "bad." a standard edition of the reissue will be available without the wembley performance. (source: rolling stone)
2108	a gay couple was forced off a london bus after the driver launched a homophobic rant and branded them "not real men." jack james, 23, and his partner were traveling home from work when the driver began shouting and swearing at them for kissing. the driver ordered them off the bus and continued the abuse as bystanders watched. this incident follows a similar one at a sainsbury's store in brighton last month, where a lesbian couple was asked to leave after a customer complained about their kiss. transport for london is investigating the bus incident and studying cctv footage. the latest incidents come after a gay couple was refused a room together at a b&b in 2010 due to their sexual orientation, resulting in a £3,600 compensation paid to the couple. all incidents have sparked criticism from gay rights campaigners.
2109	the united nations security council held an emergency meeting on monday after north korea conducted its third nuclear test, defying international condemnation and apologies from its ally china. the test, which was not a complete surprise as north korea had threatened to conduct it if sanctions were not lifted, produced an explosion estimated to be between 10 to 20 kilotons. north korea claimed the test was a successful new level improvement, while the us and other countries denounced it as a breach of international law. analysts suggest north korea conducts nuclear tests to gain diplomatic leverage, but its weapons are not currently a major security threat as it lacks an effective delivery system. with tensions escalating, the other six-party talks participants may consider new punitive measures against north korea.
2110	police in new york city are searching for two armed men who robbed a jewelry store in manhattan's diamond district, just blocks from the veterans day parade. the incident occurred around 2:30 p.m. on tuesday, when the suspects, believed to be carrying automatic weapons, entered the store on the eighth floor of a building on 47th street between 5th and 6th avenues, pistol-whipping the owner and making off with an unspecified amount of cash and jewelry. a large police presence, including swat teams, k9 units, and helicopters, was dispatched to the scene, initially believing the suspects were still inside the building, but they were not found after a floor-by-floor sweep. the suspects are described as two black men, one wearing a long black trench coat, and witnesses reported seeing them wearing masks and carrying large weapons.
2111	five employees of the blue rhino propane gas plant in florida are fighting for their lives in critical condition after a violent explosion at the facility on monday night. the blast, caused by a suspected spark from a forklift, injured eight people and forced the evacuation of residents within a mile radius due to fears of the three massive bulk tanks holding 30,000 pounds of gas each detonating. the plant contained 53,000 small 20-pound propane tanks at the time of the explosion. firefighters are still investigating the cause, with initial reports suggesting a combination of human error and equipment malfunction. the explosion continued for over two hours, with numerous propane tanks exploding one after another. witnesses described the scene as resembling bombs going off, with sounds, bright orange glows, and bursts of light. nearby residents reported hearing and feeling the explosion from up to ten miles away. fire officials are grateful that the larger tanks did not ignite, as their detonation would have resulted in numerous fatalities. the plant was used to refurbish and refill propane tanks for sale, and many of the staff were contractors working on a 10-hour shift. the workers filled around 4,000 to 5,000 tanks during their shift. blue rhino, the company that owns the plant, has relocated its headquarters to north carolina but has been in tavares for seven years. the scene remains active, with an evacuation zone reduced to a half-mile radius as of 1:30 a.m. and a shelter set up for displaced residents.
2112	photographer sergei kokinskiy captured striking images of a large king penguin colony on south george island in the southern atlantic ocean, home to up to 200,000 penguins. the colony includes chicks still going through the molting process, with brown fur patches visible on their bodies. kokinskiy, who has traveled to various extreme locations, was amazed by the sight of the "huge army" of penguins and the individual features that help young ones stand out to their parents. he took photos of chicks waiting for their parents to return with food, with some still sporting thick brown fur. the photographer fell in love with the harsh nature of the extreme north and south and the unique experience of witnessing such a massive penguin colony.
2113	european leaders have decided to end the italian naval operation mare nostrum in the mediterranean sea, which has rescued 150,000 people from drowning since last year but cost italy alone. the new operation, operation triton, run by the eu border agency frontex, will not have a search and rescue function, focusing solely on border control. this decision has been met with criticism, as it is believed that turning a blind eye to people drowning at sea will not deter them from attempting the dangerous journey to europe. the european union is currently facing the greatest refugee crisis since world war ii, with over 50 million people forcedly displaced worldwide. the majority of them will continue seeking safety in europe regardless of search and rescue ops. eu leaders are urged to offer more safe and legal channels for people to access protection instead of increasing barriers. the unhcr calls for european countries to accept more refugees for resettlement and provide them with a chance of a better life. the number of available resettlement places offered by eu countries is insufficient, currently standing at only 5,500 annual places.
2114	roberto di matteo, the new schalke coach, faces his first significant home test against second-place wolfsburg, having won all three home games since taking over. however, schalke's away form has been poor, losing all three matches. the italian is focused on the weekend's game and not the upcoming champions league encounter with his former club chelsea. schalke currently trails wolfsburg by nine points and remains three points behind the top six. borussia dortmund, currently in the bottom half of the table, needs a win against paderborn to avoid dropping further. borussia mönchengladbach seeks to bounce back from their first defeat of the season after hosting eintracht frankfurt. bayern munich continues to lead the bundesliga by seven points, while bayer leverkusen closes the gap to third place with a match against hannover. the relegation battle sees hamburg and werder bremen face off in a derby, while bottom-placed stuttgart hosts augsburg. mainz and cologne, germany's carnival strongholds, have home games against freiburg and hertha berlin.
2115	arsenal have received a boost with the returns of mathieu debuchy and wojciech szczesny to full training, but are concerned about the fitness of kieran gibbs and laurent koscielny for saturday's game against stoke. theo walcott, tomas rosicky (thigh), yaya sanogo (calf), and nacho monreal (ankle) are all ruled out. koscielny, who is suffering from an inflammation of his achilles, could miss the match. arsenal are interested in signing ipswich defender tyrone mings, and hope to have koscielny and gibbs available for selection after assessing their injuries. alexis sanchez scored a late winner against southampton on wednesday, moving arsenal up to sixth in the table. arsenal are also monitoring the progress of several young players, including mings, but have not made any signings yet. walcott is struggling with a groin injury and will have an injection on friday.
2116	in the violent-marred elections in pakistan, former prime minister nawaz sharif's pakistan muslim league-nawaz (pml-n) party is leading with unofficial results showing they won most of the seats in the national assembly, taking 16 out of 23 seats in the lower house. imran khan's tehreek-e-insaf (movement for justice) party won 4 seats, while he claimed the elections were rigged. the us secretary of state congratulated pakistan on the historic transition to a civilian government, while indian prime minister manmohan singh and other world leaders expressed support. despite reports of vote-rigging and election violence, which resulted in 29 deaths and over 50 injuries, voter turnout was nearly 60%. the elections marked the first transition between civilian governments in pakistan's 66-year history, with a significant youth and female participation. amid the celebrations, president asif ali zardari and malala yousafzai, the pakistani schoolgirl stabbed by the taliban for her education advocacy, called on the people to vote for a better future. the elections were marred by reports of vote rigging, leading to threats of boycotts from some political parties and allegations of harassment and securities concerns. eleven people were killed in violent incidents, including bombings in balochistan province and harassment of polling station staff in karachi. despite these challenges, high turnout and record numbers of new voters showed the pakistani people's determination to make their voices heard. the election also saw significant participation of women, with more than twice as many women candidates as in the previous elections. the military, which has ruled pakistan for half its life, was involved in the election process, deploying 91,000 troops around the country. the fractured political landscape has led to a deeply divided nation, with economic, political, and security challenges remaining unaddressed. the pakistani people and international community
2117	hillary clinton is strongly expected to run for president in 2016, with 29 out of 46 democratic senators having already endorsed her plans. a pro-clinton super pac, ready for hillary, has helped secure seventeen of these endorsements from senators including tim kaine and mark warner of virginia, dick durbin of illinois, and barbara boxer of california. female democratic senators have also written a secret letter encouraging clinton to run. before her official announcement, over 60% of democratic senators had endorsed her campaign. some notable endorsers include tammy baldwin of wisconsin, cory booker of new jersey, and barbara mikulski of maryland. however, not all senators have endorsed clinton, with some preferring to wait and see if joe biden runs. senators sherrod brown of ohio, chris coons of delaware, and bernie sanders of vermont, among others, have not yet endorsed. some senators, like harry reid of nevada, have been unclear about their support.
2118	cristiano ronaldo reached a career milestone of 400 goals in real madrid's 3-0 win over celta vigo, but he has never scored in the seventh minute of a professional match. arsenal's theo walcott was ruled out for up to six months with an anterior cruciate ligament injury, while italy's top scorer giuseppe rossi could miss up to three months with a knee injury. kaka scored twice in ac milan's 3-0 win over atalanta, and miroslav klose gave lazio a winning start under new manager edoardo reja. napoli defeated sampdoria with a brace from dries mertens, and verona and parma also posted victories. at the bottom, catania and genoa both won. ronaldo dedicated his goals to portuguese legend eusebio, and carlo ancelotti criticized real's defensive performance.
2119	the snuggle house, a business that offered hugging, cuddling, and spooning services from professional snugglers in madison, wisconsin, closed less than a month after opening due to alleged harassment from city officials. city officials expressed concerns that the business could be a front for prostitution and accused owner matthew hurtado of having no business plan, no insurance, and no training protocols. snugglers argue that touching helps relieve stress, but city attorneys were drafting new regulations. the snuggle house announced on facebook that it had closed for good due to the "push back and harassment." local officials suggested that the business may not have had the anticipated customer base. similar businesses have been successful in other states, but madison seemed to have deeper concerns. the snuggle house offered an hour-long session for $60 and claimed it was a legitimate business, but police in cities where similar businesses operate have reported no complaints. critics argue that the snuggling industry is not legitimate and risks enabling sex work. cuddle parties and cuddling sessions offered by organizations follow strict guidelines, including keeping clothes on and having pre-session workshops on consent and communication.
2120	the strong museum in rochester, new york, is creating a new exhibit, the world video game hall of fame, to recognize the cultural and societal impact of games like "pong" and "grand theft auto." the public can vote online for their favorite games to be considered as initial inductees. anyone can nominate a game, and an internal advisory committee will choose finalists. selection will be based on four criteria: icon-status, longevity, geographical reach, and influence on design, entertainment, popular culture, and society. electronic games have changed the way people play, learn, and connect, and the new hall will be dedicated to arcade, console, computer, hand-held, and mobile games. don daglow, video game designer since the 1970s, expressed his support for the initiative. the strong's international center for the history of electronic games, with over 55,000 video games and related artifacts, is uniquely qualified to create this hall of fame. nominations for the inaugural class are open until the end of march.
2121	experts recommend incorporating sudoku and crosswords into schools to enhance children's brain power, boost memory, improve verbal fluency, and expand vocabulary. the university of cambridge conducted an extensive review, "puzzles in education," which found that while 75% of teachers use puzzles in their lessons, they are primarily viewed as engagement tools rather than academic benefits. puzzles, such as sudoku and word games, were discovered to support abstract reasoning, memorizing data, and terminology and vocabulary learning. sudoku is particularly effective in teaching math and science concepts through adaptation, such as using chemical symbols instead of numbers. with increasing tablet use among toddlers, internet safety education is necessary in pre-schools. word searches are recommended for learning specific topics, and crosswords aid verbal fluency, memory, and problem-solving skills. overall, puzzles align with the national curriculum. kath donovan, director of primary at pearson, emphasized the importance and underutilization of puzzles in education.
2122	researchers led by psychologist oriana aragon at yale university suggest that crying during happy experiences, such as weddings or reunions, is not an incorrect response but rather a way to restore emotional equilibrium. this response helps individuals manage intense positive emotions and recover more quickly. the study presents various examples of this phenomenon and suggests that there may be benefits to expressing negative emotions in response to positive experiences. these findings offer new insights into how people express and control their emotions and could contribute to a better understanding of mental health, relationships, and teamwork.
2123	ronny deila, the celtic manager, felt as if he had woken from a nightmare after a 6-1 aggregate loss to legia warsaw in the champions league, costing the club a potential £15million windfall. days later, in slovenia preparing for a play-off against maribor, deila admitted he was tired and probably overwhelmed at the time but learned quickly and now feels confident. celts, who have been in strong form domestically, aim to take full advantage of the champions league lifeline, with improved preparation and a better understanding of his team. he acknowledged making mistakes in warsaw but is more confident this time around, despite maribor's recent successes against scottish opponents. deila acknowledged injuries to james forrest and adam matthews, and challenges in adapting international players to european competition. however, he expressed optimism in the squad's ability to perform and secure a positive result in the first leg against maribor.
2124	levante have warned atletico madrid that they must meet the £8 million buy-out clause if they want to sign costa rica goalkeeper keylor navas, who has impressive performances at the world cup. navas saved a crucial penalty against greece and conceded just twice in the tournament as costa rica reached the quarter-finals. atletico have reportedly offered £5 million plus brazilian striker leo baptistao for navas, but levante insists on the full buy-out fee. levante president quico catalan stated that the release clause is €10 million, and atletico's offer falls short. navas gave no hint of his future intentions during the world cup and is focused on the tournament.
2125	mackenzie phillips' revelation of her alleged incestuous relationship with her father, john phillips, has resulted in a strong reaction from her family. chynna phillips doesn't believe mackenzie's story and has found it difficult, but recognizes the importance of the dialogue started. bijou phillips is hurt and confused, as she was told about the incest when she was young but later denied it. michelle phillips, a former wife of john's, and genevieve waite, who married him in 1972, have vehemently denied mackenzie's accusations, with michelle calling it a "difficult and unfortunate circumstance." the family members expressed love and support for one another amidst the controversy, and mackenzie's memoir, "high on arrival," has gathered letters and messages of gratitude from incest survivors.
2126	a study conducted by ofcom, the communications watchdog, found that children as young as six have a better understanding of modern technology than most 45-year-olds. the millennium generation, born between 2000 and 2001, is shaping the future of media and digital communications due to their early exposure to technology. young adults spend over three and a half hours on their smartphones every day, compared to the national average. primary school children are more confident in using the latest devices than their parents. older generations are still learning to use email, while teenagers prefer impersonal forms of communication. ofcom also found that nearly half of adults check their work emails out of office hours due to the spread of smartphones and broadband internet. while children and teenagers are the most digitally savvy, all age groups are benefiting from new technology. however, some people believe the younger generation's reliance on technology may signal the demise of traditional phone calls and other forms of personal communication.
2127	a new study funded by the medical research council (mrc) in the uk found that while more premature babies born at 24, 25, and 26 weeks are surviving, the chances of survival for babies born before 24 weeks remain rare. the study compared babies born between 22-26 weeks in 2006 with those born between 22-25 weeks in 1995. over the 11-year period, the overall survival rate increased by 13%, from 40 to 53%, but there was no significant improvement in the survival of babies born before 24 weeks. the study also found that the number of babies born between 22 and 25 weeks and admitted to intensive care units increased by 44%. the vast majority of babies born before 27 weeks still face significant health issues and many go on to live with long-term health problems such as cerebral palsy, learning difficulties, and lung conditions. the authors of the study emphasized that ethical guidelines in the uk do not suggest providing active care for babies born at 22 weeks six days and earlier, as the survival rate is small to nonexistent. the study also noted that as the number of premature births rises, so will the demand for healthcare, education, and social services to support survivors with disabilities. uk government officials have called for a reduction in the current legal limit for abortion, which is at 24 weeks, citing medical advances as justification. however, the authors of the study argue that the focus should be on preventing premature birth in the first place.
2128	maria kang, a california mother of three with an extremely toned body, faced backlash after posting a provocative photo on facebook with the caption "what's your excuse?" surrounded by her sons. the post went viral, receiving over 16 million views and 12,000 comments, most of which were positive. however, some women criticized kang for being a "showoff," "bully," and even a "bad mother." kang's intention was to inspire and motivate people to get healthy and take care of themselves despite the challenges of raising children. her crusade is personal: she saw her mother's health issues and wants to set a different example for her children. despite the criticism, kang believes she is being a good mother and is not backing down. the episode highlights the competitive nature of mothering and the coarsening of public dialogue, with many forgetting their grandma's advice to only say nice things about others.
2129	two new jersey teenagers, matt molinari and eric schnepf, were stopped by police for attempting to make extra money by shoveling driveways during the travel curfew imposed due to storm juno. they were reported as suspicious by a neighbor and ordered to go back inside, unaware of the travel ban. the state of emergency was lifted the next day, allowing them to resume their snow shoveling business. there was no restriction on shoveling services during the ban, as stated by the local police chief, michael jannone. the incident sparked controversy on social media, with some falsely claiming that permits were required for shoveling driveways.
2130	alberto contador, a two-time tour de france champion, crashed and withdrew from this year's race during the 10th stage after falling on the descent of petit ballon. he sustained injuries to his right knee and was unable to keep up with the main peloton despite team efforts to help him regain position. contador, who previous won the tour in 2007 and 2009, was in ninth place before the crash, four minutes and eight seconds behind leader tony gallopin. vincenzo nibali took the stage win and the yellow jersey after overtaking joaquim rodriguez in the final kilometer. thibaut pinot finished second on the stage, while alejandro valverde took third place, moving up to third overall. chris froome, last year's winner, also withdrew from the race due to injuries sustained in previous falls. nibali now leads the standings, with valverde and porte in second and third place, respectively.
2131	andy powell, a former wales international rugby player, started the year on a life-changing note with the birth of his first child, henry, on new year's day. this came after a tumultuous year where his wife, natasha, accused him of cheating and sold his belongings on ebay. the couple had separated, but reconciled after natasha fell pregnant, and they are now delighted with the birth of their son. natasha had previously sold powell's wedding suit, rugby memorabilia, and even intimate letters during their public split. powell has played rugby at the highest level and has been capped 23 times for wales. he currently plays for newport gwent dragons in the guinness pro12. despite the challenges, the couple is back on track and is happy with the new addition to their family.
2132	scientists have identified a protein called periostin, which plays a major role in tumor spread and could lead to new cancer treatments. they found that without this protein, cancer stem cells cannot initiate metastasis and instead disappear or remain dormant. periostin naturally exists in the extracellular matrix and has been shown to play a role in fetal development. in adults, it is only active in specific parts of the body such as the mammary glands, bones, skin, and intestine. the scientists showed that mice bred to lack periostin avoided metastatic cancer and developed an antibody that attaches to the protein, rendering it dysfunctional. while the treatment had few side effects in mice, there is caution about applying the same method to humans as it is not clear if an equivalent antibody will work in humans or whether the side effects will be the same. most cancer deaths are caused by metastatic spread to vital organs such as the liver or brain.
2133	the bank of england is expected to raise interest rates and introduce a cap on mortgage lending in the coming months due to rising concerns about the housing market. the new powers will allow the bank to limit the proportion of high loan-to-income mortgages each bank can lend or even ban all new lending above a specific loan-to-income ratio. the cap is believed to be around three to three-and-a-half times the borrower's salary. chancellor george osborne insists there is no immediate threat to financial stability from the housing market but acknowledged potential concerns for the future. banks have been criticized for offering mortgages worth up to five times borrowers' salaries, which would make homes unaffordable for many if a similar cap were implemented. the government aims to build 200,000 homes per year and force councils to pre-approve planning permissions on brownfield sites, while senior bank executives are discussing potential action to control the housing market. options under consideration include requiring larger deposits, restricting high loans, and longer-term mortgages. business secretary vince cable expressed concern over high mortgage offers and advocated for a more stable level of three to three-and-a-half times borrowers' salaries. approximately 3.4 million mortgage holders, or around 38% of the total, have mortgages worth more than three times their net household income.
2134	ten-year-old michael joseph delvecchio, who went missing from his orlando, florida home on sunday afternoon, was found safe on monday morning. he was spotted near a publix on orange blossom trail by a motorist who recognized him from news bulletins. the motorist contacted the police, and mickey was reunited with his family. authorities had conducted a search for him using deputies, a bloodhound, and a helicopter after he was reported missing, expressing concern for his well-being due to his age. he was last seen wearing athletic clothing and carrying a black and blue scooby doo backpack.
2135	sandra samuel, a daring indian nanny, saved the life of 2-year-old moshe holtzberg during last week's terror attacks in mumbai that killed nearly 180 people, including moshe's parents, rabbi gavriel and rivka holtzberg, and four others. amid the chaos, samuel came face to face with a gunman but managed to escape with moshe, hiding in a storage room and making it to safety at the home of an israeli consul before arriving in israel. moshe, who is being cared for by the chabad movement, asks for his mother frequently and still suffers nightmares, but samuel, a non-jewish native of india, plans to stay in israel to care for him for as long as he needs her. samuel sees no heroism in her actions and only wishes she could have done more to save moshe's parents.
2136	bailee madison, the youth spokesperson for alex's lemonade stand foundation, shares her heartfelt connection to the organization. founded by alex scott, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma at a young age, alex's lemonade stand aimed to raise money for pediatric cancer research. at age 4, alex held her first lemonade stand and eventually raised over $1 million before passing away at the age of 8 in 2004. inspired by alex's story, bailee emphasizes the importance of making a difference at any age. the foundation has since grown, raising over $80 million for research and providing assistance to families in need. bailee recently joined the annual "original" lemonade stand in philadelphia and held her own in fort lauderdale, inspiring her community to come together and support the cause. together, every dollar raised brings hope for finding a cure for pediatric cancer.
2137	chelsea clinton's interest in africa was sparked at the age of 10, when she watched nelson mandela's release from prison with her parents at the arkansas governor's mansion. today, she is involved in various projects through the clinton foundation to help historically disadvantaged people in africa realize their potential. her experiences traveling with her mother, former secretary of state hillary clinton, and encounters with girls in other countries, led her to question how she could make a difference in the world. the clinton foundation's initiatives focus on health care, economic empowerment, climate change and other issues, with over $27.8 billion in commitments from members of the clinton global initiative, which facilitates projects to bring together philanthropists, corporations and others to make a positive impact. chelsea clinton's nine-day, six-stop trip to africa this week includes visits to malawi, zambia, tanzania, zanzibar, rwanda and south africa, where they will meet with leaders and tour foundation sites, with a focus on improving health care and economic opportunities.
2138	connecticut governor dannel malloy signed a bill into law on wednesday, abolishing the death penalty and making it the 17th state to abolish capital punishment. the law, effective immediately, replaces the death penalty with life in prison without parole as the state's highest form of punishment. malloy cited the unworkability of connecticut's death penalty law, which had only resulted in the execution of two individuals since the 1960s, as a reason for the repeal. the repeal comes five years after similar attempts were blocked, and opponents argue that capital punishment acts as a criminal deterrent and offers justice for victims and their families. the bill passed the house of representatives with a vote of 86 to 63 and the senate a week prior. california voters will decide on the issue in november.
2139	ukrainian political candidate olga lyulchak, 30, claims she is a victim of an icloud hack after naked pictures of her leaked online. she dismisses criticism of her raunchy images, comparing them to fine art. ms. lyulchak, a candidate for the ukrainian democratic alliance for reform (udar) party, has faced controversy but remains unashamed. she argues against demonizing women for appearing naked in photographs and compares her images to works of artists like van gogh and titian. ms. lyulchak's elections will be held on october 26, and udar is led by vitali klitschko, whose brother's fiancée, hayden panettiere, is also believed to be an icloud hacking victim.
2140	in a five-week operation dubbed "caireen," new york city area authorities arrested 71 individuals, including a police officer, paramedic, rabbi, nurse, and boy scout leader, on charges related to the anonymous trading of child porn over the internet. this is one of the largest local roundups of its kind, according to officials. the investigation netted nearly 600 seized digital devices with a total storage capacity of 175 terabytes. the national center for missing and exploited children will review the images to identify potential victims. some of the suspects were suspected of having access to children, but there were no reports of abuse. the operation was prompted by the arrest of a former police chief on similar charges.
2141	kenyan-born british rider chris froome won the seventh stage of the tour de france on saturday, while teammate bradley wiggins took over the yellow jersey. froome, known for his climbing skills, showed his strength with a two-second victory over defending champion cadel evans. wiggins replaced fabian cancellara as race leader, with evans in second place, ten seconds behind, and vincenzo nibali of italy in third. froome will support wiggins in his bid to be the first british rider to win the tour. sunday's stage features seven categorized climbs, and monday's time trial is expected to determine the overall winner. several riders pulled out before the start of saturday's leg due to injuries from friday's mass crash.
2142	reuben santiago, interim police chief of columbia, south carolina, faced backlash after threating a man who criticized the police department for focusing too much on minor drug offenses on facebook. santiago posted a response accusing the man of potentially being a criminal and "gave us reasonable suspicion to believe you might be a criminal," adding they would "work on finding you." the post was deleted but caused chaos and anger, with many calling it an unnecessary threat. santiago later admitted to writing the post himself and claimed he was only trying to warn potential criminals, but his statement only fueled more controversy. the incident stemmed from a police department post highlighting a drug seizure and arrest in a local district, to which a resident suggested the police focus on more serious crimes instead.
2143	hundreds of militants attacked a joint american-afghan outpost in eastern afghanistan on saturday, resulting in the deaths of at least eight american troops and two afghan national security force members. this is the largest number of american fatalities from hostile action in over a year, according to cnn records. the militants used rockets, mortars, and heavy-caliber machine guns, and firing positions in the mountains made it difficult for u.s. troops to fight back effectively due to the terrain and weather conditions. both american and afghan forces repelled the attack and inflicted "heavy enemy casualties." preliminary reports suggest that at least 13 afghan police officers were captured, and portions of the outpost burned down. the military is investigating the incident and withholding the identities of the deceased until their families are notified. the u.s. military had planned to leave the post prior to the attack, and the focus is now on protecting afghan civilians rather than holding remote outposts. the last time american troops suffered similar casualties was in the wanat attack in 2008, but the pentagon is still investigating the causes of that incident, including the failure of intelligence.
2144	a tourism chief in torquay, england, expressed her disappointment andconcern over the return of mark jenkins, the real-life inspiration for the basil fawlty character in the classic comedy series "the hotel," for a fourth series this summer. the show, which previously depicted jenkins' eccentric leadership of the grosvenor hotel, has been criticized for portraying torquay's hotel standards in an unbalanced way. jenkins will now star as an entertainments manager at the cavendish hotel, and while the owners are keeping quiet about the deal, they believe it will bring good publicity to the area. however, carolyn custerson, the chairman of visitdevon, has expressed her opposition to the negative portrayal of torquay's hotels and believes that all publicity is not good publicity. john cleese, the co-writer of "fawlty towers," based the character of basil fawlty on donald sinclair, a former owner of the gleneagles hotel in torquay, who was known for his rude behavior.
2145	guide dogs for the blind association has expressed concern among its members about the increasing number of incidents involving collisions or near-misses with cyclists in london. in a survey of 33 guide dog owners in the city, approximately half reported being involved in a crash with a cyclist, and three-quarters had experienced a near-miss. the main causes were identified as cyclists disregarding red lights at pedestrian crossings and riding on the pavement. the charity, working with transport for london and the london cycling campaign, has launched the cycleyes campaign, urging cyclists to be aware of blind and partially sighted pedestrians and maintain a duty of care. the campaign also advises cyclists to use bells or call out when approaching guide dogs on the sidewalk and to dismount and walk their bikes when necessary. transport for london supports the campaign, committing to enhancing pedestrian crossings with tactile paving and audible signals. the survey findings were gathered from 33 of 320 guide dog owners in london, where over 41,000 people are registered blind or partially sighted. of those surveyed, 14 reported involvement in collisions and 25 in near-misses. mayor of london boris johnson has pledged nearly £913 million to a 'cycling revolution' in the city.
2146	chelsea suffered a contentious decision during their match against southampton when referee anthony taylor denied a clear penalty call against southampton's matt targett for tripping cesc fabregas, while also booking fabregas for diving. this came after previous controversy involving chelsea players branislav ivanovic and diego costa being cautioned for simulation against hull and west ham, respectively. the referees have regular meetings to prepare for assignments, but prejudgment is not acceptable. chelsea, currently the league leaders, have been criticized for simulating offenses and need to acknowledge their contribution to the issue. previously, ivanovic was involved in a simulation controversy against west ham, which contributed to the referee's perception during the southampton match.
2147	barbara walters, a veteran broadcaster, opened up about her experiences with sexism early in her career. in the 1970s, her male co-host refused to do joint interviews with her unless he could ask the first three questions. walters advised women to "just do your job, get in early, stay late, and don't complain." she faced challenges such as being asked to wear a swimsuit on air when a model failed to appear and having to settle for asking only the fourth question in interviews. walters shares that her friendly demeanor when interviewing guests, like senator hillary clinton, has helped her ask probing questions throughout her career. throughout her 50-year career, she interviewed a range of guests from dr. jack kevorkian to elmo, and her interview with monica lewinsky in 1999 remains her highest-rated interview of all time. despite facing sexism in her industry, walters remained focused on her job and made an impact by opening doors for women in journalism and interviewing subjects that were often reserved for men. walters' friendly approach and dedication to preparation have been the secrets to her successful interviews.
2148	designer katharina unger aims to make eating insects more appealing and sustainable by inventing a solar-powered appliance, named farm 432: insect breeding, that incubates black soldier flies for human consumption. the device conceals the process of insect farming, producing 2.4 kilograms of nutritious fly larvae over 18 days, and uses design language from consumer products to familiarize people with the concept. unger overcame the initial disgust and researched various edible insects through taste tests to design an appliance where users never have to touch the insects. with growing awareness of entomophagy, she aims to create a community around this concept, develop recipes, and create buzz by presenting insects as a live food source. the goal is to reduce the need for expanding livestock cultivation and double protein production as the world population approaches nine billion by 2050.
2149	the lumbia belt is a new device aimed at addressing lower back pain, or lumbago, which affects 80% of people at some point in their lives. the belt uses a vibrating mechanism to remind users to sit up straight and correct poor posture. a sensor in the belt detects slouching and transmits data to a computer for analysis by a therapist. the technology, which may be available in 2014, is hoped to prevent the need for surgery and help manage the £12 billion annual cost of back pain in the uk. physiotherapist sammy margo recommends maintaining good posture by interlinking fingers behind the back to open the chest and keep shoulders back. poor posture can lead to back pain by causing certain muscles to work too hard and others to weaken.
2150	pope francis, in a personal message ahead of eid al-fitr, the muslim holiday marking the end of ramadan, called for mutual respect between religions, particularly between muslims and christians. he signed the message himself, expressing esteem and friendship for muslims and proposing the theme of promoting mutual respect through education. francis stressed the importance of respecting the life, dignity, and rights of every person. in march, he had emphasized the need for dialogue and cooperation between christians and muslims during a speech to the vatican diplomatic corps. previously, his predecessor, pope benedict xvi, upset the muslim world by quoting a 14th-century byzantine emperor's criticisms of islam. francis' message, which was sent out in multiple languages, including arabic, omitted any mention of women's rights or gender equality.
2151	a muslim cleric, identified as ae due to an anonymity order, is demanding £50,000 compensation from the home office after being placed under house arrest over suspected links to al-qaeda. the control order, imposed in 2006 after mi5 alleged his extremist and criminal contacts in the uk, was quashed by the high court due to the security services' refusal to reveal additional evidence. mi5 also claimed ae had visited extremist websites and was involved in identity fraud. ae's lawyer, mohammed ayub, stated his client could not receive a fair trial without the disclosed evidence and is currently negotiating compensation. the home office declined to comment on the individual case.
