2152	new york's metropolitan transportation authority (mta) discussed the potential installation of platform doors in the subway system to prevent train fatalities during a recent committee meeting. two incidents last year involved people being pushed onto the tracks and killed. however, the installation would face significant challenges due to the age and diversity of the 468 subway stations and the need for major modifications to their structures and electrical systems. the cost and complexity of the project were also concerns, as well as alignment and communication issues. the mta is investigating alternatives like intrusion-detection technology and exploring historical and landmark station approvals. manhattan borough president scott stringer has called for a comprehensive approach to subway safety, including investigating new safety programs.
2153	"the age atomic" by adam christopher is a science fiction and fantasy novel that defies traditional genre classifications. set in new york city and its alternate version, the empire state, the story follows private investigator rad bradley as he tries to save his world by rebooting the fissure connecting the two universes and preventing a transdimensional invasion of killer robots. the novel blends elements of pulp fiction, detective novel, superhero story, and science fiction and fantasy. christopher, inspired by his love for "doctor who" and various authors like stephen king and robert mccammon, writes with a unique flair that combines science fiction and fantasy elements in a place-centric story. with a sequel to "the age atomic" in the works and several other projects in development, the author continues to push the boundaries of genre fiction.
2154	in the europa league last 32 decider between tottenham and fiorentina, roberto soldado missed a golden opportunity to open the scoring for spurs when he hesitated between passing to nacer chadli or shooting. mauricio pochettino, the spurs manager, chose to rest some players for the upcoming capital one cup final against chelsea and faced criticism for his team selection. harry kane, tottenham's leading scorer, was among those left out, with emmanuel adebayor also absent. despite a weakened side, tottenham needed to score to keep their european dreams alive. pochettino defended his decision, acknowledging that winning the final on sunday would vindicate him, while a loss would label him as a bad manager. the focus now shifts to the cup final, where spurs will aim to grind chelsea into submission with their top players.
2155	leaders from france, germany, ukraine, and russia converged in minsk, belarus, for peace talks aimed at ending the violence and bitter divisions in ukraine. the stakes are high as the conflict in eastern ukraine, where pro-russian rebels have declared independence, has claimed over 5,000 lives, many of them civilians, and threatened regional stability. the main points of negotiations include the withdrawal of heavy weapons, the creation of a demilitarized zone, and the future status of the donbas area. however, past ceasefires have failed to last. the discussions come amid escalating violence, with both sides accusing each other of shelling civilian areas and disregard for previous peace agreements. the eu announced additional sanctions against russian and separatist interests but delayed their implementation to give diplomatic efforts a chance. the outcome of the summit is uncertain, with previous peace deals failing to halt the violence.
2156	lebron james made his return to the cleveland cavaliers in the first half of a preseason game against maccabi tel aviv, scoring 12 points before sitting out with knee and back issues. fans were happy to see him back, but attention shifted to his receding hairline on social media. the cavaliers comfortably beat maccabi without james, prompting some users to question his importance to the team. coach david blatt, who previously coached maccabi in the euroleague, expressed mixed emotions about the matchup. james will have until saturday to rest before facing his former team, the miami heat, in a preseason game in rio de janeiro. the cavaliers' regular season opener is at home against the new york knicks on october 30.
2157	in this month's quest special, "man's best friend: a modern insight into our enduring bond with dogs," singer joss stone and actor richard gere are among those celebrating the special connection between humans and dogs. the show takes viewers from the pampered pooches of los angeles, where humans cater to their every need, to the new leash on life dog rescue center, where less fortunate dogs await adoption. actress allison janney and quest help a rescued pit bull/boxer mix named belle find a new home, while joss stone shares her love for her own canine companions. the program also explores the work of dog trainers and animal agencies like american humane, and highlights the important roles dogs play in society, such as serving as therapy animals and search and rescue dogs. don't miss this heartwarming and entertaining exploration of man's best friend. email this link to a friend who loves dogs! 2158	santa and mrs. claus made an early visit to the yup'ik eskimo village of kwethluk, alaska, thanks to the alaska national guard's operation santa claus. due to a mechanical issue, volunteers and gifts initially meant for bethel were transported to kwethluk instead, reaching nearly 300 students. the visit brought excitement to the community, with volunteers adapting and overcoming challenges, including harsh weather and limited resources, to ensure the children received gifts and a memorable christmas experience. the annual program, which visits several remote alaska native villages each year, aims to bring joy and laughter to the children and families.
2159	the btk (bind, torture, kill) serial killer, identified as dennis rader, aged 69, who is currently serving 10 consecutive life sentences for murdered victims in wichita, kansas between 1974 and 1991, is reportedly writing a book about his criminal mind. rader communicated this in a handwritten letter to the university of pennsylvania professor, aiming to help the victims' families financially through the book. he cannot profit from the book directly due to legal agreements. the book is not meant to be sensationalist and will reportedly provide insights into the criminal mind. rader's daughter, kerri rawson, previously condemned stephen king for exploiting her father's crimes through his new film, "a good marriage," which was allegedly inspired by rader's case. rader expressed regret over his daughter's upset and acknowledged keeping his crimes a secret from his family.
2160	the united states believes iran is ready to make a quick deal to limit its nuclear program in exchange for relief from international sanctions that have devastated its economy, according to a senior u.s. administration official. the negotiations, involving the five permanent members of the un security council, germany, and iran, are scheduled to begin on thursday and friday in geneva. the u.s. aims for a two-phase deal with iran, requiring it to take actions regarding its nuclear program first, such as halting all uranium enrichment activities and shipping stockpiles abroad. in return, iran would receive limited sanctions relief. the senior official stated that iran's new willingness to compromise can be attributed to the severity of economic sanctions that have impacted its oil output, banking sector, and currency exchange. despite differences between the parties, the official expressed optimism about reaching a deal while acknowledging the significant gaps that must be bridged. the iaea estimates iran has enriched around 10 metric tonnes of uranium to 5% purity and 185 kilograms of uranium to 20% purity, with some of that further processed for medical and research purposes. weapons experts suggest iran could enrich enough uranium for a single nuclear bomb within months to over a year, but iran maintains its nuclear program is purely for peaceful, civilian use. the senior official acknowledged that all the negotiating nations possess nuclear weapons except iran. the tourist industry in iran has seen a boom, leading the country to relax visa requirements.
2161	a 16th century scottish castle with a one-acre garden and three bedrooms is on the market for £375,000, making it the cheapest castle listed by estate agency knight frank.this price is £25,000 less than the cost of a parking space in some posh areas of west london. kilmartin castle, located in argyll, offers easy access to outdoor activities such as trout fishing, deer stalking, shooting, sailing, and golf. the current owners, an elderly couple who use it as a second home, bought it as a ruin and restored it in the 1980s. the castle has been priced competitively to attract a new owner or rental income as a holiday let. knight frank noted that scottish castles typically sell for between £5million and £6million, but affordable options like kilmartin are rare. meanwhile, in kensington, a parking space can cost £400,000, making the scottish castle an attractive alternative for those looking for unique investment opportunities or a dream home.
2162	sir alex ferguson, in updated chapters of his autobiography, defends david moyes' tenure at manchester united and refutes suggestions that he left behind an aging team and an 'antiquated' club. ferguson insists moyes found it a 'massive jump' from goodison park to old trafford and was unable to live up to ferguson's high standards. he also reveals that he was not involved in moyes' appointment or sacking. moyes faced criticism for introducing a slow tempo of play and united suffered several poor results under him, including defeats by liverpool and manchester city. ferguson, who retired from management in 2013, dismisses claims that united was an outdated setup and criticizes suggestions that he exerted too much influence after his retirement. he also reveals that he tried to persuade moyes to keep mike phelan as assistant manager but was unsuccessful. moyes was sacked in april 2014, and ferguson learned of his dismissal from a newspaper report while flying back to manchester. ferguson won 13 premier league titles, five fa cups, and two european cups during his 26-and-a-half-year tenure at united, which ended with his retirement in 2013.
2163	nick clegg, the deputy prime minister, has blocked proposed tory childcare reforms that would have allowed nurseries and childminders to care for more children,claiming there is no evidence they would reduce costs for parents. the row deepened as clegg dismissed a study suggesting cost savings and claimed the response from parent groups was overwhelmingly negative. tory mps criticized clegg for ignoring the plight of parents with high childcare bills, and his decision was described as a major setback for childcare minister elizabeth truss and education secretary michael gove. the final childcare package has not been agreed upon in the coalition.
2164	rob stutzman, a public affairs consultant from sacramento, california, and a chef named jonathan wheeler have filed a class-action lawsuit against lance armstrong and his publishers for selling them fiction as fact in armstrong's books "it's not about the bike" and "every second counts." the lawsuit accuses armstrong and the publishers of fraud and false advertising, as armstrong repeatedly denied using banned substances in these books. stutzman, who met armstrong years before the confession, recommended the book to friends and even thanked armstrong upon meeting him. the lawsuit does not specify the amount sought but asks for damages, attorneys' fees, expenses, and costs. armstrong's confession of doping could lead to more litigation, and several people have already sued or expressed plans to do so.
2165	bali tourism operators are trying to encourage australian tourists to explore other parts of indonesia instead of just visiting bali, as concerns grow over the island's saturation and environmental stress. nyoman sukma arida from udayana university has been warning of tourist overpopulation in bali for a decade and thinks the island should be used as a hub to distribute tourists to other destinations in indonesia. i ketut ardana from the association of indonesian tour and travel agencies agrees that promoting other indonesian tourist destinations in bali is important, as australian tourists typically stay longer and have limited knowledge of other options. the push comes as a documentary series featuring a self-confessed gigolo's antics in bali sparks outrage in australia.
2166	at the australian reptile park in new south wales, a koala named maddie was surprised to find herself caring for three babies instead of one. two wandering joeys, milly and molly, had attached themselves to maddie, who didn't question her new role and continued to care for all three. despite the shock to the marsupial keepers, maddie showed equal affection to all three and provided them with group hugs. the birth of the four koalas this year at the park is welcome news, as land clearing has been impacting their numbers.
2167	a landmark decision has been made to allow television broadcasts of court proceedings in england and wales for the first time since 1925. this comes after outrage over lenient sentences, such as that given to sex attacker stuart hall, and the upcoming broadcast of a documentary capturing an entire murder trial. the case of nat fraser, convicted of murdering his wife, was filmed for channel 4's "murder trial" documentary. the opening of courts to cameras has sparked debate, with judges having the final say on which cases can be broadcast. high-profile trials involving celebrities and child murderers are likely to be prioritized. the move was initiated by prime minister david cameron and justice secretary chris grayling to increase transparency and accountability in the court system. some legal experts have expressed concerns that broadcasting trials could potentially harm the justice process.
2168	manchester united teammates juan mata and ander herrera competed against each other in a crossbar challenge designed to determine which player is better at hitting the crossbar from 18 yards. the video, posted by f2 freestylers, revealed a close contest between the midfielders, with each player joking and bantering during the challenge. ander herrera led for most of the competition but lost the lead when juan mata scored to level the scores at 2-2. the pair struggled to find a winner and the competition was taken to a sudden-death shootout. mata won the contest, leaving herrera to keep training despite his teammate's jesting. both players have impressed on the pitch for manchester united, with mata signed for £37 million and herrera for £29 million.
2169	a man named barry "junior" eaton allegedly used his acquaintance with footballer ashley cole to lure two jewellers to a hotel under the false pretense of selling them diamonds and watches. the jewellers, dean magri and christopher agathocleous, arrived at the verta hotel in battersea, london, but cole did not show up. instead, eaton and his friend raphael francis allegedly robbed the men outside, wearing balaclavas and wielding a fake gun. eaton had contacted cole's "gatekeeper" mohammed ayub about the jewellery, but ayub denied arranging any meeting or seeing pictures of the jewellery. the trial, which is expected to last a week, continues with eaton and francis both denying two counts of robbery and one count of having an imitation firearm. magri, who worked at farringdon's jewellers, and agathocleous, who is a friend of eaton and had no shop but loaned the items he brought from other jewelers, were also present at the scene. the jewellery and watches worth over £120,000 were stolen, but only some items were recovered.
2170	koichi wakata, oleg kotov, mike hopkins, mikhail tyurin, rick mastracchio, and sergey ryazansky are the current inhabitants of the international space station (iss), living and conducting research there continuously for over 13 years. the iss is a collaboration between five space agencies and is the size of a football field, orbiting earth every 90 minutes at a speed of 17,500 miles per hour. the public's interest has waned since the era of mercury, gemini, and apollo, with the routine nature of shuttle flights and the long occupation of the iss contributing to lackluster attention. recently, the iss has been in the news due to extended funding and delayed christmas gifts for the astronauts. private companies are now contracted to deliver supplies, and there are plans for privately-owned "space taxis" for astronaut transportation. astronaut mastracchio has a following of 36,300 on twitter, paling in comparison to celebrities like justin bieber, lebron james, and katy perry. despite its scientific significance and the remarkable accomplishment of the astronauts, the iss has faced challenges in attracting public attention.
2171	pharrell williams, singer, rapper, and producer, became emotional during an interview with oprah winfrey on her "oprah prime" show about his global hit "happy." the song gained massive popularity after the release of its music video in november 2013, with fans creating their own videos and sharing what "happy" meant to them. williams was touched by the outpouring of love and appreciation, expressing his gratitude for the support he's received throughout his career. oprah also shared her thoughts on the song's infectious nature, attributing its success to its authentic and uninterrupted flow of positive energy. both williams and winfrey were moved to tears by the song's widespread impact.
2172	the badger cull in england last year cost taxpayers over £3,300 per badger, with a total cost of £6.3 million to kill 1,879 badgers in somerset and gloucestershire. the government spent around £2.6 million on monitoring humane methods and £2.3 million on efficiency. the cost was higher due to rigorous safety rules and the extension of the cull after marksmen missed their targets. the badger trust had previously challenged the cull in court. the government argues that the cost is necessary to protect farms from tuberculosis in cattle, which poses a significant threat to the farming industry and food security in england. a second cull has been approved for this year, and the government has spent over £500 million on dealing with tuberculosis in the last decade. labor criticized the cost of the cull, stating little effect was achieved.
2173	a man in his 40s from kansas is being tested for ebola at the university of kansas hospital after returning from west africa where he treated seriously ill patients on a commercial ship. the patient presented with typical symptoms such as diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and general fatigue. he is currently in isolation, and doctors are awaiting the results of his blood test. meanwhile, a patient is being observed at maine medical center for possible ebola exposure. in new york city, two patients were evaluated for ebola but were later cleared after tests came back negative. bellevue hospital in new york has established an intake center prepared to treat up to four patients with suspected ebola. there have been reports of suspected cases in boston and los angeles, but both have been deemed negative. the cdc and public health officials are on high alert and following protocols for dealing with possible ebola cases in the us.
2174	a high school teacher and baseball coach, eric estes, pleaded guilty in maryland to sexually assaulting a 15-year-old boy nearly 20 years ago when he was a pitcher on a minor league baseball team. estes, who was around 24 at the time, was living with the family of the victim in maryland while playing for the baltimore orioles' affiliates, the frederick keys and the bowie baysox. the alleged abuse took place between april and september of 1997. estes, who has taught social studies in the vancouver school district for 14 years and coached baseball there since 2006, entered his guilty plea in the frederick maryland circuit court and is recommended to serve three years of supervised probation and register as a sex offender. students and former players express shock and sadness, describing estes as a father figure and a great coach. estes has been on paid administrative leave since may 2014 and is in the process of being fired by the school district.
2175	a new phenomenon has emerged where sensitive cats are experiencing seizures from everyday household noises, such as the clicking of a computer mouse or the opening of a tin of cat food. vets from university college london and a specialist veterinary center are investigating this issue after receiving reports from owners. the condition, believed to be similar to reflex epilepsy in humans, is not triggered by stress and can occur during happy times like feeding. symptoms include jerking motions, freezing, or jumps. recovery occurs once the noise stops. some cats have been affected by repetitive tapping or clicking sounds, while others respond to metal items dropped on tiled floors or ceramic bowls, or even the sound of owners slapping their foreheads or clicking their tongues. the researchers hope to establish if there is any genetic link and to learn more about similar conditions in humans. owners are encouraged to report these incidences to the veterinary community. seizures are not triggered by the volume of the noise. the condition has been described as reminiscent of tom and jerry cartoons, where cats run around in circles and collide with furniture.
2176	michael gargiulo, 35, known as the 'hollywood ripper,' is now facing new charges for the stabbing death of tricia pacaccio in chicago in 1993, in addition to the violent stabbing deaths of ashley ellerin in los angeles in 2001 and maria bruno in el monte, california in 2005. gargiulo allegedly confessed to two men about the chicago killing who came forward after it was featured on cbs show '48 hours.' he had been a family friend of pacaccio and was arrested in 2008 for stabbing a woman in santa monica. the bodies of ellerin and pacaccio were found with multiple stab wounds. gargiulo is currently being held in los angeles and will face trial there before being extradited to chicago for the latest charge. the victims' families hope for justice in the long-unsolved cases.
2177	according to new data from the department for education, approximately one-fifth of all pupils in state schools have special educational needs (sen), with boys twice as likely as girls to be affected. sen includes learning difficulties, speech and language needs, and autism. schools can claim extra funds and better exam results if they classify a child as having certain types of sen. some education experts, including chris mcgovern from the campaign for real education, believe that this system has grown into an industry and that many children are improperly labeled as having sen due to poor teaching or to secure additional funding. the report also revealed that pupils with sen are more likely to be expelled or suspended, and some parents may lobby for positive diagnoses to receive additional support. the government is trying to reform the sen system to provide more control and better information for families, improve integration of services, and create a unified system from birth to age 25.
2178	tracey emin's controversial art piece, "my bed," which was included in the 1999 turner prize exhibition and caused outrage with its soiled sheets, empty vodka bottles, and cigarette butts, is now being sold by its owner, multi-millionaire art collector charles saatchi. the piece, which emin created in her waterloo flat in 1998 following a bout of severe depression and excessive drinking, is expected to fetch up to £1.2 million at auction this summer, significantly more than the £150,000 saatchi paid for it in 2000. emin described the sale as "the end of an era," as saatchi had kept the piece in his collection like a time capsule. emin's dealer, david maupin, believes the estimated price of £800,000 to £1.2 million is too low for the historic and priceless work. "my bed" is a confessional self-portrait that represents emin's personal experiences and is considered a significant work in modern art history.
2179	the article discusses the "fat-finger typo" theory, which suggested that a trader's erroneous entry of "billion" instead of "million" in a computer-ordered sale of stocks might have caused the stock market crash in 2010. the theory, although initially gaining attention, was later debunked, leaving typos with their previous reputation as mere irritations. however, the article emphasizes the importance of discipline and diligence in correcting typos, using examples of an incorrect star on the hollywood walk of fame for actress julia louis-dreyfus and a misprinted name of chicago cubs player ryne sandberg at shea stadium. the writer expresses frustration over these errors and the importance of accuracy, even if they may seem insignificant in the grand scheme of things.
2180	joann howells, a 46-year-old cancer patient, married her partner neil ward at worthing hospital in west sussex after staff rallied to ensure her wedding could still go ahead despite her diagnosis with lung cancer. an emergency license was granted, and donations of flowers, decorations, food, and drink were collected through a local radio appeal. hospital chefs baked the wedding cake and provided canapes and sandwiches for the reception, which was held in a day room at the hospital. nurses and staff transformed the rooms, including the chapel where the service was held, with rose petals. the couple, who went home following the wedding, expressed their gratitude to everyone involved, expressing amazement at the kindness of people.
2181	the agricultural community in ireland has joined the selfie trend with "felfies," where farmers take self-portraits with their livestock. some animals appear unimpressed or even startled in the pictures. the irish farmer's journal held a "selfie on the farm" competition, where the best images were selected and the winner, p.j. ryan, was awarded a hamper. ryan's image featuring him with a pipe, thumbs up and herd of selles in the background gathered 2,000 likes on facebook. other notable entries include a displeased sheepdog, a startled calf, and happy cows eager to be in the shot. the competition caused a stir on the internet, with a facebook group attracting 20,000 likes and american media outlets sharing the entertaining images.
2182	frank lampard, who signed a pre-contract agreement with new york city fc (nycfc) in january but remained at manchester city (mc) on loan, will meet his new teammates for the first time when nycfc plays two friendlies against st. mirren and brondby in february at mc's new £200m academy stadium. despite the delay, lampard, who is fully committed to his new mls career, insists he joined nycfc to keep fit before the move in july. nycfc coach jason kreis is delighted to have top-class opposition for the pre-season friendlies, which will help prepare the team for their first competitive mls game against orlando city on march 8.
2183	investigators have completed contacting all physicians and pharmacies related to whitney houston's death, and no criminal activity has been discovered so far. the toxicology report should be completed around march 23rd, and investigators are trying to interview houston's daughter, bobbi kristina brown, before closing the case. the singer, who won six grammys and sold 170 million albums, died in february at the beverly hilton hotel in beverly hills. authorities do not suspect foul play, and the initial cause of death was listed as "deferred." the investigation is being kept under a "security hold," restricting the release of information. no signs of trauma were found on houston's body after her death, and the amount of medication recovered was less than typical in overdose cases. the singer struggled with drug addiction in recent years.
2184	the author, amy, was drawn back to botswana after her first visit in 2011, following her olympic gold win in the skeleton at the vancouver olympics. she returned in 2014 with her fiance, craig, for a personalized safari organized by rob barber and charlotte bennett-diver of golden africa. the journey began at maun airport and included stays at meno a kwena, where they encountered various wildlife, and khwai in the okavango delta, known for its diverse wildlife and beautiful scenery. they also went horseback riding at african horseback safaris and visited victoria falls in zambia. throughout the trip, they experienced traditional bushmen culture and enjoyed luxurious accommodations while immersing themselves in the natural beauty of botswana. prices for golden africa safaris start from £2,995 per person for eight nights and include internal transfers and fully inclusive accommodation.
2185	this week in congress, republican infighting came to a head over the debate on increasing the federal borrowing limit. in the house, house speaker john boehner and 28 other republicans defied most of their colleagues by voting to allow the debt limit to increase, alongside near-unanimous democratic support. the next day in the senate, senate minority leader mitch mcconnell and 11 other gop senators voted to reject an attempted filibuster by sen. ted cruz of texas against the same legislation. however, these 12 senators later joined cruz and other republicans in voting against the bill, which ultimately passed due to democratic support. the situations in the house and senate were similar in that republican leaders sought to avoid a politically damaging showdown over the debt ceiling but were thwarted by more extreme conservative elements in their party. the fear of another financial market instability and public backlash following the 16-day government shutdown in october also played a role in their decisions. republican leaders were praised by some fellow gop colleagues for putting party interests first, despite potential damage to their own political careers. however, cruz and his supporters were critical of republican leaders for betraying their ideological principles. the ongoing tension within the republican party was described as a 'real civil war' by some democrats and a 'classic victory for the washington establishment' by others.
2186	a liberal democratic mp's son, dean hancock, was arrested and charged with assaulting a photographer outside his father's home in fareham, hampshire. police were called to the scene following reports of an altercation between hancock and members of the media. the incident occurred after a leaked report claimed mike hancock, the mp for portsmouth south, had shown "serious and unwelcome sexual behavior" towards a vulnerable constituent. hancock was later suspended from the party. dean hancock allegedly headbutted and punched steve reigate, the photographer, and tried to stop him from taking pictures of hancock's mother as she left the property. it took nearly an hour for police to arrive, and they arrested hancock around 10.40am. hancock was charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm and released on bail, with a court date set for february 12. the leadership of the liberal democrats acted against mike hancock after a copy of the unpublished report was leaked online, but some party members accused them of not following due process as the council investigation and ongoing civil action were not yet complete. hancock had resigned the parliamentary party whip last year amid the allegations but still sat as a lib dem councillor.
2187	diego costa confirmed his inevitable £32million move to chelsea after admitting "it looks like" he will join jose mourinho's side. chelsea have already triggered costa's buyout clause and have been frustrated with atletico madrid's attempts to delay the transfer. costa put in an impressive performance in spain's 2-0 friendly win against el salvador, creating several chances, despite not scoring. vicente del bosque praised costa's comeback from injury. mourinho has been eager to bring a top striker to chelsea this summer.
2188	the australian government, led by assistant treasurer josh frydenberg, has announced plans to review the tax exemption on goods bought overseas worth less than $1000, which could lead to an end of cheaper prices for consumers shopping for bargains online. local retailers have long complained about this tax "loophole" giving their overseas competitors an unfair advantage, and have been lobbying for its reduction. if implemented, the review could result in higher online prices for household goods such as tvs, books, clothes, and small electronic appliances. the australian retailers association has welcomed this move, as they believe it will help boost local jobs and collected revenue for the government. the impact on consumer behavior and the potential impact on local retailers and international competitors remain to be seen.
2189	the author, jamie carragher, reflects on england's past match against estonia in 2007, which was significant for him as it marked the end of his international career. he had hoped to play in the euro 2008 qualifier after a strong season with liverpool and the champions league, but was left on the bench in favor of ledley king. carragher was disappointed and realized it was time to focus solely on his club career. this week, he is looking forward to reading roy keane's new book, praising the former manchester united midfielder for his skill and outspoken personality. carragher worked with keane as an itv pundit during euro 2012 and was impressed by his football knowledge and good company off-camera. keane's career is celebrated in his latest autobiography, "the second half."
2190	in the hours leading up to the official results of the 2012 french presidential elections, paris was buzzing with excitement as francois hollande, the socialist candidate, appeared poised for victory. young and old, waved flags and chanted "victoire!" ("victory!") along the left bank boulevards, while nicolas sarkozy's planned celebration at the concorde was cancelled. with 51.7% of the votes, hollande secured a narrow yet historic victory over sarkozy. in his first few hours as president, hollande took a more low-key approach than his predecessor, delivering a calming and conciliatory speech from corrèze and speaking to the crowds at the bastille late into the night. hollande's election was not so much a response to his policies, but rather his perceived personality. despite france's financial troubles, many voters preferred his more laid-back demeanor to sarkozy's aggressive attitude. in the coming days, hollande will face numerous challenges, including reassuring the markets, pushing for economic growth, and addressing the upcoming g8 and nato summits. he will also need to secure a strong majority at the national assembly in order to effectively implement his policies. despite the hurdles ahead, hollande has expressed intentions to spearhead a new anti-austerity movement in europe and has made a few symbolic gestures, such as lowering the retirement age for some workers and raising students' scholarships, to signify a departure from sarkozysm. these actions are likely to be popular with the french public. the success of hollande's presidency, particularly in relation to germany and europe, remains to be seen.
2191	ning is a free, fast-growing social networking site launched two years ago, which allows users to custom build their own platforms based on common interests and passions. with over 4.7 million unique visitors and 1 million active social networks, ning enables people to connect around various topics, from hip-hop music and video gaming to political and social causes. founded on the principle of providing the means for people to create new social networks, ning's ceo, gina bianchini, sees tremendous potential in niche social networking sites and plans to make their service perfect for people looking to meet new individuals with similar interests. ning generates revenue through a la carte features and contextual ads on free services.
2192	david cameron has ordered the drawing up of possible sanctions against russia after a briefing paper with details of the uk's plans for putting pressure on russia was accidentally exposed to photographers. the document revealed the uk's intentions to break off relations with russia through international organizations, suspend cooperations, and not support trade sanctions or closing london's financial center to russians. the document also discussed a deep and comprehensive trade deal with ukraine and providing alternative gas supplies if russia cuts them off. following the leak, hugh powell, a deputy national security adviser and an old etonian friend of cameron, is facing disciplinary proceedings. cameron warned russia of diplomatic, political, and economic costs for its actions in ukraine, while william hague dismissed russia's excuses and indicated that eu leaders would discuss sanctions at a summit. the leaked document has undermined cameron and hague's previous claims of a tough stance against russia.
2193	cate blanchett and her husband, andrew upton, have purchased a secluded three-floor waterfront home in berowra waters, a quiet area on the hawkesbury river in northern sydney. the property, which cost $1,495,000, features stunning river views, a self-contained unit, three bedrooms, living and dining rooms, a spa, sauna, pontoon, and terraced gardens. the area is known for its natural beauty and seclusion, and the couple will be able to enjoy local restaurants, walking trails, and easy access to sydney cbd and public transportation. they previously lived in several other properties in new south wales and moved back to australia from england in the early 2000s to be closer to family. the home was purchased through a company owned by andrew upton.
2194	alex oxlade-chamberlain, an arsenal midfielder and england player, trained with a knee brace on monday at the urca military base in rio de janeiro after sustaining inflamed ligaments in his right knee during england's draw against ecuador last week. head physio gary lewin put him through running exercises. oxlade-chamberlain is hoping to prove his fitness to england boss roy hodgson, who has until 24 hours before the opening group game against italy on saturday to make a decision on his inclusion in the squad. captain steven gerrard also trained away from the main group and finished early due to groin tightness. the england team was guarded by brazilian army personnel and trained in the shadow of sugar loaf mountain in the searing heat. oxlade-chamberlain was tackled by ecuador's carlos gruezo during the previous game, resulting in his injury.
2195	a jury visited mark bridger's cottage, mount pleasant, in mid wales, where april jones, a five-year-old girl, is believed to have been taken and eventually found dead. the prosecution alleges that april's dna was discovered in the cottage's hallway and blood was found in the bathroom, washing machine, and on the white leather sofa. bridger, a former lifeguard, claims he accidentally ran april over with his car but cannot remember what he did with her body, which was later found near his home. the cottage is situated in an isolated location and has a wood-burning stove in the living room, where remains of april's skull and blood spots were discovered. the jury also visited the roadside layby where bridger was seen carrying a black bin bag, presumably containing april's body, the day after she disappeared. the trial continues.
2196	paralympian oscar pistorius appeared in court today accused of premeditated murder after shooting dead his girlfriend reeva steenkamp in the early hours of valentine's day. prosecutor gerrie nel claimed pistorius got up from bed, put on his prosthetic legs, and intentionally shot steenkamp through a bathroom door. however, pistorius stated he woke up to a sound in the bathroom, believed it was an intruder, and shot in self-defense. the bail hearing was postponed twice due to pistorius's emotional distress. steenkamp's funeral was held in port elizabeth, attended by her family and friends. major sponsors, including thierry mugler, oakley, and nike, have since distanced themselves from pistorius amidst the allegations. pistorius won two gold medals and a silver at the 2012 paralympic games. the case will continue in court on wednesday.
2197	a major investigation by the australian crime commission has revealed widespread use of banned drugs in professional sports by elite athletes, with links to organized crime and possible match-fixing. the report found evidence of athletes using banned substances, including peptides and other drugs, in orchestrated doping programs with the help of coaches, sports scientists, support staff, doctors, and pharmacists. the findings have shocked the australian sports community, with many expressing concern about the involvement of criminal networks and the potential long-term impact on the integrity of sports in the country. multiple sports codes, including the australian football league, national rugby league, football federation australia, australian rugby union, and cricket australia, have pledged full cooperation with investigating authorities and established integrity units to address the issue. the report also warned of a potential link between match-fixing and organized crime, particularly in soccer, cricket, and tennis, due to big offshore bets and lower levels of scrutiny at sub-elite competitions. independent senator nick xenophon has called for an immediate suspension of all sports betting until all investigations are complete.
2198	china criticized the norwegian nobel committee for awarding the nobel peace prize to chinese dissident liu xiaobo, calling it a "blasphemy." liu, serving an 11-year prison term for inciting subversion, won for his nonviolent work towards human rights and political reform in china. ma zhaoxu, china's foreign ministry spokesman, condemned the selection, as liu is a "convicted criminal." the committee stood by its choice, citing a tradition of awarding the prize to human rights activists, and china's response may harm relations between the countries. liu's friend, human rights lawyer pu zhiqiang, believes the award will leave a lasting impact on china, while the dalai lama, who won the prize in 1989, praised it as a recognition of growing voices calling for reforms.
2199	a town in essex, england, named harlow, has been dealing with a significant issue of travelers setting up 79 illegal camps in the past year. the caravans have been parked on verges, roundabouts, cycle tracks, and school grounds, causing intimidation and leaving piles of rubbish behind. residents have demanded action, and the problem has resulted in over £50,000 in cleanup and eviction costs for taxpayers. local mp robert halfon criticized the situation, calling it "shocking," and a change in the law to make illegal camping a criminal offense is being proposed. the travelers, who insist they are mere waiting for legal plots, have indicated they will not leave the town where their children attend school. the camps, ranging from one to over 30 caravans, are moved frequently, and the town has two legal traveler sites but not enough room for the newcomers. authorities are taking action to protect the land, and a possession hearing is scheduled. council leader jon clempner is requesting a review of the balance between travelers' and residents' rights, while chief superintendent sean o'callaghan emphasizes that the police can only use their powers if they are lawful, necessary, and proportionate. the town is close to dale farm, britain's most notorious illegal camp that was cleared out after violent confrontations.
2200	the russian parliament's lower house, the state duma, gave preliminary approval on friday for the new strategic arms reduction treaty (new start) between russia and the united states. the treaty, which limits both countries to 1,550 warheads and 700 launchers, needed 225 votes to pass and received 350-58 in favor. the treaty will undergo two more readings before being sent to the upper house for approval. u.s. senate approved the accord by a 71-26 vote on wednesday and president barack obama discussed the agreement with russian president dmitry medvedev during a phone conversation on thursday. obama considered it a key foreign policy victory, while medvedev called it the basis of security for both countries. russia's foreign minister sergey lavrov criticized a u.s. senate resolution concerning the treaty's interpretation of the link between strategic offensive and defensive weapons.
2201	paul pogba impressed juventus team-mates during training in qatar by nonchalantly scoring a goal from behind the goal line next to the corner flag. the italian champions are in qatar for the italian super cup clash against napoli, who have won the competition once in 1990. napoli captain marek hamsik expressed confidence in beating juventus, who have won the super cup for the last three seasons and seek to make it a record seven times. pogba, a former manchester united player, showcased his ball skills during training and scored during a session against an empty net. napoli may struggle without diego maradona, but hamsik believed they could win with the same intensity they displayed against roma. both teams drew 1-1 in their last league match against sampdoria.
2202	fitness experts and scientists have identified walking as the newest "superfood" in fitness, emphasizing its importance over intense exercise. biomechanist katy bowman, author of "move your dna: restore your health through natural movement," believes that walking is necessary to meet the body's movement requirements, just like dietary nutrients. preliminary research suggests that a combination of physical activity and inactivity could be more critical for chronic disease risk than just physical activity alone. experts advise that sitting around for long durations cannot be offset by one hour of exercise. leslie sansone, creator of the "walk at home: mix & match walk blasters" dvd, encourages people to embrace the ease of walking instead of pursuing lengthy gym sessions for fitness. a small study published in the journal of medicine & science in sports and exercise indicates that taking short walks throughout prolonged sitting may reverse the negative effects of prolonged sitting on leg arteries. dr. carol ewing garber, president of the american college of sports medicine (acsm), suggests that walking 7,500 steps per day, which is less than the current acsm guidelines of 10,000 steps, may be more realistic. garber, a professor of movement sciences at columbia university in new york, acknowledges that walking has its limitations for bone health and strength, but maintains that it still holds numerous benefits and should be a priority when choosing one form of exercise.
2203	an 11-year-old girl named abigail baker from desborough, northamptonshire, created a dress made from 25,000 loom bands and sold it on ebay for £155. she spent seven days making the multi-colored garment and made a £65 profit. however, two women from wales previously sold an almost identical dress for £170,000, but the buyer backed out. abigail's parents are proud of her dedication and creativity. she made the dress to raise money for a family holiday and donate to her old brownie pack. experts warn that loom bands, which are made of plastic elastic, could be harmful to marine life and seabirds if they end up in the ocean. the national marine aquarium in plymouth, devon, urges children to leave loom bands at home when they go to the beach and to dispose of them carefully to minimize the risk to wildlife.
2204	a new study by victoria university revealed that 80% of secondary school students in australia experienced distressing homophobic comments, mostly in physical education classes. these casual comments, such as "you're so gay," were causing mental health problems, particularly among students identifying as gay, lesbian, bisexual, and gender diverse, who reported severe levels of depression nearly double that of their straight counterparts. the study found that 25% of these students also experienced physical abuse and pushing during pe lessons. the research highlighted pe as a particularly problematic environment due to the traditional gender roles and masculinity reinforced in sports. beyondblue, a mental health organization, has called for action to prevent homophobic abuse in schools, including standing against derogatory language and creating inclusive and safe environments. there are existing awareness initiatives in place, but there is a need for greater education and support for teachers to tackle such abuse.
2205	samuel l. jackson criticized president barack obama in an expletive-filled interview with playboy magazine for "dumbing down" his language to relate to ordinary americans. the harvard-educated former law professor's omission of the letter "g" at the end of words drew jackson's ire, with the actor questioning why obama was trying to appear more down-to-earth instead of being true to himself. jackson, himself a university graduate, expressed annoyance with high-profile figures using "street language" and believed that such behavior encouraged mediocrity. jackson's attack on obama's speech was ironic given his own profanity-laden roles and past use of expletives in campaigns, including an obama reelection video based on the book "go the f\*\*\* to sleep."
2206	a middle school student named katarina lucardie, who has alopecia areata, a condition that causes hair loss, decided to stop wearing a wig to her colorado middle school despite fears of bullying. with the support of her teachers and counselor, she made a documentary about her condition to educate her peers about alopecia and debunk any myths or misconceptions. the documentary was screened for several student groups, resulting in many students crying and showing empathy towards katarina. her decision to be herself was inspiring to her mother and teachers, and katarina expressed a desire to be loved for who she is rather than her appearance. katarina's bravery has made her a role model for her classmates.
2207	the original domesday book, a 900-year-old record of english settlements commissioned by william the conqueror in 1085, has survived longer than the bbc's 1986 domesday project on laser discs. the corporation aimed to celebrate the anniversary with a modern-day version, but within a decade, the equipment became obsolete. recently, the project was rebooted with the domesday project loaded onto a 52in touch-screen at the national museum of computing. in the 1980s, viewers needed an acorn bbc master computer, scsi controller, and a philips vp415 laserdisc player. the u.s.-uk project camileon saved the day by emulating the old technology and extracting the data. the updated project, domesday reloaded, includes information on life in 2011, making the touchtable a snapshot of the past and present. launched in april 2021, the touchtable contains 50gb of data and can accommodate four users. project leader peter armstrong, who contributed to the original project, expressed his pleasure, saying it was 'amazing' and '25 years later, a new generation of programmers made this happen.' the national museum of computing exhibition at bletchley park opened recently, with key data from the original domesday book available online since 2004 and the original book kept securely at the national archives.
2208	in western iraq's anbar province, seven police officers were killed and nine were injured in a series of attacks at security checkpoints in the town of al-rutba on tuesday. the first attack was a suicide car bombing at a police checkpoint, which killed four officers and injured three others. gunmen then attacked several other checkpoints in the town, resulting in three more officer deaths and six injuries. in central iraq, a car bomb explosion near a market in musayyib killed one person and injured 11. both towns have seen increasing tension between sunni and shiite populations, with al-rutba being a predominantly sunni community and musayyib, a largely shiite town. in total, more than 6,000 people have been killed in iraq in 2013, with over 1,000 deaths in september and almost 350 deaths this month.
2209	the monaco grand prix is a formula one race held annually on the streets of monaco, known for its glamour and sophistication. with 78 laps around the principality's tight streets, the race provides a unique experience with wealthy spectators watching from expensive yachts in the mediterranean port. first held in 1929, notable drivers like michael schumacher (5-time winner) and ayrton senna (6-time winner) have left their mark on this prestigious event. schumacher attributes his success to feeling at home in monaco, having lived there. the monaco grand prix is a favorite among drivers and attracts f1's top executives for the huge parties and prestige associated with it. monaco's challenging layout and rich history make it the jewel of the f1 season, with renowned drivers like sir stirling moss (3-time winner) proudly claiming victory in this race.
2210	eva braun, who married adolf hitler just days before their suicide in april 1945, is believed to have written farewell letters to her friend hertha schneider, revealing her growing sense of despair as the soviet army approached berlin. in the first letter, dated april 19, she expressed her happiness to be close to hitler and remained hopeful, but by april 22, she wrote of impending doom and preparing to die. the letters, published in a new book, are claimed to be genuine by the author, anna maria sigmund. hitler and eva braun had kept their relationship secret from the german people during hitler's rule, but had been together for several years. the letters offer a glimpse into the mood in the bunker during the final days of the war.
2211	china's growing appreciation for european and american luxury brands has made chinese shoppers a familiar sight in high-end stores in london, new york, and paris. with china accounting for over a quarter of the global luxury market, the influence of chinese consumers on the fashion industry is significant. however, a new generation of chinese fashion designers, such as haizhen wang and huishan zhang, is making waves in the fashion world. trained in the west but influenced by their chinese heritage, these designers aim to showcase that the flow of fashion capital goes both ways. they face the challenge of convincing people that "made in china" can represent high-quality and are trying to bridge the gap between chinese and western fashion perspectives. designers like huishan zhang are incorporating chinese influences into their collections, and the increasing demand for new fashion in china makes it a key market for global fashion brands. industry experts and fashion insiders believe that the chinese fashion industry is evolving with changing social norms and that chinese consumers have undergone a significant learning curve in recent years. as more chinese designers gain recognition, china seems poised to take its place as a serious player on the global fashion stage.
2212	a meteor that exploded over southwestern russia in february, the largest to hit earth since the 1908 tunguska incident, was hard to detect due to its darkened surface caused by previous collisions that melted metallic elements and formed fissures, according to a finnish researcher. the meteor, about 60 feet long, exploded with the force of about 30 nuclear bombs and resulted in over 1,500 injuries. dark asteroids, which reflect 5% or less of sunlight, are harder to detect than regular asteroids. nasa estimates there are approximately 4,700 "potentially hazardous" asteroids, and the chelyabinsk meteor incident raised concerns about humanity's vulnerability to such objects. nasa aims to send a spacecraft to seize and tow an asteroid into orbit around the moon for study, a project also considered a planetary defense mission, but it faced opposition in congress and funding was blocked.
2213	controversial anti-obama billboards showing children giving the middle finger to president barack obama and making derogatory remarks have sparked outrage and debate in hanson, massachusetts. the posters, displayed outside a motorbike accessories store, include one showing a girl calling obama a "jerk" for overspending, another depicting the president with communist symbols and the phrase "somewhere in kenya a village is missing its idiot," and a third showing obama with the same communist symbols and the statement "bankrupt america...yes we can!" some find the signs amusing, while others call them offensive and racist. officials have debated whether they are legal, as the store owner did not obtain a permit to display them. the signs have drawn comparisons to other controversial anti-obama displays, such as a tea party billboard in indiana comparing obama to osama bin laden.
2214	in the height of his political power following his landslide election in 1964, president lyndon b. johnson faced a significant dilemma – pushing forward with a progressive domestic agenda while escalating america's involvement in the vietnam war. despite his doubts and concerns, johnson, under political pressure and adhering to the "domino theory," requested congressional authorization for military intervention through the gulf of tonkin resolution. johnson's fear of being perceived as weak on defense, despite the advice of advisors to withdraw, eventually resulted in the us getting deeper into the vietnam war, ultimately leading to a devastating and defining aspect of his presidency. despite his achievements in areas such as civil rights and social programs, johnson's legacy remains heavily tainted by the vietnam war.
2215	abbey clancy, a mother-of-one and lingerie lover, has been named the new face of ultimo's party lingerie range. in the campaign shoot, she models the brand's problem-solving bras, including the low back body, low back bra, and strapless 'wear 5 ways' multi-way. abbey, who previously admitted to not wearing a bra until she was 16 and has a long relationship with underwear, poses seductively in the french-style boudoir shoot. she has also recently become the face of avon fragrance and starred in a mother-daughter campaign with her 53-year-old mother. abbey is known for her fitness regime and devotion to her husband peter crouch. she has previously designed a range for matalan and was also the face of veet and scholl earlier this year.
2216	a google engineer used a system similar to how the search engine ranks web pages to create a list of people's historical importance. nelson mandela ranks 356th, with jesus, napoleon, and muhammad as the top three. winston churchill is ranked 37th, behind adolf hitler and former us presidents george w. bush and ronald reagan. william shakespeare is the highest-ranked briton in fourth place, while queen elizabeth i is the highest-ranked woman at 13th. the ranking is based on significance on wikipedia, online newspaper reports, books published on the web, and other parts of the internet. the system gives equal weight to fame and gravitas, with a 'reputation decay' mathematical formula predicting impact up to 200 years after death. the software suggests a third of historical figures studied in us schools are relatively obscure. the book "who's bigger? where historical figures really rank" by steaven skiena and charles ward was published with these findings. other notable mentions on the list include mozart as the most significant musician and elvis presley as the highest-ranked pop star. however, historian antony beevor deemed the idea that historical significance could be reduced to a formula as "preposterous."
2217	the das park hotel presents a unique budget accommodation option in germany and austria, offering rooms in refurbished sewer pipes. these 6ft-tall structures, converted into cosy rooms, have features like double beds, luggage space, power points, and even wall paintings. however, there are no windows, and guests use local facilities for toilets and showers. the hotel allows free three-night stays or guests can pay what they can afford. operating from may to october, das park hotel's minimalist design includes three suites in ottensheim, austria, and five suites in bernepark, germany. by incorporating local infrastructure and businesses, the hotel offers an unconventional and sustainable travel experience, with guests unlocking their rooms through codes on acceptance of booking. the thick cement insulation ensures a comfortable interior temperature.
2218	a blizzard brought over 2 feet of snow to the mid-atlantic states, causing power outages for hundreds of thousands, closures of airports and roads, and slippery conditions for president obama during his speech to democrats in washington d.c. the heaviest snowfall was reported in maryland, virginia, and west virginia, with some areas receiving up to 3 feet. the storm also resulted in numerous accidents, including a fatal crash in virginia. emergency measures were taken in several states, and authorities urged residents to stay indoors and avoid travel.
2219	shane greene, a new $500,000-a-year pitcher for the new york yankees, made headlines for a disastrous underarm toss to first base during a game against the texas rangers last night. instead of reaching his teammate, the ball sailed over infielder kelly johnson's head, allowing the batter, jim adduci, to advance to second base. greene made three errors in total during the game, causing widespread mockery on social media, with many comparing his throw unfavorably to an impressive underhand toss made by a 105-year-old fan, agnes mckee, the previous night. greene, who joined the yankees' roster in november, had made his first start at yankee stadium earlier this month.
2220	edin dzeko, the bosnia and herzegovina striker, will miss the euro 2016 qualifier against israel due to a calf injury, which could keep him sidelined for up to three weeks. team doctor reuf karabeg described it as a "very serious injury" that requires extensive treatment. dzeko expressed his disappointment but expressed faith in his teammates. bosnia's injury woes continue as ibisevic, vrsajevic, and susic are also doubtful for the match. coach safet susic has expressed concern and believes his team has little chance of winning without dzeko, who is their top scorer. with a poor performance in their last three qualifiers, susic is under pressure and will have to find alternatives to field a team without natural strikers against israel.
2221	the british ska band the specials, known for their new wave sound, concluded their five-date anniversary tour at london's brixton academy. the energetic performance drew a large and diverse crowd, who sang along to hits like "do the dog," "too much too young," and "gangsters." despite the absence of songwriter jerry dammers and vocalist lynval golding's hoarse voice, the band gave a tight and lively performance, and the audience, ranging from middle-aged fans to post-margaret thatcher indie kids, eagerly joined in. frontman terence hall, a manchester united fan and vocal about his team's league success, and neville staple, with his boundless energy, led the show. the specials, who reformed recently, brought a powerful stage presence and relevant lyrics to the concert, with "ghost town" resonating with the audience as a portrait of urban britain's challenges.
2222	rafaels cabrera-bello of spain had a strong second round at the dp world tour championship in dubai, opening with five birdies to surge into contention. he trailing rory mcilroy and shane lowry, who both shot a 6-under par 66 in the first round, by just two strokes. mcilroy, returning from a six-week layoff, had a stellar start with four birdies in his first five holes but missed a six-foot birdie putt on the third. graeme mcdowell of northern ireland also made a move up the leaderboard with two early birdies, sitting two strokes behind the leaders.
2223	bitter arctic winds are predicted to bring the coldest august weather in almost a century to parts of britain, with temperatures dropping near freezing in some areas. low pressure is drawing in cold air from the north, resulting in two weeks of wet, windy, and cool weather. the met office reported that the last time it was this cold in august was in 1919, with temperatures not rising above 8.9°c for four days in yorkshire and cumbria. the cold and miserable week ahead comes after hurricane bertha brought gales and heavy rain through the uk earlier in the month. temperatures will hover around the high teens, with scattered showers across the uk, particularly in the eastern side of the country. the bank holiday weekend is expected to be disappointing, with cool, windy weather and scattered showers.
2224	in this october 2013 article from gq magazine by ashley collman, weiner, who lost the new york mayoral primary a month earlier due to a sexting scandal, gives a candid post-election interview where he finally expresses remorse for the pain he caused his wife, huma abedin. weiner admitted that his sexting behavior was "remarkably meaningless" to him but significant to his wife, and he was compared to a "video game" where he "click[ed] and send[ed]" messages without considering the impact on his marriage. despite abedin's public support during the scandal and her continued living arrangement with weiner, their future remains uncertain as he declined to directly answer questions about their relationship's future. weiner expressed regret for the harsh media coverage of his wife and his own role in causing it, stating that she deserved better. after losing the election with only 5% of the votes, weiner returned to his role as a stay-at-home dad, and when asked if he would run for mayor again, he acknowledged the mistakes in his campaign and sexting discussions.
2225	a 26-year-old man named mitchell whisenhunt from longview, texas, passed away over the weekend due to complications from marfan's syndrome, a rare disorder affecting the heart valves and aorta. his wife, ashley, discovered 30 letters he left behind for her and their 1-year-old daughter. these letters were written for special occasions, including mitchell's upcoming memorial service, and contained thoughtful messages and financial assistance to ease his wife's financial burden during her grieving period. ashley plans to give their daughter the remaining letters on her birthdays up until she turns 18. the whisenhunt family is currently raising funds through gofundme to cover the costs of mitchell's memorial service. the letters serve as a touching reminder of their late husband and father, evoking the sentiment of the novel and movie, "p.s. i love you."
2226	a measles outbreak, which started at disneyland in california last month, has spread to at least 95 people across the us, including in arizona, where health officials are monitoring 1,000 people. those who haven't been vaccinated are being urged to stay at home for 21 days or wear masks in public. the outbreak has also been reported in utah, washington, colorado, oregon, nebraska, and mexico. arizona and california have seen the most cases, with 7 confirmed in the grand canyon state as of tuesday. health officials are working to contact families who may have been exposed at a phoenix medical center last week. some of the infected individuals were not vaccinated, leading to concerns about the growing anti-vaccination movement. health experts emphasized the importance of getting the mmr vaccine, which is not 100% effective but helps prevent the spread of the disease. in arizona, 17 people are being tracked after a confirmed case at a hospital in globe, and signs warning of potential measles exposure have gone up in a few businesses in kearny. the us experienced a record number of measles cases last year, with 644 infections reported in 27 states.
2227	pro-russian activists in odessa, ukraine, stormed a police station to free arrested comrades following clashes with pro-ukrainian supporters that resulted in dozens of deaths two days prior. protesters overpowered the police, smashing windows and fighting in riot gear. thousands gathered to welcome released detainees, many of whom were accused of financing the violence. the unrest comes as ukrainian forces confront separatists in the east and russia threatens military action. meanwhile, international condemnation and threatened sanctions continue against russia for its involvement in the violence.
2228	a 22-year-old marine corps corporal, cesar laurean, was extradited from mexico to the united states late friday and held on a murder charge for the december 2007 death of pregnant marine lance corporal maria lauterbach. laurean, a dual citizen, could not be deported and had to go through the extradition process. he is being held without bond in onslow county, north carolina, where he is scheduled for an arraignment on monday. lauterbach, who was 8 months pregnant when she disappeared, was found dead in laurean's backyard in january 2008 with a note claiming she had killed herself during an argument. the autopsy showed she died from blunt-force trauma to the head. laurean had previously been investigated for allegations of rape and harassment against lauterbach. he is being charged with first-degree murder, financial card transaction fraud, and obtaining property by false pretenses. if convicted, he would face a maximum sentence of life in prison without parole. mexican extradition policy prohibits u.s. authorities from seeking the death penalty against fugitives. lauterbach's mother has criticized the marine corps for not taking the rape allegations seriously.
2229	ukraine's interior ministry accused opposition leader oleg layashko of inciting attacks on law enforcement, resulting in the death of a policeman and the capture of three others. protests against the government's decision not to sign a trade agreement with the european union have continued in kiev for months, with the opposition demanding resignations and early elections, while the government has refused. talks between the government and opposition parties have been unproductive. protesters have set up tent cities and barricades, and there have been violent clashes between them and police. the european union is attempting to mediate the conflict, with eu representative stefan fule meeting with president viktor yanukovych and opposition leaders, urging an end to violence and the rebuilding of trust. fule's talks were a precursor to a scheduled visit next week by the eu's foreign policy chief catherine ashton and a european parliament delegation.
2230	japan's obsession with yuru-kyara, or loose or relaxed characters, has led to an overabundance of mascots, with some japanese officials trying to limit the number in osaka in order to boost the popularity and brand identity of the city's chosen mascot, moppi. japanese people have a deep emotional bond with non-human characters, with roots in ancient polytheism, leading to the creation of beloved regional mascots like kumamon and hikonyan. these mascots have become bona fide celebrities, appearing on various promotional materials and merchandise. however, with over 45 osaka-themed mascots, the city's government is focusing on moppi, designed in the 1990s to resemble a native bird species, as the core mascot to promote women's and children's issues. the plan is to develop the moppi brand and potentially create offspring. while some oppose the cull of other mascots, the benefits of focusing on one or two distinctive characters in japan's crowded marketplace make sense.
2231	indonesia summoned australia's ambassador to express anger over allegations that australian intelligence tried to intercept phone calls of then-president susilo bambang yudhoyono in 2009. the reports, based on documents leaked by edward snowden, claimed that yudhoyono's mobile phone was monitored for 15 days, with at least one call attempted to be listened into but not successful. the australian government refused to comment on the specific intelligence matters, with prime minister tony abbott stating that all governments gather information and acknowledge that other governments do the same. indonesia demanded clarification from australia and expressed concerns over the potential damage to bilateral relations.

2233	the syrian civil war has inflicted unprecedented trauma and physical harm on over 2 million syrian children. one in three children have suffered injuries, while many more are malnourished, diseased, or lack basic protection from preventable diseases due to decimated vaccination programs. children are increasingly being used as pawns in the conflict, with reports of recruitment by armed groups and forces, and over 3 million buildings destroyed, forcing families to flee and seek shelter in caves, parks, and overcrowded homes. with the constant shifting front lines, no dwelling is safe from bombings. many children have witnessed or experienced the killings of loved ones – a new study found that three out of every four syrian children interviewed had lost a relative. the conflict has disrupted education, with over 2,000 schools damaged or turned into shelters. the united nations has called for a united plan to bring an end to the civil war, but two years of diplomacy, negotiations, and stalemates at the security council have failed to produce an effective solution. families, like syrian mother hiba, are caught in the crossfire, helplessly watching their children pay the ultimate price.
2234	nigel farage, ukip leader, called for limiting access to the national health service (nhs) to british citizens, despite over 10% of nhs staff being foreign. he argued for £3 billion savings if the uk leaves the european union and criticized foreign citizens living in the uk for using the nhs. ukip was previously criticized for party secretary matthew richardson's 2010 comments calling the nhs a "waste of money" and a " reichstag bunker of socialism." farage defended richardson's comments, claiming he made them as a conservative and not as ukip leader. farage also called for a referendum on leaving the eu, stating that only british citizens should be allowed to vote. he previously criticized the nhs as a "biggest waste of money in the uk." the british medical association warned that without non-british staff, many nhs services would struggle to provide effective care. the uk population's increase and health tourism were cited as contributing factors to the nhs crisis. farage also announced an extra £3 billion a year for the nhs, funded by eu membership fees, and pledged to reduce tuition fees for medical students to decrease the nhs's reliance on migrant workers.
2235	a missouri man, david lee mangum, is facing multiple charges for knowingly exposing sexual partners to hiv without disclosing his positive status between 2003 and 2013. authorities say mangum, 36, had over 300 sexual partners, some of whom may have unknowingly passed the virus on to others. police in dexter, missouri, have filed a probable cause statement for two more alleged victims, and more charges may follow. prosecuting attorney russell oliver urged potential victims to get tested and avoid further spread of the virus. mangum is currently in jail on a felony charge from one victim and is being held on a $250,000 bail. authorities are struggling to locate numerous unidentified partners, whom mangum claimed he only knew by their first names and some of whom were in the dallas area. knowingly exposing someone to hiv without their consent is punishable by up to 15 years in prison under missouri law, and infection can bring a life term.
2236	in a house budget committee hearing on february 5, 2014, douglas elmendorf, the director of the congressional budget office (cbo), testified that obamacare would result in the loss of 2.5 million full-time jobs in the next ten years. however, democratic representatives insisted that these job losses were a good thing, as consumers would have more health insurance choices, and many americans might opt to retire early or spend more time with their families. republican lawmakers, on the other hand, criticized obamacare as a poverty trap that disincentivized work and would negatively impact the economy, shrinking the tax base and raising budget deficits. the cbo report also estimated that the affordable care act would cost taxpayers around $2 trillion over the next decade.
2237	andrea hill, the chief executive of suffolk county council, has left her position with a £219,000 pay-off following accusations of bullying and excessive expenses. hill, who earned around £75,000 more than prime minister david cameron's salary, repeatedly refused to take a 10% pay cut. she had been on paid leave since easter but stepped down after an investigation into bullying allegations and her expense claims. the news was welcomed by council critic kathy pollard, who expressed relief and called it an "unhappy chapter" in suffolk's history. hill's resignation follows that of two senior council officers and the apparent suicide of the head of legal services, david white, in april. an anonymous whistleblower had accused hill of having a domineering management style, leading to a detailed investigation by a leading london law firm. hill had been in position since 2008 and was criticized for her high salary, which was topped up with a deferred pay payment of £50,000 a year. critics argued that the salary was awarded without proper procedure and that hill's refusal to take a pay cut made her position untenable.
2238	yahoo ceo carol bartz was unexpectedly fired from her position after a tumultuous three-year tenure marked by stagnating growth, a dispute with a chinese partner, and increasing competition from google and facebook. bartz, who lacked experience in the internet or advertising industries, announced her departure via email and was replaced on an interim basis by cfo timothy morse. yahoo's revenue growth trailed google's during her leadership, leading to cost-cutting measures including layoffs and service closures, and the company's stock price plummeted from a peak of $125 in 2000 to just over $13 in after-hours trading at the time of her departure. speculation had been mounting regarding potential takeover offers from companies like news corp, at&t, and verizon. bartz's departure was first reported by the wall street journal and was met with a rise in yahoo's stock price. she joined yahoo after 17 years at autodesk, and roy bostock, yahoo's chairman, had publicly backed her earlier in the year but ultimately decided to let her go after disappointing financial results. morse expressed enthusiasm for his new role and working with the yahoo team to drive growth.
