2398	samsung is set to unveil two new galaxy s6 handsets on march 1st in barcelona: a standard version that looks similar to the iphone 6, and an edge version with curved screens on both sides. the curved technology gives samsung an edge over rival apple, who does not currently offer a product with such screens. the standard galaxy s6 is expected to have a 5.1-inch screen, an octa-core processor, and a 16mp rear-facing camera. the curved galaxy s6, or s6 edge, will reportedly have a mid-level 64gb model priced at €949 ($1,076), and a top-end 128gb model priced at €1,049 ($1,189). the curved screen has caused manufacturing issues, leading to potential yield problems and limited supply upon release. samsung has been struggling to make the curved displays and the pricing could deter popularity. both versions are expected to feature all-metal bodies and wireless charging capabilities built-in. samsung is a member of multiple wireless charging organizations, and with the upcoming galaxy smartphones, users will enter a new wireless world.
2399	a coalition of liberal and progressive groups, including unions and civil rights activists, held a rally at the lincoln memorial in washington d.c. on saturday to push for good jobs, immigration and education reform. the "one nation working together" rally came a month before midterm elections and aimed to present a positive alternative to negative rhetoric and the tea party movement. naacp president ben jealous stated that the movement is not an alternative to the tea party but an antidote, inviting a conservative speaker to the rally who did not address the group. the rally focused on issues such as direct assistance for unemployed workers, a minimum wage increase, and health care reform. organizers claimed widespread support from various groups, including senior citizens, veterans, and faith leaders. the rally followed glenn beck's tea party rally at the same location in august, which sparked controversy due to its proximity to martin luther king jr.'s "i have a dream" speech anniversary. speakers included the reverend al sharpton, who urged attendees to vote in the upcoming midterm elections.
2400	the republican primary race for the presidential nomination is heating up as the halfway point approaches, and the question of inevitability for former massachusetts governor mitt romney's campaign is a topic of conversation. while romney holds a significant lead in delegates, with 519, his opponents former senator rick santorum, former house speaker newt gingrich, and representative ron paul still have a mathematical chance to win the nomination with 239, 138, and 69 delegates, respectively. the primary contests come down to amassing as many delegates as possible, with 1,144 needed to win the nomination. the allocation of delegates varies from state to state, and the road to 1,144 is challenging for all candidates due to proportional delegates and winner-take-all contests. unpledged delegates, who are not required to vote based on the state results, could play a significant role in the outcome. the campaign strategies of santorum, gingrich, and paul differ, with santorum focusing on the may contests, gingrich leveraging texas and endorsements, and paul attempting to pick up delegates during state conventions. the importance of unpledged delegates and the crucial role of party leaders, such as the party chair and national committee members, cannot be overlooked as they can influence delegates on the second or third ballot in a brokered convention. romney aims to lock up delegates before the convention to avoid a floor fight and prepare for the general election against president barack obama.
2401	a new study published in the journal pediatrics found that children with autism spectrum disorder (asd) or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd) spend more time playing video games and are at an increased risk of gaming addictions than typically developing children. a survey of 141 boys between the ages of 8 and 18 revealed that children with asd played 2.1 hours of video games daily, those with adhd played 1.7 hours, and normally developing children played 1.2 hours. children with asd or adhd were also more likely to have a video game system in their rooms. the researchers found that children with asd or adhd were more likely to exhibit symptoms of video game addiction, with inattention and role-playing games being the main drivers of problematic video game use. the american academy of pediatrics recommends that children limit their screen time to 2 hours per day.
2402	matt cain's summer holiday was ruined when he experienced yet another fainting episode, which left him terrified and anxious about the condition he had lived with since childhood. despite numerous diagnoses, including epilepsy and psychological causes, cain remained undiagnosed for 30 years. his attacks, which could be triggered by various factors or occur randomly, made everyday activities challenging and caused significant anxiety. cain's condition, autonomically mediated syncope with asystole, was eventually diagnosed through a tilt table test at the national hospital for neurology in london. the physical condition involves defects in the pathways between the brain and heart, causing the heart to shut down and interrupting blood flow to the brain. although the brain can usually restart the heart, the risk is significant injury from falling during an attack. following the diagnosis and pacemaker implantation, cain was able to come off medication and regain his energy and memory. however, he experienced a high number of activations from his pacemaker in the first month, which led to a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder and a decision to leave his stressful job to pursue his dream of writing novels. cain's debut romantic comedy novel, "shot through the heart," was published in april 2014 by pan macmillan.
2403	a woman in far north queensland who died from a multi-drug resistant strain of tuberculosis (tb) in september has caused five people who had contact with her to test positive for the dormant form of the disease during screenings. the positive results do not mean they are currently infectious, as the individuals likely have a latent form of tb, which is not contagious. the woman, who traveled regularly to the torres strait and papua new guinea, is believed to have been the source of infection for these individuals. thirty people have been tested, with twenty more still to undergo screening. the cairns tb control unit is handling the situation.
2404	china-based criminals have begun producing almost perfect bi-metallic coins, raising concerns about the vulnerability of the £2 coin to a new wave of forgeries. historically, £1 coins have been heavily faked, but the £2 coin's production process, which involves connecting two metal pieces together, has deterred counterfeiters. however, a recent seizure of over £390,000 worth of fake euros in italy revealed that forgers are now mass-producing bi-metallic coins. the leader of the criminal group behind this operation is believed to be operating from shanghai, china. the royal mint has stated that £2 coins are difficult to forge due to their bi-color design and security features such as edge lettering and latent elements. a recent survey in the uk identified only one fake £2 coin, and the royal mint works closely with hm treasury, the national crime agency, and the cash-handling industry to remove counterfeit coins from circulation.
2405	a design studio has created a customized dress for women using 3d printing technology, which takes 48 hours to print and costs £1,900. the dress, named a "4d dress," features 2,279 printed panels interconnected by 3,316 hinges and can change from a compressed object to its intended shape. the company uses selective laser sintering to print the dress using nylon powder. they have also developed a smartphone and tablet app that allows users to manipulate their dresses in terms of pattern, style, and flexibility. the founders believe that this technology is the future of fashion as it allows for more personal and customized garments.
2406	a retired mother-of-one, ksenia martin, is "devastated" after discovering that a new £150 million roundabout permanently blocked access to her recently refurbished £20,000 driveway in nottinghamshire. mrs. martin, who bought her house in 2011, spent the money on landscaping and repairing her driveway, but was unaware that the roundabout plans would prevent her from using it permanently. she has been unable to sell her house since the start of the roadworks and has been left feeling isolated and vulnerable due to the distance from the small parking area provided by the highways agency. the agency offered to explore the possibility of a new access route but was unsuccessful. mrs. martin and her daughter, lisa eden, have expressed their frustration and concern for her well-being. the highways agency stated that standard practice includes engaging with stakeholders and carrying out public consultations before finalizing plans, which were in place when mrs. martin purchased the property.
2407	a 47-year-old woman identified as rachida h. has been charged with murder after storming into a classroom in albi, south-west france, and stabbing 34-year-old fabienne calmes, a mother of two, to death in front of her five- and six-year-old students. the suspect, who was arrested shortly after the incident, is currently being held in a psychiatric unit, as she is being considered mentally disturbed. the attack took place on the last day before the summer holidays at the edouard herriot school. fabienne calmes was pronounced dead at the scene around 11am, and it was reported that she had been previously cautioned for child neglect. france's education minister and president condemned the crime, which is the fifth known case of a teacher being killed in a french classroom over the past three decades. rachida h. faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted.
2408	a 16-year-old graffiti artist named sam opolli, also known by the tag name 'tame,' died after falling from a three-story-high industrial building while spray painting in digbeth, birmingham, over the weekend. opolli, who worked in a pub, was found by a passerby in the early hours of sunday and later died at birmingham's queen elizabeth hospital with his family by his side. his father, john opolli, sent out a plea on facebook for his brother to reach the hospital before sam's passing. sam's father and other family and friends have since paid tribute to him online. the derelict building where the tragedy occurred now has a graffiti tribute reading "rest in peace bro" next to one of sam's tags. an inquest into sam's death is scheduled for next week.
2409	the food and drug administration (fda) estimates that new graphic cigarette labels, which include images of diseased lungs, dead bodies, and a man with a tracheotomy, will reduce the number of smokers in the us by 213,000 in 2013. these labels, which feature phrases such as "smoking can kill you" and "cigarettes cause cancer," are part of the most significant change to us cigarette packaging in 25 years. all cigarette packages and advertisements will be required to feature these labels, which take up the top half of the pack, starting in october 2012. the mandate is part of a law passed in 2009 that gives the fda authority to regulate tobacco. while it is impossible to determine exactly how many people quit smoking due to the labels, studies suggest they do encourage quitting. the new labels will appear on about 46 million packs of cigarettes used by approximately 20% of adults in the us, and the fda estimates that these labels will lead to a total reduction of 1 million smokers by 2031. tobacco companies have voiced concerns about the impact of the labels on their branding but have yet to comment on the final design. the fda believes the new labels will effectively convey the health risks of smoking and encourage current smokers to quit and deter youth from starting.
2410	three south koreans died after allegedly inhaling toxic gas while constructing a nuclear power plant in ulsan. the incident came days after hackers published documents on nuclear facilities and threatened to disable the control systems of the state-run korea hydro and nuclear power company. the workers are believed to have been killed by a nitrogen leak, which is used in power plants for various purposes. authorities suspect a nitrogen leak caused the accident but have yet to confirm the cause. the company is scheduled to complete construction of the plant in june. last week, south korean employees conducted cybersecurity drills in response to the hackers' threats. the hackers published stolen nuclear documents online with the signature "who am i?" the company maintains that the safety of the country's nuclear power plants was not affected by the threats.
2411	a heart-warming story about larissa and ian murphy, a pennsylvania couple whose love survived despite ian's debilitating brain injury. the couple met in college in 2005 and were planning to marry in december 2006. however, ian's plans were put on hold when he got into a serious car crash that left him unable to communicate. larissa moved in with his family to support him and wait for his recovery, continuing to date him despite his condition. they were eventually married in 2008, but with ian's continued disability, the couple faced numerous challenges, including getting approval from a judge to marry. despite the hardships, larissa remained devoted to ian and continues to care for him while working to support their household. they are determined to live their lives together with faith and love.
2412	a business dispute resulted in a lone gunman shooting and killing businessman peter thompson, 59, and his son john, 36, at their farm and horse-riding center in auldhouse, lanarkshire, scotland. the gunman, believed to be robert mccormick, 53, took his own life shortly after the shooting. police are investigating the incident, which they believe was targeted, and have urged the public to stay calm. the thompsons had been involved in disputes regarding illegal dumping and business debts, and had both previously been made bankrupt. one neighbor reported hearing a helicopter and police cars in the area shortly after the shooting, and armed officers attended the scene to secure the area. superintendent elaine ferguson of police scotland confirmed that both men had died and that a 36-year-old man was injured and receiving treatment in the hospital. police are not searching for any other suspects in connection with the incident.

2414	the united states is advising airlines with direct flights to russia to be cautious about potential explosives concealed in toothpaste or cosmetic tubes, according to a house homeland security committee chairman. a department of homeland security bulletin warned of the threat, indicating that authorities believe the explosives might be used during flights or smuggled into sochi, where the winter olympics are being held. the concern arises as the games begin, with increasing confidence about the safety of the venues but increasing worry about targets outside the area, including transportation links. u.s. intelligence is picking up increased chatter about potential threats, focusing on groups based in russia's caucasus region and al-qaeda-linked groups from elsewhere. the threat, based on credible information, has led to heightened security measures at airports worldwide and a ban on carry-on liquids in russia. u.s. authorities have been sharing intelligence with the russians, who have reportedly rounded up and poisoned stray dogs in the city in preparation for the games. travelers are encouraged to take the threat seriously and be alert but officials have not discouraged travel to sochi. authorities have been especially focused on aviation security since the 9/11 attacks, with a shift from hijackings to bombs and an increased concern for creative packaging or novel ways to conceal explosives.
2415	the new york society library discovered two books, "law of nations" and the 12th volume of "common debates," were checked out by president george washington in 1789 but never returned. the fine for the late return has accumulated over 221 years, amounting to over $4,000, and the library is unsure where the books are or if they'll ever be returned. the library recently rediscovered the old ledger in their basement that documented the missing books. since the fine was based on pre-decimal currency, it has significantly increased over time. the library is more concerned about recovering the missing books than the fine.
2416	the tropical rainforests of brazil and indonesia are home to an estimated two-thirds of earth's terrestrial species, according to the secretariat of the convention on biological diversity. the exact number of species that depend on these ancient ecosystems, which have endured for millions of years, is unknown. yasuni national park in ecuador, which covers less than 0.5% of the amazon basin, is estimated to contain around 100,000 species of insects alone. a typical 10-square-kilometer patch of rainforest can host up to 1,500 flowering plants, 750 tree species, 400 bird species, and 150 butterfly species. new species are continually being discovered, such as the pac-man frog and crayola katydid. these forests also provide valuable resources like timber, agricultural land, food, water, minerals, and energy, as well as medicinal and commercial products. the millennium ecosystem assessment in 2005 identified over 5,000 commercial products derived from forests. the loss of these rainforests can lead to the extinction of many species and the loss of significant biodiversity.
2417	three drunken stockbrokers, archie madden, vinny sullivan, and simon abouzaki, have been jailed for assaulting a man outside a london club after they harassed his girlfriend. edward blackman was kicked and punched as he lay helpless on the ground, suffering only a black eye and bruises. madden was sentenced to 60 weeks, sullivan to 10 months, and abouzaki to 18 months after his suspended sentence for possessing mdma was activated. a fourth broker, faisal khan, received a community order with 150 hours of unpaid work for throwing the initial punches. the attack was captured on cctv, and judge alistair mcreath criticized their dangerous behavior, stating that by good fortune, the victim's injuries were not more severe. blackman, from st. albans, called for the brokers to be barred from working in banking after the shocking attack.
2418	britain had an extraordinary night at the olympics with three gold medals in track and field. jessica ennis won the heptathlon with a thrilling finish in the 800m, just 45 points shy of the 7,000-point barrier. greg rutherford took the long jump title, his first for a british athlete since 1964, with a jump of 8.31m. mo farah denied ethiopian great kenenisa bekele a hat-trick in the men's 10,000 meters, crossing the line in 27:30.42 seconds. farah's win was the sixth gold for britain on the day, with two in rowing and one in track cycling. shelly-ann fraser-pryce retained her olympic 100m title for jamaica in a close race against carmelita jeter, with a time of 10.75 seconds. jamaica's strength in sprinting was further evidenced with the approaching men's 100m final.

2420	american airlines announced on tuesday that it will inspect 47 boeing 757 aircraft after seats came loose on two of its jetliners. one flight diverted to new york's jfk airport on saturday, and the other returned on monday. the company initially planned to evaluate eight planes but increased the number due to safety concerns. the root cause of the issue was identified as saddle clamps improperly installed on the foot of the row legs. thirty-six planes have been inspected, with six having loose seats. the federal aviation administration is investigating the incidents. additionally, an american airlines flight from chicago to london was diverted to shannon airport in ireland due to a smoky odor, and an overhead fan was found to be the source of the issue. american airlines has faced labor troubles, delays, and flight cancellations, with over 1,000 flights canceled and 12,000 delayed in the past month alone. negotiations between the airline and pilots union are set to resume this week. the transport workers union of america dismissed the notion that the seat issues were linked to labor problems.

2422	ian brady, the moors murderer who, along with myra hindley, was responsible for the murders of five children in the 1960s, is expected to appear at a mental health tribunal next week despite suffering from broken bones in his back and a recent seizure. brady, who has been on a hunger strike for 12 years and is currently tube-fed, wants to be declared sane and allowed to die in prison. he was taken to aintree university hospital for treatment and was kept under guard in a private room. the public was outraged that taxpayer money was being spent on treating him, especially since some patients had to wait long hours for treatment. brady and hindley lured and sexually tortured their victims before burying their bodies on saddleworth moor. they were convicted and jailed for life in 1966. hindley died in jail in 2002.
2423	a former model, traci vaillancourt, who lost her good looks due to drug addiction and whose boyfriend, timothy troy walker, shot and killed police sergeant derek johnson in utah in 2013, has been released from jail after accepting a plea agreement. vaillancourt was initially charged with obstructing justice but has avoided trial and a potential lengthy sentence by agreeing to a deal that will see her spend the next 36 months on probation. her boyfriend, walker, has already been sentenced to life in prison for the murder. sgt. johnson's widow welcomed the decision to avoid a trial and relive the trauma of the murder. vaillancourt's addiction to pain medication started after she was diagnosed with a rare blood disorder following the birth of her first child. her older sister revealed that her sibling's downward spiral into drug addiction began after she became dependent on her pain medication following multiple strokes before the age of 30. the couple was previously living out of motels and sleeping in their car before the shootings occurred.
2424	a transgender teacher, mark krolikowski, is suing st. francis preparatory school in queens, new york, for discrimination after being terminated in august 2012 following the disclosure of his gender identity. krolikowski, 59, had taught at the catholic institution for 32 years and was a beloved and respected teacher among students. he alleges that his employment was terminated illegally after a parent expressed concerns over his long hair and fancy nails, and that school officials discriminated against him following his admission of being transgender. krolikowski's lawsuit accuses the school and its principal, leonard conway, of breaking the law with his termination, and claims that he was branded 'worse than gay' and asked to 'appear as a woman' in the next school year. the lawsuit maintains that krolikowski's termination violated new york state and city laws against discrimination based on gender identity. the school and its principal have not commented on the allegations, but their lawyer, philip semprevivo jr., denied all allegations and said the contract was terminated legally. former students have launched an online petition in support of krolikowski, describing him as a beloved teacher and an influential figure during their time at st. francis. the petition urges the school to apologize. krolikowski says he had always been openly himself at the school, and his students and colleagues were accepting of his gender identity, which was never a problem until the dispute with the parent. the lawsuit also alleges that krolikowski was asked to 'tone down' his appearance by removing his earrings and french manicure, which he refused to do.

following the jimmy savile scandal. thompson, who left the bbc last month, admitted in an interview with the new york times that he first learned about the investigation into savile's sexual abuse allegations last christmas from bbc foreign correspondent caroline hawley. however, in a previous interview with the new york times, thompson claimed he "never heard any allegations" about savile during his tenure as director general. thompson then spoke to an unnamed senior executive and bbc head of news helen boaden, who assured him that the investigation was dropped for journalistic reasons. but thompson's inconsistent account and the new york times public editor margaret sullivan's concerns about his role in the savile scandal have raised doubts about his suitability for the job. sullivan wrote in a blog post that it's "worth considering now whether he is the right person for the job, given this turn of events." the savile scandal has engulfed the bbc after an itv documentary accused him of being a paedophile who abused hundreds of young victims, including on the corporation's premises. newsnight had carried out its own investigation into savile, including an interview with a victim, but the report was shelved at the last minute. the bbc has now launched two inquiries into the affair, one to address savile's actions and how he went undetected during his career, and the other to examine why the newsnight report was pulled. thompson's predecessor at the bbc, george entwistle, was grilled by mps in parliament this week over allegations that the broadcaster covered up savile's crimes. thompson's spokesman ed williams claimed thompson had been "speculating" about the investigation and that it was "totally reasonable for institutions like the new york times and the bbc to be free to examine everything, including subjects of corporate interest in the institution itself." thompson
2434	home ownership in australia can be costlier than expected, with a mortgage of under $500,000 potentially ending up costing over $1 million by the time it's paid off, according to finder.com.au's michelle hutchison. sydney has the most expensive median house price of $825,000, meaning borrowers will surpass $1 million by year 11. hutchison advocates for borrowers to consider different loan options, interest rates, and haggling with lenders to secure better deals. she suggests paying extra each month or week to save money over time. the research by finder.com.au found that for melbourne's median house price of $633,000, a mortgage of $506,400 would cost $1.035 million over 30 years. the average variable rate of 5.5% was used in the calculations, but hutchison emphasized the importance of considering various loan offers to avoid unwanted costs. borrowers can use online tools and calculators to compare home loans and determine monthly repayments. additionally, haggling with lenders and paying extra can lead to significant savings.
2435	muhammad saad iqbal, a pakistani citizen, was released from the guantanamo bay detention facility in cuba after serving over six years without being charged. iqbal is currently considering suing the u.s. government for unlawful detention and seeks compensation for the loss of seven years of his life. he was taken into u.s. custody in 2002 while visiting family in indonesia and was accused of making a shoe bomb threat, which he denies. iqbal alleges he was tortured during his time at guantanamo, including beatings during a six-month hunger strike and withheld medical treatment until he cooperated. former president bush and senior officials have repeatedly denied using torture on detainees, but iqbal says he attempted suicide multiple times while in custody. iqbal was among nearly 800 individuals classified as suspected terrorists held at guantanamo, most of whom were never charged with a crime and were released without charge with the help of a u.s.-based lawyer. iqbal is demanding justice but intends to pursue this through legal means rather than violence. president obama signed three executive orders on thursday to close the guantanamo facility within a year, ban torture, and establish an inter-agency task force to review detention policies and individual cases.
2436	landscape gardener patrick norfolk, 65, who was diagnosed with motor neurone disease in 2008 and had been desperately wanting to die peacefully in his garden surrounded by his family, took the agonizing decision to end his life at the dignitas clinic in switzerland due to britain's laws against assisted suicide. his wife anne, 58, spoke out for the first time about his death in june, hoping it would reignite the debate over the country's "barbaric and archaic" laws. patrick's youngest daughter, vicky, had committed suicide in 2011 due to depression, and his condition and her death left him feeling hopeless and wanting to spare his family the misery of watching him die. anne and their daughters bridget and colette flew to switzerland with him, and patrick died outside surrounded by nature. nearly 200 people from britain have ended their lives at dignitas since it was set up in 1998, but opponents argue that it is a violation of medical ethics. the motor neurone disease association has a neutral stance on the issue.
2437	u.s. skiing star lindsey vonn, a four-time overall world cup champion and olympic gold medalist, has been sidelined for over two years due to knee injuries and missed the 2014 winter olympics. her boyfriend, golf star tiger woods, went through similar rehab and provided support and motivation. woods, a 14-time major champion, struggled with injury-plagued 2014 and also missed the ryder cup. vonn empathizes with woods' media attention and defended him against critical articles. she called their relationship competitive, with vonn holding a hole-in-one against woods' superior ping-pong skills.
2438	julian barnes, the man booker prize-winning author, has expressed concerns about the increasing pressure on writers to include explicit sex scenes in literature. he believes that graphically describing intercourse exposes authors to being ridiculed by future generations. barnes cited the three cardinal sins of bad sex writing as being too pornographic, too facetious, or overly solemn. he highlighted the use of "safe" clichés such as the wrong underpants and impotence as replacements for old euphemisms. barnes believes british literature began writing more detailed sex scenes after the failure of the lady chatterley's lover obscenity trial in 1960. he added that using a comic tone can lead to bad sex writing as it is difficult to be funny about good sex. barnes, who won the man booker prize in 2011 for "the sense of an ending," also expressed concerns about vocabulary and naming body parts in literary descriptions of sex. he mentioned that comparing the male member to a yam, as john updike did in one novel, can distract from the sexual encounter rather than enhance it.
2439	nbc's olympics coverage has come under criticism for manufacturing unnecessary suspense during the women's gymnastics final between the us and russia, with russia's ksenia afanaseva's cringe-worthy stumble on the floor exercise being a major factor. the us dominated the competition, leading by a five-point margin before afanaseva's fall, which led to tears from russian team members and the silver medal for their team. the russian team struggled throughout the final with issues on the balance beam and other events, leaving them unable to challenge the us for gold. nbc was criticized for not showing afanaseva's fall during its broadcast and for creating doubt about the us performance, which the network denied. the us team, led by aly raisman, celebrated an astonishing victory, earning their place in history and receiving congratulations from president obama and celebrities like justin bieber and taylor swift. the nbc olympics coverage has faced intense scrutiny this year due to social media, with criticisms ranging from spoilers to content decisions. the network has issued apologies and acknowledged the issues, but viewers continue to express their frustrations.
2440	john hay, a retired marketing director from barningham, county durham, transformed a former british telecom phone box into a miniature world war i museum. filled with newspapers, collectables, and memorabilia from 1914, the phone box, now known as the listening post, includes historic items such as replica brass tins, tin helmets, maps, and a copy of the village flyer disguised as the trench magazine "wipers times." the phone box also features memorabilia related to soldiers' experiences, like sandbags, toy rats, and bully beef tins. hay created the museum after painting a portrait of his world war i veteran grandfather and named it in honor of the 15 men from barningham who died in the war. the green phone box, which was sold to the parish council for £1 in 2012, previously contained a carpet, a beer glass, and spiders. hay has since used it as an art gallery, displaying new works every three months.
2441	the abandoned summer resorts in upstate new york's sullivan and ulster counties serve as hauntingly beautiful reminders of the once-popular borscht belt area, which was famed for being a glamorous holiday destination for the middle-class jewish community and easily accessible from new york city. renowned resorts like grossinger's in liberty and the homowack lodge in wurtsboro village, which boasted amenities such as bowling alleys and swimming pools, were the epitome of luxury and recreation during the 1960s. however, these grand structures have fallen into disrepair and now lie abandoned, retaining their former grandeur in decaying images. grossinger's, which closed in 1986, and the homowack lodge are among the many forgotten hotels that once offered relief from the summer heat, but now stand as eerie symbols of a bygone era. photographer bellink's works showcase these abandoned sites in all their stark beauty, capturing their decay and relics, like giant toy rockets, with a sense of longing and illusion. the images of these once-grand venues now covered in snow and gathering dust speak to the passing of an era and the remnants of its colorful past.
2442	pauline phillips, who wrote under the pen name "dear abby," passed away at the age of 94 in minneapolis, minnesota, after a long battle with alzheimer's disease. phillips began writing the advice column in 1956 and it quickly became the most widely syndicated column in the world, with a daily readership of over 110 million. she became known for her direct, no-nonsense advice on relationships, family matters, and other issues. born in sioux city, iowa, in 1918, phillips ventured into journalism in 1955 and gained success with her advice column, which advocated for equal rights and promoted awareness on various social issues. she is survived by her husband of 73 years, mort phillips, daughter jeanne phillips, four grandchildren, and two great-granddaughters.
2443	nelson mandela, south africa's first black president and a nobel peace prize laureate, died at the age of 95 surrounded by family. mandela's passing was mourned by people around the world, with many recognizing his role in peacefully ending an era of white domination in south africa and his remarkable lack of bitterness and commitment to reconciliation. mandela's body was moved to a military hospital in pretoria and is expected to lie in state in the coming days before a state funeral and burial. the african national congress, the political party long associated with mandela, hailed him as a colossus and an epitome of humility, equality, justice, peace, and hope. mourners gathered outside mandela's house and other locations around the country, singing, dancing, and paying tribute to the late leader. the united nations and leaders from around the world expressed their condolences and paid tribute to mandela's legacy. mandela, who had spent 27 years in prison for fighting apartheid, emerged as a global symbol of forgiveness and reconciliation. he left the presidency in 1999 but remained an international ambassador for peace and human rights until his retirement from public life due to health issues.
2444	gascoigne primary school in barking, east london, which had 90% english-speaking pupils in 1997, now has only 10% with over 60 different languages spoken. the school, which has over 1,100 students, faces significant challenges due to the influx of children from diverse linguistic backgrounds. about 30% of new arrivals don't speak english and struggle to cope, impacting the education of english speakers. critics argue this trend may widen the educational gap between less-prosperous and more affluent backgrounds. the documentary highlights cases of students from bulgaria and portugal having difficulties and the role of eal teachers and support assistants in helping them improve. gascoigne was rated 'good' by ofsted, but its test results for 11-year-olds are below the national average. some parents appreciate the school's multicultural environment, while others, like education expert alan smithers, express concerns.
2445	a former mother of the year in san diego, california, named kathy j. rowe, 53, was recently sentenced to five years probation, one year of electronic surveillance, and a 10-year protective order against a couple whom she had terrorized after they outbid her for her dream home in 2011. rowe had advertised on the internet for men to visit their home for sex and claimed it was the wife's fantasy to be raped, even distributing her photo and address. jerry rice and janice ruhter reported experiencing mysteriously listed homes for sale online, inundated mail, and ads inviting men to their house for a "freak show." rowe, a county administrative analyst, was charged with solicitation of rape and stalking. she expressed her regret in court but felt no harm was intended, stating that it was a response to losing the house due to miscommunication with real estate agents and the grief and anger that followed. the judgment was handed down after she pleaded guilty to stalking charges, and felony charges for soliciting rape and sodomy, and misdemeanor charges for identity theft and harassment were dropped. the victims believe that the situation could have escalated if law enforcement had not intervened.
2446	this seventeenth-century barn, originally from acton hall in suffolk, is up for sale for £100,000 in dismantled form. made from solid oak beams, it has been stored for 25 years and will require diy to reassemble. each piece is numbered, and an expert will assist in its rebuilding. the barn was dismantled and sold to a brewery for a planned function venue, but a suitable location was never found. now it's back on the market at summers place auction house. measuring 121ft long, 28ft wide, and 25ft tall when rebuilt, the buyer will need an additional £100,000 to fully restore it. the barn's historic framework, hand-hewn from oak, is in excellent condition, making it a unique and exceptional building. formerly a thatched tithe barn and later a country house, it is an ideal candidate for a wedding venue.
2447	in the summer of 1989, nasa's voyager 2 spacecraft became the first and only spacecraft to visit neptune, providing unprecedented images of the planet's largest moon, triton. a newly restored video and map of triton's surface have been released, revealing its detailed features in high resolution. voyager 2 was launched in 1977, and along with its twin voyager 1, they have been exploring the outer reaches of the solar system since then. the missions primary objective was the exploration of jupiter and saturn, but they were later extended to visit uranus and neptune. triton is 1,681 miles across, icy, and may even have clouds in its skies. the map, with a resolution of 1,970 feet per pixel, shows details of triton's dynamic and active surface, which can be compared with other active worlds in the solar system, such as europa and enceladus. voyager 2 is currently in interstellar space, and next year, nasa's new horizons probe will flyby the dwarf planet pluto, using the experiences and data from voyager 2's encounter with triton to maximize the information gained from the mission. the scientists involved hope for future missions to explore uranus, neptune or both, with modern scientific instruments. in another milestone for the voyager mission, 25 august also marks the two-year anniversary of voyager 1 reaching interstellar space.
2448	"50/50" is a comedy-drama about a young man named adam, played by joseph gordon-levitt, who receives a diagnosis of a rare form of cancer. his best friend, played by seth rogen, learns of adam's 50/50 chances of survival and tries to help him through his ordeal, showing growth and maturity. adam deals with his diagnosis in a clumsy and often humorous way, while most of the dramatic weight falls on gordon-levitt's understated performance. the film touches on practical concerns of cancer treatment, such as getting to and from the hospital, and features a strong supporting cast including anna kendrick as a trainee therapist, anjelica huston as adam's difficult mother, and bryce dallas howard as his girlfriend. the film handles the balance between comedy and pathos effectively and offers a realistic, but not unpredictable, look at cancer and its impact on patients and their loved ones.
2449	an 18-year-old student named nida naseer from newport, south wales vanished from her parents' house in december 2020 following a disagreement over cultural differences. her body was found in marshland three months later, and despite extensive searches and emotional appeals, no credible sightings of her were reported. the circumstances surrounding her death remain a mystery, as a post-mortem examination revealed no sign of injuries and the cause of her death could not be determined. on the night of her disappearance, the river usk was on flood alert, and an expert suggested that nida might have fallen into the river from the southern distributor bridge. nida had wanted to pursue her education at university but couldn't due to her family's inability to pay for her tuition fees after their asylum claim was denied. her claim for asylum was turned down, leaving her degree dreams in tatters. an open verdict was recorded at the inquest.
2450	tens of thousands of people have been displaced from their homes due to the bursting of the river elbe dams in eastern germany, which led to extensive flooding and the closure of a major railway route. at least 21 flood-related deaths have been reported in central europe following a week of heavy rain. in magdeburg, around 23,000 people had to leave their homes after the city flooded and lost power. elsewhere, ten villages had to be evacuated due to the breach of a levee in fischbeck, west of berlin. more than 7,000 soldiers and volunteers laid out a million sandbags to strengthen flood defenses along the river elbe and the danube, which have affected germany, austria, slovakia, poland, and the czech republic in the worst floods in a decade. the danube river, which flows through four capital cities and ten countries, started rising rapidly in hungary last friday. at least 1,400 people have been evacuated from towns and villages along the danube, and 44 roads have been closed. officials have warned that the next two days will be crucial in efforts to contain the flooding, with budapest, the heart of hungary, now at risk.

properly. the woman, identified as kathy, claimed she was raped by shorten during a young labor conference in portarlington, victoria, in 1986. she handed the police a 19-page statement with details of the alleged incident and the names of three witnesses. however, kathy alleges that the police failed to locate any of the witnesses. in a statement to daily mail australia, victoria police said that they had investigated the allegation as they would any other sexual assault claim and sought advice from the office of public prosecutions, which advised there was no reasonable prospect of conviction. kathy, who waived her right to anonymity, has expressed her disappointment and frustration with the police, stating that she believed her case would have been handled differently if shorten was not a prominent figure. shorten's spokesperson stated that he would not be making any further comments, and deputy labor leader tanya plibersek stated that the allegations were thoroughly investigated by the police. the police spokesperson encouraged anyone with concerns about the manner in which the investigation was conducted to contact the professional standards command or the independent broad-based anti-corruption commission. shorten had previously dismissed the claims as 'untrue and abhorrent' and confirmed the investigation had been dropped in august 2020, stating that it had been a deeply distressing time for him and his family. the alleged victim made the claims on facebook in 2020, and the police investigation concluded that there was no basis for the claim. richard marles, the shadow minister for immigration and border protection, who is a long-time friend of shorten, also said that the allegations were not true and described it as one of the worst moments of shorten's life. the police investigation has now concluded, and shorten has made a statement clearing his name.

2460	bt, the telecommunications company, has secured the rights to broadcast champions league and europa league football matches in the uk for £900 million ($1.442 billion) over three years, outbidding sky and itv. this marks bt's biggest sporting coup and challenges sky's dominance in football broadcasting for the past two decades. bt will be the sole uk broadcaster, paying £299 million ($479 million) per season, more than double what sky and itv currently pay, indicating a highly aggressive bid. the champions league deal is part of bt's strategy to attract customers to its premium fibre broadband packages, which include free sports channels. bt has promised to make some games accessible to non-subscribers for free. the investment is intended to boost bt as a serious competitor in viewers and advertisers' eyes. bt shareholders will expect a clear return from such significant investments, which come after the group focused on cost-cutting and streamlining operations. the sports tv strategy's success remains uncertain, as the recent acquisitions lowered earnings. itv, unsuccessful in acquiring fa cup rights, had hoped for continued uefa offers for terrestrial television.
2461	a diary belonging to sir miles dempsey, a second world war army general, has been discovered with the week of the d-day landings (june 6-11, 1944) mysteriously cleared by a blue squiggly line. dempsey, a modest and important wartime figure, documented top secret meetings with allied commanders in the black book. he is pictured alongside king george vi and field marshal montgomery. although the reasons for erasing those days are unclear, dempsey recorded engagements after d-day with "d+1," "d+2," and noted specific divisions that landed. sir miles was the first person to be knighted on a battlefield since agincourt and played a significant role in pinning down german troops after d-day. he went from major to general in charge of half a million troops in just six years. the german high command tried to surrender to him on june 3, 1945, but he sent them away as they had to surrender to field marshal bernard montgomery by protocol. the diary, along with letters of congratulations from dwight eisenhower and montgomery, photos, and an order of service for a church service before d-day, is being sold as part of an archive and has a pre-sale estimate of almost £40,000. the auction takes place on june 26. commemoration events, including an international flotilla of ships and ceremonies at the beaches of normandy and bayeux cathedral, will mark the 70th anniversary of d-day, which involved 132,000 soldiers and 11,000 aircraft, and resulted in approximately 10,000 deaths.
2462	a teenager named natasha evans from tyne and wear was shocked after discovering a missing 3ft royal python in her bath tub. the snake, which had been slithering around under the floorboards for months, belonged to a previous neighbor who had reported it missing in july. the royal python, also known as a ball python, is a non-venomous african snake that can go months without food during the winter breeding season. the evans family was unaware of the snake's presence and expressed concern for their pets, including their dog, if it had come into contact with them. the missing snake has since been removed from the house, but the family remains worried about potential hidden snakes in the floorboards and is considering having the house checked thoroughly. the royal python is known for its tendency to curl into a ball when stressed or frightened, and can grow up to 6ft long.
2463	an internal va audit report revealed systemic issues within the veterans health administration (vha) system, including questionable scheduling practices and a lack of integrity at some facilities. these concerns were raised in 216 site audit reports, prompting secretary eric shinseki to resign after meeting with president obama. the audit covered scheduling practices at 258 points of access to medical care and uncovered complications in meeting wait-time targets, improper scheduling instructions, and pressures placed on schedulers to manipulate waiting times. the va is conducting another audit and plans to hold accountable those responsible for undesired practices. obama has urged for swift action to address the va's troubled history and find a new leader capable of regaining veterans' trust.
2464	asda, a supermarket in the uk, is now offering 3d printing services for customers, making it the first supermarket in the country to do so. the service allows customers to get detailed 3d-printed miniature versions of themselves or other objects, starting at £40. the process involves scanning the object with asda's portable 3d scanner, which captures the image and sends it to a 3d printing factory where it is recreated using high-quality ceramic. anything can be scanned, including people, cars, and items. the lifelike figures can be made in color, white, or covered in a bronze-style coating, and are expected to be popular as personalized wedding cake toppers or family pet models. asda's 3d printing scanner uses cameras to capture the entire surface area of the subject in around two minutes. in related news, a group from texas-based systems and materials research corporation has created a 3d-printed pizza using dough, ketchup, and cream cheese. the printer lays down layers of these materials and then bakes the pizza on a heated surface. the software can identify up to six million different colors, and the figures can be scaled to whatever size the customer wants. asda plans to trial the service in its york store starting october 15 and aims to roll it out nationwide in the future.

2467	liverpool striker ryan babel has been charged by the english football association (fa) for improper conduct following his criticism of referee howard webb on twitter after sunday's fa cup third round match between liverpool and manchester united. webb awarded a controversial first-minute penalty against liverpool, resulting in liverpool captain steven gerrard being sent off and manchester united winning 1-0. babel posted a mocked-up image of webb wearing a manchester united shirt and expressed his displeasure in a tweet, which he later apologized for. the fa has stated that babel has until thursday to respond to the charge, the first time such action has been taken over a twitter posting. babel has previously faced issues for his tweets, having to apologize for criticizing former liverpool manager rafael benitez.
2468	actress kelly rutherford has filed an emergency motion in a new york court to prevent her children from returning to france to live with their father, daniel griesch. she claims the california court ruling that awarded custody to griesch and ordered the children's return was unconstitutional and amounts to an "illegal deportation." rutherford, who petitioned the secretary of homeland security and attorney general, argues only federal courts can deal with deportation matters and wants emergency authority over her children. she also demands griesch be given a visa to enter the us. the children have been on vacation in new york with rutherford, but are set to return to france on august 19. the case is the latest development in a bitter custody battle between the former gossip girl star and griesch, which has left rutherford emotionally drained and bankrupt from legal fees and travel expenses to france. the legal action is aimed at upholding the children's rights as us citizens and ensuring they are not forced to leave the country unless ordered by a federal authority in a constitutional manner. rutherford has custody of her children 50% of the time but they live and go to school in france. the breakdown of trust between the pair led rutherford to hire a private investigator to spy on griesch regarding child custody and other matters. griesch has not commented on the matter.
2469	clare balding, a 42-year-old broadcaster, revealed that her grandmother called her "disgusting" after a newspaper reported on her being a lesbian with former newsreader alice arnold in 2003. the incident led to a six-month estrangement between them. in the same interview on desert island discs, balding also discussed her battle with thyroid cancer, which she was diagnosed with in 2009. she described herself as "hopeless" during the initial stages of her diagnosis and pretended it wasn't happening. balding eventually made peace with her grandmother after the intervention of her dog, archie. she had two operations and underwent radioactive iodine treatment before being given the all-clear in early 2011. balding refused to host the open golf championship at muirfield in 2013 due to the club's ban on women becoming members. she also spoke about being "outed" in 2003 and her grandmother's reaction to her relationship. the interview included balding's choice of music, luxury items, and book for desert island discs.
2470	the european champions, spain, were drawn in group i for the euro 2012 qualifiers along with the czech republic, scotland, lithuania, and liechtenstein. in total, there are ten groups with five or six teams each. group winners and the best runner-up, along with the hosts poland and ukraine, will qualify directly for the tournament. the other eight second-placed teams will face playoffs in november 2011. spain, the 2008 champions, will defend their title against the czech republic and other teams in their group. england, portugal, italy, and the netherlands are among the top teams in different groups, facing challenging opponents. the qualifiers will begin in september 2010.
2471	aston villa manager paul lambert is set to bring darren bent back into the first-team squad next season after owner randy lerner insisted he use all players at his disposal. the striker was frozen out last season and trained separately from the first team, but despite villa's attempts to offload him, they could not find a buyer for his £8million valuation. bent, who joined villa for an initial £18m in 2011, has a year left on his contract and will provide much-needed cover up front with christian benteke and libor kozak injured. another player set to return is charles n'zogbia, who missed the entirety of last season with an achilles injury, while alan hutton will also be back if a buyer cannot be found. tom ince has expressed his desire to join inter milan and follow in his father paul's footsteps, but his future remains uncertain. after jettisoning high-wage players last season, lambert now faces the challenge of making signings during the transfer window, with the club up for sale and uncertainty about the future. bent's return reflects lerner's desire to see more of the money spent on players used on the pitch. lambert added that christian benteke is recovering well from an injury but it's still too early to determine how long he will be out.
2472	at least 24 people were killed and 61 injured in a raid by houthi shia militants on a sunni town in northern yemen, according to medic and witness reports. the attack, which occurred in the predawn hours in sa'ada, resulted in the shelling of sunni homes with grenades, leaving the injured without medical attention due to the town being under siege. witnesses reported that the attacks were concentrated on a sunni religious center. the houthi movement, which opposes yemen's interim government, rejected a power transfer agreement signed in riyadh earlier this week and has expanded its control in several provinces. the houthi movement, led by abdul malik al-houthi, has over 100,000 fighters and controls major areas in sa'ada, jawf, amran, marib, and sana'a. sectarian violence is at a peak in northern yemen, and saudi arabia previously failed to stop the houthi expansion with military action in 2009. yemen's vice president called for presidential elections to be held in february, following the departure of president ali abdullah saleh, who stepped down after months of protests but has since returned to yemen.
2473	comedian mike birbiglia has joined the cast of "orange is the new black" for its third season on netflix. known for his critically acclaimed 2012 film "sleepwalk with me" and recent appearances in "the fault in our stars" and the upcoming "annie" film, birbiglia's role and character details have been kept secret. showrunner jenji kohan has hinted that season 3 will explore the theme of faith.
2474	khalid sheik mohammed, self-proclaimed september 11 mastermind, has filed a court document claiming that sulaiman abu ghailtan, a former osama bin laden spokesperson and son-in-law, had no involvement in the 9/11 terror attacks. mohammed stated that abu ghailtan was only al-qaida's "talking head" due to his eloquence and had no role in military operations. abu ghailtan is currently on trial in manhattan federal court for conspiring to kill americans in his role as al-qaida's spokesperson after 9/11. his lawyers argue that he made inflammatory remarks but did not conspire to carry out terrorism. khalid sheik mohammed, who is currently detained at guantanamo bay, has previously been allowed to answer written questions during abu ghailtan's court proceedings and his statements have been used in terrorism trials before. abu ghailtan was arrested in iran in 2014 after sneaking out of afghanistan and faces life in prison for representing al-qaida. the abu ghailtan case is the only trial related to the september 11 attacks taking place in new york, where the attacks occurred, as the original plan was to try khalid sheik mohammed in the same federal courthouse but it was surrendered to a military tribunal due to objections from victims and politicians.
2475	in woolwich, london, drummer lee rigby, a married father and veteran of the afghanistan war, was brutally murdered by two men, identified as michael adebolajo and michael adebowale, near his barracks. the attackers were reportedly inspired by islamist extremism and had been monitored by mi5 for eight years. adebolajo was photographed with hate preacher anjem choudary in 2007 and attempted to travel to somalia to join terrorists last year. both men were under armed guard in hospitals after being shot by police. the killing triggered a wave of national revulsion and prime minister david cameron ordered a full intelligence review. adebolajo served jail time for violence and was a member of a banned terrorist group. the second suspect was named as adebowale. the victim's friends and colleagues paid tribute to him, and thousands visited the scene to lay flowers and pay their respects. the authorities are facing questions about how the men were able to carry out the attack despite having been known to the security services for years.
2476	this cnn article focuses on an undecided young voter, cat del valle castellanos, who was raised with conservative values but grew up in a progressive environment in washington d.c. she is socially liberal and fiscally conservative and is currently struggling to decide who to vote for in the upcoming presidential election. del valle castellanos finds the debates entertaining but hasn't been swayed by them. she praises president obama for his efforts towards the youth vote and criticizes mitt romney for his stance on social issues and lack of connection with young people. del valle castellanos believes obama needs to address the national debt and offer more than just slogans, while romney needs to humanize himself and connect emotionally with voters to win her over. she concludes that she, as an undecided american, is a valuable demographic for both candidates.
2477	a report by paul revoir, published on march 4, 2013, and updated on march 5, 2013, reveals that russell crowe was spotted having lunch with his "les misérables" co-star samantha barks in los angeles. the pair were seen deep in conversation and comfortable with each other, but no overt signs of affection were present. despite speculation from an australian magazine that they were a couple, samantha's father insisted they were just friends. the two have been seen working out together and performing together in new york. russell has also publicly praised samantha on twitter. however, both russell and samantha have denied the romantic rumors. russell recently split from his wife of nine years, danielle spencer.
2478	a real estate agent's drone accidentally captured images of a topless grandmother sunbathing in her own backyard while taking photos of a neighboring property for sale. mandy lingard, 50, was embarrassed to find herself featured on the billboard advertisement and in real estate magazine, after the photos were taken several weeks ago without her knowledge. the agent, steve walsh, defended the use of drones for real estate purposes, stating that most listings benefit from elevated shots. lingard believes the agent had a responsibility to inform homeowners before taking pictures. the billboard was taken down on monday. this incident follows a similar instance in mosman, where a woman reported seeing a real estate agent's drone flying outside her apartment. the use of drones for advertising purposes is legal, provided the operator has approval and meets certain licensing requirements.
2479	a study by the website needaproperty.com found that properties on streets with rude-sounding names, such as crotch crescent, turkey cock lane, bell end, and the knob, are on average one fifth cheaper than similar homes nearby. the top three most embarrassing street names, as voted by 2,000 people, were minge lane in upton-upon-severn, worcestershire (31% of votes), slag lane in lowton, lancashire (26%), and fanny hands lane in ludford, lincolnshire (24.9%). the research compared property prices in these streets with all other streets within a quarter mile radius and found that 11 of the 15 streets had significantly cheaper properties. the average price difference was 22% or £84,000. for example, a detached house on minge lane sold for £253,389 while a similar property in longfield sold for £325,000. some residents of these streets, such as annie gray in fanny hands lane, said the cheapness of the property was a factor in their decision to move there, while others, like janette hill in slag lane, were not bothered by the potentially embarrassing names.
2480	a power outage on september 10, 2011, affected over six million people in arizona, california, and parts of mexico. the cause is still under investigation, but officials believe a single employee at the north gila substation may have tripped a 500-kv transmission line, leading to the failure of safeguards and a massive blackout. the incident left buildings and roads in darkness, causing inconvenience, vandalism, and traffic accidents. authorities quickly ruled out sabotage or terrorist activities, and restoring power was a slow process. similar power failures have occurred in recent years, including a major outage in 2003 affecting over 50 million people in the midwest and northeast.
2481	a massive water main break on sunset boulevard in los angeles caused extensive flooding on tuesday, turning streets into rivers and parts of ucla into lakes. at least 8 million to 10 million gallons of water gushed out, leading to swift-water rescues of several people and vehicles. ucla's pauley pavilion, which had undergone a multi-million-dollar renovation two years ago, was severely damaged, with volleyball courts submerged. no injuries were reported from the explosion, but the timing was unfortunate, as california is currently experiencing a drought and has implemented water restrictions. authorities are working to stop the water flow and repair the damage.
2482	the election of jorge mario bergoglio as pope francis i represents a significant shift in the influence of the roman catholic church from europe to the americas and africa. bergoglio, the third non-italian pope in a row and the first outside europe in over a millennium, is a jesuit with deep ties to italy and europe, which should appease traditionalists. his election also signifies the growing strength of the catholic church in latin america and africa, where the largest proportion of the world's 1.2 billion catholics now reside. argentina, bergoglio's birthplace, viewed his election as a source of national pride. previously mentioned candidates, such as ghanaian cardinal peter turkson, advocated for more leadership roles for developing world churches. bergoglio's appointment balances the need for tradition and the desire for change.
2483	retired nba star yao ming appeared in a 2009 public service announcement (psa) in china to reduce the consumption of shark-fin soup, which kills up to 70 million sharks annually. wildlife demand reduction efforts like yao's have seen success, with shark fin consumption in china reportedly down by 50% to 70% in the last two years. in a similar vein, education for nature vietnam plans to create a psa about the pangolin, the most trafficked mammal in the world, thanks to reader donations following a cnn feature on the animal. the extra funds will help the organization break up the pangolin trade and shut down illegal sales. education for nature vietnam has produced several psas to curb local demand for wildlife and create social shame around consumption.
2484	a bbc war reporter, jon donnison, caused outrage when he mistakenly tweeted a photograph of an injured syrian child, labeling it as from gaza, accompanied by the word "heartbreaking." the tweet, which reached donnison's 7,971 followers, was met with anger and criticism. the bbc's middle east correspondent, quentin sommerville, later acknowledged the error and apologized. donnison also apologized for the blunder. critics accused donnison of deliberate misinformation or a failure to fact-check. this is the latest in a series of embarrassing incidents for the bbc, including the lord mcalpine scandal. violence continued in the region, with six palestinian men accused of being israeli spies being executed in gaza city. palestinian children and civilians have been among the casualties in the ongoing conflict, with over 100 deaths in seven days of military operations. disorder and chaos prevailed in gaza, with palestinian gunmen dragging the body of a suspected israeli collaborator through the streets.
2485	in july 1864, the first railway murder in britain occurred when 70-year-old thomas briggs, a respectable city banker, was bludgeoned to death in a first-class train carriage from fenchurch street to hackney wick. the murder made headlines nationwide, even surpassing the coverage of the american civil war. victorian britain was shocked as they believed they were safe in their newly-industrialised nation with its railways. the suspect, franz muller, a german immigrant tailor, fled the country aboard a ship to new york, but metropolitan police detective richard tanner pursued him, eventually finding him and arresting him based on the suspicions of a cabbie and a hat found at the crime scene, which didn't belong to mr. briggs. muller was tried and hanged at newgate in front of a massive crowd, but doubts about his guilt still lingered among historians as no murder weapon was found. the riotous behavior at his hanging led to the eventual banning of public hangings. the bbc is set to air a new documentary on the case titled "murder on the victorian railway" on bbc two next thursday at 9pm.
2486	the british government is investigating allegations that computers in whitehall, the seat of the british government, were used to make insulting and abusive edits to wikipedia entries about the hillsborough disaster over a period of three years. changes included adding "blame liverpool fans" and "nothing for the victims of the heysel stadium disaster" to descriptions of the hillsborough memorial and the disaster itself. ip addresses of computers in the cabinet office, department for culture, media and sport, treasury, and solicitor general's office were traced to the edits. the families of the 96 victims who perished in the 1989 fa cup semi-final tragedy have demanded a formal inquiry. the cabinet office has pledged to make "urgent inquiries" into the matter and stressed its support for the families of the victims.
2487	in an investigation led by nbc's rossen reports, several major fashion retailers, including neiman marcus, nordstrom rack, gilt group, and belk, were found to have sold items labeled as "faux fur" but in fact made from real animal pelts. brands like michael kors, aquatalia, jacadi, and cluny were implicated, with tests at the microtrace laboratory in chicago confirming the use of real fur from animals such as coyotes, rabbits, and raccoon dogs. retailers blamed "clerical errors," but animal rights groups argue that it's a deceitful practice and that animals are cruelly killed for low-quality, cheaper alternatives to faux fur. the sale of real fur in the us was worth $1.39 billion in 2013, despite increasing moral objections. previous mislabeling incidents involve kohl's and neiman marcus. peta advises customers to avoid any fur product if there's doubt about its authenticity.
2488	liverpool legend steve nicol criticized arsenal's summer signing alexis sanchez for his performance in arsenal's 2-1 win against crystal palace, labeling it "awful." sanchez struggled to make an impact and failed to deliver accurate passes. olivier giroud also drew criticism from nicol despite playing a key role in arsenal's winning goal. arsene wenger's side needed a late winner from aaron ramsey to secure the victory. sanchez, who joined arsenal from barcelona for £30million, has been dealing with a world cup hangover and the pressure to perform after an impressive campaign with chile. the team faces besiktas in the champions league qualifier on tuesday night, and wenger is determined to secure a win.
2489	a couple who sneaked into a stranger's flat in hackney, east london, for some privacy during a party were caught on camera by the residents. the pair, who had mistakefully entered sean thorne's flat after his friends left the door open, were surprised to find themselves confronted by the housemates when they emerged. the residents, who had returned home from a night out, filmed the couple's "walk of shame" and the footage sparked a twitter storm. thorne, who was away that weekend, was alerted to the incident and the housemates even clapped as the couple left shamefully. the incident has since been dubbed the "sex burglars" by social media users.
2490	a 74-year-old british expat named robert dolby, originally from romford, essex, was sentenced to 30 years in prison for murder, rape, and attempted murder in the alpes-maritimes assizes court in nice, france. known as a 'sex-obsessed jekyll and hyde narcissist' and a 'lying pervert,' dolby was convicted of murdering annie-claude chevalier in 2010 by administering a powerful sedative and of raping and attempting to murder a 31-year-old woman in 2012. both crimes allegedly took place in dolby's flat in beausoleil and at another nearby apartment. the jury recommended a 30-year sentence, 15 of which would be without remission. dolby's name will be added to france's sex offenders list, and he will be expelled from the country upon release from prison. in 2012, a 29-year-old frenchwoman, identified as cindy, was found brutally assaulted in the beausoleil apartment block, leading police to uncover evidence linking dolby to the 2010 murder. a court-appointed psychologist described him as having a 'dr. jekyll and mr. hyde' personality, with a history of lying about his previous convictions, mostly for theft and burglary, and sexual assault in the uk in 1991. another psychiatrist diagnosed dolby with narcissistic perversion and the ability to display 'seductive hooks' while being 'emotionally anaesthetised and very cold.'
2491	five teenagers, aged between 16 and 18, died in a car crash on the a630 in conisbrough near doncaster, south yorkshire, on saturday night. the crash happened around 9.40pm in foggy conditions and involved a toyota and a seat. three males and two females were in the toyota, and a man in the seat was taken to hospital with a broken leg. a 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving. the road was closed for over five hours and reopened at around 3am. the crash site is approximately 100 yards from where three teenagers died in a similar accident three years ago. tributes to the teenagers who died in the previous crash are still visible at the scene. south yorkshire police and fire and rescue service expressed their condolences to the families affected.
2492	new jersey governor chris christie, who underwent lap-band surgery in february 2013 to lose weight, is still considered too heavy by image experts to run for president according to a daily mail report. sylvie di giusto, an image expert, believes christie needs to continue losing weight as his face plays a significant role in politics, and voters want to see discipline and action from their leaders. despite ongoing speculation about christie's chances as a gop presidential contender in 2016, he has assured the public that he is up for the rigors of a campaign and feels healthier since his weight loss. however, some critics have mocked his weight, as seen in an unflattering time magazine cover, and mitt romney allegedly passing him over as a vice presidential candidate due to health concerns. christie, who weighed over 330 pounds before surgery, claims he is halfway to his goal weight and is still in the process of getting used to his new eating habits.
2493	a communications watchdog, ofcom, is investigating the bbc motoring show top gear over a controversial episode where presenter jeremy clarkson made a comment that some consider racially offensive towards people of asian descent. the incident occurred during filming in burma and thailand in march, where clarkson and his co-stars built a bridge over the river kwai. clarkson's remark, "that is a proud moment, but there's a slope on it," was interpreted as derogatory by some viewers, leading actress somi guha to instruct her lawyers to make a formal complaint. clarkson, who has been under scrutiny for other racial remarks, defended himself by claiming he was not racist. the top gear executive producer, andy wilman, admitted that the wordplay was "light-hearted" but acknowledged it could be offensive to some audiences. this comes after another controversy surrounding clarkson, where he was accused of using the n-word during the filming of the hit bbc series. clarkson vehemently denies the allegations and claimed the bbc forced him to apologize, while guha is suing the corporation for up to £1million.
2494	andrew marr, a bbc broadcaster, left his family home after his wife was "very cross" following photos of him in an intimate encounter with another woman. marr admitted the incident was "poor behavior" and a "drunken clinch," denying any romantic connection. he has previously had an extramarital affair with a journalist, which he attempted to hide through a gagging order. marr is known for his professionalism and appeared on his show despite the personal controversy.
2495	beverley jeffs, a former care home manager from derbyshire, is on trial for forging an elderly man's will and altering her own medical records to claim she was his daughter, in an attempt to inherit £300,000. she also stands accused of stealing £51,000 from another resident and fraudulently signing their cheques. the altered will promised a minibus to the home and money to an employee. jeffs denies eight counts of fraud, two theft charges, and three counts of converting criminal property. the trial continues.
2496	a british airways boeing 777 plane was forced to make two unscheduled landings at shannon airport in ireland within a three-day period due to technical issues. the latest incident occurred on a flight from seattle to london heathrow on sunday morning, carrying 220 passengers. no injuries were reported, and passengers were placed on a replacement flight later that day. the same plane also encountered technical difficulties on its journey from heathrow to boston on friday night. british airways confirmed that there were suspected technical issues in both incidents and that the plane was thoroughly checked over at shannon airport before continuing its journey. the airline stated that safety was their top priority and the diversions were made as precautions.
2497	the detroit tigers acquired pitcher david price from the tampa bay rays, making them the first baseball team to have three consecutive cy young award winners with max scherzer and justin verlander. the al central-leading tigers aim to win their fourth straight division title and strengthened their pitching rotation with price. the deal also involved the seattle mariners, with austin jackson, drew smyly, nick franklin, and minor league shortstop willy adames exchanging teams. tampa bay decided to trade price due to their weak position in the al east race and the financial strain caused by his high salary. the tigers will use price in their rotation alongside verlander, scherzer, anibal sanchez, and rick porcello. price is currently seventh in the american league in whip, fifth in strikeouts per nine innings, and third in strikeouts per walk.
2498	goldfish have the ability to distinguish between classical music compositions by johann sebastian bach and igor stravinsky, according to a study by japanese researchers. goldfish have evolved advanced hearing mechanisms similar to complex animals, enabling them to recognize complex auditory stimuli. researchers trained four goldfish to associate one piece with a reward, and they were able to distinguish the music around three-quarters of the time. however, it took over 100 training sessions for the fish to learn the difference. the fish were also tested with unfamiliar pieces by the same composers, but they did not recognize them. the findings suggest goldfish have individual tastes and challenge the myth that they have low intelligence, as recent research suggests their memory span can be up to three months.
