2585	a corrupt detective, nicholas mcfadden, who made £600,000 by selling seized drugs and used the money to buy luxuries for his mistress behind his wife's back, was sentenced to 23 years in jail for drug dealing and money laundering. his brother, simon mcfadden, received 16 years for the same charges, and they had raided drugs earmarked for destruction at west yorkshire police. the pair spent the proceeds on expensive lifestyles, including luxurious holidays, designer clothes, and champagne. the court heard that nicholas had taken the drugs from a hold containing those recovered from three major police operations, and his suspicious activity was first noticed when he deposited £30,000 in small payments into cash machines over three months. when police raided his home, they found £430,000 of his money and an additional £160,000 belonging to simon that couldn't be traced to a legitimate source. west yorkshire police expressed disappointment and betrayal by his former colleagues.
2586	james robertson, a 56-year-old detroit resident, has walked a 21-mile round trip commute to his job in rochester hills, michigan, for the past ten years. he does this five days a week, rain or shine, because his car broke down over a decade ago, and bus service only covers part of the route. despite the grueling commute and the cold, dark nights, robertson refuses to take time off and has never missed a day of work. his boss, todd wilson, admires his work ethic and calls him an attendance role model. robertson claims to power his long commute with two liters of mountain dew and countless cans of coke each day. colleagues and a local resident have provided him with rides occasionally, but his situation may change after an online campaign raised almost $42,000 for him to buy a car.
2587	amber le bon, daughter of model yasmin le bon, turned heads at fashion night out in westfield last week with her shocking pink and blue dyed hair. the model, who previously had chocolate brown locks, boldly dyed half of her blonde streaks herself. her mother, yasmin, recently caused a stir with her edgy short hairstyle. fashion night out is a global initiative to encourage shopping and support the fashion industry, and included giveaways and competitions at various stores in westfield. amber's drastic new hair style was a hit with onlookers, including jessica wright and sam faiers from the only way is essex. amber's boyfriend, jonny hynes, also approved of her bold new look. yasmin's short, slicked back hair with an undercut seemed to channel a 90s style, and she pulled off the look with her radiant skin. though dip dyeing is not for the faint of heart, it can be maintained with proper care to ensure longevity of the color.
2588	a senate report released on october 3, 2012, criticized the 77 fusion centers, which are part of a multibillion-dollar information-sharing network among local, state, and federal officials, for violating americans' civil liberties and failing to produce valuable intelligence on terrorism. the report found that fusion centers improperly collected information about innocent citizens, and their reports seldom dealt with terrorism. instead, much of the money went towards ordinary crime-fighting, including expensive equipment like laptops, televisions, and vehicles. the report called out the department of homeland security (dhs) for wasteful spending, while dhs disagreed with the report's conclusions, saying it was outdated and inaccurate. regardless, fusion centers have remained politically important for state and local governments due to the significant federal funding they receive, even though their reports were found to be useless or infringing on civil liberties. the convoluted grants process makes it difficult for the federal government to determine how fusion center funding is being used, leading to millions spent on programs with questionable impact on counterterrorism efforts.
2589	brickhouse security, a security company, is providing free gps tracking devices to churches to help prevent the theft of baby jesus figurines from nativity scenes. the matchbox-sized device can be hidden on or in the figurine, and if stolen, will alert the owner with a text or email, allowing law enforcement to locate and recover the stolen item. the program, called "save jesus," has been running for eight years and has been adopted by an increasing number of churches every year. reverend george smith from st. mark's episcopal church in glen ellyn, illinois, shared a personal experience of losing two wise men figurines and expressed gratitude for the offer of a free tracking device to prevent further thefts. despite the program's success, brickhouse security ceo todd morris hopes that it won't be necessary in the future.
2590	judy murray, mother of tennis players andy and jamie, has split from her long-term boyfriend, phil reid, and is reportedly in advanced talks to appear in the next series of strictly come dancing. judy previously wrote about romantic dinners with reid but is now single. her marriage to andy's father ended when andy was nine, and the family was raised by her ex-husband for several years. judy has expressed admiration for tennis player feliciano lopez, to andy's embarrassment.
2591	the formula 1 calendar includes iconic circuits like monaco and silverstone, but next week's japanese grand prix will feature a new track at fuji speedway, which hasn't hosted an f1 race since 1977. the circuit, which was the setting for the classic arcade game "pole position," has undergone significant changes, with german architect hermann tilke leading the redesign in 2003. f1 teams prepare for the unfamiliar circuit using computer simulations and virtual testing, with bmw sauber and toyota f1 teams analyzing every detail of the track layout, including downforce levels, gear ratios, and brake specifications. the long main straight and relatively twisty track will require a balance between maximum speed and optimal grip. the testing is aimed to ensure that lap times and top speed calculated using simulation software vary by no more than one percent from the actual values, but unpredictable incidents during the race can significantly impact strategy. despite some controversies surrounding the switch from suzuka to fuji, the japanese grand prix is set to alternate hosting locations between fuji and suzuka after 2009.
2592	monster beverage corporation is facing a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the family of a 14-year-old girl, anais fournier, who died from caffeine toxicity after consuming two 24-ounce cans of monster energy drink within 24 hours. the food and drug administration (fda) is currently investigating reports of five deaths and one non-fatal heart attack linked to monster energydrinks, prompting a 14% drop in the company's shares. an autopsy revealed that anais died due to cardiac arrhythmia caused by caffeine toxicity, which impeded her heart's ability to pump blood. her parents claim that monster failed to warn about the risks of consuming its products. the fda investigation does not necessarily prove that the drinks caused the deaths or injuries. monster beverage corp. maintains that its drinks are not responsible for anais' death and intends to vigorously defend itself in the lawsuit. the company's shares fell significantly following the announcements. energy drinks represent about 3% of sales volume in the carbonated soft drink market. heightened scrutiny from state and federal authorities, including investigations by new york state attorney general eric schneiderman and senators dick durbin and richard blumenthal, has increased due to the rising sales volume of energy drinks.
2593	reports of a possible cease-fire in gaza brokered by egypt emerged on tuesday, but any long-term truce is uncertain without addressing the root causes of conflict between israel and hamas. the latest israeli offensive in gaza is the sixth major military operation since israel withdrew from the strip in 2005 and the first since the "cast lead" campaign in 2008. egypt, as a key player with a stake in gaza's stability, may act as a peacemaker. israel seeks an end to rocket attacks from gaza, while hamas wants the blockade lifted and borders reopened. however, neither side appears to have a clear endgame, and the underlying grievances of both sides must be addressed to prevent continued violence. egypt's relations with israel and the us have been strained due to their open support for israeli military action. hamas is expected to emerge from the latest conflict with increased political power, while palestinian authority president mahmoud abbas has been criticized for his ineffectiveness. egypt is best positioned to mediate a solution that addresses the needs of all parties, including reconciliation between fatah and hamas. reestablishing palestinian unity is crucial for salvaging abbas' leadership and weakening hamas' ties to iran. while challenges exist, including israeli and us opposition to palestinian reconciliation, a grand bargain that addresses the concerns of all parties may be the best way to prevent future conflicts.
2594	a federal judge dismissed a cyberstalking case against william lawrence cassidy for his threatening tweets and blog posts towards buddhist leader alyce zeoli, ruling that they were protected under the first amendment. zeoli, a public figure and subject of a 2000 book, cooperated with the fbi in having cassidy indicted on interstate stalking charges. cassidy argued that the charges violated freedom of speech. the judge, roger w. titus, agreed, likening twitter and blogs to billboards and concluding that the first amendment protects speech, even if it challenges religious beliefs, political attitudes, or conventional standards of good taste. zeoli was "appalled and frightened" by the ruling, and an appeal may be pursued. cassidy's public defenders are working to release him from jail. the ruling sparks debate over whether threatening posts on social media should be protected.
2595	a new poll in scotland reveals that a third of voters prefer a labour-snp coalition, which could potentially see alex salmond in the british cabinet. ed miliband faces the possibility of a labour wipeout in scotland, making a power-sharing deal with the snp a potential option to secure an overall majority in the may general election. although scottish first minister nicola sturgeon has previously ruled out a formal coalition with labour, she has indicated the possibility of a confidence and supply arrangement. miliband has yet to categorically rule out such a deal. the poll shows that 35.1% of scottish voters prefer a labour-snp coalition, with 19.8% wanting a majority labour government, while 13.8% back a conservative majority. a further 7% intend to vote lib dem, among other smaller parties, and the snp is expected to win 52 seats and labour to be reduced to just six. miliband has refrained from ruling out a deal with the snp during a recent interview, despite previously stating he is "not about deals and coalitions."
2596	ayoze perez, a 21-year-old spanish forward, went from a viral youtube goal at newcastle united's training ground to scoring the winning goal against liverpool in the premier league in a week. he made his full premier league debut against tottenham and won awards in spain for best breakthrough player and best attacking midfielder in the second division. perez's goal broke a streak of liverpool and newcastle not sharing a 0-0 draw since 1974. he joined newcastle in june after receiving offers from barcelona and real madrid. his recent performances have impressed teammates and manager alan pardew, who feels perez has a natural instinct for scoring in the penalty box despite needing to learn more about english football. perez has scored two goals in three appearances for newcastle and feels ahead of schedule in his career.
2597	bobbi kristina brown's father, bobby brown, and his wife, alicia etheredge, visited bobbi at emory university hospital in atlanta on wednesday, where she is in a medically-induced coma after being found unconscious in a bathtub at her home in roswell, georgia on saturday. nick gordon, her partner, discovered her and attempted to revive her while a friend called 911. police are investigating if people may have fled the scene before they arrived and are reviewing surveillance footage. bobbi kristina, the only child of bobby and late singer whitney houston, remains in critical condition and tests have shown minimal brain function. bobby and alicia were joined by bobby's daughter laprincia, 24. bobby has a complicated past with drugs and alcohol, having admitted to using drugs and alcohol in the past. bobbi kristina and nick were not married, although they had been in a relationship and had announced their engagement on social media. relations between nick and other family members have been strained, with a protective order barring him from being near bobbi's aunt.
2598	glass onion catering has recalled over 180,000 pounds of ready-to-eat salads and sandwich wraps due to potential e. coli contamination. these products, produced between september 23 and november 6, were shipped to distribution centers in az, ca, nv, nm, or, tx, ut, and wa. affected brands include delish, atherstone fine foods, lunch spot, super fresh foods, and trader joe's. contaminated items may contain e. coli o157:h7, which causes dehydration, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal cramps, and can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome. at least 26 people have fallen ill in three states, with 15 of them consuming the recalled products. the recall includes various types of salads and wraps with chicken and ham.
2599	a 49-year-old man, who had traveled to saudi arabia and was infected with middle east respiratory syndrome coronavirus (mers-ncv), died at st. thomas' hospital in london on june 28, 2013, making him the third person to die from the virus in britain. the virus, which is believed to be more deadly than sars, has caused 41 deaths and 77 confirmed cases across nine countries since it emerged last year. the world health organization (who) has identified mers-ncv as a threat to the entire world due to its potential to spread person-to-person and its persistence in the middle east region since 2012. cases have also been reported in jordan, qatar, saudi arabia, the united arab emirates, france, germany, italy, tunisia, and the uk. british health officials have been advised to be vigilant for severe unexplained respiratory illness in anyone who has recently traveled in the middle east or in any unexplained clusters of such illness. mers-ncv is in the same family as viruses that cause the common cold and sars, which caused hundreds of deaths and panic during an outbreak in asia in 2003.
2600	a report by migrationwatch uk claims that immigration is responsible for 84% of britain's population growth this century, contrary to the office for national statistics (ons) reporting 57%. this discrepancy is due to the ons not counting children born to foreign parents as migrants, resulting in a significant underestimation of the impact of immigration on population growth. the think-tank argues that, with the current net migration rate at around 245,000, future population growth is expected to be entirely due to migration. sir andrew green, chairman of migrationwatch uk, emphasized the importance of recognizing the role of immigration in population growth and its implications for public services and wages.
2601	the ig nobel awards is an annual event celebrating the weird and humorous sides of scientific discoveries, with this year's winners hailing from various fields including psychology and biology. in psychology, researchers found that people who think they are drunk also believe they are more attractive, while biology and astronomy winners discovered that lost dung beetles use the milky way to help find their way home. other winners included a study on opera's impact on heart transplant patients and an electro-mechanical anti-hijacking device. the awards ceremony was held at harvard university and was presented by science magazine annals of improbable research. the psychology prize went to laurent bègue, oulmann zerhouni, baptiste subra, medhi ourabah, and brad bushman, while the biology and astronomy prize was awarded to marie dacke, emily baird, marcus byrne, clarke scholtz, and eric warrant.
2602	comet ison, also known as the "comet of the century," was expected to disintegrate as it approached the sun on november 28, 2013. however, recent images from nasa and the european space agency suggest that the comet, or at least some of its fragments, may have survived the close encounter. initial observations showed the comet fading away, but subsequent images indicated that it was getting brighter. some scientists feared the comet had already started to disintegrate due to the extremely high temperatures it was exposed to as it entered the sun's outer layers. the comet, discovered in 2012, was making its first pass through the inner solar system and was visible to the naked eye through december. it was believed to be a pristine remnant from the formation of the solar system and was moving at incredible speeds as it approached the sun. while the comet was expected to be visible throughout december, it could not be ruled out that it had been torn apart during its close encounter with the sun.
2603	cnn's conservative historian lee edwards ranked dick cheney as one of the best and worst vice presidents since the 1950s. he placed cheney at number 5 on the good list due to his washington experience and contributions to the bush administration, but also at number 4 on the bad list for becoming an unpopular figure in an unpopular administration. other picks on edwards' lists include: good list: 1. lyndon b. johnson (selected by john f. kennedy in 1960) 2. george h.w. bush (joined reagan in 1980 after running against him in primaries) 3. al gore (provided washington experience to clinton's ticket in 1992) 4. dick cheney (brought experience to bush in 2000, but later became unpopular) 5. richard nixon (brought youth, california, and political skills to eisenhower's ticket in 1952) bad list: 1. thomas eagleton (mcgovern's pick in 1972, replaced by sargent shriver after health issues and electroshock treatments emerged) 2. dan quayle (bush's pick in 1988, became a laughingstock due to verbal blow during debate) 3. spiro agnew (helped nixon get elected president in 1968 but pleaded no contest to tax evasion and money laundering) 4. dick cheney (a double-edged sword, praised for experience but became unpopular) these vice presidential picks have left lasting impacts on american history.
2604	in june 2013, a deadly fire at a poultry processing plant in jilin province, china, killed 121 people and injured 76. two fire chiefs and two plant bosses have been convicted and sentenced to prison terms of up to nine years for safety regulation violations and falsifying information. the plant, jilin baoyuanfeng, had complex design features that caused difficulties in escape and resulted in blocked exits and lights going out. firefighters arrived six hours after the electrical short ignited flammable goods, and many survivors described scenes of panic as they struggled to escape. the plant produced 67,000 tonnes of processed chicken per year and employed about 1,200 people. the former chief of the local fire department and his deputy were sentenced for abuse of power. prosecutors found that inspections of the plant had not been conducted honestly, and the plant was producing chicken near the town of dеhui, about 800 kilometers northeast of beijing. survivors and families of the deceased wept at the scene of the smouldering remains as they awaited information.
2605	a london man was arrested on suspicion of making roadside bombs in iraq during the conflict between 2003-2011. the 37-year-old, who remains in custody, is facing investigation by scotland yard's counter-terrorism command. roadside bombs, also known as improvised explosive devices (ieds), accounted for nearly two-thirds of all deaths suffered by american and british forces and their allies in iraq. insurgents often hid ieds in everyday items like drinks cans and food boxes or even used donkey carts loaded with explosives. ieds were used to slow down military columns, force vehicles off course, or even directly target troops. thousands of british troops were deployed to iraq following the us-led invasion in 2003, which toppled dictator saddam hussein. the conflict led to widespread violence and fears of terror attacks in the uk, with hundreds of british citizens traveling to iraq to join insurgent groups and later planning attacks at home. the use of ieds led to significant changes in british military vehicle design to deflect explosions and protect troops. britain and the us began withdrawing their military forces in 2009, with the last troops returning home in 2011. al-qaeda leader abu musab al-zarqawi made several appeals for foreign fighters to travel to iraq, and he was killed in 2006. currently, comments are not being accepted on this article.
2606	a pampered pomeranian named harvey moon, rescued by his owner stephanie mariam, has become a social media sensation with over 8,000 facebook fans, 500 instagram and twitter followers, and a £6,000-a-year income. stephanie invested £15,000 in harvey's grooming, outfits, and accessories, including £140 monthly for clothes, £200 for fur dyes, and £60 for "pawdicures." harvey now has his own wardrobe, agent, personal assistant, and bank account, and receives gifts from fans worth hundreds of pounds. his social media following and reputation have opened doors for him in the entertainment industry as an extra in a music video and the animated face of an energy saving company. despite the high expenses, stephanie believes it's worth it for harvey to "become an international icon." harvey enjoys a comfortable living situation with three mini-four poster beds, cooling coats, and custom dog jackets. he has specific dietary needs, eating only £120 worth of prepared meals from lily's kitchen. the total monthly cost of harvey's care amounts to £845.
2607	thousands of sun-worshippers headed to the british coast today as temperatures reached 82f (28c) in some parts of the country. beachgoers enjoyed packed scenes at fistral beach in newquay, cornwall, for the relentless boardmasters music and surf festival, while in bournemouth, 60,000 people flocked to the seven-mile stretch of sand. long queues for ice creams and cold drinks were reported, and seaside traders were grateful for the business. families built sandcastles and enjoyed the sunshine, while some parts of britain prepared for rain this weekend. the warm weather came after a disastrous year for gardener ken stock, who saw his dazzling displays of dahlias ruined by the erratic weather. temperatures in scotland will be the coolest in the nation this weekend, and forecasters predict showers throughout the south-east on sunday afternoon. britain is experiencing a mixed weekend of sunshine and rain.
2608	phyllis hall, a nurse during john f. kennedy's assassination in 1963, claimed in a recent interview that she saw a "mystery bullet" that was removed from the president's neck and never presented as evidence. hall was working in the hospital when jfk was brought in after being shot in dallas, texas. she described the bullet as being completely undamaged and unlike the bullets later produced. amidst the chaos, hall helped in saving the president's life, but he ultimately succumbed to his wounds after a 43-minute struggle. despite offering her condolences to the first lady, jacqueline kennedy, hall said jackie appeared distant. hall, now 78, did not tell her husband about what she had witnessed until recently and is a believer in the conspiracy theories surrounding jfk's death.
2609	a utah woman, karla cabo, posed as a real attorney named karla stirling fierro and opened her own law office, representing at least one client in court using fraudulently obtained bar number. the real attorney, karla stirling, was unaware of the impersonation and expressed concerns for her clients whose cases might have been affected by cabo's lack of legal training. cabo was arrested for identity theft, forgery, and communications fraud. the client she represented in court on december 23 is likely to be given the opportunity to withdraw their guilty plea as it was essentially uncounseled. cabo's actions violated constitutional rules.
2610	an independent review led by former fbi director robert s. mueller iii found that the nfl did not receive the video of ray rice knocking out his fiancée in an atlantic city casino elevator before it was published online. the nfl should have taken additional steps to obtain all available information about the february 15 incident, mueller stated. rice, a ravens running back, was initially suspended for two games following his arrest for punching his now-wife janay during a night out at the casino. however, after video of the incident was published on tmz, he was released by the team and suspended indefinitely from the league, although this decision was later reversed. the investigation, which did not have subpoena power, did not contact the law enforcement official who claimed to have sent the video to the league or any of the police officers who investigated the incident. the report found that the nfl's deference to the criminal justice system and lack of follow-up on initial conversations with the ravens contributed to deficiencies in the league's investigation. the nfl has since implemented new policies regarding domestic violence and conduct violations.
2611	a sainsbury's executive named john maylam, who was in charge of buying potato crops for the supermarket, was jailed for four years for taking bribes worth £5 million from greenvale, a major supplier, in exchange for a multi-million-pound contract. maylam allowed greenvale to overcharge sainsbury's by £8.7 million through complex financial arrangements, and the money was laundered through bogus companies for maylam's extravagant lifestyle. he spent the money on sports cars, yachts, and expensive holidays. greenvale directors andrew behagg and david baxter were also jailed for their involvement in the scam. sainsbury's was effectively bribed with its own money, and maylam and baxter believed their fraud was too complex to be detected. the trio was arrested after irregular payments were discovered during an audit.
2612	a dejected-looking mountain gorilla was captured on camera yawning and nursing a nap as it huddled in the undergrowth of rwanda's virunga mountains during a rainy day. the silverback gorilla, with its long and thick fur, seemed to be struggling with the region's heavy rainfall of over 70 inches per year. nearly half of the world's critically endangered mountain gorillas reside in the virunga mountains region. the grumpy gorilla was seen wrapping its arms around itself and even chomping on vegetation as it settled for a snooze. despite its thick coat, the gorilla appeared to be in a sulky mood, contemplating another rainy day with little comfort.
2613	tropical storm arthur, the first storm of the hurricane season, is heading up the eastern seaboard, threatening to ruin fourth of july celebrations from the carolinas to new england. the storm, currently about 95 miles off cape canaveral, florida, was upgraded to a tropical storm on tuesday and has the potential to strengthen into a hurricane. coastal flooding, rough surf, thunderstorms, and heavy downpours are expected starting thursday along the interstate 95 corridor and worsening over the weekend, particularly in the outer banks of north carolina. the storm will bring rain and thunderstorms to much of the eastern seaboard and midwest as it moves northeast. a tropical storm watch is in effect for florida's east coast, and forecasters predict the storm will clear out to sea by saturday, leaving a sunny and warm holiday weekend for most of the country. tropical storm elida is also developing in the pacific, with maximum sustained winds near 50 mph and a tropical storm warning in effect for mexico's coast from lazaro cardenas to cabo corrientes.
2614	the european champions league final on may 22 at the estadio santiago bernabeu in madrid will determine the winner of the most lucrative soccer competition in the world. the two participating teams, inter milan and bayern munich, are two european giants led by coaches jose mourinho and louis van gaal. mourinho, who won the european cup with porto in 2004 and has already secured the italian title and cup for inter, aims to complete a treble. bayern, after winning the bundesliga title and domestic cup, also seeks to add the champions league title to their collection. the match will feature top players such as arjen robben, samuel eto'o, bastian schweinsteiger, and lucio. cnn will provide coverage and analysis of the game in a special preview program hosted by pedro pinto and alex thomas on cnn international at 1800 gmt. you can share your prediction on which coach will win by commenting on the blog.
2615	a colorado man identified as edward tom, 40, from boulder, tragically died after falling around 100 feet while searching for a campsite during a strong storm on the slopes of grand teton in wyoming's grand teton national park over the weekend. two physicians attempted to revive him, but unfortunately, they were unable to do so. tom and a climbing partner had planned to camp at petzold caves before climbing the 13,770-foot grand teton peak on saturday. the incident occurred as the peak's summit is the highest point in the park, situated outside of jackson, wyoming.
2616	george p. bush, the grandson of former president george h.w. bush and nephew of former president george w. bush, brought his baby great-grandson prescott to vote with him in the texas land commissioner primary on tuesday. prescott received an 'i voted' sticker despite not being old enough to vote. bush easily won the republican nomination and will face former el paso mayor john cook in the general election, aiming to manage billions of state assets. bush, an attorney, identifies as pro-life, pro-gun, and pro-energy, and has raised over $3.5 million for his campaign. this is the first political foray for the 37-year-old. bush's mother is from mexico, and he has addressed voters in both english and spanish. he is the son of former florida governor jeb bush and has white house connections.
2617	a vicar and his daughter, both suspects in the suspicious death of the vicar's grandson, were described by relatives as being very religious and taking a dim view of pregnancies out of wedlock. reverend jim percival, 64, and his daughter ruth, 28, were questioned by police for a second day after the newborn's body was found at their £400,000 vicarage. police have granted them bail until march 5, 2023. regular members of percival's congregation were unaware of ruth's pregnancy. the trio, including the vicar's wife susan, 65, are also suspected of conspiring to conceal the birth of a child. percival grew up in london and became a clergyman after an overnight conversion. neighbors described him as a private man and the family as keeping to themselves. police are investigating the baby's father's identity and continue to search the vicarage and question the family. the diocese of blackburn is offering pastoral support.
2618	ronnie lee gardner, who is scheduled to be executed by firing squad in utah for the murder of attorney michael burdell in 1985, unexpectedly expressed his support for capital punishment during his commutation hearing on thursday. gardner, who accepts responsibility for the crime, argued that executing him would not be fair because he has never been able to present evidence in court that might have changed the jury's verdict. he expressed remorse and regret, particularly for not being able to apologize to the families of his victims. gardner's crimes included the killing of melvyn otterstrom during an escape attempt at a salt lake city courthouse and shooting bailiff nick kirk. friends and relatives of the victims were split on the issue, with some calling for mercy and others insisting on the death penalty. witnesses testified about the painful consequences of gardner's crimes, including damage to the victims' lives and the emotional trauma for their families. some critics argued that gardner's childhood marked by poverty, neglect, and abuse could have contributed to his criminal behavior. the hearing will continue with closing arguments on friday and a decision is expected on monday. gardner's attorney argued that the jury in the burdell trial was not given the option to sentence him to life in prison without parole, and that they were not informed of gardner's difficult upbringing or his addiction to inhalants. craig haney, a professor of psychiatry, testified that gardner's life was among the worst he had encountered in his research on death-row inmates. valdean kirk, widow of the murdered bailiff, expressed her intent to witness the execution, maintaining that gardner knew right from wrong. nu, the fiancée of burdell and a member of the summum religious movement, opposed the execution and argued that it would not bring closure or peace to the victims' families.
2619	the fearless dragons is a unique running team based in hong kong, comprised of blind, deaf, and able-bodied runners. founded by kim mok, who lost his vision at a young age, the team aims to raise awareness for people with disabilities and provide a platform for them to reach their potential. the team, which includes over 60 members, has competed in international marathons and local races. mok was motivated to create the team after the suicide of a blind friend and the lack of government support and education opportunities for people with disabilities in the 1980s and 1990s. the team is part of a larger initiative, the hong kong network for the promotion of an inclusive society, which has set up an education fund to support children of parents with disabilities, raising money through the team's races.
2620	in siberia, a russian court released andrei kurochkin's friends, alexei gorulenko and alexander abdullaev, despite their admission to eating kurochkin during a fishing expedition where they got lost in the frozen wilderness for months. kurochkin's widow, olga korochkin, was left with only a few human remains, including a foot with toes, one finger, and the back of his skull. gorulenko was convicted of causing bodily harm and received a suspended three-and-a-half-year jail sentence, while abdullaev was treated as a witness and not charged. the case raised concerns and outrage, with olga and their daughter appealing to president vladimir putin for proper investigation and justice. kurochkin and his friends had been missing for almost two months when their jeep sunk in a frozen river, leaving them stranded in a remote and isolated area. a fourth member of the group, vladimir komarov, remains missing, presumed dead.
2621	the u.s. open tennis tournament is set to break its own record for the highest prize money payout to singles winners, distributing a total of $38.3 million this year. the winners will receive a tournament record $3 million, which is a doubledigit increase from previous years. this increase comes as many professional tennis players, especially those outside the top 100 rankings, find it difficult to make a profit from their earnings. russia's dmitry tursunov, currently ranked 30th, revealed that he needs to earn $200,000 a season just to break even. the u.s. open, along with wimbledon, leads the way in prize money among the four grand slam tournaments. the u.s. open has also announced double-digit raises in each round of the singles to benefit lower-ranked players. rafael nadal and serena williams are the reigning champions of the tournament, which begins on august 25.
2622	a woman identified as hannah bennett, 35, from bovington, dorset, was caught on cctv kicking her 13-year-old staffordshire bull terrier, mace, so hard that the dog flew through railings and into an adjacent car park. witnesses were left in disbelief as bennett continued to pull and drag the injured animal despite being confronted by the public. mace was later taken to the vet and recovered after ten days. bennett, who can be seen addressing her pet before kicking him, was banned from owning animals for five years, received an £80 surcharge, and a suspended two-week custodial sentence at weymouth magistrates' court. rspca inspector graham hammond stated, "mace clearly trusted his owner, and she abused that trust when she kicked him. no animal should suffer at the hands of its owner."
2623	a sinkhole caused by a breaking water main swallowed a family's car in bladensburg, maryland, on tuesday morning. darwin mendoza was in the car with his eight-year-old son, four-year-old daughter, and six-month-old baby when the incident happened as he was backing out of his driveway. only one tire initially sank, but the sinkhole continued to grow, eventually absorbing the entire car. nearby homes suffered from flooding, and around five households were evacuated. the water main responsible is over 90 years old and was put in the ground during the presidency of calvin coolidge. the maintenance work caused disruption to water services for 77 people. the cars were eventually removed from the sinkhole, and 15 feet of the pipe needed to be replaced.
2624	michael brown's family, represented by attorney daryl parks, is considering filing a civil rights case against darren wilson or the ferguson police department following the grand jury's decision not to indict wilson for the fatal shooting of the unarmed teenager. parks expressed concern over wilson's use of derogatory language to describe brown and believes it may indicate a racial component, potentially leading to a civil rights violation. brown's parents have publicly doubted wilson's account of the incident and have been vocal in their disbelief since the decision was announced. protests and unrest have continued in ferguson, with activists like al sharpton rallying in support. despite these ongoing issues, ferguson mayor james knowles has expressed his commitment to rebuilding the city and restoring it to a thriving community.
2625	sudanese journalist lubna al-hussein faces a possible 40-lashing sentence after being arrested for wearing trousers. she was detained with 18 other women on july 3 for wearing indecent clothes. al-hussein, who works for a newspaper and the u.n. mission in sudan, was wearing pants, a blouse, and a hijab at the time of her arrest. the charges against her include having too tight pants and a too-transparent blouse. al-hussein insists she did nothing wrong and has been released to her home in khartoum. six women were released, ten received the prescribed 40-stroke public flogging, and al-hussein and two others are fighting the charges. the arabic network for human rights information stated that this was an official retaliation against the reporter for her critical writings against the sudanese regime and extremists. u.n. secretary-general ban ki-moon expressed deep concern and promised to take steps to protect his staff member. the punishment of wearing indecent attire has only one penalty under sudanese law.
2626	jamie lee peterson, a michigan man, was released from prison after serving 16 years for a 1996 rape and murder of a 68-year-old retired school teacher, geraldine montgomery. peterson initially confessed but later denied involvement. new dna evidence cleared him, revealing that someone else was the actual perpetrator. the conviction was vacated, and all charges were dropped. despite this, peterson will not receive compensation, as michigan does not have a compensation law for wrongfully convicted individuals. his legal team is considering a civil lawsuit. the town of kalkaska was shocked by the crime, and peterson's initial false confession raised concerns about potential false confessions.
2627	following superstorm sandy, new jersey faced a significant challenge as half of hoboken remained flooded, with thousands of people trapped in their homes. national guard troops were deployed to help evacuate residents, particularly the elderly and those with medical emergencies. the city asked for assistance from people with generators and boats. many residents were unable to leave their flooded neighborhoods due to narrow streets and the contaminated water, which was a mixture of rainwater and sewage. hoboken mayor dawn zimmer implemented an evacuation order for basement and street-level units on sunday. residents were seen wading through floodwaters, carrying their pets, and using boats to navigate the area. the national guard helped evacuate those in need and delivered emergency supplies to the homeless shelter. mayor zimmer appealed for help due to the small city streets and the presence of live wires and contaminated water. new york giants quarterback eli manning, who lives in hoboken, was also affected by the storm. the flooding caused extensive damage, with public transportation halted and boats washed ashore. residents wore waterproof clothing and used bicycles to get around the city. the national guard provided electric power for storm victims to charge electronic devices and pumps were used to remove water from flooded buildings. evidence of price-grouging was reported as residents struggled to find supplies.
2628	an oregon high school student named nicholas sayre, a junior at lincoln high school in portland, recorded a video of his school bus driver apparently falling asleep at the wheel. he noticed the driver's tendency to doze off weeks prior and shared the video with his parents and teachers out of safety concerns. in the 30-second video, the driver is seen with closed eyes at intersections, waking up and shaking his head, and even dozing off again. the driver was fired by the portland public school transportation service after the video was shared, and it was revealed that other students had previously complained about the same driver. the transportation service had been told about the earlier incidents but did not take immediate action until the video was shared. the driver's identity remains unknown, and sayre plans to monitor his new bus driver as well.
2629	drones, which were once used primarily by military experts for secretive surveillance missions, have become a controversial and increasingly popular tool for the us military and are raising concerns for domestic use. president obama signed a law in 2012 to allow drones in us airspace by 2015, with potential uses including border patrol, criminal hunting, and maintaining crops. some police forces in the us have already shown interest in using drones, some of which could be equipped with face- recognition software, but concerns over privacy and government intrusion have emerged. drones have been used heavily by the us military to spy and kill enemy fighters, and their use has increased dramatically in the past decade, with over 11,000 in use by the us military and over 50 countries using them as well. the small size of some drones, including those that are just the size of a hummingbird, has added to the controversy. the federal aviation administration (faa) has issued over 1,400 permits for drone use since 2007, with an estimated 10,000 drones expected to take to the skies by 2020. however, opposition from privacy and civil liberties groups has led to restrictions on their use in some us states. the article also notes that drones could potentially replace most manned military aircraft in the future.
2630	militants from the al-shabaab group, who control parts of somalia's capital city, have been publicly flogging women for violating their radical interpretation of islamic law. in the last two days, over 130 people, including women not wearing headscarves and men chewing dried khat leaves, have been detained in mogadishu and the town of luuq. al-shabaab militants rounded up more than 50 women in mogadishu on wednesday for not wearing the veil, which is required under some interpretations of islamic law. the women, mostly vegetable traders, cannot afford to buy veils for around $23. an additional 80 civilians were detained in luuq for defying orders. al-shabaab, considered a terrorist organization by the us due to its ties to al qaeda, has been increasingly imposing stricter rules on civilians living in the areas they control. earlier this month, al-shabaab militants whipped women for wearing bras in northern mogadishu.
2631	a territorial army soldier, private matthew thornton, was killed by a large improvised explosive device (ied) in helmand, afghanistan, while on patrol with the first battalion yorkshire regiment. the ied was hidden in undergrowth beneath a wall, and it is believed that grenades were thrown to lure the soldiers into the area. thornton's body was found around 30ft up a tree. his colleagues and medics were unable to save him, and a pathologist's report confirmed that his death was instantaneous. thornton, from barnsley, was described as a "cracking soldier who gave 100%" by his captain. his family stated that he was proud to serve in the yorkshire regiment and was dedicated to making a difference in the country. the inquest recorded a verdict of unlawful killing.
2632	squadron leader gareth prendergast returned to raf marham in norfolk after a six-month tour in afghanistan, marking the end of raf combat operations in the area. his wife, rachel, and sons, felix (one) and hector (three), eagerly awaited his return. felix, who was not even walking when his father left, excitedly raced to greet him. gareth held his sons and smiled, expressing that being away from family was the hardest part of his deployment. other raf personnel and their families were also reunited, including oliver payne and his partner liza brooks and their puppy islay. tornado crews had served at kandahar airfield since 2009 and 170 personnel were set to return over the coming days.
2633	the independent institute for fiscal studies (ifs) has warned that chancellor george osborne will need to impose significant spending cuts, estimated at £21 billion, to maintain the current pace of reductions after the next election. this would mean slashing welfare or increasing taxes. the think-tank suggested a "fundamental re-imagining of the role of the state" if public spending is reduced to 35.2% of gdp by 2018-19. the government's decision to protect spending on areas like health, schools, and foreign aid means deeper cuts to other sectors, such as defence, transport, and the home office. plans to name and shame serial tax dodgers could unfairly target the innocent, critics argue. the ifs also warned that labour's slower plan to reduce the deficit would result in additional borrowing of around £25 billion. the chancellor defended his proposals, insisting voters faced a choice between his plan for economic prosperity and a return to the chaos seen under labour. the lack of tax revenue growth is causing concerns, with the office for budget responsibility producing a £21 billion shortfall in expected revenues by 2017-18. osborne aims for a budget surplus of £23 billion by 2019-20, which would require an additional £14 billion in cuts. the ifs expressed disappointment in the progress made towards reducing the deficit, with the gap between spending and income falling by only £6 billion in the past year.
2634	new jersey governor chris christie criticized president barack obama for not speaking firmly enough on israel's behalf against hamas, saying the country no longer trusts it has the full support of the united states. christie made these remarks during the unrest in the middle east, as israel targeted civilian institutions with suspected hamas ties and declared it would increase bombardment of northern gaza. israel claims to be acting in self-defense against hamas rockets. palestinian protests have occurred across the world over the crisis in gaza. christie urged obama to condemn hamas' actions against israel and be a forceful voice for democracy in the region. israel widened its bombing targets and deployed ground troops inside gaza for the first time. more than 156 palestinians have been killed in the past five days. the un security council called for a cease-fire, and foreign ministers from the uk, france, and germany will discuss cease-fire efforts on sunday. so far, neither israel nor hamas has signaled a willingness to stop. the israeli military has carried out over 1,200 air strikes this week and plans to attack northern gaza with "great force" to prevent rocket attacks from there. christie is a potential 2016 presidential contender and has spoken more aggressively on international affairs in recent months, despite having limited foreign policy experience.
2635	a 16-year-old boy, willian cornick, was sentenced to life in prison with a minimum tariff of 20 years for murdering spanish teacher ann maguire in leeds. penelope gibbs, the chairman of the standing committee for youth justice, criticized the sentence as too long and out of line with western european countries. gibbs argued that there is no evidence to justify the 20-year minimum and that prisons, such as grendon, can effectively rehabilitate offenders in less time. her comments were criticized on twitter, but some agreed that the focus should be on the impact on the victim and the need for rehabilitation. cornick attacked maguire from behind in a classroom and made threats to kill other teachers. he showed no remorse after the crime and even expressed a desire for more murders. the sentence was described as a "monumental act of cowardice and evil" by ann maguire's widower, don.
2636	a wave of foreclosed properties is flooding the housing market, causing property value declines, family displacement, and municipal financial struggles. however, some buyers view this as an opportunity to purchase homes at ultra-low prices. interested buyers from various locations, including foreign countries, are contacting real estate agents to buy foreclosed properties in bulk. for example, an investor wants to buy 200 houses under $10,000. prospective homeowners can also benefit from this situation by considering first-time home ownership. for instance, a friend of real estate agent tonya perkins-stoudermire of mcmullan realty in cleveland bought a low-priced foreclosed house with two baths, a two-car garage, and two fireplaces. however, experts warn against hasty decisions. buyers should carefully evaluate repair costs, the neighborhood, past utilities usage, landscaping, and property conditions. home inspections are essential, even for cash transactions, as previous inspections only offer a snapshot in time. the department of housing and urban development (hud) offers advantages, such as regular appraisals and property condition reports, but a private inspection is still recommended. investors should not expect quick profits and may face penalties for neglectful property ownership. overall, investing in foreclosed properties requires careful planning, homework, and dedication.
2637	kim kardashian, with her 22 million instagram followers, has more followers than the population of scandinavia. in november, she attempted to "break the internet" with provocative nude pictures. as a child psychiatrist and mother, i am not surprised by her exhibitionism or desire for publicity, but i am concerned about the disconnect between what educators and policy makers are saying about growing up in the digital world and the reality of popular culture. the american academy of pediatrics recommends no screen time before age 2 and less than 2 hours for older kids, but statistics show that tweens and teenagers average over 8 hours a day. parents struggle with balancing respecting their children's privacy and spying on them, and the dialogue has focused on fear of screen time and its potential negative effects on empathy and relationships. researchers suggest that interactive screen time and teaching kids how to use their devices responsibly can help develop empathy. the goal should be to encourage children to use their devices responsibly and thoughtfully, rather than taking them away. parents need to have a dialogue with their children about online celebrity and the cost of "facebook fame." monitoring and cultivating online resilience is essential, but it should be done with transparency and open communication rather than spying. kim kardashian, as an adult who has charted a course online, can serve as a discussion point for parents on the importance of choosing what to share and the potential consequences of online overexposure.
2638	"cnn" discusses the release of the long-awaited "dumb and dumber to" sequel, highlighting the film's initial success in 1994 and the enthusiasm of audiences for nostalgia. however, the article critically evaluates the sequel, questioning if the original's charm and impact can be replicated with the aging stars, jim carrey and jeff daniels. the piece also cites various other examples of successful hollywood sequels or revivals, including "veronica mars," "arrested development," "psycho ii," "tron: legacy," and "girl meets world," emphasizing the enduring appeal of nostalgia in entertainment.
2639	the chelsea flower show, set to take place on may 20, has sold out in the second-fastest time in its history due to the anticipated return of alan titchmarsh as a garden exhibitor after a 34-year absence. titchmarsh's garden, titled "from the moors to the sea," is charting his journey from yorkshire to the isle of wight, causing massive demand for tickets. touts are reselling tickets for up to £575, which is 25 times the face value of £23 for evening entry. the royal horticultural society (rhs) has urged fans not to buy tickets from touts and instead offers special £400 charity tickets. other show highlights include gardens designed by celeb west, matthew keightley, and hugo bugg as well as military-themed gardens for abf the soldiers' charity and help for heroes. sarah eberle is creating a garden for gucci, featuring a mini catwalk and gucci jewelry-inspired bouquets, while david rich holds the title of the youngest ever professional designer with his "vital earth the night sky garden." the queen is expected to visit the show for her 50th time.
2640	the supreme court granted a request from utah officials to delay the recognition of hundreds of same-sex marriages performed in december 2013 and january 2014. the state argued that recognizing these marriages before constitutional issues are fully resolved would be disruptive. the utah court of appeals previously ruled the state's voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage violated equal protection rights, leading to about 1,300 same-sex marriages. similar developments occurred in colorado, where county clerks were ordered to cease issuing same-sex marriage licenses until the issue is fully decided. both utah and colorado plan to ask the supreme court to settle the constitutional debate. the supreme court's temporary action does not signal its ultimate decision on the larger constitutional issues surrounding same-sex marriage.
2641	the average dress size of british women has increased from 12 to 16 in the past decade, yet fashion stores continue to display clothes on size 10 mannequins. the government and equality minister jo swinson have urged retailers to use mannequins that reflect more diverse body shapes for promoting body confidence among women. debenhams in oxford street, london, is leading the way by showcasing a range of size 16 mannequins. healthy eating campaigners believe this change could help prevent low self-esteem and guilt felt by women with fuller figures, caused by the false representation of body image in fashion. not all retailers are following suit, with some arguing their mannequins match their customer profiles. the debate around body confidence and realistic representation in fashion has been ongoing for years. in the late 1990s, us president bill clinton criticized the fashion industry for promoting unhealthy body images. despite this, british fashion insiders argue that retailers are already making efforts to address body confidence by offering wide size ranges and figure-flattering fashion tips.
2642	the world's largest model railroad, northlandz, is located in flemington, new jersey, and covers 52,000 square feet with over 8 miles of track and approximately 100 trains. the attraction, which took 16 years to build, features around 400 bridges, 3,000 miniature buildings, and 50,000 trees. creator bruce williams zaccagnino designed and handcrafted most of the scenery. northlandz attracts thousands of visitors each year, some of whom are famous, such as rod stewart and neil young. the railroad includes city skylines, steep cliffs, and represents various biomes, and visitors can spend up to two hours exploring the 16-acre attraction. additional model railroad enthusiasts, like elaine silets in the greater chicago area, open their personal estates once a year as model train-themed charity events.
2643	clark howard, a well-known consumer advocate and radio show host from atlanta, georgia, revealed on his show on wednesday that he has been diagnosed with prostate cancer. the cancer was detected in its early stages after he underwent regular tests and biopsies due to high prostate-specific antigen (psa) levels. according to the american cancer society, one in six men will develop prostate cancer in their lifetime, and it's recommended that men get regular checks, especially if they're 40 and above. howard encouraged both men and women to encourage their partners to visit the doctor for regular check-ups. he also spoke about the various treatment options and the importance of considering age, health conditions, and side effects when selecting a method. notable figures like former secretary of state colin powell, former senator bob dole, and actor robert de niro have also had prostate cancer.
2644	in an exhilarating stunt reminiscent of a blockbuster action film, australian freestyle bike rider joel brown performed a back-flip over a flying plane in maitland, nsw. the clip, produced by aussie adrenaline, shows brown gaining momentum before executing the daring move in slow motion. brown aims to bring this stunt to international audiences and reveals plans to add additional features, without disclosing the details. the current australian freestyle motocross champion, brown spoke about the safety measures taken, including considering wind effects, ensuring correct speeds, and the pilot's low altitude approval. despite the nerves and potential risks, brown is planning a national tour and considering a career as a stunt performer, such as the one robbie maddison, another australian motorbike stunt rider, pursued in the latest 007 movie. the stunt has received a massive response online, bringing brown new followers and attention for aussie adrenaline.
2645	an amateur stuntman named gogulan pvel, 24, got stranded 70ft above st. petersburg's nevsky prospekt while attempting to pull himself along a 60-metre-long power cable without a safety harness or helmet. he managed to hoist himself to safety, but the stunt left him in a precarious position, hanging on with just an elbow and a leg at one point. witnesses observed the dangerous act with horror, as pvel seemed to be in real trouble, going hand by hand with no special clothing except for gloves, which he discarded. despite facing criticism and the danger involved, pvel expressed determination to complete the stunt in its entirety in the future.
2646	in atlanta, georgia, bar owner rufus terrill uses a modified barbecue smoker mounted on a three-wheeled scooter, named "bum-bot" or "robocop," to patrol the streets and chase away drug dealers and homeless people near his bar and a nearby daycare center. equipped with an infrared camera, spotlight, loudspeaker, and aluminum water cannon, the robot operates via remote control. while some welcome the robot's presence, others believe it is confusing the issue and creating more harm than good. daycare operator lydia meredith supports terrill's actions, while homeless shelter director anita beatty is skeptical. atlanta police acknowledge the uniqueness of the robot but warn against assaulting people, and no charges have been filed against terrill. residents report a noticeable difference in the neighborhood with the robot's presence.
2647	john terry, chelsea's captain and center back, was written off by many last season due to injuries and tactical preferences under rafa benitez. however, he was declared fit by manager jose mourinho for the champions league semi-final against atletico madrid. terry, who joined chelsea from school and has been at the club since he was 14, expressed his desire to stay at the club beyond the end of his contract. he credited mourinho for reviving his career and for believing in him, despite his past failures in champions league finals. both chelsea and atletico are known for their defensive styles and have not conceded many goals recently, making for an anticipated tense and nervous match. chelsea's first-choice goalkeeper petr cech is out with an injury, and mark schwarzer is expected to start in goal, while eden hazard and samuel eto'o could return from injury to play a part in the game.
2648	a primary school teacher, elen meirion, from ruthin, north wales, died two days after falling down a flight of stairs at her home following a night of drinking. the accident occurred in april 2012, a year after she led her school choir to victory on bbc's songs of praise. the inquest heard that meirion had been drinking wine and cava while her companion, david tudor, had vodka. tudor testified that he heard her fall and found her with head injuries at the foot of the stairs. meirion was two and a half times over the legal alcohol limit at the time of her death. her ex-husband and daughter were proud of her dedication to music and her work, and her organs were donated, saving five lives. the family raised £15,000 at her funeral for the welsh air ambulance and the intensive care unit at ysbyty glan clwyd. meirion's brother, tenor rhys meirion, performed in her memory.
2649	diwali, also known as the "festival of lights," is an important hindu spiritual event celebrated between mid-october and mid-november. the name "diwali" comes from the sanskrit word "deepavali," meaning "row of lights." during the holiday, candles and oil lamps called "diyas" are lit to commemorate the return of the hindu god rama from exile and to honor the goddess lakshmi. in addition to india, diwali is celebrated in cities around the world with significant indian populations. people make colorful rangoli decorations, buy or make their own sand for the designs, and clean their houses and prepare traditional foods. diwali is a time for community and socializing, with friends and family gathering to help light diyas and enjoy each other's company. in some places, there are fireworks displays as well.
2650	flyniki, an austrian low-cost airline, plans to launch the world's shortest international scheduled flight between vienna and bratislava, covering just 30 miles. the journey takes less time by car or train, raising questions about the convenience and appeal of the quick flight. the airline aims to start the service in april, but the 15-minute drive to the airports from both cities and limited connection benefits make it unlikely to attract many travellers. the current record for the world's shortest flight is the 47-second journey between westray and papa westray in scotland, while the longest is qantas' 16-hour and 55-minute sydney to dallas flight.
2651	the pakistani taliban claimed responsibility for a double suicide bombing attack on a military training facility in the northwestern pakistani district of charsadda, which killed at least 80 people, mostly military recruits. the bombings were in retaliation for the killing of osama bin laden, according to the taliban. the district borders mohmand agency, a known hideout for taliban fighters and al qaeda-linked militants. the pakistani military and us forces were accused of alerting each other to bin laden's location. the attacks were condemned by the us state department, with spokesman mike toner warning of more attacks. pakistani opposition leader imran khan called for the resignation of the government and free and fair elections due to its poor handling of the crisis. khan also criticized pakistan's perception as being an "america's hired gun," reducing its ability to win the war on terror. the pakistani taliban, a confederation of taliban groups, have close ties to al qaeda and are headquartered in quetta. they are different from the afghan taliban, which is focused on re-establishing the islamic emirate in afghanistan. the pakistani military has carried out numerous operations in mohmand but has not been able to stamp out militants. prior to 2004, there were no suicide attacks or militant taliban in pakistan.
2652	maria teresa turrion borrallo, prince george's new spanish nanny, was considered a strong candidate for becoming a nun due to her austere lifestyle and devotion to helping others. born in madrid but raised in palencia, borrallo attended church regularly and received private lessons from a neighbor. she left spain for the uk over 20 years ago with a degree in teaching, but returned to see her family, which includes a violin and viola teaching brother. borrallo graduated from prestigious norland college, where she learned to care for high-profile children and avoid paparazzi. her passion for looking after children led her to the role as prince george's nanny, and she is described as quiet, shy, and a good person. borrallo's parents, who married in a prestigious roman catholic school, are proud of her achievements and share her love for classic spanish foods.
2653	"the king's speech" is a compelling drama based on the true story of king george vi of the united kingdom, who suffered from a stammer and sought help from an unconventional speech therapist, lionel logue. colin firth delivers a nuanced performance as the monarch, and geoffrey rush is hilarious and heartfelt as logue. directed by tom hooper, the film brings vibrant humanity to the dry historical accounts, producing emotions that are staggering. hooper's direction and david seidler's insightful script breathe new life into every frame. the film explores the emotional turmoil and insecurities of the royal family, including prince albert's (later george vi) embarrassment, his wife elizabeth's compassion, and his brother edward viii's abdication. firth and rush's chemistry generates uproarious moments, with logue pushing the king to lose his composure and speak fluently. the intimacy and feeling they create on-screen is one of the best movies of the year, even without grand spectacle. rolling stone gave it a 3 1/2-star review.
2654	two historians, margarita torres and jose miguel ortega del rio, have claimed that a 1000-year-old chalice on display at the basilica of san isidoro in leon, spain, is actually the long-lost holy grail. they argue that the onyx goblet, which has been touted as belonging to 11th century queen urraca, once belonged to jesus christ and was stolen from jerusalem by muslims in the centuries after the last supper. the scholars claim that arabic manuscripts prove that the chalice was sent to spain as a gift to king fernando i in the 11th century in thanks for aid during a famine. the medieval chalice, which isdecorated with gold, pearls, emeralds, amethysts, and sapphires, was later given to queen urraca and housed in the basilica. torres and ortiga del rio's theory challenges other popular theories, such as the one that suggests the holy grail is located in the saint mary of valencia cathedral in spain or that it was taken to montserrat abbey near barcelona during world war ii by ss chief heinrich himmler in search of the grail.
2655	swansea city is determined to keep hold of striker bafetimbi gomis despite his expressed desire to leave due to a lack of playing time. the french international has become swansea's only senior striker after wilfried bony's departure, and the club feels they are being "held to ransom." gomis, who has scored just once in 18 premier league appearances this season, claimed that swansea broke their promise of playing time and has been approached by several clubs, including crystal palace, arsenal, newcastle, borussia dortmund, and schalke. swansea would have to pay the remainder of gomis' £8m signing-on fee if he were to leave, which is a major obstacle. the welsh club has agreed to a deal with tottenham for full-back kyle naughton to help address their defensive concerns.
2656	a burglar identified as miguel luna, 25, attempted to rob a los angeles home last tuesday, but left empty-handed after being confronted by the homeowner. luna, from pacoima, california, parked his honda in the driveway and kicked in the front door, seemingly overlooking warning signs of surveillance. the noise from the break-in woke the homeowner, who chased luna out of the house, injuring him with a garden hoe. luna returned to his car, which wouldn't start, and begged the homeowner not to call the police. however, as he fled, he left behind several ipads, one of which contained his photos. lapd lt. paul vernon stated that luna's actions at the crime scene showed an exceptional ability to be caught. luna has a criminal history, consisting of three arrests in 2012 for methamphetamine possession, receiving stolen property, and possession of burglary tools, as well as a 2010 burglary arrest. (source: daily mail)
2657	fall is here, and it's the perfect time for a hike. for beginners, hiking expert tony caligiuri recommends hikes with beautiful views and easy terrain, such as grayson highlands state park in virginia, where you can enjoy rhododendron trails and see friendly wild ponies, or white clay creek preserve in delaware and pennsylvania, with its scenic walks along old railbeds and an old growth forest. for more experienced hikers, consider old rag mountain in virginia, with its challenging eight-mile circuit trail, or walker ranch loop in colorado, a 7.8-mile hike with stunning views. for those who prefer urban hikes, caligiuri suggests exploring the streets of philadelphia or new york city. check out these hiking recommendations and share your own suggestions in the comments below.
2658	dallas seavey won the 2014 iditarod trail sled dog race by overtaking second place finisher aliy zirkle in the final hours of the competition. seavey, who is the youngest champion ever at 25 years old and comes from a mushing family, had to make up a three-hour deficit to take the lead. conditions were challenging due to a lack of snow caused by a warm winter, resulting in several injuries and dropouts. the winner receives $50,000 and a new truck, while the 29 teams after that receive decreasing cash prizes, and all other finishers receive $1,049. seavey is a hermit and doesn't own a television, but has appeared on the reality television series 'ultimate survival alaska.' the race began on march 2 in willow and ended in nome, with 53 teams finishing out of the initial 69. notable finishes include jeff king in first place and aliy zirkle in second place.
2659	megan harvey, a 14-year-old girl from kent, has a rare condition called cyclical vomiting syndrome (cvs), which causes her to vomit for hours if she gets excited. this condition emerged when she reached secondary school and has ruined several family holidays and social events, including her school prom. megan's mother, jodie harvey, describes the condition as making her daughter go into a "waking coma" during vomiting attacks, and she can't remember what happens afterward. the family has had to make numerous adjustments to avoid excitement and prevent sickness attacks, which have left megan hospitalized multiple times. megan now takes a cocktail of drugs to manage her condition and has missed out on several events due to her illness. a recent camping trip with friends was ruined when megan was mistaken for being drunk and vomiting.
2660	kumar mangalam birla, india's 43-year-old industrialist and ceo of aditya birla group, managing aluminum sheeting production for car manufacturers and life insurance, inherited the company from his father in 1995. after taking over, he increased the turnover from $2 billion to $29 billion by 2010, aiming to double the figure by 2015. he comes from a business-oriented family going back four generations and took over as chairman after his father's unexpected death at 28, vowing to carry on his work despite the emotional challenges. the company also practices charitable giving, giving 3% of its net profits to various programs impacting 3,000 villages and 7 million people annually. birla has overseen the acquisition of 20 companies globally to boost revenues and enhance india's reputation as a business powerhouse on the world stage.
2661	darren wilson, a six-year veteran officer in the small town of ferguson, missouri, shot and killed 18-year-old michael brown on august 9. the shooting sparked protests and looting, with tensions heightened by the long-standing tension between the mostly african-american community and the predominantly white police force. wilson, described as a gentle and distinguished officer, had been staying at a secure location due to death threats. new details released by the police implicated brown in a convenience-store robbery before the shooting, which was met with skepticism and anger from the community. brown's family was "beyond outraged" at the timing of the robbery allegation and accused the police of attempting a coverup. the police chief described wilson as devastated and well-mannered, stating that he never wanted the attention or the shooting. wilson and brown's initial contact was not due to the robbery report, but because brown was obstructing traffic. brown, who was unarmed, was shot in a struggle for the officer's gun. the shooting led to numerous arrests and renewed calls for reform within the police department. the community of ferguson is predominantly african-american, but the police force is mostly white.
2662	blake mycoskie, the founder of toms shoes, started the company in 2006 with the commitment to give a pair of shoes to an impoverished child for every pair sold. he drew inspiration from a trip to argentina where he saw children without shoes. with no prior experience in shoes or fashion, mycoskie approached the business with "reckless ambition." toms initially sold the argentine alpargata style and quickly gained popularity, surpassing initial expectations. today, toms has evolved into a business model of "one-for-one" giving, producing shoes in factories with fair labor practices. the company's future plans include expanding into other product lines while continuing to prioritize philanthropy.
2663	senior conservatives criticized mark reckless, a tory mp who defected to ukip, for lying and betraying the party. reckless, who left hours before the conservative conference, faced hostility from constituents who labeled him and ukip leader nigel farage as "beer-swilling racists." in an interview, reckless defended his decision, accusing the conservatives of breaking promises on immigration and the deficit. cameron called the defections of reckless and douglas carswell "senseless and counter-productive," and party chairman grant shapps attacked reckless for accepting support from conservatives before defecting. reckless was previously recorded in a voicemail expressing his willingness to campaign for the party. ukip's planned "wag tax" on handbags and shoes was scrapped less than 48 hours after being announced. reckless and farage received a hostile reception during a walkabout in reckless's constituency, and reckless left suddenly through a side door while farage left in a car with security. local residents expressed their disappointment and disdain for the pair. reckless, who was nicknamed "legless" after admitting to being too drunk to vote, represented the conservatives for less than five years before defecting.
2664	a man named jordan pyke, 20, was arrested and sentenced to 18 weeks in a young offenders' institution for burglarizing frederick's ice cream parlour in wigan, greater manchester. during the raid in december last year, the intruders forced open two windows and stole cash and partially emptied boxes of crisps. police found a packet of quavers with a matching serial number in pyke's pocket during their investigation and arrested him along with two others. pyke denied involvement, claiming the crisps were given to him, but was found guilty following a trial. he also had a kitchen knife in his pocket, for which he was sentenced for possessing a bladed article in a public place. the court suspended a compensation order owed to his mother due to her agreement.
2665	a heartwarming video has emerged on youtube showing a loyal dog pushing its elderly owner's wheelchair through floodwaters in russia. the incident, filmed from a passing car, displays the dog struggling in deep water almost a meter high. some youtube users have expressed concern that no one had stopped to help the man, while others believe the dog might have just been holding onto him. the only indication of the location is the russian voice in the background remarking on the dog's assistance. although russia has been mostly unaffected by the recent european floods, flooding has affected regions in central and eastern europe, forcing hundreds of people from their homes and causing extensive damage.
2666	harry arter, a midfielder for bournemouth, found himself in non-league football oblivion when he was released from charlton at the age of 19. he turned to his brother-in-law, scott parker, a former england regular and premier league winner, for guidance. parker had previously tried to advise arter when he was a young promising player at charlton but was ignored. arter now regrets not listening and considers parker's advice crucial in turning his career around. bournemouth manager eddie howe also played a significant role in arter's progression, signing him in 2010 and bringing him to the premier league with bournemouth in 2015. arter's career hit a rough patch after howe left for burnley in 2012, but he flourished when howe returned in 2012. parker and arter met when parker was just 15 and staying at the football association's school of excellence at lilleshall. they have been together ever since and have four children. parker's clean-cut, respected, and hard-working image influenced arter, who aspired to become a professional footballer.
